in
the
adage
<EOS>
"
Those
the
cap
fits
,
let
them
wear
it
,
"
immediately
commenced
a
somewhat
acrimonious
and
personal
retort
,
wherein
she
was
much
comforted
and
abetted
by
her
sister
Mercy
,
who
laughed
at
the
same
with
great
heartiness
;
indeed
far
more
naturally
than
life
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
being
quite
impossible
that
any
difference
of
opinion
can
take
place
among
women
without
every
woman
who
is
within
hearing
taking
active
part
in
it
,
the
strong
-
minded
lady
and
her
two
daughters
,
and
Mrs
Spottletoe
,
and
the
deaf
cousin
(
who
was
not

all
disqualified
from
joining
in
the
dispute
by

of
being
perfectly
unacquainted
with
its
merits
)
,
one
and
all
plunged
into
the
quarrel
directly
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
being
a
pretty
good
match
for
the
three
Miss
Chuzzlewits
,
and
all
five
young
ladies
having
,
in
the
figurative
language
of
the
day
,
a
great
amount
of
steam
to
dispose
of
,
the
altercation
would
no
doubt
have
been
a
long
one
but
for
the
high
valour
and
prowess
of
the
strong
-
minded
woman
,
who
,
in
right
of
her
reputation
for
powers
of
sarcasm
,
did
so
belabour
and
pummel
Mrs
Spottletoe
with
taunting
words
that
the
poor
lady
,
before
the
engagement
was
two
minutes
old
,
had
no
refuge
but
in
tears
.
 
<EOS>
These
she
shed
so
plentifully
,
and
so
much
to
the
agitation
and
grief
of
Mr
Spottletoe
,
that
that
gentleman
,
after
holding
his
clenched
fist
close
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
eyes
,
as
if
it
were
some
natural
curiosity
from
the
near
inspection
whereof
he
was
likely
to
derive
high
gratification
and
improvement
,
and
after
offering
(
for
no
particular
reason
that
anybody
could
discover
)
to
kick
Mr
George
Chuzzlewit
for
,
and
in
consideration
of
,
the
trifling
sum
of
sixpence
,
took
his
wife
under
his
arm
and
indignantly
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
This
diversion
,
by
distracting
the
attention
of
the
combatants
,
put
an
end
to
the
strife
,
which
,
after
breaking
out
afresh
some
twice
or
thrice
in
certain
inconsiderable

and
dashes
,
died
away
in
silence
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
then
that
Mr
Pecksniff
once
more
rose
from
his
chair
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
then
that
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
composed
themselves
to
look
as
if
there
were
no
such
beings
---
not
to
say
present
,
but
in
the
whole
compass
of

world
---
as
the
three
Miss
Chuzzlewits
;
while
the
three
Miss
Chuzzlewits
became
equally
unconscious
of
the
existence
of
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
to
be
lamented
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
a
forgiving

of
Mr
Spottletoe
's

,
"
that
our
friend
should
have
withdrawn
himself
so
very

,
though
we
have
cause
for
mutual

even

,
since
we

he
is
not

of
us
in

anything

may
say
or
do
while
he
is

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
that
is
very
soothing
,
is
it
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pecksniff
,
"
said
Anthony
,
who
had
been
watching
the
whole
party
with

from
the
first
---
"
do

you

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
what
,

?
"
demanded
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
hypocrite
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Charity
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
when
I
take

chamber
candlestick
to
-
night
,

to

more
than
usually
particular
in
praying
for
Mr
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
;
who
has
done
me
an
injustice
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
said
in
a
very

,
and
aside
,
as
being

to
his
daughter
's

.
 
<EOS>
With

of
conscience
,
prompting

,
he
then
resumed
:
   
<EOS>
"
All
our

centring
in
our
very

unkind

,
and
<EOS>
he
being
as

were

,
we
are
met
to
-

,
really

,
except
---
a

---
that

no

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
lady
was
not
at
all
sure
that
this
was

.
 
<EOS>
Quite
the
contrary
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

dear

!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
that
as

,
here

;
and
being

,
we
are
to

any

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

,
"
that

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

ANY

,
we

ANY

,

our

to

.
 
<EOS>
Whether

is

to
make

that

female
whose

,
whose

,
in

himself
"
---
here

sunk

---
"
really

upon

;
and
who
,
we
know
"
---
here

again
 
---
"
else
<EOS>
why

his

?
<EOS>
harbours

upon

.
"
   
<EOS>
In

strong

,

,
who

,
all

as

.
 
<EOS>
Good
Heaven
,
that
she
should
harbour

upon
his
property
!
 
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
lady
was
for
poison
,
her
three
daughters
were
for
Bridewell
and
bread
-
and
-
water
,
the
cousin
with
the
toothache
advocated
Botany
Bay
,
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
suggested
flogging
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
but
Mr
Tigg
,
who
,
notwithstanding
his
extreme
shabbiness
,
was
still
understood
to
be
in
some
sort
a
lady
's
man
,
in

,
indicated

;
and

Miss
Chuzzlewits
with

,

,
"
You

down
upon
her
to

,
my

,
upon

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,

in

"
I

,

,

;
"
one

;
"

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

,
<EOS>
that

,

---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
interposed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

our

,

---
"
   
"
Go

,
Pa
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
The

(
pagan
,

)

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

"
swans
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not

.
 
<EOS>
Very
like

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thank

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

with
the

of

,

,

"
Oysters
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with

,
"
nor

.
 
<EOS>
But
by
no
means
unlike

;
a

;
thank

,
my

,

.
 
<EOS>
Wait
!
 
<EOS>
Sirens
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
sirens
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
,
I
say
,
that
means
might
be
devised
of
disposing
our
respected
relative
to
listen
to
the
promptings
of
nature
,
and
not
to
the
siren
-
like
delusions
of
art
.
 
<EOS>
Now
we
must
not
lose
sight
of
the
fact
that
our
esteemed
friend
has
a
grandson
,
to
whom
he
was
,
until

,
very

,
and
whom
I
could
have
wished
to
see
here
to
-
day
,
for
I

real

deep

for
him
.
 
<EOS>
A
fine
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
a
very
fine
young
man
!
 
<EOS>
I
would
submit
to
you
,
whether
we
might
not
remove
Mr
Chuzzlewit
's

us
,

by
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
If
Mr
George
Chuzzlewit

,
"

-

woman
,

,
"
I

man
;
and

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

looking
,
I
have

,
Mrs
Ned
,
"
returned
Mr
George
,

,
"
that
a
cat

free

;
and
therefore
I
hope
I

some

,
having

born

,
to
look

a

who
only

.
 
<EOS>
As
to
eating
,
I
beg

,
whatever

your

and

may
suggest
to
you
,
that
I
am
not
a
cannibal
,
ma'am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
strong
-
minded
woman
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
if
I
was
a
cannibal
,
"
said
Mr
George
Chuzzlewit
,
greatly
stimulated
by
this
retort
,
"
I
think
it
would
occur
to

that
a
lady
who
had

three
husbands
,
and
suffered
so
very
little
from
their

,
must
be
most
uncommonly
tough
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
woman
immediately
rose
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
will
further
add
,
"
said
Mr
George
,
nodding
his

violently
at
every

;
"
naming
no
names
,
and
therefore
hurting
nobody
but
those
whose
consciences
tell
them
they
are
alluded
to
,
that
I

,

that

,
would

acting

part

in

this

.
 
<EOS>
I
think
it
would
be
full

,

,
if
those

would
keep

,

(

)

;

,

,

,
which
they
flavour
much
more
than

,
I
can
tell

,
when
they

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
might
have
been
prepared

this
!
"
<EOS>

-

woman
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

fully

.
 
<EOS>
What

"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

halfpay
-
officers
'

,

,
"

;
"
for
I
wo
n't

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

smart
stab
at
a

by
the
strong
-
minded
woman
,
during
her

and
before

.
<EOS>
It
told

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
passed
from
the

a

country
,
you

,
"
said

,
"
when
I

;

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
,
we

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thank

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
With

,
did

strong

Pecksniffian

;

,

,
as

,
elevated

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

to

among

;
and
with
this

great

.
   
<EOS>
Before
Mr
Pecksniff
or

,

passed

,

in

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Compared
with

present
state
of

,

had
gone
out
a
man
of

.
 
<EOS>
His

distilled
such
oil
upon

,
that

rich
and

with

;
his
face
was

,
his

;
and

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
sir
!
<EOS>
"

Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
"

other
;
"
<EOS>
oh
yes
,
certainly
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
to
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
 
<EOS>
You
hear

?
 
<EOS>
You
hear

?
<EOS>
all

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing

!
<EOS>
It
's

!
 
<EOS>
Ask

!
 
<EOS>
HE'll

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

not

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

is

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unintelligible
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Unintelligible
!
 
<EOS>
Do

,

!
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Gone
while

.
<EOS>
Gone
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody

where

's

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
 
<EOS>
Nobody

was

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
 
<EOS>
The
landlady
thought
up
to
the
very
last
moment
that
they
were
merely

for
a

;
she

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
 
<EOS>
She
's

this

's

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

course
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
Adding

a
kind

ironical

,
and

upon
the
company
for
one

,

,
the
irritated
gentleman
started
off
again
at
the
same
tremendous
pace
,
and
was
seen
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
for
Mr
Pecksniff
to
assure
them
that
this
new
and
opportune
evasion
of
the
family
was
at
least

great

shock

to

as
to
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
the
bullyings
and

that
were
ever
heaped
on
one
unlucky
head
,
none
can
ever

exceeded
in

those
with
which
he
was
complimented
by
each
of
his
remaining
relatives
,
singly
,
upon
bidding
him
farewell
.
   
<EOS>
The
moral
position
taken
by
Mr
Tigg
was
something
quite
tremendous
;
and
the
deaf
cousin
,
who
had
the
complicated
aggravation
of
seeing
all
the
proceedings
and
hearing
nothing
but
the

,
actually
scraped
her
shoes
upon
the

,
and
afterwards
distributed
impressions
of
them
all
over
the
top

,
in
token
that
she
shook
the
dust
from
her

before
quitting
that
dissembling
and
perfidious

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
,
in
short
,
but
one
comfort
,
and
that
was
the
knowledge
that
all
these
his
relations
and
friends
had
hated
him
to
the
very
utmost
extent
before
;
and
that
he
,
for

part
,
had
not
distributed
among

any
more
love
than
,
with
his
ample
capital
in
that
respect
,
he

comfortably

part

.
 
<EOS>
This
view
of
his
affairs
yielded
him
great

;
and
the
fact
deserves
to
be
noted
,
as
showing
with
what
ease
a
good
man
may
be
consoled
under
circumstances
of
failure
and
disappointment
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
05
.
<EOS>
Containing
a
full
account
of
the
installation
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
new
pupil
into
the
bosom
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
family
.
 
<EOS>
With
all
the
festivities
held
on
that
occasion
,
and
the
great
enjoyment
of
Mr
Pinch
 
<EOS>
The
best
of
architects
and
land
surveyors
kept
a
horse
,
in
whom
the
enemies
already
mentioned
more
than
once
in
these
pages
pretended
to
detect
a
fanciful
resemblance
to
his
master
.
 
<EOS>
Not
in
his
outward
person
,
for
he
was
a
raw
-
boned
,
haggard
horse
,
always
on
a
much
shorter
allowance
of
corn
than
Mr
Pecksniff
;
but
in
his
moral
character
,
wherein
,
said
they
,
he
was
full
of
promise
,
but
of
no
performance
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
in
a
manner
,
going
to
go
,
and
never
going
.
 
<EOS>
When
at
his
slowest
rate
of
travelling
he
would
sometimes
lift
up
his
legs
so
high
,
and
display
such
mighty
action
,
that
it
was
difficult
to
believe
he
was
doing
less
than
fourteen
miles
an
hour
;
and
he
was
for
ever
so
perfectly
satisfied
with
his
own
speed
,
and
so
little
disconcerted
by
opportunities
of
comparing
himself
with
the
fastest
trotters
,
that
the
illusion
was
the
more
difficult
of
resistance
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
kind
of
animal
who
infused
into
the
breasts
of
strangers
a
lively
sense
of
hope
,
and
possessed
all
those
who
knew
him
better
with
a
grim
despair
.
 
<EOS>
In
what
respect
,
having
these
points
of
character
,
he
might
be
fairly
likened
to
his
master
,
that
good
man
's
slanderers
only
can
explain
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
a
melancholy
truth
,
and
a
deplorable
instance
of
the
uncharitableness
of
the
world
,
that
they
made
the
comparison
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
horse
,
and
the
hooded
vehicle
,
whatever
its
proper
name
might
be
,
to
which
he
was
usually
harnessed
---
it
was
more
like
a
gig
with
a
tumour
than
anything
else
---
<EOS>
all
Mr
Pinch
's
thoughts
and
wishes
centred
,
one
bright
frosty
morning
;
for
with
this
gallant
equipage
he
was
about
to
drive
to
Salisbury
alone
,
there
to
meet
with
the
new
pupil
,
and
thence
to
bring
him
home
in

.
   
<EOS>
Blessings
on
thy
simple
heart
,
Tom
Pinch
<EOS>
,
how
proudly
dost
thou
button
up
that
scanty
coat
,
called
by
a
sad

,
for
these
many
years
,
a
"
great
"
one
;
and
how

,
as
with
thy

thou

adjurest
Sam
the
hostler
"
<EOS>
not
to
let
him
go
yet
,
"
dost
thou
believe
that
quadruped
desires
to
go
,
and
would
go
if
he
might
!
 
<EOS>
Who
could
repress
a
smile
---
of
love
for
thee
,
Tom
Pinch
,
and
not
in
jest
at
thy
expense
,
for
thou
art
poor
enough
already
<EOS>
,
Heaven
knows
---
to
think
that
such
a
holiday
as
lies
before
thee
should
awaken
that
quick
flow
and
hurry
of
the

,
in
which
thou
settest
down
again
,
almost
untasted
,
on
the
kitchen
window
-
sill
,
that
great

mug
(
put
by
,
by
thy
own

,
last

,
that
breakfast
might
not

)
,

layest
yonder

upon

,
to

,
when
thou
art
calmer
in
thy
high

!
 
<EOS>
Who
,
as
thou
drivest
off
,
a
happy
,
man
,
and
noddest
with
a
grateful

to
Pecksniff
in
his
nightcap
at
his
chamber
-
window
,
would
not
cry
,
"
Heaven

thee
,
Tom
,
and
send
that
thou
wert
going
off
for
ever
to
some
quiet
home
where
thou
mightst
live
at
peace
,
and
sorrow
should
not
touch
thee
!
"
   
<EOS>
What
better
time
for
driving
,
riding
,
walking
,
moving
through
the
air
by
any
means
,
than
a
fresh
,
frosty
morning
,
when
hope
runs
cheerily
through
the
veins
with
the
brisk
blood
,
and
tingles
in
the
frame
from
head
to
foot
!
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
glad
commencement
of
a
bracing
day
in
early
winter
,
such
as
may
put
the
languid
summer
season
(
speaking
of
it
when
it
ca
n't
be
had
)
to
the
blush
,
and
shame
the
spring
for
being
sometimes
cold
by
halves
.
 
<EOS>
The
sheep
-
bells
rang
as
clearly
in
the
vigorous
air
,
as
if
they
felt
its
wholesome
influence
like
living
creatures
;
the
trees
,
in
lieu
of
leaves
or
blossoms
,
shed
upon
the
ground
a
frosty
rime
that
sparkled
as
it
fell
,
and
might
have
been
the
dust
of
diamonds
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
was
to
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
From
cottage
chimneys
,
smoke
went
streaming
up
high
,
high
,
as
if
the
earth
had
lost
its
grossness
,
being
so
fair
,
and
must
not
be
oppressed
by
heavy
vapour
.
 
<EOS>
The
crust
of
ice
on
the
else
rippling
brook
was
so
transparent
,
and
so
thin
in
texture
,
that
the
lively
water
might
of
its
own
free
will
have
stopped
---
in
Tom
's
glad
mind
<EOS>
it
had
---
to
look
upon
the
lovely
morning
.
 
<EOS>
And
lest
the
sun
should
break
this
charm
too
eagerly
,
there
moved
between
him
and
the
ground
,
a
mist
like
that
which
waits
upon
the
moon
on
summer
nights
---
the
very
same
to
Tom
---
and
wooed
him
to
dissolve
it
gently
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
went
on
;
not
fast
,
but
with
a
sense
of
rapid
motion
,
which
did
just
as
well
;
and
as
he
went
,
all
kinds
of
things
occurred
to
keep
him
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
when
he
came
within
sight
of
the
turnpike
,
and
was
---
oh
a
long
way
off
!
<EOS>
---
he
saw
the
tollman
's
wife
,
who
had
that
moment
checked
a
waggon
,
run
back
into
the
little
house
again
like
mad
,
to
say
(
she
knew
)
that
Mr
Pinch
was
coming
up
.
 
<EOS>
And
she
was
right
,
for
when
he
drew
within
hail
of
the
gate
,
forth
rushed
the
tollman
's
children
,
shrieking
in
tiny
chorus
,
"
Mr
Pinch
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
to
Tom
's
intense
delight
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
tollman
,
though
an
ugly
chap
in
general
,
and
one
whom
folks
were
rather
shy
of
handling
,
came
out
himself
to
take
the
toll
,
and
give
him
rough
good
morning
;
and
that
with
all
this
,
and
a
glimpse
of
the
family
breakfast
on
a
little
round
table
before
the
fire
,
the
crust
Tom
Pinch
had
brought
away
with
him
acquired
as
rich
a
flavour
as
though
it
had
been
cut
from
a
fairy
loaf
.
   
<EOS>
But
there
was
more
than
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
only
the
married
people
and
the
children
who
gave
Tom
Pinch
a
welcome
as
he
passed
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
<EOS>
Sparkling
eyes
and
snowy
breasts
came
hurriedly
to
many
an
upper
casement
as
he
clattered
by
,
and
gave
him
back
his
greeting
:
not
stinted
either
,
but
sevenfold
,
good
measure
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
all
merry
.
<EOS>
They
all
laughed
.
 
<EOS>
And
some
of
the
wickedest
among
them
even
kissed
their
hands
as
Tom
looked
back
.
 
<EOS>
For
who
minded
poor
Mr
Pinch
?
<EOS>
There
was
no
harm
in
HIM
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
morning
grew
so
fair
,
and
all
things
were
so
wide
awake
and
gay
,
that
the
sun
seeming
to
say
---
Tom
had
no
doubt
he
said
---
"
I
ca
n't
stand
it
any
longer
;
I
must
have
a
look
,
"
streamed
out
in
radiant
majesty
.
 
<EOS>
The
mist
,
too
shy
and
gentle
for
such
lusty
company
,
fled
off
,
quite
scared
,
before
it
;
and
as
it
swept
away
,
the
hills
and
mounds
and
distant
pasture
lands
,
teeming
with
placid
sheep
and
noisy
crows
,
came
out
as
bright
as
though
they
were
unrolled
bran
new
for
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
In
compliment
to
which
discovery
,
the
brook
stood
still
no
longer
,
but
ran
briskly
off
to
bear
the
tidings
to
the
water
-
mill
,
three
miles
away
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
was
jogging
along
,
full
of
pleasant
thoughts
and
cheerful
influences
,
when
he
saw
,
upon
the
path
before
him
,
going
in
the
same
direction
with
himself
,
a
traveller
on
foot
,
who
walked
with
a
light
quick
step
,
and
sang
as
he
went
---
for
certain
in
a
very
loud
voice
,
but
not
unmusically
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
fellow
,
of
some
five
or
six
-
and
-
twenty
perhaps
,
and
was
dressed
in
such
a
free
and
fly
-
away
fashion
,
that
the
long
ends
of
his
loose
red

were
streaming
out
behind
him
quite
as
often
as
before
;
and
the
bunch
of
bright
winter
berries
in

of
his
velveteen
coat
was
as
visible
to
Mr
Pinch
's
rearward
observation
,
as
if
he
had
worn
that
garment
wrong
side
foremost
.
 
<EOS>
He
continued
to
sing
with
so
much
energy
,
that
he
did
not
hear
the
sound
of
wheels
until
it
was
close

;
when
he
turned
a
whimsical
face
and
a
very
merry
pair
of
blue

on
Mr
Pinch
,
and
checked
himself
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mark
?
"
said
Tom
Pinch
,
stopping
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
'd
have
thought
of
seeing
you
here
?
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
this
is
surprising
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mark
touched
his
hat
,
and
said
,
with
a
very
sudden
decrease
of
vivacity
,
that
he
was
going
to
Salisbury
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
spruce
you
are
,
too
!
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
surveying
him
with
great
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
,
I
did
n't
think
you
were
half
such
a
tight
-
made
fellow
,
Mark
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
Pretty
well
for
that
,
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
my
fault
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
With
regard
to
being
spruce
,
sir
,
that
's
where
it
is
,
you
see
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
here
he
looked
particularly
gloomy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
what
is
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
demanded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
the

of
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Any
man
may
be
in
good

and
good

when
he

.
 
<EOS>
There
an't
much

in
that
.
<EOS>
If
I
was
very
ragged
and
very
jolly
,
then
I

begin

feel
I
had
gained
a
point
,
Mr
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So

were

just

,
to

,
as
it
were
,
against

well

,

,
Mark
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
conversation
's
always

to
print
,

,
"
rejoined
Mark
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
was

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
cried
Pinch
,
"
you
are
the
strangest
young

,
Mark
<EOS>
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
always

;
but

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going

Salisbury
,

.
 
<EOS>
Will

get

?
 
<EOS>
I

very

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young

made

and

;

,
and

,
to

on

,
and
by
the

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
As

along
,
the
conversation
proceeded
after
this

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
more
than

,
just

,

you
so

,
"
said
Pinch
,
"
that
you
must

,
Mark
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
I
've

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
might

some

in
being
jolly
with
a
wife
,
"
specially
if
the
children
had
the
measles
and
that
,
and
was
very

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'm
a'most
afraid
to
try
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
see
my
way
clear
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
very

of

,

?
"
said
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
particular
,

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
the
way

be
,

,
Mark
,
according

,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

,

;

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps

might
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
At

they
both
laughed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
you
do
n't
half
know
me
,
though
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
there
ever
was
a
man
as

that
would
make
other
men

,
as
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
get
a
chance
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
my
opinion
that
nobody
never
will
know
half
of
what
's
in
me
,
unless
something
very
unexpected
turns
up
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
do
n't

any

of

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
-
going
to
leave
the
Dragon
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
to
leave
the
Dragon
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pinch
,
looking
at

with
great

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mark
,
you
take
my
breath
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
he
rejoined
,
looking
straight
before
him
and
a
long
way
off
,
as
men
do
sometimes
when
they
cogitate
profoundly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
of
my
stopping
at
the
Dragon
?
 
<EOS>
It
an't
at
all
the
sort
of
place
for
ME
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
left
London
(
I
'm
a
Kentish
man
by
birth
,
though
)
,
and
took
that
situation
here
,
I
quite

mind
that
it
was
the
dullest
little
out
-
of
-
the
-
way
corner
in
England
,
and
that

some

in

under
such

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Lord
,
there
's
no
dullness
at
the
Dragon
!
 
<EOS>
Skittles
,
cricket
,
quoits
,
nine
-
pins
,
comic
songs
,
choruses
,
company
round
the
chimney
corner
every
winter
's

.
 
<EOS>
Any
man
could
be
jolly
at
the
Dragon
.
<EOS>
There
's

credit
in
THAT
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

common
report

,
Mark
,

I

,

able

,
"

Pinch
,
"
you

the

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
after

,
his
usually

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
hardly

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
what
will
become
of
Mrs
Lupin
,
Mark
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mark

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"
said

Pinch
,
"
but
I

Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,

,

;

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
said

courting

<EOS>
like

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

"

"

.

.
<EOS>
way
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Good

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
good
damp
,

,

,
"
said

,

,
"

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,
"
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In

"

,

,
"
there

.
<EOS>
Undertaking
now
.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
A

's

would
n't

bad
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
A
jailor
sees
a
deal

.
 
<EOS>
A
doctor
's
man
is
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
A

's
an't

nat'rally
.
<EOS>
Even

-
gatherer
must

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
lots

in

I

,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
was
so

by

that
he

do
nothing
but
occasionally

on
some

odd
friend
(
who

quite

his
observation
)
,
until
they
reached
a
certain
corner
of
the
road
,
close
upon
the
outskirts
of
the
city
,
when
Mark
said
he
would
jump
down
there
,
if
he
pleased
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
bless
my
soul
,
Mark
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
who
in
the
progress
of
his
observation
just
then
made
the
discovery
that
the
bosom
of
his
companion
's
shirt
was
as
much
exposed
as
if
it
was
Midsummer
,
and
was
ruffled
by
every
breath
of
air
,
"
why
do
n't
you
wear
a
waistcoat
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
good
of
one
,
sir
?
"
asked
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
of
one
?
"
said
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
to
keep
your
chest
warm
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
love
you
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mark
,
"
you
do
n't
know
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
chest
do
n't
want
no
warming
.
 
<EOS>
Even
if
it
did
,
what
would
no
waistcoat
bring
it
to
?
 
<EOS>
Inflammation
of
the
lungs
,
perhaps
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
there
'd
be
some
credit
in
being
jolly
,
with
a
inflammation
of
the
lungs
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pinch
returned
no
other
answer
than
such
as
was
conveyed
in
his
breathing
very
hard
,
and
opening
his
eyes
very
wide
,
and
nodding
his
head
very
much
,
Mark
thanked
him
for
his
ride
,
and
without
troubling
him
to
stop
,
jumped
lightly
down
.
 
<EOS>
And
away
he
fluttered
,
with
his
red
neckerchief
,
and
<EOS>
his
open
coat
,
down
a
cross
-
lane
;
turning
back
from
time
to
time
to
nod
to
Mr
Pinch
,
and
looking
one
of
the
most
careless
,
good
-
humoured
comical
fellows
in
life
.
 
<EOS>
His
late
companion
,
with
a
thoughtful
face
pursued
his
way
to
Salisbury
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
had
a
shrewd
notion
that
Salisbury
was
a
very
desperate
sort
of
place
;
an
exceeding
wild
and
dissipated
city
;
and
when
he
had
put
up
the
horse
,
and
given
the
hostler
to
understand
that
he
would
look
in
again
in
the
course
of
an
hour
or
two
to
see
him
take
his
corn
,
he
set
forth
on
a
stroll
about
the
streets
with
a
vague
and
not
unpleasant
idea
that
they
teemed
with
all
kinds
of
mystery
and
bedevilment
.
 
<EOS>
To
one
of
his
quiet
habits
this
little
delusion
was
greatly
assisted
by
the
circumstance
of
its
being
market
-
day
,
and
the
thoroughfares
about
the
market
-
place
being
filled
with
carts
,
horses
,
donkeys
,
baskets
,
waggons
,
garden
-
stuff
,
meat
,
tripe
,
pies
,
poultry
and
huckster
's
wares
of
every
opposite
description
and
possible
variety
of
character
.
 
<EOS>
Then
there
were
young
farmers
and
old
farmers
with
smock
-
frocks
,
brown
great
-
coats
,
drab
great
-
coats
,
red
worsted
comforters
,
leather
-
leggings
,
wonderful
shaped
hats
,
hunting
-
whips
,
and
rough
sticks
,
standing
about
in
groups
,
or
talking
noisily
together
on
the
tavern
steps
,
or
paying
and
receiving
huge
amounts
of
greasy
wealth
,
with
the
assistance
of
such
bulky
pocket
-
books
that
when
they
were
in
their
pockets
it
was
apoplexy
to
get
them
out
,
and
when
they
were
out
it
was
spasms
to
get
them
in
again
.
 
<EOS>
Also
there
were
farmers
'
wives
in
beaver
bonnets
and
red
cloaks
,
riding
shaggy
horses
purged
of
all
earthly
passions
,
who
went
soberly
into
all
manner
of
places
without
desiring
to
know
why
,
and
who
,
if
required
,
would
have
stood
stock
still
in
a
china
shop
,
with
a
complete
dinner
-
service
at
each
hoof
.
 
<EOS>
Also
a
great
many
dogs
,
who
were
strongly
interested
in
the
state
of
the
market
and
the
bargains
of
their
masters
;
and
a
great
confusion
of
tongues
,
both
brute
and
human
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
regarded
everything
exposed
for
sale
with
great
delight
,
and
was
particularly
struck
by
the
itinerant
cutlery
,
which
he
considered
of
the
very
keenest
kind
,
insomuch
that
he
purchased
a
pocket
knife
with
seven
blades
in
it
,
and
not
a
cut
(
as
he
afterwards
found
out
)
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
exhausted
the
market
-
place
,
and
watched
the
farmers
safe
into
the
market
dinner
,
he
went
back
to
look
after
the
horse
.
 
<EOS>
Having
seen
him
eat
unto
his
heart
's
content
he
issued
forth
again
,
to
wander
round
the
town
and
regale
himself
with
the
shop
windows
;
previously
taking
a
long
stare
at
the
bank
,
and
wondering
in
what
direction
underground
the
caverns
might
be
where
they
kept
the
money
;
and
turning
to
look
back
at
one
or
two
young
men
who
passed
him
,
whom
he
knew
to
be
articled
to
solicitors
in
the
town
;
and
who
had
a
sort
of
fearful
interest
in
his
eyes
,
as
jolly
dogs
who
knew
a
thing
or
two
,
and
kept
it
up
tremendously
.
   
<EOS>
But
the
shops
.
 
<EOS>
First
of
all
there
were
the
jewellers
'
shops
,
with
all
the
treasures
of
the
earth
displayed
therein
,
and
such
large
silver
watches
hanging
up
in
every
pane
of
glass
,
that
if
they
were
anything
but
first
-
rate
goers
it
certainly
was
not
because
the
works
could
decently
complain
of
want
of
room
.
 
<EOS>
In
good
sooth
they
were
big
enough
,
and
perhaps
,
as
the
saying
is
,
ugly
enough
,
to
be
the
most
correct
of
all
mechanical
performers
;
in
Mr
Pinch
's
eyes
,
however
they
were
smaller
than
Geneva
ware
;
and
when
he
saw
one
very
bloated
watch
announced
as
a
repeater
,
gifted
with
the
uncommon
power
of
striking
every
quarter
of
an
hour
inside
the
pocket
of
its
happy
owner
,
he
almost
wished
that
he
were
rich
enough
to
buy
it
.
   
<EOS>
But
what
were
even
gold
and
silver
,
precious
stones
and
clockwork
,
to
the
bookshops
,
whence
a
pleasant
smell
of
paper
freshly
pressed
<EOS>
came
issuing
forth
,
awakening
instant
recollections
of
some
new
grammar
had
at
school
,
long
time
ago
,
with
"
Master
Pinch
,
Grove
House
Academy
,
"
inscribed
in
faultless
writing
on
the
fly
-
leaf
!
 
<EOS>
That
whiff
of
russia
leather
,
too
,
and
all
those
rows
on
rows
of
volumes
neatly
ranged
within
---
what
happiness
did
they
suggest
!
 
<EOS>
And
in
the
window
were
the
spick
-
and
-
span
new
works
from
London
,
with
the
title
-
pages
,
and
sometimes
even
the
first
page
of
the
first
chapter
,
laid
wide
open
;
tempting
unwary
men
to
begin
to
read
the
book
,
and
then
,
in
the
impossibility
of
turning
over
,
to
rush
blindly
in
,
and
buy
it
!
 
<EOS>
Here
too
were
the
dainty
frontispiece
and
trim
vignette
,
pointing
like
handposts
on
the
outskirts
of
great
cities
,
to
the
rich
stock
of
incident
beyond
;
and
store
of
books
,
with
many
a
grave
portrait
and
time
-
honoured
name
,
<EOS>
whose
matter
he
knew
well
,
and
would
have
given
mines
to
have
,
in
any
form
,
upon
the
narrow
shell
beside
his
bed
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
heart
-
breaking
shop
it
was
!
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
;
not
quite
so
bad
at
first
,
but
still
a
trying
shop
;
where
children
's
books
were
sold
,
and
where
poor
Robinson
Crusoe
stood
alone
in
his
might
,
with
dog
and
hatchet
,
goat
-
skin
cap
and
fowling
-
pieces
;
calmly
surveying
Philip
Quarn
and
the
host
of
imitators
round
him
,
and
calling
Mr
Pinch
to
witness
that
he
,
of
all
the
crowd
,
impressed
one
solitary
footprint
on
the
shore
of
boyish
memory
,
whereof
the
tread
of
generations
should
not
stir
the
lightest
grain
of
sand
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
too
were
the
Persian
tales
,
with
flying
chests
and
students
of
enchanted
books
shut
up
for
years
in
caverns
;
and
there
too
was
Abudah
,
the
merchant
,
with
the
terrible
little
old
woman
hobbling
out
of
the
box
in
his
bedroom
;
and
there
the
mighty
talisman
,
the
rare
Arabian
Nights
,
with
Cassim
Baba
,
divided
by
four
,
like
the
ghost
of
a
dreadful
sum
,
<EOS>
hanging
up
,
all
gory
,
in
the
robbers
'
cave
.
 
<EOS>
Which
matchless
wonders
,
coming
fast
on
Mr
Pinch
's
mind
,
did
so
rub
up
and
chafe
that
wonderful
lamp
within
him
,
that
when
he
turned
his
face
towards
the
busy
street
,
a
crowd
of
phantoms
waited
on
his
pleasure
,
and
he
lived
again
,
with
new
delight
,
the
happy
days
before
the
Pecksniff
era
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
less
interest
now
in
the
chemists
'
shops
,
with
their
great
glowing
bottles
(
with
smaller
repositories
of
brightness
in
their
very
stoppers
)
;
and
in
their
agreeable
compromises
between
medicine
and
perfumery
,
in
the
shape
of
toothsome
lozenges
and
virgin
honey
.
<EOS>
Neither
had
he
the
least
regard
(
but
he
never
had
much
)
for
the
tailors
'
,
where
the
newest
metropolitan
waistcoat
patterns
were
hanging
up
,
which
by
some
strange
transformation
always
looked
amazing
there
,
and
never
appeared
at
all
like
the
same
thing
anywhere
else
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
stopped
to
read
the
playbill
at
the
theatre
and
surveyed
the
doorway
with
a
kind
of
awe
,
which
was
not
diminished
when
a
sallow
gentleman
with
long
dark
hair
came
out
,
and
told
a
boy
to
run
home
to
his
lodgings
and
bring
down
his
broadsword
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
stood
rooted
to
the
spot
on
hearing
this
,
and
might
have
stood
there
until
dark
,
but
that
the
old
cathedral
bell
began
to
ring
for
vesper
service
,
on
which
he
tore
himself
away
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
the
organist
's
assistant
was
a
friend
of
Mr
Pinch
's
,
which
was
a
good
thing
,
for
he
too
was
a
very
quiet
gentle
soul
,
and
had
been
,
like
Tom
,
a
kind
of
old
-
fashioned
boy
at
school
,
though
well
liked
by
the
noisy
fellow
too
.
 
<EOS>
As
good
luck
would
have
it
<EOS>
(
Tom
always
said
he
had
great
good
luck
)
<EOS>
the
assistant
chanced
that
very
afternoon
to
be
on
duty
by
himself
,
with
no
one
in
the
dusty
organ
loft
<EOS>
but
Tom
;
so
while
he
played
,
Tom
helped
him
with
the
stops
;
and
finally
,
the
service
being
just
over
,
Tom
took
the
organ
himself
.
<EOS>
It
was
then
turning
dark
,
and
the
yellow
light
that
streamed
in
through
the
ancient
windows
in
the
choir
was
mingled
with
a
murky
red
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
grand
tones
resounded
through
the
church
,
they
seemed
,
to
Tom
,
to
find
an
echo
in
the
depth
of
every
ancient
tomb
,
no
less
than
in
the
deep
mystery
of
his
own
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Great
thoughts
and
hopes
came
crowding
on
his
mind
as
the
rich
music
rolled
upon
the
air
and
yet
among
them
---
something
more
grave
and
solemn
in
their
purpose
,
but
the
same
---
were
all
the
images
of
that
day
,
down
to
its
very
lightest
recollection
of
childhood
.
 
<EOS>
The
feeling
that
the
sounds
awakened
,
in
the
moment
of
their
existence
,
seemed
to
include
his
whole
life
and
being
;
and
as
the
surrounding
realities
of
stone
and
wood
and
glass
grew
dimmer
in
the
darkness
,
these
visions
grew
so
much
the
brighter
that
Tom
might
have
forgotten
the
new
pupil
and
the
expectant
master
,
and
have
sat
there
pouring
out
his
grateful
heart
till
midnight
,
but
for
a
very
earthy
old
verger
insisting
on
locking
up
the
cathedral
forthwith
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
took
leave
of
his
friend
,
with
many
thanks
,
groped
his
way
out
,
as
well
as
he
could
,
into
the
now
lamp
-
lighted
streets
,
and
hurried
off
to
get
his
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
All
the
farmers
being
by
this
time
<EOS>
jogging
homewards
,
there
was
nobody
in
the
sanded
parlour
of
the
tavern
where
he
had
left
the
horse
;
so
he
had
his
little
table
drawn
out
close
before
the
fire
,
and
fell
to
work
upon
a
well
-
cooked
steak
and
smoking
hot
potatoes
,
with
a
strong
appreciation
of
their
excellence
,
and
a
very
keen
sense
of
enjoyment
.
 
<EOS>
Beside
him
,
too
,
there
stood
a
jug
of
most
stupendous
Wiltshire
beer
;
and
the
effect
of
the
whole
was
so
transcendent
,
that
he
was
obliged
every
now
and
then
to
lay
down
his
knife
and
fork
,
rub
his
hands
,
and
think
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
time
the
cheese
and
celery
came
,
Mr
Pinch
had
taken
a
book
out
of
his
pocket
,
and
could
afford
to
trifle
with
the
viands
;
now
eating
a
little
,
now
drinking
a
little
,
now
reading
a
little
,
and
now
stopping
to
wonder
what
sort
of
a
young
man
the
new
pupil
would
turn
out
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
passed
from
this
latter
theme
and
was
deep
in
his
book
again
,
when
the
door
opened
,
and
another
guest
came
in
,
bringing
with
him
such
a
quantity
of
cold
air
,
that
he
positively
seemed
at
first
to
put
the
fire
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
hard
frost
to
-
night
,
sir
,
"
said
the
newcomer
,
courteously
acknowledging
Mr
Pinch
's
withdrawal
of
the
little
table
,
that
he
might
have
place
:
"
Do
n't
disturb
yourself
,
I
beg
.
"
   
<EOS>
Though
he
said
this
with
a
vast
amount
of
consideration
for
Mr
Pinch
's
comfort
,
he
dragged
one
of
the
great
leather
-
bottomed
chairs
to
the
very
centre
of
the
hearth
,
notwithstanding
;
and
sat
down
in
front
of
the
fire
,
with
a
foot
on
each
hob
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
feet
are
quite
numbed
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Bitter
cold
to
be
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
in
the
air
some
considerable
time
,
I
dare
say
?
"
said
Mr
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
day
.
 
<EOS>
Outside
a
coach
,
too
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
accounts
for
his
making
the
room
so
cool
,
"
thought
Mr
Pinch
.
"
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
 
<EOS>
How
thoroughly
chilled
he
must
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
stranger
became
thoughtful
likewise
,
and
sat
for
five
or
ten
minutes
looking
at
the
fire
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
rose
and
divested
himself
of
his
shawl
and
great
-
coat
,
which
(
far
different
from
Mr
Pinch
's
)
was
a
very
warm
and
thick
one
;
but
he
was
not
a
whit
more
conversational
out
of
his
great
-
coat
than
in
it
,
for
he
sat
down
again
in
the
same
place
and
attitude
,
and
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
began
to
bite
his
nails
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
young
---
one
-
and
-
twenty
,
perhaps
---
and
handsome
;
with
a
keen
dark
eye
,
and
a
quickness
of
look
and
manner
which
made
Tom
sensible
of
a
great
contrast
in
his
own
bearing
,
and
caused
him
to
feel
even
more
shy
than
usual
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
clock
in
the
room
,
which
the
stranger
often
turned
to
look
at
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
made
frequent
reference
to
it
also
;
partly
from
a
nervous
sympathy
with
its
taciturn
companion
;
and
partly
because
the
new
pupil
was
to
inquire
for
him
at
half
after
six
,
and
the
hands
were
getting
on
towards
that
hour
.
 
<EOS>
Whenever
the
stranger
caught
him
looking
at
this
clock
,
a
kind
of
confusion
came
upon
Tom
as
if
he
had
been
found
out
in
something
;
and
it
was
a
perception
of
his
uneasiness
which
caused
the
younger
man
to
say
,
perhaps
,
with
a
smile
:
   
"
We
both
appear
to
be
rather
particular
about
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
I
have
an
engagement
to
meet
a
gentleman
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
have
I
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
half
-
past
six
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
half
-
past
six
,
"
said
Tom
in
the
very
same
breath
;
whereupon
the
other
looked
at
him
with
some
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
,
I
expect
,
"
remarked
Tom
,
timidly
,
"
was
to
inquire
at
that
time
for
a
person
by
the
name
of
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
cried
the
other
,
jumping
up
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
have
been
keeping
the
fire
from
you
all
this
while
!
 
<EOS>
I
had
no
idea
<EOS>
you
were
Mr
Pinch
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
Mr
Martin
for
whom
you
were
to
inquire
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
excuse
me
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
do
draw
nearer
,
pray
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at
all
cold
,
and
you
are
;
and
we
have
a
cold
ride
before
us
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
if
you
wish
it
,
I
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
am
very
glad
,
"
said
Tom
,
smiling
with
an
embarrassed
frankness
peculiarly
his
,
and
which
was
as
plainly
a
confession
of
his
own
imperfections
,
and
an
appeal
to
the
kindness
of
the
person
he
addressed
,
as
if
he
had
drawn
one
up
in
simple
language
and
committed
it
to
paper
:
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
indeed
that
you
turn
out
to
be
the
party
I
expected
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
thinking
,
but
a
minute
ago
,
that
I
could
wish
him
to
be
like
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
returned
Martin
,
shaking
hands
with
him
again
;
"
for
I
assure
you
,
I
was
thinking
there
could
be
no
such
luck
as
Mr
Pinch
's
turning
out
like
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
really
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
with
great
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
serious
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
I
am
,
"
replied
his
new
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
and
I
will
get
on
excellently
well
,
I
know
;
which
it
's
no
small
relief
to
me
to
feel
,
for
to
tell
you
the
truth
<EOS>
,
I
am
not
at
all
the
sort
of
fellow
who
could
get
on
with
everybody
,
and
that
's
the
point
on
which
I
had
the
greatest
doubts
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
're
quite
relieved
now
.
<EOS>
---
Do
me
the
favour
to
ring
the
bell
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
rose
,
and
complied
with
great
alacrity
---
the
handle
hung
just
over
Martin
's
head
,
as
he
warmed
himself
---
and
listened
with
a
smiling
face
to
what
his
friend
went
on
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
:
   
"
<EOS>
If
you
like
punch
,
you
'll
allow
me
to
order
a
glass
<EOS>
apiece
,
as
hot
as
it
can
be
made
,
that
we
may
usher
in
our
friendship
in
a
becoming
manner
.
 
<EOS>
To
let
you
into
a
secret
,
Mr
Pinch
,
I
never
was
so
much
in
want
of
something
warm
and
cheering
in
my
life
;
but
I
did
n't
like
to
run
the
chance
of
being
found
drinking
it
,
without
knowing
what
kind
of
person
you
were
;
for
first
impressions
,
you
know
,
often
go
a
long
way
,
and
last
a
long
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
assented
,
and
the
punch
was
ordered
.
 
<EOS>
In
due
course
it
came
;
hot
and
strong
.
 
<EOS>
After
drinking
to
each
other
in
the
steaming
mixture
,
they
became
quite
confidential
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
sort
of
relation
of
Pecksniff
's
,
you
know
,
"
said
the
young
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
cried
Mr
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
My
grandfather
is
his
cousin
,
so
he
's
kith
and
kin
to
me
,
somehow
,
if
you
can
make
that
out
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
Martin
is
your
Christian
name
?
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
thoughtfully
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
is
,
"
returned
his
friend
:
"
<EOS>
I
wish
it
was
my
surname
for
my
own
<EOS>
is
not
a
very
pretty
one
,
and
it
takes
a
long
time
to
sign
Chuzzlewit
<EOS>
is
my
name
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
cried
Mr
Pinch
,
with
an
involuntary
start
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
surprised
at
my
having
two
names
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
returned
the
other
,
setting
his
glass
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Most
people
have
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
"
not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
!
 
<EOS>
Well
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
remembering
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
privately
cautioned
him
to
say
nothing
in
reference
to
the
old

the
same
name
who
had
lodged
at
the

,
but
to

all

of
that

for

,
he
had
no

of
hiding
his

than

own

to

.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
at
each
other
out
of
their
respective

for
a

seconds
,
and
then
put
them
down
empty
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
told
them
in
the
stable
to
be
ready
for
us
ten
minutes
ago
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
glancing
at
the
clock
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
go
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
returned
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
like
to
drive
?
"
said
Mr
Pinch
;
his
whole
face
beaming
with
a
consciousness
of
the
splendour
of
his
offer
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
shall
,
if
you
wish
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
that
depends
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Martin
,
laughing
,
"
upon
what
sort
of
a
horse
you
have
.
 
<EOS>
Because
if
he
's
a
bad
one
,
I
would
rather
keep
my
hands
warm
by
holding
them
comfortably
in
my
greatcoat
pockets
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
think
this
such
a
good
joke
,
that
Mr
Pinch
was
quite
sure
it
must
be
a
capital
one
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
laughed
too
,
and
was
fully
persuaded
that
he
enjoyed
it
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
settled
his
bill
,
and
Mr
Chuzzlewit
paid
for
the
punch
;
and
having
wrapped
themselves
up
,
to
the
extent
of
their
respective
means
,
they
went
out
together
to
the
front
door
,
where
Mr
Pecksniff
's
property
stopped
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
drive
,
thank
you
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Martin
,
getting
into
the
sitter
's
place
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
bye
,
there
's
a
box
of
mine
.
 
<EOS>
Can
we
manage
to
take
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Put
it
in
,
Dick
,
anywhere
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
precisely
of
that
convenient
size
which
would
admit
of
its
being
squeezed
into
any
odd
corner
,
but
Dick
the
hostler
got
it
in
somehow
,
and
Mr
Chuzzlewit
helped
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
on
Mr
Pinch
's
side
,
and
Mr
Chuzzlewit
said
he
was
very
much
afraid
it
would
encumber
him
;
to
which
Tom
said
,
"
Not
at
all
;
"
though
it
forced
him
into
such
an
awkward
position
,
that
he
had
much
ado
to
see
anything
but
his
own
knees
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
an
ill
wind
that
blows
nobody
any
good
;
and
the
wisdom
of
the
saying
was
verified
in
this
instance
;
for
the
cold
air
came
from
Mr
Pinch
's
side
of
the
carriage
,
and
by
interposing
a
perfect
wall
of
box
and
man
between
it
and
the
new
pupil
,
he
shielded
that
young
gentleman
effectually
;
which
was
a
great
comfort
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
clear
evening
,
with
a
bright
moon
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
landscape
was
silvered
by
its
light
and
by
the
hoar
-
frost
;
and
everything
looked
exquisitely
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
the
great
serenity
and
peace
through
which
they
travelled
,
disposed
them
both
to
silence
;
but
in
a
very
short
time
the
punch
within
them
and
the
healthful
air
without
,
made
them
loquacious
,
and
they
talked
incessantly
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
were
halfway
home
,
and
stopped
to
give
the
horse
some
water
,
Martin
(
who
was
very
generous
with
his
money
)
ordered
another
glass
of
punch
,
which
they
drank
between
them
,
and
which
had
not
the
effect
of
making
them
less
conversational
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
Their
principal
topic
of
discourse
was
naturally
Mr
Pecksniff
and
his
family
;
of
whom
,
and
of
the
great
obligations
they
had
heaped
upon
him
,
Tom
Pinch
,
with
the
tears
standing
in
his
eyes
,
drew
such
a
picture
as
would
have
inclined
any
one
of
common
feeling
almost
to
revere
them
;
and
of
which
Mr
Pecksniff
had
not
the
slightest
foresight
or
preconceived
idea
,
or
he
certainly
(
being
very
humble
)
would
not
have
sent
Tom
Pinch
to
bring
the
pupil
home
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
way
they
went
on
,
and
on
,
and
on
---
in
the
language
of
the
story
-
books
---
until
at
last
the
village
lights
appeared
before
them
,
and
the
church
spire
cast
a
long
reflection
on
the
graveyard
grass
;
as
if
it
were
a
dial
(
alas
,
the
truest
in
the
world
!
)
<EOS>
marking
,
whatever
light
shone
out
of
Heaven
,
the
flight
of
days
and
weeks
and
years
,
by
some
new
shadow
on
that
solemn
ground
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
pretty
church
!
<EOS>
"
said
Martin
,
observing
that
his
companion
slackened
the
slack
pace
of
the
horse
,
as
they
approached
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
with
great
pride
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
sweetest
little
organ
there
<EOS>
you
ever
heard
.
 
<EOS>
I
play
it
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
?
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
hardly
worth
the
trouble
,
I
should
think
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
get
for
that
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
answered
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
returned
his
friend
,
"
you
ARE
a
very
strange
fellow
!
"
   
<EOS>
To
which
remark
there
succeeded
a
brief
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
say
nothing
,
"
observed
Mr
Pinch
,
cheerfully
,
"
I
am
wrong
,
and
do
n't
say
what
I
mean
,
because
I
get
a
great
deal
of
pleasure
from
it
,
and
the
means
of
passing
some
of
the
happiest
hours
I
know
.
<EOS>
It
led
to
something
else
the
other
day
;
but
you
will
not
care
to
hear
about
that
I
dare
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
I
shall
.
 
<EOS>
What
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
led
to
my
seeing
,
"
said
Tom
,
in
a
lower
voice
,
"
one
of
the
loveliest
and
most
beautiful
faces
you
can
possibly
picture
to
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
am
able
to
picture
a
beautiful
one
,
"
said
his
friend
,
thoughtfully
,
"
or
should
be
,
if
I
have
any
memory
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
came
"
said
Tom
,
laying
his
hand
upon
the
other
's
arm
,
"
for
the
first
time
very
early
in
the
morning
,
when
it
was
hardly
light
;
and
when
I
saw
her
,
over
my
shoulder
,
standing
just
within
the
porch
,
I
turned
quite
cold
,
almost
believing
her
to
be
a
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
A
moment
's
reflection
got
the
better
of
that
,
of
course
,
and
fortunately
it
came
to
my
relief
so
soon
,
that
I
did
n't
leave
off
playing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
fortunately
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
?
 
<EOS>
Because
she
stood
there
,
listening
.
 
<EOS>
I
had
my
spectacles
on
,
and
saw
her
through
the
chinks
in
the
curtains
as
plainly
as
I
see
you
;
and
she
was
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
while
she
glided
off
,
and
I
continued
to
play
until
she
was
out
of
hearing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
do
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
see
?
"
responded
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
she
might
suppose
I
had
n't
seen
her
;
and
might
return
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
did
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
she
did
.
 
<EOS>
Next
morning
,
and
next
evening
too
<EOS>
;
<EOS>
but
always
when
there
were
no
people
about
,
and
always
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
rose
earlier
and
sat
there
later
,
that
when
she
came
,
she
might
find
the
church
door
open
,
and
the
organ
playing
,
and
might
not
be
disappointed
.
<EOS>
She
strolled
that
way
for
some
days
,
and
always
stayed
to
listen
.
<EOS>
But
she
is
gone
now
,
and
of
all
unlikely
things
in
this
wide
world
,
it
is
perhaps
the
most
improbable
that
I
shall
ever
look
upon
her
face
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
anything
more
about
her
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
never
followed
her
when
she
went
away
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
distress
her
by
doing
that
?
"
said
Tom
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
likely
that
she
wanted
my
company
?
 
<EOS>
She
came
to
hear
the
organ
,
not
to
see
me
;
and
would
you
have
had
me
scare
her
from
a
place
she
seemed
to
grow
quite
fond
of
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Heaven
bless
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
"
to
have
given
her
but
a
minute
's
pleasure
every
day
,
I
would
have
gone
on
playing
the
organ
at
those
times
until
I
was
an
old
man
;
quite
contented
if
she
sometimes
thought
of
a
poor
fellow
like
me
,
as
a
part
of
the
music
;
and
more
than
recompensed
if
she
ever
mixed
me
up
with
anything
she
liked
as
well
as
she
liked
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
new
pupil
was
clearly
very
much
amazed
by
Mr
Pinch
's
weakness
,
and
would
probably
have
told
him
so
,
and
given
him
some
good
advice
,
but
for
their
opportune
arrival
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
door
;
the
front
door
this
time
,
on
account
of
the
occasion
being
one
of
ceremony
and
rejoicing
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
man
was
in
waiting
for
the
horse
who
had
been
adjured
by
Mr
Pinch
in
the
morning
not
to
yield
to
his
rabid
desire
to
start
;
and
after
delivering
the
animal
into
his
charge
,
and
beseeching
Mr
Chuzzlewit
in
a
whisper
never
to
reveal
a
syllable
of
what
he
had
just
told
him
in
the
fullness
of
his
heart
,
Tom
led
the
pupil
in
,
for
instant
presentation
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
clearly
not
expected
them
for
hours
to
come
;
for
he
was
surrounded
by
open
books
,
and
was
glancing
from
volume
to
volume
,
with
a
black
lead
-
pencil
in
his
mouth
,
and
a
pair
of
compasses
in
his
hand
,
at
a
vast
number
of
mathematical
diagrams
,
of
such
extraordinary
shapes
that
they
looked
like
designs
for
fireworks
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
had
Miss
Charity
expected
them
,
for
she
was
busied
,
with
a
capacious
wicker
basket
before
her
,
in
making
impracticable
nightcaps
for
the
poor
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
had
Miss
Mercy
expected
them
,
for
she
was
sitting
upon
her
stool
,
tying
on
the
---
oh
good
gracious
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
the
petticoat
of
a
large
doll
that
she
was
dressing
for
a
neighbour
's
child
---
really
,
quite
a
grown
-
up
doll
,
which
made
it
more
confusing
---
and
had
its
little
bonnet
dangling
by
the
ribbon
from
one
of
her
fair
curls
,
to
which
she
had
fastened
it
lest
it
should
be
lost
or
sat
upon
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
difficult
,
if
not
impossible
,
to
conceive
a
family
so
thoroughly
taken
by
surprise
as
the
Pecksniffs
were
,
on
this
occasion
.
   
<EOS>
Bless
my
life
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
up
,
and
gradually
exchanging
his
abstracted
face
for
one
of
joyful
recognition
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
already
!
 
<EOS>
Martin
,
my
dear
boy
,
I
am
delighted
to
welcome
you
to
my
poor
house
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
kind
greeting
,
Mr
Pecksniff
fairly
took
him
to
his
arms
,
and
patted
him
several
times
upon
the
back
with
his
right
hand
the
while
,
as
if
to
express
that
his
feelings
during
the
embrace
were
too
much
for
utterance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
here
,
"
he
said
,
recovering
,
"
are
my
daughters
,
Martin
;
my
two
only
children
,
whom
(
if
you
ever
saw
them
)
you
have
not
beheld
---
ah
,
these
sad
family
divisions
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
since
you
were
infants
together
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
my
dears
,
why
blush
at
being
detected
in
your
everyday
pursuits
?
 
<EOS>
We
had
prepared
to
give
you
the
reception
of
a
visitor
,
Martin
,
in
our
little
room
of
state
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
smiling
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
like
this
better
,
I
like
this
better
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
blessed
star
of
Innocence
,
wherever
you
may
be
,
how
did
you
glitter
in
your
home
of
ether
,
when
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
put
forth
each
her
lily
hand
,
and
gave
the
same
,
with
mantling
cheeks
,
to
Martin
!
 
<EOS>
How
did
you
twinkle
,
as
if
fluttering
with
sympathy
,
when
Mercy
,
reminded
of
the
bonnet
in
her
hair
,
hid
her
fair
face
and
turned
her
head
aside
;
<EOS>
the
while
her
gentle
sister
plucked
it
out
,
and
smote
her
with
a
sister
's
soft
reproof
,
upon
her
buxom
shoulder
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
turning
round
after
the
contemplation
of
these
passages
,
and
taking
Mr
Pinch
in
a
friendly
manner
by
the
elbow
,
"
how
has
our
friend
used
you
,
Martin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
indeed
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
on
the
best
terms
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Old
Tom
Pinch
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
on
him
with
affectionate
sadness
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
seems
but
yesterday
that
Thomas
was
a
boy
fresh
from
a
scholastic
course
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
years
have
passed
,
I
think
,
since
Thomas
Pinch
and
I
first
walked
the
world
together
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
could
say
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
too
much
moved
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
pressed
his
master
's
hand
,
and
tried
to
thank
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Thomas
Pinch
and
I
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
a
deeper
voice
,
"
will
walk
it
yet
,
in
mutual
faithfulness
and
friendship
!
 
<EOS>
And
if
it
comes
to
pass
that
either
of
us
be
run
over
in
any
of
those
busy
crossings
which
divide
the
streets
of
life
,
the
other
will
convey
him
to
the
hospital
in
Hope
,
and
sit
beside
his
bed
in
Bounty
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
well
!
"
he
added
in
a
happier
tone
,
as
he
shook
Mr
Pinch
's
elbow
hard
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
more
of
this
!
 
<EOS>
Martin
,
my
dear
friend
,
that
you
may
be
at
home
within
these
walls
,
let
me
show
you
how
we
live
,
and
where
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
took
up
a
lighted
candle
,
and
,
attended
by
his
young
relative
,
prepared
to
leave
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
door
,
he
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
bear
us
company
,
Tom
Pinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
Aye
,
cheerfully
,
though
it
had
been
to
death
,
would
Tom
have
followed
him
;
glad
to
lay
down
his
life
for
such
a
man
!
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
opening
the
door
of
an
opposite
parlour
,
"
is
the
little
room
of
state
,
I
mentioned
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
My
girls
have
pride
in
it
,
Martin
!
 
<EOS>
This
,
"
opening
another
door
,
"
is
the
little
chamber
in
which
my
works
(
slight
things
at
best
)
have
been
concocted
.
 
<EOS>
Portrait
of
myself
by
Spiller
.
 
<EOS>
Bust
by
Spoker
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
is
considered
a
good
likeness
.
 
<EOS>
I
seem
to
recognize
something
about
the
left
-
hand
corner
of
the
nose
,
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
thought
it
was
very
like
,
but
scarcely
intellectual
enough
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
observed
that
the
same
fault
had
been
found
with
it
before
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
it
should
have
struck
his
young
relation
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
glad
to
see
he
had
an
eye
for
art
.
   
<EOS>
"
Various
books
you
observe
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
waving
his
hand
towards
the
wall
,
"
connected
with
our
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
scribbled
myself
,
but
have
not
yet
published
.
 
<EOS>
Be
careful
how
you
come
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
"
opening
another
door
<EOS>
,
"
is
my
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
I
read
here
when
the
family
suppose
I
have
retired
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
injure
my
health
rather
more
than
I
can
quite
justify
to
myself
,
by
doing
so
;
but
art
is
long
and
time
is
short
.
 
<EOS>
Every
facility
you
see
for
jotting
down
crude
notions
,
even
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
latter
words
were
explained
by
his
pointing
to
a
small
round
table
on
which
were
a
lamp
,
divers
sheets
of
paper
,
a
piece
of
India
rubber
,
and
a
case
of
instruments
;
all
put
ready
,
in
case
an
architectural
idea
should
come
into
Mr
Pecksniff
's
head
in
the
night
;
in
which
event
he
would
instantly
leap
out
of
bed
,
and
fix
it
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
opened
another
door
on
the
same
floor
,
and
shut
it
again
,
all
at
once
,
as
if
it
were
a
Blue
Chamber
.
 
<EOS>
But
before
he
had
well
done
so
,
he
looked
smilingly
round
,
and
said
,
"
Why
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
could
n't
say
why
not
,
because
he
did
n't
know
anything
at
all
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
So
Mr
Pecksniff
answered
himself
,
by
throwing
open
the
door
,
and
saying
:
   
"
My
daughters
'
room
.
 
<EOS>
A
poor
first
-
floor
to
us
,
but
a
bower
to
them
.
<EOS>
Very
neat
.
 
<EOS>
Very
airy
.
 
<EOS>
Plants
you
observe
;
hyacinths
<EOS>
;
books
again
;
birds
.
"
 
<EOS>
These
birds
,
by
the
bye
,
comprised
,
in
all
,
one
staggering
old
sparrow
without
a
tail
,
which
had
been
borrowed
expressly
from
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
trifles
as
girls
love
are
here
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
.
<EOS>
Those
who
seek
heartless
splendour
,
would
seek
here
in
vain
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
led
them
to
the
floor
above
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
throwing
wide
the
door
of
the
memorable
two
-
pair
front
;
"
is
a
room
where
some
talent
has
been
developed
I
believe
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
room
in
which
an
idea
for
a
steeple
occurred
to
me
that
I
may
one
day
give
to
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
We
work
here
,
my
dear
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Some
architects
have
been
bred
in
this
room
;
a
few
,
I
think
,
Mr
Pinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
fully
assented
;
and
,
<EOS>
what
is
more
,
fully
believed
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
passing
the
candle
rapidly
from
roll
to
roll
of
paper
,
"
some
traces
of
our
doings
here
.
 
<EOS>
Salisbury
Cathedral
from
the
north
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
south
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
east
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
west
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
south
-
east
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
nor'west
.
 
<EOS>
A
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
An
almshouse
.
 
<EOS>
A
jail
.
 
<EOS>
A
church
.
 
<EOS>
A
powder
-
magazine
.
 
<EOS>
A
wine
-
cellar
.
<EOS>
A
portico
.
 
<EOS>
A
summer
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
An
ice
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
Plans
,
elevations
,
sections
,
every
kind
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
,
"
he
added
,
having
by
this
time
reached
another
large
chamber
on
the
same
story
,
with
four
little
beds
in
it
,
"
this
is
your
room
,
of
which
Mr
Pinch
here
is
the
quiet
sharer
.
 
<EOS>
A
southern
aspect
;
a
charming
prospect
;
Mr
Pinch
's
little
library
<EOS>
,
you
perceive
;
everything
agreeable
and
appropriate
.
<EOS>
If
there
is
any
additional
comfort
you
would
desire
to
have
here
at
anytime
,
pray
mention
it
.
 
<EOS>
Even
to
strangers
,
far
less
to
you
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Martin
,
there
is
no
restriction
on
that
point
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
undoubtedly
true
,
and
may
be
stated
in
corroboration
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
that
any
pupil
had
the
most
liberal
permission
to
mention
anything
in
this
way
that
suggested
itself
to
his
fancy
.
 
<EOS>
Some
young
gentlemen
had
gone
on
mentioning
the
very
same
thing
for
five
years
without
ever
being
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
domestic
assistants
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
sleep
above
;
and
that
is
all
.
"
 
<EOS>
After
which
,
and
listening
complacently
as
he
went
,
to
the
encomiums
passed
by
his
young
friend
on
the
arrangements
generally
,
he
led
the
way
to
the
parlour
again
.
   
<EOS>
Here
a
great
change
had
taken
place
;
for
festive
preparations
on
a
rather
extensive
scale
were
already
completed
,
and
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
were
awaiting
their
return
with
hospitable
looks
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
two
bottles
of
currant
wine
,
white
and
red
;
a
dish
of
sandwiches
(
very
long
and
very
slim
)
;
another
of
apples
;
another
of
captain
's
biscuits
(
which
are
always
a
moist
and
jovial
sort
of
viand
)
;
a
plate
of
oranges
cut
up
small
and
gritty
;
with
powdered
sugar
,
and
a
highly
geological
home
-
made
cake
.
 
<EOS>
The
magnitude
of
these
preparations
quite
took
away
Tom
Pinch
's
breath
;
for
though
the
new
pupils
were
usually
let
down
softly
,
as
one
may
say
,
particularly
in
the
wine
department
,
which
had
so
many
stages
of
declension
,
that
sometimes
a
young
gentleman
was
a
whole
fortnight
in
getting
to
the
pump
;
still
this
was
a
banquet
;
a
sort
of
Lord
Mayor
's
feast
in
private
life
;
a
something
to
think
of
,
and
hold
on
by
,
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
entertainment
,
which
apart
from
its
own
intrinsic
merits
,
had
the
additional
choice
quality
,
that
it
was
in
strict
keeping
with
the
night
,
being
both
light
and
cool
<EOS>
,
Mr
Pecksniff
besought
the
company
to
do
full
justice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Martin
,
"
he
said
,
"
will
seat
himself
between
you
two
,
my
dears
,
and
Mr
Pinch
will
come
by
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
drink
to
our
new
inmate
,
and
may
we
be
happy
together
!
 
<EOS>
Martin
,
my
dear
friend
,
my
love
to
you
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
if
you
spare
the
bottle
we
shall
quarrel
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
trying
(
in
his
regard
for
the
feelings
of
the
rest
)
to
look
as
if
the
wine
were
not
acid
and
did
n't
make
him
wink
,
Mr
Pecksniff
did
honour
to
his
own
toast
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
he
said
,
in
allusion
to
the
party
,
not
the
wine
,
"
is
a
mingling
that
repays
one
for
much
disappointment
and
vexation
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
be
merry
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
he
took
a
captain
's
biscuit
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
poor
heart
that
never
rejoices
;
and
our
hearts
are
not
poor
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
such
stimulants
to
merriment
did
he
beguile
the
time
,
and
do
the
honours
of
the
table
;
while
Mr
Pinch
,
perhaps
to
assure
himself
that
what
he
saw
and
heard
was
holiday
reality
,
and
not
a
charming
dream
,
ate
of
everything
,
and
in
particular
disposed
of
the
slim
sandwiches
to
a
surprising
extent
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
he
stinted
in
his
draughts
of
wine
;
but
on
the
contrary
,
remembering
Mr
Pecksniff
's
speech
,
attacked
the
bottle
with
such
vigour
,
that
every
time
he
filled
his
glass
anew
,
Miss
Charity
,
despite
her
amiable
resolves
,
could
not
repress
a
fixed
and
stony
glare
,
as
if
her
eyes
had
rested
on
a
ghost
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
also
became
thoughtful
at
those
moments
,
not
to
say
dejected
;
but
as
he
knew
the
vintage
,
it
is
very
likely
he
may
have
been
speculating
on
the
probable
condition
of
Mr
Pinch
upon
the
morrow
,
and
discussing
within
himself
the
best
remedies
for
colic
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
and
the
young
ladies
were
excellent
friends
already
,
and
compared
recollections
of
their
childish
days
,
to
their
mutual
liveliness
and
entertainment
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mercy
laughed
immensely
at
everything
that
was
said
;
and
sometimes
,
after
glancing
at
the
happy
face
of
Mr
Pinch
,
was
seized
with
such
fits
of
mirth
as
brought
her
to
the
very
confines
of
hysterics
.
 
<EOS>
But
for
these
bursts
of
gaiety
,
her
sister
,
in
her
better
sense
,
reproved
her
;
observing
,
in
an
angry
whisper
,
that
it
was
far
from
being
a
theme
for
jest
;
and
that
she
had
no
patience
with
the
creature
;
though
it
generally
ended
in
her
laughing
too
---
but
much
more
moderately
---
and
saying
that
indeed
it
was
a
little
too
ridiculous
and
intolerable
to
be
serious
about
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
it
became
high
time
to
remember
the
first
clause
of
that
great
discovery
made
by
the
ancient
philosopher
,
for
securing
health
,
riches
,
and
wisdom
;
the
infallibility
of
which
has
been
for
generations
verified
by
the
enormous
fortunes
constantly
amassed
by
chimney
-
sweepers
and
other
persons
who
get
up
early
and
go
to
bed
betimes
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
accordingly
rose
,
and
having
taken
leave
of
Mr
Chuzzlewit
with
much
sweetness
,
and
of
their
father
with
much
duty
and
of
Mr
Pinch
with
much
condescension
,
retired
to
their
bower
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
insisted
on
accompanying
his
young
friend
upstairs
for
personal
superintendence
of
his
comforts
;
and
taking
him
by
the
arm
,
conducted
him
once
more
to
his
bedroom
,
followed
by
Mr
Pinch
,
who
bore
the
light
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
seating
himself
with
folded
arms
on
one
of
the
spare
beds
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
any
snuffers
in
that
candlestick
.
<EOS>
Will
you
oblige
me
by
going
down
,
and
asking
for
a
pair
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
only
too
happy
to
be
useful
,
went
off
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
excuse
Thomas
Pinch
's
want
of
polish
,
Martin
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
a
smile
of
patronage
and
pity
,
as
soon
as
he
had
left
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
means
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
very
good
fellow
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Thomas
Pinch
means
well
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
very
grateful
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
regretted
having
befriended
Thomas
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
you
never
would
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
I
hope
not
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
,
he
is
always
disposed
to
do
his
best
;
but
he
is
not
gifted
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
make
him
useful
to
you
,
Martin
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
If
Thomas
has
a
fault
,
it
is
that
he
is
sometimes
a
little
apt
to
forget
his
position
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
is
soon
checked
.
 
<EOS>
Worthy
soul
!
 
<EOS>
You
will
find
him
easy
to
manage
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
By
this
time
Mr
Pinch
had
returned
with
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
good
night
to
YOU
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
sound
sleep
to
you
both
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Invoking
this
benediction
on
the
heads
of
his
young
friends
with
great
fervour
,
he
withdrew
to
his
own
room
;
while
they
,
being
tired
,
soon
fell
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
If
Martin
dreamed
at
all
,
some
clue
to
the
matter
of
his
visions
may
possibly
be
gathered
from
the
after
-
pages
of
this
history
.
 
<EOS>
Those
of
Thomas
Pinch
were
all
of
holidays
,
church
organs
,
and
seraphic
Pecksniffs
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
some
time
before
Mr
Pecksniff
dreamed
at
all
,
or
even
sought
his
pillow
,
as
he
sat
for
full
two
hours
before
the
fire
in
his
own
chamber
,
looking
at
the
coals
and
thinking
deeply
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
,
too
,
slept
and
dreamed
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
in
the
quiet
hours
of
the
night
,
one
house
shuts
in
as
many
incoherent
and
incongruous
fancies
as
a
madman
's
head
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
06
.
<EOS>
Comprises
,
among
other
important
matters
,
Pecksniffian
and
achitectural
,
and
exact
relation
of
the
progress
made
by
Mr
Pinch
in
the
confidence
and
friendship
of
the
new
pupil
 
<EOS>
It
was
morning
;
and
the
beautiful
Aurora
,
of
whom
so
much
hath
been
written
,
said
,
and
sung
,
did
,
with
her
rosy
fingers
,
nip
and
tweak
Miss
Pecksniff
's
nose
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
frolicsome
custom
of
the
Goddess
,
in
her
intercourse
with
the
fair
Cherry
,
so
to
do
;
or
in
more
prosaic
phrase
,
the
tip
of
that
feature
in
the
sweet
girl
's
countenance
was
always
very
red
at
breakfast
-
time
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
most
part
,
indeed
,
it
wore
,
at
that
season
of
the
day
,
a
scraped
and
frosty
look
,
as
if
it
had
been
rasped
;
while
a
similar
phenomenon
developed
itself
in
her
humour
,
which
was
then
observed
to
be
of
a
sharp
and
acid
quality
,
as
though
an
extra
lemon
(
figuratively
speaking
)
had
been
squeezed
into
the
nectar
of
her
disposition
,
and
had
rather
damaged
its
flavour
.
   
<EOS>
This
additional
pungency
on
the
part
of
the
fair
young
creature
led
,
on
ordinary
occasions
,
to
such
slight
consequences
as
the
copious
dilution
of
Mr
Pinch
's
tea
,
or
to
his
coming
off
uncommonly
short
in
respect
of
butter
,
or
to
other
the
like
results
.
 
<EOS>
But
on
the
morning
after
the
Installation
Banquet
,
she
suffered
him
to
wander
to
and
fro
among
the
eatables
and
drinkables
,
a
perfectly
free
and
unchecked
man
;
so
utterly
to
Mr
Pinch
's
wonder
and
confusion
,
that
like
the
wretched
captive
who
recovered
his
liberty
in
his
old
age
,
he
could
make
but
<EOS>
little
use
of
his
enlargement
,
and
fell
into
a
strange
kind
of
flutter
for
want
of
some
kind
hand
to
scrape
his
bread
,
and
cut
him
off
in
the
article
of
sugar
with
a
lump
,
and
pay
him
those
other
little
attentions
to
which
he
was
accustomed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
something
almost
awful
,
too
,
about
the
self
-
possession
of
the
new
pupil
;
who
"
troubled
"
Mr
Pecksniff
for
the
loaf
,
and
helped
himself
to
a
rasher
of
that
gentleman
's
own
particular
and
private
bacon
,
with
all
the
coolness
in
life
.
 
<EOS>
He
even
seemed
to
think
that
he
was
doing
quite
a
regular
thing
,
and
to
expect
that
Mr
Pinch
would
follow
his
example
,
since
he
took
occasion
to
observe
of
that
young
man
"
that
he
did
n't
get
on
"
;
a
speech
of
so
tremendous
a
character
,
that
Tom
cast
down
his
eyes
involuntarily
,
and
felt
as
if
he
himself
had
committed
some
horrible
deed
and
heinous
breach
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
agony
of
having
such
an
indiscreet
remark
addressed
to
him
before
the
assembled
family
,
was
breakfast
enough
in
itself
,
and
would
,
without
any
other
matter
of
reflection
,
have
settled
Mr
Pinch
's
business
and
quenched
his
appetite
,
for
one
meal
,
though
he
had
been
never
so
hungry
.
   
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
,
however
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
likewise
,
remained
in
the
very
best
of
spirits
in
spite
of
these
severe
trials
,
though
with
something
of
a
mysterious
understanding
among
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
meal
was
nearly
over
,
Mr
Pecksniff
smilingly
explained
the
cause
of
their
common
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
often
,
"
he
said
,
"
Martin
,
that
my
daughters
and
I
desert
our
quiet
home
to
pursue
the
giddy
round
of
pleasures
that
revolves
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
think
of
doing
so
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
!
"
cried
the
new
pupil
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
tapping
his
left
hand
with
a
letter
which
he
held
in
his
right
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
summons
here
to
repair
to
London
;
on
professional
business
,
my
dear
Martin
;
strictly
on
professional
business
;
and
I
promised
my
girls
,
long
ago
,
that
whenever
that
happened
again
,
they
should
accompany
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
go
forth
to
-
night
by
the
heavy
coach
---
like
the
dove
of
old
,
my
dear
Martin
---
and
it
will
be
a
week
before
we
again
deposit
our
olive
-
branches
in
the
passage
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
say
olive
-
branches
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
explanation
,
"
I
mean
,
our
unpretending
luggage
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
the
young
ladies
will
enjoy
their
trip
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
that
I
'm
sure
we
shall
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mercy
,
clapping
her
hands
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
gracious
,
Cherry
,
my
darling
,
the
idea
of
London
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ardent
child
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
gazing
on
her
in
a
dreamy
way
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
there
is
a
melancholy
sweetness
in
these
youthful
hopes
!
<EOS>
It
is
pleasant
to
know
that
they
never
can
be
realised
.
 
<EOS>
I
remember
thinking
once
myself
,
in
the
days
of
my
childhood
,
that
pickled
onions
grew
on
trees
,
and
that
every
elephant
was
born
with
an
impregnable
castle
on
his
back
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
found
the
fact
to
be
so
;
far
from
it
;
and
yet
those
visions
have
comforted
me
under
circumstances
of
trial
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
I
have
had
the
anguish
of
discovering
that
I
have
nourished
in
my
breast
on
ostrich
,
and
not
a
human
pupil
---
even
in
that
hour
of
agony
,
they
have
soothed
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
At
this
dread
allusion
to
John
Westlock
,
Mr
Pinch
precipitately
choked
in
his
tea
;
for
he
had
<EOS>
that
very
morning
received
a
letter
from
him
,
as
Mr
Pecksniff
very
well
knew
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
take
care
,
my
dear
Martin
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
resuming
his
former

,
"
that
the
house
does
not
run
away
in
our
absence
.
 
<EOS>
We
leave
you
in
charge
of
everything
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
mystery
;
all
is
free
and
open
.
 
<EOS>
Unlike
the
young
man
in
the
Eastern

---
who
is
described
as
a
one
-

almanac
,
if
I
am
not
mistaken
,
Mr
Pinch
?
---
"
   
"
A
one
-
eyed
calender
,
I
think
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
faltered
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
are
pretty

,

,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,

;
"
or

my

.
<EOS>
Unlike
that
young
man
,
my
dear
Martin
,
you
are
forbidden
to
enter
no
corner
of
this
house
;
but
are
requested
to
make
yourself
perfectly
at
home
in
every

of

.
 
<EOS>
You
will
be
jovial
,
my
dear
Martin
,
and
will
kill
the
fatted
calf
if
you
please
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
not
the
least
objection
,
doubtless
,
to
the
young
man
's
slaughtering
and
appropriating
to

own

any

,

,
that

might
happen

upon

;
but
as
no

chanced
at
that

Mr
Pecksniff
's

,
this

must
be
considered
rather
as
a

that
a
substantial

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
finishing
ornament
of
the
conversation
;
for
when
he
had
delivered

,
Mr
Pecksniff
rose
and
led

way
to
that
hotbed
of
architectural
genius
,
the
two
-
pair
front
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
"
he
said
,
searching
among
the
papers
,
"
how
you
can
best
employ
yourself
,
Martin
,
while
I
am
absent
.
 
<EOS>
Suppose
you
were
to
give
me
your
idea
of
a
monument
to
a

of
London
;
or
a

a

;
or
your

a

in

.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
now
,
"
said

Pecksniff
,

,
"
that
I
should
very
much
like
to
see
your
notion

a

?
"
   
<EOS>
But
Martin
by
no
means
appeared
to
relish

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
pump
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
is
very
chaste
practice
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
found
that
a
lamp
post
is
calculated
to
refine
the
mind
and
give
it
a
classical
tendency
.
 
<EOS>
An
ornamental
turnpike
has
a
remarkable
effect
upon
the
imagination
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
say
to
beginning
with
an
ornamental
turnpike
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whatever
Mr
Pecksniff
pleased
,
"
said
Martin
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
"
said
that

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
<EOS>
as
you
're
ambitious
,
and
are
a
very
neat

,
you
shall
---
ha
ha
!
<EOS>
---
you
shall
try
your
hand
on
these

a

;

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

"

"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Who

?
 
<EOS>
For

,

Martin
<EOS>
,

in

,
that

tell
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Now

,
"

"
an

to
me
,
to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
readily
undertook
this
task
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
forthwith

to

with
the

for

;
dwelling
meanwhile
on
the
magical

of
a
few
finishing

from

hand

a

;
which
,
indeed
,
as
some

said
(
and
these
were

old

again
!
)
was
unquestionably

,
and

;
as
there

cases
on
record
in
which
the

introduction
of
an
additional

,
or

,
or

-
a
-

,

,
had
made

a
pupil
Mr

's

,
and
had

substantial

into

's

.
<EOS>
But
such
is
the
magic
of

,
which
changes
all
it

into

!
   
<EOS>
"
When

,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
Thomas
Pinch
will

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
There

,

of

.
 
<EOS>
If

my

,

say

<EOS>

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,
in
which

he
remained
all

;
so
that
Tom
,
after
trying

once

with

,
felt
a
delicacy
in
obtruding
himself
upon
his

,
and
said
no

.
   
<EOS>
He
would
not

had

,
had

been
ever
so

;
for

Mr
Pecksniff
called

and

,
until

;
and

Miss
Charity
called

to

and

;
and
then
Miss
Mercy
sent

to

mend

;
and
then

the
fullest

for

;
and

;

see

to
the

-

at

;
and
then
to
mind

till

.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,

day
's
work
would
have

a

for

,
but

good
-
will
made

;
and

,

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

about

,
"
that
I

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

,

Pecksniff

.
 
<EOS>
I

Westlock

,

Pecksniff

.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,

where

,

.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Ruth
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom

seemed

for

,
but
he

,

:
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,
I
do

think
,

(

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

!
 
<EOS>
Such

,

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,

!
<EOS>
and
he
a

Pecksniff
's

,

<EOS>
Here
he
comes
while
the

on

lips
<EOS>
"
said

;
"
walking
down

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
As

<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>
"
For

,

.
 
<EOS>
Yes

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Make

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
He

that
Tom

<EOS>
(

,

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
the
fright
!
 
<EOS>
The
bare
idea
of
a
Miss
Pinch
!
 
<EOS>
Good
heavens
!
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
greatly

to

so

,
for
he
took

as
a
token
of
their

,
and
good

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
he
laughed
too
and
rubbed
his
hands
and
wished
them
a
pleasant

and
safe

,
and
was
quite
brisk
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when

had
rolled
away
with

olive
-

in
the
boot
and
the
family
of
doves
inside
,
he
stood

and

;
so
much

by

of

,
that

was
quite

,
for

,
of
Martin
Chuzzlewit
,
who

against

-

,
and
who
after
disposing
of
his
fair
charge
had

from

.
   
<EOS>
The

which

upon

of

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

,
as
by

,
and
moved

-

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
melancholy
you
are
!
"
said
Tom
;
"
what
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
worth
speaking
of
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
little
more
than
was
the
matter
yesterday
,
and
much
more
<EOS>
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm

,
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
cried

,
"
now

know
I
am
in
capital
spirits
today
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
It

kind

,
John
,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"
said

;
"
I

would
have

do

,

,
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just

to

,
"
Tom

;
"
but
no
,
he
keeps

,
and

,
"
My
dear
Pinch
,
I
often

,
"
and
all

of
kind

of

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
must

-

,
"
said
Martin
,
somewhat

:
"
because
he
ca
n't
mean
that
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose

can
,
eh
?
"
said
Tom
,
looking

in
his
companion
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
says
so
to
please
me
,
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
is
it
likely
,
"
rejoined
Martin
,
with
greater
earnestness
,
"
that
a
young
man
newly
escaped
from
this
kennel
of
a
place
,
and
fresh
to
all
the
delights
of
being
his
own
master
in
London
,
can
have
much
leisure
or
inclination
to
think
favourably
of
anything
or
anybody
he
has
left
behind
him
here
?
 
<EOS>
I
put
it
to
you
,
<EOS>
Pinch
,
is
it
natural
?
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
short
reflection
,
Mr
Pinch
replied
,
in
a
more
subdued
tone
,
that
to
be
sure
it
was
unreasonable
to
expect
any
such
thing
,
and
that
he
had
no
doubt
Martin
knew
best
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
I
know
best
,
"
Martin
observed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
feel
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
mildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
said
so
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
had
made
this
rejoinder
,
they
fell
into
a
blank
silence
again
,
which
lasted
until
they
reached
home
;
by
which
time
it
was
dark
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Miss
Charity
Pecksniff
,
in
consideration
of
the
inconvenience
of
carrying
them
with
her
in
the
coach
,
and
the
impossibility
of
preserving
them
by
artificial
means
until
the
family
's
return
,
had
set
forth
,
in
a
couple
of
plates
,
the
fragments
of
yesterday
's
feast
.
 
<EOS>
In
virtue
of
which
liberal
arrangement
,
they
had
the
happiness
to
find
awaiting
them
in
the
parlour
two
chaotic
heaps
of
the
remains
of
last
night
's
pleasure
,
consisting
of
certain
filmy
bits
of
oranges
,
some
mummied
sandwiches
,
various
disrupted
masses
of
the
geological
cake
,
and
several
entire
captain
's
biscuits
.
 
<EOS>
That
choice
liquor
in
which
to
steep
these
dainties
might
not
be
wanting
,
the
remains
of
the
two
bottles
of
currant
wine
had
been
poured
together
and
corked
with
a
curl
-
paper
;
so
that
every
material
was
at
hand
for
making
quite
a
heavy
night
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
Chuzzlewit
beheld
these
roystering
preparations
with
infinite
contempt
,
and
stirring
the
fire
into
a
blaze
(
to
the
great
destruction
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
coals
)
,
sat
moodily
down
before
it
,
in
the
most
comfortable
chair
he
could
find
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
might
the
better
squeeze
himself
into
the
small
corner
that
was
left
for
him
,
Mr
Pinch
took
up
his
position
on
Miss
Mercy
Pecksniff
's
stool
,
and
setting
his
glass
down
upon
the
hearthrug
and
putting
his
plate
upon
his
knees
,
began
to
enjoy
himself
.
   
<EOS>
If
Diogenes
coming
to
life
again
could
have
rolled
himself
,
tub
and
all
,
into
Mr
Pecksniff
's
parlour
and
could
have
seen
Tom
Pinch
as
he
sat
on
Mercy
Pecksniff
's
stool
with
his
plate
and
glass
before
him
he
could
not
have
faced
it
out
,
though
in
his
surliest
mood
,
but
must
have
smiled
good
-
temperedly
.
 
<EOS>
The
perfect
and
entire
satisfaction
of
Tom
;
his
surpassing
appreciation
of
the
husky
sandwiches
,
which
crumbled
in
his
mouth
like
saw
-
dust
;
the
unspeakable
relish
with
which
he
swallowed
the
thin
wine
by
drops
,
and
smacked
his
lips
,
as
though
it
were
so
rich
and
generous
that
to
lose
an
atom
of
its
fruity
flavour
were
a
sin
;
the
look
with
which
he
paused
sometimes
,
with
his
glass
in
his
hand
,
proposing
silent
toasts
to
himself
;
and
the
anxious
shade
that
came
upon
his
contented
face
when
,
after
wandering
round
the
room
,
exulting
in
its
uninvaded
snugness
,
his
glance
encountered
the
dull
brow
of
his
companion
;
no
cynic
in
the
world
,
though
in
his
hatred
of
its
men
a
very
griffin
,
could
have
withstood
these
things
in
Thomas
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
Some
men
would
have
slapped
him
on
the
back
,
and
pledged
him
in
a
bumper
of
the
currant
wine
,
though
it
had
been
the
sharpest
vinegar
 
---
aye
,
and
liked
its
flavour
too
;
some
would
have
seized
him
by
his
honest
hand
,
and
thanked
him
for
the
lesson
that
his
simple
nature
taught
them
.
 
<EOS>
Some
would
have
laughed
with
,
and
others
would
have
laughed
at
him
;
of
which
last
class
was
Martin
Chuzzlewit
,
who
,
unable
to
restrain
himself
,
at
last
laughed
loud
and
long
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
said
Tom
,
nodding
approvingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Cheer
up
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
capital
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
which
encouragement
young
Martin
laughed
again
;
and
said
,
as
soon
as
he
had
breath
and
gravity
enough
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
such
a
fellow
as
you
are
,
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
you
though
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
it
's
very
likely
you
do
find
me
strange
,
because
I
have
hardly
seen
anything
of
the
world
,
and
you
have
seen
a
good
deal
I
dare
<EOS>
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
for
my
time
of
life
,
"
rejoined
Martin
,
drawing
his

nearer
to
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Deuce
take
it
,
I
must
talk
openly
to
somebody
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
talk
openly
to
you
,
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
take
it
as
being
very
friendly
of
you
,
"
   
"
I
'm
not
in
your
way
,

?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Martin
,
glancing
down
at
Mr
Pinch
,
who
was
by
this
time
looking
at
the
fire
over
his
leg
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
!
"
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
must
know
then
,
to
make
short
of
a
long
story
,
"
said
Martin
,
beginning
with
a
kind

effort
,
as

were
not

to

;
"
that
I
have
been
bred
up
from
childhood
with
great
expectations
,
and
have
always
been
taught
to
believe
that
I
should
be
,
one
day
,
very
rich
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
should
have
been
,
but
for
certain
brief
reasons
which
I
am
going
to
tell
you
,
and
which
have
led
to
my
being
disinherited
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
your
father
?
"
inquired
Mr
Pinch
,
with
open

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
my
grandfather
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
no
parents
these
many
years
.
<EOS>
Scarcely
within
my
remembrance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Neither
have
I
,
"
said
Tom
,
touching
the
young
man
's
hand
with
his
own
and
timidly
