again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
as
to
that
,
you
know
,
Pinch
,
"
pursued
the
other
,
stirring
the
fire
again
,
and
speaking
in
his
rapid
,
off
-
hand

;
"
it
's
all
very
right
and
proper
to
be
fond
of
parents
when
we
have
them
,
and
to
bear
them
in
remembrance
after
they
're
dead
,
if
you
have

known
anything
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
I
never
did
know
anything
about
mine
personally
,
you
know
,
why
,
I
ca
n't
be
expected
to
be
very
sentimental
about
'em
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
not
;
that
's
the
truth
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
was
just
then
looking
thoughtfully
at
the
bars
.
 
<EOS>
But
on
his
companion
pausing
in
this
place
,
he
started
,
and
said
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
of
course
"
---
and
composed
himself
to
listen
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
word
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
I
have
been
bred
and
reared
all
my
life
by
this
grandfather
of
whom
I
have
just
spoken
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
he
has
a
great
many
good
points
---
there
is
no
doubt
about
that
;
I
'll
not
disguise
the

you
---
but
he
has
two
very
great

,
which
are
the
staple
of
his

.
 
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
he
has
the
most
confirmed
obstinacy
of
character
you
ever
met
with
in
any
human
creature
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
second
,
he
is
most
abominably
selfish
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
indeed
?
"
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
those
two
respects
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
there
never
was
such
a
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
heard
from
those
who
know
,
that
they
have
been
,
time
out
of
mind
,
the
failings
of
our
family
;
and
I
believe
there
's
some
truth
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't
say
of
my
own
knowledge
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
have
to
do
,
you
know
,
is
to
be
very

that
they
have
n't
descended
to
me
,
and
,
to
be
very
careful
that
I
do
n't
contract
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
proper
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
resumed
Martin
,
stirring
the
fire
once
more
,
and
drawing
his
chair
still
closer
to
it
,
"
his
selfishness
makes
him
exacting
,
you
see
;
and
his
obstinacy
makes
him
resolute
in
his
exactions
.
 
<EOS>
The
consequence
is
that
he
has
always
exacted
a
great
deal
from
me
in
the
way
of
respect
,
and
submission
,
and
self
-
denial
when
his
wishes
were
in
question
,
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
borne
a
great
deal
from
him
,
because
I
have
been
under
obligations
to
him
(
if
one
can
ever
be
said
to
be
under

to
one
's
own
grandfather
)
,
and
because
I
have
been
really
attached
to
him
;
but
we
have
had
a
great
many
quarrels
for
all
that
,
for
I
could
not
accommodate
myself
to
his
ways
very
often
---
not
out
of
the
least

to
myself
,
you
understand
,
but
because
---
"
he
stammered
here
,
and
was
rather
at
a
loss
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
being
about
the
worst
man
in
the
world
to
help
anybody
out
of
a
difficulty
of
this
sort
,
said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
as
you
understand
me
,
"
resumed
Martin
,
quickly
,
"
I
need
n't
hunt
for
the
precise
expression
I
want
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
come
to
the
cream
of
my
story
,
and
the
occasion
of
my
being
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
love
,
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
looked
up
into
his
face
with
increased
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
I
am
in
love
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
in
love
with
one
of
the
most
beautiful
girls
the
sun
ever
shone
upon
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
is
wholly
and
entirely
dependent
upon
the
pleasure
of
my
grandfather
;
and
if
he
were
to
know
that
she
favoured
my
passion
,
she
would
lose
her
home
and
everything
she
possesses
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
very
selfish
in
THAT
love
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Selfish
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
acted
nobly
.
 
<EOS>
To
love
her
as
I
am
sure
you
do
,
and
yet
in
consideration
for
her
state
of
dependence
,
not
even
to
disclose
---
"
   
"
What
are
you
talking
about
,
Pinch
?
"
said
Martin
pettishly
:
"
do
n't
make
yourself
ridiculous
,
my

!
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
not
disclosing
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
answered
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
meant
that
,
or
I
would
n't
have
said
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
did
n't
tell
her
I
loved
her
,
where
would
be
the
use
of
my
being
in

?
"
said
Martin
:
"
unless
to
keep
myself
in
a
perpetual

of
worry
and

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
true
,
"
Tom

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
can
guess
what
SHE
said
when
you
told
her
,
"
he
added
,
glancing
at
Martin
's
handsome
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
not
exactly
,
Pinch
,
"
he
rejoined
,
with
a

;
"
because
she
has
some
girlish

about
duty
and

,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
,
which
are
rather
hard
to
fathom
;
but
in
the
main

are
right
.
 
<EOS>
Her
heart
was
mine
,
I
found
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
what
I
supposed
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
natural
!
"
<EOS>
and
,
in
his
great
satisfaction
,
he
took
a
long
sip
out
of
his
wine
-
glass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Although
I
had
conducted
myself
from
the
first
with
the
utmost
circumspection
,
"
pursued
Martin
,
"
<EOS>
I
had
not
managed
matters
so
well
but
that
my
grandfather
,
who
is
full
of
jealousy
and
distrust
,
suspected
me
of
loving
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
to
her
,
but
straightway
attacked
me
in
private
,
and
charged
me
with
designing
to
corrupt
the
fidelity
to
himself
(
there
you
observe
his
selfishness
)
,
of
a
young
creature
whom
he
had
trained
and
educated
to
be
his
only
disinterested
and
faithful
companion
,
when
he
should
have
disposed
of
me
in
marriage
to
his
heart
's
content
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
that
,
I
took
fire
immediately
,
and
told
him
that
with
his
good
leave
I
would
dispose
of
myself
in
marriage
,
and
would
rather
not
be
knocked
down
by
him
or
any
other
auctioneer
to
any
bidder
whomsoever
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
opened
his
eyes
wider
,
and
looked
at
the
fire
harder
than
he
had
done
yet
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
sure
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
that
this
nettled
him
,
and
that
he
began
to
be
the
very
reverse
of
complimentary
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Interview
succeeded
interview
;
words
engendered
words
,
as
they
always
do
;
and
the
upshot
of
it
was
,
that
I
was
to
renounce
her
,
or
be
renounced
by
him
.
 
<EOS>
Now
you
must
bear
in
mind
,
Pinch
,
that
I
am
not
only
desperately
fond
of
her
(
<EOS>
for
though
she
is
poor
,
her
beauty
and
intellect
would
reflect
great
credit
on
anybody
,
I
do
n't
care
of
what
pretensions
who
might
become
her
husband
)
,
but
that
a
chief
ingredient
in
my
composition
is
a
most
determined
---
"
   
"
Obstinacy
,
"
suggested
Tom
in
perfect
good
faith
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
suggestion
was
not
so
well
received
as
he
had
expected
;
for
the
young
man
immediately
rejoined
,
with
some
irritation
,
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
fellow
you
are
,
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
thought
you
wanted
a
word
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
want
that
word
,
"
he
rejoined
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
obstinacy
was
no
part
of
my
character
,
did
I
not
?
 
<EOS>
I
was
going
to
say
,
if
you
had
given
me
leave
,
that
a
chief
ingredient
in
my
composition
is
a
most
determined
firmness
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
cried
Tom
,
screwing
up
his
mouth
,
and
nodding
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
;
I
see
!
"
   
"
<EOS>
And
being
firm
,
"
pursued
Martin
,
"
of
course
I
was
not
going
to
yield
to
him
,
or
give
way
by
so
much
as
the
thousandth
part
of
an
inch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
the
more
he
urged
,
the
more
I
was
determined
to
oppose
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
"
rejoined
Martin
,
throwing
himself
back
in
his
chair
,
with
a
careless
wave
of
both
hands
,
as
if
the
subject
were
quite
settled
,
and
nothing
more
could
be
said
about
it
---
"
There
is
an
end
of
the
matter
,
and
here
am
I
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
sat
staring
at
the
fire
for
some
minutes
with
a
puzzled
look
,
such
as
he
might
have
assumed
if
some
uncommonly
difficult
conundrum
had
been
proposed
,
which
he
found
it
impossible
to
guess
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
said
:
   
"
Pecksniff
,
of
course
,
you
had
known
before
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
by
name
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
had
never
seen
him
,
for
my
grandfather
<EOS>
kept
not
only
himself
but
me
,
aloof
from
all
his
relations
.
 
<EOS>
But
our
separation
took
place
in
a
town
in
the
adjoining
country
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
place
I
came
to
Salisbury
,
and
there
I
saw
Pecksniff
's
advertisement
,
which
I
answered
,
having
always
had
some
natural
taste
,
I
believe
,
in
the
matters
to
which
it
referred
,
and
thinking
it
might
suit
me
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
I
found
it
to
be
his
,
I
was
doubly
bent
on
coming
to
him
if
possible
,
on
account
of
his
being
---
"
   
"
Such
an
excellent
man
,
"
interposed
Tom
,
rubbing
his
hands
:
"
<EOS>
so
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
quite
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
not
so
much
on
that
account
,
if
the
truth
must
be
spoken
,
"
returned
Martin
,
"
as
because
my
grandfather
has
an
inveterate
dislike
to
him
,
and
after
the
old
man
's
arbitrary
treatment
of
me
,
I
had
a
natural
desire
to
run
as
directly
counter
to
all
his
opinions
as
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
As
I
said
before
,
here
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
My
engagement
with
the
young
lady
I
have
been
telling
you
about
is
likely
to
be
a
tolerably
long
one
;
for
neither
her
prospects
nor
mine
are
very
bright
;
and
of
course
I
shall
not
think
of
marrying
until
I
am
well
able
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
never
do
,
you
know
,
for
me
to
be
plunging
myself
into
poverty
and
shabbiness
and
love
in
one
room
up
three
pair
of
stairs
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
say
nothing
of
her
,
"
remarked
Tom
Pinch
,
in
a
low
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
so
,
"
rejoined
Martin
,
rising
to
warm
his
back
,
and
leaning
against
the
chimney
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
say
nothing
of
her
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
of
course
it
's
not
very
hard
upon
her
to
be
obliged
to
yield
to
the
necessity
of
the
case
;
first
,
because
she
loves
me
very
much
;
and
secondly
,
because
I
have
sacrificed
a
great
deal
on
her
account
,
and
might
have
done
much
better
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
long
time
before
Tom
said
"
Certainly
;
"
so
long
,
that
he
might
have
taken
a
nap
in
the
interval
,
but
he
did
say
it
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
there
is
one
odd
coincidence
connected
with
this
love
-
story
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
which
brings
it
to
an
end
.
 
<EOS>
You
remember
what
you
told
me
last
night
as
we
were
coming
here
,
about
your
pretty
visitor
in
the
church
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
I
do
,
"
said
Tom
,
rising
from
his
stool
,
and
seating
himself
in
the
chair
from
which
the
other
had
lately
risen
,
that
he
might
see
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
Undoubtedly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
she
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
knew
what
you
were
going
to
say
,
"
cried
Tom
,
looking
fixedly
at
him
,
and
speaking
very
softly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
tell
me
so
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
she
,
"
repeated
the
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
what
I
have
heard
from
Pecksniff
,
I
have
no
doubt
that
she
came
and
went
with
my
grandfather
.
<EOS>
---
Do
n't
you
drink
too
much
of
that
sour
wine
,
or
you
'll
have
a
fit
of
some
sort
,
Pinch
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
very
wholesome
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
Tom
,
setting
down
the
empty
glass
he
had
for
some
time
held
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
that
was
she
,
was
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
nodded
assent
;
and
adding
,
with
a
restless
impatience
,
that
if
he
had
been
a
few
days
earlier
he
would
have
seen
her
;
and
that
now
she
might
be
,
for
anything
he
knew
,
hundreds
of
miles
away
;
threw
himself
,
after
a
few
turns
across
the
room
,
into
a
chair
,
and
chafed
like
a
spoilt
child
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
's
heart
was
very
tender
,
and
he
could
not
bear
to
see
the
most
indifferent
person
in
distress
;
still
less
one
who
had
awakened
an
interest
in
him
,
and
who
regarded
him
(
either
in
fact
,
or
as
he
supposed
)
with
kindness
,
and
in
a
spirit
of
lenient
construction
.
<EOS>
Whatever
his
own
thoughts
had
been
a
few
moments
before
---
and
to
judge
from
his
face
they
must
have
been
pretty
serious
---
he
dismissed
them
instantly
,
and
gave
his
young
friend
the
best
counsel
and
comfort
that
occurred
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
will
be
well
in
time
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
have
no
doubt
;
and
some
trial
and
adversity
just
now
will
only
serve
to
make
you
more
attached
to
each
other
in
better
days
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
always
read
that
the
truth
is
so
,
and
I
have
a
feeling
within
me
,
which
tells
me
how
natural
and
right
<EOS>
it
is
that
it
should
be
.
 
<EOS>
That
never
ran
smooth
yet
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
a
smile
which
,
despite
the
homeliness
of
his
face
,
was
pleasanter
to
see
than
many
a
proud
beauty
's
brightest
glance
;
"
what
never
ran
smooth
yet
,
can
hardly
be
expected
to
change
its
character
for
us
;
so
we
must
take
it
as
we
find
it
,
and
fashion
it
into
the
very
best
shape
we
can
,
by
patience
and
good
-
humour
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
power
at
all
;
I
need
n't
tell
you
that
;
but
I
have
an
excellent
will
;
and
if
I
could
ever
be
of
use
to
you
,
in
any
way
whatever
,
how
very
glad
I
should
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Martin
,
shaking
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
good
fellow
,
upon
my
word
,
and
speak
very
kindly
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
you
know
,
"
he
added
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
as
he
drew
his
chair
towards
the
fire
again
,
"
I
should
not
hesitate
to
avail
myself
of
your
services
if
you
could
help
me
at
all
;
but
mercy
on
us
!
"
<EOS>
---
Here
he
rumpled
his
hair
impatiently
with
his
hand
,
and
looked
at
Tom
as
if
he
took
it
rather
ill
that
he
was
not
somebody
else
---
"
you
might
as
well
be
a
toasting
-
fork
or
a
frying
-
pan
,
Pinch
,
for
any
help
you
can
render
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Except
in
the
inclination
,
"
said
Tom
,
gently
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
to
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
I
meant
that
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
If
inclination
went
for
anything
,
I
should
n't
want
help
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
what
you
may
do
,
though
,
if
you
will
,
and
at
the
present
moment
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
that
?
"
demanded
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Read
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
delighted
,
"
cried
Tom
,
catching
up
the
candle
with
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse
my
leaving
you
in
the
dark
a
moment
,
and
I
'll
fetch
a
book
directly
.
 
<EOS>
What
will
you
like
?
 
<EOS>
Shakespeare
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
replied
his
friend
,
yawning
and
stretching
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
tired
with
the
bustle
of
to
-
day
,
and
the
novelty
of
everything
about
me
;
and
in
such
a
case
,
there
's
no
greater
luxury
in
the
world
,
I
think
,
than
being
read
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
mind
my
going
to
sleep
,
if
I
can
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
!
"
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
begin
as
soon
as
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
leave
off
when
you
see
me
getting
drowsy
(
unless
you
feel
tired
)
,
for
it
's
pleasant
to
wake
gradually
to
the
sounds
again
.
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
try
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
never
tried
that
,
"
said
Tom
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
You
can
,
you
know
,
one
of
these
days
when
we
're
both
in
the
right
humour
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
leaving
me
in
the
dark
.
 
<EOS>
Look
sharp
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
lost
no
time
in
moving
away
;
and
in
a
minute
or
two
returned
with
one
of
the
precious
volumes
from
the
shelf
beside
his
bed
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
had
in
the
meantime
made
himself
as
comfortable
as
circumstances
would
permit
,
by
constructing
before
the
fire
a
temporary
sofa
of
three
chairs
with
Mercy
's
stool
for
a
pillow
,
and
lying
down
at
full
-
length
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
too
loud
,
please
,
"
he
said
to
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
sure
you
're
not
cold
"
   
"
Not
at
all
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
ready
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
accordingly
,
after
turning
over
the
leaves
of
his
book
with
as
much
care
as
if
they
were
living
and
highly
cherished
creatures
,
made
his
own
selection
,
and
began
to
read
.
 
<EOS>
Before
he
had
completed
fifty
lines
his
friend
was
snoring
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
softly
,
as
he
stretched
out
his
head
to
peep
at
him
over
the
backs
of
the
chairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
very
young
to
have
so
much
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
How
trustful
and
generous
in
him
to
bestow
all
this
confidence
in
me
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
was
she
<EOS>
,
was
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
suddenly
remembering
their
compact
,
he
took
up
the
poem
at
the
place
where
he
had
left
off
,
and
went
on
reading
;
always
forgetting
to
snuff
the
candle
,
until
its
wick
looked
like
a
mushroom
.
 
<EOS>
He
gradually
became
so
much
interested
,
that
he
quite
forgot
to
replenish
the
fire
;
and
was
only
reminded
of
his
neglect
by
Martin
Chuzzlewit
starting
up
after
the
lapse
of
an
hour
or
so
,
and
crying
with
a
shiver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
nearly
out
,
I
declare
!
 
<EOS>
No
wonder
I
dreamed
of
being
frozen
.
 
<EOS>
Do
call
for
some
coals
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
fellow
you
are
,
Pinch
!
"
    
Chapter
07
.
<EOS>
In
which
Mr
Chevy
Slyme
asserts
the
independence
of
his
spirit
;
and
the
Blue
Dragon
loses
a
limb
 
Martin
began
to
work
at
the
grammar
-
school
next
morning
,
with
so
much
vigour
and
expedition
,
that
Mr
Pinch
had
new
reason
to
do
homage
to
the
natural
endowments
of
that
young
gentleman
,
and
to
acknowledge
his
infinite
superiority
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
pupil
received
Tom
's
compliments
very
graciously
;
and
having
by
this
time
conceived
a
real
regard
for
him
,
in
his
own
peculiar
way
,
predicted
that
they
would
always
be
the
very
best
of
friends
,
and
that
neither
of
them
,
he
was
certain
(
but
particularly
Tom
)
,
would
ever
have
reason
to
regret
the
day
on
which
they
became
acquainted
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
was
delighted
to
hear
him
say
this
,
and
felt
so
much
flattered
by
his
kind
assurances
of
friendship
and
protection
,
that
he
was
at
a
loss
how
to
express
the
pleasure
they
afforded
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
indeed
it
may
be
observed
of
this
friendship
,
such
as
it
was
,
that
it
had
within
it
more
likely
materials
of
endurance
than
many
a
sworn
brotherhood
that
has
been
rich
in
promise
;
for
so
long
as
the
one
party
found
a
pleasure
in
patronizing
,
and
the
other
in
being
patronised
(
which
was
in
the
very
essence
of
their
respective
characters
)
<EOS>
,
it
was
of
all
possible
events
among
the
least
probable
,
that
the
twin
demons
,
Envy
and
Pride
,
would
ever
arise
between
them
.
<EOS>
So
in
very
many
cases
of
friendship
,
or
what
passes
for
it
,
the
old
axiom
is
reversed
,
and
like
clings
to
unlike
more
than
to
like
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
both
very
busy
on
the
afternoon
succeeding
the
family
's
departure
---
Martin
with
the
grammar
-
school
,
and
Tom
in
balancing
certain
receipts
of
rents
,
and
deducting
Mr
Pecksniff
's
commission
from
the
same
;
in
which
abstruse
employment
he
was
much
distracted
by
a
habit
his
new
friend
had
of
whistling
aloud
while
he
was
drawing
---
when
they
were
not
a
little
startled
by
the
unexpected
obtrusion
into
that
sanctuary
of
genius
,
of
a
human
head
which
,
although
a
shaggy
and
somewhat
alarming
head
in
appearance
,
smiled
affably
upon
them
from
the
doorway
,
in
a
manner
that
was
at
once
waggish
,
conciliatory
,
and
expressive
of
approbation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
industrious
myself
,
gents
both
,
"
said
the
head
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
know
how
to
appreciate
that
quality
in
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
I
may
turn
grey
and
ugly
,
if
it
is
n't
in
my
opinion
,
next
to
genius
,
one
of
the
very

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

,
I
am

to

friend
Pecksniff
for

to

as

.
 
<EOS>
You
remind

of
Whittington
,
afterwards
thrice
Lord
Mayor
of
London
.
 
<EOS>
I
give
you
my
unsullied
word
of
honour
,
that
you
very
strongly
remind
me
of
that
historical
character
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
pair
of
Whittingtons
,
gents
,
without
the

;
which

,

I

not

<EOS>
My

Tigg
;
how

?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Pinch

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

The

"

quite

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
With

rapped

twice

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr

with

that

to

,
checked

off
,

,
by

.
 
<EOS>
When

to
a

for

,

<EOS>
"
Then

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
at
this

in

,

,

,

,

will

.
 
<EOS>
There

actually

,
at

Blue
Dragon
in

---
an
ale
-

,
observe
;
a

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
!
<EOS>
ha
!
 
<EOS>
For

.
 
<EOS>
I

---
 
for

bill
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
"

,
"
we

Fox
's

,

,

;

being

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

cried
Mark
,
with
a
grin
;
"
why
no
,
sir
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
little
credit
---
not
much
---
in
being
jolly
,
when
such
fellows
as
him
is
a
-
going
about
like
roaring
lions
;
if
there
is
any
breed
of
lions
,
at
least
,
as
is
all
roar
and
mane
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
there
between
him
and
Mrs
Lupin
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
there
's
a
score
between
him
and
Mrs
Lupin
.
<EOS>
And
I
think
Mrs
Lupin
lets
him
and
his
friend
off
very
easy
in
not
charging
'em
double
prices
for
being
a
disgrace
to
the
Dragon
.
<EOS>
That
's
my
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
any
such
Peter
the
Wild
Boy
as
him
in
my
house
,
sir
,
not
if
I
was
paid
race
-
week
prices
for
it
.
<EOS>
He
's
enough
to
turn
the
very
beer
in
the
casks
sour
with
his
looks
;
he
is
!
<EOS>
So
he
would
,
if
it
had
judgment
enough
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
answering
my
question
,
you
know
,
Mark
,
"
observed
Mr
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
I
do
n't
know
as
there
's
much
to
answer
further
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
Him
and
his
friend
goes
and
stops
at
the
Moon
and
Stars
till
they
've
run
a
bill
there
;
and
then
comes
and
stops
with
us
and
does
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
The
running
of
bills
is
common
enough
Mr
Pinch
;
it
an't
that
as
we
object
to
;
it
's
the
ways
of
this
chap
.
<EOS>
Nothing
's
good
enough
for
him
;
all
the
women
is
dying
for
him
he
thinks
,
and
is
overpaid
if
he
winks
at
'em
;
and
all
the
men
was
made
to
be
ordered
about
by
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
not
being
aggravation
enough
,
he
says
this
morning
to
me
,
in
his
usual
captivating
way
,
"
We
're
going
to
-
night
,
my
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
,
sir
?
"
says
I.
 
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
'd
like
the
bill
got
ready
,
sir
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
my
man
<EOS>
,
"
he
says
;
"
you
need
n't
mind
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
give
Pecksniff
orders
to
see
to
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
reply
to
which
,
the
Dragon
makes
answer
,
"
Thankee
,
sir
,
you
're
very
kind
to
honour
us
so
far
,
but
as
we
do
n't
know
any
particular
good
of
you
,
and
you
do
n't
travel
with
luggage
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
an't
at
home
(
which
perhaps
you
may
n't
happen
to
be
aware
of
,
sir
)
,
we
should
prefer
something
more
satisfactory
;
"
and
that
's
where
the
matter
stands
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
ask
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
pointing
,
in

,
to
Mr
Tigg
,
with

,
"
any
lady

,
possessing
ordinary
strength
of
mind
,
to
say
whether
he
's
a
disagreeable
-
looking
chap
or
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
inquire
,
"
said
Martin
,
interposing
between
this
candid
speech
and
the
delivery
of
some
blighting

by
Mr
Tigg
,
"
what
the
amount
of
this
debt
may
be
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
point
of
money
,
sir
,
very
little
,
"
answered
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
Only
just
turned
of
three
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
an't
<EOS>
that
;
it
's
the
---
"
   
"
Yes
,
yes
,
you
told
us
so
before
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pinch
,
a
word
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Tom
,
retiring
with
him
to
a
corner
of
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
simply
---
I
am
ashamed

say
---
that
this
Mr
Slyme
is
a

,
of

never
heard
anything

;
and
that

do

here

,
and
think

would

cheaply
got

,

,
for
three

.
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
enough
money
to
pay

bill
,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
shook
his
head
to
an

that
left
no

of
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
for
I
am
poor
too
;
and

case

had
had

,
I
'd

.
 
<EOS>
But
if
we
told
this

we
would
see
her
paid
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
that
would
answer
the
same
purpose
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
yes
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
knows
me
,
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
let
us
go
down
at
once
and
tell
her
so
;
for
the
sooner
we
are
rid
of
their
company
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
As
you
have
conducted
the
conversation
with
this
gentleman
hitherto
,
perhaps
you
'll
tell
him
what
we
purpose
doing
;
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
complying
,
at
once
imparted
the
intelligence
to
Mr
Tigg
,
who
shook
him
warmly
by
the
hand
in
return
,
assuring
him
that
his
faith
in
anything
and
everything
was
again
restored
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
so
much
,
he
said
,
for
the
temporary
relief
of
this
assistance
that
he
prized
it
,
as
for
its
vindication
of
the
high
principle
that
Nature
's
Nobs
felt
with
Nature
's
Nobs
,
and
that
true
greatness
of
soul
sympathized
with
true
greatness
of
soul
,
all
the
world
over
.
<EOS>
It
proved
to
him
,
he
said
,
that
like
him
they
admired
genius
,
even
when
it
was
coupled
with
the
alloy
occasionally
visible
in
the
metal
of
his
friend
Slyme
;
and
on
behalf
of
that
friend
,
he
thanked
them
;
as
warmly
and
heartily
as
if
the
cause
were
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
Being
cut
short
in
these
speeches
by
a
general
move
towards
the
stairs
,
he
took
possession
at
the
street
door
of
the
lapel
of
Mr
Pinch
's
coat
,
as
a
security
against
further
interruption
;
and
entertained
that
gentleman
with
some
highly
improving
discourse
until
they
reached
the
Dragon
,
whither
they
were
closely
followed
by
Mark
and
the
new
pupil
.
   
<EOS>
The
rosy
hostess
scarcely
needed
Mr
Pinch
's
word
as
a
preliminary
to
the
release
of
her
two
visitors
,
of
whom
she
was
glad
to
be
rid
on
any
terms
;
indeed
,
their
brief
detention
had
originated
mainly
with
Mr
Tapley
,
who
entertained
a
constitutional
dislike
to
gentleman
out
-
at
-
elbows
who
flourished
on
false
pretences
;
and
had
conceived
a
particular
aversion
to
Mr
Tigg
and
his
friend
,
as
choice
specimens
of
the
species
.
 
<EOS>
The
business
in
hand
thus
easily
settled
,
Mr
Pinch
and
Martin
would
have
withdrawn
immediately
,
but
for
the
urgent
entreaties
of
Mr
Tigg
that
they
would
allow
him
the
honour
of
presenting
them
to
his
friend
Slyme
,
which
were
so
very
difficult
of
resistance
that
,
yielding
partly
to
these
persuasions
and
partly
to
their
own
curiosity
,
they
suffered
themselves
to
be
ushered
into
the
presence
of
that
distinguished
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
brooding
over
the
remains
of
yesterday
's
decanter
of
brandy
,
and
was
engaged
in
the
thoughtful
occupation
of
making
a
chain
of
rings
on
the
top
of
the
table
with
the
wet
foot
of
his
drinking
-
glass
.
 
<EOS>
Wretched
and
forlorn
as
he
looked
,
Mr
Slyme
had
once
been
in
his
way
,
the
choicest
of
swaggerers
;
putting
forth
his
pretensions
boldly
,
as
a
man
of
infinite
taste
and
most
undoubted
promise
.
 
<EOS>
The
stock
-
in
-
trade
requisite
to
set
up
an
amateur
in
this
department
of
business
is
very
slight
,
and
easily
got
together
;
a
trick
of
the
nose
and
a
curl
of
the
lip
sufficient
to
compound
a
tolerable
sneer
,
being
ample
provision
for
any
exigency
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
an
evil
hour
,
this
off
-
shoot
of
the
Chuzzlewit
trunk
,
being
lazy
,
and
ill
qualified
for
any
regular
pursuit
and
having
dissipated
such
means
as
he
ever
possessed
,
had
formally
established
himself
as
a
professor
of
Taste
for
a
livelihood
;
and
finding
,
too
late
,
that
something
more
than
his
old
amount
of
qualifications
was
necessary
to
sustain
him
in
this
calling
,
<EOS>
had
quickly
fallen
to
his
present
level
,
where
he
retained
nothing
of
his
old
self
but
his
boastfulness
and
his
bile
,
and
seemed
to
have
no
existence
separate
or
apart
from
his
friend
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
so
abject
and
so
pitiful
<EOS>
was
he
---
at
once
so
maudlin
,
insolent
,
beggarly
,
and
proud
---
that
even
his
friend
and
parasite
,
standing
erect
beside
him
,
swelled
into
a
Man
by
contrast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Chiv
,
"
said
Mr
Tigg
,
clapping
him
on
the
back
,
"
my
friend
Pecksniff
not
being
at
home
,
I
have
arranged
our
trifling
piece
of
business
with
Mr
Pinch
and
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
and
friend
,
Mr
Chevy
Slyme
!
<EOS>
Chiv
,
Mr
Pinch
and
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
These
are
agreeable
circumstances
in
which
to
be
introduced
to
strangers
,
"
said
Chevy
Slyme
,
turning
his

Tom
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
most
miserable
man
in
the
world
,
I
believe
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
begged
he
would
n't
mention
it
;
and
finding
him
in
this
condition
,
retired
,
after
an
awkward
pause
,
followed
by
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Tigg
so
urgently
conjured
them
,
by
coughs
and
signs
,
to
remain
in
the
shadow
of
the
door
,
that
they
stopped
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
swear
,
"
cried
Mr
Slyme
,
giving
the
table
an
imbecile
blow
with
his
fist
,
and
then
feebly
leaning
his
head
upon
his
hand
,
while
some
drunken
drops
oozed
from
his
eyes
,
"
that
I
am
the
wretchedest
creature
on
record
.
 
<EOS>
Society
is
in
a
conspiracy
against
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
the
most
literary
man
alive
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
full
of
scholarship
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
full
of
genius
;
I
'm
full
of
information
;
I
'm
full
of
novel
views
on
every
subject
;
yet
look
at
my
condition
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
<EOS>
at
this
moment
obliged
to
two
strangers
for
a
tavern
bill
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
replenished
his
friend
's
glass
,
pressed
it
into
his
hand
,
and
nodded
an
intimation
to
the
visitors
that
they
would
see
him
in
a
better
aspect
immediately
.
   
<EOS>
"
Obliged
to
two
strangers
for
a
tavern
bill
,
eh
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Slyme
,
after
a
sulky
application
to
his
glass
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
pretty
!
 
<EOS>
And
crowds
of
impostors
,
the
while
,
becoming
famous
;
men
who
are
no
more
on
a
level
with
me
than
---
<EOS>
Tigg
,
I
take
you
to
witness
that
I
am
the
most
persecuted
hound
on
the
face
of
the
earth
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
a
whine
,
not
unlike
the
cry
of
the
animal
he
named
,
in
its
lowest
state
of
humiliation
,
he
raised
his
glass
to
his
mouth
again
.
<EOS>
He
found
some
encouragement
in
it
;
for
when
he
set
it
down
he
laughed
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
that
Mr
Tigg
gesticulated
to
the
visitors
once
more
,
and
with
great
expression
,
implying
that
now
the
time
was
come
when
they
would
see
Chiv
in
his
greatness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
,
"
laughed
Mr
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
"
Obliged
to
two
strangers
for
a
tavern
bill
!
 
<EOS>
Yet
I
think
I
've
a
rich
uncle
,
Tigg
,
who
could
buy
up
the
uncles
of
fifty
strangers
!
 
<EOS>
Have
I
,
or
have
I
not
?
 
<EOS>
I
come
of
a
good
family
,
I
believe
!
 
<EOS>
Do
I
,
or
do
I
not
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
a
man
of
common
capacity
or
accomplishments
,
I
think
!
 
<EOS>
Am
I
,
or
am
I
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
American
aloe
of
the
human
race
,
my
dear
Chiv
,
"
said
Mr
Tigg
,
"
which
only
blooms
once
in
a
hundred
years
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
laughed
Mr
Slyme
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Obliged
to
two
strangers
for
a
tavern
bill
!
 
<EOS>
I
obliged
to
two
architect
's
apprentices
.
 
<EOS>
Fellows
who
measure
earth
with
iron
chains
,
and
build
houses
like
bricklayers
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
the
names
of
those
two
apprentices
.
 
<EOS>
How
dare
they
oblige
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
was
quite
lost
in
admiration
of
this
noble
trait
in
his
friend
's
character
;
as
he
made
known
to
Mr
Pinch
in
a
neat
little
ballet
of
action
,
spontaneously
invented
for
the
purpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
let
'em
know
,
and
I
'll
let
all
men
know
,
"
cried
Chevy
Slyme
,
"
that
I
'm
none
of
the
mean
,
grovelling
,
tame
characters
they
meet
with
commonly
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
an
independent
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
heart
that
swells
in
my
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
soul
that
rises
superior
to
base
considerations
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
Chiv
,
Chiv
,
"
murmured
Mr
Tigg
,
"
you
have
a
nobly
independent
nature
,
Chiv
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
go
and
do
your
duty
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Slyme
,
angrily
,
"
and
borrow
money
for
travelling
expenses
;
and
whoever
you
borrow
it
of
<EOS>
,
let
'em
know
that
I
possess
a
haughty
spirit
,
and
a
proud
spirit
,
and
have
infernally
finely
-
touched
chords
in
my
nature
,
which
wo
n't
brook
patronage
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
 
<EOS>
Tell
'em
I
hate
'em
,
and
that
that
's
the
way
I
preserve
my
self
-
respect
;
and
tell
'em
that
no
man
ever
respected

more
than
I
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
might
have
added
that
he
hated
two
sorts
of
men
;
all

who
did

,
and

;
as
in
either

their
position
was
an

to
a
man
of

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
;
for
with
the
apt
closing
words
above
recited
<EOS>
,
Mr
Slyme
;
of
too
haughty
a
stomach
to
work
,
to
beg
,
to
borrow
,
or
to

;
yet
mean
enough
to
be
worked
or
borrowed
,
begged
or
stolen
for
,
by
any

that
would

;
too
insolent
to
lick
the
hand
that
fed
him
in
his
need
,
yet
cur

bite

in

;
with

apt

Mr
Slyme
fell
forward

upon

,
and
so

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"
such

<EOS>
Was

?
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
gents
both

,

<EOS>
Mr

,

such

of

Tapley

as

.
   
<EOS>
In

,

TETE

-

in

<EOS>
In

;

,

<EOS>

;

it

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

-

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

"

---

"

?
"
   
<EOS>
But

;
not

;
Mrs

,
and

---
not
unkindly
,
quite
the

---
what
he

take
?
   
<EOS>
It
is
proverbial
that
there
are
certain
things
which
flesh

blood
can
not
bear
.
 
<EOS>
Such

,

,

,

,

as
,
Mark
's
flesh

concerned

<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Accompanies

thither
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

Mr
Pecksniff
justly
observed
 
---

,

---
 
<EOS>
it

,
that

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
"

"
(

,
"

<EOS>
And

That

"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
The

mankind
when
it
falls
asleep
in
coaches
,
is
to

up

;
to

;
and
its

an

.
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
not

from
the
common

of

found
himself
,
at

end

,
so

,
that

visit

upon

;

in

random

,

of

,
when

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
In

,

vehicle
,
which
was
solemnly
licensed
by
Act
of
Parliament
to
carry
any
six
persons
who
could
be
got
in
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
was
lucky
!
<EOS>
"
whispered
the
old
man
,
when
they
moved
on
again
.
"
<EOS>
And
a
great
stroke
of
policy
in
you
to
observe
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
,
he
,
he
!
 
<EOS>
We
could
n't
have
gone
outside
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
died
of
the
rheumatism
!
"
   
<EOS>
Whether
it
occurred
to
the
dutiful
son
that
he
had
in
some
degree
over
-
reached
himself
by
contributing
to
the
prolongation
of
his
father
's
days
;
or
whether
the
cold
had
effected
his
temper
;
is
doubtful
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
gave
his
father
such
a
nudge
in
reply
,
that
that
good
old
gentleman
was
taken
with
a
cough
which
lasted
for
full
five
minutes
without
intermission
,
and
goaded
Mr
Pecksniff
to
that
pitch
of
irritation
,
that
he
said
at
last
---
and
very
suddenly
:
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
room
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
really
no
room
in
this
coach
for
any
gentleman
with
a
cold
in
his
head
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mine
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
after
a
moment
's
pause
,
"
is
upon
my
chest
,
Pecksniff
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
voice
and
manner
,
together
,
now
that
he
spoke
out
;
the
composure
of
the
speaker
;
the
presence
of
his
son
;
and
his
knowledge
of
Mr
Pecksniff
;
afforded
a
clue
to
his
identity
which
it
was
impossible
to
mistake
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
<EOS>
I
thought
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
returning
to
his
usual
mildness
,
"
that
I
addressed
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
I
find
that
I
address
a
relative
<EOS>
,
Mr
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
and
his
son
Mr
Jonas
---
for
they
,
my
dear
children
,
are
our
travelling
companions
---
will
excuse
me
for
an
apparently
harsh
remark
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
MY
desire
to
wound
the
feelings
of
any
person
with
whom
I
am
connected
in
family
bonds
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
be
a
Hypocrite
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
cuttingly
;
"
but
I
am
not
a
Brute
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pooh
,
pooh
!
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
signifies
that
word
,
Pecksniff
?
 
<EOS>
Hypocrite
!
<EOS>
why
,
we
are
all
hypocrites
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
all
hypocrites
t'other
day
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
felt
that
to
be
agreed
upon
among
us
,
or
I
should
n't
have
called
you
one
.
 
<EOS>
We
should
not
have
been
there
at
all
,
if
we
had
not
been
hypocrites
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
difference
between
you
and
the
rest
was
---
<EOS>
shall
I
tell
you
the
difference
between
you
and
the
rest
now
,
Pecksniff
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
you
please
,
my
good
sir
;
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
annoying
quality
in
YOU
,
is
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
that
you
never
have
a
confederate
or
partner
in
YOUR
juggling
;
you
would
deceive
everybody
,
even
those
who
practise
the
same
art
;
and
have
a
way
with
you
,
as
if
you
---
he
,
he
,
he
!
<EOS>
---
as
if
you
really
believed
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
lay
a
handsome
wager
now
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
if
I
laid
wagers
,
which
I
do
n't
and
never
did
,
that
you
keep
up
appearances
by
a
tacit
understanding
,
even
before
your
own
daughters
here
.
 
<EOS>
Now
I
,
when
I
have
a
business
scheme
in
hand
,
tell
Jonas
what
it
is
,
and
we
discuss
it
openly
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
not
offended
,
Pecksniff
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Offended
,
my
good
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
that
gentleman
,
as
if
he
had
received
the
highest
compliments
that
language
could
convey
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
travelling
to
London
,
Mr
Pecksniff
?
"
asked
the
son
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Mr
Jonas
,
we
are
travelling
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
have
the
pleasure
of
your
company
all
the
way
,
I
trust
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
ecod
,
you
had
better
ask
father
<EOS>
that
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
a
-
going
to
commit
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
greatly
entertained
by
this
retort
.
 
<EOS>
His
mirth
having
subsided
,
Mr
Jonas
gave
him
to
understand
that
himself
and
parent
were
in
fact
travelling
to
their
home
in
the
metropolis
;
and
that
,
since
the
memorable
day
of
the
great
family
gathering
,
they
had
been
tarrying
in
that
part
of
the
country
,
watching
the
sale
of
certain
eligible
investments
,
which
they
had
had
in
their
copartnership
eye
when
they
came
down
;
for
it
was
their
custom
,
Mr
Jonas
said
,
whenever
such
a
thing
was
practicable
,
to
kill
two
birds
with
one
stone
,
and
never
to
throw
away
sprats
,
but
as
bait
for
whales
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
communicated
to
Mr
Pecksniff
these
pithy
scraps
of
intelligence
,
he
said
,
"
That
if
it
was
all
the
same
to
him
,
he
would
turn
him
over
to
father
,
and
have
a
chat
with
the
gals
;
"
and
in
furtherance
of
this
polite
scheme
,
he
vacated
his
seat
adjoining
that
gentleman
,
and
established
himself
in
the
opposite
corner
,
next
to
the
fair
Miss
Mercy
.
   
<EOS>
The
education
of
Mr
Jonas
had
been
conducted
from
his
cradle
on
the
strictest
principles
of
the
main
chance
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
first
word
he
learnt
to
spell
was
"
gain
,
"
and
the
second
(
when
he
got
into
two
syllables
)
,
"
money
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
for
two
results
,
which
were
not
clearly
foreseen
perhaps
by
his
watchful
parent
in
the
beginning
,
his
training
may
be
said
to
have
been
unexceptionable
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
these
flaws
was
,
that
having
been
long
taught
by
his
father
to
over
-
reach
everybody
,
he
had
imperceptibly
acquired
a
love
of
over
-
reaching
that
venerable
monitor
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
,
that
from
his
early
habits
of
considering
everything
as
a
question
of
property
,
he
had
gradually
come
to
look
,
with
impatience
,
on
his
parent
as
a
certain
amount
of
personal
estate
,
which
had
no
right
whatever
to
be
going
at
large
,
but
ought
to
be
secured
in
that
particular
description
of
iron
safe
which
is
commonly
called
a
coffin
,
and
banked
in
the
grave
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
cousin
!
"
said
Mr
Jonas
---
"
Because
we
ARE
cousins
,
you
know
,
a
few
times
removed
<EOS>
---
so
you
're
going
to
London
?
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mercy
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
pinching
her
sister
's
arm
at
the
same
time
,
and
giggling
excessively
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lots
of
beaux
in
London
,
cousin
!
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
slightly
advancing
his
elbow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
!
"
cried
the
young
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
wo
n't
hurt
us
,
sir
,
I
dare
say
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
And
having
given
him
this
answer
with
great
demureness
<EOS>
she
was
so
overcome
by
her
own
humour
,
that
she
was
fain
to
stifle
her
merriment
in
her

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Merry
,
"
cried
that
more
prudent
damsel
,
"
<EOS>
really
I
am
ashamed
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
go
on
so
?
 
<EOS>
You
wild
thing
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
which
Miss
Merry
only
laughed
the
more
,
of
course
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
saw
a
wildness
in
her
eye
,
t'other
day
,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,

Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
're
the
one
to
sit
solemn
!
 
<EOS>
I
say
---
<EOS>
You
were
regularly
prim
,
cousin
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
The
old
-
fashioned
fright
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Merry
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
Cherry
my
dear
,
upon

word
you
must
sit

.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
die

if
he

;
I

,

!
"
 
<EOS>
To

,

as

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
Come

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

that

,
"

Jonas
;
"
she

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
Is

-

,
Pecksniff
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tread

,

?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
foot
next
<EOS>
you
's
the
gouty

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
hesitating
to

,
Mr
Jonas
did

;
at
the

<EOS>
:
   
"
Come
,

,
father
,

you

,
and

,
I

.
<EOS>
---
Do
you
ever
have
the
nightmare
,
cousin
?
"
<EOS>
he

,
with

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
"
answered

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
other

,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
after
a
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
Does
SHE
ever
have
the
nightmare
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replied
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
ask
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
laughs
so
,
"
said
Jonas
;
<EOS>
"
there
's
no
talking
to
her
.
 
<EOS>
Only

she
's
a
-
going
on

!
 
<EOS>
You
're
the
sensible
one
,
cousin
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Charity
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
But
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mercy
is
a
little
giddy
,
"
said
Miss
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
'll
sober
down
in
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
'll
be
a
very
long
time
,
then
,
if
she
does
at
all
,
"
rejoined
her
cousin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
a
little
more
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
of
crowding
you
,
"
said
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
took
it
notwithstanding
;
and
after
one
or
two
remarks
on
the
extreme
heaviness
of
the
coach
,
and
the
number
of
places
it
stopped
at
,
they
fell
into
a
silence
which
remained
unbroken
by
any
member
of
the
party
until
supper
-
time
.
   
<EOS>
Although
Mr
Jonas
conducted
Charity
to
the
hotel
and
sat
himself
beside
her
at
the
board
,
it
was
pretty
clear
that
he
had
an
eye
to
"
the
other
one
"
also
,
for
he
often
glanced
across
at
Mercy
,
and
seemed
to
draw
comparisons
between
the
personal
appearance
of
the
two
,
which
were
not
unfavourable
to
the
superior
plumpness
of
the
younger
sister
.
 
<EOS>
He
allowed
himself
no
great
leisure
for
this
kind
of
observation
,
however
,
being
busily
engaged
with
the
supper
,
which
,
as
he
whispered
in
his
fair
companion
's
ear
,
was
a
contract
business
,
and
therefore
the
more
she
ate
,
the
better
the
bargain
was
.
 
<EOS>
His
father
and
Mr
Pecksniff
,
probably
acting
on
the
same
wise
principle
,
demolished
everything
that
came
within
their
reach
,
and
by
that
means
acquired
a
greasy
expression
of
countenance
,
indicating
contentment
,
if
not
repletion
,
which
it
was
very
pleasant
to
contemplate
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
could
eat
no
more
,
Mr
Pecksniff
and
Mr
Jonas
subscribed
for
two
sixpenny
-
worths
of
hot
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
which
the
latter
gentleman
considered
a
more
politic
order
than
one
shillingsworth
;
there
being
a
chance
of
their
getting
more
spirit
out
of
the
innkeeper
under
this
arrangement
than
if
it
were
all
in
one
glass
.
<EOS>
Having
swallowed
his
share
of
the
enlivening
fluid
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
under
pretence
of
going
to
see
if
the
coach
were
ready
,
went
secretly
to
the
bar
,
and
had
his
own
little
bottle
filled
,
in
order
that
he
might
refresh
himself
at
leisure
in
the
dark
coach
without
being
observed
.
   
<EOS>
These
arrangements
concluded
,
and
the
coach
being
ready
,
they
got
into
their
old
places
and
jogged
on
again
.
 
<EOS>
But
before
he
composed
himself
for
a
nap
,
Mr
Pecksniff
delivered
a
kind
of
grace
after
meat
,
in
these
words
:
   
"
<EOS>
The
process
of
digestion
,
as
I
have
been
informed
by
anatomical
friends
,
is
one
of
the
most
wonderful
works
of
nature
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
how
it
may
be
with
others
,
but
it
is
a
great
satisfaction
to
me
to
know
,
when
regaling
on
my
humble
fare
,
that
I
am
putting
in
motion
the
most
beautiful
machinery
with
which
we
have
any
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
I
really
feel
at
such
times
as
if
I
was
doing
a
public
service
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
have
wound
myself
up
,
if
I
may
employ
such
a
term
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
with
exquisite
tenderness
,
"
and
know
that
I
am
Going
<EOS>
,
I
feel
that
in
the
lesson
afforded
by
the
works
within
me
,
I
am
a
Benefactor
to
my
Kind
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
nothing
could
be
added
to
this
,
nothing
was
said
;
and
Mr
Pecksniff
,
exulting
<EOS>
,
it
may
be
presumed
,
in
his
moral
utility
,
went
to
sleep
again
.
   
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
night
wore
away
in
the
usual
manner
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
and
Old
Anthony
kept
tumbling
against
each
other
and
waking
up
much
terrified
,
or
crushed
their
heads
in
opposite
corners
of
the
coach
and
strangely
tattooed
the
surface
of
their
faces
---
Heaven
knows
how
 
---
in
their
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
The
coach
stopped
and
went
on
,
and
went
on
and
stopped
,
times
out
of
number
.
 
<EOS>
Passengers
got
up
and
passengers
got
down
,
and
fresh
horses
came
and
went
and
came
again
,
with
scarcely
any
interval
between
each
team
as
it
seemed
to
those
who
were
dozing
,
and
with
a
gap
of
a
whole
night
between
every
one
as
it
seemed
to
those
who
were
broad
awake
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
they
began
to
jolt
and
rumble
over
horribly
uneven
stones
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
looking
out
of
window
said
it
was
to
-
morrow
morning
,
and
they
were
there
.
   
<EOS>
Very
soon
afterwards
the
coach
stopped
at
the
office
in
the
city
;
and
the
street
in
which
it
was
situated
was
already
in
a
bustle
,
that
fully
bore
out
Mr
Pecksniff
's
words
about
its
being
morning
,
though
for
any
signs
of
day
yet
appearing
in
the
sky
it
might
have
been
midnight
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
dense
fog
too
;
as
if
it
were
a
city
in
the
clouds
,
which
they
had
been
travelling
to
all
night
up
a
magic
beanstalk
;
and
there
was
a
thick
crust
upon
the
pavement
like
oilcake
;
which
,
one
of
the
outsides
(
mad
,
no
doubt
)
said
to
another
(
his
keeper
,
of
course
)
,
was
Snow
.
   
<EOS>
Taking
a
confused
leave
of
Anthony
and
his
son
,
and
leaving
the
luggage
of
himself
and
daughters
at
the
office
to
be
called
for
afterwards
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
one
of
the
young
ladies
under
each
arm
,
dived
across
the
street
,
and
then
across
other
streets
,
and
so
up
the
queerest
courts
,
and
down
the
strangest
alleys
and
under
the
blindest
archways
,
in
a
kind
of
frenzy
;
now
skipping
over
a
kennel
,
now
running
for
his
life
from
a
coach
and
horses
;
now
thinking
he
had
lost
his
way
,
now
thinking
he
had
found
it
;
now
in
a
state
of
the
highest
confidence
,
now
despondent
to
the
last
degree
,
but
always
in
a
great
perspiration
and
flurry
;
until
at
length
they
stopped
in
a
kind
of
paved
yard
near
the
Monument
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
to
say
,
Mr
Pecksniff
told
them
so
;
for
as
to
anything
they
could
see
of
the
Monument
,
or
anything
else
but
the
buildings
close
at
hand
,
they
might
as
well
have
been
playing
blindman
's
buff
at
Salisbury
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
about
him
for
a
moment
,
and
then
knocked
at
the
door
of
a
very
dingy
edifice
,
even
among
the
choice
collection
of
dingy
edifices
at
hand
;
on
the
front
of
which
was
a
little
oval
board
like
a
tea
-
tray
,
with
this
inscription
---
"
<EOS>
Commercial
Boarding
-
House
:
M
Todgers
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
that
M
Todgers
was
not
up
yet
,
for
Mr
Pecksniff
knocked
twice
and
rang
thrice
,
without
making
any
impression
on
anything
but
a
dog
over
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
a
chain
and
some
bolts
were
withdrawn
with
a
rusty
noise
,
as
if
the
weather
had
made
the
very
fastenings
hoarse
,
and
a
small
boy
with
a
large
red
head
,
and
no
nose
to
speak
of
,
and
a
very
dirty
Wellington
boot
on
his
left
arm
,
appeared
;
who
(
being
surprised
)
rubbed
the
nose
just
mentioned
with
the
back
of
a
shoe
-
brush
,
and
said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Still
a
-
bed
my
man
?
"
asked
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Still
a
-
bed
!
"
replied
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
they
wos
still
a
-
bed
.
<EOS>
They
're
very
noisy
a
-
bed
;
all
calling
for
their
boots
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
was
the
Paper
,
and
wondered
why
you
did
n't
shove
yourself
through
the
grating
as
usual
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
?
"
   
<EOS>
Considering
his
years
,
which
were
tender
,
the
youth
may
be
said
to
have
preferred
this
question
sternly
,
and
in
something
of
a
defiant
manner
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
,
without
taking
umbrage
at
his
bearing
put
a
card
in
his
hand
,
and
bade
him
take
that
upstairs
,
and
show
them
in
the
meanwhile
into
a
room
where
there
was
a
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
Or
if
there
's
one
in
the
eating
parlour
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
I
can
find
it
myself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
he
led
his
daughters
,
without
waiting
for
any
further
introduction
,
into
a
room
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
where
a
table
-
cloth
(
rather
a
tight
and
scanty
fit
in
reference
to
the
table
it
covered
)
was
already
spread
for
breakfast
;
displaying
a
mighty
dish
of
pink
boiled
beef
;
an
instance
of
that
particular
style
of
loaf
which
is
known
to
housekeepers
as
a
slack
-
baked
,
crummy
quartern
;
a
liberal
provision
of
cups
and
saucers
;
and
the
usual
appendages
.
   
<EOS>
Inside
the
fender
were
<EOS>
some
half
-
dozen
pairs
of
shoes
and
boots
,
of
various
sizes
,
just
cleaned
and
turned
with
the
soles
upwards
to
dry
;
and
a
pair
of
short
black
gaiters
,
on
one
of
which
was
chalked
 
---
in
sport
,
it
would
appear
,
by
some
gentleman
who
had
slipped
down
for
the
purpose
,
pending
his
toilet
,
and
gone
up
again
---
"
Jinkins
's
Particular
,
"
while
the
other
exhibited
a
sketch
in
profile
,
claiming
to
be
the
portrait
of
Jinkins
himself
.
   
<EOS>
M
Todgers
's
Commercial
Boarding
-
House
was
a
house
of
that
sort
which
is
likely
to
be
dark
at
any
time
;
but
that
morning
it
was
especially
dark
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
odd
smell
in
the
passage
,
as
if
the
concentrated
essence
of
all
the
dinners
that
had
been
cooked
in
the
kitchen
since
the
house
was
built
,
lingered
at
the
top
of
the
kitchen
stairs
to
that
hour
,
and
like
the
Black
Friar
in
Don
Juan
,
"
would
n't
be
driven
away
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
particular
,
there
was
a
sensation
of
cabbage
;
as
if
all
the
greens
that
had
ever
been
boiled
there
,
were
evergreens
,
and
flourished
in
immortal
strength
.
 
<EOS>
The
parlour
was
wainscoted
,
and
communicated
to
strangers
a
magnetic
and
instinctive
consciousness
of
rats
and
mice
.
 
<EOS>
The
staircase
was
very
gloomy
and
very
broad
,
with
balustrades
so
thick
and
heavy
that
they
would
have
served
for
a
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
sombre
corner
on
the
first
landing
,
stood
a
gruff
old
giant
of
a
clock
,
with
a
preposterous
coronet
of
three
brass
balls
on
his
head
;
whom
few
had
ever
seen
---
none
ever
looked
in
the
face
---
and
who
seemed
to
continue
his
heavy
tick
for
no
other
reason
than
to
warn
heedless
people
from
running
into
him
accidentally
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
not
been
papered
or
painted
,
had
n't
Todgers
's
,
within
the
memory
of
man
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
black
,
begrimed
,
and
mouldy
.
<EOS>
And
,
at
the
top
of
the
staircase
,
was
an
old
,
disjointed
,
rickety
,
ill
-
favoured
skylight
,
patched
and
mended
in
all
kinds
of
ways
,
which
looked
distrustfully
down
at
everything
that
passed
below
,
and
covered
Todgers
's
up
as
if
it
were
a
sort
of
human
cucumber
-
frame
,
and
only
people
of
a
peculiar
growth
were
reared
there
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
and
his
fair
daughters
had
not
stood
warming
themselves
at
the
fire
ten
minutes
,
when
the
sound
of
feet
was
heard
upon
the
stairs
,
and
the
presiding
deity
of
the
establishment
came
hurrying
in
.
   
<EOS>
M
Todgers
was
a
lady
,
rather
a
bony
and
hard
-
featured
lady
,
with
a
row
of
curls
in
front
of
her
head
,
shaped
like
little
barrels
of
beer
;
and
on
the
top
of
it
something
made
of
net
---
you
could
n't
call
it
a
cap
exactly
---
which
looked
like
a
black
cobweb
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
little
basket
on
her
arm
,
and
in
it
a
bunch
of
keys
that
jingled
as
she
came
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
other
hand
she
bore
a
flaming
tallow
candle
,
which
,
after
surveying
Mr
Pecksniff
for
one
instant
by
its
light
,
she
put
down
upon
the
table
,
to
the
end
that
she
might
receive
him
with
the
greater
cordiality
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pecksniff
!
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
Welcome
to
London
!
 
<EOS>
Who
would
have
thought
of
such
a
visit
as
this
,
after
so
---
dear
,
dear
!
---
<EOS>
so
many
years
!
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
DO
,
Mr
Pecksniff
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
well
as
ever
;
<EOS>
and
as
glad
to
see
you
,
as
ever
;
"
Mr
Pecksniff
made
response
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
are
younger
than
you
used
to
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
are
,
I
am
sure
!
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
a
bit
changed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
to
this
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
stretching

towards
the
young

.
 
<EOS>
"
Does
this
make
me
no
older
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
your
daughters
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
lady
,
raising
her

and
clasping

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
Mr
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
Your
second
,
and
her
bridesmaid
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
smiled
complacently
;
shook
his
head
;
and
said
,
"
<EOS>
My
daughters
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
Merely
my
daughters
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
sighed
the
good
lady
,
"
I
must
believe
you
,
for
now
I
look
at
'em
<EOS>
I
think
I
should
have

'em
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
how
happy
your
Pa
has
made

!
"
   
<EOS>
She
hugged
them
both
;
and
being
by
this
time
overpowered
by
her
feelings
or
the

,
jerked
a
little

out
of

little

,
and
applied
the

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
good
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
I
know
the
rules
of
your
establishment
,
and
that
you
only
receive
gentlemen
boarders
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
occurred
to
me
,
when
I
left
home
,
that
perhaps
you
would
give
my
daughters
house
room
,
and
make
an
exception
in
their

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
?
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
ecstatically
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
?
"
   
"
I
may
say
then
,
that
I
was
sure
you
would
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
you
have
a
little
room
of
your
own
,
and
that
they
can
be
comfortable
there
,
without
appearing
at
the
general
table
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
girls
!
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
take
that
liberty
once
more
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
meant
by
this
that
she
must
embrace
them
once
more
,
which
she
accordingly
did
with
great
ardour
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
truth
was
that
the
house
being
full
with
the
exception
of
one
bed
,
which
would
now
be
occupied
by
Mr
Pecksniff
,
she
wanted
time
for
consideration
;
and
so
much
time
too
<EOS>
(
for
it
was
a
knotty
point
how
to
dispose
of
them
)
,
that
even
when
this
second
embrace
was
over
,
she
stood
for
some

gazing
at
the
sisters
,
with
affection
beaming
in
one
eye
,
and
calculation
shining
out
of
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
know
how
to
arrange

,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
at
length
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
sofa
bedstead
in
the
little
third
room
which
opens
from
my
own
parlour
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
dear
girls
!
"
   
<EOS>
Thereupon
she
embraced
them
once
more
,
observing
that
she
could
not
decide
which
was
most
like
their
poor
mother
(
which
was
highly
probable
,
seeing
that
she
had
never
beheld
that
lady
)
,
but
that
she
rather
thought
the
youngest
was
;
and
then
she
said
that
as
the
gentlemen
would
be
down
directly
,
and
the
ladies
were
fatigued
with
travelling
,
would
they
step
into
her
room
at
once
?
   
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
same
floor
;
being
,
in
fact
,
the
back
parlour
;
and
had
,
as
Mrs
Todgers
said
,
the
great
advantage
(
in
London
)
of
not
being
overlooked
;
as
they
would
see
when
the
fog
cleared
off
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
this
a
vainglorious
boast
,
for
it
commanded
at
a
perspective
of
two
feet
,
a
brown
wall
with
a
black
cistern
on
the
top
.
 
<EOS>
The
sleeping
apartment
designed
for
the
young
ladies
was
approached
from
this
chamber
by
a
mightily
convenient
little
door
,
which
would
only
open
when
fallen
against
by
a
strong
person
.
 
<EOS>
It
commanded
from
a
similar
point
of
sight
another
angle
of
the
wall
,
and
another
side
of
the
cistern
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
the
damp
side
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
THAT
is
Mr
Jinkins
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
In

first

these

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Having

;
where

.
   
<EOS>

I
wo

.

?
"
   
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
(

.
)

,

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

.
 
<EOS>
All

!
"
   
<EOS>
Whether

's

,

,
"
all

.
"
    
Chapter
09
.
<EOS>
Town
and
Todger
's
 
<EOS>
Surely
there
never
was
,
in
any
other
borough
,
city
,
or
hamlet
in
the
world
,
such
a
singular
sort
of
a
place
as
Todgers
's
.
 
<EOS>
And
surely
London
,
to
judge
from
that
part
of
it
which
hemmed
Todgers
's
round
and
hustled
it
,
and
crushed
it
,
and
stuck
its
brick
-
and
-
mortar
elbows
into
it
,
and
kept
the
air
from
it
,
and
stood
perpetually
between
it
and
the
light
,
was
worthy
of
Todgers
's
,
and
qualified
to
be
on
terms
of
close
relationship
and
alliance
with
hundreds
and
thousands
of
the
odd
family
to
which
Todgers
's
belonged
.
   
<EOS>
You
could
n't
walk
about
Todgers
's
neighbourhood
,
as
you
could
in
any
other
neighbourhood
.
 
<EOS>
You
groped
your
way
for
an
hour
through
lanes
and
byways
,
and
court
-
yards
,
and
passages
;
and
you
never
once
emerged
upon
anything
that
might
be
reasonably
called
a
street
.
 
<EOS>
A
kind
of
resigned
distraction
came
over
the
stranger
as
he
trod
those
devious
mazes
,
and
,
giving
himself
up
for
lost
,
went
in
and
out
and
round
about
and
quietly
turned
back
again
when
he
came
to
a
dead
wall
or
was
stopped
by
an
iron
railing
,
and
felt
that
the
means
of
escape
might
possibly
present
themselves
in
their
own
good
time
,
but
that
to
anticipate
them
was
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
Instances
were
known
of
people
who
,
being
asked
to
dine
at
Todgers
's
,
had
travelled
round
and
round
for
a
weary
time
,
with
its
very
chimney
-
pots
in
view
;
and
finding
it
,
at
last
,
impossible
of
attainment
,
had
gone
home
again
with
a
gentle
melancholy
on
their
spirits
,
tranquil
and
uncomplaining
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
had
ever
found
Todgers
's
on
a
verbal
direction
,
though
given
within
a
few
minutes
'
walk
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Cautious
emigrants
from
Scotland
or
the
North
of
England
had
been
known
to
reach
it
safely
,
by
impressing
a
charity
-
boy
,
town
-
bred
,
and
bringing
him
along
with
them
;
or
by
clinging
tenaciously
to
the
postman
;
but
these
were
rare
exceptions
,
and
only
went
to
prove
the
rule
that
Todgers
's
was
in
a
labyrinth
,
whereof
the
mystery
was
known
but
to
a
chosen
few
.
   
<EOS>
Several
fruit
-
brokers
had
their
marts
near
Todgers
's
;
and
one
of
the
first
impressions
wrought
upon
the
stranger
's
senses
was
of
oranges
 
---
of
damaged
oranges
---
with
blue
and
green
bruises
on
them
,
festering
in
boxes
,
or
mouldering
away
in

.
 
<EOS>
All
day
long
,
a
stream
of
porters
from
the
wharves
beside
the
river
,
each
bearing
on
his
back
a
bursting
chest
of
oranges
,
poured
slowly
through
the
narrow

;
while
underneath
the
archway
by
the
public
-
house
,
the
knots
of
those
who
rested
and
regaled
within
,
were
piled
from
morning
until
night
.
 
<EOS>
Strange
solitary
pumps
were
found
near
Todgers
's
hiding
themselves
for
the
most
part
in
blind
alleys
,
and
keeping
company
with
fire
-

.
 
<EOS>
There
were
churches
also
by
dozens
,
with
many
a
ghostly
little
churchyard
,
all
overgrown
with
such
straggling
vegetation
as
springs
up
spontaneously
from
damp
,
and
graves
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
In
some

these
dingy
resting
-
places
which
bore
much
the
same
analogy
to
green
churchyards
,
as
the
pots
of
earth
for
mignonette
and
wall
-

in
the
windows
overlooking
them
did
to
rustic
gardens
,
there
were
trees
;
tall
trees
;
still
putting
forth
their
leaves
in
each
succeeding
year
,
with
such
a
languishing
remembrance
of
their
kind
(
so
one
might
fancy
,
looking
on
their
sickly

)
as
birds
in

have
of
theirs
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
paralysed
old

guarded
the
bodies
of
the
dead
at
night
,
year
after
year
,
until
at
last
they
joined
that
solemn

;
and
,
saving
that
they
slept
below
the
ground
a
sounder

than
even
they
had
ever
known
above
it
,
and
were
shut
up
in
another
kind
of
box
,
their
condition
can
hardly
be
said
to
have
undergone
any
material

when
they
,
in
turn
,
were
watched
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
Among
the
narrow

at
hand
,
there
lingered
,
here
<EOS>
and
there
,
an
ancient
doorway
of
carved

,
from
which
,
of
old
,
the
sounds
of
revelry
and
feasting
often
came
;
but
now
these
mansions
,
only
used
for

,
were
dark
and
dull
,
and
,
being
filled
with
wool
,
and
cotton
,
and
the
like
---
such
heavy
merchandise
as
stifles

and
stops

---
had
an
air
of
palpable

about
them
which
,
added
to
their

and

,
made
them
very
grim
.
 
<EOS>
In
like
manner
,
there
were
gloomy
courtyards
in
these
parts
,
<EOS>
into
which
few
but
belated
wayfarers
ever
strayed
,
and
where
vast
bags
and
packs
of
goods
,
upward

downward
bound
,
were
for
ever
dangling
between
heaven
and
earth
from
lofty
cranes
There
were
more
trucks
near
Todgers
's
than
you
would
suppose
whole
city
could
ever
need
;
not
active
trucks
,
but
a
vagabond
race
,
for
ever
lounging
in
the
narrow

before
their
masters
'
doors
and
stopping
up
the
pass
;
so
that
when
a
stray
hackney
-

or

came
that
way
,
they
were
the
cause
of
such
an
uproar
as
enlivened
the
whole
neighbourhood
,
and
made
the
bells
in
the
next
churchtower
vibrate
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
throats
and
maws
of
dark
no
-
thoroughfares
near
Todgers
's
,
individual
wine
-
merchants
and
wholesale

in
grocery
-
ware
had
perfect
little
towns
of
their
own
;
and
,
deep
among
the
foundations
of
these

,
the
ground
was
undermined
and
burrowed
out
into
stables
,
where
cart
-

,
troubled
by
rats
,
might
be
heard
on
a
quiet
Sunday
rattling
their
halters
,
as
disturbed
spirits
in
tales
of
haunted
houses
are
said
to
clank

.
   
<EOS>
To
tell
of
half
the
queer
old
taverns
that
had
a
drowsy
and
secret
existence
near
Todgers
's
,
would
fill
a
goodly
book
;
while
a
second
volume
no
less

might
be

to
an

of
the
quaint

who
frequented

.
<EOS>
These
were
,
in
general
,
ancient
inhabitants
of
that
region
;
born
,
and
bred
there
from
boyhood
.
 
<EOS>
who
had
long
since
become
wheezy
and
asthmatical
,
and
short
of
breath
,
except
in
the
article
of
story
-

;
in
which
respect
they
were
still
marvellously
long
-
winded
.
<EOS>
These
gentry
were
much
opposed
to
steam
and
all
new
-
fangled
ways
,
and
held
ballooning
to
be
sinful
,
and
deplored
the
degeneracy
of
the
times
;
which
that
particular
member
of
each
little
club
who
kept
the
keys
of
the
nearest
church
,
professionally
,
always
attributed
to
the
prevalence
of
dissent
and

;
though
the
major
part
of
the
company
inclined
to
the
belief
that
virtue
went
out
with
hair
-
powder
,
and
that
Old
England
's
greatness
had
decayed
amain
with
barbers
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
Todgers
's
itself
---
speaking
of
it
only
as
a
house
in
that
neighbourhood
,
and
making
no
reference
to
its
merits
as
a
commercial
boarding
establishment
---
it
was
worthy
to
stand
where
it
did
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
one
staircase
-
window
in
it
,
at
the
side
of
the
house
,
on
the
ground
floor
;
which
tradition
said
had
not
been
opened
for
a
hundred
years
at
least
,
and
which
,
abutting
on
an
always
dirty
lane
,
was
so
begrimed
and
coated
with
a
century
's
mud
,
that
no
one
pane
of
glass
could
possibly
fall
out
,
though
all
were
cracked
and
broken
twenty
times
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
grand
mystery
of
Todgers
's
was
the
cellarage
<EOS>
,
approachable
only
by
a
little
back
door
and
a
rusty
grating
;
which
cellarage
within
the
memory
of
man
had
had
no
connection
with
the
house
,
but
had
always
been
the
freehold
property
of
somebody
else
,
and
was
reported
to
be
full
of
wealth
;
though
in
what
shape
---
whether
in
silver
,
brass
,
or
gold
,
or
butts
of
wine
,
or

of
gun
-

---
 
was
matter
of
profound
uncertainty
and
supreme
indifference
to
Todgers
's
and
all
its
inmates
.
   
<EOS>
The
top
of
the
house
was
worthy
of
notice
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
sort
of
terrace
on
the
roof
,
with
posts
and
fragments
of
rotten
lines
,
once
intended
to
dry
clothes
upon
;
and
there
were
two
or
three
tea
-
chests
out
there
,
full
of
earth
,
with
forgotten
plants
in
them
,
like
old
walking
-
sticks
.
 
<EOS>
Whoever
climbed
to
this
observatory
,
was
stunned
at
first
from
having
knocked
his
head
against
the
little
door
in
coming
out
;
and
after
that
,
was
for
the
moment
choked
from
having
looked
perforce
,
straight
down
the
kitchen
chimney
;
but
these
two
stages
over
,
there
were
things
to
gaze
at
from
the
top
of
Todgers
's
,
<EOS>
well
worth
your
seeing
too
.
 
<EOS>
For
first
and
foremost
,
if
the
day
were
bright
,
you
observed
upon
the
house
-
tops
,

far
away
,
a
long

;
the
shadow
of
the
Monument
;
and
turning
round
,
the
tall
original
was
close

,
with
every
hair

upon

,
as
if
the

the

.
 
<EOS>
Then
there
were
steeples
,

,

,

,
and
masts
of
ships
;
a
very
forest
.
 
<EOS>
Gables
,
housetops
,
garret
-
windows
,
wilderness
upon
wilderness
.
 
<EOS>
Smoke
and
noise
enough
for
all
the
world
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
After
the
first
glance
,
there
were
slight
features
in
the
midst
of
this
crowd
of
objects
,
which
sprung
out
from
the
mass
without
any
reason
,
as
it
were
,
and
took

of
the
attention
whether
the
spectator
would
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
the
revolving
chimney
-
pots
on
one
great
stack
of
buildings
seemed
to
be
turning
gravely
to
each
other
every
now
and
then
,
and
whispering
the
result
of
their
separate
observation
of
what
was
going

.
 
<EOS>
Others
,
of
a

,
appeared
to
be
maliciously
holding
themselves
askew
,
that
they
might
shut
the
prospect
out
and

Todgers
's
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
who
was
mending
a
pen
at
an
upper
window
over
the
way
,
became
of
paramount

in
the
scene
,
and
made
a
blank
in
it
,
ridiculously
disproportionate
in
its
extent
,
when
he
retired
.
 
<EOS>
The
gambols
of
a
piece
of
cloth
upon
the
dyer
's
pole
had
far
more
interest
for
the
moment
than
all
the
changing
motion
of
the
crowd
.
<EOS>
Yet
even
while
the
looker
-
on
felt
angry
with
himself
for
this
,
and
wondered
how
it
was
,
the
tumult
swelled
into
a
roar
;
the
hosts
of
objects
seemed
to
thicken
and
expand
a
hundredfold
,
and
after

round
him
,
quite
scared
,
he
turned
into
Todgers
's
again
,
much
more

than

came
out
;
and
ten
to
one
he
told
M
Todgers
afterwards
that
if
he
had
n't
done
so
,
he
would
certainly
have
come
into
the
street
by
the
shortest
cut
;
that
is
to
say
,
head
-
foremost
.
   
<EOS>
So
said
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
when
they
retired
with
Mrs
Todgers
from
this
place
of
espial
,
leaving
the
youthful
porter
to
close
the
door
and
follow
them

;
who
,
being
of
a
playful

,
and
contemplating
with
a

peculiar
to
his
sex
and
time
of
life
,
any
chance
of
dashing
himself
into
small
fragments
,
lingered
behind
to
walk
upon
the
parapet
.
   
<EOS>
It
being
the
second
day
of
their
stay
in
London
,
the
Miss
Pecksniffs
and
Mrs
Todgers
were
by
this
time
highly
confidential
,
insomuch
that
the
last
-
named
lady
had
already
communicated
the
particulars
of
three
early
disappointments
of
a
tender
nature
;
and
had
furthermore
possessed
her
young
friends
with
a
general
summary
of
the
life
,
conduct
,
and
character
of
Mr
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
Who
,
it
seemed
,
had
cut
his
matrimonial
career
rather
short
,
by
unlawfully
running
away
from
his
happiness
,
and
establishing
himself
in
foreign
countries
as
a
bachelor
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
pa
was
once
a
little
particular
in
his
attentions
,
my
dears
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
but
to
be
your
ma
was
too
much
happiness
denied
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
'd
hardly
know
who
this
was
done
for
,
perhaps
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
called
their
attention
to
an
oval
miniature
,
like
a
little
blister
,
which
was
tacked
up
over
the
kettle
-
holder
,
and
in
which
there
was
a
dreamy
shadowing
forth
of
her
own
visage
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
speaking
likeness
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
considered
so
once
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
warming
herself
in
a
gentlemanly
manner
at
the
fire
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
hardly
thought
you
would
have
known
it
,
my
loves
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
would
have
known
it
anywhere
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
could
have
met
with
it
in
the
street
,
or
seen
it
in
a
shop
window
,
they
would
have
cried
"
Good
gracious
!
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Presiding
over
an
establishment
like
this
,
makes
sad
havoc
with
the
features
,
my
dear
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gravy
alone
,
is
enough
to
add
twenty
years
to
one
's
age
,
I
do
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
'
!
"
cried
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
anxiety
of
that
one
item
,
my
dears
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
keeps
the
mind
continually
upon
the
stretch
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
passion
in
human
nature
,
as
the
passion
for
gravy
among
commercial
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
It
's
nothing
to
say
a
joint
wo
n't
yield
---
a
whole
animal
would
n't
yield
---
<EOS>
the
amount
of
gravy
<EOS>
they
expect
each
day
at
dinner
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
I
have
undergone
in
consequence
,
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
,
raising
her
eyes
and
shaking
her
head
,
"
no
one
would
believe
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
like
Mr
Pinch
,
Merry
!
"
said
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
always
noticed
it
in
him
,
you
remember
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
,
"
giggled
Merry
,
"
but
<EOS>
we
have
never
given
it
him
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
my
dears
,
having
to
deal
with
your
pa
's
pupils
who
ca
n't
help
themselves
,
are
able
to
take
your
own
way
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
;
"
but
in
a
commercial
establishment
,
where
any
gentleman
may
say
any
Saturday
evening
,
"
Mrs
Todgers
,
this
day
week
we
part
,
in
consequence
of
the
cheese
,
"
it
is
not
so
easy
to
preserve
a
pleasant
understanding
.
<EOS>
Your
pa
was
kind
enough
,
"
added
the
good
lady
,
"
to
invite
me
to
take
a
ride
with
you
to
-
day
;
and
I
think
he
mentioned
that
you
were

to
call
upon
Miss
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
Any
relation
to
the
gentleman
you
were
speaking
of
just
now
,
Miss
Pecksniff
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
For
goodness
sake
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
interposed
the
lively
Merry
,
"
do
n't
call
him
a
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Cherry
,
Pinch
a
gentleman
!
<EOS>
The
idea
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
wicked
girl
you
are
!
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
,
embracing
her
with
great
affection
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
a
quiz
,
I
do
declare
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Miss
Pecksniff
,
what
a
happiness
<EOS>
your
sister
's
spirits
must
be
to
your
pa
and
self
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
the
most
hideous
,
goggle
-
eyed
creature
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
in
existence
,
"
resumed
Merry
:
"
<EOS>
quite
an
ogre
.
 
<EOS>
The
ugliest
,
awkwardest
frightfullest
being
,
you
can
imagine
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
his
sister
,
so
I
leave
you
to
suppose
what
SHE
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
be
obliged
to
laugh
outright
<EOS>
,
I
know
I
shall
!
"
cried
the
charming
girl
,
"
I
never
shall
be
able
to
keep
my
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
The
notion
of
a
Miss
Pinch
presuming
to
exist
at
all
is
sufficient
to
kill
one
,
but
to
see
her
 
---
<EOS>
oh
my
stars
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
laughed
immensely
at
the
dear
love
's
humour
,
and
declared
she
was
quite
afraid
of
her
,
that
she
was
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
very
severe
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
is
severe
?
"
cried
a
voice
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
such
thing
as
severity
in
our
family
,
I
hope
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
Mr
Pecksniff
peeped
smilingly
into
the
room
,
and
said
,
"
May
I
come
in
,
Mrs
Todgers
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
almost
screamed
,
for
the
little
door
of
communication
between
that
room
and
the
inner
one
being
wide
open
,
there
was
a
full
disclosure
of
the
sofa
bedstead
in
all
its
monstrous
impropriety
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
had
the
presence
of
mind
to
close
this
portal
in
the
twinkling
of
an
eye
;
and
having
done
so
,
said
,
though
not
without
confusion
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
you
can
come
in
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
are
we
to
-
day
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
jocosely
.
 
<EOS>
"
and
what
are
our
plans
?
 
<EOS>
Are
we
ready
to
go
and
see
Tom
Pinch
's
sister
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
Poor
Thomas
Pinch
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
we
ready
,
"
returned
Mrs
Todgers
,
nodding
her
head
with
mysterious
intelligence
,
"
to
send
a
favourable
reply
to
Mr
Jinkins
's
round
-
robin
?
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
first
question
,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
Mr
Jinkins
's
robin
,
my
dear
madam
?
"
asked
Mr
Pecksniff
,
putting
one
arm
round
Mercy
,
and
the
other
round
Mrs
Todgers
,
whom
he
seemed
,
in
the
abstraction
of
the
moment
,
to
mistake
for
Charity
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
Mr
Jinkins
's
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
he
began
to
get
it
up
,
and
indeed
always
takes
the
lead
in
the
house
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
playfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
why
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jinkins
is
a
man
of
superior
talents
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
conceived
a
great
regard
for
Jinkins
.
 
<EOS>
I
take
Jinkins
's
desire
to
pay
polite
attention
to
my
daughters
,
as
an
additional
proof
of
the
friendly
feeling
of
Jinkins
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
now
,
"
returned
that
lady
,
"
having
said
so
much
,
you
must
say
the
rest
,
Mr
Pecksniff
;
so
tell
the
dear
young
ladies
all
about
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
she
gently
eluded
Mr
Pecksniff
's
grasp
,
and
took
Miss
Charity
into
her
own
embrace
;
though
whether
she
was
impelled
to
this
proceeding
solely
by
the
irrepressible
affection
she
had
conceived
for
that
young
lady
,
or
whether
it
had
any
reference
to
a
lowering
,
not
to
say
distinctly
spiteful
expression
which
had
been
visible
in
her
face
for
some

,
has
never
been
exactly
ascertained
.
 
<EOS>
Be
this
as
it
may
,
Mr
Pecksniff
went
on
to
inform
his
daughters
of
the
purport
and
history
of
the
round
-
robin
aforesaid
,
which
was
in
brief
,
that
the
commercial
gentlemen
who
helped
to
make
up
the
sum
and
substance
of
that
noun
of
multitude
signifying
many
,
called
Todgers
's
,
desired
the
honour
of
their
presence
at
the
general
table
,
so
long
as
they
remained
in
the
house
,
and
besought
that
they
would
grace
the
board
at
dinner
-
time
next
day
,
the
same
being
Sunday
.
 
<EOS>
He
further
said
,
that
Mrs
Todgers
being
a
consenting
party
to
this
invitation
,
he
was
willing
,
for
his
part
,
to
accept
it
;
and
so
left
them
that
he
might
write
his
gracious
answer
,
the
while
they
armed
themselves
with
their
best
bonnets
for
the
utter
defeat
and
overthrow
of
Miss
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
's
sister
was
governess
in
a
family
,
a
lofty
family
;
perhaps
the
wealthiest
brass
and
copper
founders
'
family
known
to
mankind
.
 
<EOS>
They
lived
at
Camberwell
;
in
a
house
so
big
and
fierce
,
that
its
mere
outside
,
like
the
outside
of
a
giant
's
castle
,
struck
terror
into
vulgar
minds
and
made
bold
persons
quail
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
front
gate
;
with
a
great
bell
,
whose
handle
was
in
itself
a
note
of
admiration
;
and
a
great
lodge
;
which
being
close
to
the
house
,
rather
spoilt
the
look
-
out
certainly
but
made
the
look
-
in
tremendous
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
entry
,
a
great
porter
kept
constant
watch
and
ward
;
and
when
he
gave
the
visitor
high
leave
to
pass
,
he
rang
a
second
great
bell
,
responsive
to
whose
note
a
great
footman
appeared
in
due
time
at
the
great
halldoor
,
with
such
great
tags
upon
his
liveried
shoulder
that
he
was
perpetually
entangling
and
hooking
himself
among
the
chairs
and
tables
,
and
led
a
life
of
torment
which
could
scarcely
have
been
surpassed
,
if
he
had
been
a
blue
-
bottle
in
a
world
of
cobwebs
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
mansion
Mr
Pecksniff
,
accompanied
by
his
daughters
and
Mrs
Todgers
,
drove
gallantly
in
a
one
-
horse
fly
.
 
<EOS>
The
foregoing
ceremonies
having
been
all
performed
,
they
were
ushered
into
the
house
;
and
so
,
by
degrees
<EOS>
,
they
got
at
last
into
a
small
room
with
books
in
it
,
where
Mr
Pinch
's
sister
was
at
that
moment
instructing
her
eldest
pupil
;
to
wit
,
a
premature
little
woman
of
thirteen
years
old
,
who
had
already
arrived
at
such
a
pitch
of
whalebone
and
education
that
she
had
nothing
girlish
about
her
,
which
was
a
source
of
great
rejoicing
to
all
her
relations
and
friends
.
   
<EOS>
"
Visitors
for
Miss
Pinch
!
"
said
the
footman
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
have
been
an
ingenious
young
man
,
for
he
said
it
very
cleverly
;
with
a
nice
discrimination
between
the
cold
respect
with
which
he
would
have
announced
visitors
to
the
family
,
and
the
warm
personal
interest
with
which
he
would
have
announced
visitors
to
the
cook
.
   
<EOS>
"
Visitors
for
Miss
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pinch
rose
hastily
;
with
such
tokens
of
agitation
as
plainly
declared
that
her
list
of
callers
was
not
numerous
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
the
little
pupil
became
alarmingly
upright
,
and
prepared
herself
to
take
mental
notes
of
all
that
might
be
said
and
done
.
<EOS>
For
the
lady
of
the
establishment
was
curious
in
the
natural
history
and
habits
of
the
animal
called
Governess
,
and
encouraged
her
daughters
to
report
thereon
whenever
occasion
served
;
which
was
,
in
reference
to
all
parties
concerned
,
very
laudable
,
improving
,
and
pleasant
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
a
melancholy
fact
;
but
it
must
be
related
,
that
Mr
Pinch
's
sister
was
not
at
all
ugly
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
she
had
a
good
face
;
a
very
mild
and
prepossessing
face
;
and
a
pretty
little
figure
---
slight
and
short
,
but
remarkable
for
its
neatness
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
something
of
her
brother
,
much
of
him
indeed
,
in
a
certain
gentleness
of
manner
,
and
in
her
look
of
timid
trustfulness
;
but
she
was
so
far
from
being
a
fright
,
or
a
dowdy
,
or
a
horror
,
or
anything
else
,
predicted
by
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
that
those
young
ladies
naturally
regarded
her
with
great
indignation
,
feeling
that
this
was
by
no
means
what
they
had
come
to
see
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mercy
,
as
having
the
larger
share
of
gaiety
,
bore
up
the
best
against
this
disappointment
,
and
carried
it
off
,
in
outward
show
at
least
,
with
a
titter
;
but
her
sister
,
not
caring
to
hide
her
disdain
,
expressed
it
pretty
openly
in
her
looks
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Mrs
Todgers
,
she
leaned
on
Mr
Pecksniff
's
arm
and
preserved
a
kind
of
genteel
grimness
,
suitable
to
any
state
of
mind
,
and
involving
any
shade
of
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
Miss
Pinch
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
taking
her
hand
condescendingly
in
one
of
his
,
and
patting
it
with
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
called
to
see
you
,
in
pursuance
of
a
promise
given
to
your
brother
,
Thomas
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
My
name
---
compose
yourself
,
Miss
Pinch
---
is
Pecksniff
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
good
man
emphasised
these
words
as
though
he
would
have
said
,
"
You
see
in
me
,
young
person
,
the
benefactor
of
your
race
;
the
patron
of
your
house
;
the
preserver
of
your
brother
,
who
is
fed
with
manna
daily
from
my
table
;
and
in
right
of
whom
there
is
a
considerable
balance
in
my
favour
at
present
standing
in
the
books
beyond
the
sky
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
no
pride
,
for
I
can
afford
to
do
without
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
poor
girl
felt
it
all
as
if
it
had
been
Gospel
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Her
brother
writing
in
the
fullness
of
his
simple
heart
,
had
often
told
her
so
,
and
how
much
more
!
 
<EOS>
As

Pecksniff

,

<EOS>
"
Oh
<EOS>
very

,

"

,
"
crying

"
   
<EOS>
"
Thomas

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Eh

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

pa

?

<EOS>

We

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

's

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Show

!
"
   
<EOS>
With

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
put
on
his
hat
,
and
walked
with
great

and
in
profound
silence
to
the
fly
,
gazing
at
the
clouds
as
he
went
,
with
great
interest
.
 
<EOS>
After
helping
his
daughters
and
Mrs
Todgers
into
that
conveyance
,
he
stood
looking
at
it
for
some

,
as
if
he
were
not
quite
certain
whether
it
was
a
carriage
or
a

;
but
having
settled
this
point
in
his
mind
,
he
got
into
his
place
,
spread
his
hands
out
on
his
