,
and
smiled
upon
the
three
beholders
.
   
<EOS>
But
his
daughters
,
less
tranquil
-
minded
,
burst
into
a
torrent
of
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
This
came
,
they
said
,
of
cherishing
such
creatures
as
the
Pinches
.
 
<EOS>
This
came
of
lowering
themselves
to
their
level
.
 
<EOS>
This
came
of
putting
themselves
in
the
humiliating
position
of
seeming
to
know
such
bold
,
audacious
,
cunning
,
dreadful
girls
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
expected
this
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
predicted
it
to
Mrs
Todgers
,
as
she
(
Todgers
)
could
depone
,
that
very
morning
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
,
they
added
,
that
the
owner
of
the
house
,
supposing
them
to
be
Miss
Pinch
's
friends
,
had
acted
,
in
their
opinion
,
quite
correctly
,
and
had
done
no
more
than
,
under
such
circumstances
,
might
reasonably
have
been
expected
.
 
<EOS>
To
that
they
added
(
with
a
trifling
inconsistency
)
,
that
he
was
a
brute
and
a
bear
;
and
then
they
merged
into
a
flood
of
tears
,
which
swept
away
all
wandering
epithets
before
it
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
Miss
Pinch
was
scarcely
so
much
to
blame
in
the
matter
as
the
Seraph
,
who
,
immediately
on
the
withdrawal
of
the
visitors
,
had
hastened
to
report
them
at
head
-
quarters
,
with
a
full
account
of
their
having
presumptuously
charged
her
with
the
delivery
of
a
message
afterwards
consigned
to
the
footman
;
which
outrage
,
taken
in
conjunction
with
Mr
Pecksniff
's
unobtrusive
remarks
on
the
establishment
,
might
possibly
have
had
some
share
in
their
dismissal
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Miss
Pinch
,
however
,
had
to
bear
the
brunt
of
it
with
both
parties
;
being
so
severely
taken
to
task
by
the
Seraph
's
mother
for
having
such
vulgar
acquaintances
,
that
she
was
fain
to
retire
to
her
own
room
in
tears
,
which
her
natural
cheerfulness
and
submission
,
and
the
delight
of
having
seen
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
having
received
a
letter
from
her
brother
,
were
at
first
insufficient
to
repress
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Pecksniff
,
he
told
them
in
the
fly
,
that
a
good
action
was
its
own
reward
;
and
rather
gave
them
to
understand
,
that
if
he
could
have
been
kicked
in
such
a
cause
,
he
would
have
liked
it
all
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
was
no
comfort
to
the
young
ladies
,
who
scolded
violently
the
whole
way
back
,
and
even
exhibited
,
more
than
once
,
a
keen
desire
to
attack
the
devoted
Mrs
Todgers
;
on
whose
personal
appearance
,
but
particularly
on
whose
offending
card
and
hand
-
basket
,
they
were
secretly
inclined
to
lay
the
blame
of
half
their
failure
.
   
<EOS>
Todgers
's
was
in
a
great
bustle
that
evening
,
partly
owing
to
some
additional
domestic
preparations
for
the
morrow
,
and
partly
to
the
excitement
always
inseparable
in
that
house
from
Saturday
night
,
when
every
gentleman
's
linen
arrived
at
a
different
hour
in
its
own
little
bundle
,
with
his
private
account
pinned
on
the
outside
.
<EOS>
There
was
always
a
great
clinking
of
pattens
downstairs
,
too
,
until
midnight
or
so
,
on
Saturdays
;
together
with
a
frequent
gleaming
of
mysterious
lights
in
the
area
;
much
working
at
the
pump
;
and
a
constant
jangling
of
the
iron
handle
of
the
pail
.
 
<EOS>
Shrill
altercations
from
time
to
time
arose
between
Mrs
Todgers
and
unknown
females
in
remote
back
kitchens
;
and
sounds
were
occasionally
heard
,
indicative
of
small
articles
of
iron
mongery
and
hardware
being
thrown
at
the
boy
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
custom
of
that
youth
on
Saturdays
,
to
roll
up
his
shirt
sleeves
to
his
shoulders
,
and
pervade
all
parts
of
the
house
in
an
apron
of
coarse
green
baize
;
moreover
,
he
was
more
strongly
tempted
on
Saturdays
than
on
other
days
(
it
being
a
busy
time
)
,
to
make
excursive
bolts
into
the
neighbouring
alleys
when
he
answered
the
door
,
and
there
to
play
at
leap
-
frog
and
other
sports
with
vagrant
lads
,
until
pursued
and
brought
back
by
the
hair
of
his
head
or
the
lobe
of
his
ear
;
thus
he
was
quite
a
conspicuous
feature
among
the
peculiar
incidents
of
the
last
day
in
the
week
at
Todgers
's
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
especially
so
on
this
particular
Saturday
evening
,
and
honoured
the
Miss
Pecksniffs
with
a
deal
of
notice
;
seldom
passing
the
door
of
Mrs
Todgers
's
private
room
,
where
they
sat
alone
before
the
fire
,
working
by
the
light
of
a
solitary
candle
,
without
putting
in
his
head
and
greeting
them
with
some
such
compliments
as
,
"
There
you
are
agin
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
An't
it
nice
?
"
<EOS>
---
and
similar
humorous
attentions
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
he
whispered
,
stopping
in
one
of
his
journeys
to
and
fro
,
"
young
ladies
,
there
's
soup
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
She
's
a
-
making
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
An't
<EOS>
she
a
-
putting
in
the
water
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
not
at
all
neither
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
answering
another
knock
,
he
thrust
in
his
head
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
fowls
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Not
skinny
ones
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
Presently
he
called
through
the
key
-
hole
:
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
fish
to
-
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
Just
come
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
eat
none
of
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
And
,
with
this
special
warning
,
vanished
again
.
   
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
bye
,
he
returned
to
lay
the
cloth
for
supper
;
it
having
been
arranged
between
Mrs
Todgers
and
the
young
ladies
,
that
they
should
partake
of
an
exclusive
veal
-
cutlet
together
in
the
privacy
of
that
apartment
.
 
<EOS>
He
entertained
them
on
this
occasion
by
thrusting
the
lighted
candle
into
his
mouth
,
and
exhibiting
his
face
in
a
state
of
transparency
;
after
the
performance
of
which
feat
,
he
went
on
with
his
professional
duties
;
brightening
every
knife
as
he
laid
it
on
the
table
,
by
breathing
on
the
blade
and
afterwards
polishing
the
same
on
the
apron
already
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
completed
his
preparations
,
he
grinned
at
the
sisters
,
and
expressed
his
belief
that
the
approaching
collation
would
be
of
"
rather
a
spicy
sort
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
it
be
long
,
before
it
's
ready
,
Bailey
?
"
asked
Mercy
.
    
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Bailey
,
"
it
IS
cooked
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
come
up
,
she
was
dodging
among
the
tender
pieces
with
a
fork
,
and
eating
of
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
he
had
scarcely
achieved
the
utterance
of
these
words
,
when
he
received
a
manual
compliment
on
the
head
,
which
sent
him
staggering
against
the
wall
;
and
Mrs
Todgers
,
dish
in
hand
,
stood
indignantly
before
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
you
little
villain
!
"
said
that
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
you
bad
,
false
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
worse
than
yerself
,
"
retorted
Bailey
,
guarding
his
head
,
on
a
principle
invented
by
Mr
Thomas
Cribb
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Come
now
!
 
<EOS>
Do
that
again
,
will
yer
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
the
most
dreadful
child
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
setting
down
the
dish
,
"
I
ever
had
to
deal
with
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
spoil
him
to
that
extent
,
and
teach
him
such
things
,
that
I
'm
afraid
nothing
but
hanging
will
ever
do
him
any
good
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bailey
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
Wot
do
you
go
a
-
lowerin
<EOS>
the
table
-
beer
for
then
,
and
destroying
my
constitooshun
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
downstairs
,
you
vicious
boy
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
holding
the
door
open
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
me
?
 
<EOS>
Go
along
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
two
or
three
dexterous
feints
,
he
went
,
and
was
seen
no
more
that
night
,
save
once
,
when
he
brought
up
some
tumblers
and
hot
water
,
and
much
disturbed
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
by
squinting
hideously
behind
the
back
of
the
unconscious
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
Having
done
this
justice
to
his
wounded
feelings
,
he
retired
underground
;
where
,
in
company
with
a
swarm
of
black
beetles
and
a
kitchen
candle
,
he
employed
his
faculties
in
cleaning
boots
and
brushing
clothes
until
the
night
was
far
advanced
.
   
<EOS>
Benjamin
was
supposed
to
be
the
real
name
of
this
young
retainer
<EOS>
but
he
was
known
by
a
great
variety
of
names
.
 
<EOS>
Benjamin
,
for
instance
,
had
been
converted
into
Uncle
Ben
,
and
that
again
had
been
corrupted
into
Uncle
;
which
,
by
an
easy
transition
,
had
again
passed
into
Barnwell
,
in
memory
of
the
celebrated
relative
in
that
degree
who
was
shot
by
his
nephew
George
,
while
meditating
in
his
garden
at
Camberwell
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
at
Todgers
's
had
a
merry
habit
,
too
,
of
bestowing
upon
him
,
for
the
time
being
,
the
name
of
any
notorious
malefactor
or
minister
;
and
sometimes
when
current
events
were
flat
they
even
sought
the
pages
of
history
for
these
distinctions
;
as
Mr
Pitt
,
Young
Brownrigg
,
and
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
period
of
which
we
write
,
he
was
generally
known
among
the
gentlemen
as
Bailey
junior
;
a
name
bestowed
upon
him
in
contradistinction
,
perhaps
,
to
Old
Bailey
;
and
possibly
as
involving
the
recollection
of
an
unfortunate
lady
of
the
same
name
,
who
perished
by
her
own
hand
early
in
life
,
and
has
been
immortalised
in
a
ballad
.
   
<EOS>
The
usual
Sunday
dinner
-
hour
at
Todgers
's
was
two
o'clock
---
a
suitable
time
,
it
was
considered
for
all
parties
;
convenient
to
Mrs
Todgers
,
on
account
of
the
bakers
;
and
convenient
to
the
gentlemen
with
reference
to
their
afternoon
engagements
.
 
<EOS>
But
on
the
Sunday
which
was
to
introduce
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
to
a
full
knowledge
of
Todgers
's
and
its
society
,
the
dinner
was
postponed
until
five
,
in
order
that
everything
might
be
as
genteel
as
the
occasion
demanded
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
hour
drew
nigh
,
Bailey
junior
,
testifying
great
excitement
,
appeared
in
a
complete
suit
of
cast
-
off
clothes
several
sizes
too
large
for
him
,
and
in
particular
,
mounted
a
clean
shirt
of
such
extraordinary
magnitude
,
that
one
of
the
gentlemen
(
remarkable
for
his
ready
wit
)
called
him
"
collars
"
on
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
At
about
a
quarter
before
five
,
a
deputation
,
consisting
of
Mr
Jinkins
,
and
another
gentleman
,
whose
name
was
Gander
,
knocked
at
the
door
of
Mrs
Todgers
's
room
,
and
,
being
formally
introduced
to
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
by
their
parent
who
was
in
waiting
,
besought
the
honour
of
conducting
them
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
The
drawing
-
room
at
Todgers
's
was
out
of
the
common
style
;
so
much
<EOS>
so
indeed
,
that
you
would
hardly
have
taken
it
to
be
a
drawingroom
,
unless
you
were
told
so
by
somebody
who
was
in
the
secret
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
floor
-
clothed
all
over
;
and
the
ceiling
,
including
a
great
beam
in
the
middle
,
was
papered
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
the
three
little
windows
,
with
seats
in
them
,
commanding
the
opposite
archway
,
there
was
another
window
looking
point
blank
,
without
any
compromise
at
all
about
it
into
Jinkins
's
bedroom
;
and
high
up
,
all
along
one
side
of
the
wall
was
a
strip
of
panes
of
glass
,
two
-
deep
,
giving
light
to
the
staircase
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
the
oddest
closets
possible
,
with
little
casements
in
them
like
eight
-
day
clocks
,
lurking
in
the
wainscot
and
taking
the
shape
of
the
stairs
;
and
the
very
door
itself
(
which
was
painted
black
)
had
two
great
glass
eyes
in
its
forehead
,
with
an
inquisitive
green
pupil
in
the
middle
of
each
.
   
<EOS>
Here
the
gentlemen
were
all
assembled
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
general
cry
of
"
Hear
,
hear
!
"
<EOS>
and
"
Bravo
Jink
!
<EOS>
"
when
Mr
Jinkins
appeared
with
Charity
on
his
arm
;
which
became
quite
rapturous
as
Mr
Gander
followed
,
escorting
Mercy
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
brought
up
the
rear
with
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
Then
the
presentations
took
place
.
 
<EOS>
They
included
a
gentleman
of
a
sporting
turn
,
who
propounded
questions
on
jockey
subjects
to
the
editors
of
Sunday
papers
,
which
were
regarded
by
his
friends
as
rather
stiff
things
to
answer
;
and
they
included
a
gentleman
of
a
theatrical
turn
,
who
had
once
entertained
serious
thoughts
of
"
coming
out
,
"
but
had
been
kept
in
by
the
wickedness
of
human
nature
;
and
they
included
a
gentleman
of
a
debating
turn
,
who
was
strong
at
speech
-
making
;
and
a
gentleman
of
a
literary
turn
,
who
wrote
squibs
upon
the
rest
,
and
knew
the
weak
side
of
everybody
's
character
but
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
gentleman
of
a
vocal
turn
,
and
a
gentleman
of
a
smoking
turn
,
and
a
gentleman
of
a
convivial
turn
;
some
of
the
gentlemen
had
a
turn
for
whist
,
and
a
large
proportion
of
the
gentlemen
had
a
strong
turn
for
billiards
and
betting
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
all
,
it
may
be
presumed
,
a
turn
for
business
;
being
all
commercially
employed
in
one
way
or
other
;
and
had
,
every
one
in
his
own
way
,
a
decided
turn
for
pleasure
to
boot
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
was
of
a
fashionable
turn
;
being
a
regular
frequenter
of
the
Parks
on
Sundays
,
and
knowing
a
great
many
carriages
by
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
spoke
mysteriously
,
too
,
of
splendid
women
,
and
was
suspected
of
having
once
committed
himself
with
a
Countess
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Gander
was
of
a
witty
turn
being
indeed
the
gentleman
who
had
originated
the
sally
about
"
collars
;
"
which
sparkling
pleasantry
was
now
retailed
from
mouth
to
mouth
,
under
the
title
of
Gander
's
Last
,
and
was
received
in
all
parts
of
the
room
with
great
applause
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
<EOS>
it
may
be
added
,
was
much
the
oldest
of
the
party
;
being
a
fish
-
salesman
's
book
-
keeper
,
<EOS>
aged
forty
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
oldest
boarder
also
;
and
in
right
of
his
double
seniority
,
took
the
lead
in
the
house
,
as
Mrs
Todgers
had
already
said
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
considerable
delay
in
the
production
of
dinner
,
and
<EOS>
poor
Mrs
Todgers
,
being
reproached
in
confidence
by
Jinkins
,
slipped
in
and
out
,
at
least
twenty
times
to
see
about
it
;
always
coming
back
as
though
she
had
no
such
thing
upon
her
mind
,
and
had
n't
been
out
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
hitch
in
the
conversation
nevertheless
;
for
one
gentleman
,
who
travelled
in
the
perfumery
line
,
exhibited
an
interesting
nick
-
nack
,
in
the
way
of
a
remarkable
cake
of
shaving
soap
which
he
had
lately
met
with
in
Germany
;
and
the
gentleman
of
a
literary
turn
repeated
(
by
desire
)
<EOS>
some
sarcastic
stanzas
he
had
recently
produced
on
the
freezing
of
the
tank
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
These
amusements
,
with
the
miscellaneous
conversation
arising
out
of
them
,
passed
the
time
splendidly
,
until
dinner
was
announced
by
Bailey
junior
in
these
terms
:
   
<EOS>
"
The
wittles
is
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
On
which
notice
they
immediately
descended
to
the
banquet
-
hall
;
some
of
the
more
facetious
spirits
in
the
rear
taking
down
gentlemen
as
if
they
were
ladies
,
in
imitation
of
the
fortunate
possessors
of
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
said
grace
---
a
short
and
pious
grace
,
involving
a
blessing
on
the
appetites
of
those
present
,
and
committing
all
persons
who
had
nothing
to
eat
,
to
the
care
of
Providence
;
whose
business
(
so
said
the
grace
,
in
effect
)
<EOS>
it
clearly
was
,
to
look
after
them
.
 
<EOS>
This
done
,
they
fell
to
with
less
ceremony
than
appetite
;
the
table
groaning
beneath
the
weight
,
not
only
of
the
delicacies
whereof
the
Miss
Pecksniffs
had
been
previously
forewarned
,
but
of
boiled
beef
,
roast
veal
,
bacon
,
pies
and
abundance
of
such
heavy
vegetables
as
are
favourably
known
to
housekeepers
for
their
satisfying
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
which
,
there
were
bottles
of
stout
,
bottles
of
wine
,
bottles
of
ale
,
and
divers
other
strong
drinks
,
native
and
foreign
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
was
highly
agreeable
to
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
who
were
in
immense
request
;
sitting
one
on
either
hand
of
Mr
Jinkins
at
the
bottom
of
the
table
;
and
who
were
called
upon
to
take
wine
with
some
new
admirer
every
minute
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
hardly
ever
felt
so
pleasant
,
and
so
full
of
conversation
,
in
their
lives
;
Mercy
,
in
particular
,
was
uncommonly
brilliant
,
and
said
so
many
good
things
in
the
way
of
lively
repartee
that
she
was
looked
upon
as
a
prodigy
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
"
as
that
young
lady
observed
,
"
they
felt
now
,
indeed
,
that
they
were
in
London
,
and
for
the
first
time
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
Their
young
friend
Bailey
sympathized
in
these
feelings
to
the
fullest
extent
,
and
,
abating
nothing
of
his
patronage
,
gave
them
every
encouragement
in
his
power
;
favouring
them
,
when
the
general
attention
was
diverted
from
his
proceedings
,
with
many
nods
and
winks
and
other
tokens
of
recognition
,
and
occasionally
touching
his
nose
with
a
corkscrew
,
as
if
to
express
the
Bacchanalian
character
of
the
meeting
.
 
<EOS>
In
truth
,
perhaps
even
the
spirits
of
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
and
the
hungry
watchfulness
of
Mrs
Todgers
,
were
less
worthy
of
note
than
the
proceedings
of
this
remarkable
boy
,
whom
nothing
disconcerted
or
put
out
of
his
way
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
piece
of
crockery
,
a
dish
or
otherwise
,
chanced
to
slip
through
his
hands
(
which
happened
once
or
twice
)
,
he
let
it
go
with
perfect
good
breeding
,
and
never
added
to
the
painful
emotions
of
the
company
by
exhibiting
the
least
regret
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
,
by
hurrying
to
and
fro
,
disturb
the
repose
of
the
assembly
,
as
many
well
-
trained
servants
do
;
on
the
contrary
,
feeling
the
hopelessness
of
waiting
upon
so
large
a
party
,
he
left
the
gentlemen
to
help
themselves
to
what
they
wanted
,
and
seldom
stirred
from
behind
Mr
Jinkins
's
chair
,
where
,
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
and
his
legs
planted
pretty
wide
apart
,
he
led
the
laughter
,
and
enjoyed
the
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
The
dessert
was
splendid
.
 
<EOS>
No
waiting
either
.
 
<EOS>
The
pudding
-
plates
had
been
washed
in
a
little
tub
outside
the
door
while
cheese
was
on
,
and
though
they
were
moist
and
warm
with
friction
,
still
there
they
were
again
,
up
to
the
mark
,
and
true
to
time
.
 
<EOS>
Quarts
of
almonds
;
dozens
of
oranges
;
pounds
of
raisins
;
stacks
of
biffins
;
soup
-
plates
full
of
nuts
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
Todgers
's
could
do
it
when
it
chose
!
<EOS>
mind
that
.
   
<EOS>
Then
more
wine
came
on
;
red
wines
and
white
wines
;
and
a
large
china
bowl
of
punch
,
brewed
by
the
gentleman
of
a
convivial
turn
,
who
adjured
the
Miss
Pecksniffs
not
to
be
despondent
on
account
of
its
dimensions
,
as
there
were
materials
in
the
house
for
the
decoction
of
half
a
dozen
more
of
the
same
size
.
 
<EOS>
Good
gracious
,
how
they
laughed
!
 
<EOS>
How
they
coughed
when
they
sipped
it
,
because
it
was
so
strong
;
and
how
they
laughed
again
when
somebody
vowed
that
but
for
its
colour
it
might
have
been
mistaken
,
in
regard
of
its
innocuous
qualities
,
for
new
milk
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
shout
of
"
No
!
"
<EOS>
burst
from
the
gentlemen
when
they
pathetically
implored
Mr
Jinkins
to
suffer
them
to
qualify
it
with
hot
water
;
and
how
blushingly
,
by
little
and
little
,
did
each
of
them
drink
her
whole
glassful
,
down
to
its
very
dregs
!
   
<EOS>
Now
comes
the
trying
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
sun
,
as
Mr
Jinkins
says
(
gentlemanly
creature
,
Jinkins
---
never
at
a
loss
!
)
,
is
about
to
leave
the
firmament
.
 
<EOS>
"
Miss
Pecksniff
!
"
says
Mrs
Todgers
,
softly
,
"
will
you
---
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
no
more
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
rises
;
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
rise
;
all
rise
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mercy
Pecksniff
looks
downward
for
her
scarf
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
,
where
CAN
it
be
?
<EOS>
Sweet
girl
,
she
has
it
on
;
not
on
her
fair
neck
,
but
loose
upon
her
flowing
figure
.
 
<EOS>
A
dozen
hands
assist
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
all
confusion
.
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
thirsts
to
murder
Jinkins
.
 
<EOS>
She
skips
and
joins
her
sister
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sister
has
her
arm
about
the
waist
of
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
She
winds
her
arm
around
her
sister
.
 
<EOS>
Diana
,
what
a
picture
!
 
<EOS>
The
last
things
visible
are
a
shape
and
a
skip
.
 
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
let
us
drink
the
ladies
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
enthusiasm
is
tremendous
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
of
a
debating
turn
rises
in
the
midst
,
and
suddenly
lets
loose
a
tide
of
eloquence
which
bears
down
everything
before
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
reminded
of
a
toast
---
a
toast
to
which
they
will
respond
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
individual
present
;
he
has
him
in
his
eye
;
to
whom
they
owe
a
debt
of
gratitude
.
 
<EOS>
He
repeats
it
---
a
debt
of
gratitude
.
 
<EOS>
Their
rugged
natures
have
been
softened
and
ameliorated
that
day
,
by
the
society
of
lovely
woman
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
gentleman
in
company
whom
two
accomplished
and
delightful
<EOS>
females
regard
with
veneration
,
as
the
fountain
of
their
existence
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
when
yet
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
lisped
in
language
scarce
intelligible
,
they
called
that
individual
"
Father
!
"
 
<EOS>
There
is
great
applause
.
 
<EOS>
He
gives
them
"
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
God
bless
him
!
"
 
<EOS>
They
all
shake
hands
with
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as
they
drink
the
toast
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
does
so
with
a
thrill
;
for
he
feels
that
a
mysterious
influence
pervades
the
man
who
claims
that
being
in
the
pink
scarf
for
his
daughter
.
   
<EOS>
What
saith
Mr
Pecksniff
in
reply
?
 
<EOS>
Or
rather
let
the
question
be
,
What
leaves
he
unsaid
?
 
<EOS>
Nothing
.
 
<EOS>
More
punch
is
called
for
,
and
produced
,
and
drunk
.
 
<EOS>
Enthusiasm
mounts
still
higher
.
 
<EOS>
Every
man
comes
out
freely
in
his
own
character
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
of
a
theatrical
turn
recites
.
 
<EOS>
The
vocal
gentleman
regales
them
with
a
song
.
 
<EOS>
Gander
leaves
the
Gander
of
all
former
feasts
whole
leagues
behind
.
 
<EOS>
HE
rises
to
propose
a
toast
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
,
The
Father
of
Todgers
's
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
their
common
friend
Jink
<EOS>
---
it
is
old
Jink
,
if
he
may
call
him
by
that
familiar
and
endearing
appellation
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
utters
a
frantic
negative
.
 
<EOS>
He
wo
n't
have
it
<EOS>
---
he
ca
n't
bear
it
---
it
must
n't
be
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
depth
of
feeling
is
misunderstood
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
supposed
to
be
a
little
elevated
;
and
nobody
heeds
him
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
thanks
them
from
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
,
by
many
degrees
,
the
proudest
day
in
his
humble
career
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
looks
around
him
on
the
present
occasion
,
he
feels
that
he
wants
words
in
which
to
express
his
gratitude
.
 
<EOS>
One
thing
he
will
say
.
 
<EOS>
He
hopes
it
has
been
shown
that
Todgers
's
can
be
true
to
itself
;
and
that
,
an
opportunity
arising
,
it
can
come
out
quite
as
strong
as
its
neighbours
---
perhaps
stronger
.
 
<EOS>
He
reminds
them
,
amidst
thunders
of
encouragement
,
that
they
have
heard
of
a
somewhat
similar
establishment
in
Cannon
Street
;
and
that
they
have
heard
it
praised
.
 
<EOS>
He
wishes
to
draw
no
invidious
comparisons
;
he
would
be
the
last
man
to
do
it
;
but
when
that
Cannon
Street
establishment
shall
be
able
to
produce
such
a
combination
of
wit
and
beauty
as
has
graced
that
board
that
day
,
and
shall
be
able
to
serve
up
(
<EOS>
all
things
considered
)
such
a
dinner
as
that
of
which
they
have
just
partaken
,
he
will
be
happy
to
talk
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Until
then
,
gentlemen
,
he
will
stick
to
Todgers
's
.
   
<EOS>
More
punch
,
more
enthusiasm
,
more
speeches
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
's
health
is
drunk
,
saving
the
youngest
gentleman
's
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
He
sits
apart
,
with
his
elbow
on
the
back
of
a
vacant
chair
,
and
glares
disdainfully
at
Jinkins
.
 
<EOS>
Gander
,
in
a
convulsing
speech
,
gives
them
the
health
of
Bailey
junior
;
hiccups
are
heard
;
and
a
glass
is
broken
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
feels
that
it
is
time
to
join
the
ladies
.
 
<EOS>
He
proposes
,
as
a
final
sentiment
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
worthy
to
be
remembered
separately
.
 
<EOS>
Hear
,
hear
.
 
<EOS>
So
she
is
;
no
doubt
of
it
.
<EOS>
They
all
find
fault
with
her
at
other
times
;
but
every
man
feels
now
,
that
he
could
die
in
her
defence
.
   
<EOS>
They
go
upstairs
,
where
they
are
not
expected
so
soon
;
for
Mrs
Todgers
is
asleep
,
Miss
Charity
is
adjusting
her
hair
,
and
Mercy
,
who
has
made
a
sofa
of
one
of
the
window
-
seats
is
in
a
gracefully
recumbent
attitude
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
rising
hastily
,
when
Mr
Jinkins
implores
her
,
for
all
their
sakes
,
not
to
stir
;
she
looks
too
graceful
and
too
lovely
,
he
remarks
,
to
be
disturbed
.
 
<EOS>
She
laughs
,
and
yields
,
and
fans
herself
,
and
drops
her
fan
,
and
<EOS>
there
is
a
rush
to
pick
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
Being
now
installed
,
by
one
consent
,
as
the
beauty
of
the
party
,
she
is
cruel
and
capricious
,
and
sends
gentlemen
on
messages
to
other
gentlemen
,
and
forgets
all
about
them
before
they
can
return
with
the
answer
,
and
invents
a
thousand
tortures
,
rending
their
hearts
to
pieces
.
 
<EOS>
Bailey
brings
up
the
tea
and
coffee
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
small
cluster
of
admirers
round
Charity
;
but
they
are
only
those
who
can
not
get
near
her
sister
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
is
pale
,
but
collected
,
and
still
sits
apart
;
for
his
spirit
loves
to
hold
communion
with
itself
,
and
his
soul
recoils
from
noisy
revellers
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
a
consciousness
of
his
presence
and
adoration
.
 
<EOS>
He
sees
it
flashing
sometimes
in
the
corner
of
her
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Have
a
care
<EOS>
,
Jinkins
,
ere
you
provoke
a
desperate
man
to
frenzy
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
followed
his
younger
friends
upstairs
,
and
taken
a
chair
at
the
side
of
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
also
spilt
a
cup
of
coffee
over
his
legs
without
appearing
to
be
aware
of
the
circumstance
;
nor
did
he
seem
to
know
that
there
was
muffin
on
his
knee
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
have
they
used
you
downstairs
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
asked
the
hostess
.
   
<EOS>
"
Their
conduct
has
been
such
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
as
I
can
never
think
of
without
emotion
,
or
remember
without
a
tear
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
goodness
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
that
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
low
you
are
in
your
spirits
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
man
,
my
dear
madam
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shedding
tears
and
speaking
with
an
imperfect
articulation
,
"
but
I
am
also
a
father
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
also
a
widower
.
 
<EOS>
My
feelings
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
will
not
consent
to
be
entirely
smothered
,
like
the
young
children
in
the
Tower
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
grown
up
,
and
the
more
I
press
the
bolster
on
them
,
the
more
they
look
round
the
corner
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
suddenly
became
conscious
of
the
bit
of
muffin
,
and
stared
at
it
intently
;
shaking
his
head
the
while
,
in
a
forlorn
and
imbecile
manner
,
as
if
he
regarded
it
as
his
evil
genius
,
and
mildly
reproached
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
beautiful
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
he
said
,
turning
his
glazed
eye
again
upon
her
,
without
the
least
preliminary
notice
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
had
a
small
property
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
heard
,
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
with
great
sympathy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Those
are
her
daughters
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
pointing
out
the
young
ladies
,
with
increased
emotion
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
had
no
doubt
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mercy
and
Charity
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
Charity
and
Mercy
.
 
<EOS>
Not
unholy
names
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pecksniff
!
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a
ghastly
smile
!
 
<EOS>
Are
you
ill
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
pressed
his
hand
upon
her
arm
,
and
answered
in
a
solemn
manner
,
and
a
faint
voice
,
"
Chronic
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cholic
?
"
cried
the
frightened
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Chron
-
ic
,
"
he
repeated
with
some
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
"
Chron
-
ic
.
 
<EOS>
A
chronic
disorder
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
its
victim
from
childhood
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
carrying
me
to
my
grave
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forbid
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
reckless
with
despair
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
rather
glad
of
it
,
upon
the
whole
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
like
her
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
squeeze
me
so
tight
,
pray
,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
of
the
gentlemen
should
notice

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
For
her

,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Permit
me
---
in
honour
of
her

.
 
<EOS>
For
the
sake
of
a
voice
from
the
tomb
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
VERY
like
her
Mrs
Todgers
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
world
this
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Indeed
you
may
say
that
!
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
it
is
a
vain
and

world
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
overflowing
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
These
young
people
about
us
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
sense
<EOS>
have
they
of
their
responsibilities
?
 
<EOS>
None
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
your
other
hand
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
lady
hesitated
,
and
said
"
she
did
n't
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
a
voice
from
the
grave
no
influence
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
,
dismal

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
irreligious
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
creature
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Hush
!
"
urged
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
Really
you
must
n't
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
me
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
suppose
it
's
me
;
it
's
the

;
it
's

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Pecksniff
deceased
,
must
have
had
an
unusually
thick
and
husky
voice
for
a

,
and
rather
a

,
and
to

truth
somewhat
of

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
been

,
Mrs
Todgers
,

.
 
<EOS>
It
has
reminded
me
of
my
loneliness
.
 
<EOS>
What
am
I
in
the
world
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
An

,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
There

consolation
in

,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Am
I
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
better
man
living
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
I
am
sure
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
smiled
through
his
tears
,
and
slightly
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
he
said
,
"
thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
great
happiness
to
me
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
to
make
young
people
happy
.
 
<EOS>
The
happiness
of
my
pupils
is
my
chief
object
.
 
<EOS>
I
dote
upon
'em
.
 
<EOS>
They
dote
upon
me
too
---
 
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Always
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
they
say
they
have
n't
improved
,
ma'am
,
"
whispered
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
at

with
profound

,
and
motioning
to

to
advance

a

.
 
<EOS>
"
When
they
say
they
have
n't
improved
,
ma'am
,
and
the
premium
was
too

,
they
lie
!
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't

to

mentioned
;
you
will
understand
me
;
but
I

as

,
they
lie
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Base
wretches
they
must
be
!
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
you
are

.
 
<EOS>
I
respect
you
for
that

.
 
<EOS>
A
word
in
your
ear
.
 
<EOS>
To
Parents
and
Guardians
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
in
confidence
,
Mrs
Todgers
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
strictest
,
of
course
!
"
cried
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
Parents
and
Guardians
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
eligible
opportunity
now
offers
,
which
unites
the
advantages
of
the
best
practical
architectural
education
with
the

of
a
home
,
and
the
constant

with
some
,
who
,
however
humble
their
sphere
and
limited
their
capacity
---
observe
!
<EOS>
---
are
not
unmindful
of
their
moral
responsibilities
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
looked
a
little
puzzled
to
know
what
this
might
mean
,
as
well
she
might
;
for
it
was
,
as
the
reader
may
perchance
remember
,
Mr
Pecksniff
's
usual
form
of
advertisement
when
he
wanted
a

;
and
seemed
to
have
no
particular
reference
,
at

,
to
anything
.
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
held
up
his
finger
as

to

not
to
interrupt

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
any
parent
or

,
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
who
desires
to
avail

of
such
an
opportunity
for
a
young

?
 
<EOS>
An
orphan
would
be
preferred
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
of
any
orphan
with
three
or
four
hundred
pound
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
reflected
,
and
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
hear
of
an
orphan
with
three
or
four
hundred
pound
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
let
that
dear
orphan
's
friends
apply
,
by
letter
post
-
paid
,
to
S*P
,
Post
Office
,
Salisbury
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
who
he
is
exactly
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
falling
heavily
against

;
"
Chronic
---
chronic
!
 
<EOS>
Let
's
have
a
little
drop
of
something
to
drink
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
life
,
Miss
Pecksniffs
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
Todgers
,
aloud
,
"
your
dear
pa
's
took
very
poorly
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
straightened
himself
by
a
surprising

,
as
every
one
turned
hastily
towards
him
;
and
standing
on

,
regarded

with

.
 
<EOS>
Gradually

gave
place
to
a
smile
;
a
feeble
,

,

;
bland
,

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
repine
,
my
friends
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
tenderly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
not
weep
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
chronic
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
with
these
words
,
after
making
a
futile
attempt
to
pull
off
his
shoes
,
he
fell
into
the
fireplace
.
   
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
had
him
out
in
a
second
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
before
a
hair
upon
his
head
was
singed
,
he
had
him
on
the
hearth
-
rug
---
her
father
!
   
<EOS>
She
was
almost
beside
herself
.
 
<EOS>
So
was
her
sister
.
 
<EOS>
Jinkins
consoled
them
both
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
consoled
them
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
had
something
to
say
,
except
the
youngest
gentleman
in
company
,
who
with
a
noble
self
-
devotion
did
the
heavy
work
,
and
held
up
Mr
Pecksniff
's
head
without
being
taken
notice
of
by
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
they
gathered
round
,
and
agreed
to
carry
him
upstairs
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
was
rebuked
by
Jinkins
for
tearing
Mr
Pecksniff
's
coat
!
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
But
no
matter
.
   
<EOS>
They
carried
him
upstairs
,
and
crushed
the
youngest
gentleman
at
every
step
.
 
<EOS>
His
bedroom
was
at
the
top
of
the
house
,
and
it
was
a
long
way
;
but
they
got
him
there
in
course
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
them
frequently
on
the
road
for
a
little
drop
of
something
to
drink
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
an
idiosyncrasy
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
in
company
proposed
a
draught
of
water
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
called
him
opprobious
names
for
the
suggestion
.
   
<EOS>
Jinkins
and
Gander
took
the
rest
upon
themselves
,
and
made
him
as
comfortable
as
they
could
,
on
the
outside
of
his
bed
;
and
when
he
seemed
disposed
to
sleep
,
they
left
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
before
they
had
all
gained
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
,
a
vision
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
strangely
attired
,
was
seen
to
flutter
on
the
top
landing
.
 
<EOS>
He
desired
to
collect
their
sentiments
,
it
seemed
,
upon
the
nature
of
human
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
friends
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
over
the
banisters
,
"
let
us
improve
our
minds
by
mutual
inquiry
and
discussion
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
be
moral
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
contemplate
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
Jinkins
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
"
cried
that
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
to
bed
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
bed
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bed
!
 
<EOS>
"
Tis
the
voice
of
the
sluggard
,
I
hear
him
complain
<EOS>
,
you
have
woke
me
too
soon
,
I
must
slumber
again
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
young
orphan
will
repeat
the
remainder
of
that
simple
piece
from
Doctor
Watts
's
collection
,
an
eligible
opportunity
now
offers
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nobody
volunteered
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
soothing
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
after
a
pause
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Extremely
so
.
 
<EOS>
Cool
and
refreshing
;
particularly
to
the
legs
!
 
<EOS>
The
legs
of
the
human
subject
,
my
friends
,
are
a
beautiful
production
.
<EOS>
Compare
them
with
wooden
legs
,
and
observe
the
difference
between
the
anatomy
of
nature
and
the
anatomy
of
art
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
leaning
over
the
banisters
,
with
an
odd
recollection
of
his
familiar
manner
among
new
pupils
at
home
,
"
that
I
should
very
much
like
to
see
Mrs
Todgers
's
notion
of
a
wooden
leg
,
if
perfectly
agreeable
to
herself
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
it
appeared
impossible
to
entertain
any
reasonable
hopes
of
him
after
this
speech
,
Mr
Jinkins
and
Mr
Gander
went
upstairs
again
,
and
once
more
got
him
into
bed
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
had
not
descended
to
the
second
floor
before
he
was
out
again
;
nor
,
when
they
had
repeated
the
process
,
had
they
descended
the
first
flight
,
before
he
was
out
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
as
often
as
he
was
shut
up
in
his
own
room
,
he
darted
out
afresh
,
charged
with
some
new
moral
sentiment
,
which
he
continually
repeated
over
the
banisters
,
with
extraordinary
relish
,
and
an
irrepressible
desire
for
the
improvement
of
his
fellow
creatures
that
nothing
could
subdue
.
   
<EOS>
Under
these
circumstances
,
when
they
had
got
him
into
bed
for
the
thirtieth
time
or
so
,
Mr
Jinkins
held
him
,
while
his
companion
went
downstairs
in
search
of
Bailey
junior
,
with
whom
he
presently
returned
.
 
<EOS>
That
youth
having
been
apprised
of
the
service
required
of
him
,
was
in
great
spirits
,
and
brought
up
a
stool
,
a
candle
,
and
his
supper
;
to
the
end
that
he
might
keep
watch
outside
the
bedroom
door
with
tolerable
comfort
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
had
completed
his
arrangements
,
they
locked
Mr
Pecksniff
in
,
and
left
the
key
on
the
outside
;
charging
the
young
page
to
listen
attentively
for
symptoms
of
an
apoplectic
nature
,
with
which
the
patient
might
be
troubled
,
and
,
in
case
of
any
such
presenting
themselves
,
to
summon
them
without
delay
.
 
<EOS>
To
which
Mr
Bailey
modestly
replied
that
"
he
hoped
he
knowed
wot
o'clock
it
wos
in
gineral
,
and
did
n't
date
his
letters
to
his
friends
from
Todgers
's
for
nothing
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
10
.
<EOS>
Containing
strange
matter
,
on
which
many
events
in
this
history
may
,
for
their
good
or
evil
influence
,
chiefly
depend
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
came
to
town
on
business
.
 
<EOS>
Had
he
forgotten
that
?
<EOS>
Was
he
always
taking
his
pleasure
with
Todgers
's
jovial
brood
,
unmindful
of
the
serious
demands
,
whatever
they
might
be
,
upon
his
calm
consideration
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
   
<EOS>
Time
and
tide
will
wait
for
no
man
,
saith
the
adage
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
men
have
to
wait
for
time
and
tide
.
 
<EOS>
That
tide
which
,
taken
at
the
flood
,
would
lead
Seth
Pecksniff
on
to
fortune
,
was
marked
down
in
the
table
,
and
about
to
flow
.
 
<EOS>
No
idle
Pecksniff
lingered
far
inland
,
unmindful
of
the
changes
of
the
stream
;
but
there
,
upon
the
water
's
edge
,
over
his
shoes
already
,
stood
the
worthy
creature
,
prepared
to
wallow
in
the
very
mud
,
so
that
it
slid
towards
the
quarter
of
his
hope
.
   
<EOS>
The
trustfulness
of
his
two
fair
daughters
was
beautiful
indeed
.
<EOS>
They
had
that
firm
reliance
on
their
parent
's
nature
,
which
taught
them
to
feel
certain
that
in
all
he
did
he
had
his
purpose
straight
and
full
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
its
noble
end
and
object
was
himself
,
which
almost
of
necessity
included
them
,
they
knew
.
 
<EOS>
The
devotion
of
these
maids
was
perfect
.
   
<EOS>
Their
filial
confidence
was
rendered
the
more
touching
,
by
their
having
no
knowledge
of
their
parent
's
real
designs
,
in
the
present
instance
.
 
<EOS>
All
that
they
knew
of
his
proceedings
was
,
that
every
morning
,
after
the
early
breakfast
,
he
repaired
to
the
post
office
and
inquired
for
letters
.
 
<EOS>
That
task
performed
,
his
business
for
the
day
was
over
;
and
he
again
relaxed
,
until
the
rising
of
another
sun
proclaimed
the
advent
of
another
post
.
   
<EOS>
This
went
on
for
four
or
five
days
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
one
morning
,
Mr
Pecksniff
returned
with
a
breathless
rapidity
,
strange
to
observe
in
him
,
at
other
times
so
calm
;
and
,
seeking
immediate
speech
with
his
daughters
,
shut
himself
up
with
them
in
private
conference
for
two
whole
hours
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
that
passed
in
this
period
,
only
the
following
words
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
utterance
are
known
:
   
<EOS>
"
How
he
has
come
to
change
so
very
much
(
if
it
should
turn
out
as
I
expect
,
that
he
has
)
,
we
need
n't
stop
to
inquire
.
 
<EOS>
My
dears
,
I
have
my
thoughts
upon
the
subject
,
but
I
will
not
impart
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
that
we
will
not
be
proud
,
resentful
,
or
unforgiving
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
wants
our
friendship
he
shall
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
We
know
our
duty
,
I
hope
!
"
   
<EOS>
That
same
day
at
noon
,
an
old
gentleman
alighted
from
a
hackney
-
coach
at
the
post
-
office
,
and
,
giving
his
name
,
inquired
for
a
letter
addressed
to
himself
,
and
directed
to
be
left
till
called
for
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
lying
there
some
days
.
 
<EOS>
The
superscription
was
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
hand
,
and
it
was
sealed
with
Mr
Pecksniff
's
seal
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
very
short
,
containing
indeed
nothing
more
than
an
address
"
with
Mr
Pecksniff
's
respectful
,
and
(
not
withstanding
what
has
passed
)
sincerely
affectionate
regards
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
tore
off
the
direction
---
scattering
the
rest
in
fragments
to
the
winds
---
and
giving
it
to
the
coachman
,
bade
him
drive
as
near
that
place
as
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
In
pursuance
of
these
instructions
he
was
driven
to
the
Monument
;
where
he
again
alighted
,
and
dismissed
the
vehicle
,
and
walked
towards
Todgers
's
.
   
<EOS>
Though
the
face
,
and
form
,
and
gait
of
this
old
man
,
and
even
his
grip
of
the
stout
stick
on
which
he
leaned
,
were
all
expressive
of
a
resolution
not
easily
shaken
,
and
a
purpose
(
it
matters
little
<EOS>
whether
right
or
wrong
,
just
now
)
such
as
in
other
days
might
have
survived
the
rack
,
and
had
its
strongest
life
in
weakest
death
;
still
there
were
grains
of
hesitation
in
his
mind
,
which
made
him
now
avoid
the
house
he
sought
,
and
loiter
to
and
fro
in
a
gleam
of
sunlight
,
that
brightened
the
little
churchyard
hard
by
.
 
<EOS>
There
may
have
been
,
in
the
presence
of
those
idle
heaps
of
dust
among
the
busiest
stir
of
life
,
something
to
increase
his
wavering
;
but
there
he
walked
,
awakening
the
echoes
as
he
paced
up
and
down
,
until
the
church
clock
,
striking
the
quarters
for
the
second
time
since
he
had
been
there
,
roused
him
from
his
meditation
.
 
<EOS>
Shaking
off
his
incertitude
as
the
air
parted
with
the
sound
of
the
bells
,
he
walked
rapidly
to
the
house
,
and
knocked
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
seated
in
the
landlady
's
little
room
,
and
his
visitor
found
him
reading
---
by
an
accident
;
he
apologised
for
it
---
an
excellent
theological
work
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
cake
and
wine
upon
a
little
table
---
by
another
accident
,
for
which
he
also
apologised
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
he
said
,
he
had
given
his
visitor
up
,
and
was
about
to
partake
of
that
simple
refreshment
with
his
children
,
when
he
knocked
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
daughters
are
well
?
<EOS>
"
said
old
Martin
,
laying
down
his
hat
and
stick
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
endeavoured
to
conceal
his
agitation
as
a
father
when
he
answered
Yes
,
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
good
girls
,
he
said
,
very
good
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
not
venture
to
recommend
Mr
Chuzzlewit
to
take
the
easy
-
chair
,
or
to
keep
out
of
the
draught
from
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
made
any
such
suggestion
,
he
would
expose
himself
,
he
feared
,
to
most
unjust
suspicion
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
,
therefore
,
content
himself
with
remarking
that
there
was
an
easy
-
chair
in
the
room
,
and
that
the
door
was
far
from
being
air
-
tight
.
 
<EOS>
This
latter
imperfection
,
he
might
perhaps
venture
to
add
,
was
not
uncommonly
to
be
met
with
in
old
houses
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
sat
down
in
the
easy
-
chair
,
and
after
a
few
moments
'
silence
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
let
me
thank
you
for
coming
to
London
so
promptly
,
at
my
almost
unexplained
request
;
I
need
scarcely
add
,
at
my
cost
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
YOUR
cost
,
my
good
sir
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
a
tone
of
great
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
,
"
said
Martin
,
waving
his
hand
impatiently
,
"
my
habit
to
put
my
---
well
!
<EOS>
my
relatives
---
to
any
personal
expense
to
gratify
my
caprices
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Caprices
,
my
good
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
scarcely
the
proper
word
either
,
in
this
instance
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
inwardly
very
much
relieved
to
hear
it
,
though
he
did
n't
at
all
know
why
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
"
repeated
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
a
caprice
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
built
up
on
reason
,
proof
,
and
cool
comparison
.
 
<EOS>
Caprices
never
are
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
I
am
not
a
capricious
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Most
assuredly
not
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
?
"
returned
the
other
quickly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
begin
to
know
it
now
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
to
test
and
prove
it
,
in
time
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
You
and
yours
are
to
find
that
I
can
be
constant
,
and
am
not
to
be
diverted
from
my
end
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
very
much
regret
,
"
Martin
resumed
,
looking
steadily
at
him
,
and
speaking
in

;
"
I
very
much
regret
that
you
and
I
held
such

conversation
together
,
as
that
which
passed
between

at

.
 
<EOS>
I
very

regret
that
I
laid
open
to
you
what
were

my

of
you
,
so

I
did
.
 
<EOS>
The
intentions
that
I
bear
towards
you
now
are
of
another
kind
;
deserted
by
all
in
whom
I
have
ever
trusted
;
hoodwinked
and
beset
by
all
who
should
help
and
sustain

;
I
fly
to
you
for
refuge
.
 
<EOS>
I
confide
in
you
to
be
my
ally
;
to
attach
yourself
to
me
by
ties
of
Interest
and
Expectation
"
---
he
laid
great
stress
upon
these
words
,
though
Mr
Pecksniff
particularly
begged
him
not
to
mention
it
;
"
and
to
help
me
to
visit
the
consequences
of
the
very
worst
species
of
meanness
,
dissimulation
,
and
subtlety
,
on
the
right
heads
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
noble
sir
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
catching
at
his
outstretched
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
YOU
regret
the
having
harboured
unjust
thoughts
of
me
!
<EOS>
YOU
with
those
grey
hairs
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Regrets
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
are
the
natural
property
of
grey
hairs
;
and
I
enjoy
,
in
common
with
all
other
men
,
at
least
my
share
of
such
inheritance
.
 
<EOS>
And
so
enough
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
regret
having
been
severed
from
you
so
long
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
known
you
sooner
,
and
sooner
used
you
as
you
well
deserve
,
I
might
have
been
a
happier
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
up
to
the
ceiling
,
and
clasped
his
hands
in
rapture
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
daughters
,
"
said
Martin
,
after
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
them
.
 
<EOS>
Are
they
like
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
nose
of
my
eldest
and
the
chin
of
my
youngest
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
returned
the
widower
,
"
their
sainted
parent
(
not
myself
,
their
mother
)
lives
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
in
person
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Morally
,
morally
.
"
   
"
'
Tis
not
for
me
to
say
,
"
retorted
Mr
Pecksniff
with
a
gentle

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
my
best
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
wish
to
see
them
,
"
said
Martin
;
"
are
they
near
at
hand
?
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
,
very
near
;
for
they
had
in
fact
been
listening
at
the
door
from
the
beginning
of
this
conversation
until
now
,
when
they
precipitately
retired
.
 
<EOS>
Having
wiped
the
signs
of
weakness
from
his
eyes
,
and
so
given
them
time
to
get
upstairs
,
Mr
Pecksniff
opened
the
door
,
and
mildly
cried
in
the

,
   
"
<EOS>
My
own
darlings
,
where
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
my
dear
pa
!
"
replied

of
Charity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
down
into
the
back
parlour
,
if
you
please
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
and
bring
your
sister
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
pa
,
"
cried
Merry
;
and
down
they
came
directly
(
being
all
obedience
)
,
singing
as
they
came
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
could
exceed
the
astonishment
of
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
when
they
found
a
stranger
with
their
dear
papa
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
could
surpass
their
mute
amazement
when
he
said
,
"
My
children
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
when
he
told
them
that
Mr
Chuzzlewit
and
he
were
friends
,
and
that
Mr
Chuzzlewit
had
said
such
kind
and
tender
words
as
pierced
his
very
heart
,
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
cried
with
one
accord
,
"
Thank
Heaven
for
this
!
"
and
fell
upon
the
old
man
's
neck
.
<EOS>
And
when
they
had
embraced
him
with
such
fervour
of
affection
that
no
words
can
describe
it
,
they
grouped
themselves
about
his
chair
,
and
hung
over
him
,
as
figuring
to
themselves
no
earthly
joy
like
that
of
ministering
to
his
wants
,
and
crowding
into
the
remainder
of
his
life
,
the
love
they
would
have
diffused
over
their
whole
existence
,
from
infancy
,
if
he
---
dear
obdurate
!
---
<EOS>
had
but
consented
to
receive
the
precious
offering
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
attentively
from
one
to
the
other
,
and
then
at
Mr
Pecksniff
,
several
times
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
"
he
asked
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
happening
to
catch
his
eye
in
its
descent
;
for
until
now
it
had
been
piously
upraised
,
with
something
of
that
expression
which
the
poetry
of
ages
has
attributed
to
a

bird
,
when
breathing
its
last
amid
the
ravages
of
an
electric
storm
:
"
What
are
their
names
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
told
him
,
and
added
,
rather
hastily
;
his
caluminators
would
have
said
,
with
a
view
to
any
testamentary
thoughts
that
might
be
flitting
through
old
Martin
's
mind
;
"
Perhaps
,
my
dears
,
you
had
better
write
them
down
.
 
<EOS>
Your
humble
autographs
are
of
no
value
in
themselves
,
but
affection
may
prize
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Affection
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
will
expend
itself
on
the
living
originals
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
trouble
yourselves
,
my
girls
<EOS>
,
I
shall
not
so
easily
forget
you
,
Charity
and
Mercy
,
as
to
need
such
tokens
of
remembrance
.
 
<EOS>
Cousin
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
alacrity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
never
sit
down
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
---
yes
---
occasionally
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
who
had
been
standing
all
this
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
do
so
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can
you
ask
me
,
"
returned
Mr
Pecksniff
,
slipping
into
a
chair
immediately
,
"
whether
I
will
do
anything
that
you
desire
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
talk
confidently
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
and
you
mean
well
;
but
I
fear
you
do
n't
know
what
an
old
man
's
humours
are
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
what
it
is
to
be
required
to
court
his
likings
and
dislikings
;
to
adapt
yourself
to
his
prejudices
;
to
do
his
bidding
,
be
it
what

may
;
to
bear
with
his
distrusts
and
jealousies
;
and
always
still
be
zealous
in
his
service
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
remember
how
numerous
these
failings
are
in
me
,
and
judge
of
their
occasional
enormity
by
the
injurious
thoughts
I
lately
entertained
of
you
,
I
hardly
dare
to
claim
you
for
my
friend
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
worthy
sir
,
"
returned
his

,
"
how
CAN
you
talk
in
such
a
painful
strain
!
 
<EOS>
What
was
more
natural
than
that
you
should
make
one
slight
mistake
,
when
in
all
other
respects
you
were
so
very

,
and
have
had
such

---
such
very
sad
and
undeniable
reason
---
to
judge
of
every
one
about
you
in
the
worst
light
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
lenient
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
always
said
,
my
girls
and
I
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
with
increasing

,
"
that
while
we
mourned
the
heaviness
of
our
misfortune
in
being
confounded

the
base
and

,
still
we
could
not
wonder
at

.
 
<EOS>
My
dears
,
you
remember
?
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
vividly
!
 
<EOS>
A
thousand
times
!
   
<EOS>
"
We
uttered
no
complaint
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Occasionally

had

with

Truth
would
in
the

,

Virtue

;
but
not
often
.
<EOS>
My
loves
,
you
recollect
?
"
   
<EOS>
Recollect
!
 
<EOS>
Could
he
doubt
it
!
 
<EOS>
Dearest
pa
,
what
strange
unnecessary
questions
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
I
saw
you
,
"
resumed

Pecksniff
,

,
"
in

,
I

in
me
,

;
that

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
---
not
all
,
"
said
Martin
,
who
had

upon

for
some

,
and

;
"
you
said
much
more
,
which
,

to
other
circumstances
that
have

to

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
spoke

,

,
on
behalf
of
---
<EOS>
I
need
n't
name
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
whom
I
mean
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Trouble
was
expressed
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's

,
as

pressed
his
hot
hands
together
,
and
replied
,
with

,
"
Quite
disinterestedly
,
sir
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
said
old
Martin
,
in
his
quiet

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
said
so
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
disinterested
too
,
in
you
,
to
draw
that
herd
of
harpies
off
from
me
,
and
be
their
victim
yourself
;
most
other

have
suffered

to
display

in
all
their

,
and
would

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
felt
for
me
,
and
drew

,
for

I
owe
you
many

.
 
<EOS>
Although
I
left

,
I
know
what
passed

,
you
see
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
amaze

,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
;
which

enough
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
knowledge
of
your

,
"
said
the
old
man
,
does
not

.
 
<EOS>
You
have

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

"
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
---

?
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
For

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

.
"
   
<EOS>

I

"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Deceit
---
 
deceit
,

Chuzzlewit
,
would

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The

fair

,
but

Miss
Mercy
,
whom
,

,

looked
full
in

,

greater

interest
than

yet

in

.
<EOS>
His

again

Mr
Pecksniff
,
as

,
composedly
:
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
know
that
he
has
made

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
rubbing
his
hair
up
very
stiff
upon

,
and
staring

at

.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
becoming
tremendous
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
the
fact
?
"
repeated
Martin
   
<EOS>
"
Surely
not
without
his
grandfather
's
consent
and
approbation
my
dear
sir
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
tell
me
that
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
honour
of
human
nature
,
say
you
're
not
about
to
tell
me
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
he
had
suppressed
it
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
The
indignation
felt
by
Mr
Pecksniff
at
this
terrible
disclosure
,
was
only
to
be
equalled
by
the
kindling
anger
of
his
daughters
.
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
Had
they
taken
to
their
hearth
and
home
a
secretly
contracted
serpent
;
a
crocodile
,
who
had
made
a
furtive
offer
of
his
hand
;
an
imposition
on
society
;
a
bankrupt
bachelor
with
no
effects
,
trading
with
the
spinster
world
on
false
pretences
!
 
<EOS>
And
oh
,
to
think
that
he
should
have
disobeyed
and
practised
on
that
sweet
,
that
venerable
gentleman
,
whose
name
he
bore
;
that
kind
and
tender

;
his
more
than
father
---
to
say
nothing
at
all
of
mother
---
horrible
,
horrible
!
 
<EOS>
To
turn
him
out
with
ignominy
would
be
treatment
much
too
good
.
 
<EOS>
Was
there
nothing
else
that
could
be
done
to

?
 
<EOS>
Had
he
incurred
no
legal
pains
and
penalties
?
 
<EOS>
Could
it
be
that
the
statutes
of
the
land
were
so
remiss
as
to
have
affixed
no
punishment
to
such

?
 
<EOS>
Monster
;
how
basely
had

!
   
<EOS>
"
I

second
me
<EOS>
so

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will

full

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

Pecksniff
,
"
not

,

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
You
MAY
look

as
done
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

topic
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
<EOS>
on

I
hope

.
 
<EOS>
You

Mary
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

I

,

,
as

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Excuse

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
told

her
history
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
I
also

,

,

dears
,
"

Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Silly
girls
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
---
quite
moved
by
it
,
they
were
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

now
!
"
said
Martin
,

;
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
find

have
no

!
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
You
have
no
cause
for
any
,
to

.
 
<EOS>
She
has
nothing
to
gain
from
me
,
my
dears
,
and
she
knows

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
murmured
their
approval
of
this
wise
arrangement
,
and
their
cordial
sympathy
with
its
interesting
object
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
have
anticipated
what
has
come
to
pass
between
us
four
,
"
said
the
old
man
thoughtfully
;
"
but
it
is
too
late
to
think
of
that
.
<EOS>
You
would
receive
her
courteously
,
young
ladies
,
and
be
kind
to
her
,
if
need
were
?
"
   
<EOS>
Where
was
the
orphan
whom
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
would
not
have
cherished
in
their
sisterly
bosom
!
 
<EOS>
But
when
that
orphan
was
commended
to
their
care
by
one
on
whom
the
dammed
-
up
love
of
years
was
gushing
forth
,
what
exhaustless
stores
of
pure
affection
yearned
to
expend
themselves
upon
her
!
   
<EOS>
An
interval
ensued
,
during
which
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
in
an
absent
frame
of
mind
,
sat
gazing
at
the
ground
,
without
uttering
a
word
;
and
as
it
was
plain
that
he
had
no
desire
to
be
interrupted
in
his
meditations
,
Mr
Pecksniff
and
his
daughters
were
profoundly
silent
also
.
 
<EOS>
During
the
whole
of
the
foregoing
dialogue
,
he
had
borne
his
part
with
a
cold
,
passionless
promptitude
,
as
though
he
had
learned
and
painfully
rehearsed
it
all
a
hundred
times
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
his
expressions
were
warmest
and
his
language
most
encouraging
,
he
had
retained
the
same
manner
,
without
the
least
abatement
.
 
<EOS>
But
now
there
was
a
keener
brightness
in
his
eye
,
and
more
expression
in
his
voice
,
as
he
said
,
awakening
from
his
thoughtful
mood
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
what
will
be
said
of
this
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
reflected
?
"
   
"
Said
of
what
,
my
dear
sir
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
asked
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
this
new
understanding
between
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
benevolently
sagacious
,
and
at
the
same
time
far
above
all
earthly
misconstruction
,
as
he
shook
his
head
,
and
observed
that
a
great
many
things
would
be
said
of
it
,
no
doubt
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
great
many
,
"
rejoined
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Some
will
say
that
I
dote
in
my
old
age
;
that
illness
has
shaken
me
;
that
I
have
lost
all
strength
of
mind
,
and
have
grown
childish
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
bear
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
answered
that
it
would
be
dreadfully
hard
to
bear
,
but
he
thought
he
could
,
if
he
made
a
great
effort
.
   
<EOS>
"
Others
will
say
---
<EOS>
I
speak
of
disappointed
,
angry
people
only
---
that
you
have
lied
and
fawned
,
and
wormed
yourself
through
dirty
ways
into
my
favour
;
by
such
concessions
and
such
crooked
deeds
,
such
meannesses
and
vile
endurances
,
as
nothing
could
repay
;
no
,
not
the
legacy
of
half
the
world
we
live
in
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
bear
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
made
reply
that
this
would
be
also
very
hard
to
bear
,
as
reflecting
,
in
some
degree
,
on
the
discernment
of
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
<EOS>
Still
he
had
a
modest
confidence
that
he
could
sustain
the
calumny
,
with
the
help
of
a
good
conscience
,
and
that
gentleman
's
friendship
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
the
great
mass
of
slanderers
,
"
said
old
Martin
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
"
the
tale
,
as
I
clearly
foresee
,
will
run
thus
:
That
to
mark
my
contempt
for
the
rabble
<EOS>
whom
I
despised
,
I
chose
from
among
them
the
very
worst
,
and
made
him
do
my
will
,
and
pampered
and
enriched
him
at
the
cost
of
all
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
after
casting
about
for
the
means
of
a
punishment
which
should
rankle
in
the
bosoms
of
these
kites
the
most
,
and
strike
into
their
gall
,
I
devised
this
scheme
at
a
time
when
the
last
link
in
the
chain
of
grateful
love
and
duty
,
that
held
me
to
my
race
,
was
roughly
snapped
asunder
;
roughly
,
for
I
loved
him
well
;
roughly
,
for
I
had
ever
put
my
trust
in
his
affection
;
roughly
,
for
that
he
broke
it
when
I
loved
him
most
<EOS>
---
God
help
me
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and
he
without
a
pang
could
throw
me
off
,
while
I
clung
about
his
heart
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
dismissing
this
passionate
outburst
as
suddenly
as
he
had
yielded
to
it
,
"
is
your
mind
made
up
to
bear
this
likewise
?
 
<EOS>
Lay
your
account
with
having
it
to
bear
,
and
put
no
trust
in
being
set
right
by
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
cried
Pecksniff
in
an
ecstasy
,
"
for
such
a
man
as
you
have
shown
yourself
to
be
this
day
;
for
a
man
so
injured
,
yet
so
very
humane
;
for
a
man
so
---
I
am
at
a
loss
what
precise
term
to
use
---
yet
<EOS>
at
the
same
time
so
remarkably
---
I
do
n't
know
how
to
express
my
meaning
;
for
such
a
man
as
I
have
described
,
I
hope
it
is
no
presumption
to
say
that
I
,
and
I
am
sure
I
may
add
my
children
also
<EOS>
(
my
dears
,
we
perfectly
agree
in
this
,
I
think
?
)
,
would
bear
anything
whatever
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Enough
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
charge
no
consequences
on
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
do
you
retire
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whenever
you
please
,
<EOS>
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
To
-
night
if
you
desire
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
desire
nothing
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
"
that
is
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
Such
a
request
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
be
ready
to
return
at
the
end
of
this
week
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
very
time
of
all
others
that
Mr
Pecksniff
would
have
suggested
if
it
had
been
left
to
him
to
make
his
own
choice
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
his
daughters
---
the
words
,
"
Let
us
be
at
home
on
Saturday
,
dear
pa
,
"
were
actually
upon
their
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
expenses
,
cousin
,
"
said
Martin
,
taking
a
folded
slip
of
paper
from
his
pocketbook
,
"
may
possibly
exceed
that
amount
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
let
me
know
the
balance
that
I
owe
you
,
when
we
next
meet
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
useless
if
I
told
you
where
I
live
just
now
;
indeed
,
I
have
no
fixed
abode
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
have
,
you
shall
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
and
your
daughters
may
expect
to
see
me
before
long
;
in
the
meantime
I
need
not
tell
you
that
we
keep
our
own
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
What
you
will
do
when
you
get
home
is
understood
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
no
account
of
it
at
any
time
;
and
never
refer
to
it
in
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
that
as
a
favour
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
commonly
a
man
of
few
words
,
cousin
;
and
all
that
need
be
said
just
now
is
said
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
One
glass
of
wine
---
one
morsel
of
this
homely
cake
?
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
venturing
to
detain
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dears
---
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
sisters
flew
to
wait
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
girls
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
excuse
their
agitation
,
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
made
up
of
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
A
bad
commodity
to
go
through
the
world
with
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
!
 
<EOS>
My
youngest
daughter
is
almost
as
much
of
a
woman
as
my
eldest
,
is
she
not
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
IS
the
youngest
?
"
asked
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mercy
,
by
five
years
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
sometimes
venture
to
consider
her
rather
a
fine
figure
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Speaking
as
an
artist
,
I
may
perhaps
be
permitted
to
suggest
that
its
outline
is
graceful
and
correct
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
naturally
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
drying
his
hands
upon
his
handkerchief
,
and
looking
anxiously
in
his
cousin
's
face
at
almost
every
word
,
"
proud
,
if
I
may
use
the
expression
,
to
have
a
daughter
who
is
constructed
on
the
best
models
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
seems
to
have
a
lively
disposition
,
"
observed
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
quite
remarkable
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
defined
her
character
,
my
dear
sir
,
as
correctly
as
if
you
had
known
her
from
her
birth
.
 
<EOS>
She
HAS
a
lively
disposition
.
 
<EOS>
I
assure
you
,
my
dear
sir
,
that
in
our
unpretending
home
her
gaiety
is
delightful
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
returned
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Charity
,
upon
the
other
hand
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
is
remarkable
for
strong
sense
,
and
for
rather
a
deep
tone
of
sentiment
,
if
the
partiality
of
a
father
may
be
excused
in
saying
so
.
 
<EOS>
A
wonderful
affection
between
them
,
my
dear
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
drink
your
health
.
<EOS>
Bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
little
thought
,
"
retorted
Martin
,
"
but
a
month
ago
,
that
I
should
be
breaking
bread
and
pouring
wine
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
drink
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Not
at
all
abashed
by
the
extraordinary
abruptness
with
which
these
latter
words
were
spoken
,
Mr
Pecksniff
thanked
him
devoutly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
let
me
go
,
"
said
Martin
,
putting
down
the
wine
when
he
had
merely
touched
it
with
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dears
,
good
morning
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
But
this
distant
form
of
farewell
was
by
no
means
tender
enough
for
the
yearnings
of
the
young
ladies
,
who
again
embraced
him
with
all
their
hearts
---
with
all
their
arms
at
any
rate
---
to
which
parting
caresses
their
new
-
found
friend
submitted
with
a
better
grace
than
might
have
been
expected
from
one
who
,
not
a
moment
before
,
had
pledged
their
parent
in
such
a
very
uncomfortable
manner
.
 
<EOS>
These
endearments
terminated
,
he
took
a
hasty
leave
of
Mr
Pecksniff
and
withdrew
,
followed
to
the
door
by
both
father
and
daughters
,
who
stood
there
kissing
their
hands
and
beaming
with
affection
until
he
disappeared
;
though
,
by
the
way
,
he
never
once
looked
back
,
after
he
had
crossed
the
threshold
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
returned
into
the
house
,
and
were
again
alone
in
Mrs
Todgers
's
room
,
the
two
young
ladies
exhibited
an
unusual
amount
of
gaiety
;
insomuch
that
they
clapped
their
hands
,
and
laughed
,
and
looked
with
roguish
aspects
and
a
bantering
air
upon
their
dear
papa
.
 
<EOS>
This
conduct
was
so
very
unaccountable
,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
(
being
singularly
grave
himself
)
could
scarcely
choose
but
ask
them
what
it
meant
;
and
took
them
to
task
,
in
his
gentle
manner
,
for
yielding
to
such
light
emotions
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
was
possible
to
divine
any
cause
for
this
merriment
,
even
the
most
remote
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
should
not
reprove
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
you
can
have
none
<EOS>
whatever
---
<EOS>
oh
,
really
,
really
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
admonition
had
so
little
effect
on
Mercy
,
that
she
was
obliged
to
hold
her
handkerchief
before
her
rosy
lips
,
and
to
throw
herself
back
in
her
chair
,
with
every
demonstration
of
extreme
amusement
;
which
want
of
duty
<EOS>
so
offended
Mr
Pecksniff
that
he
reproved
her
in
set
terms
,
and
gave
her
his
parental
advice
to
correct
herself
in
solitude
and
contemplation
.
 
<EOS>
But
at
that
juncture
they
were
disturbed
by
the
sound
of
voices
in
dispute
;
and
as
it
proceeded
from
the
next
room
,
the
subject
matter
of
the
altercation
quickly
reached
their
ears
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
that
!
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
said
the
young
gentleman
who
had
been
the
youngest
gentleman
in
company
on
the
day
of
the
festival
;
"
I
do
n't
care
THAT
,
ma'am
,
"
said
he
,
snapping
his
fingers
,
"
for
Jinkins
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
suppose
I
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
certain
you
do
n't
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
too
independent
a
spirit
,
I
know
,
to
yield
to
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
And
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
reason
why
you
should
give
way
to
any
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Everybody
must
be
well
aware
of
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
no
more
of
admitting
daylight
into
the
fellow
,
"
said
the
youngest
gentleman
,
in
a
desperate
voice
,
"
than
if
he
was
a
bulldog
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
did
not
stop
to
inquire
whether
,
as
a
matter
of
principle
,
there
was
any
particular
reason
for
admitting
daylight
even
into
a
bulldog
,
otherwise
than
by
the
natural
channel
of
his
eyes
,
but
she
seemed
to
wring
her
hands
,
and
she
moaned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
him
be
careful
,
"
said
the
youngest
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
give
him
warning
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
shall
step
between
me
and
the
current
of
my
vengeance
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
a
Cove
---
"
he
used
that
familiar
epithet
in
his
agitation
but
corrected
himself
by
adding
,
"
a
gentleman
of
property
,
I
mean
---
who
practices
with
a
pair
of
pistols
(
fellows
too
)
of
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
am
driven
to
borrow
'em
,
and
to
send
at
friend
to
Jinkins
,
a
tragedy
will
get
into
the
papers
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
Mrs
Todgers
moaned
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
borne
this
long
enough
,
"
said
the
youngest
gentleman
<EOS>
but
now
my
soul
rebels
against
it
,
and
I
wo
n't
stand
it
any
longer
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
home
originally
,
because
I
had
that
within
me
which
would
n't
be
domineered
over
by
a
sister
;
and
do
you
think
I
'm
going
to
be
put
down
by
HIM
?
 
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
wrong
in
Mr
Jinkins
;
I
know
it
is
perfectly
inexcusable
in
Mr
Jinkins
,
if
he
intends
it
,
"
observed
Mrs
Todgers
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
intends
it
!
"
cried
the
youngest
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
he
interrupt
and
contradict
me
on
every
occasion
?
 
<EOS>
Does
he
ever
fail
to
interpose
himself
between
me
and
anything
or
anybody
that
he
sees
I
have
set
my
mind
upon
?
 
<EOS>
Does
he
make
a
point
of
always
pretending
to
forget
me
,
when
he
's
pouring
out
the
beer
?
 
<EOS>
Does
he
make
bragging
remarks
about
his
razors
,
and
insulting
allusions
to
people
who
have
no
necessity
to
shave
more
than
once
a
week
?
 
<EOS>
But
let
him
look
out
!
<EOS>
He
'll
find
himself
shaved
,
pretty
close
,
before
long
,
and
so
I
tell
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
was
mistaken
in
this
closing
sentence
,
inasmuch
as
he
never
told
it
to
Jinkins
,
but
always
to
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
However
,
"
he
said
,
"
these
are
not
proper
subjects
for
ladies
'
ears
.
<EOS>
All
I
've
got
to
say
to
you
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
is
,
a
week
's
notice
from
next
Saturday
.
 
<EOS>
The
same
house
ca
n't
contain
that
miscreant
and
me
any
longer
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
get
over
the
intermediate
time
without
bloodshed
,
you
may
think
yourself
pretty
fortunate
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
myself
expect
we
shall
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
!
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
what
would
I
have
given
to
have
prevented
this
?
 
<EOS>
To
lose
you
,
sir
,
would
be
like
losing
the
house
's
right
-
hand
.
 
<EOS>
So
popular
as
you
are
among
the
gentlemen
;
so
generally
looked
up
to
;
and
so
much
liked
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
hope
you
'll
think
better
of
it
;
if
on
nobody
else
's
account
,
on
mine
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
Jinkins
,
"
said
the
youngest
gentleman
,
moodily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
favourite
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
console
you
,
and
the
gentlemen
too
,
for
the
loss
of
twenty
such
as
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
understood
in
this
house
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
have
been
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
run
away
with
that
opinion
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs
Todgers
,
with
a
show
of
honest
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
make
such
a
charge
as
that
against
the
establishment
,
I
must
beg
of
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
so
bad
as
that
comes
to
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Make
any
remark
you
please
against
the
gentlemen
,
or
against
me
;
but
do
n't
say
you
're
not
understood
in
this
house
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
treated
as
if
I
was
,
"
said
the
youngest
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
you
make
a
great
mistake
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mrs
Todgers
,
in
the
same
strain
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
many
of
the
gentlemen
and
I
have
often
said
,
you
are
too
sensitive
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
where
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
of
too
susceptible
a
nature
;
it
's
in
your
spirit
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
coughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
as
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
as
to
Mr
Jinkins
,
I
must
beg
of
you
,
if
we
ARE
to
part
,
to
understand
that
I
do
n't
abet
Mr
Jinkins
by
any
means
.
 
<EOS>
Far
from
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
wish
that
Mr
Jinkins
would
take
a
lower
tone
in
this
establishment
,
and
would
not
be
the
means
of
raising
differences
between
me
and
gentlemen
that
I
can
much
less
bear
to
part
with
than
I
could
with
Mr
Jinkins
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
is
not
such
a
boarder
,
sir
,
"
added
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
that
all
considerations
of
private
feeling
and
respect
give
way
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
the
contrary
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
was
so
much
mollified
by
these
and
similar
speeches
on
the
part
of
Mrs
Todgers
,
that
he
and
that
lady
gradually
changed
positions
;
so
that
she
became
the
injured
party
,
and
he
was
understood
to
be
the
injurer
;
but
in
a
complimentary
,
not
in
an
offensive
sense
;
his
cruel
conduct
being
attributable
to
his
exalted
nature
,
and
to
that
alone
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
in
the
end
,
the
young
gentleman
withdrew
his
notice
,
and
assured
Mrs
Todgers
of
his
unalterable
regard
;
and
having
done
so
,
went
back
to
business
.
   
<EOS>
"
Goodness
me
,
Miss
Pecksniffs
!
"
cried
that
lady
,
as
she
came
into
the
back
room
,
and
sat
wearily
down
,
with
her
basket
on
her
knees
,
and
her
hands
folded
upon
it
,
"
what
a
trial
of
temper
it
is
to
keep
a
house
like
this
!
 
<EOS>
You
must
have
heard
most
of
what
has
just
passed
.
<EOS>
Now
did
you
ever
hear
the
like
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
!
"
said
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
all
the
ridiculous
young
fellows
that
ever
I
had
to
deal
with
,
"
resumed
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
that
is
the
most
ridiculous
and
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
is
hard
upon
him
sometimes
,
but
not
half
as
hard
as
he
deserves
.
 
<EOS>
To
mention
such
a
gentleman
as
Mr
Jinkins
in
the
same
breath
with
HIM
---
you
know
it
's
too
much
!
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
's
as
jealous
of
him
<EOS>
,
bless
you
,
as
if
he
was
his
equal
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
were
greatly
entertained
by
Mrs
Todgers
's
account
,
no
less
than
with
certain
anecdotes
illustrative
of
the
youngest
gentleman
's
character
,
which
she
went
on
to
tell

.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
quite
stern
and
angry
;
and
when
she
had
concluded
,
said
in
a
solemn
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
if
I
may
inquire
,
what
does
that
young
gentleman
contribute
towards
the
support
of
these

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
for
what
HE
has
,
he
pays
about
eighteen
shillings
a
week
!
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eighteen
shillings
a
week
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Taking
one
week
with
another
;
as
near
that
as
possible
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
rose
from
his
chair
,
folded
his
arms
,
looked
at
her
,
and
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do
you
mean
to
say
,
ma'am
---
is
it
possible
,
Mrs
Todgers
---
that
for
such
a
miserable
consideration
as
eighteen
shillings
a
week
,
a
female
of
your
understanding
can
so
far
demean
herself
as
to
wear
a
double
face
,
even
for

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
forced
to
keep
things
on
the
square
if
I
can
,
sir
,
"
faltered
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
preserve
peace
among
them
,
and
keep
my
connection
together
,
if
possible
,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
The
profit
is
very
small
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
profit
!
"
cried
that
gentleman
,
laying
great
stress
upon
the
word
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
profit
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
 
<EOS>
You
amaze
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
severe
,
that
Mrs
Todgers
shed
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
profit
!
"
repeated
Mr
pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
profit
of
dissimulation
!
<EOS>
To
worship
the
golden
calf
of
Baal
,
for
eighteen
shillings
a
week
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
in
your
own
goodness
be
too
hard
upon
me
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
cried
Mrs
Todgers
,
taking
out
her
handkerchief
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
Calf
,
Calf
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
mournfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Baal
,
Baal
!
<EOS>
oh
my
friend
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
 
<EOS>
To
barter
away
that
precious
jewel
,
self
-
esteem
,
and
cringe
to
any
mortal
creature
---
for
eighteen
shillings
a
week
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
subdued
and
overcome
by
the
reflection
,
that
he
immediately
took
down
his
hat
from
its
peg
in
the
passage
,
and
went
out
for
a
walk
,
to
compose
his
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
Anybody
passing
him
in
the
street
might
have
known
him
for
a
good
man
at
first
sight
;
for
his
whole
figure
teemed
with
a
consciousness
of
the
moral
homily
he
had
read
to
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
Eighteen
shillings
a
week
!
 
<EOS>
Just
,
most
just
,
thy
censure
,
upright
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
Had
it
been
for
the
sake
of
a
ribbon
,
star
,
or
garter
;
sleeves
of
lawn
,
a
great
man
's

,
a

in

,
a

upon

from
a

;
a
place
,
a
party
,
or
a
thriving
lie
,
or
eighteen

pounds
,
or
even
eighteen
hundred
;
---
but
to
worship
the
golden
calf
for
eighteen
shillings
a
week
!
<EOS>
oh
pitiful
,
pitiful
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
11
.
<EOS>
Wherein
a
certain
gentleman
becomes
particular
in
his
attentions
to
a
certain
lady
;
and
more
coming
events
than
one
,
cast
their
shadows
before
 
The
family
were
within
two
or
three
days
of
their
departure
from
Mrs
Todgers
's
,
and
the
commercial
gentlemen
were
to
a
man
despondent
and
not
to
be
comforted
,
because
of
the
approaching
separation
,
when
Bailey
junior
,
at
the
jocund
time
of
noon
,
presented
himself
before
Miss
Charity
Pecksniff
,
then
sitting
with
her
sister
in
the
banquet
chamber
,
hemming
six
new
pocket
-
handkerchiefs
for
Mr
Jinkins
;
and
having
expressed
a
hope
,
preliminary
and
pious
,
that
he
might
be
blest
,
gave
her
in
his
pleasant
way
to
understand
that
a
visitor
attended
to
pay
his
respects
to
her
,
and
was
at
that
moment
waiting
in
the
drawing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
this
last
announcement
showed
in
a
more
striking
point
of
view
than
many
lengthened
speeches
could
have
done
,
the
trustfulness
and
faith
of
Bailey
's
nature
;
since
he
had
,
in
fact
,
last
seen
the
visitor
on
the
door
-
mat
,
where
,
after
signifying
to
him
that
he
would
do
well
to
go
upstairs
,
he
had
left
him
to
the
guidance
of
his
own
sagacity
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
it
was
at
least
an
even
chance
that
the
visitor
was
then
wandering
on
the
roof
of
the
house
,
or
vainly
seeking
to
extricate
himself
from
the
maze
of
bedrooms
;
Todgers
's
being
precisely
that
kind
of
establishment
in
which
an
unpiloted
stranger
is
pretty
sure
to
find
himself
in
some
place
where
he
least
expects
and
least
desires
to
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
for
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Charity
,
pausing
in
her
work
;
"
my
gracious
,
Bailey
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Bailey
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
IS
my
gracious
,
an't
it
?
 
<EOS>
Would
n't
I
be
gracious
neither
,
not
if
I
wos
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
remark
was
rendered
somewhat
obscure
in
itself
,
by
reason
(
as
the
reader
may
have
observed
)
of
a
redundancy
of
negatives
;
but
accompanied
by
action
expressive
of
a
faithful
couple
walking
arm
-
in
-
arm
towards
a
parochial
church
,
mutually
exchanging
looks
of
love
,
it
clearly
signified
this
youth
's
conviction
that
the
caller
's
purpose
was
of
an
amorous
tendency
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
affected
to
reprove
so
great
a
liberty
;
but
she
could
not
help
smiling
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
strange
boy
,
to
be
sure
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
always
some
ground
of
probability
and
likelihood
mingled
with
his
absurd
behaviour
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
best
of
it
!
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
know
any
gentlemen
,
Bailey
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
must
have
made
a
mistake
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
smiled
at
the
extreme
wildness
of
such
a
supposition
,
and
regarded
the
young
ladies
with
unimpaired
affability
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Merry
,
"
said
Charity
,
"
who
CAN
it
be
?
 
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
odd
?
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
great
mind
not
to
go
to
him
really
.
 
<EOS>
So
very
strange
,
you
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
younger
sister
plainly
considered
that
this
appeal
had
its
origin
in
the
pride
of
being
called
upon
and
asked
for
;
and
that
it
was
intended
as
an
assertion
of
superiority
,
and
a
retaliation
upon
her
for
having
captured
the
commercial
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
she
replied
,
with
great
affection
and
politeness
,
that
it
was
,
no
doubt
,
very
strange
indeed
;
and
that
she
was
totally
at
a
loss
to
conceive
what
the
ridiculous
person
unknown
could
mean
by
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
impossible
to
divine
!
"
said
Charity
,
with
some
sharpness
,
"
though
still
,
at
the
same
time
,
you
need
n't
be
angry
,
my
dear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
retorted
Merry
,
singing
at
her
needle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
aware
of
that
,
my
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
your
head
is
turned
,
you
silly
thing
,
"
said
Cherry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Merry
,
with
engaging
candour
,
"
that
I
have
been
afraid
of
that
,
myself
,
all
along
!
 
<EOS>
So
much
incense
and
nonsense
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
,
is
enough
to
turn
a
stronger
head
than
mine
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
relief
it
must
be
to
you
,
my
dear
,
to
be
so
very
comfortable
in
that
respect
,
and
not
to
be
worried
by
those
odious
men
!
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
it
,
Cherry
?
"
   
<EOS>
This
artless
inquiry
might
have
led
to
turbulent
results
,
but
for
the
strong
emotions
of
delight
evinced
by
Bailey
junior
,
whose
relish
in
the
turn
the
conversation
had
lately
taken
was
so
acute
,
that
it
impelled
and
forced
him
to
the
instantaneous
performance
of
a
dancing
step
,
extremely
difficult
in
its
nature
,
and
only
to
be
achieved
in
a
moment
of
ecstasy
,
which
is
commonly
called
The
Frog
's
Hornpipe
.
 
<EOS>
A
manifestation
so
lively
,
brought
to
their
immediate
recollection
the
great
virtuous
precept
,
"
Keep
up
appearances
whatever
you
do
,
"
in
which
they
had
been
educated
.
 
<EOS>
They
forbore
at
once
,
and
jointly
signified
to
Mr
Bailey
that
if
he
should
presume
to
practice
that
figure
any
more
in
their
presence
,
they
would
instantly
acquaint
Mrs
Todgers
with
the
fact
,
and
would
demand
his
condign
punishment
,
at
the
hands
of
that
lady
.
 
<EOS>
The
young
gentleman
having
expressed
the
bitterness
of
his
contrition
by
affecting
to
wipe
away
scalding
tears
with
his
apron
,
and
afterwards
feigning
to
wring
a
vast
amount
of
water
from
that
garment
,
held
the
door
open
while
Miss
Charity
passed
out
;
and
so
that
damsel
went
in
state
upstairs
to
receive
her
mysterious
adorer
.
   
<EOS>
By
some
strange
occurrence
of
favourable
circumstances
he
had
found
out
the
drawing
-
room
,
and
was
sitting
there
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
cousin
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
,
you
see
.
 
<EOS>
You
thought
I
was
lost
,
I
'll
be
bound
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
how
do
you
find
yourself
by
this
time
?
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
replied
that
she
was
quite
well
,
and
gave
Mr
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
"
and
you
've
got
over
the
fatigues
of
the
journey
<EOS>
have
you
?
 
<EOS>
I
say
.
 
<EOS>
How
's
the
other
one
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
sister
is
very
well
,
I

,
"

young

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
not

complain

any

,
