.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
would
like

see

,

yourself
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
cousin
!
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
sitting
down

window
-

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
in
a

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
occasion
for
that
,
you

.
 
<EOS>
What
a

girl

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
impossible
for
YOU
to
know
,
"
said
Cherry
,
"
whether
I
am
or
not
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
perhaps
it
is
,
"
said

Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
---
<EOS>
Did

?
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
told

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
think

all
about

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Did

you
though
?
"
said
Jonas
,
pondering
upon
this
strange
reply
.
<EOS>
"
Did
the
other
one
?
"
   
"
I
am
sure
it
's
impossible
for
me
to
say
what
my
sister
may
,
or
may
not
have
thought
on
such
a
subject
,
"
cried
Cherry
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
never
said
anything
to
me
about
it
,
one
way
or
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
she
laugh
about
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
did
n't
even
laugh
about
it
,
"
answered
Charity
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
terrible
one
to
laugh
,
an't
she
?
"
said
Jonas
,
lowering
his
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
lively
,
"
said
Cherry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Liveliness
is
a
pleasant
thing
---
when
it
do
n't
lead
to
spending
money
.
 
<EOS>
An't
it
?
"
asked
Mr
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
much
so
,
indeed
,
"
said
Cherry
,
with
a
demureness
of
manner
that
gave
a
very
disinterested
character
to
her
assent
.
   
<EOS>
"
Such
liveliness
as
yours
<EOS>
I
mean
,
you
know
,
"
observed
Mr
Jonas
,
as
he
nudged
her
with
his
elbow
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
come
to
see
you
before
,
but
I
did
n't
know
where
you
was
.
 
<EOS>
How
quick
you
hurried
off
,
that
morning
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
amenable
to
my
papa
's
directions
,
"
said
Miss
Charity
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
he
had
given
me
his
direction
,
"
returned
her
cousin
,
"
and
then
I
should
have
found
you
out
before
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
should
n't
have
found
you
even
now
,
if
I
had
n't
met
him
in
the
street
this
morning
.
<EOS>
What
a
sleek
,
sly
chap
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
Just
like
a
tomcat
,
an't
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
trouble
you
to
have
the
goodness
to
speak
more
respectfully
of
my
papa
,
Mr
Jonas
,
"
said
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
allow
such
a
tone
as
that
,
even
in
jest
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,
you
may
say
what
you
like
of
MY
father
,
then
,
and
so
I
give
you
leave
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
's
liquid
aggravation
that
circulates
through
his
veins
,
and
not
regular
blood
.
 
<EOS>
How
old
should
you
think
my
father
was
,
cousin
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Old
,
no
doubt
,
"
replied
Miss
Charity
;
"
but
a
fine
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
fine
old
gentleman
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Jonas
,
giving
the
crown
of
his
hat
an
angry
knock
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
time
he
was
thinking
of
being
drawn
out
a
little
finer
too
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
he
's
eighty
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
,
indeed
?
"
said
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
ecod
,
"
cried
Jonas
,
"
<EOS>
now
he
's
gone
so
far
without
giving
in
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
see
much
to
prevent
his
being
ninety
;
no
,
nor
even
a
hundred
.
<EOS>
Why
,
a
man
with
any
feeling
ought
to
be
ashamed
of
being
eighty
,
let
alone
more
.
 
<EOS>
Where
's
his
religion
,
I
should
like
to
know
,
when
he
goes
flying
in
the
face
of
the
Bible
like
that
?
 
<EOS>
Threescore
-
and
-
ten
's
the
mark
,
and
no
man
with
a
conscience
,
and
a
proper
sense
of
what
's
expected
of
him
,
has
any
business
to
live
longer
.
"
   
<EOS>
Is
any
one
surprised
at
Mr
Jonas
making
such
a
reference
to
such
a
book
for
such
a
purpose
?
 
<EOS>
Does
any
one
doubt
the
old
saw
,
that
the
Devil
(
being
a
layman
)
quotes
Scripture
for
his
own
ends
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
will
take
the
trouble
to
look
about
him
,
he
may
find
a
greater
number
of
confirmations
of
the
fact
in
the
occurrences
of
any
single
day
,
than
the
steam
-
gun
can
discharge
balls
in
a
minute
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
there
's
enough
of
my
father
,
"
said
Jonas
;
"
it
's
of
no
use
to
go
putting
one
's
self
out
of
the
way
by
talking
about
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
I
called
to
ask
you
to
come
and
take
a
walk
,
cousin
,
and
see
some
of
the
sights
;
and
to
come
to
our
house
afterwards
,
and
have
a
bit
of
something
.
<EOS>
Pecksniff
will
most
likely
look
in
in
the
evening
,
he
says
,
and
bring
you
home
.
 
<EOS>
See
,
here
's
his
writing
;
I
made
him
put
it
down
this
morning
when
he
told
me
he
should
n't
be
back
before
I
came
here
;
in
case
you
would
n't
believe
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
like
proof
,
is
there
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
say
---
you
'll
bring
the
other
one
,
you
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
cast
her
eyes
upon
her
father
's
autograph
,
which
merely
said
---
"
Go
,
my
children
,
with
your
cousin
.
 
<EOS>
Let
there
be
union
among
us
when
it
is
possible
;
"
and
after
enough
of
hesitation
to
impart
a
proper
value
to
her
consent
,
withdrew
to
prepare
her
sister
and
herself
for
the
excursion
.
 
<EOS>
She
soon
returned
,
accompanied
by
Miss
Mercy
,
who
was
by
no
means
pleased
to
leave
the
brilliant
triumphs
of
Todgers
's
for
the
society
of
Mr
Jonas
and
his
respected
father
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
cried
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
you
are
,
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
fright
,
"
said
Mercy
,
"
here
I
am
;
and
I
would
much
rather
be
anywhere
else
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
mean
that
,
"
cried
Mr
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
n't
possible
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
can
have
what
opinion
you
like
,
fright
,
"
retorted
Mercy
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
content
to
keep
mine
;
and
mine
is
that
you
are
a
very
unpleasant
,
odious
,
disagreeable
person
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
she
laughed
heartily
,
and
seemed
to
enjoy
herself
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
're
a
sharp
gal
!
"
said
Mr
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
regular
teaser
,
an't
<EOS>
she
,
cousin
?
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
replied
in
effect
,
that
she
was
unable
to
say
what
the
habits
and
propensities
of
a
regular
teaser
might
be
;
and
that
even
if
she
possessed
such
information
,
it
would
ill
become
her
to
admit
the
existence
of
any
creature
with
such
an
unceremonious
name
in
her
family
;
far
less
in
the
person
of
a
beloved
sister
;
"
whatever
,
"
added
Cherry
with
an
angry
glance
,
"
whatever
her
real
nature
may
be
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Merry
,
"
the
only
observation
I
have
to
make
is
,
that
if
we
do
n't
go
out
at
once
,
I
shall
certainly
take
my
bonnet
off
again
,
and
stay
at
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
threat
had
the
desired
effect
of
preventing
any
farther
altercation
,
for
Mr
Jonas
immediately
proposed
an
adjournment
,
and
the
same
being
carried
unanimously
,
they
departed
from
the
house
straightway
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
doorstep
,
Mr
Jonas
gave
an
arm
to
each
cousin
;
which
act
of
gallantry
being
observed
by
Bailey
junior
,
from
the
garret
window
,
was
by
him
saluted
with
a
loud
and
violent
fit
of
coughing
,
to
which
paroxysm
he
was
still
the
victim
when
they
turned
the
corner
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
inquired
in
the
first
instance
if
they
were
good
walkers
and
being
answered
,
"
Yes
,
"
submitted
their
pedestrian
powers
to
a
pretty
severe
test
;
for
he
showed
them
as
many
sights
,
in
the
way
of
bridges
,
churches
,
streets
,
outsides
of
theatres
,
and
other
free
spectacles
,
in
that
one
forenoon
,
as
most
people
see
in
a
twelvemonth
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
observable
in
this
gentleman
,
that
he
had
an
insurmountable
distaste
to
the
insides
of
buildings
,
and
that
he
was
perfectly
acquainted
with
the
merits
of
all
shows
,
in
respect
of
which
there
was
any
charge
for
admission
,
which
it
seemed
were
every
one
detestable
,
and
of
the
very
lowest
grade
of
merit
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
thoroughly
possessed
with
this
opinion
,
that
when
Miss
Charity
happened
to
mention
the
circumstance
of
their
having
been
twice
or
thrice
to
the
theatre
with
Mr
Jinkins
and
party
,
he
inquired
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
"
where
the
orders
came
from
?
"
and
being
told
that
Mr
Jinkins
and
party
paid
,
was
beyond
description
entertained
,
observing
that
"
they
must
be
nice
flats
,
certainly
;
"
and
often
in
the
course
of
the
walk
,
bursting
out
again
into
a
perfect
convulsion
of
laughter
at
the
surpassing
silliness
of
those
gentlemen
,
and
(
doubtless
)
at
his
own
superior
wisdom
.
   
<EOS>
When
they
had
been
out
for
some
hours
and
were
thoroughly
fatigued
,
it
being
by
that
time
twilight
<EOS>
,
Mr
Jonas
intimated
that
he
would
show
them
one
of
the
best
pieces
of
fun
with
which
he
was
acquainted
.
 
<EOS>
This
joke
was
of
a
practical
kind
,
and
its
humour
lay
in
taking
a
hackney
-
coach
to
the
extreme
limits
of
possibility
for
a
shilling
.
 
<EOS>
Happily
it
brought
them
to
the
place
where
Mr
Jonas
dwelt
,
or
the
young
ladies
might
have
rather
missed
the
point
and
cream
of
the
jest
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
-
established
firm
of
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
and
Son
,
Manchester
Warehousemen
,
and
so
forth
,
had
its
place
of
business
in
a
very
narrow
street
somewhere
behind
the
Post
Office
;
where
every
house
was
in
the
brightest
summer
morning
very
gloomy
;
and
where
light
porters
watered
the
pavement
,
each
before
his
own
employer
's
premises
,
in
fantastic
patterns
,
in
the
dog
-
days
;
and
where
spruce
gentlemen
with
their
hands
in
the
pockets
of
symmetrical
trousers
,
were
always
to
be
seen
in
warm
weather
,
contemplating
their
undeniable
boots
in
dusty
warehouse
doorways
;
which
appeared
to
be
the
hardest
work
they
did
,
except
now
and
then
carrying
pens
behind
their
ears
.
 
<EOS>
A
dim
,
dirty
,
smoky
,
tumble
-
down
,
rotten
old
house
it
was
,
as
anybody
would
desire
to
see
;
but
<EOS>
there
the
firm
of
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
and
Son
transacted
all
their
business
and
their
pleasure
too
,
such
as
it
was
;
for
neither
the
young
man
nor
the
old
had
any
other
residence
,
or
any
care
or
thought
beyond
its
narrow
limits
.
   
<EOS>
Business
,
as
may
be
readily
supposed
,
was
the
main
thing
in
this
establishment
;
insomuch
indeed
that
it
shouldered
comfort
out
of
doors
,
and
jostled
the
domestic
arrangements
at
every
turn
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
in
the
miserable
bedrooms
there
were
files
of
moth
-
eaten
letters
hanging
up
against
the
walls
;
and
linen
rollers
,
and
fragments
of
old
patterns
,
and
odds
and
ends
of
spoiled
goods
,
strewed
upon
the
ground
;
while
the
meagre
bedsteads
,
washing
-
stands
,
and
scraps
of
carpet
,
were
huddled
away
into
corners
as
objects
of
secondary
consideration
,
not
to
be
thought
of
but
as
disagreeable
necessities
,
furnishing
no
profit
,
and
intruding
on
the
one
affair
of
life
.
 
<EOS>
The
single
sitting
-
room
was
on
the
same
principle
,
a
chaos
of
boxes
and
old
papers
,
and
had
more
counting
-
house
stools
in
it
than
chairs
;
not
to
mention
a
great
monster
of
a
desk
straddling
over
the
middle
of
the
floor
,
and
an
iron
safe
sunk
into
the
wall
above
the
fireplace
.
<EOS>
The
solitary
little
table
for
purposes
of
refection
and
social
enjoyment
,
bore
as
fair
a
proportion
to
the
desk
and
other
business
furniture
,
as
the
graces
and
harmless
relaxations
of
life
had
ever
done
,
in
the
persons
of
the
old
man
and
his
son
,
to
their
pursuit
of
wealth
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
meanly
laid
out
now
for
dinner
;
and
in
a
chair
before
the
fire
sat
Anthony
himself
,
who
rose
to
greet
his
son
and
his
fair
cousins
as
they
entered
.
   
<EOS>
An
ancient
proverb
warns
us
that
we
should
not
expect
to
find
old
heads
upon
young
shoulders
;
to
which
it
may
be
added
that
we
seldom
meet
with
that
unnatural
combination
,
but
we
feel
a
strong
desire
to
knock
them
off
;
merely
from
an
inherent
love
we
have
of
seeing
things
in
their
right
places
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
improbable
that
many
men
,
in
no
wise
choleric
by
nature
,
felt
this
impulse
rising
up
within
them
,
when
they
first
made
the
acquaintance
of
Mr
Jonas
;
but
if
they
had
known
him
more
intimately
in
his
own
house
,
and
had
sat
with
him
at
his
own
board
,
it
would
assuredly
have
been
paramount
to
all
other
considerations
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
ghost
!
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
dutifully
addressing
his
parent
by
that
title
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
dinner
nearly
ready
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
was
,
"
rejoined
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
good
of
that
?
"
<EOS>
rejoined
the
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
to
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
for
certain
,
"
said
Anthony
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
know
for
certain
,
"
rejoined
his
son
in
a
lower
tone
.
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
anything
for
certain
,
YOU
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Give

candle
here
.
 
<EOS>
I

for

.
"
   
<EOS>
Anthony
handed
him

,
with

Mr
Jonas

;

,
and

,
until

.
 
<EOS>
The

of

;
and

,

left
to

own

.
   
<EOS>
"
Bachelor
's
Hall
,
you
know
,
cousin
,
"

Jonas
to

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
say
---
the

,
wo

?
 
<EOS>
Here
;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Other

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
that
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
An't

lively
?
"
<EOS>

to

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
I
really
do
n't

!
"

Miss

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
tired

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

father

?
"

Jonas
,
seeing

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

Jonas

"

.
   
<EOS>
"

ca

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

;

!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
stupid
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
It

that
he
did

,
for

did

.
 
<EOS>
As

,
the
door
of
a
small

office
,
which

off
from
the
rest

the

,
was

,
and
a

,

,

came

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
of
a
remote
fashion
,
and
dusty
,
like
the
rest
of
the
furniture
;
he
was
dressed
in
a
decayed

of
black
;
with

garnished
at
the

with
rusty

of

,
the
very
paupers
of
shoestrings
;
on
the
lower

of
his
spindle

were
dingy

of

same

.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
as
if
he
had
been
put
away
and
forgotten
half
a
century
before
,
and
somebody
had
just
found
him
in
a

-
closet
.
   
<EOS>
Such
as
he
was
,
he
came
slowly

on
towards
the
table
,
until
at
last
he
crept
into
the
vacant

,
from

,
as
his
dim

became

of

,
and
those
strangers
ladies
,
he
rose
again
,
apparently

to

.
<EOS>
But
he
sat
down
once
more
without
having
made
it
,
and
breathing
on
his
shrivelled
hands
to

them
,
remained
with
his
poor
blue
nose
immovable
above
his
plate
,
looking
at
nothing
,
with
eyes
that
saw
nothing
,
and
a

that
meant
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Take
him
in
that
state
,
and
he
was
an
embodiment
of
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
else
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
clerk
,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
as

of
the

:
"
Old
Chuffey
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
He

deaf
,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
"
N
---
 
<EOS>
no
.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Certainly

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
'll

,
"

Jonas
,
apart

,
"

,

;
and

<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>

"

"

do

,

!
"
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>
"
Why

,
"

,
"

's

;
and

ago
<EOS>
or

went
and

.
 
<EOS>
All

(

)
<EOS>
he

;

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
He
an't
<EOS>

at

events
<EOS>
,
"
observed

;
"
and
he

his
salt
,

-

.
 
<EOS>
I

that
he
hardly

any
one
except

;
he
always

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
's

!
 
<EOS>
Why
,

;

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

,
"

Jonas
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
eats
---
when
he
's

.
 
<EOS>
But

do

,

;
so
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Chuffey
,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Chuffey
remained

.
   
<EOS>
"
Always
a
perverse
old
file
,

,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ask

,

.
"
   
"
Are

,

?
"
<EOS>

man
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
"
said

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

,

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

,
all
ready
,
all
ready
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With

stopped
,
smilingly

and
listened
for
some

;
but

spoken
to
no

,
the
light
forsook
his

by

,
until
he
was
nothing
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
'll
be
very

,
mind
,
"
said
Jonas
,

old

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
always
chokes
himself
when
it
an't
broth
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
him
,
now
!
 
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
a
horse
with
such
a
wall
-
eyed
expression
as
he
's
got
?
<EOS>
If
it
had
n't
been
for
the
joke
of
it
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
let
him
come
in
to
-
day
;
but
I
thought
he
'd
amuse
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
poor
old
subject
of
this
humane
speech
was
,
happily
for
himself
,
as
unconscious
of
its
purport
as
of
most
other
remarks
that
were
made
in
his
presence
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
mutton
being
tough
,
and
his
gums
weak
,
he
quickly
verified
the
statement
relative
to
his
choking
propensities
,
and
underwent
so
much
in
his
attempts
to
dine
,
that
Mr
Jonas
was
infinitely
amused
;
protesting
that
he
had
seldom
seen
him
better
company
in
all
his
life
,
and
that
he
was
enough
to
make
a
man
split
his
sides
with
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
went
so
far
as
to
assure
the
sisters
,
that
in
this
point
of
view
he
considered
Chuffey
superior
to
his
own
father
;
which
,
as
he
significantly
added
,
was
saying
a
great
deal
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
strange
enough
that
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
,
himself
so
old
a
man
,
should
take
a
pleasure
in
these
gibings
of
his
estimable
son
at
the
expense
of
the
poor
shadow
at
their
table
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
did
,
unquestionably
;
though
not
so
much
---
to
do
him
justice
---
with
reference
to
their
ancient
clerk
,
as
in
exultation
at
the
sharpness
of
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
same
reason
that
young
man
's
coarse

,
even
to
himself
,
filled
him
with
a

;
causing

rub

and
chuckle

,
as
if
he
said
in
his

,
"
I
taught
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
trained
him
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
the
heir
of
my
bringing
-
up
.
<EOS>
Sly
,
cunning
,
and
covetous
<EOS>
,
he
'll
not
squander
my
money
.
 
<EOS>
I
worked
for
this
;
I
hoped
for
this
;
it
has
been
the
great
end
and

of
my
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
What
a
noble
end
<EOS>
and
aim
it
was
to
contemplate
in
the
attainment
truly
!
 
<EOS>
But
there
be
some
who
manufacture
idols
after
the
fashion
of
themselves
,
and
fail
to
worship
them
when
they
are
made
;
charging
their
deformity
on
outraged
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Anthony
was
better
than
these
at
any
rate
.
   
<EOS>
Chuffey
boggled
over
his
plate
so
long
,
that
Mr
Jones
,
losing

,
took

at

and

"
peg

;
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,

!
"
cried

,

,
when
this

,
"
quite

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

!
 
<EOS>
Bless

a
sharp

!
 
<EOS>
Bless

,

him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
considered
this
so
particularly
childish
(
perhaps

)
,
that

,

was
afraid
one
of
these
fine

,
Chuffey
would
be
the

him
.
 
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
then

,

the

,

,

,
as

.
 
<EOS>
But

that

,
and

him
to
be
in
earnest
<EOS>
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall

,
"
said
Anthony
,
"
to
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Your
father
,
my
dears
.
 
<EOS>
A
clever

,
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
A
wary

!
 
<EOS>
A

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
A

,
girls
,

?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Well
,

he

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
may

.
 
<EOS>
Ask
Jonas
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
overdo
taking
care
of
yourself
,
"
observed
that
hopeful
gentleman
with
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you

,
my

?
"
<EOS>
cried

,
quite

.
<EOS>
"
Wisdom
,

!
 
<EOS>
A

,
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
It

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Except

"

Jonas

"
except
when

lives

long
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Tell
the
other
one
that
---
I
say
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
me
!
"
said
Cherry
,
in
a
petulant
manner
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
tell
her
yourself
,
if
you
wish
,
ca
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
seems
to
make
such
game
of
one
,
"
replied
Mr
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
why
need
you
trouble
yourself
about
her
?
"
said
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
she
does
n't
trouble
herself
much
about
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
she
though
?
"
asked
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
me
,
need
I
tell
you
that
she
do
n't
?
"
returned
the
young
lady
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
made
no
verbal
rejoinder
,
but
he
glanced
at
Mercy
with
an
odd
expression
in
his
face
;
and
said
THAT
would
n't
break
his
heart
,
she
might
depend
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
looked
on
Charity
with
even
greater
favour
than
before
,
and
besought
her
,
as
his
polite
manner
was
,
to
"
come
a
little
closer
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
another
thing
that
's
not
easily
overdone
,
father
,
"
remarked
Jonas
,
after
a
short
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
father
;
grinning
already
in
anticipation
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
bargain
,
"
said
the
son
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
rule
for
bargains
---
"
<EOS>
Do
other
men
,
for
they
would
do
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
true
business
precept
.
<EOS>
All
others
are
counterfeits
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
delighted
father
applauded
this
sentiment
to
the
echo
;
and
was
so
much
tickled
by
it
,
that
he
was
at
the
pains
of
imparting
the
same
to
his
ancient
clerk
,
who
rubbed
his
hands
,
nodded
his
palsied
head
,
winked
his
watery
eyes
,
and
cried
in
his
whistling
tones
,
"
<EOS>
Good
!
<EOS>
good
!
 
<EOS>
Your
own
son
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
"
with
every
feeble
demonstration
of
delight
that
he
was
capable
of
making
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
old
man
's
enthusiasm
had
the
redeeming
quality
of
being
felt
in
sympathy
with
the
only
creature
to
whom
he
was
linked
by
ties
of
long
association
,
and
by
his
present
helplessness
.
 
<EOS>
And
if
there
had
been
anybody
there
,
who
cared
to
think
about
it
,
some
dregs
of
a
better
nature
unawakened
,
might
perhaps
have
been
descried
through
that
very
medium
,
melancholy
though
it
was
,
yet
lingering
at
the
bottom
of
the
worn
-
out
cask
called
Chuffey
.
   
<EOS>
As
matters
stood
,
nobody
thought
or
said
anything
upon
the
subject
;
so
Chuffey
fell
back
into
a
dark
corner
on
one
side
of
the
fireplace
,
where
he
always
spent
his
evenings
,
and
was
neither
seen
nor
heard
again
that
night
;
save
once
,
when
a
cup
of
tea
was
given
him
,
in
which
he
was
seen
to
soak
his
bread
mechanically
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
reason
to
suppose
that
he
went
to
sleep
at
these
seasons
,
or
that
he
heard
,
or
saw
,
or
felt
,
or
thought
.
 
<EOS>
He
remained
,
as
it
were
,
frozen
up
---
if
any
term
expressive
of
such
a
vigorous
process
can
be
applied
to
him
---
until
he
was
again
thawed
for
the
moment
by
a
word
or
touch
from
Anthony
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
made
tea
by
desire
of
Mr
Jonas
,
and
felt
and
looked
so
like
the
lady
of
the
house
that
she
was
in
the
prettiest
confusion
imaginable
;
the
more
so
from
Mr
Jonas
sitting
close
beside
her
,
and
whispering
a
variety
of
admiring
expressions
in
her
ear
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Mercy
,
for
her
part
,
felt
the
entertainment
of
the
evening
to
be
so
distinctly
and
exclusively
theirs
,
that
she
silently
deplored
the
commercial
gentlemen
---
at
that
moment
,
no
doubt
,
wearying
for
her
return
---
and
yawned
over
yesterday
's
newspaper
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
Anthony
,
he
went
to
sleep
outright
,
so
Jonas
and
Cherry
had
a
clear
stage
to
themselves
as
long
as
they
chose
to
keep
possession
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
tea
-
tray
was
taken
away
,
as
it
was
at
last
,
Mr
Jonas
produced
a
dirty
pack
of
cards
,
and
entertained
the
sisters
with
divers
small
feats
of
dexterity
:
whereof
the
main
purpose
of
every
one
was
,
that
you
were
to
decoy
somebody
into
laying
a
wager
with
you
that
you
could
n't
do
it
;
and
were
then
immediately
to
win
and
pocket
his
money
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
informed
them
that
these
accomplishments
were
in
high
vogue
in
the
most
intellectual
circles
,
and
that
large
amounts
were
constantly
changing
hands
on
such
hazards
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
may
be
remarked
that
he
fully
believed
this
;
for
there
is
a
simplicity
of
cunning
no
less
than
a
simplicity
of
innocence
;
and
in
all
matters
where
a
lively
faith
in
knavery
and
meanness
was
required
as
the
ground
-
work
of
belief
,
Mr
Jonas
was
one
of
the
most
credulous
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
His
ignorance
,
which
was
stupendous
,
may
be
taken
into
account
,
if
the
reader
pleases
,
separately
.
   
<EOS>
This
fine
young
man
had
all
the
inclination
to
be
a
profligate
of
the
first
water
,
and
only
lacked
the
one
good
trait
in
the
common
catalogue
of
debauched
vices
---
open
-
handedness
---
to
be
a
notable
vagabond
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
his
griping
and
penurious
habits
stepped
in
;
and
as
one
poison
will
sometimes
neutralise
another
,
when
wholesome
remedies
would
not
avail
,
so
he
was
restrained
by
a
bad
passion
from
quaffing
his
full
measure
of
evil
,
when
virtue
might
have
sought
to
hold
him
back
in
vain
.
   
<EOS>
By
the
time
he
had
unfolded
all
the
peddling
schemes
he
knew
upon
the
cards
,
it
was
growing
late
in
the
evening
;
and
Mr
Pecksniff
not
making
his
appearance
,
the
young
ladies
expressed
a
wish
to
return
home
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
,
Mr
Jonas
,
in
his
gallantry
,
would
by
no
means
allow
,
until
they
had
partaken
of
some
bread
and
cheese
and
porter
;
and
even
then
he
was
excessively
unwilling
to
allow
them
to
depart
;
often
beseeching
Miss
Charity
to
come
a
little
closer
,
or
to
stop
a
little
longer
,
and
preferring
many
other
complimentary
petitions
of
that
nature
in
his
own
hospitable
and
earnest
way
.
 
<EOS>
When
all
his
efforts
to
detain
them
were
fruitless
,
he
put
on
his
hat
and
greatcoat
preparatory
to
escorting
them
to
Todgers
's
;
remarking
that
he
knew
they
would
rather
walk
thither
than
ride
;
and
that
for
his
part
he
was
quite
of
their
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
night
,
"
said
Anthony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
night
;
remember
me
to
---
ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
---
to
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Take
care
of
your
cousin
,
my
dears
;
beware
of
Jonas
;
he
's
a
dangerous
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
quarrel
for
him
,
in
any
case
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
the
creature
!
"
cried
Mercy
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
idea
of
quarrelling
for
HIM
!
<EOS>
You
may
take
him
,
Cherry
,
my
love
,
all
to
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
you
a
present
of
my
share
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
sour
grape
,
am
I
,
cousin
?
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
was
more
entertained
by
this
repartee
than
one
would
have
supposed
likely
,
considering
its
advanced
age
and
simple
character
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
her
sisterly
affection
she
took
Mr
Jonas
to
task
for
leaning
so
very
hard
upon
a
broken
reed
,
and
said
that
he
must
not
be
so
cruel
to
poor
Merry
any
more
,
or
she
(
Charity
)
would
positively
be
obliged
to
hate
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mercy
,
who
really
had
her
share
of
good
humour
,
only
retorted
with
a
laugh
;
and
they
walked
home
in
consequence
without
any
angry
passages
of
words
upon
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
being
in
the
middle
,
and
having
a
cousin
on
each
arm
,
sometimes
squeezed
the
wrong
one
;
so
tightly
too
,
as
to
cause
her
not
a
little
inconvenience
;
but
as
he
talked
to
Charity
in
whispers
the
whole
time
,
and
paid
her
great
attention
,
no
doubt
this
was
an
accidental
circumstance
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
arrived
at
Todgers
's
,
and
the
door
was
opened
,
Mercy
broke
hastily
from
them
,
and
ran
upstairs
;
but
Charity
and
Jonas
lingered
on
the
steps
talking
together
for
more
than
five
minutes
;
so
,
as
Mrs
Todgers
observed
next
morning
,
to
a
third
party
,
"
It
was
pretty
clear
what
was
going
on
THERE
,
and
she
was
glad
of
it
,
for
it
really
was
high
time
that
Miss
Pecksniff
thought
of
settling
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
day
was
coming
on
,
when
that
bright
vision
which
had
burst
on
Todgers
's
so
suddenly
,
and
made
a
sunshine
in
the
shady

of
Jinkins
,
was
to
be
seen
no
more
;
when
it
was
to
be
packed
,
like
a
brown

,
or
a
fish
-
basket
,
or
an
oyster

or
a
fat
gentleman
,
or
any
other
dull
reality
of
life
,
in
a
stagecoach
and
carried
down
into
the
country
.
   
<EOS>
"
Never
,
my
dear
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
when
they
retired
to
rest
on
the
last
night
of
their
stay
,
"
never
have
I
seen
an
establishment
so
perfectly
broken
-
hearted
as
mine
is
at
this
present
moment
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
the
gentlemen
will
be
the
gentlemen
they
were
,
or
anything
like
it
---
no
,
not
for
weeks
to
come
.
<EOS>
You
have
a
great
deal
to
answer
for
,
both
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
modestly
disclaimed
any
wilful
agency
in
this
disastrous
state
of
things
,
and
regretted
it
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
pious
pa
,
too
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
loss
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
your
pa
is
a
perfect
missionary
of
peace
and
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
Entertaining
an
uncertainty
as
to
the
particular
kind
of
love
supposed
to
be
comprised
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
mission
,
the
young
ladies
received
the
compliment
rather
coldly
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
dared
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
perceiving
this
,
"
to
violate
a
confidence
which
has
been
reposed
in
me
,
and
to
tell
you
why
I
must
beg
of
you
to
leave
the
little
door
between
your
room
and
mine
open
tonight
<EOS>
,
I
think
you
would
be
interested
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
must
n't
do
it
,
for
I
promised
Mr
Jinkins
faithfully
,
that
I
would
be
as
silent
as
the
tomb
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mrs
Todgers
!
 
<EOS>
What
can
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
my
sweet
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
"
said
the
lady
of
the
house
;
"
my
own
loves
,
if
you
will
allow
me
the
privilege
of
taking
that
freedom
on
the
eve
of
our
separation
,
Mr
Jinkins
and
the
gentlemen
have
made
up
a
little
musical
party
among
themselves
,
and
DO
intend
,
in
the
dead
of
this
night
,
to
perform
a
serenade
upon
the
stairs
outside
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
have
wished
,
I
own
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
with
her
usual
foresight
,
"
that
it
had
been
fixed
to
take
place
an
hour
or
two
earlier
;
because
when
gentlemen
sit
up
late
they
drink
,
and
when
they
drink
they
're
not
so
musical
,
perhaps
,
as
when
they
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
is
the
arrangement
;
and
I
know
you
will
be
gratified
,
my
dear
Miss
Pecksniffs
,
by
such
a
mark
of
their
attention
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
were
at
first
so
much
excited
by
the
news
,
that
they
vowed
they
could
n't
think
of
going
to
bed
until
the
serenade
was
over
.
 
<EOS>
But
half
an
hour
of
cool
waiting
so
altered
their
opinion
that
they
not
only
went
to
bed
,
but
fell
asleep
;
and
were
,
moreover
,
not
ecstatically
charmed
to
be
awakened
some
time
afterwards
by
certain
dulcet
strains
breaking
in
upon
the
silent
watches
of
the
night
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
very
affecting
---
<EOS>
very
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
dismal
could
have
been
desired
by
the
most
fastidious
taste
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
of
a
vocal
turn
was
head
mute
,
or
chief
mourner
;
Jinkins
took
the
bass
;
and
the
rest
took
anything
they
could
get
.
 
<EOS>
The
youngest
gentleman
blew
his
melancholy
into
a
flute
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
blow
much
out
of
it
,
but
that
was
all
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
two
Miss
Pecksniffs
and
Mrs
Todgers
had
perished
by
spontaneous
combustion
,
and
the
serenade
had
been
in
honour
of
their
ashes
,
it
would
have
been
impossible
to
surpass
the
unutterable
despair
expressed
in
that
one
chorus
,
"
Go
where
glory
waits
thee
!
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
requiem
,
a
dirge
,
a
moan
,
a
howl
,
a
wail
,
a
lament
,
an
abstract
of
everything
that
is
sorrowful
and
hideous
in
sound
.
 
<EOS>
The
flute
of
the
youngest
gentleman
was
wild
and
fitful
.
 
<EOS>
It
came
and
went
in
gusts
,
like
the
wind
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
long
time
together
he
seemed
to
have
left
off
,
and
when
it
was
quite
settled
by
Mrs
Todgers
and
the
young
ladies
that
,
overcome
by
his
feelings
,
he
had
retired
in
tears
,
he
unexpectedly
turned
up
again
at
the
very
top
of
the
tune
,
gasping
for
breath
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
tremendous
performer
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
knowing
where
to
have
him
;
and
exactly
when
you
thought
he
was
doing
nothing
at
all
,
then
was
he
doing
the
very
thing
that
ought
to
astonish
you
most
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
several
of
these
concerted
pieces
;
perhaps
two
or
three
too
many
,
though
that
,
as
Mrs
Todgers
said
,
was
a
fault
on
the
right
side
.
 
<EOS>
But
even
then
,
even
at
that
solemn
moment
,
when
the
thrilling
sounds
may
be
presumed
to
have
penetrated
into
the
very
depths
of
his
nature
,
if
he
had
any
depths
,
Jinkins
could
n't
leave
the
youngest
gentleman
alone
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
him
distinctly
,
before
the
second
song
began
---
as
a
personal
favour
too
,
mark
the
villain
in
that
---
not
to
play
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
<EOS>
;
he
said
so
;
not
to
play
.
 
<EOS>
The
breathing
of
the
youngest
gentleman
was
heard
through
the
key
-
hole
of
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
DIDN'T
play
.
 
<EOS>
What
vent
was
a
flute
for
the
passions
swelling
up
within
his
breast
?
 
<EOS>
A
trombone
would
have
been
a
world
too
mild
.
   
<EOS>
The
serenade
approached
its
close
.
 
<EOS>
Its
crowning
interest
was
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
of
a
literary
turn
had
written
a
song
on
the
departure
of
the
ladies
,
and
adapted
it
to
an
old
tune
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
joined
,
except
the
youngest
gentleman
in
company
,
who
,
for
the
reasons
aforesaid
,
maintained
a
fearful
silence
.
 
<EOS>
The
song
(
which
was
of
a
classical
nature
)
invoked
the
oracle
of
Apollo
,
and
demanded
to
know
what
would
become
of
Todgers
's
when
CHARITY
and
MERCY
were
banished
from
its
walls
.
 
<EOS>
The
oracle
delivered
no
opinion
particularly
worth
remembering
,
according
to
the
not
infrequent
practice
of
oracles
from
the
earliest
ages
down
to
the
present
time
.
<EOS>
In
the
absence
of
enlightenment
on
that
subject
,
the
strain
deserted
it
,
and
went
on
to
show
that
the
Miss
Pecksniffs
were
nearly
related
to
Rule
Britannia
,
and
that
if
Great
Britain
had
n't
been
an
island
,
there
could
have
been
no
Miss
Pecksniffs
.
 
<EOS>
And
being
now
on
a
nautical
tack
,
it
closed
with
this
verse
:
    
"
All
hail
to
the
vessel
of
Pecksniff
the
sire
!
    
<EOS>
And
favouring
breezes
to
fan
;
     
While
Tritons
flock
round
it
,
and
proudly
admire
    
The
architect
,
artist
,
and
man
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
they
presented
this
beautiful
picture
to
the
imagination
,
the
gentlemen
gradually
withdrew
to
bed
to
give
the
music
the
effect
of
distance
;
and
so
it
died
away
,
and
Todgers
's
was
left
to
its
repose
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
reserved
his
vocal
offering
until
the
morning
,
when
he
put
his
head
into
the
room
as
the
young
ladies
were
kneeling
before
their
trunks
,
packing
up
,
and
treated
them
to
an
imitation
of
the
voice
of
a
young
dog
in
trying

;
when
that
animal
is
supposed
by
persons
of
a
lively
fancy
,
to
relieve
his

by
calling
for
pen
and
ink
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
young
ladies
,
"
said
the
youth
,
"
<EOS>
so
you
're
a
-
going
home
,
are
you
,
worse
luck
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Bailey
,
we
're
going
home
,
"
returned
Mercy
.
   
<EOS>
"
An't
you
<EOS>
a
-
going
to
leave
none
of
'em
a
lock
of
your
hair
?
"
inquired

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
real
,

it
?
"
   
<EOS>
They

this
,
and
told

of

was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is

of

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know

than
that
.
 
<EOS>
Hers
an't
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
see
it
hanging

,

.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
have

;
and
she
never
<EOS>
know'd
.
 
<EOS>
I

,

I

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

-

stand

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Mercy
inquired

;
in

Mr
Bailey
intimated
that
he
thought

either

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Into
the
army
!
"
cried

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said

,
"
why
not
?
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
many

in

Tower
.
<EOS>
I
'm

.
 
<EOS>
Do

their
country
set
a
valley
on
'em
<EOS>
,

!
 
<EOS>
Not

all
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
shot
,
I
see
,
"
observed
Mercy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"

,
"
<EOS>
wot
if
I
am
?
 
<EOS>
There
's
something
gamey
in

,
young

,

?
 
<EOS>
I
'd
sooner

,

a
-

,

,

.
<EOS>
Wot

"

wot

DO

.
 
<EOS>
It

MY

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
oh
!
 
<EOS>
No

may

!
<EOS>
but

.
 
<EOS>
But
I

a
-

.
 
<EOS>
I
an't
<EOS>
a
-

to

markets
is
dear
.
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
stop
.
 
<EOS>
And
therefore
,
"
added

Bailey
,

into

,
"
<EOS>
wotever

,

,
becos
<EOS>
if

agin
,
I
sha

;
and
as

other
boy
,
HE
wo

nothing
,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
ladies
,
on
behalf
of
Mr
Pecksniff
and
themselves
,
acted
on
this
thoughtful

;
and
in
consideration
of
their
private

,
presented
Mr
Bailey
with
a
gratuity
so
liberal
that
he
could
hardly
do
enough
to
show
his
gratitude
;
which
found
but
an
imperfect
vent
,
during
the
remainder
of
the
day
,
in
divers
secret
slaps
upon
his
pocket
,
and
other
such
facetious
pantomime
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
confined
to
these
ebullitions
;
for
besides
crushing
a
bandbox
,
with
a
bonnet
in
it
,
he
seriously
damaged
Mr
Pecksniff
's
luggage
,
by
ardently
hauling
it
down
from
the
top
of
the
house
;
and
in
short
evinced
,
by
every
means
in
his
power
,
a
lively
sense
of
the
favours
he
had
received
from
that
gentleman
and
his
family
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
and
Mr
Jinkins
came
home
to
dinner
arm
-
in
-
arm
;
for
the
latter
gentleman
had
made
half
-
holiday
on
purpose
;
thus
gaining
an
immense
advantage
over
the
youngest
gentleman
and
the
rest
,
whose
time
,
as
it
perversely
chanced
,
was
all
bespoke
,
until
the
evening
.
<EOS>
The
bottle
of
wine
was
Mr
Pecksniff
's
treat
,
and
they
were
very
sociable
indeed
;
though
full
of
lamentations
on
the
necessity
of
parting
.
 
<EOS>
While
they
were
in
the
midst
of
their
enjoyment
,
old
Anthony
and
his
son
were
announced
;
much
to
the
surprise
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
greatly
to
the
discomfiture
of
Jinkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
to
say
<EOS>
good
-
bye
<EOS>
,
you
see
,
"
said
Anthony
,
in

low

,
to
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as

apart
at
the

,
while
the
rest

.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
's
the
use

a

between
you
and

?
 
<EOS>
We
are

two

of
a

,
when
apart
,
Pecksniff
;
but

.
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
"
Unanimity
,
my
good

,
"

Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
is
always

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
that
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
for
there
are
some
people
I
would
rather
differ

than

.
 
<EOS>
But
you
know
my
opinion
of
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,
still
having
"
hypocrite
"

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Complimentary
,
"
said
Anthony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Complimentary
,
upon
my
word
.
 
<EOS>
It
was

to
your
abilities
,
even

;

.
 
<EOS>
But

agreed

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"
<EOS>

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Anthony

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

Pecksniff
's

;
but

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Jonas

,
"

"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
You

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

"

<EOS>
"
It

;

<EOS>
Supposing

,

(

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
And

!
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

we

,

.
 
<EOS>
Thank

.
 
<EOS>
We

now

;
which

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
He
rose
as

;
and
giving

Pecksniff
a

,

away

him
to

young

were

;

man
somewhat

by
such
very

,
and
not

free
from

of
having

in

his

.
   
<EOS>
But
the
night
-
coach
had
a
punctual
character
,
and
it
was
time
to
join
it
at
the
office
;
which
was
so
near

hand
that
they
had
already
sent
their

and
arranged
to
walk
.
 
<EOS>
Thither
the
whole
party
repaired
,
therefore
,
after
no
more
delay
than
sufficed
for
the
equipment
of
the
Miss
Pecksniffs
and
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
They
found
the
coach
already
at
its
starting
-
place
,
and
the
horses
in
;
there
,
too
,
were
a
large
majority
of
the
commercial
gentlemen
,
including
the
youngest
,
who
was
visibly
agitated
,
and
in
a
state
of
deep
mental

.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
could
equal
the
distress
of
Mrs
Todgers
in

from
the
young
ladies
,
except
the
strong

with

to
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Never

was
a
pocket

so

,

supported

;
and

of
the
good

's

,
as
the
constant

of
Mr

allowed
.
 
<EOS>
For

,
to
the
last
the

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

Mr

,

of

;

the

,

deep
in

.
 
<EOS>

,

the

<EOS>
They

;
and
Todgers
's

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Chapter
12
.
<EOS>
Will

seen

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Young

forms

resolution

;
"
not
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
rest
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
the
matter
of
that
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
it
's
no
mystery
,
and
you
wo
n't
think
much
of
it
;
but
it
's
very
pleasant
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
John
always
used
to
say
when
he
was
here
,
"
Mark
my
words
,
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
When
my
father
's
executors
cash
up
"
---
he
used
strange

now
and
then
,
but
that
was
his
way
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cash
-
up
's
a
very
good
expression
,
"
observed
Martin
,
"
when
other
people
do
n't
apply
it
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
---
What
a
slow
fellow
you
are
,
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
am
<EOS>
I
know
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
but
you
'll
make
me

if

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm

you
have
put
me

a

now
,
<EOS>
for
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
John
's
father
's
executors
cashed
up
,
"
said
Martin

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

,
to
be

,
"
cried

;
"
yes
.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
Now
,

John
wrote
the

---
the
morning
Pecksniff

,
you

---
he

?
 
<EOS>
I

,
any

;
<EOS>
and

,

new

,
and
what

,

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

John

"
---
<EOS>
Tom
produced
it
---
"
fixes
to
-

;
sends

;
and

;

;
but
at
the

.
 
<EOS>
Read
what
he
says
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Very
well
,
"
said
Martin
,
glancing
over
it
with
his
customary

;
"
much
obliged
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
agreeable
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
could
have
wished
him
to
be
a
little
more
astonished
,
a
little
more
pleased
,
or
in
some
form
or
other

little

interested
in
such

great
event
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
perfectly
self

;
and
falling
into
his
favourite

of
whistling
,
took
another
turn
at
the
grammar
-
school
,
as
if
nothing

had

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
horse
being
regarded
in
the
light
of
a
sacred
animal
,
only
to
be
driven
by
him
,
the
chief

of
that

,
or

some

nominated
for
the

being
to
that
high
office
by
himself
,
the
two
young

agreed
to
walk
to
Salisbury
;
and
<EOS>
so
,
when
the
time
came
,
they
set
off
on
foot
;
which
was
,
after
all
,
a
better
mode
of
travelling
than
in
the
gig
,
as
the
weather
was
very
cold
and
very
dry
.
   
<EOS>
Better
!
 
<EOS>
A
rare
strong
,
hearty
,
healthy
walk
---
four
statute
miles
an
hour
---
preferable
to
that
rumbling
,
tumbling
,
jolting
,
shaking
,
scraping
,
creaking
,
villanous

?
 
<EOS>
Why
,
the
two
things
will
not
admit
of
comparison
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
an
insult
to
the
walk
,
to
set
them
side
by
side
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
an
instance
of
a
gig
having
ever
circulated
a
man
's
blood
,
unless
when
,
putting
him
in
danger
of
his
neck
,
it
awakened
in

and
in

,
and
all

,
a
tingling

,
much
more

than
agreeable
?
 
<EOS>
When
did
a
gig
ever
sharpen
anybody
's
wits

energies
,
unless
it
was
when
the
horse
bolted
,
and
,
crashing

down
a

,
his

suggested
to
the
only

inside
,
some
novel
and
unheard

of
mode
of
dropping
out
behind
?
 
<EOS>
Better
than
the
gig
!
   
<EOS>
The
air
was
cold
,
Tom
;
so
it
was
,
<EOS>
there
was
no
denying
it
;
but
would
it
have
been
more
genial
in
the
gig
?
 
<EOS>
The
blacksmith
's
fire
burned
very
bright
,
and
leaped
up
high
,
as
though
it
wanted
men
to
warm
;
but
would
it
have
been
less
tempting
,
looked
at
from
the
clammy

of
a

?
 
<EOS>
The
wind
blew
keenly
,
nipping
the
features
of
the
hardy
wight
who
fought
his
way
along
;
blinding

with
his
own

if

enough

,
and
wintry

if
he
had

;
stopping
his

as

in

;
tearing

-
up
,
and
whistling
in
the
very

of

bones
;
but
it
would
have
done
all
this
a
hundred
times
more
fiercely
to
a
man
in
a
gig
,
would

it
?
 
<EOS>
A
fig
for
gigs
!
   
<EOS>
Better
than
the
gig
!
 
<EOS>
When
were
travellers
by
wheels
and
hoofs
seen
with
such
red
-
hot
cheeks
as
those
?
<EOS>
when
were
they
so
good
-
humouredly
and
merrily

?
<EOS>
when
did
their
laughter
ring
upon
the
air
,
as
they
turned
them
round
,
what
time
the
stronger

came
sweeping
up
;
and
,
facing
round
again
as
they
passed
by
,
dashed
on
,
in
such
a
glow
of
ruddy
health
as
nothing
could
keep
pace
with
,
but
the
high

it
engendered
?
 
<EOS>
Better
than
the
gig
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
here
is
a
man
in
a
gig
coming
the
same
way
now
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
him
as
he
passes
his
whip
into

left

,
chafes
his
numbed
right

on
his
granite

,
and
beats
those
marble

of
his
upon
the
foot

.
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Who
would
exchange
this
rapid
hurry
of
the
blood
for
yonder
stagnant
misery
,
though
its
pace
were
twenty
miles
for
one
?
   
<EOS>
Better
than
the
gig
!
 
<EOS>
No
man
in
a
gig
could
have
such
interest
in
the
milestones
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
in
a
gig
could
see
,
or
feel
,
or
think
,
like
merry
users
of
their
legs
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
as
the
wind
sweeps
on
,
upon
these
breezy
downs
,
it
tracks
its
flight
in
darkening
ripples
on
the
grass
,
and
smoothest
shadows
on
the
hills
!
 
<EOS>
Look
round
and
round
upon
this
bare
bleak
plain
,
and
see
even
here
,
upon
a
winter
's

,
how
beautiful
the
shadows
are
!
 
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
it
is
the
nature
of
their
kind
to
be
so
.
 
<EOS>
The
loveliest
things
in
life
,
Tom
,
are
but
shadows
;
and
they
come
and
go
,
and
change
and
fade

,
as

as
these
!
   
<EOS>
Another
mile
,
and
then
begins
a
fall
of
snow
,
making
the
crow
,
who
skims
away
so
close
above
the
ground
to
shirk
the
wind
,
a

of
ink
upon

.
 
<EOS>
But
though
it
drives
and

against

as

,
stiffening
on

,
and
freezing
in
the

,
they
would

fall
more

,
no
,
not
so
much
as
by

,
although

.
 
<EOS>
And
,
lo
!
<EOS>
the

of

Old
Cathedral
rise
before

,
even
now
!
<EOS>
and

into
the

,
made

;
and
so
to
the
Inn
for
which

are

;
<EOS>
where

present
such
flushed

to
the
cold

,
and
are
so
brimful
of

,
that
he

by

;
and
,

the
attack
(
being

,

,
from
the

in
the
coffee
-

)
,
is
quite

of

.
   
<EOS>
A
famous
Inn
!
<EOS>
the
hall
a
very
grove
of
dead
game
,
and
dangling
joints
of
mutton
;
and
in
one
corner
an
illustrious
larder
,
with
glass
doors
,
developing
cold
fowls
and
noble

,
and
tarts
<EOS>
wherein
the
raspberry
jam
coyly
withdrew
itself
,
as
such

precious
creature
<EOS>
should
,
behind
a
lattice

of

.
 
<EOS>
And
behold
,
on
the
first

,
at
the

of
the
house
,
in
a
room
with
all
the
window

,
a
fire
piled
half
-

up

,
plates

before

,
wax

gleaming
everywhere
,
and
a
table
spread
for
three
,
with
silver
and
glass
enough
for
thirty
---
 
John
Westlock
;
not
the
old
John
of
Pecksniff
's
,
but
a
proper
gentleman
;
looking
another
and
a
grander

,
with
the

of
being
his
own

and
having
money
in

;
and
yet

the
old
John

,
for
he
seized
Tom
Pinch
by
both
his
hands
the
instant
he
appeared
,
and
fairly

him
,
in
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
,
"
said
John
,
"
is
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
glad
to
see
him
!
"
<EOS>
---
John
had
an
off
-
hand
manner
of
his
own
;
so
they
shook
hands
warmly
,
and
were
friends
in
no
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
off
a
moment
,
Tom
,
"
cried
the
old
pupil
,
laying
one
hand
on
each
of
Mr
Pinch
's
shoulders
,
and
holding
him
out
at
arm
's
length
.
"
<EOS>
Let
me
look
at
you
!
 
<EOS>
Just
the
same
!
 
<EOS>
Not
a
bit
changed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
not
so
very
long
ago
,
you
know
,
"
said
Tom
Pinch
,
"
after
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
seems
an
age
to
me
,
"
cried
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
and
so
it
ought
to
seem
to
you
,
you
dog
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
he
pushed
Tom
down
into
the
easiest
chair
,
and
clapped
him
on
the
back
so
heartily
,
and
so
like
his
old
self
in
their
old

at
old
Pecksniff
's
that
it
was
a
toss
-
up
with
Tom
Pinch
whether
he
should
laugh
or
cry
.
 
<EOS>
Laughter
won
it
;
and
they
all
three
laughed
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
ordered
everything
for
dinner
,
that
we
used
to
say
we
'd
have
,
Tom
,
"
observed
John
Westlock
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Tom
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Everything
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
laugh
,
if
you
can
help
it
,
before
the
waiters
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
when
I
was
ordering
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
like
a
dream
.
"
   
<EOS>
John
was
wrong
there
,
because
nobody
ever
dreamed
such
soup
as
was
put
upon
the
table
directly
afterwards
;
or
such
fish
;
or
such
side
-
dishes
;
or
such
a
top
and
bottom
;
or
such
a
course
of
birds
and
sweets
;
or
in
short
anything
approaching
the
reality
of
that
entertainment
at
ten
-
and
-
sixpence
a
head
,
exclusive
of
wines
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
THEM
,
the
man
who
can
dream
such
iced
champagne
,
such
claret
,
port
,
or
sherry
,
had
better
go
to
bed
and
stop
there
.
   
<EOS>
But
perhaps
the
finest
feature
of
the
banquet
was
,
that
nobody
was
half
so
much
amazed
by
everything
as
John
himself
,
who
in
his
high
delight
was
constantly
bursting
into
fits
of
laughter
,
and
then
endeavouring
to
appear
preternaturally
solemn
,
lest
the
waiters
should
conceive
he
was
n't
used
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
things
they
brought
him
to
carve
,
were
such
outrageous
practical
jokes
,
though
,
that
it
was
impossible
to
stand
it
;
and
when
Tom
Pinch
insisted
,
in
spite
of
the
deferential
advice
of
an
attendant
,
not
only
on
breaking
down
the
outer
wall
of
a
raised
pie
with
a
tablespoon
,
but
on
trying
to
eat
it
afterwards
,
John
lost
all
dignity
,
and
sat
behind
the
gorgeous
dish
-
cover
at
the
head
of
the
table
,
roaring
to
that
extent
that
he
was
audible
in
the
kitchen
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
had
he
the
least
objection
to
laugh
at
himself
,
as
he
demonstrated
when
they
had
all
three
gathered
round
the
fire
and
the
dessert
was
on
the
table
;
at
which
period
the
head
waiter
inquired
with
respectful
solicitude
whether
that
port
,
being
a
light
and
tawny
wine
,
<EOS>
was
suited
to
his
taste
,
or
whether
he
would
wish
to
try
a
fruity
port
with
greater
body
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
John
gravely
answered
that
he
was
well
satisfied
with
what
he
had
,
which
he
esteemed
,
as
one
might
say
,
a
pretty
tidy
vintage
;
for
which
the
waiter
thanked
him
and
withdrew
.
<EOS>
And
then
John
told
his
friends
,
with
a
broad
grin
,
that
he
supposed
it
was
all
right
,
but
he
did
n't
know
;
and
went
off
into
a
perfect
shout
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
very
merry
and
full
of
enjoyment
the
whole
time
,
but
not
the
least
pleasant
part
of
the
festival
was
when
they
all
three
sat
about
the
fire
,
cracking
nuts
,
drinking
wine
and
talking
cheerfully
.
<EOS>
It
happened
that
Tom
Pinch
had
a
word
to
say
to
his
friend
the
organist
's
assistant
,
and
so
deserted
his
warm
corner
for
a
few
minutes
at
this
season
,
lest
it
should
grow
too
late
;
leaving
the
other
two
young
men
together
.
   
<EOS>
They
drank
his
health
in
his
absence
,
of
course
;
and
John
Westlock
took
that
opportunity
of
saying
,
that
he
had
never
had
even
a
peevish
word
with
Tom
during
the
whole
term
of
their
residence
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
This
naturally
led
him
to
dwell
upon
Tom
's
character
,
and
to
hint
that
Mr
Pecksniff
understood
it
pretty
well
.
<EOS>
He
only
hinted
this
,
and
very
distantly
;
knowing
that
it
pained
Tom
Pinch
to
have
that
gentleman
disparaged
,
and
thinking
it
would
be
as
well
to
leave
the
new
pupil
to
his
own
discoveries
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
impossible
to
like
Pinch
better
than
I
do
,
or
to
do
greater
justice
to
his
good
qualities
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
the
most
willing
fellow
I
ever
saw
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
rather
too
willing
,
"
observed
John
,
who
was
quick
in
observation
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
a
fault
in
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
true
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
fellow
only
a
week
or
so
ago
---
a
Mr
Tigg
---
who
borrowed
all
the
money
he
had
,
on
a

to
repay
it
in
a

days
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
but
half
a
sovereign
,
to
be
sure
;
but
it
's
well
<EOS>
it
was
no
more
,
for
he
'll
never
see
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
said
John
,
who
had
been
very
attentive
to
these
few
words
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
have
not
had
an
opportunity
of
observing
that
,
in
his
own
pecuniary
transactions
,
Tom
's
proud
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
have
n't
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Wo
n't
he
borrow
?
"
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
very
odd
,
"
said
Martin
,
setting
down
his
empty
glass
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
strange
compound
,
to
be
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
to
receiving
money
as
a
gift
,
"
resumed
John
Westlock
;
"
I
think
he
'd
die
first
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
made
up
of
simplicity
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Help
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
however
,
"
pursued
John
,
filling
his
own
glass
,
and
looking
at
his
companion
with
some

,
"
who
are
older
than
the
majority

Mr
Pecksniff
's
assistants
,
and
have
evidently
had
much
more
experience
,
understand
him
<EOS>
,
I
have
no

,
and
see
how
liable
he
is
to
be
imposed
upon
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
"
said
Martin
,
stretching

,
and
holding

wine
between

and
the
light
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pecksniff
knows
that
too
.
<EOS>
So
do
his
daughters
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
John
Westlock
smiled
,
but
made
no

.
   
<EOS>
"
By
the
bye
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
that
reminds
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
your
opinion
of
Pecksniff
?
 
<EOS>
How
did
he
use
you
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
him
now
?
<EOS>
---
 
<EOS>
Coolly
,
you
know
,
when
it
's
all
over
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
Pinch
,
"
returned
the
old
pupil
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
knows
what
my
sentiments
used
to
be
upon
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
not
changed
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
I
'd
rather

from

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
Pinch
says
they
are
unjust
,
"
urged
John
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
well
!
 
<EOS>
Then
I
know
what
course
they
take
beforehand
,
"
said
Martin
;
"
<EOS>
and
,
therefore
,
you
can
have
no
delicacy
in
speaking
plainly
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
mind
me
,
I
beg
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
him
<EOS>
I
tell
you
frankly
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
with
him
because
it
happens
from
particular
circumstances
to
suit
my
convenience
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
some
ability
,
I
believe
,
in
that
way
;
and
the
obligation
,
if
any
,
will
most
likely
be
on

and
not

.
 
<EOS>
At
the
lowest
mark
,
the
balance
will
be
even
,
and
there
'll
be
no

at
all
.
 
<EOS>
So
you
may
talk
to
me
,
as
if
I
had
no
connection
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
press
me
to

---
"
returned
John
Westlock
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
oblige
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
I
should
say
,
"
resumed
the
other
,
"
that
he
is
the
most
consummate
scoundrel
on
the
face
of
the
earth
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Martin
,
as
coolly
as
ever
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
rather
strong
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
stronger
than
he
deserves
,
"
said
John
;
"
and
if
he
called
upon
me
to
express
my
opinion
of
him
to
his
face
,
I
would
do
so
in
the
very
same
terms
,
without
the
least
qualification
.
 
<EOS>
His
treatment
of
Pinch
is
in
itself
enough
to
justify
them
;
but
when
I
look
back
upon
the
five
years
I
passed
in
that
house
,
and
remember
the
hyprocrisy
,
the
knavery
,
the
meannesses
,
the
false
pretences
,
the
lip
service
of
that
fellow
,
and
his
trading
in
saintly
semblances
for
the
very
worst
realities
;
when
I
remember
how
often
I
was
the
witness
of
all
this
and
how
often
I
was
made
a
kind
of
party
to
it
,
by
the
fact
of
being
there
,
with
him
for
my
teacher
;
I
swear
to
you
that
I
almost
despise
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
drained
his
glass
,
and
looked
at
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
to
say
that
is
a
right
feeling
,
"
pursued
John
Westlock
"
because
it
was
no
fault
of
mine
;
and
I
can
quite
understand
---
you
for
instance
,
fully
appreciating
him
,
and
yet
being
forced
by

to
remain
there
.
 
<EOS>
I
tell
you
simply
what
my
feeling
is
;
and
even
now
,
when
,
as
you
say
,
it
's
all
over
;
and
when
I
have
the
satisfaction
of
knowing
that
he
always
hated
me
,
and
we
always

,
and
I
always
told
him
my
mind
;
even
now
,
I
feel
sorry
that
I
did
n't
yield
to
an
impulse
I
often
had
,
as

boy
,
of
running

from

and
going
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
abroad
?
"
asked

,

speaker
.
   
<EOS>
"
In

,
"

John
Westlock
,

,
"
of
the

I
could
n't
have
earned
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
There

something
spirited
in

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
come
!
 
<EOS>
Fill
your

,

let

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As

as

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
In

and

,
I

only

.
 
<EOS>
I
have

so

,
and

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Your

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yours
.
 
<EOS>
And

the

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
<EOS>
Here
's

.
 
<EOS>
Strange
,

?
 
<EOS>
Not

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
entered
as

,

;
and

,
more

(
for

)
,

,
and
was
as

as
only
Tom
Pinch
could
be
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
other
simile
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
"
he

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
Well
,

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Trying
to

,
Tom
;
trying

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
There

no

what
I
may
turn
out
,
in

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose

would
n't

?
"
said
Tom
Pinch
,

;
"
although

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would

I
?
"
retorted

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
you
know

,
Pinch
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
a

heavy
box
that
I
would

to
get

Pecksniff
's
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
cried
Pinch
,

,
"
I
told

so
.
 
<EOS>
The
great
fault
in
his
character
is
his
injustice
to
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
n't
mind
a
word
he
says
on
that

.
 
<EOS>
His
prejudice
is
most
extraordinary
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
absence
of
anything
like

on
Tom
's

,
you

,
"

John
Westlock
,

,

,
"
is
perfectly

.
 
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

.
 
<EOS>
If

---

.
 
<EOS>
You
could

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

his

when

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I

his

,
"
retorted

,
"
I
'd
have
done

,
<EOS>
Tom
,
with

,
you

.
 
<EOS>
But
as
I

in
what

,
and

nothing
of
,
except
in

ability
to
probe

to
the
quick
in
other
people
,
I
am
afraid
I
can
lay
no
claim
to
your

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
being
unwilling
to
protract
a
discussion
which
might
possibly
corrupt
Martin
,
forbore
to
say
anything
in
reply
to
this
speech
;
but
John
Westlock
,
whom
nothing

an
iron
gag
would
have
silenced
when
Mr
Pecksniff
's
merits
were
once
in
question
,
continued
notwithstanding
.
   
<EOS>
"
HIS
feelings
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
he
's
a
tender
-
hearted
man
.
 
<EOS>
HIS
feelings
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
he
's
a
considerate
,
conscientious
,
self
-
examining
,
moral

,
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
HIS
feelings
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
---
what
's
the
matter
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
was
by
this
time
erect
upon
the
hearth
-
rug
,
buttoning
his
coat
with
great
energy
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
bear
it
,
"
said
Tom
,
shaking
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
I
really
can
not
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
excuse
me
,
John
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
great
esteem
and
friendship
for
you
;
I
love

very
much
;
and

to
-
day
,
to
find
you
just
the
same
as
ever
;
but
I
can
not
listen
to
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
my
old
way
,
Tom
;
and
you
say
yourself
that
you
are
glad
to
find
me
unchanged
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
in
this
respect
,
"
said
Tom
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
excuse
me
,
John
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
,
really
;
I
will
not
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
very
wrong
;
you
should
be
more
guarded
in
your
expressions
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
bad
enough
when
you
and
I
used
to
be
alone
together
,
but
under
existing
circumstances
,
I
ca
n't
endure
it
,
really
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
right
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
other
,
exchanging
looks
with
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
and
I
am
quite
wrong
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
the
deuce
we
fell
on
this
unlucky
theme
.
 
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
with
all
my
heart
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
free
and
manly
temper
,
I
know
,
"
said
Pinch
;
"
and
therefore
,
your
being
so
ungenerous
in
this
one
solitary
instance
,
only
grieves
me
the
more
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
my
pardon
you
have
to
ask
,
John
.
<EOS>
You
have
done
ME
nothing
but
kindnesses
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Pecksniff
's
pardon
then
,
"
said
young
Westlock
.
 
<EOS>
"
Anything
Tom
,
or
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
Pecksniff
's
pardon
---
will
that
do
?
 
<EOS>
Here
!
<EOS>
let
us
drink
Pecksniff
's
health
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
cried
Tom
,
shaking
hands
with
him
eagerly
,
and
filling
a
bumper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
;
I
'll
drink
it
with
all
my
heart
,
John
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
health
,
and
prosperity
to
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
echoed
the
sentiment
,
or
nearly
so
;
for
he
drank
Mr
Pecksniff
's
health
,
and
Something
to
him
---
but
what
,
was
not
quite
audible
.
 
<EOS>
The
general
unanimity
being
then
completely
restored
,
they
drew
their
chairs
closer
round
the
fire
,
and
conversed
in
perfect
harmony
and
enjoyment
until
bed
-
time
.
   
<EOS>
No
slight
circumstance
,
perhaps
,
could
have
better
illustrated
the
difference
of
character
between
John
Westlock
and
Martin
Chuzzlewit
,
than
the
manner
in
which
each
of
the
young
men
contemplated
Tom
Pinch
,
after
the
little
rupture
just
described
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
amount
of
jocularity
in
the
looks
of
both
,
no
doubt
,
but
there
all
resemblance
ceased
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
pupil
could
not
do
enough
to
show
Tom
how
cordially
he
felt
towards
him
,
and
his
friendly
regard
seemed
of
a
graver
and
more
thoughtful
kind
than
before
.
 
<EOS>
The
new
one
,
on
the
other
hand
,
had
no
impulse
but
to
laugh
at
the
recollection
of
Tom
's
extreme
absurdity
;
and
mingled
with
his
amusement
there
was
something
slighting
and
contemptuous
,
indicative
,
as
it
appeared
,
of
his
opinion
that
Mr
Pinch
was
much
too
far
gone
in
simplicity
to
be
admitted
as
the
friend
,
on
serious
and
equal
terms
,
of
any
rational
man
.
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
,
who
did
nothing
by
halves
,
if
he
could
help
it
,
had
provided
beds
for
his
two
guests
in
the
hotel
;
and
after
a
very
happy
evening
,
they
retired
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
was
sitting
on
the
side
of
his
bed
with
his
cravat
and
shoes
off
,
ruminating
on
the
manifold
good
qualities
of
his
old
friend
,
when
he
was
interrupted
by
a
knock
at
his
chamber
door
,
and
the
voice
of
John
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
asleep
yet
,
are
you
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
you
,
no
!
<EOS>
not
I.
 
<EOS>
I
was
thinking
of
you
,
"
replied
Tom
,
opening
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
going
to
detail
you
,
"
said
John
;
"
but
I
have
forgotten
all
the
evening
a
little
commission
I
took
upon
myself
;
and
I
am
afraid
I
may
forget
it
again
,
if
I
fail
to
discharge
it
at
once
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
a
Mr
Tigg
,
Tom
<EOS>
,
I
believe
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tigg
!
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tigg
!
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
who
borrowed
some
money
of
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
,
"
said
John
Westlock
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
begged
me
to
present
his
compliments
,
and
to
return
it
with
many
thanks
.
 
<EOS>
Here
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
's
a
good
one
,
but
he
is
rather
a
doubtful
kind
of
customer
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
received
the
little
piece
of
gold
with
a
face
whose
brightness
might
have
shamed
the
metal
;
and
said
he
had
no
fear
about
that
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
glad
<EOS>
,
he
added
,
to
find
Mr
Tigg
so
prompt
and
honourable
in
his
dealings
;
very
glad
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
Tom
,
"
replied
his
friend
,
"
he
is
not
always
so
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
'll
take
my
advice
,
you
'll
avoid
him
as
much
as
you
can
,
in
the
event
of
your
encountering
him
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
by
no
means
,
Tom
---
pray
bear
this
in
mind
,
for
I
am
very
serious
---
by
no
means
lend
him
money
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
with
his
eyes
wide
open
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
very
far
from
being
a
reputable
acquaintance
,
"
returned
young
Westlock
;
"
and
the
more
you
let
him
know
you
think
so
,
<EOS>
the
better
for
you
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
John
,
"
quoth
Mr
Pinch
,
as
his
countenance
fell
,
and
he
shook
his
head
in
a
dejected

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
not
getting
into
bad
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
he
replied
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
uneasy
on
that
score
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
I
AM
uneasy
,
"
said
Tom
Pinch
;
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
it
,
when
I
hear
you
talking
in
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Tigg
is
what
you
describe
him
to
be
,
you
have
no
business
to
know
him
,
John
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
laugh
,
but
I
do
n't
consider
it
by
any
means
a
laughing
matter
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
returned
his
friend
,
composing
his
features
.
 
<EOS>
"
Quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
John
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
"
your
very
good
nature
and
kindness
of
heart
<EOS>
make
you
thoughtless
,
and
you
ca
n't
be
too
careful
on
such
a
point
as
this
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
if
I
thought
you
were
falling
among
bad
companions
,
I
should
be
quite
wretched
,
for
I
know
how
difficult
you
would
find
it
to
shake
them
off
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
much
rather
have
lost
this
money
,
John
,
than
I
would
have
had
it
back
again
on
such
terms
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
my
dear

old
fellow
,
"
cried
his
friend
,
shaking
him
to
and
fro
with
both
hands
,
and
smiling
at
him
with
a
cheerful
,
open
countenance
,
that
would
have
carried
conviction
to
a
mind
much
more
suspicious
than
Tom
's
;
"
I
tell
you
there
is
no
danger
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
cried
Tom
,
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
;
I
am
overjoyed
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
there
is
not
,
when
you
say
so
in
that

.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
take
it
ill
,
John
,
<EOS>
that
I
said
what
I
did
just
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ill
!
"
said
the
other
,
giving
his
hand
a
hearty

;
"
why
what
do
you
think
I
am
made
of
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
and
I
are
not
on
such
an
intimate
footing
that
you
need
be
at
all
uneasy
,
I
give
you
my
solemn

of
that
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
quite
comfortable
now
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
once
more
,
good
night
!
"
   
"
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Tom
;
"
and
such
pleasant
dreams
to
you
as
should
attend
the
sleep
of
the
best
fellow
in
the
world
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
---
Except
Pecksniff
,
"
said
his
friend
,
stopping
at
the
door
for
a
moment
,
and
looking
gaily
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
Except
Pecksniff
,
"
answered
Tom
,
with
great
gravity
;
"
of
course
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
thus
they
parted
for
the
night
;
John
Westlock
full
of
light
-
heartedness
and
good
humour
,
and
poor
Tom
Pinch
quite
satisfied
;
though
still
,
as
he
turned
over
on
his
side
in
bed
,
he
muttered
to
himself
,
"
I
really
do
wish
,
for
all
that
,
though
,
that
he
was
n't
acquainted
with
Mr
Tigg
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
breakfasted
together
very
early
next
morning
,
for
the
two
young
men
desired
to
get
back
again
in
good
season
;
and
John
Westlock
was
to
return
to
London
by
the
coach
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
had
some
hours
to
spare
,
he
bore
them
company
for
three
or
four
miles
on
their
walk
,
and
only
parted
from
them
at
last
in
sheer
necessity
.
 
<EOS>
The
parting
was
an
unusually
hearty
one
,
not
only
as
between
him
and
Tom
Pinch
,
but
on
the
side
of
Martin
also
,
who
had
found
in
the
old
pupil
a
very
different
sort
of
person
from
the
milksop
he
had
prepared
himself
to
expect
.
   
<EOS>
Young
Westlock
stopped
upon
a
rising
ground
,
when
he
had
gone
a
little
distance
,
and
looked
back
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
walking
at
a
brisk
pace
,
and
Tom
appeared
to
be
talking
earnestly
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
had
taken
off
his
greatcoat
,
the
wind
being
now
behind
them
,
and
carried
it
upon
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
looked
,
he
saw
Tom
relieve
him
of
it
,
after
a
faint
resistance
,
and
,
throwing
it
upon
his
own
,
encumber
himself
with
the
weight
of
both
.
 
<EOS>
This
trivial
incident
impressed
the
old
pupil
mightily
,
for
he
stood
there
,
gazing
after
them
,
until
they
were
hidden
from
his
view
;
when
he
shook
his
head
,
as
if
he
were
troubled
by
some
uneasy
reflection
,
and
thoughtfully
retraced
his
steps
to
Salisbury
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Martin
and
Tom
pursued
their
way
,
until
they
halted
,
safe
and
sound
,
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
,
where
a
brief
epistle
from
that
good
gentleman
to
Mr
Pinch
announced
the
family
's
return
by
that
night
's
coach
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
would
pass
the
corner
of
the
lane
at
about
six
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
Mr
Pecksniff
requested
that
the
gig
might
be
in
waiting
at
the
finger
-
post
about
that
time
,
together
with
a
cart
for
the
luggage
.
 
<EOS>
And
to
the
end
that
he
might
be
received
with
the
greater
honour
,
the
young
men
agreed
to
rise
early
,
and
be
upon
the
spot
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
least
cheerful
day
they
had
yet
passed
together
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
was
out
of
spirits
and
out
of
humour
,
and
took
every
opportunity
of
comparing
his
condition
and
prospects
with
those
of
young
Westlock
;
much
to
his
own
disadvantage
always
.
 
<EOS>
This
mood
of
his
depressed
Tom
;
and
neither
that
morning
's
parting
,
nor
yesterday
's
dinner
,
helped
to
mend
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
So
the
hours
dragged
on
heavily
enough
;
and
they
were
glad
to
go
to
bed
early
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
not
quite
so
glad
to
get
up
again
at
half
-
past
four
o'clock
,
in
all
the
shivering
discomfort
of
a
dark
winter
's
morning
;
but
they
turned
out
punctually
,
and
were
at
the
finger
-
post
full
half
-
an
-
hour
before
the
appointed
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
by
any
means
a
lively
morning
,
for
the
sky
was
black
and
cloudy
,
and
it
rained
hard
;
but
Martin
said
there
was
some
satisfaction
in
seeing
that
brute
of
a
horse
(
by
this
,
he
meant
Mr
Pecksniff
's
Arab
steed
)
getting
very
wet
;
and
that
he
rejoiced
,
on
his
account
,
that
it
rained
so
fast
.
 
<EOS>
From
this
it
may
be
inferred
that
Martin
's
spirits
had
not
improved
,
as
indeed
they
had
not
;
for
while
he
and
Mr
Pinch
stood
waiting
under
a
hedge
,
looking
at
the
rain
,
the
gig
,
the
cart
,
and
its
reeking
driver
,
he
did
nothing
but
grumble
;
and
,
but
that
it
is
indispensable
to
any
dispute
that
there
should
be
two
parties
to
it
<EOS>
,
he
would
certainly
have
picked
a
quarrel
with
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
the
noise
of
wheels
was
faintly
audible
in
the
distance
and
presently
the
coach
came
splashing
through
the
mud
and
mire
with
one
miserable
outside
passenger
crouching
down
among
wet
straw
,
under
a
saturated
umbrella
;
and
the
coachman
,
guard
,
and
horses
,
in
a
fellowship
of
dripping
wretchedness
.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
on
its
stopping
,
Mr
Pecksniff
let
down
the
window
-
glass
and
hailed
Tom
Pinch
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
Mr
Pinch
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
possible
that
you
are
out
upon
this
very
inclement
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
cried
Tom
,
advancing
eagerly
,
"
Mr
Chuzzlewit
and
I
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
not
so
much
at
Martin
as
at
the
spot
on
which
he
stood
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Do
me
the
favour
to
see
to
the
trunks
,
if
you
please
,
Mr
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
Then
Mr
Pecksniff
descended
,
and
helped
his
daughters
to
alight
;
but
neighter
he
nor
the
young
ladies
took
the
slightest
notice
of
Martin
,
who
had
advanced
to
offer
his
assistance
,
but
was
repulsed
by
Mr
Pecksniff
's
standing
immediately
before
his
person
,
with
his
back
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
same
manner
,
and
in
profound
silence
,
Mr
Pecksniff
handed
his
daughters
into
the
gig
;
and
following
himself
and
taking
the
reins
,
drove
off
home
.
   
<EOS>
Lost
in
astonishment
,
Martin
stood
staring
at
the
coach
,
and
when
the
coach
had
driven
away
,
at
Mr
Pinch
,
and
the
luggage
,
until
the
cart
moved
off
too
;
when
he
said
to
Tom
:
   
"
Now
will
you
have
the
goodness
to
tell
me
what
THIS
portends
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
asked
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
fellow
's
behaviour
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
,
I
mean
.
 
<EOS>
You
saw
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
I
did
not
,
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
busy
with
the
trunks
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
no
matter
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Let
us
make
haste
back
!
"
<EOS>
And
without
another
word
started
off
at
such
a
pace
,
that
Tom
had
some
difficulty
in
keeping
up
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
no
care
where
he
went
,
but
walked
through
little
heaps
of
mud
and
little
pools
of
water
with
the
utmost
indifference
;
looking
straight
before
him
,
and
sometimes
laughing
in
a
strange
manner
within
himself
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
felt
that
anything
he
could
say
would
only
render
him
the
more
obstinate
,
and
therefore
trusted
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
manner
when
they
reached
the
house
,
to
remove
the
mistaken
impression
under
which
he
felt
convinced
so
great
a
favourite
as
the
new
pupil
must
unquestionably
be
labouring
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
a
little
amazed
himself
,
when
they
did
reach
it
,
and
entered
the
parlour
where
Mr
Pecksniff
was
sitting
alone
before
the
fire
,
drinking
some
hot
tea
,
to
find
that
instead
of
taking
favourable
notice
of
his
relative
and
keeping
him
,
Mr
Pinch
,
in
the
background
,
he
did
exactly
the
reverse
,
and
was
so
lavish
in
his
attentions
to
Tom
,
that
Tom
was
thoroughly
confounded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
some
tea
,
Mr
Pinch
---
take
some
tea
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
stirring
the
fire
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
very
cold
and
damp
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
take
some
tea
,
and
come
into
a
warm
place
,
Mr
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
saw
that
Martin
looked
at
Mr
Pecksniff
as
though
he
could
have
easily
found
it
in
his
heart
to
give
HIM
an
invitation
to
a
very
warm
place
;
but
he
was
quite
silent
,
and
standing
opposite
that
gentleman
at
the
table
,
regarded
him
attentively
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
a
chair
,
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
a
chair
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
How
have
things
gone
on
in
our
absence
,
Mr
Pinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
---
you
will
be
very
much
pleased
with
the
grammar
-
school
,
sir
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
nearly
finished
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
have
the
goodness
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
waving
his
hand
and
smiling
,
"
we
will
not
discuss
anything
connected
with
that
question
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
What
have
YOU
been
doing
,
Thomas
,
humph
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
looked
from
master
to
pupil
,
and
from
pupil
to
master
,
and
was
so
perplexed
and
dismayed
that
he
wanted
presence
of
mind
to
answer
the
question
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
awkward
interval
,
Mr
Pecksniff
(
who
was
perfectly
conscious
of
Martin
's
gaze
,
though
he
had
never
once
glanced
towards
him
)
poked
the
fire
very
much
,
and
when
he
could
n't
do
that
any
more
,
drank
tea
assiduously
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
said
Martin
at
last
,
in
a
very
quiet
voice
,
"
if
you
have
sufficiently
refreshed
and
recovered
yourself
,
I
shall
be
glad
to
hear
what
you
mean
by
this
treatment
of
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
turning
his
eyes
on
Tom
Pinch
,
even
more
placidly
and
gently
than
before
,
"
what
have
YOU
been
doing
,
Thomas
,
humph
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
When
he
had
repeated
this
inquiry
,
he
looked
round
the
walls
of
the
room
as
if
he
were
curious
to
see
whether
any
nails
had
been
left
there
by
accident
in
former
times
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
almost
at
his
wit
's
end
what
to
say
between
the
two
,
and
had
already
made
a

as
if
he
would
call
Mr
Pecksniff
's
attention
to
the
gentleman
who
had
last

him
,
when
Martin
saved
him
further

,
by
doing

himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
he
said
,
softly
rapping
the
table
twice
or
thrice
,
and
moving
a
step
or
two
nearer
,
so
that
he
could
have
touched
him
with

;
"
you
heard
what
I
said
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
Do
me

to

,
if

.
 
<EOS>
I
ask
you
"
---
he
raised

a

here
---
"
what
you
mean
by
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
talk
to
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
in
a
severe
voice
,
as
he
looked
at
him
for
the
first
time
,
"
presently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
obliging
,
"
returned
Martin
;
"
presently
will
not
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
trouble
you
to
talk
to
me
at
once
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
made
a
feint
of
being
deeply
interested
in
his
pocketbook
,
but
it
shook
in
his
hands
;
he
trembled
so
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
retorted
Martin
,
rapping
the
table
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
.
 
Presently
will
not
do
.
 
<EOS>
Now
!
"
   
"
Do
you
threaten
me
,
sir
?
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
looked
at
him
,
and
made
no
answer
;
but
a
curious
observer
might
have
detected
an
ominous
twitching
at
his
mouth
,
and
perhaps
an
involuntary
attraction
of
his
right
hand
in
the
direction
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
cravat
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
lament
to
be
obliged
to
say
,
sir
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
that
it
would
be
quite
in
keeping
with
your
character
if
you
did
threaten
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
deceived
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
imposed
upon
a
nature
which
you
knew
to
be
confiding
and
unsuspicious
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
obtained
admission
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
rising
,
"
to
this
house
,
on
perverted
statements
and
on
false
pretences
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Go
on
,
"
said
Martin
,
with
a
scornful
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
understand
you
now
.
<EOS>
What
more
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thus
much
more
,
sir
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
trembling
from
head
to
foot
,
and
trying
to
rub
his
hands
,
as
though
he
were
only
cold
.
"
<EOS>
Thus
much
more
,
if
you
force
me
to
publish
your
shame
before
a
third
party
,
which
I
was
unwilling
and
indisposed
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
This
lowly
roof
,
sir
,
must
not
be
contaminated
by
the
presence
of
one
who
has
deceived
,
and
cruelly
deceived
,
an
honourable
,
beloved
,
venerated
,
and
venerable
gentleman
;
and
who
wisely
suppressed
that
deceit
from
me
when
he
sought
my
protection
and
favour
,
knowing
that
,
humble
as
I
am
,
I
am
an
honest
man
,
seeking
to
do
my
duty
in
this
carnal
universe
,
and
setting
my
face
against
all
vice
and
treachery
.
 
<EOS>
I
weep
for
your
depravity
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
;
"
I
mourn
over
your
corruption
,
I
pity
your
voluntary
withdrawal
of
yourself
from
the
flowery
paths
of
purity
and
peace
;
"
here
he
struck
himself
upon
his
breast
,
or
moral
garden
;
"
but
I
can
not
have
a
leper
and
a
serpent
for
an
inmate
.
 
<EOS>
Go
forth
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
stretching
