:
"
go
forth
,
young
man
!
 
<EOS>
Like
all
who
know
you
,
I
renounce
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
what
intention
Martin
made
a
stride
forward
at
these
words
,
it
is
impossible
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
to
know
that
Tom
Pinch
caught
him
in
his
arms
,
and
that
,
at
the
same
moment
,
Mr
Pecksniff
stepped
back
so
hastily
,
that
he
missed
his
footing
,
tumbled
over
a
chair
,
and
fell
in
a
sitting
posture
on
the
ground
;
where
he
remained
without
an
effort
to
get
up
again
,
with
his
head
in
a
corner
,
perhaps
considering
it
the
safest
place
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
,
Pinch
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
shaking
him
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
hold
me
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
a
blow
could
make
him
a
more
abject
creature
than
he
is
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
if
I
spat
upon
him
,
I
could
degrade
him
to
a
lower
level
than
his
own
?
 
<EOS>
Look
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
him
,
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
involuntarily
did
so
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
sitting
,
as
has
been
already
mentioned
,
on
the
carpet
,
with
his
head
in
an
acute
angle
of
the
wainscot
,
and
all
the
damage
and
detriment
of
an
uncomfortable
journey
about
him
,
was
not
exactly
a
model
of
all
that
is
prepossessing
and
dignified
in
man
,
certainly
.
 
<EOS>
Still
he
WAS
Pecksniff
;
it
was
impossible
to
deprive
him
of
that
unique
and
paramount
appeal
to
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
returned
Tom
's
glance
,
as
if
he
would
have
said
,
"
Aye
,
Mr
Pinch
,
look
at
me
!
 
<EOS>
Here
I
am
!
 
<EOS>
You
know
what
the
Poet
says
about
an
honest
man
;
and
an
honest
man
is
one
of
the
few
great
works
that
can
be
seen
for
nothing
!
 
<EOS>
Look
at
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
that
as
he
lies
there
,
disgraced
,
bought
,
used
;
a
cloth
for
dirty
hands
,
a
mat
for
dirty
feet
,
a
lying
,
fawning
,
servile
hound
,
he
is
the
very
last
and
worst
among
the
vermin
of
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
And
mark
me
,
Pinch
!
 
<EOS>
The
day
will
come
---
he
knows
it
;
see
it
written
on
his
face
,
while
I
speak
!
<EOS>
---
when
even
you
will
find
him
out
,
and
will
know
him
as
I
do
,
and
as
he
knows
I
do
.
<EOS>
HE
renounce
ME
!
 
<EOS>
Cast
your
eyes
on
the
Renouncer
,
Pinch
,
and
be
the
wiser
for
the
recollection
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
pointed
at
him
as
he
spoke
,
with
unutterable
contempt
,
and
flinging
his
hat
upon
his
head
,
walked
from
the
room
and
from
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
so
rapidly
that
he
was
already
clear
of
the
village
,
when
he
heard
Tom
Pinch
calling
breathlessly
after
him
in
the
distance
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
what
now
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
when
Tom
came
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
"
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
!
"
<EOS>
he
echoed
.
 
<EOS>
"
Going
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
so
much
mean
that
,
as
were
you
going
now
at
once
---
in
this
bad
weather
---
on
foot
---
without
your
clothes
---
<EOS>
with
no
money
?
"
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
he
answered
sternly
,
"
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
where
?
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
where
will
you
go
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
to
America
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
cried
Tom
,
in
a
kind
of
agony
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
there
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Think
better
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
so
dreadfully
regardless
of
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
to
America
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
mind
is
made
up
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
friend
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
to
America
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
,
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Take
this
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
pressing
a
book
upon
him
in
great
agitation
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
make
haste
back
,
and
ca
n't
say
anything
I
would
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
be
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
leaf
I
have
turned
down
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
<EOS>
,
good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
simple
fellow
wrung
him
by
the
hand
,
with
tears
stealing
down
his
cheeks
;
and
they
parted
hurriedly
upon
their
separate
ways
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
13
.
<EOS>
Showing
what
became
of
martin
and
his
desparate
resolve
,
after
he
left
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
;
what
persons
he
encountered
;
what
anxieties
he
suffered
;
and
what
news
he
heard
 
Carrying
Tom
Pinch
's
book
quite
unconsciously
under
his
arm
,
and
not
even
buttoning
his
coat
as
a
protection
against
the
heavy
rain
,
Martin
went
doggedly
forward
at
the
same
quick
pace
,
until
he
had
passed
the
finger
-
post
,
and
was
on
the
high
road
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
He
slackened
very
little
in
his
speed
even
then
,
but
he
began
to
think
,
and
look
about
him
,
and
to
disengage
his
senses
from
the
coil
of
angry
passions
which
hitherto
had
held
them
prisoner
.
   
<EOS>
It
must
be
confessed
that
,
at
that
moment
,
he
had
no
very
agreeable
employment
either
for
his
moral
or
his
physical
perceptions
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
was
dawning
from
a
patch
of
watery
light
in
the
east
,
and
sullen
clouds
came
driving
up
before
it
,
from
which
the
rain
descended
in
a
thick
,
wet
mist
.
 
<EOS>
It
streamed
from
every
twig
and
bramble
in
the
hedge
;
made
little
gullies
in
the
path
;
ran
down
a
hundred
channels
in
the
road
;
and
punched
innumerable
holes
into
the
face
of
every
pond
and
gutter
.
 
<EOS>
It
fell
with
an
oozy
,
slushy
sound
among
the
grass
;
and
made
a
muddy
kennel
of
every
furrow
in
the
ploughed
fields
.
 
<EOS>
No
living
creature
was
anywhere
to
be
seen
.
 
<EOS>
The
prospect
could
hardly
have
been
more
desolate
if
animated
nature
had
been
dissolved
in
water
,
and
poured
down
upon
the
earth
again
in
that
form
.
   
<EOS>
The
range
of
view
within
the
solitary
traveller
was
quite
as
cheerless
as
the
scene
without
.
 
<EOS>
Friendless
and
penniless
<EOS>
;
incensed
to
the
last
degree
;
deeply
wounded
in
his
pride
and
self
-
love
;
full
of
independent
schemes
,
and
perfectly
destitute
of
any
means
of
realizing
them
;
his
most
vindictive
enemy
might
have
been
satisfied
with
the
extent
of
his
troubles
.
 
<EOS>
To
add
to
his
other
miseries
,
he
was
by
this
time
sensible
of
being
wet
to
the
skin
,
and
cold
at
his
very
heart
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
deplorable
condition
he
remembered
Mr
Pinch
's
book
;
more
because
it
was
rather
troublesome
to
carry
,
than
from
any
hope
of
being
comforted
by
that
parting
gift
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
the
dingy
lettering
on
the
back
,
and
finding
it
to
be
an
odd
volume
of
the
"
Bachelor
of
Salamanca
,
"
in
the
French
tongue
,
cursed
Tom
Pinch
's
folly
twenty
times
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
on
the
point
of
throwing
it
away
,
in
his
ill
-
humour
and
vexation
,
when
he
bethought
himself
that
Tom
had
referred
him
to
a
leaf
,
turned
down
;
and
opening
it
at
that
place
,
that
he
might
have
additional
cause
of
complaint
against
him
for
supposing
that
any
cold
scrap
of
the
Bachelor
's
wisdom
could
cheer
him
in
such
circumstances
,
found
!
<EOS>
---
    
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
<EOS>
not
much
,
but
Tom
's
all
.
 
<EOS>
The
half
-
sovereign
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
wrapped
it
hastily
in
a
piece
of
paper
,
and
pinned
it
to
the
leaf
.
<EOS>
These
words
were
scrawled
in
pencil
on
the
inside
:
"
I
do
n't
want
it
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not
know
what
to
do
with
it
if
I
had
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
are
some
falsehoods
,
Tom
,
on
which
men
mount
,
as
on
bright
wings
,
towards
Heaven
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
some
truths
,
cold
bitter
taunting
truths
,
wherein
your
worldly
scholars
are
very
apt
and
punctual
,
which
bind
men
down
to
earth
with
leaden
chains
.
 
<EOS>
Who
would
not
rather
have
to
fan
him
,
in
his
dying
hour
,
the
lightest
feather
of
a
falsehood
such
as
thine
,
than
all
the
quills
that
have
been
plucked
from
the
sharp
porcupine
,
reproachful
truth
,
since
time
began
!
   
<EOS>
Martin
felt
keenly
for
himself
,
and
he
felt
this
good
deed
of
Tom
's
keenly
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
few
minutes
it
had
the
effect
of
raising
his
spirits
,
and
reminding
him
that
he
was
not
altogether
destitute
,
as
he
had
left
a
fair
stock
of
clothes
behind
him
,
and
wore
a
gold
hunting
-
watch
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
a
curious
gratification
,
too
,
in
thinking
what
a
winning
fellow
he
must
be
to
have
made
such
an
impression
on
Tom
;
and
in
reflecting
how
superior
he
was
to
Tom
;
and
how
much
more
likely
to
make
his
way
in
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Animated
by
these
thoughts
,
and
strengthened
in
his
design
of
endeavouring
to
push
his
fortune
in
another
country
,
he
resolved
to
get
to
London
as
a
rallying
-
point
,
in
the
best
way
he
could
;
and
to
lose
no
time
about
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
ten
good
miles
from
the
village
made
illustrious
by
being
the
abiding
-
place
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
when
he
stopped
to
breakfast
at
a
little
roadside
alehouse
;
and
resting
upon
a
high
-
backed
settle
before
the
fire
,
pulled
off
his
coat
,
and
hung
it
before
the
cheerful
blaze
to
dry
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
different
place
from
the
last
tavern
in
which
he
had
regaled
;
boasting
no
greater
extent
of
accommodation
than
the
brick
-
floored
kitchen
yielded
;
but
the
mind
so
soon
accommodates
itself
to
the
necessities
of
the
body
,
that
this
poor
waggoner
's
house
-
of
-
call
,
which
he
would
have
despised
yesterday
,
became
now
quite
a
choice
hotel
;
while
his
dish
of
eggs
and
bacon
,
and
his
mug
of
beer
,
were
not
by
any
means
the
coarse
fare
he
had
supposed
,
but
fully
bore
out
the
inscription
on
the
window
-
shutter
,
which
proclaimed
those
viands
to
be
"
Good
entertainment
for
Travellers
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
pushed
away
his
empty
plate
;
and
with
a
second
mug
upon
the
hearth
before
him
,
looked
thoughtfully
at
the
fire
until
his
eyes
ached
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
looked
at
the
highly
-
coloured
scripture
pieces
on
the
walls
,
in
little
black
frames
like
common
shaving
-
glasses
,
and
saw
how
the
Wise
Men
(
with
a
strong
family
likeness
among
them
)
worshipped
in
a
pink
manger
;
and
how
the
Prodigal
Son
came
home
in
red
rags
to
a
purple
father
,
and
already
feasted
his
imagination
on
a
sea
-
green
calf
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
glanced
through
the
window
at
the
falling
rain
,
coming
down
aslant
upon
the
sign
-
post
over
against
the
house
,
and
overflowing
the
horse
-
trough
;
and
then
he
looked
at
the
fire
again
,
and
seemed
to
descry
a
double
distant
London
,
retreating
among
the
fragments
of
the
burning
wood
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
repeated
this
process
in
just
the
same
order
,
many
times
,
as
if
it
were
a
matter
of
necessity
,
when
the
sound
of
wheels
called
his
attention
to
the
window
out
of
its
regular
turn
;
and
there
he
beheld
a
kind
of
light
van
drawn
by
four
horses
,
and
laden
,
as
well
as
he
could
see
(
for
it
was
covered
in
)
,
with
corn
and
straw
.
 
<EOS>
The
driver
,
who
was
alone
,
stopped
at
the
door
to
water
his
team
,
and
presently
came
stamping
and
shaking
the
wet
off
his
hat
and
coat
,
into
the
room
where
Martin
sat
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
red
-
faced
burly
young
fellow
;
smart
in
his
way
,
and
with
a
good
-
humoured
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
advanced
towards
the
fire
he
touched
his
shining
forehead
with
the
forefinger
of
his
stiff
leather
glove
,
by
way
of
salutation
;
and
said
(
rather
unnecessarily
)
that
it
was
an
uncommon
wet
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
wet
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
as
ever
I
see
a
wetter
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never
felt
one
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
The
driver
glanced
at
Martin
's
soiled
dress
,
and
his
damp
shirt
-
sleeves
,
and
his
coat
hung
up
to
dry
;
and
said
,
after
a
pause
,
as
he
warmed
his
hands
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
caught
in
it
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
was
the
short
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Out
riding
,
maybe
?
"
said
the
driver
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
been
,
if
I
owned
a
horse
;
but
I
do
n't
,
"
returned
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
bad
,
"
said
the
driver
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
may
be
worse
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
Now
the
driver
said
"
That
's
bad
,
"
not
so
much
because
Martin
did
n't
own
a
horse
,
as
because
he
said
he
did
n't
with
all
the
reckless
desperation
of
his
mood
and
circumstances
,
and
so
left
a
great
deal
to
be
inferred
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
put
his
hands
in
his
pockets
and
whistled
when
he
had
retorted
on
the
driver
;
thus
giving
him
to
understand
that
he
did
n't
care
a
pin
for
Fortune
;
that
he
was
above
pretending
to
be
her
favourite
when
he
was
not
;
and
that
he
snapped
his
fingers
at
her
,
the
driver
,
and
everybody
else
.
   
<EOS>
The
driver
looked
at
him
stealthily
for
a
minute
or
so
;
and
in
the
pauses
of
his
warming
whistled
too
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
asked
,
as
he
pointed
his
thumb
towards
the
road
.
   
<EOS>
"
Up
or
down
?
"
   
"
Which
IS
up
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
London
,
of
course
,
"
said
the
driver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Up
then
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
He
tossed
his
head
in
a
careless
manner
afterwards
,
as
if
he
would
have
added
,
"
Now
you
know
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
put
his
hands
deeper
into
his
pockets
;
changed
his
tune
,
and
whistled
a
little
louder
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
going
up
,
"
observed
the
driver
;
"
Hounslow
,
ten
miles
this
side
London
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
stopping
short
and
looking
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
driver
sprinkled
the
fire
with
his
wet
hat
until
it
hissed
again
and
answered
,
"
Aye
,
to
be
sure
he
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
I
'll
be
plain
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
suppose
from
my
dress
that
I
have
money
to
spare
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
.
 
<EOS>
All
I
can
afford
for
coach
-
hire
is
a
crown
,
for
I
have
but
two
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
can
take
me
for
that
,
and
my
waistcoat
,
or
this
silk
handkerchief
,
do
.
<EOS>
If
you
ca
n't
,
leave
it
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Short
and
sweet
,
"
remarked
the
driver
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
want
more
?
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
I
have
n't
got
more
,
and
I
ca
n't
get
it
,
so
there
's
an
end
of
that
.
"
 
<EOS>
Whereupon
he
began
to
whistle
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
say
I
wanted
more
,
did
I
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
driver
,
with
something
like
indignation
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
say
my
offer
was
enough
,
"
rejoined
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
could
I
,
when
you
would
n't
let
me
?
 
<EOS>
In
regard
to
the
waistcoat
,
I
would
n't
have
a
man
's
waistcoat
,
much
less
a
gentleman
's
waistcoat
,
on
my
mind
,
for
no
consideration
;
but
the
silk
handkerchief
's
another
thing
;
and
if
you
was
satisfied
when
we
got
to
Hounslow
,
I
should
n't
object
to
that
as
a
gift
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
a
bargain
,
then
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
,
"
returned
the
other
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
finish
this
beer
,
"
said
Martin
,
handing
him
the
mug
,
and
pulling
on
his
coat
with
great
alacrity
;
"
and
let
us
be
off
as
soon
as
you
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
two
minutes
more
he
had
paid
his
bill
,
which
amounted
to
a
shilling
;
was
lying
at
full
length
on
a
truss
of
straw
,
high
and
dry
at
the
top
of
the
van
,
with
the
tilt
a
little
open
in
front
for
the
convenience
of
talking
to
his
new
friend
;
and
was
moving
along
in
the
right
direction
with
a
most
satisfactory
and
encouraging
briskness
.
   
<EOS>
The
driver
's
name
,
as
he
soon
informed
Martin
,
was
William
Simmons
,
better
known
as
Bill
;
and
his
spruce
appearance
was
sufficiently
explained
by
his
connection
with
a
large
stage
-
coaching
establishment
at
Hounslow
,
whither
he
was
conveying
his
load
from
a
farm
belonging
to
the
concern
in
Wiltshire
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
frequently
up
and
down
the
road
on
such
errands
,
he
said
,
and
to
look
after
the
sick
and
rest
horses
,
of
which
animals
<EOS>
he
had
much
to
relate
that
occupied
a
long
time
in
the
telling
.
 
<EOS>
He
aspired
to
the
dignity
of
the
regular
box
,
and
expected
an
appointment
on
the
first
vacancy
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
musical
besides
,
and
had
a
little
key
-
bugle
in
his
pocket
,
on
which
,
whenever
the
conversation
flagged
,
he
played
the
first
part
of
a
great
many
tunes
,
and
regularly
broke
down
in
the
second
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Bill
,
with
a
sigh
,
as
he
drew
the
back
of
his
hand
across
his
lips
,
and
put
this
instrument
in
his
pocket
,
after
screwing
off
the
mouth
-
piece
to
drain
it
;
"
Lummy
Ned
of
the
Light
Salisbury
,
HE
was
the
one
for
musical
talents
.
 
<EOS>
He
WAS
a
guard
.
 
<EOS>
What
you
may
call
a
Guard'an
Angel
,
was
Ned
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
dead
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dead
!
"
replied
the
other
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not

.
<EOS>
You
wo

Ned

-

.
 
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,
"
<EOS>
so

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

"

"

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Did

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
   
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Particular

<EOS>
"
New

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

;
as

;

?
<EOS>
and

.
 
<EOS>
But

his
friend
was
possessed
of
little

;
either
answering
obviously

,

;
nor

.
   
<EOS>
They

on

,

---

,

that

.
 
<EOS>

for

,

,

,

,

many

that

did

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

,
they
parted

;
and

into

own

the

,

,

,

,
upon

dreary

,

.
   
<EOS>
But

,

often

,

of
Mr
Pecksniff
operated
as

to

;
awakening
in

an

that
was
very

in
nerving

to

.
 
<EOS>
Under

this

dram
he
started

for
London
without
more
ado
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
there
in

,

where
to
find
a

,
he
was

and

until

.
   
<EOS>
He
found

,
about

,

of

;
and

,

of
an
obscure

house
,
informed

that
he

,
and

could

.
<EOS>
It
happened
by
good
luck
that
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
Though
none
of
the
gaudiest
,
it
was
tolerably
clean
,
and
Martin
felt
very
glad
and

when
he
crept
into

,
for

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
It

late
in

when

;
and

had
washed

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

,
for

that

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ha

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

,

!
"

Tigg

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
A

-
watch
,
David
,

-

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>

:

,

twenty
-
six
-
and
-
a
-
half
B
:
lodger
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here
he
winked
at
Martin
again
,
to
apprise
him
that
all
the
forms
and
ceremonies
prescribed
by
law
were
now
complied
with
,
and
nothing
remained
but
the
receipt
for
the
money
.
   
<EOS>
In
point
of
fact
,
this
proved
to
be
the
case
,
for
Martin
,
who
had
no
resource
but
to
take
what
was
offered
him
,
signified
his
acquiescence
by
a
nod
of
his
head
,
and
presently
came
out
with
the
cash
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
joined
in
the
entry
by
Mr
Tigg
,
who
warmly
congratulated
him
,
as
he
took
his
arm
and
accompanied
him
into
the
street
,
on
the
successful
issue
of
the
negotiation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
for
my
part
in
the
same
,
"
said
Mr
Tigg
,
"
do
n't
mention
it
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
compliment
me
,
for
I
ca
n't
bear
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
such
intention
,
I
assure
you
,
"
retorted
Martin
,
releasing
his
arm
and
stopping
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
oblige
me
very
much
"
said
Mr
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
observed
Martin
,
biting
his
lip
,
"
this
is
a
large
town
,
and
we
can
easily
find
different
ways
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
show
me
which
is
your
way
,
I
will
take
another
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
was
about
to
speak
,
but
Martin
interposed
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
need
scarcely
tell
you
,
after
what
you
have
just
seen
,
that
I
have
nothing
to
bestow
upon
your
friend
Mr
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
And
it
is
quite
as
unnecessary
for
me
to
tell
you
that
I
do
n't
desire
the
honour
of
your
company
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
"
cried
Mr
Tigg
,
holding
out
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
most
remarkably
long
-
headed
,
flowing
-
bearded
,
and
patriarchal
proverb
,
which
observes
that
it
is
the
duty
of
a
man
to
be
just
before
he
is
generous
.
 
<EOS>
Be
just
now
,
and
you
can
be
generous
presently
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
confuse
me
with
the
man
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
distinguish
the
man
Slyme
as
a
friend
of
mine
,
for
he
is
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
compelled
,
sir
,
to
abandon
the
party
whom
you
call
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
knowledge
of
the
party
whom
you
call
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tigg
,
striking
himself
upon
the
breast
,
"
a
premium
tulip
,
of
a
very
different
growth
and
cultivation
from
the
cabbage
Slyme
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
matters
very
little
to
me
,
"
said
Martin
coolly
,
"
whether
you
have
set
up
as
a
vagabond
on
your
own
account
,
or
are
still
trading
on
behalf
of
Mr
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
to
hold
no
correspondence
with
you
.
<EOS>
In
the
devil
's
name
,
man
"
said
Martin
,
scarcely
able
,
despite
his
vexation
,
to
repress
a
smile
as
Mr
Tigg
stood
leaning
his
back
against
the
shutters
of
a
shop
window
,
adjusting
his
hair
with
great
composure
,
"
will
you
go
one
way
or
other
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
allow
me
to
remind
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tigg
,
with
sudden
dignity
,
"
that
you
---
not
I
---
<EOS>
that
you
---
I
say
emphatically
,
YOU
---
have
reduced
the
proceedings
of
this
evening
to
a
cold
and
distant
matter
of
business
,
when
I
was
disposed
to
place
them
on
a
friendly
footing
.
 
<EOS>
It
being
made
a
matter
of
business
,
sir
,
I
beg
to
say
that
I
expect
a
trifle
(
which
I
shall
bestow
in
charity
)
as
commission
upon
the
pecuniary
advance
,
in
which
I
have
rendered
you
my
humble
services
.
 
<EOS>
After
the
terms
in
which
you
have
addressed
me
,
sir
,
"
concluded
Mr
Tigg
,
"
you
will
not
insult
me
,
if
you
please
,
by
offering
more
than
half
-
a
-
crown
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
drew
that
piece
of
money
from
his
pocket
,
and
tossed
it
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
caught
it
,
looked
at
it
to
assure
himself
of
its
goodness
,
spun
it
in
the
air
after
the
manner
of
a
pieman
,
and
buttoned
it
up
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
he
raised
his
hat
an
inch
or
two
from
his
head
with
a
military
air
,
and
,
after
pausing
a
moment
with
deep
gravity
,
as
to
decide
in
which
direction
he
should
go
,
and
to
what
Earl
or
Marquis
among
his
friends
he
should
give
the
preference
in
his
next
call
,
stuck
his
hands
in
his
skirt
-
pockets
and
swaggered
round
the
corner
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
took
the
directly
opposite
course
;
and
<EOS>
so
,
to
his
great
content
,
they
parted
company
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
with
a
bitter
sense
of
humiliation
that
he
cursed
,
again
and
again
,
the
mischance
of
having
encountered
this
man
in
the
pawnbroker
's
shop
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
comfort
he
had
in
the
recollection
was
,
Mr
Tigg
's
voluntary
avowal
of
a
separation
between
himself
and
Slyme
,
that
would
at
least
prevent
his
circumstances
(
so
Martin
argued
)
from
being
known
to
any
member
of
his
family
,
the
bare
possibility
of
which
filled
him
with
shame
and
wounded
pride
.
 
<EOS>
Abstractedly
there
was
greater
reason
,
perhaps
,
for
supposing
any
declaration
of
Mr
Tigg
's
to
be
false
,
than
for
attaching
the
least
credence
to
it
;
but
remembering
the
terms
on
which
the
intimacy
between
that
gentleman
and
his
bosom
friend
had
subsisted
,
and
the
strong
probability
of
Mr
Tigg
's
having
established
an
independent
business
of
his
own
on
Mr
Slyme
's
connection
,
it
had
a
reasonable
appearance
of
probability
;
at
all
events
,
Martin
hoped
so
;
and
that
went
a
long
way
.
   
<EOS>
His
first
step
,
now
that
he
had
a
supply
of
ready
money
for
his
present
necessities
,
was
,
to
retain
his
bed
at
the
public
-
house
until
further
notice
,
and
to
write
a
formal
note
to
Tom
Pinch
(
for
he
knew
Pecksniff
would
see
it
)
<EOS>
requesting
to
have
his
clothes
forwarded
to
London
by
coach
,
with
a
direction
to
be
left
at
the
office
until
called
for
.
 
<EOS>
These
measures
taken
,
he
passed
the
interval
before
the
box
arrived
---
three
days
---
in
making
inquiries
relative
to
American
vessels
,
at
the
offices
of
various
shipping
-
agents
in
the
city
;
and
in
lingering
about
the
docks
and
wharves
,
with
the
faint
hope
of
stumbling
upon
some
engagement
for
the
voyage
,
as
clerk
or
supercargo
,
or
custodian
of
something
or
somebody
,
which
would
enable
him
to
procure
a
free
passage
.
 
<EOS>
But
finding
,
soon
,
that
no
such
means
of
employment
were
likely
to
present
themselves
,
and
dreading
the
consequences
of
delay
,
he
drew
up
a
short
advertisement
,
stating
what
he
wanted
,
and
inserted
it
in
the
leading
newspapers
.
 
<EOS>
Pending
the
receipt
of
the
twenty
or
thirty
answers
which
he
vaguely
expected
,
he
reduced
his
wardrobe
to
the
narrowest
limits
consistent
with
decent
respectability
,
and
carried
the
overplus
at
different
times
to
the
pawnbroker
's
shop
,
for
conversion
into
money
.
   
<EOS>
And
it
was
strange
,
very
strange
,
even
to
himself
,
to
find
how
,
by
quick
though
almost
imperceptible
degrees
,
he
lost
his
delicacy
and
self
-
respect
,
and
gradually
came
to
do
that
as
a
matter
of
course
,
without
the
least
compunction
,
which
but
a
few
short
days
before
had
galled
him
to
the
quick
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
time
he
visited
the
pawnbroker
's
,
he
felt
on
his
way
there
as
if
every
person
whom
he
passed
suspected
whither
he
was
going
;
and
on
his
way
back
again
,
as
if
the
whole
human
tide
he
stemmed
,
knew
well
where
he
had
come
from
.
 
<EOS>
When
did
he
care
to
think
of
their
discernment
now
!
 
<EOS>
In
his
first
wanderings
up
and
down
the
weary
streets
,
he
counterfeited
the
walk
of
one
who
had
an
object
in
his
view
;
but
soon
there
came
upon
him
the
sauntering
,
slipshod
gait
of
listless
idleness
,
and
the
lounging
at
street
-
corners
,
and
plucking
and
biting
of
stray
bits
of
straw
,
and
strolling
up
and
down
the
same
place
,
and
looking
into
the
same
shop
-
windows
,
with
a
miserable
indifference
,
fifty
times
a
day
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
he
came
out
from
his
lodging
with
an
uneasy
sense
of
being
observed
---
even
by
those
chance
passers
-
by
,
on
whom
he
had
never
looked
before
,
and
hundreds
to
one
would
never
see
again
---
 
issuing
in
the
morning
from
a
public
-
house
;
but
now
,
in
his
comings
-
out
and
goings
-
in
he
did
not
mind
to
lounge
about
the
door
,
or
to
stand
sunning
himself
in
careless
thought
beside
the
wooden
stem
,
studded
from
head
to
heel
with
pegs
,
on
which
the
beer
-
pots
dangled
like
so
many
boughs
upon
a
pewter
-
tree
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
it
took
but
<EOS>
five
weeks
to
reach
the
lowest
round
of
this
tall
ladder
!
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
moralists
,
who
treat
of
happiness
and
self
-
respect
,
innate
in
every
sphere
of
life
,
and
shedding
light
on
every
grain
of
dust
in
God
's
highway
,
so
smooth
below
your
carriage
-
wheels
,
so
rough
beneath
the
tread
of
naked
feet
,
bethink
yourselves
in
looking
on
the
swift
descent
of
men
who
HAVE
lived
in
their
own
esteem
,
that
there
are
scores
of
thousands
breathing
now
,
and
breathing
thick
with
painful
toil
,
who
in
that
high
respect
have
never
lived
at
all
,
nor
had
a
chance
of
life
!
 
<EOS>
Go
ye
,
who
rest
so
placidly
upon
the
sacred
Bard
who
had
been
young
,
and
when
he
strung
his
harp
was
old
,
and
had
never
seen
the
righteous
forsaken
,
or
his
seed
begging
their
bread
;
go
,
Teachers
of
content
and
honest
pride
,
into
the
mine
,
the
mill
,
the
forge
,
the
squalid
depths
of
deepest
ignorance
,
and
uttermost
abyss
of
man
's
neglect
,
and
say
can
any
hopeful
plant
spring
up
in
air
so
foul
that
it
extinguishes
the
soul
's
bright
torch
as
fast
as
it
is
kindled
!
 
<EOS>
And
,
oh
!
ye
<EOS>
Pharisees
of
the
nineteen
hundredth
year
of
Christian
Knowledge
,
who
soundingly
appeal
to
human
nature
,
see
that
it
be
human
first
.
 
<EOS>
Take
heed
it
has
not
been
transformed
,
during
your
slumber
and
the
sleep
of
generations
,
into
the
nature
of
the
Beasts
!
   
<EOS>
Five
weeks
!
 
<EOS>
Of
all
the
twenty
or
thirty
answers
,
not
one
had
come
.
<EOS>
His
money
---
even
the
additional
stock
he
had
raised
from
the
disposal
of
his
spare
clothes
(
and
that
was
not
much
,
for
clothes
,
though
dear
to
buy
,
are
cheap
to
pawn
)
---
was
fast
diminishing
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
what
could
he
do
?
 
<EOS>
At
times
an
agony
came
over
him
in
which
he
darted
forth
again
,
though
he
was
but
newly
home
,
and
,
returning
to
some
place
where
he
had
been
already
twenty
times
,
made
some
new
attempt
to
gain
his
end
,
but
always
unsuccessfully
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
years
and
years
too
old
for
a
cabin
-
boy
,
and
years
upon
years
too
inexperienced
to
be
accepted
as
a
common
seaman
.
 
<EOS>
His
dress
and
manner
,
too
,
militated
fatally
against
any
such
proposal
as
the
latter
;
and
yet
he
was
reduced
to
making
it
;
for
even
if
he
could
have
contemplated
the
being
set
down
in
America
totally
without
money
,
he
had
not
enough
left
now
for
a
steerage
passage
and
the
poorest
provisions
upon
the
voyage
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
an
illustration
of
a
very
common
tendency
in
the
mind
of
man
,
that
all
this
time
he
never
once
doubted
,
one
may
almost
say
the
certainty
of
doing
great
things
in
the
New
World
,
if
he
could
only
get
there
.
 
<EOS>
In
proportion
as
he
became
more
and
more
dejected
by
his
present
circumstances
,
and
the
means
of
gaining
America
receded
from
his
grasp
,
the
more
he
fretted
himself
with
the
conviction
that
that
was
the
only
place
in
which
he
could
hope
to
achieve
any
high
end
,
and
worried
his
brain
with
the
thought
that
men
going
there
in
the
meanwhile
might
anticipate
him
in
the
attainment
of
those
objects
which
were
dearest
to
his
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
often
thought
of
John
Westlock
,
and
besides
looking
out
for
him
on
all
occasions
,
actually
walked
about
London
for
three
days
together
for
the
express
purpose
of
meeting
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
although
he
failed
in
this
;
and
although
he
would
not
have
scrupled
to
borrow
money
of
him
;
and
although
he
believed
that
John
would
have
lent
it
;
yet
still
he
could
not
bring
his
mind
to
write
to
Pinch
and
inquire
where
he
was
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
For
although
,
as
we
have
seen
,
he
was
fond
of
Tom
after
his
own
fashion
,
he
could
not
endure
the
thought
(
feeling
so
superior
to
Tom
)
of
making
him
the
stepping
-
stone
to
his
fortune
,
or
being
anything
to
him
but
a
patron
;
and
his
pride
so
revolted
from
the
idea
that
it
restrained
him
even
now
.
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
yielded
,
however
;
and
no
doubt
must
have
yielded
soon
,
but
for
a
very
strange
and
unlooked
-
for
occurrence
.
   
<EOS>
The
five
weeks
had
quite
run
out
,
and
he
was
in
a
truly
desperate
plight
,
<EOS>
when
one
evening
,
having
just
returned
to
his
lodging
,
and
being
in
the
act
of
lighting
his
candle
at
the
gas
jet
in
the
bar
before
stalking
moodily
upstairs
to
his
own
room
,
his
landlord
called
him
by
his
name
.
 
<EOS>
Now
as
he
had
never
told
it
to
the
man
,
but
had
scrupulously
kept
it
to
himself
,
he
was
not
a
little
startled
by
this
;
and
so
plainly
showed
his
agitation
that
the
landlord
,
to
reassure
him
,
said
"
it
was
only
a
letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
letter
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
Mr
Martin
Chuzzlewit
,
"
said
the
landlord
,
reading
the
superscription
of
one
he
held
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Noon
.
 
<EOS>
Chief
office
.
<EOS>
Paid
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
took
it
from
him
,
thanked
him
,
and
walked
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
sealed
,
but
pasted
close
;
the
handwriting
was
quite
unknown
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
opened
it
and
found
enclosed
,
without
any
name
,
address
,
or
other
inscription
or
explanation
of
any
kind
whatever
,
a
Bank
of
England
note
for
Twenty
Pounds
.
   
<EOS>
To
say
that
he
was
perfectly
stunned
with
astonishment
and
delight
;
that
he
looked
again
and
again
at
the
note
and
the
wrapper
;
that
he
hurried
below
stairs
to
make
quite
certain
that
the
note
was
a
good
note
;
and
then
hurried
up
again
to
satisfy
himself
for
the
fiftieth
time
that
he
had
not
overlooked
some
scrap
of
writing
on
the
wrapper
;
that
he
exhausted
and
bewildered
himself
with
conjectures
;
and
could
make
nothing
of
it
but
that
there
the
note
was
,
and
he
was
suddenly
enriched
;
would
be
only
to
relate
so
many
matters
of
course
to
no
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
The
final
upshot
of
the
business
at
that
time
was
,
that
he
resolved
to
treat
himself
to
a
comfortable
but
frugal
meal
in
his
own
chamber
;
and
having
ordered
a
fire
to
be
kindled
,
went
out
to
purchase
it
forthwith
.
   
<EOS>
He
bought
some
cold
beef
,
and
ham
,
and
French
bread
,
and
butter
,
and
came
back
with
his
pockets
pretty
heavily
laden
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
somewhat
of
a
damping
circumstance
to
find
the
room
full
of
smoke
,
which
was
attributable
to
two
causes
;
firstly
,
to
the
flue
being
naturally
vicious
and
a
smoker
;
and
secondly
,
to
their
having
forgotten
,
in
lighting
the
fire
,
an
odd
sack
or
two
and
some
trifles
,
which
had
been
put
up
the
chimney
to
keep
the
rain
out
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
already
remedied
this
oversight
,
however
;
and
propped
up
the
window
-
sash
with
a
bundle
of
firewood
to
keep
it
open
;
so
that
except
in
being
rather
inflammatory
to
the
eyes
and
choking
to
the
lungs
,
the
apartment
was
quite
comfortable
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
in
no
vein
to
quarrel
with
it
,
if
it
had
been
in
less
tolerable
order
,
especially
when
a
gleaming
pint
of
porter
was
set
upon
the
table
,
and
the
servant
-
girl
withdrew
,
bearing
with
her
particular
instructions
relative
to
the
production
of
something
hot
when
he
should
ring
the
bell
.
 
<EOS>
The
cold
meat
being
wrapped
in
a
playbill
,
Martin
laid
the
cloth
by
spreading
that
document
on
the
little
round
table
with
the
print
downwards
,
and
arranging
the
collation
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
foot
of
the
bed
,
which
was
very
close
to
the
fire
,
answered
for
a
sideboard
;
and
when
he
had
completed
these
preparations
,
he
squeezed
an
old
arm
-
chair
into
the
warmest
corner
,
and
sat
down
to
enjoy
himself
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
begun
to
eat
with
great
appetite
,
glancing
round
the
room
meanwhile
with
a
triumphant
anticipation
of
quitting
it
for
ever
on
the
morrow
,
when
his
attention
was
arrested
by
a
stealthy
footstep
on
the
stairs
,
and
presently
by
a
knock
at
his
chamber
door
,
which
,
although
it
was
a
gentle
knock
enough
,
communicated
such
a
start
to
the
bundle
of
firewood
,
that
it
instantly
leaped
out
of
window
,
and
plunged
into
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
More
coals
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
an't
a
liberty
,
sir
,
though
it
seems
so
<EOS>
,
"
rejoined
a
man
's
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
servant
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Hope
<EOS>
you
're
pretty
well
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
stared
at
the
face
that
was
bowing
in
the
doorway
,
perfectly
remembering
the
features
and
expression
,
but
quite
forgetting
to
whom
they
belonged
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tapley
,
sir
,
"
said
his
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Him
as
formerly
lived
at
the
Dragon
,
sir
,
and
was
forced
to
leave
in
consequence
of
a
want
of
jollity
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
did
you
come
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Right
through
the
passage
,
and
up
the
stairs
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
did
you
find
me
out
,
I
mean
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
I
've
passed
you
once
or
twice
in
the
street
,
if
I
'm
not
mistaken
;
and
when
I
was
a
-
looking
in
at
the
beef
-
and
-
ham
shop
just
now
,
along
with
a
hungry
sweep
,
as
was
very
much
calculated
to
make
a
man
jolly
,
sir
---
I
see
you
a
-
buying
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
reddened
as
he
pointed
to
the
table
,
and
said
,
somewhat
hastily
:
   
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
What
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
I
made
bold
to
foller
;
and
as
I
told
'em
downstairs
that
you
expected
me
,
I
was
let
up
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
charged
with
any
message
,
that
you
told
them
you
were
expected
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
I
an't
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
was
what
you
may
call
a
pious
fraud
,
sir
,
that
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
cast
an
angry
look
at
him
;
but
there
was
something
in
the
fellow
's
merry
face
,
and
in
his
manner
---
which
with
all
its
cheerfulness
was
far
from
being
obtrusive
or
familiar
---
that
quite
disarmed
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
lived
a
solitary
life
too
,
for
many
weeks
,
and
the
voice
was
pleasant
in
his
ear
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tapley
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
'll
deal
openly
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
From
all
I
can
judge
and
from
all
I
have
heard
of
you
through
Pinch
,
you
are
not
a
likely
kind
of
fellow
to
have
been
brought
here
by
impertinent
curiosity
or
any
other
offensive
motive
.
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
glad
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'd
as
lieve
stand
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
sit
down
,
"
retorted
Martin
,
"
I
'll
not
talk
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
sir
,
"
observed
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
will
's
a
law
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Down
it
is
;
"
and
he
sat
down
accordingly
upon
the
bedstead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Help
yourself
,
"
said
Martin
,
handing
him
the
only

.
   
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
After
you
've
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
take
it
now
,
you
'll
not
have
any
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
good
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
being
your
desire
---
now
it
is
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
which
reply
he
gravely
helped
himself
and
went
on
eating
.
<EOS>
Martin
having
done
the
like
for
a
short
time
in
silence
,
said
abruptly
:
   
"
What
are
you
doing
in
London
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
at
all
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
's
that
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
a
place
,
"
said
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
for
you
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
To
attend
upon
a
single
gentleman
,
"
resumed
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
from
the
country
the
more
desirable
.
 
<EOS>
Makeshifts
would
be
preferred
.
 
<EOS>
Wages
<EOS>
no
object
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
said
this
so
pointedly
,
that
Martin
stopped
in
his
eating
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
If
you
mean
me
---
"
   
"
Yes
,
I
do
,
sir
,
"
interposed
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
may
judge
from
my
style
of
living
here
,
of
my
means
of
keeping
a
man
-
servant
.
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
am
going
to
America
immediately
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
,
quite
unmoved
by
this
intelligence
"
from
all
that
<EOS>
ever
I
heard
about
it
,
I
should
say
America
is
a
very
likely
sort
of
place
for
me
to
be
jolly
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
Again
Martin
looked
at
him
angrily
;
and
again
his
anger
melted
away
in
spite
of
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
what
is
the
use
of
us
a
-
going
round
and
round
,
and
hiding
behind
the
corner
,
and
dodging
up
and
down
,
when
we
can
come
straight
to
the
point
in
six
words
?
 
<EOS>
I
've
had
my
eye
upon
you
any
time
this
fortnight
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
<EOS>
well
enough
there
's
a
screw
loose
in
your
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
I
know'd
<EOS>
well
enough
the
first
time
I
see
you
down
at
the
Dragon
that
it
must
be
so
,
sooner
or
later
.
<EOS>
Now
,
sir
here
am
I
,
without
a
sitiwation
;
without
any
want
of
wages
for
a
year
to
come
;
for
I
saved
up
<EOS>
(
I
did
n't
mean
to
do
it
,
but
I
could
n't
help
it
)
at
the
Dragon
---
<EOS>
here
am
I
with
a
liking
for
what
's
wentersome
,
and
a
liking
for
you
,
and
a
wish
to
come
out
strong
under
circumstances
as
would
keep
other
men
down
;
and
will

take
me
,
or

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
take
you
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
say

,
"
rejoined
Mark
,
"
I
mean
will
you
let
me
go
?
<EOS>
and
when
I
say
will
you
let
me
go
<EOS>
,
I
mean
will
you
let
me
go
along

you
?
<EOS>
for
go
<EOS>
I
will
,
somehow
or
another
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
you
've
said
America
<EOS>
,
I
see
clear
at

,
that
that
's
the

for

to

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
,
if
I
do
n't
pay
my
own
passage
in
the
ship
you
go
in
,
sir
,
I
'll
pay
my
own
passage
in
another
.
 
<EOS>
And
mark
my
words
,
if
I
go
alone
it
shall
be
,
to
carry
out
the
principle
,
in
the
rottenest
,
craziest
,
leakingest
tub
of
a
wessel
that
a
place
can
be
got
in
for
love
or

.
 
<EOS>
So
if
I
'm
lost
upon
the
way
,
sir
,
there
'll
be
a
drowned
man
at
your
door
---
and
always
a
-
knocking
double

at
it
,
too
,
or
never
trust
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
mere
folly
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
good
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
to
hear
it
,
because
if
you
do
n't
mean
to
let
me
go
,
you
'll
be
more
comfortable
,
perhaps
,
on
account
of
thinking
so
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
I
contradict
no
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
I
say
is
,
that
if
I
do
n't
emigrate
to
America
in
that
case
,
in
the
beastliest
old
cockle
-
shell
as
goes
out
of
port
,
I
'm
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
You
do
n't
mean

you
say
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
I
do
,
"
cried
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
I
know
better
,
"
rejoined
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
good
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
with
the
same
air

perfect

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
it
stand
that

at
present
,
sir
,
and
wait

see

it
turns
out
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
love
my
heart
alive
!
<EOS>
the
only
doubt
I
have
is
,
whether
there
's
any
credit
in
going
with
a

like
you
<EOS>
,

's
as
certain
to
make

as
a

<EOS>
is
to
go
through
soft
deal
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
touching
Martin
on
his
weak
point
,
and
having
him
at
a
great
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
help
thinking
,
either
,
what
a
brisk
fellow
this
Mark
was
,
and
how
great

change
he
had
wrought
in
the
atmosphere
of
the
dismal
little
room
already
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
certainly
,
Mark
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
have
hopes
of
doing
well
there
,
or
I
should
n't
go
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
have
the
qualifications
for
doing
well
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
you
have
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
"
Everybody
knows
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
Martin
,
leaning
his
chin
upon
his
hand
,
and
looking
at
the
fire
,
"
ornamental
architecture
applied
to
domestic
purposes
,
can
hardly
fail
to
be
in
great
request
in
that
country
;
for
men
are
constantly
changing
their
residences
there
,
and
moving
further
off
;
and
it
's
clear
they
must
have
houses
to
live
in
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
say
,
sir
,
"
observed
Mark
,
"
that
that
's
a
state
of
things
as
opens
one
of
the
jolliest
look
-
outs
for
domestic
architecture
that
ever
I
heerd
tell
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
glanced
at
him
hastily
,
not
feeling
quite
free
from
a
suspicion
that
this
remark
implied
a
doubt
of
the
successful
issue
of
his
plans
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Tapley
was
eating
the
boiled
beef
and
bread
with
such
entire
good
faith
and
singleness
of
purpose
expressed
in
his
visage
that
he
could
not
but
be
satisfied
.
 
<EOS>
Another
doubt
arose
in
his
mind
however
,
as
this
one
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
produced
the
blank
cover
in
which
the
note
had
been
enclosed
,
and
fixing
his
eyes
on
Mark
as
he
put
it
in
his
hands
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Now
tell
me
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
anything
about
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mark
turned
it
over
and
over
;
held
it
near
his
eyes
;
held
it
away
from
him
at
arm
's
length
;
held
it
with
the
superscription
upwards
and
with
the
superscription
downwards
;
and
shook
his
head
with
such
a
genuine
expression
of
astonishment
at
being
asked
the
question
,
that
Martin
said
,
as
he
took
it
from
him
again
:
   
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
see
you
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
How
should
you
!
 
<EOS>
Though
,
indeed
,
your
knowing
about
it
would
not
be
more
extraordinary
than
its
being
here
.
 
<EOS>
Come
,
Tapley
,
"
he
added
,
after
a
moment
's
thought
,
<EOS>
"
I
'll
trust
you
with
my
history
,
such
as
it
is
,
and
then
you
'll
see
more
clearly
what
sort
of
fortunes
you
would
link
yourself
to
,
if
you
followed
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
;
"
but
afore
you
enter
upon
it
will
you
take
me
if
I
choose
to
go
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
turn
off
me
---
Mark
Tapley
---
formerly
of
the
Blue
Dragon
,
as
can
be
well
recommended
by
Mr
Pinch
,
and
as
wants
a
gentleman
of
your
strength
of
mind
to
look
up
to
;
or
will
you
,
in
climbing
the
ladder
as
you
're
certain
to
get
to
the
top
of
,
take
me
along
with
you
at
a
respectful
dutance
?
 
<EOS>
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
it
's
of
very
little
importance
to
you
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
there
's
the
difficulty
;
but
it
's
of
very
great
importance
to
me
,
and
will
you
be
so
good
as
to
consider
of
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
If
this
were
meant
as
a
second
appeal
to
Martin
's
weak
side
,
founded
on
his
observation
of
the
effect
of
the
first
,
Mr
Tapley
was
a
skillful
and
shrewd
observer
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
an
intentional
or
an
accidental
shot
,
it
hit
the
mark
fully
for
Martin
,
relenting
more
and
more
,
said
with
a
condescension
which
was
inexpressibly
delicious
to
him
,
after
his
recent
humiliation
:
   
<EOS>
"
We
'll
see
about
it
,
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
tell
me
in
what
disposition
you
find
yourself
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
rubbing
his
hands
,
"
the
job
's
done
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
,
sir
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
all
attention
.
"
   
<EOS>
Throwing
himself
back
in
his
arm
-
chair
,
and
looking
at
the
fire
,
with
now
and
then
a
glance
at
Mark
,
who
at
such
times
nodded
his
head
sagely
,
to
express
his
profound
interest
and
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
ran
over
the
chief
points
in
his
history
,
to
the
same
effect
as
he
had
related
them
,
weeks
before
,
to
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
adapted
them
,
according
to
the
best
of
his
judgment
,
to
Mr
Tapley
's
comprehension
;
and
with
that
view
made
as
light
of
his
love
affair
as
he
could
,
and
referred
to
it
in
very
few
words
.
 
<EOS>
But
here
he
reckoned
without
his
host
;
for
Mark
's
interest
was
keenest
in
this
part
of
the
business
,
and
prompted
him
to
ask
sundry
questions
in
relation
to
it
;
for
which
he
apologised
as
one
in
some
measure
privileged
to
do
so
,
from
having
seen
(
as
Martin
explained
to
him
)
<EOS>
the
young
lady
at
the
Blue
Dragon
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
a
young
lady
as
any
gentleman
ought
to
feel
more
proud
of
being
in
love
with
,
"
said
Mark
,
energetically
,
"
do
n't
draw
breath
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
You
saw
her
when
she
was
not
happy
,
"
said
Martin
,
gazing
at
the
fire
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
seen
her
in
the
old
times
,
indeed
---
"
   
"
Why
,
she
certainly
was
a
little
down
-
hearted
,
sir
,
and
something
paler
in
her
colour
than
I
could
have
wished
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
but
none
the
worse
in
her
looks
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
she
seemed
better
,
sir
,
after
she
come
to
London
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
withdrew
his
eyes
from
the
fire
;
stared
at
Mark
as
if
he
thought
he
had
suddenly
gone
mad
;
and
asked
him
what
he
meant
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
offence
intended
,
sir
,
"
urged
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
to
say
she
was
any
the
happier
without
you
;
but
I
thought
she
was
a
-
looking
better
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
tell
me
she
has
been
in
London
?
"
asked
Martin
,
rising
hurriedly
,
and
pushing
back
his
chair
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
do
,
"
said
Mark
,
rising
too
,
in
great
amazement
from
the
bedstead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
tell
me
she
is
in
London
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Most
likely
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
mean
to
say
she
was
a
week
ago
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
know
where
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
cried
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Martin
,
clutching
him
by
both
arms
<EOS>
,
"
I
have
never
seen
her
since
I
left
my
grandfather
's
house
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
then
!
"
cried
Mark
,
giving
the
little
table
such
a
blow
with
his
clenched
fist
that
the
slices
of
beef
and
ham
danced
upon
it
,
while
all
his
features
seemed
,
with
delight
,
to
be
going
up
into
his
forehead
,
and
never
coming
back
again
any
more
,
"
<EOS>
if
I
an't
your
nat'ral
born
servant
,
hired
by
Fate
,
there
an't
<EOS>
such
a
thing
in
natur
"
as
a
Blue
Dragon
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
when
I
was
a
-
rambling
up
and
down
a
old
churchyard
in
the
City
,
getting
myself
into
a
jolly
state
,
did
n't
I
see
your
grandfather
a
-
toddling
to
and
fro
for
pretty
nigh
a
mortal
hour
!
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
I
watch
him
into
Todgers
's
commercial
boarding
-
house
,
and
watch
him
out
,
and
watch
him
home
to
his
hotel
,
and
go
and
tell
him
as
his
was
the
service
for
my
money
,
and
I
had
said
so
,
<EOS>
afore
I
left
the
Dragon
!
 
<EOS>
Was
n't
the
young
lady
a
-
sitting
with
him
then
,
and
did
n't
she
fall
a
-
laughing
in
a
manner
as
was
beautiful
to
see
!
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
your
grandfather
say
,
"
Come
back
again
next
week
,
"
and
did
n't
I
go
next
week
;
and
did
n't
he
say
that
he
could
n't
make
up
his
mind
to
trust
nobody
no
more
;
and
therefore
would
n't
engage
me
,
but
at
the
same
time
stood
something
to
drink
as
was
handsome
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
"
cried
Mr
Tapley
,
with
a
comical
mixture
of
delight
and
chagrin
,
"
<EOS>
where
's
<EOS>
the
credit
of
a
man
's
being
jolly
under
such
circumstances
!
 
<EOS>
Who
could
help
it
,
when
things
come
about
like
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
For
some
moments
Martin
stood
gazing
at
him
,
as
if
he
really
doubted
the
evidence
of
his
senses
,
and
could
not
believe
that
Mark
stood
there
,
in
the
body
,
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
asked
him
whether
,
if
the
young
lady
were
still
in
London
,
he
thought
he
could
contrive
to
deliver
a
letter
to
her
secretly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
think
I
can
?
"
cried
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
THINK
I
can
?
 
<EOS>
Here
,
sit
down
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Write
it
out
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
cleared
the
table
by
the
summary
process
of
tilting
everything
upon
it
into
the
fireplace
;
snatched
some
writing
materials
from
the
mantel
-
shelf
;
set
Martin
's
chair
before
them
;
forced
him
down
into
it
;
dipped
a
pen
into
the
ink
;
and
put
it
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cut
away
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
Make
it
strong
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Let
it
be
wery
pinted
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
think
so
?
 
<EOS>
I
should
think
so
.
 
<EOS>
Go
to
work
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
required
no
further
adjuration
,
but
went
to
work
at
a
great
rate
;
while
Mr
Tapley
,
installing
himself
without
any
more
formalities
into
the
functions
of
his
valet
and
general
attendant
,
divested
himself
of
his
coat
,
and
went
on
to
clear
the
fireplace
and
arrange
the
room
;
talking
to
himself
in
a
low
voice
the
whole
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jolly
sort
of
lodgings
,
"
said
Mark
,
rubbing
his
nose
with
the
knob
at
the
end
of
the
fire
-
shovel
,
and
looking
round
the
poor
chamber
;
"
that
's
a
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
's
come
through
the
roof
too
.
 
<EOS>
That
an't
bad
.
 
<EOS>
A
lively
old
bedstead
,
I
'll
be
bound
;
popilated
by
lots
of
wampires
,
no
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
my
spirits
is
a
-
getting
up
again
.
 
<EOS>
An
uncommon
ragged
nightcap
this
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
good
sign
.
 
<EOS>
We
shall
do
yet
!
<EOS>
Here
,
Jane
,
my
dear
,
"
calling
down
the
stairs
,
"
bring
up
that
there
hot
tumbler
for
my
master
as
was
a
-
mixing
when
I
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
right
,
sir
,
"
to
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
at
it
as
if
you
meant
it
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Be
very
tender
,
sir
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
make
it
too
strong
,
sir
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
14
.
<EOS>
In
which
Martin
bids
adieu
to
the
lady
of
his
love
;
and
honours
an
obscure
individual
whose
fortune
he
intends
to
make
by
commending
her
to
his
protection
 
<EOS>
The
letter
being
duly
signed
,
sealed
,
and
delivered
,
was
handed
to
Mark
Tapley
,
for
immediate
conveyance
if
possible
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
succeeded
so
well
in
his
embassy
as
to
be
enabled
to
return
that
same
night
,
just
as
the
house
was
closing
,
with
the
welcome
intelligence
that
he
had
sent
it
upstairs
to
the
young
lady
,
enclosed
in
a
small
manuscript
of
his
own
,
purporting
to
contain
his
further
petition
to
be
engaged
in
Mr
Chuzzlewit
's
service
;
and
that
she
had
herself
come
down
and
told
him
,
in
great
haste
and
agitation
,
that
she
would
meet
the
gentleman
at
eight
o'clock
to
-
morrow
morning
in
St.
James
's
Park
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
then
agreed
between
the
new
master
and
the
new
man
,
that
Mark
should
be
in
waiting
near
the
hotel
in
good
time
,
to
escort
the
young
lady
to
the
place
of
appointment
;
and
when
they
had
parted
for
the
night
with
this
understanding
,
Martin
took
up
his
pen
again
;
and
before
he
went
to
bed
wrote
another
letter
,
whereof
more
will
be
seen
presently
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
up
before
daybreak
,
and
came
upon
the
Park
with
the
morning
,
which
was
clad
in
the
least
engaging
of
the
three
hundred
and
sixty
-
five
dresses
in
the
wardrobe
of
the
year
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
raw
,
damp
,
dark
,
and
dismal
;
the
clouds
were
as
muddy
as
the
ground
;
and
the
short
perspective
of
every
street
and
avenue
was
closed
up
by
the
mist
as
by
a
filthy
curtain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Fine
weather
indeed
,
"
Martin
bitterly
soliloquised
,
"
to
be
wandering
up
and
down
here
in
,
like
a
thief
!
 
<EOS>
Fine
weather
indeed
,
for
a
meeting
of
lovers
in
the
open
air
,
and
in
a
public
walk
!
 
<EOS>
I
need
be
departing
,
with
all
speed
,
for
another
country
;
for
I
have
come
to
a
pretty
pass
in
this
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
might
perhaps
have
gone
on
to
reflect
that
of
all
mornings
in
the
year
,
it
was
not
the
best
calculated
for
a
young
lady
's
coming
forth
on
such
an
errand
,
either
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
stopped
on
the
road
to
this
reflection
,
if
his
thoughts
tended
that
way
,
by
her
appearance
at
a
short
distance
,
on
which
he
hurried
forward
to
meet
her
.
 
<EOS>
Her
squire
,
Mr
Tapley
,
at
the
same
time
fell
discreetly
back
,
and
surveyed
the
fog
above
him
with
an
appearance
of
attentive
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Martin
,
"
said
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Mary
,
"
said
Martin
;
and
lovers
are
such
a
singular
kind
of
people
that
this
is
all
they
did
say
just
then
,
though
Martin
took
her
arm
,
and
her
hand
too
,
and
they
paced
up
and
down
a
short
walk
that
was
least
exposed
to
observation
,
half
-
a
-
dozen
times
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
changed
at
all
,
my
love
,
since
we
parted
,
"
said
Martin
at
length
,
as
he
looked
upon
her
with
a
proud
delight
,
"
it
is
only
to
be
more
beautiful
than
ever
!
"
   
<EOS>
Had
she
been
of
the
common
metal
of
love
-
worn
young
ladies
,
she
would
have
denied
this
in
her
most
interesting
manner
;
and
would
have
told
him
that
she
knew
she
had
become
a
perfect
fright
;
or
that
she
had
wasted
away
with
weeping
and
anxiety
;
or
that
she
was
dwindling
gently
into
an
early
grave
;
or
that
her
mental
sufferings
were
unspeakable
;
or
would
,
either
by
tears
or
words
,
or
a
mixture
of
both
,
have
furnished
him
with
some
other
information
to
that
effect
,
and
made
him
as
miserable
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
had
been
reared
up
in
a
sterner
school
than
the
minds
of
most
young
girls
are
formed
in
<EOS>
;
she
had
had
her
nature
strengthened
by
the
hands
of
hard
endurance
and
necessity
;
had
come
out
from
her
young
trials
constant
,
self
-
denying
,
earnest
,
and
devoted
;
had
acquired
in
her
maidenhood
---
whether
happily
in
the
end
,
for
herself
or
him
,
is
foreign
to
our
present
purpose
to
inquire
---
something
of
that
nobler
quality
of
gentle
hearts
which
is
developed
often
by
the
sorrows
and
struggles
of
matronly
years
,
but
often
by
their
lessons
only
.
<EOS>
Unspoiled
,
unpampered
in
her
joys
or
griefs
;
with
frank
and
full
,
and
deep
affection
for
the
object
of
her
early
love
;
she
saw
in
him
one
who
for
her
sake
was
an
outcast
from
his
home
and
fortune
,
and
she
had
no
more
idea
of
bestowing
that
love
upon
him
in
other
than
cheerful
and
sustaining
words
,
full
of
high
hope
and
grateful
trustfulness
,
than
she
had
of
being
unworthy
of
it
,
in
her
lightest
thought
or
deed
,
for
any
base
temptation
that
the
world
could
offer
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
change
is
there
in
YOU
,
Martin
,
"
she
replied
;
"
for
that
concerns
me
nearest
?
 
<EOS>
You
look
more
anxious
and
more
thoughtful
than
you
used
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
as
to
that
,
my
love
,
"
said
Martin
as
he
drew
her
waist
within
his
arm
,
first
looking
round
to
see
that
there
were
no
observers
near
,
and
beholding
Mr
Tapley
more
intent
than
ever
on
the
fog
;
"
it
would
be
strange
if
I
did
not
;
for
my
life
---
especially
of
late
---
has
been
a
hard
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
must
have
been
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
have
I
forgotten
to
think
of
it
and
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
often
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
often
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
Not
often
,
I
have
some
right
to
expect
,
Mary
;
for
I
have
undergone
a
great
deal
of
vexation
and
privation
,
and
I
naturally
look
for
that
return
,
you
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
very
,
very
poor
return
<EOS>
,
"
she
answered
with
a
fainter
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
it
,
and
will
have
it
always
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
paid
a
dear
price
for
a
poor
heart
,
Martin
;
but
it
is
at
least
your
own
,
and
a
true
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
feel
quite
certain
of
that
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
or
I
should
n't
have
put
myself
in
my
present
position
.
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't
say
a
poor
heart
,
Mary
,
<EOS>
for
I
say
a
rich
one
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
am
about
to
break
a
design
to
you
,
dearest
,
which
will
startle
you
at
first
,
but
which
is
undertaken
for
your
sake
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
,
"
he
added
slowly
,
looking
far
into
the
deep

of
her
bright

,
"
abroad
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Abroad
,
Martin
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
to
America
.
 
<EOS>
See
now
.
 
<EOS>
How
you
droop
directly
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
,
or
,
I
hope
I
may
say
,
if
I
did
,
"
she
answered
,
raising
her
head
after
a

,
and
looking
once
more
into
his
face
,
"
it
was
for
grief
to
think
of
what
you
are
resolved
to
undergo
for
me
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
venture
to
dissuade
you
,
Martin
;
but
it
is
a
long
,
long
distance
;
there
is
a
wide

to
be
crossed
;
illness
and
want
are
sad
calamities
in
any
place
,
but
in
a
foreign
country
dreadful
to
endure
.
 
<EOS>
Have
you
thought
of
all
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thought
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
abating
,
in
his
fondness
---
and
he
WAS
very
fond
of
her
---
hardly
an
iota
of
his
usual
impetuosity
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
very
well
to
say
,
"
Have
I
thought
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
my
love
;
but
you
should
ask
me
in
the
same

,
have
I
thought
of
starving
at
home
;
have
I
thought
of
doing
porter
's

for

;
have
I
thought
of
holding

in
the

to
earn

roll

bread

?
 
<EOS>
Come
,

,
"
he

,

,
"

,
my

,
for
I
need

that
your
sweet

can

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
that
's
well
!
 
<EOS>
Now
you
are
brave
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
endeavouring
to
be
,
"
she
answered
,
smiling
through

.
   
<EOS>
"
Endeavouring
to
be
anything
that
's
good
,
and
being
it
,
is
,
with
you
,
all
one
.
 
<EOS>
Do

I
know
that
of
old
?
<EOS>
"

Martin
,
gaily
.
"
<EOS>
So
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
famous
!
 
<EOS>
Now
I
can
tell
you
all
my
plans
as

as
if
you
were
my
little
wife
already
,
Mary
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
hung
more
closely
on
his
arm
,
and
looking
upwards
in
his
face
,
bade
him
speak
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
said
Martin
,
playing
with
the
little

upon

,
"
that
my

to

at

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
Mary
,

.
 
<EOS>
But
so
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Have

late
of
any

mine

,

Pecksniff
?
 
<EOS>
Only

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
that
it

we

,

visit

---

.
 
<EOS>
He
HAS

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
pair

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
A

!
 
<EOS>
Gems

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
jesting
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
sort
of
jesting
which
is
very
much
in

,
and
includes
some
pretty
serious

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
jest
in

Mr
Pecksniff
(
at

I
have

,

)

.
 
<EOS>
Whatever

,

,
never

,
Mary
;

,

,

---
Pecksniff
is

.
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
In

,

,

else
.
 
<EOS>
A

from

,

nethermost

.
<EOS>
Of
his
daughters
I
will
only

that
,
to
the

of
my
knowledge
and
belief
,
they
are
dutiful
young
ladies
,
and
take
after
their
father
closely
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
a
digression
from
the
main
point
,
and
yet
it
brings
me
to
what
I
was
going

say
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
to
look
into
her
eyes
again
,
and
seeing
,
in

over
his
shoulder
,
that

near
,
and
that
Mark
was
still

upon
the
fog
,
not
only
looked
at
her
lips
,
too
,
but
kissed
them
into
the
bargain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
am
going
to
America
,
with
great

of
doing
well
,
and
of
returning
home
myself
very

;
it
may

to
take
you
there
for

,
but
,
at

,
to
claim
you

;

,

,
I

do
with
no

your
still

a
duty

to
him
who
will
not

me
to
live
(
for

true
)
,
if
he
can

,
in
my

.
 
<EOS>
How

I
may
be
absent
is
,

course
,
uncertain
;
but
it
shall
not

long
.
<EOS>
Trust

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
dear
Martin
---
"
   
"
That
's

I
am

to
.
 
<EOS>
In

you
shall
hear
,
constantly
,
of
all
my
goings
-
on
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
.
"
   
He
paused
to

the
letter
he
had
written
overnight
,
and
then

:
   
"
<EOS>
In
this
fellow
's
employment
,
and
living
in
this
fellow
's
house
(
by
fellow
,
I
mean
Mr
Pecksniff
,

)
,

a
certain

Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

;
a
poor
,

,

,
Mary
;
but
thoroughly
honest

;
full

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
Which
I
mean
to
return
one
of
these
days
,
by
setting
him
up
in
life
in
some

or
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
old
kind
nature
,
Martin
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Martin
,
"
that
's
not
worth
speaking
of
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
very
grateful
and

to

;
and
I
am
more

.
<EOS>
Now
one

I

Pinch
my

,

all
about
myself

you
;
in

he
was
not

,
I
can

,

!
 
<EOS>
Aye
,

---
and
the

for

---
<EOS>
but
you

;
and
he

;

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
HE
the
organist
?
"

Mary
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thank

from

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

,
"

,

nothing

.
<EOS>
There

!
 
<EOS>
Quite

!
 
<EOS>
But
a
very
good
sort

creature
<EOS>
,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure

,
"
she

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
no

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
It
has

---
but

.
 
<EOS>
If
I
read

I
have
written
and

him
by
post
to
-
night
<EOS>
it

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

Tom
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
That
's

,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>
but
I
call

my

Pinch
because

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
!
<EOS>
"

Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
as
well
to
be
kind

;
and
,

,
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Tom
Pinch
---
I
address

Mrs
Lupin
,
at
the
Blue
Dragon
,
and
have

;

.
 
<EOS>
My

for
so

will
be
at

to
you
"
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't

,
by
the
bye
,
"
said
Martin
,
breaking

,
"
for
he
's
slow

,

;
but
he
'll

out

.
 
<EOS>
My

simply
is
,
that
I
do
n't
want
my
letters
to
be

by

;
and
particularly

the
scoundrel
whom
he
thinks
an
angel
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pecksniff
again
?
"
asked
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
same
,
"
said
Martin
"
---
will

.
 
<EOS>
I

;

"
---
<EOS>
meaning
,

,
"

"
our

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Fear
!

<EOS>
"
Why
,

?
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
What

<EOS>
When

,

<EOS>
But

!
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
A

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

;

,

<EOS>
Time

!
 
<EOS>
I
can

,
so
that
I
have
swift

,
Mary
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Was

,

<EOS>
Was

,
with
this
one

"
self
"
for

?
 
<EOS>
Not

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

which

away
as
dross

all

for

,

she

;
and
<EOS>
she

.
 
<EOS>
That

where
self
has
found
no

and

,
is
slow

.
 
<EOS>
As

,

know

"
The

!
"

,

"
I

<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Let

!
 
<EOS>
By

,
he

;

"
   
<EOS>
"
Martin
!
 
<EOS>
If

,

"

"

;

<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Has

?
"

,

"

;

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

because

<EOS>
And

,
love
"
---

"

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,

!
 
<EOS>
This

;
but
our
next

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
One

,

<EOS>
Have

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Have

?
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
<EOS>
;

;

"
Have

?
 
<EOS>
Why
,

!
 
<EOS>
How

land

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
 
<EOS>
More

.
 
<EOS>
Twenty

.
 
<EOS>
A

-

.
 
<EOS>
Mark

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

's

-

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-

a

"

in
a
trembling
voice
.
   
<EOS>
But
how
cold
the
comfort
in
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
 
<EOS>
Mark
Tapley
knew
it
perfectly
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
knew
it
from
his
reading
,
perhaps
from
his
experience
,
perhaps
from
intuition
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
impossible
to
say
;
but
however
he
knew
it
,
his
knowledge
instinctively
suggested
to
him
the
wisest
course
of
proceeding
that
any
man
could
have
adopted
under
the
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
taken
with
a
violent
fit
of
sneezing
,
and
was
obliged
to
turn
his
head
another
way
.
 
<EOS>
In
doing
which
,
he
,
in
a
manner
fenced
and
screened
the
lovers
into
a
corner
by
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
short
pause
,
but
Mark
had
an
undefined
sensation
that
it
was
a
satisfactory
one
in
its
way
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Mary
,
with
her
veil

,
passed
him
with

,
and
beckoned
him
to
follow
.
<EOS>
She
stopped
once
more
before
they

that
corner
;
looked
back
;
and
waved
her

to
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
a
start

them
at
the
moment
as
if
he
had
some
other

to
say
;
but
she
only

off
the
faster
,
and
Mr
Tapley
followed
as
in

.
   
<EOS>
When
he

Martin
again
in
his
own

,
he
found
that
gentleman
seated
moodily
before
the

,
with
his
two

on
the

,
his
two

on
his

,
and
his
chin
supported
,
in
a
not
very
ornamental
manner
,
on
the
palms
of
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mark
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
,
taking
a
long
breath
,
"
I
see
the
young
lady
safe
home
,
and
I
feel
pretty
comfortable
after
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
sent
a
lot
of
kind
words
,
sir
,
and
this
,
"
handing
him
a
ring
,
"
for
a
parting
keepsake
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Diamonds
!
"
said
Martin
,
kissing
it
---
let
us
do
him
justice
,
it
was
for
her
sake
;
not
for
theirs
---
and
putting
it
on
his
little
finger
.
"
<EOS>
Splendid
diamonds
!
 
<EOS>
My
grandfather
is
a
singular
character
,
Mark
.
<EOS>
He
must
have
given
her
this
now
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mark
Tapley
knew
as
well
that
she
had
bought
it
,
to
the
end
that
that
unconscious
speaker
might
carry
some
article
of
sterling
value
with
him
in
his

;
as
he
knew
that
it
was
day
,
and
not
night
.
 
<EOS>
Though
he
had
no
more
acquaintance
of
his
own
knowledge
with
the
history
of
the
glittering
trinket
on
Martin
's
outspread
finger
,
than
Martin
himself
had
,
he
was
as
certain
that
in
its
purchase
she
had
expended
her
whole
stock
of
hoarded

,
as

had
seen
it
paid
down

.
 
<EOS>
Her

strange

in

,
promptly

to
Mark
's

its
real

;
and
from

he
had

clear

into
the
one

principle
of
Martin
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
worthy
of
the
sacrifices
I
have
made
,
"
said
Martin
,
folding

,
and
looking
at
the
ashes
in
the
stove
,
as
if
in
resumption
of
some
former

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
worthy
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
No
riches
"
<EOS>
---
here
he
stroked
his
chin
and
mused
---
"
could
have
compensated
for
the
loss
of
such
a
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Not
to
mention
that
in
gaining
her
affection
I
have
followed
the
bent
of
my
own
wishes
,
and
baulked
the
selfish
schemes
of
others
who
had
no
right
to
form

.
 
<EOS>
She
is
quite
worthy
---
more
than
worthy
---
of
the
sacrifices
I
have
made
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
These
ruminations
might
or
might
not
have
reached
Mark
Tapley
;
for
though
they
were
by
no
means
addressed
to
him
,
yet
they
were
softly
uttered
.
 
<EOS>
In
any
case
,
he
stood
there
,
watching
Martin
with
an
indescribable
and
most
involved
expression
on
his
visage
,
until
that
young
man
roused
himself
and
looked
towards
him
;
when
he
turned
away
,
as
being
suddenly
intent
upon
certain
preparations
for
the
journey
,
and
,
without
giving
vent
to
any
articulate

,
smiled
with
surpassing

,
and
seemed
by
a
twist

his
features
and
a
motion
of
his
lips
,
to
release
himself
of
this
word
:
   
"
Jolly
!
"
    
Chapter
15
.
<EOS>
The
burden
whereof
,
is
hail
Columbia
!
 
<EOS>
A
dark
and
dreary
night
;
people
nestling
in
their
beds
or
circling
late
about
the
fire
;
Want
,
colder
than
Charity
,
shivering
at
the
street
corners
;
church
-
towers
humming
with
the
faint
vibration
of
their
own
tongues
,
but
newly
resting
from
the
ghostly
preachment
"
One
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
earth
covered
with
a
sable
pall
as
for
the
burial
of
yesterday
;
the
clumps
of
dark
trees
,
its
giant
plumes
of
funeral
feathers
,
waving
sadly
to
and
fro
:
all
hushed
,
all
noiseless
,
and
in
deep
repose
,
save
the
swift
clouds
that
skim
across
the
moon
,
and
the
cautious
wind
,
as
,
creeping
after
them
upon
the
ground
,
it
stops
to
listen
,
and
goes
rustling
on
,
and
stops
again
,
and
follows
,
like
a
savage
on
the
trail
.
   
<EOS>
Whither
go
the
clouds
and
wind
so
eagerly
?
 
<EOS>
If
,
like
guilty
spirits
,
they
repair
to
some
dread
conference
with
powers
like
themselves
,
in
what
wild
regions
do
the
elements
hold
council
,
or
where
unbend
in
terrible
disport
?
   
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
Free
from
that
cramped
prison
called
the
earth
,
and
out
upon
the
waste
of
waters
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
roaring
,
raging
,
shrieking
,
howling
,
all
night
long
.
 
<EOS>
Hither
come
the
sounding
voices
from
the
caverns
on
the
coast
of
that
small
island
,
sleeping
,
a
thousand
miles
away
,
so
quietly
in
the
midst
of
angry
waves
;
and
hither
,
to
meet
them
,
rush
the
blasts
from
unknown
desert
places
of
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
Here
,
in
the
fury
of
their
unchecked
liberty
,
they
storm
and
buffet
with
each
other
,
until
the
sea
,
lashed
into
passion
like
their
own
,
leaps
up
,
in
ravings
mightier
than
theirs
,
and
the
whole
scene
is
madness
.
   
<EOS>
On
,
on
,
on
,
over
the
countless
miles
of
angry
space
roll
the
long
heaving
billows
.
 
<EOS>
Mountains
and
caves
are
here
,
and
yet
are
not
;
for
what
is
now
the
one
,
is
now
the
other
;
then
all
is
but
a
boiling
heap
of
rushing
water
.
 
<EOS>
Pursuit
,
and
flight
,
and
mad
return
of
wave
on
wave
,
and
savage
struggle
,
ending
in
a
spouting
-
up
of
foam
that
whitens
the
black
night
;
incessant
change
of
place
,
and
form
,
and
hue
;
constancy
in
nothing
,
but
eternal
strife
;
on
,
on
,
on
,
they
roll
,
and
darker
grows
the
night
,
and
louder
howls
the
wind
,
and
more
clamorous
and
fierce
become
the
million
voices
in
the
sea
,
when
the
wild
cry
goes
forth
upon
the
storm
"
A
ship
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Onward
she
comes
,
in
gallant
combat
with
the
elements
,
her
tall
masts
trembling
,
and
her
timbers
starting
on
the
strain
;
onward
she
comes
,
now
high
upon
the
curling
billows
,
now
low
down
in
the
hollows
of
the
sea
,
as
hiding
for
the
moment
from
its
fury
;
and
every
storm
-
voice
in
the
air
and
water
cries
more
loudly
yet
,
"
A
ship
!
"
   
<EOS>
Still
she
comes
striving
on
;
and
at
her
boldness
and
the
spreading
cry
,
the
angry
waves
rise
up
above
each
other
's
hoary
heads
to
look
;
and
round
about
the
vessel
,
far
as
the
mariners
on
the
decks
can
pierce
into
the
gloom
,
they
press
upon
her
,
forcing
each
other
down
and
starting
up
,
and
rushing
forward
from
afar
,
in
dreadful

.
 
<EOS>
High
over
her
they
break
;
and
round
her
surge
and
roar
;
and
giving
place
to
others
,
moaningly
depart
,
and
dash
themselves
to
fragments
in
their
baffled
anger
.
 
<EOS>
Still
she
comes
onward
bravely
.
<EOS>
And
though
the
eager
multitude
crowd
thick
and
fast
upon
her
all
the
night
,
and
dawn
of
day
discovers
the
untiring
train
yet
bearing
down
upon
the
ship
in
an
eternity
of
troubled
water
,
onward
she
comes
,
with
dim
lights
burning
in
her
hull
,
and
people
there
,
asleep
;
as
if
no
deadly

were
peering
in
at
every

,
and
no

grave
,
with
but

plank
to
cover

,
were
yawning
in
the
unfathomable

below
.
   
<EOS>
Among
these
sleeping
voyagers
were
Martin
and
Mark
Tapley
,
who
,
rocked
into
a
heavy
drowsiness
by
the
unaccustomed
motion
,
were
as
insensible
to
the
foul
air
in
which

,
as

the

without
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
broad
day
when
the
latter
awoke
with
a
dim
idea
that
he
was
dreaming
of
having
gone
to
sleep
in
a
four
-
post

which
had
turned
bottom
upwards
in
the
course
of
the

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
more
reason
in
this
too
,
than
in
the
roasting
of
eggs
;
for
the
first
objects
Mr
Tapley
recognized
when

were
his
own

---
looking
down

him
,
as
he
afterwards

,
from

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Mark
,
getting
himself
into
a

,
after
various
ineffectual

with
the
rolling
of
the
ship
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
first
time
as
ever
I
stood
on
my
head
all
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
should

go

upon

,
"
growled

.
   
<EOS>
"
With

to
WHERE
?
"
asked
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
repeated
his
previous
sentiment
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
wo
n't
another
time
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
when
I
know
whereabouts
on
the
map
that
country
is
.
 
<EOS>
In
the

I
can

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
nor
any
other
friend

mine
never
go
to
sleep
with
his
head
in
a
ship

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
gave
a
grunt
of
discontented

,
turned
over
in
his
berth
,
and
drew
his

over

.
   
<EOS>
"
---
For
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
pursuing
the
theme
by
way
of
soliloquy
in
a
low

of
voice
;
"
the
sea
is
as
nonsensical
a
thing
as
any
going
.
 
<EOS>
It
never
knows
what
to
do
with
itself
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
n't
got
no
employment
for
its
mind
,
and
is
always
in
a
state
of
vacancy
.
 
<EOS>
Like
them
<EOS>
Polar
bears
in
the
wild
-

shows
as
is
constantly
a
-
nodding
their
heads
from
side
to
side
<EOS>
,
it
never
CAN

quiet
.
 
<EOS>
Which
is
entirely
owing
to
its
uncommon

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
you
,
Mark
?
"

from
another

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
as
much
of
me
as
is
left
,
<EOS>
sir
,
after
a
fortnight
of
this
work
,
"

,
"
What
with
leading
the

,
ever
since
I
've

aboard
---
for
I
've

perpetually

-

---
<EOS>
what

that
,

,

a

,
and
taking

,

much

.
 
<EOS>
How

this

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
miserable
,
"
said
Martin
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ugh
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
wretched
,
indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Creditable
,
"
muttered
Mark
,
pressing
one
hand
upon
his
aching

and
looking

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
great
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
It
IS
creditable
to
keep
up
one
's
spirits
here
.
 
<EOS>
Virtue
's
its
own
reward
.
 
<EOS>
So
's
jollity
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mark
was
so
far
right
that
unquestionably
any
man
who
retained
his
cheerfulness
among
the
steerage
accommodations
of
that
noble
and
fast
-
sailing
line
-
of
-
packet
ship
,
"
THE
SCREW
,
"
was
solely
indebted
to
his
own
resources
,
and
shipped
his
good
humour
,
like
his
provisions
,
without
any
contribution
or
assistance
from
the
owners
.
<EOS>
A
dark
,
low
,
stifling
cabin
,
surrounded
by
berths
all
filled
to
overflowing
with
men
,
women
,
and
children
,
in
various
stages
of
sickness
and
misery
,
is
not
the
liveliest
place
of
assembly
at
any
time
;
but
when
it
is
so
crowded
(
as
the
steerage
cabin
of
the
Screw
was
,
every
passage
out
)
,
<EOS>
that
mattresses
and
beds
are
heaped
upon
the
floor
,
to
the
extinction
of
everything
like
comfort
,
cleanliness
,
and
decency
,
it
is
liable
to
operate
not
only
as
a
pretty
strong
banner
against
amiability
of
temper
,
but
as
a
positive
encourager
of
selfish
and
rough
humours
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
felt
this
,
as
he
sat
looking
about
him
;
and
his
spirits
rose
proportionately
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
English
people
,
Irish
people
,
Welsh
people
,
and
Scotch
people
there
;
all
with
their
little
store
of
coarse
food
and
shabby
clothes
;
and
nearly
all
with
their
families
of
children
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
children
of
all
ages
;
from
the
baby
at
the
breast
,
to
the
slattern
-
girl
who
was
as
much
a
grown
woman
as
her
mother
.
 
<EOS>
Every
kind
of
domestic
suffering
that
is
bred
in
poverty
,
illness
,
banishment
,
sorrow
,
and
long
travel
in
bad
weather
,
was
crammed
into
the
little
space
;
and
yet
was
there
infinitely
less
of
complaint
and
querulousness
,
and
infinitely
more
of
mutual
assistance
and
general
kindness
to
be
found
in
that
unwholesome
ark
,
than
in
many
brilliant
ballrooms
.
   
<EOS>
Mark
looked
about
him
wistfully
,
and
his
face
brightened
as
he
looked
.
 
<EOS>
Here
an
old
grandmother
was
crooning
over
a
sick
child
,
and
rocking
it
to
and
fro
,
in
arms
hardly
more
wasted
than
its
own
young
limbs
;
here
a
poor
woman
with
an
infant
in
her
lap
,
mended
another
little
creature
's
clothes
,
and
quieted
another
who
was
creeping
up
about
her
from
their
scanty
bed
upon
the
floor
.
 
<EOS>
Here
were
old
men
awkwardly
engaged
in
little
household
offices
,
wherein
they
would
have
been
ridiculous
but
for
their
good
-
will
and
kind
purpose
;
and
here
were
swarthy
fellows
---
giants
in
their
way
---
doing
such
little
acts
of
tenderness
for
those
about
them
,
as
might
have
belonged
to
gentlest
-
hearted
dwarfs
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
idiot
in
the
corner
who
sat
mowing
there
,
all
day
,
had
his
faculty
of
imitation
roused
by
what
he
saw
about
him
;
and
snapped
his
fingers
to
amuse
a
crying
child
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
then
,
"
said
Mark
,
nodding
to
a
woman
who
was
dressing
her
three
children
at
no
great
distance
from
him
---
and
<EOS>
the
grin
upon
his
face
had
by
this
time
spread
from
ear
to
ear
<EOS>
---
"
Hand
over
one
of
them
<EOS>
young
'
uns
<EOS>
according
to
custom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
'd
get
breakfast
,
Mark
,
instead
of
worrying
with
people
who
do
n't
belong
to
you
,
"
observed
Martin
,
petulantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
SHE'll
do
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
fair
division
of
labour
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
wash
her
boys
,
and
she
makes
our
tea
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
COULD
make
tea
,
but
any
one
can
wash
a
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
woman
,
who
was
delicate
and
ill
,
felt
and
understood
his
kindness
,
as
well
she
might
,
for
she
had
been
covered
every
night
with
his
greatcoat
,
while
he
had
for
his
own
bed
the
bare
boards
and
a
rug
.
 
<EOS>
But
Martin
,
who
seldom
got
up
or
looked
about
him
,
was
quite
incensed
by
the
folly
of
this
speech
,
and
expressed
his
dissatisfaction
by
an
impatient

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
it
is
,
certainly
,
"
said
Mark
,
brushing
the
child
's
hair
as
coolly
as
if
he
had
been
born
and
bred
a
barber
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
talking
about
,
now
?
"

Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
you
said
,
"
replied
Mark
;
"
or
what
you
meant
,
when
you
gave
that
there
dismal
vent
to
your
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
I
quite
go
along
with
it
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
IS
very
hard
upon
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Making
the
voyage
by
herself
along
with
these
young

here
,
and
going
such
a
way
at
such
a
time
of
the
year
to
join
her

.
 
<EOS>
If

do
n't
want
to
be
driven
mad
with
yellow
soap
in

,
young
man
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
to
the
second
urchin
,
who
was
by
this
time
under
his
hands
at
the
basin
,
"
you
'd
better
shut
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
does
she
join
her
husband
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Martin
,
yawning
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
'm
very

,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
in

,
"
that
she
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
she
may
n't
miss

.
 
<EOS>
But
she
sent
her
last
letter
by
hand
,
and
it
do

seem
to
have

very
clearly

between
'em
without
it
,
and
if
she
do

see
him
a
-
waving

on

,

a

,

is
,

'll

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
in
Folly
's
name
,
does
the
woman
come
to
be
on
board
ship
on
such
a
wild
-
goose
venture
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
glanced
at
him
for
a
moment
as
he
lay
prostrate
in
his
berth
,
and
then
said
,
very
quietly
:
   
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
How
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
think
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
been
away
from
her
for
two
year
;
she
's
been
very
poor
and
lonely
in
her
own
country
;
and
has
always
been
a
-
looking

to

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
very
strange
<EOS>
she
should
be
here
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
amazing
!
 
<EOS>
A
little
mad
perhaps
!
 
<EOS>
There
ca
n't
be
no
other
way
of
accounting
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
too
far
gone
in
the
lassitude
of
sea
-
sickness
to
make
any
reply
to
these
words
,
or
even

to

as

were
spoken
.
<EOS>
And
the
subject
of
their
discourse
returning
at
this

with
some
hot
tea
,
effectually
put
a
stop
to
any

of
the
theme
by
Mr
Tapley
;
who
,
when
the
meal
was
over
and
he
had
adjusted
Martin
's
bed
,
went
up
on
deck
to
wash

breakfast
service
,
which
consisted
of
two
half
-
pint
tin
mugs
,
and
a
shaving

pot
of
the
same
metal
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
due
to
Mark
Tapley
to
state
that
he
suffered
at
least
as
much
from
sea
-
sickness
as
any
man
,
woman
,
or
child
,
on
board
;
and
that
he
had
a
peculiar
faculty
of
knocking
himself
about
on
the
smallest
provocation
,
and
losing
his
legs
at
every
lurch
of
the
ship
.
 
<EOS>
But
resolved
,
in
his
usual
phrase
,
to
"
come
out
strong
"
under
disadvantageous
circumstances
,
he
was
the
life
and
soul
of
the
steerage
,
and
made
no
more
of
stopping
in
the
middle
of
a
facetious
conversation
to
go
away
and
be
excessively
ill
by
himself
,
and
afterwards
come
back
in
the
very
best
and
gayest
of
tempers
to
resume
it
,
than
if
such
a
course
of
proceeding
had
been
the
commonest
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
said
that
as
his
illness
wore
off
,
his
cheerfulness
and
good
nature
increased
,
because
they
would
hardly
admit
of
augmentation
;
but
his
usefulness
among
the
weaker
members
of
the
party
was
much
enlarged
;
and
at
all
times
and
seasons
there
he
was
exerting
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
gleam
of
sun
shone
out
of
the
dark
sky
,
down
Mark
tumbled
into
the
cabin
,
and
presently
up
<EOS>
he
came
again
with
a
woman
in
his
arms
,
or
half
-
a
-
dozen
children
,
or
a
man
,
or
a
bed
,
or
a
saucepan
,
or
a
basket
,
or
something
animate
or
inanimate
,
that
he
thought
would
be
the
better
for
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
If
an
hour
or
two
of
fine
weather
in
the
middle
of
the
day
tempted
those
who
seldom
or
never
came
on
deck
at
other
times
to
crawl
into
the
long
-
boat
,
or
lie
down
upon
the
spare

,
and
try

eat
,
there
,
in
the
centre
of
the
group
,
was
Mr
Tapley
,
handing
about
salt

and

,
or
dispensing
tastes
of
grog
,
or
cutting
up
the
children
's
provisions
with
his
pocketknife
,
for
their
greater
ease
and
comfort
,
or
reading
aloud
from
a
venerable
newspaper
,
or
singing
some
roaring
old
song
to
a
select
party
,
or
writing
the
beginnings
of
letters
to
their
friends
at
home
for
people
who
could
n't
write
,
or
cracking
jokes
with
the
crew
,
or
nearly
getting
blown
over
the
side
,
or
emerging
,
half

,
from
a

of
spray
,
or
lending
a
hand
somewhere
or
other
;
but
always
doing
something
for
the
general
entertainment
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
,
when
the
cooking
-
fire
was
lighted
on
the

,
and
the

that

,

,
seemed

with
certain

by

,

;
there
,

,
was
Mr
Tapley
,
with

off
and
his

turned
up
to

,
doing
all
kinds
of
culinary
offices
;
compounding
the
strangest

;
recognized
by
every
one
as
an
established
