;
and
helping
all
parties
to
achieve
something
which
,
left
to

,
they
never
could
have
done
,
and
never

dreamed
of
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
there
never

a
more
popular
character
than
Mark
Tapley
became
,
on
board
<EOS>
that
noble

-

-
packet

,

Screw
;
and
he

at

such

of

,
that

to
have

within

whether

reasonably
claim

for
being

under

.
   
<EOS>
"
If

was

last
,
"

,
"
there
'd

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

afraid
that
the
Fates
is
determined
to
make

easy

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mark
,
"
said
Martin
,
near

.
 
<EOS>
"
When

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Another

,

,

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
The

's
a
-
going

,
as

,

;

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
And

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

ca

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

,
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
often

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
to
lying
here
,
"
cried
Martin
,
raising

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you

's

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
All

,
"

,
"
could

as

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then

?
"

,
"
I

do

,

,
by
any

-

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

-
cabin
<EOS>
I
should

.
 
<EOS>
As
I
could
n't
I
hide
it
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
,

,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't

took

so
much

as
this
comes

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

did
n't
know
,
"
returned

.
 
<EOS>
"
How
should

,

?
 
<EOS>
It
's

you
,
Mark
,

.
 
<EOS>
It

do

.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
you
do

this

can

have
half

as

?
<EOS>
Do

?
"
<EOS>
he

,

at
Mark
,
with
an
expression
of
great
earnestness
not
unmixed
with
wonder
.
   
<EOS>
Mark
twisted
his
face
into
a
tight
knot
,
and
with
his
head
very
much
on
one
side
,
pondered
upon
this
question
as
if
he
felt
it
an
extremely
difficult
one
to
answer
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
relieved
from
his
embarrassment
by
Martin
himself
,
who
said
,
as
he
stretched
himself
upon
his
back
again
and
resumed
the
book
he
had
been
reading
:
   
<EOS>
"
But
what
is
the
use
of
my
putting
such
a
case
to
you
,
when
the
very
essence
of
what
I
have
been
saying
is
,
that
you
can
not
by
possibility
understand
it
!
 
<EOS>
Make
me
a
little
brandy
-
and
-
water
---
cold
and
very
weak
---
and
give
me
a
biscuit
,
and
tell
your
friend
,
who
is
a
nearer
neighbour
of
ours
than
I
could
wish
,
to
try
and
keep
her
children
a
little
quieter
to
-
night
than
she
did
last
night
;
that
's
a
good
fellow
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
set
himself
to
obey
these
orders
with
great
alacrity
,
and
pending
their
execution
,
it
may
be
presumed
his
flagging
spirits
revived
;
inasmuch
as
he
several
times
observed
,
below
his
breath
,
that
in
respect
of
its
power
of
imparting
a
credit
to
jollity
,
the
Screw
unquestionably
had
some
decided
advantages
over
the
Dragon
.
<EOS>
He
also
remarked
that
it
was
a
high
gratification
to
him
to
reflect
that
he
would
carry
its
main
excellence
ashore
with
him
,
and
have
it
constantly
beside
him
wherever
he
went
;
but
what
he
meant
by
these
consolatory
thoughts
he
did
not
explain
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
a
general
excitement
began
to
prevail
on
board
;
and
various
predictions
relative
to
the
precise
day
,
and
even
the
precise
hour
at
which
they
would
reach
New
York
,
were
freely
broached
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
infinitely
more
crowding
on
deck
and
looking
over
the
ship
's
side
than
there
had
been
before
;
and
an
epidemic
broke
out
for
packing
up
things
every
morning
,
which
required
unpacking
again
every
night
.
<EOS>
Those
who
had
any
letters
to
deliver
,
or
any
friends
to
meet
,
or
any
settled
plans
of
going
anywhere
or
doing
anything
,
discussed
their
prospects
a
hundred
times
a
day
;
and
as
this
class
of
passengers
was
very
small
,
and
the
number
of
those
who
had
no
prospects
whatever
was
very
large
,
there
were
plenty
of
listeners
and
few
talkers
.
<EOS>
Those
who
had
been
ill
all
along
,
got
well
now
,
and
those
who
had
been
well
,
got
better
.
 
<EOS>
An
American
gentleman
in
the
after
-
cabin
,
who
had
been
wrapped
up
in
fur
and
oilskin
the
whole
passage
,
unexpectedly
appeared
in
a
very
shiny
,
tall
,
black
hat
,
and
constantly
overhauled
a
very
little
valise
of
pale
leather
,
which
contained
his
clothes
,
linen
,
brushes
,
shaving
apparatus
,
books
,
trinkets
,
and
other
baggage
.
 
<EOS>
He
likewise
stuck
his
hands
deep
into
his
pockets
,
and
walked
the
deck
with
his
nostrils
dilated
,
as
already
inhaling
the
air
of
Freedom
which
carries
death
to
all
tyrants
,
and
can
never
(
under
any
circumstances
worth
mentioning
)
be
breathed
by
slaves
.
 
<EOS>
An
English
gentleman
who
was
strongly
suspected
of
having
run
away
from
a
bank
,
with
something
in
his
possession
belonging
to
its
strong
box
besides
the
key
,
grew
eloquent
upon
the
subject
of
the
rights
of
man
,
and
hummed
the
Marseillaise
Hymn
constantly
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
one
great
sensation
pervaded
the
whole
ship
,
and
the
soil
of
America
lay
close
before
them
;
so
close
at
last
,
that
,
upon
a
certain
starlight
night
they
took
a
pilot
on
board
,
and
within
a
few
hours
afterwards
lay
to
until
the
morning
,
awaiting
the
arrival
of
a
steamboat
in
which
the
passengers
were
to
be
conveyed
ashore
.
   
<EOS>
Off
she
came
,
soon
after
it
was
light
next
morning
,
and
lying
alongside
an
hour
or
more
---
during
which
period
her
very
firemen
were
objects
of
hardly
less
interest
and
curiosity
than
if
they
had
been
so
many
angels
,
good
or
bad
---
took
all
her
living
freight
aboard
.
<EOS>
Among
them
Mark
,
who
still
had
his
friend
and
her
three
children
under
his
close
protection
;
and
Martin
,
who
had
once
more
dressed
himself
in
his
usual
attire
,
but
wore
a
soiled
,
old
cloak
above
his
ordinary
clothes
,
until
such
time
as
he
should
separate
for
ever
from
his
late
companions
.
   
<EOS>
The
steamer
---
which
,
with
its
machinery
on
deck
,
looked
,
as
it
worked
its
long
slim
legs
,
like
some
enormously
magnified
insect
or
antediluvian
monster
---
dashed
at
great
speed
up
a
beautiful
bay
;
and
presently
they
saw
some
heights
,
and
islands
,
and
a
long
,
flat
,
straggling
city
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
looking
far
ahead
,
"
is
the
Land
of
Liberty
,
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
agreeable
.
 
<EOS>
Any
land
will
do
for
me
,
after
so
much
water
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
16
.
<EOS>
Martin
disembarks
from
that
noble
and
fast
-
sailing
line
-
of
-
packet
ship
,
"
The
Screw
'
,
at
the
port
of
New
York
,
in
the
United
States
of
America
.
 
<EOS>
He
makes
some
acquaintances
,
and
dines
at
a
boarding
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
particulars
of
those
transactions
 
<EOS>
Some
trifling
excitement
prevailed
upon
the
very
brink
and
margin
of
the
land
of
liberty
;
for
an
alderman
had
been
elected
the
day
before
;
and
Party
Feeling
naturally
running
rather
high
on
such
an
exciting
occasion
,
the
friends
of
the
disappointed
candidate
had
found
it
necessary
to
assert
the
great
principles
of
Purity
of
Election
and
Freedom
of
opinion
by
breaking
a
few
legs
and
arms
,
and
furthermore
pursuing
one
obnoxious
gentleman
through
the
streets
with
the
design
of
hitting
his
nose
.
 
<EOS>
These
good
-
humoured
little
outbursts
of
the
popular
fancy
were
not
in
themselves
sufficiently
remarkable
to
create
any
great
stir
,
after
the
lapse
of
a
whole
night
;
but
they
found
fresh
life
and
notoriety
in
the
breath
of
the
newsboys
,
who
not
only
proclaimed
them
with
shrill
yells
in
all
the
highways
and
byways
of
the
town
,
upon
the
wharves
and
among
the
shipping
,
but
on
the
deck
and
down
in
the
cabins
of
the
steamboat
;
which
,
before
she
touched
the
shore
,
was
boarded
and
overrun
by
a
legion
of
those
young
citizens
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
this
morning
's
New
York
Sewer
!
"
<EOS>
cried
one
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
this

's
New
York
Stabber
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's

New

Family

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's

New
York
Private

!
 
<EOS>

's

New

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's

New

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

;

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
Here

,

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
Sewer
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
New
York
Sewer
!
<EOS>
Here

the

of

-
day
's
Sewer
,

,

,

,

,

;

's

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
some
of
the

thousand
of
the
New
York
Sewer
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the

's
exposure
of

Wall

Gang
,

's

of

,

when

;
now

,

,

.
<EOS>
Here
's

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's

New
York
Sewer
,
in

,

New
Yorkers
to

,

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's

's

upon

Judge
that

,
day
afore
yesterday
,
for

,

's

independent
Jury
that
did
n't

,

's

expected
if

!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
Sewer
,
here
's
the
Sewer
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
wide
-
awake
Sewer
;
always
on
the
lookout
;
the
leading
Journal
of
the
United
States
,
now
in
its
twelfth
thousand
,
and
still
a
-
printing
off
:
---
Here
's
the
New
York
Sewer
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
in
such
enlightened
means
,
"
said
a
voice
almost
in
Martin
's
ear
,
"
that
the
bubbling
passions
of
my
country
find
a
vent
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
turned
involuntarily
,
and
saw
,
standing
close
at
his
side
,
a
sallow
gentleman
,
with
sunken
cheeks
,
black
hair
,
small
twinkling
eyes
,
and
a
singular
expression
hovering
about
that
region
of
his
face
,
which
was
not
a
frown
,
nor
a
leer
,
and
yet
might
have
been
mistaken
at
the
first
glance
for
either
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
it
would
have
been
difficult
,
on
a
much
closer
acquaintance
,
to
describe
it
in
any
more
satisfactory
terms
than
as
a
mixed
expression
of
vulgar
cunning
and
conceit
.
 
<EOS>
This
gentleman
wore
a
rather
broad
-
brimmed
hat
for
the
greater
wisdom
of
his
appearance
;
and
had
his
arms
folded
for
the
greater
impressiveness
of
his
attitude
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
somewhat
shabbily
dressed
in
a
blue
surtout
reaching
nearly
to
his
ankles
,
short
loose
trousers
of
the
same
colour
,
and
a
faded
buff
waistcoat
,
through
which
a
discoloured
shirt
-
frill
struggled
to
force
itself
into
notice
,
as
asserting
an
equality
of
civil
rights
with
the
other
portions
of
his
dress
,
and
maintaining
a
declaration
of
Independence
on
its
own
account
.
 
<EOS>
His
feet
,
which
were
of
unusually
large
proportions
,
were
leisurely
crossed
before
him
as
he
half
leaned
against
,
<EOS>
half
sat
upon
,
the
steamboat
's
bulwark
;
and
his
thick
cane
,
shod
with
a
mighty
ferule
at
one
end
and
armed
with
a
great
metal
knob
at
the
other
,
depended
from
a
line
-
and
-
tassel
on
his
wrist
.
<EOS>
Thus
attired
,
and
thus
composed
into
an
aspect
of
great
profundity
,
the
gentleman
twitched
up
the
right
-
hand
corner
of
his
mouth
and
his
right
eye
simultaneously
,
and
said
,
once
more
:
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
in
such
enlightened
means
that
the
bubbling
passions
of
my
country
find
a
vent
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
looked
at
Martin
,
and
nobody
else
was
by
,
Martin
inclined
his
head
,
and
said
:
   
"
You
allude
to
---
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
To
the
Palladium
of
rational
Liberty
at
home
,
sir
,
and
the
dread
of
Foreign
oppression
abroad
,
"
returned
the

,
as
he

with
his

to
an
uncommonly
dirty
newsboy
with
one

.
 
<EOS>
"
To
the
Envy
of
the
world
,
sir
,
and
the
leaders
of
Human
Civilization
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
ask
you
sir
,
"
he
added
,
bringing
the
ferule
of
his
stick
heavily
upon
the
deck
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
must
not
be
equivocated
with
,
"
how
do
you
like
my
Country
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
hardly
prepared
to
answer
that
question
yet
,
"
said
Martin
"
seeing
that
I
have
not
been
ashore
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
should
expect
you
were
not
prepared
,
sir
,
"
said
the

,
"
to

signs
of
National
Prosperity
as
those
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
pointed
to
the
vessels
lying
at
the
wharves
;
and
then
gave
a
vague
flourish
with
his
stick
,
as
if
he
would
include
the
air
and
water
,
generally
,
in
this
remark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
was
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
glanced
at
him
with
a
knowing
look
,
and
said
he
liked
his
policy
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
natural
,
he
said
,
and
it
pleased
him
as
a
philosopher
to
observe
the
prejudices
of
human
nature
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
brought
,
I
see
,
sir
,
"
he
said
,
turning
round
towards
Martin
,
and
resting

chin
on
the
top
of

stick
,
"
the
usual
amount
of
misery
and
poverty
and

and

,
to
be
located
in
the
bosom

the
great
Republic
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
sir
!
<EOS>
let
'em
come
on
in
shiploads
from
the
old
country
.
 
<EOS>
When
vessels
are
about
to
founder
,
the
rats
are
said
to
leave
'em
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
considerable
of
truth
,
I
find
,
in
that
remark
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
old
ship
will
keep
afloat
a
year
or
two
longer
yet
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Martin
with

,

by
what
the
gentleman

,
and
partly

saying
it
,
which
was
odd
enough
for
he
emphasised
all
the
small
words
and
syllables
in
his
discourse
,
and
left
the
others
to
take
care
of
themselves
;
as
if
he
thought
the
larger
parts
of
speech
could
be
trusted
alone
,
but
the
little
ones
required
to
be
constantly
looked
after
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hope
is
said
by
the
poet
,
sir
,
"
observed
the
gentleman
,
"
to
be
the
nurse
of
young
Desire
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
signified
that
he
had
heard
of
the
cardinal
virtue
in
question
serving
occasionally
in
that
domestic
capacity
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
will
not
rear
her
infant
in
the
present
instance
,
sir
,
you
'll
find
,
"
observed
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Time
will
show
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
nodded
his
head
gravely
;
and
said
,
"
What
is
your
name
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
told
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
old
are
you
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
told
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
profession
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
told
him
that
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
destination
,
sir
?
"
inquired
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
said
Martin
laughing
,
"
I
ca
n't
satisfy
you
in
that
particular
,
for
I
do
n't
know
it
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
?
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
adjusted
his
cane
under
his
left

,
and
took
a
more
deliberate
and
complete
survey
of
Martin
than
he
had
yet

to

.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
completed

,

,
shook
Martin
's
hand
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
My
name
is
Colonel
Diver
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
Editor
of
the
New
York
Rowdy
Journal
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
received
the
communication
with
that
degree
of
respect
which
an
announcement
so
distinguished
appeared
to
demand
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
New
York
Rowdy
Journal
,
sir
,
"
resumed
the
colonel
,
"
is
,
as
I
expect
you
know
,
the
organ
of
our
aristocracy
in
this
city
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
there
IS
an
aristocracy
here
,
then
?
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
what
is
it
composed
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
intelligence
,
sir
,
"
replied

colonel
;
"
of
intelligence
and
virtue
.
 
<EOS>
And
of
their
necessary

in
this
republic
---
 
dollars
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
very
glad
to
hear
this
,
feeling
well
assured
that
if
intelligence
and
virtue
led
,
as
a
matter
of
course
,
to
the
acquisition
of
dollars
,
he
would
speedily
become
a
great
capitalist
.
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
express
the
gratification
such
news
afforded
him
,
when
he
was
interrupted
by
the
captain
of

,
who

to

with
the

;
and
who
,
seeing
a
well
-
dressed

on
the
deck
(
for
Martin
had
thrown
aside
his

)
,
shook
hands
with
him
also
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
an
unspeakable
relief
to
Martin
,
who
,
in
spite
of
the
acknowledged
supremacy
of
Intelligence

virtue
in
that
happy

,
would
have
been
deeply
mortified
to
appear
before
Colonel
Diver
in
the
poor
character
of
a
steerage
passenger
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
cap'en
!
"
said
the
colonel
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
colonel
,
"
cried
the
captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
looking
most
uncommon
bright
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
hardly
realise
its
being
you
,
and
that
's
a
fact
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
good
passage
,
cap'en
?
<EOS>
"
inquired

colonel
,
taking
him
aside
,
   
<EOS>
"
Well
now
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
pretty
spanking
run
,
sir
,
"
said
,
or

,
the

,
who

;
"
con
-
siderin
'
the
weather
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
,
sir
,
"
said

captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
just
now
sent
a
boy
up
to
your

with

passenger

list
,
colonel
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
got
another
boy

,
p'raps
,

?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
guess
there
air
a
dozen
if

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
One
moderate
big
'
un
could

champagne
,

,
"

,

"
to

.
 
<EOS>
You
said
a
spanking
run
,
I

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

I
did
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
can

,

.
<EOS>
---
A
first

rate

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
most
e####tarnal
spanker
,
"
said
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
admire

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
might
loan

,

<EOS>
half
-
a
-

if

.
<EOS>
However

against

's

,
the
Screw
,

,
"

,

,

,
"
her

either

is
almost

spanker
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
captain
,
who
had
the
Sewer
below
at
that
moment
,
lunching
expensively
in
one
cabin
,
while
the
amiable
Stabber
was
drinking
himself
into
a
state
of
blind
madness
in
another
,
took
a
cordial
leave
of
his
friend
the
colonel
,
and
hurried
away
to
dispatch
the
champagne
;
<EOS>
well
knowing
(
as
it
afterwards
appeared
)
that
if
he
failed
to
conciliate
the
editor
of
the
Rowdy
Journal
,
that
potentate
would
denounce
him
and
his
ship
in
large
capitals
before
he
was
a
day
older
;
and
would
probably
assault
the
memory
of
his
mother
also
,
who
had
not
been
dead
more
than
twenty
years
.
 
<EOS>
The
colonel
being
again
left
alone
with
Martin
,
checked
him
as
he
was
moving
away
,
and
offered
in
consideration
of
his
being
an
Englishman
,
to
show
him
the
town
and
to
introduce
him
,
if
such
were
his
desire
,
to
a
genteel
boarding
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
before
they
entered
on
these
proceedings
(
he
said
)
,
he
would
beseech
the
honour
of
his
company
at
the
office
of
the
Rowdy
Journal
,
to
partake
of
a
bottle
of
champagne
of
his
own
importation
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
was
so
extremely
kind
and
hospitable
,
that
Martin
,
though
it
was
quite
early
in
the
morning
,
readily
acquiesced
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
instructing
Mark
,
who
was
deeply
engaged
with
his
friend
and
her
three
children
,
that
when
he
had
done
assisting
them
,
and
had
cleared
the
baggage
,
he
was
to
wait
for
further
orders
at
the
Rowdy
Journal
Office
<EOS>
,
Martin
accompanied
his
new
friend
on
shore
.
   
<EOS>
They
made
their
way
as
they
best
could
through
the
melancholy
crowd
of
emigrants
upon
the
wharf
,
who
,
grouped
about
their
beds
and
boxes
,
with
the
bare
ground
below
them
and
the
bare
sky
above
,
might
have
fallen
from
another
planet
,
for
anything
they
knew
of
the
country
;
and
walked
for
some
short
distance
along
a
busy
street
,
bounded
on
one
side
by
the
quays
and
shipping
;
and
on
the
other
by
a
long
row
of
staring
red
-
brick
storehouses
and
offices
,
ornamented
with
more
black
boards
and
white
letters
,
and
more
white
boards
and
black
letters
,
than
Martin
had
ever
seen
before
,
in
fifty
times
the
space
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
they
turned
up
a
narrow
street
,
and
presently
into
other
narrow
streets
,
until
at
last
they
stopped
before
a
house
whereon
was
painted
in
great
characters
,
"
ROWDY
JOURNAL
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
colonel
,
who
had
walked
the
whole
way
with
one
hand
in
his
breast
,
his
head
occasionally
wagging
from
side
to
side
,
and
his
hat
thrown
back
upon
his
ears
,
like
a
man
who
was
oppressed
to
inconvenience
by
a
sense
of
his
own
greatness
,
led
the
way
up
a
dark
and
dirty
flight
of
stairs
into
a
room
of
similar
character
,
all
littered
and
bestrewn
with
odds
and
ends
of
newspapers
and
other
crumpled
fragments
,
both
in
proof
and
manuscript
.
 
<EOS>
Behind
a
mangy
old
writing
-
table
in
this
apartment
sat
a
figure
with
a
stump
of
a
pen
in
its
mouth
and
a
great
pair
of
scissors
in
its
right
hand
,
clipping
and
slicing
at
a
file
of
Rowdy
Journals
;
and
it
was
such
a
laughable
figure
that
Martin
had
some
difficulty
in
preserving
his
gravity
,
though
conscious
of
the
close
observation
of
Colonel
Diver
.
   
<EOS>
The
individual
who
sat
clipping
and
slicing
as
aforesaid
at
the
Rowdy
Journals
,
was
a
small
young
gentleman
of
very
juvenile
appearance
,
and
unwholesomely
pale
in
the
face
;
partly
,
perhaps
,
from
intense
thought
,
but
partly
,
there
is
no
doubt
,
from
the
excessive
use
of
tobacco
,
which
he
was
at
that
moment
chewing
vigorously
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
his
shirt
-
collar
turned
down
over
a
black
ribbon
;
and
his
lank
hair
,
a
fragile
crop
,
was
not
only
smoothed
and
parted
back
from
his
brow
,
that
none
of
the
Poetry
of
his
aspect
might
be
lost
,
but
had
,
here
and
there
,
been
grubbed
up
by
the
roots
;
which
accounted
for
his
loftiest
developments
being
somewhat
pimply
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
that
order
of
nose
on
which
the
envy
of
mankind
has
bestowed
the
appellation
"
snub
,
"
and
it
was
very
much
turned
up
at
the
end
,
as
with
a
lofty
scorn
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
the
upper
lip
of
this
young
gentleman
were
tokens
of
a
sandy
down
;
so
very
,
very
smooth
and
scant
,
that
,
though
encouraged
to
the
utmost
,
it
looked
more
like
a
recent
trace
of
gingerbread
than
the
fair
promise
of
a
moustache
;
and
this
conjecture
,
his
apparently
tender
age
went
far
to
strengthen
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
intent
upon
his
work
.
 
<EOS>
Every
time
he
snapped
the
great
pair
of
scissors
,
he
made
a
corresponding
motion
with
his
jaws
,
which
gave
him
a
very
terrible
appearance
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
not
long
in
determining
within
himself
that
this
must
be
Colonel
Diver
's
son
;
the
hope
of
the
family
,
and
future
mainspring
of
the
Rowdy
Journal
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
he
had
begun
to
say
that
he
presumed
this
was
the
colonel
's
little
boy
,
and
that
it
was
very
pleasant
to
see
him
playing
at
Editor
in
all
the
guilelessness
of
childhood
,
when
the
colonel
proudly
interposed
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
My
War
Correspondent
,
sir
---
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
could
not
help
starting
at
this
unexpected
announcement
,
and
the
consciousness
of
the
irretrievable
mistake
he
had
nearly
made
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Brick
seemed
pleased
with
the
sensation
he
produced
upon
the
stranger
,
and
shook
hands
with
him
,
with
an
air
of
patronage
designed
to
reassure
him
,
and
to
let
him
blow
that
there
was
no
occasion
to
be
frightened
,
for
he
(
Brick
)
would
n't
hurt
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
of
Jefferson
Brick
,
I
see
,
sir
,
"
quoth
the
colonel
,
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
England
has
heard
of
Jefferson
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
Europe
has
heard
of
Jefferson
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
When
did
you
leave
England
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Five
weeks
ago
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Five
weeks
ago
,
"
repeated
the
colonel
,
thoughtfully
;
as
he
took
his
seat
upon
the
table
,
and
swung

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now

,
sir
which
of
Mr

's
articles
had

that

most

the
British

Saint
James
's
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
I
---
"
   
"
I
have
reason
to
know
,
sir
,
"
interrupted

colonel
,
"
that
the
aristocratic
circles
of
your
country
quail
before
the
name
of
Jefferson
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
be
informed
,
sir
,
from
your
lips
,
which
of
his
sentiments
has

---
"
   
"
At
the

of
the
Hydra

Corruption
now

Reason
,

,

,
"

,
putting

little

,
and
quoting
his
last
article
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
libation
of
freedom
,
Brick
"
---
hinted
the
colonel
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
Must
sometimes
be
quaffed
in
blood
,
colonel
,
"
cried
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
said
"
blood
,
"
he
gave
the
great
pair
of
scissors
a
sharp
snap
,
as
if
THEY
said
blood
too
,
and
were
quite
of
his
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
This
done
,
they
both
looked
at
Martin
,
pausing
for
a
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
life
,
"
said
Martin
,
who
had
by
this
time
quite
recovered
his
usual
coolness
,
"
I
ca
n't
give
you
any
satisfactory
information
about
it
;
for
the
truth
is
that
I
---
"
   
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
colonel
,
glancing
sternly
at
his
war
correspondent
and
giving
his
head
one
shake
after
every
sentence
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
you
never
heard
of
Jefferson
Brick
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
never
read
Jefferson
Brick
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
never
saw
the
Rowdy
Journal
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
never
knew
,
sir
,
of
its
mighty
influence
upon
the
cabinets
of
Europe
.
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
was
about
to
observe
,
certainly
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
cool
,
Jefferson
,
"
said
the
colonel
gravely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
bust
!
<EOS>
oh
you
Europeans
!
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
let
's
have
a
glass
of
wine
!
"
 
<EOS>
So
saying
,
he
got
down
from
the
table
,
and
produced
,
from
a
basket
outside
the
door
,
a
bottle
of
champagne
,
and
three
glasses
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
,
sir
,
"
said
the
colonel
,
filling
Martin
's
glass
and
his
own
,
and
pushing
the
bottle
to
that
gentleman
,
"
will
give
us
a
sentiment
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
"
cried
the
war
correspondent
,
"
Since
you
have
concluded
to
call
upon
me
,
I
will
respond
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
give
you
,
sir
,
The
Rowdy
Journal
and
its
brethren
;
the
well
of
Truth
,
whose
waters
are
black
from
being
composed
of
printers
'
ink
,
but
are
quite
clear
enough
for
my
country
to
behold
the
shadow
of
her
Destiny
reflected
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
,
hear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
colonel
,
with
great
complacency
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
are
flowery
components
,
sir
,
in
the
language
of
my
friend
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
much
so
,
indeed
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
to
-
day
's
Rowdy
,
sir
,
"
observed
the
colonel
,
handing
him
a
paper
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
find
Jefferson
Brick
at
his
usual
post
in
the
van
of
human
civilization
and
moral
purity
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
colonel
was
by
this
time
seated
on
the
table
again
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Brick
also
took
up
a
position
on
that
same
piece
of
furniture
;
and
they
fell
to
drinking
pretty
hard
.
 
<EOS>
They
often
looked
at
Martin
as
he
read
the
paper
,
and
then
at
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
laid
it
down
,
which
was
not
until
they
had
finished
a
second
bottle
,
the
colonel
asked
him
what
he
thought
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
it
's
horribly
personal
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
The
colonel
seemed
much
flattered
by
this
remark
;
and
said
he
hoped
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
independent
here
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
do
as
we
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
may
judge
from
this
specimen
,
"
returned
Martin
,
"
there
must
be
a
few
thousands
here
,
rather
the
reverse
of
independent
,
who
do
as
they
do
n't
like
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
They
yield
to
the
popular
mind
of
the
Popular
Instructor
,
sir
,
"
said
the
colonel
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
rile
up
,
sometimes
;
but
in
general
we
have
a
hold
upon
our
citizens
,
both
in
public
and
in
private
life
,
which
is
as
much
one
of
the
ennobling
institutions
of
our
happy
country
as
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
As
nigger
slavery
itself
,
"
suggested
Mr
Brick
.
   
<EOS>
"
En
-
tirely
so
,
"
remarked
the
colonel
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
said
Martin
,
after
some

,
"
may
I
venture
to
ask
,
with
reference
to
a
case
I
observe
in
this
paper
of
yours
,
whether
the
Popular
Instructor
often
deals
in
<EOS>
---
I
am
at
a
loss
to
express
it
without
giving
you
offence
---
in
forgery
?
 
<EOS>
In
forged
letters
,
for
instance
,
"
he
pursued
,
for
the
colonel
<EOS>
was
perfectly
calm
and
quite
at

,
"
solemnly
purporting
to
have
been
written
at
recent
periods
by
living

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
"
replied
the
colonel
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
does
,
now
and
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
the
popular
instructed
---
what
do
they
do
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Buy
'
em
<EOS>
:
"
said
the
colonel
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
expectorated
and
laughed
;
the
former
copiously
,
the
latter
approvingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Buy
'em
by
hundreds
of
thousands
,
"
resumed
the
colonel
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
a
smart
people
here
,
and
can
appreciate
smartness
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
smartness
American
for
forgery
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
colonel
,
"
I
expect
it
's
American
for
a
good
many
things
that
you
call
by
other
names
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
ca
n't
help
yourself
in
Europe
.
 
<EOS>
We
can
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
do
,
sometimes
,
"
thought
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
help
yourselves
with
very
little
ceremony
,
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
whatever
name
we
choose
to
employ
,
"
said
the
colonel
,
stooping
down
to
roll
the
third

into
a

after
the
other

,
"
I
suppose
the
art
of
forgery
was
not
invented
here
sir
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose

,
"
replied
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
any
other
kind
of
smartness
I
reckon
?
"
   
"
Invented
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
presume
not
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
colonel
;
"
then
we
got
it
all
from
the
old
country
,
and
the
old
country
's
to
blame
for
it
,
and
not
the
new
'
un
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
an
end
of
THAT
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
if
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
and
you
will
be
so
good
as
to
clear
,
I
'll
come
out
last
,
and
lock

.
"
   
<EOS>
Rightly
interpreting
this
as
the
signal
for
their
departure
,
Martin
walked
downstairs
after
the
war
correspondent
,
who
preceded
him
with
great
majesty
.
 
<EOS>
The
colonel
following
,
they
left
the
Rowdy
Journal
Office
and
walked
forth
into
the
streets
;
Martin
feeling
doubtful
whether
he
ought
to
kick
the
colonel
for
having
presumed
to
speak
to
him
,
or
whether
it
came
within
the
bounds
of
possibility
that
he
and
his
establishment
could
be
among
the
boasted
usages
of
that
regenerated
land
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
clear
that
Colonel
Diver
,
in
the
security
of
his
strong
position
,
and
in
his
perfect
understanding
of
the
public
sentiment
,
cared
very
little
what
Martin
or
anybody
else
thought
about
him
.
<EOS>
His
high
-
spiced
wares
were
made
to
sell
,
and
they
sold
;
and
his
thousands
of
readers
could
as
rationally
charge
their
delight
in
filth
upon
him
,
as
a
glutton
can
shift
upon
his
cook
the
responsibility
of
his
beastly
excess
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
would
have
delighted
the
colonel
more
than
to
be
told
that
no
such
man
as
he
could
walk
in
high
success
the
streets
of
any
other
country
in
the
world
;
for
that
would
only
have
been
a
logical
assurance
to
him
of
the
correct
adaptation
of
his
labours
to
the
prevailing
taste
,
and
of
his
being
strictly
and
peculiarly
a
national
feature
of
America
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
a
mile
or
more
along
a
handsome
street
which
the
colonel
said
was
called
Broadway
,
and
which
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
said
"
whipped
the
universe
.
"
 
<EOS>
Turning
,
at
length
,
into
one
of
the
numerous
streets
which
branched
from
this
main
thoroughfare
,
they
stopped
before
a
rather
mean
-
looking
house
with
jalousie
blinds
to
every
window
;
a
flight
of
steps
before
the
green
street
-
door
;
a
shining
white
ornament
on
the
rails
on
either
side
like
a
petrified
pineapple
,
polished
;
a
little
oblong
plate
of
the
same
material
over
the
knocker
whereon
the
name
of
"
Pawkins
"
was
engraved
;
and
four
accidental
pigs
looking
down
the
area
.
   
<EOS>
The
colonel
knocked
at
this
house
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
lived
there
;
and
an
Irish
girl
popped
her
head
out
of
one
of
the
top
windows
to
see
who
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Pending
her
journey
downstairs
,
the
pigs
were
joined
by
two
or
three
friends
from
the
next
street
,
in
company
with
whom
they
lay
down
sociably
in
the
gutter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
the
major
indoors
?
"
inquired
the
colonel
,
as
he
entered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
the
master
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
returned
the
girl
,
with
a
hesitation
which
seemed
to
imply
that
they
were
rather
flush
of
majors
in
that
establishment
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
master
!
"
said
Colonel
Diver
,
stopping
short
and
looking
round
at
his
war
correspondent
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
The
depressing
institutions
of
that
British
empire
,
colonel
!
"
said
Jefferson
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
"
Master
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
with
the
word
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
hope
it
was
never
heard
in
our
country
,
sir
;
that
's
all
,
"
said
Jefferson
Brick
;
"
except
when
it
is
used
by
some
degraded
Help
,
as
new
to
the
blessings
of
our
form
of
government
,
as
this
Help
is
.
<EOS>
There
are
no
masters
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
"
owners
,
"
are
they
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
followed
in
the
Rowdy
Journal
's
footsteps
without
returning
any
answer
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
took
the
same
course
,
thinking
as
he
went
,
that
perhaps
the
free
and
independent
citizens
,
who
in
their
moral
elevation
,
owned
the
colonel
for
their
master
,
might
render
better
homage
to
the
goddess
,
Liberty
,
in
nightly
dreams
upon
the
oven
of
a
Russian
Serf
.
   
<EOS>
The
colonel
led
the
way
into
a
room
at
the
back
of
the
house
upon
the
ground
-
floor
,
light
,
and
of
fair
dimensions
,
but
exquisitely
uncomfortable
;
having
nothing
in
it
but
the
four
cold
white
walls
and
ceiling
,
a
mean
carpet
,
a
dreary
waste
of
dining
-
table
reaching
from
end
to
end
,
and
a
bewildering
collection
of
cane
-
bottomed
chairs
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
further
region
of
this
banqueting
-
hall
was
a
stove
,
garnished
on
either
side
with
a
great
brass
spittoon
,
and
shaped
in
itself
like
three
little
iron
barrels
set
up
on
end
in
a
fender
,
and
joined
together
on
the
principle
of
the
Siamese
Twins
.
 
<EOS>
Before
it
,
swinging
himself
in
a
rocking
-
chair
,
lounged
a
large
gentleman
with
his
hat
on
,
who
amused
himself
by
spitting
alternately
into
the
spittoon
on
the
right
hand
of
the
stove
,
and
the
spittoon
on
the
left
,
and
then
working
his
way
back
again
in
the
same
order
.
 
<EOS>
A
negro
lad
in
a
soiled
white
jacket
was
busily
engaged
in
placing
on
the
table
two
long
rows
of
knives
and
forks
,
relieved
at
intervals
by
jugs
of
water
;
and
as
he
travelled
down
one
side
of
this
festive
board
,
he
straightened
with
his
dirty
hands
the
dirtier
cloth
,
which
was
all
askew
,
and
had
not
been
removed
since
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
The
atmosphere
of
this
room
was
rendered
intensely
hot
and
stifling
by
the
stove
;
but
being
further
flavoured
by
a
sickly
gush
of
soup
from
the
kitchen
,
and
by
such
remote
suggestions
of
tobacco
as
lingered
within
the
brazen
receptacles
already
mentioned
,
it
became
,
to
a
stranger
's
senses
,
almost
insupportable
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
in
the
rocking
-
chair
having
his
back
towards
them
,
and
being
much
engaged
in
his
intellectual
pastime
,
was
not
aware
of
their
approach
until
the
colonel
,
walking
up
to
the
stove
,
contributed
his
mite
towards
the
support
of
the
left
-
hand
spittoon
,
just
as
the
major
---
for
it
was
the
major
---
bore
down
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Major
Pawkins
then
reserved
his
fire
,
and
looking
upward
,
said
,
with
a
peculiar
air
of
quiet
weariness
,
like
a
man
who
had
been
up
all
night
---
an
air
which
Martin
had
already
observed
both
in
the
colonel
and
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
---
    
<EOS>
"
Well
,
colonel
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
is
a
gentleman
from
England
,
major
,
"
the
colonel
replied
,
"
who
has
concluded
to
locate
himself
here
if
the
amount
of
compensation
suits
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
see
you
,
sir
,
"
observed
the
major
,
shaking
hands
with
Martin
,
and
not
moving
a
muscle
of
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
pretty
bright
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
better
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
never
likely
to
be
,
"
returned
the
major
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
the
sun
shine
HERE
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
remember
to
have
seen
it
shine
at
home
sometimes
,
"
said
Martin
,
smiling
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
not
,
"
replied
the
major
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
so
with
a
stoical
indifference
certainly
,
but
still
in
a
tone
of
firmness
which
admitted
of
no
further
dispute
on
that
point
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
thus
settled
the
question
,
he
put
his
hat
a
little
on
one
side
for
the
greater
convenience
of
scratching
his
head
,
and
saluted
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
with
a
lazy
nod
.
   
<EOS>
Major
Pawkins
(
a
gentleman
of
Pennsylvanian
origin
)
was
distinguished
by
a
very
large
skull
,
and
a
great
mass
of
yellow
forehead
;
in
deference
to
which
commodities
it
was
currently
held
in
bar
-
rooms
and
other
such
places
of
resort
that
the
major
was
a
man
of
huge
sagacity
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
further
to
be
known
by
a
heavy
eye
and
a
dull
slow
manner
;
and
for
being
a
man
of
that
kind
who
---
mentally
speaking
---
requires
a
deal
of
room
to
turn
himself
in
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
trading
on
his
stock
of
wisdom
,
he
invariably
proceeded
on
the
principle
of
putting
all
the
goods
he
had
(
and
more
)
into
his
window
;
and
that
went
a
great
way
with
his
constituency
of
admirers
.
<EOS>
It
went
a
great
way
,
perhaps
,
with
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
,
who
took
occasion
to
whisper
in
Martin
's
ear
:
   
<EOS>
"
One
of
the
most
remarkable
men
in
our
country
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
must
not
be
supposed
,
however
,
that
the
perpetual
exhibition
in
the
market
-
place
of
all
his
stock
-
in
-
trade
for
sale
or
hire
,
was
the
major
's
sole
claim
to
a
very
large
share
of
sympathy
and
support
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
great
politician
;
and
the
one
article
of
his
creed
,
in
reference
to
all
public
obligations
involving
the
good
faith
and
integrity
of
his
country
,
was
,
"
run
a
moist
pen
slick
through
everything
,
and
start
fresh
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
made
him
a
patriot
.
 
<EOS>
In
commercial
affairs
he
was
a
bold
speculator
.
 
<EOS>
In
plainer
words
he
had
a
most
distinguished
genius
for
swindling
,
and
could
start
a
bank
,
or
negotiate
a
loan
,
or
form
a
land
-
jobbing
company
(
entailing
ruin
,
pestilence
,
and
death
,
on
hundreds
of
families
)
,
with
any
gifted
creature
in
the
Union
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
him
an
admirable
man
of
business
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
hang
about
a
bar
-
room
,
discussing
the
affairs
of
the
nation
,
for
twelve
hours
together
;
and
in
that
time
could
hold
forth
with
more
intolerable
dulness
,
chew
more
tobacco
,
smoke
more
tobacco
,
drink
more
rum
-
toddy
,
mint
-
julep
,
gin
-
sling
,
and
cocktail
,
than
any
private
gentleman
of
his
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
him
an
orator
and
a
man
of
the
people
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
the
major
was
a
rising
character
,
and
a
popular
character
,
and
was
in
a
fair
way
to
be
sent
by
the
popular
party
to
the
State
House
of
New
York
,
if
not
in
the
end
to
Washington
itself
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
a
man
's
private
prosperity
does
not
always
keep
pace
with
his
patriotic
devotion
to
public
affairs
;
and
as
fraudulent
transactions
have
their
downs
as
well
as
ups
,
the
major
was
occasionally
under
a
cloud
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
,
just
now
Mrs
Pawkins
kept
a
boarding
-
house
,
and
Major
Pawkins
rather
"
loafed
"
his
time
away
than
otherwise
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
come
to
visit
our
country
,
sir
,
at
a
season
of
great
commercial
depression
,
"
said
the
major
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
an
alarming
crisis
,
"
said
the
colonel
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
a
period
of
unprecedented
stagnation
,
"
said
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
that
,
"
returned
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
likely
to
last
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
knew
nothing
about
America
,
or
he
would
have
known
perfectly
well
that
if
its
individual
citizens
,
to
a
man
,
are
to
be
believed
,
it
always
IS
depressed
,
and
always
IS
stagnated
,
and
always
IS
at
an
alarming
crisis
,
and
never
was
otherwise
;
though
as
a
body
they
are
ready
to
make
oath
upon
the
Evangelists
at
any
hour
of
the
day
or
night
,
that
it
is
the
most
thriving
and
prosperous
of
all
countries
on
the
habitable
globe
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
likely
to
last
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
returned
the
major
,
"
<EOS>
I
expect
we
shall
get
along
somehow
,
and
come
right
in
the
end
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
an
elastic
country
,
"
said
the
Rowdy
Journal
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
a
young
lion
,
"
said
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
revivifying
and
vigorous
principles
within
ourselves
,
"
observed
the
major
.
 
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
drink
a
bitter
afore
dinner
,
colonel
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
colonel
assenting
to
this
proposal
with
great
alacrity
,
Major
Pawkins
proposed
an
adjournment
to
a
neighbouring
bar
-
room
,
which
,
as
he
observed
,
was
"
only
in
the
next
block
.
"
 
<EOS>
He
then
referred
Martin
to
Mrs
Pawkins
for
all
particulars
connected
with
the
rate
of
board
and
lodging
,
and
informed
him
that
he
would
have
the
pleasure
of
seeing
that
lady
at
dinner
,
which
would
soon
be
ready
,
as
the
dinner
hour
was
two
o'clock
,
and
it
only
wanted
a
quarter
now
.
 
<EOS>
This
reminded
him
that
if
the
bitter
were
to
be
taken
at
all
,
there
was
no
time
to
lose
;
so
he
walked
off
without
more
ado
,
and
left
them
to
follow
if
they
thought
proper
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
major
rose
from
his
rocking
-
chair
before
the
stove
,
and
so
disturbed
the
hot
air
and
balmy
whiff
of
soup
which
fanned
their
brows
,
the
odour
of
stale
tobacco
became
so
decidedly
prevalent
as
to
leave
no
doubt
of
its
proceeding
mainly
from
that
gentleman
's
attire
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
as
Martin
walked
behind
him
to
the
bar
-
room
,
he
could
not
help
thinking
that
the
great
square
major
,
in
his
listlessness
and
langour
,
looked
very
much
like
a
stale
weed
himself
;
such
as
might
be
hoed
out
of
the
public
garden
,
with
great
advantage
to
the
decent
growth
of
that
preserve
,
and
tossed
on
some
congenial
dunghill
.
   
<EOS>
They
encountered
more
weeds
in
the
bar
-
room
,
some
of
whom
(
being
thirsty
souls
as
well
as
dirty
)
were
pretty
stale
in
one
sense
,
and
pretty
fresh
in
another
.
 
<EOS>
Among
them
was
a
gentleman
who
,
as
Martin
gathered
from
the
conversation
that
took
place
over
the
bitter
,
started
that
afternoon
for
the
Far
West
on
a
six
months
'
business
tour
,
and
who
,
as
his
outfit
and
equipment
for
this
journey
,
had
just
such
another
shiny
hat
and
just
such
another
little
pale
valise
as
had
composed
the
luggage
of
the
gentleman
who
came
from
England
in
the
Screw
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
walking
back
very
leisurely
;
Martin
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
,
and
the
major
and
the
colonel
side
-
by
-
side
before
them
;
when
,
as
they
came
within
a
house
or
two
of
the
major
's
residence
,
they
heard
a
bell
ringing
violently
.
 
<EOS>
The
instant
this
sound
struck
upon
their
ears
,
the
colonel
and
the
major
darted
off
,
dashed
up
the
steps
and
in
at
the
street
-
door
(
which
stood
ajar
)
like
lunatics
;
while
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
,
detaching
his
arm
from
Martin
's
,
made
a
precipitate
dive
in
the
same
direction
,
and
vanished
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
premises
are
on
fire
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
an
alarm
bell
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
smoke
to
be
seen
,
nor
any
flame
,
nor
was
there
any
smell
of
fire
.
 
<EOS>
As
Martin
faltered
on
the
pavement
,
three
more
gentlemen
,
with
horror
and
agitation
depicted
in
their
faces
,
came
plunging
wildly
round
the
street
corner
;
jostled
each
other
on
the
steps
;
struggled
for
an
instant
;
and
rushed
into
the
house
,
a
confused
heap
of
arms
and
legs
.
 
<EOS>
Unable
to
bear
it
any
longer
,
Martin
followed
.
 
<EOS>
Even
in
his
rapid
progress
he
was
run
down
,
thrust
aside
,
and
passed
,
by
two
more
gentlemen
,
stark
mad
,
as
it
appeared
,
with
fierce
excitement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
breathlessly
,
to
a
negro
whom
he
encountered
in
the
passage
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
eatin
room
,
sa
.
 
<EOS>
Kernell
,
sa
,
him
<EOS>
kep
a
seat
"
side
himself
,
sa
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
seat
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
a
dinnar
,
sa
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
started
at
him
for
a
moment
,
and
burst
into
a
hearty
laugh
;
to
which
the
negro
,
out
of
his
natural
good
humour
and
desire
to
please
,
so
heartily
responded
,
that
his
teeth
shone
like
a
gleam
of
light
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
the
pleasantest
fellow
I
have
seen
yet
,
"
said
Martin
clapping
him
on
the
back
,
"
and
give
me
a
better
appetite
than
bitters
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
sentiment
he
walked
into
the
dining
-
room
and
slipped
into
a
chair
next
the
colonel
,
which
that
gentleman
(
by
this
time
nearly
through
his
dinner
)
had
turned
down
in
reserve
for
him
,
with
its
back
against
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
numerous
company
---
eighteen
or
twenty
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
Of
these
some
five
or
six
were
ladies
,
who
sat
wedged
together
in
a
little
phalanx
by
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
knives
and
forks
were
working
away
at
a
rate
that
was
quite
alarming
;
very
few
words
were
spoken
;
and
everybody
seemed
to
eat
his
utmost
in
self
-
defence
,
as
if
a
famine
were
expected
to
set
in
before
breakfast
time
to
-
morrow
morning
,
and
it
had
become
high
time
to
assert
the
first
law
of
nature
.
 
<EOS>
The
poultry
,
which
may
perhaps
be
considered
to
have
formed
the
staple
of
the
entertainment
---
for
there
was
a
turkey
at
the
top
,
a
pair
of
ducks
at
the
bottom
,
and
two
fowls
in
the
middle
---
disappeared
as
rapidly
as
if
every
bird
had
had
the
use
of
its
wings
,
and
had
flown
in
desperation
down
a
human
throat
.
 
<EOS>
The
oysters
,
stewed
and
pickled
,
leaped
from
their
capacious
reservoirs
,
and
slid
by
scores
into
the
mouths
of
the
assembly
.
 
<EOS>
The
sharpest
pickles
vanished
,
whole
cucumbers
at
once
,
like
sugar
-
plums
,
and
no
man
winked
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Great
heaps
of
indigestible
matter
melted
away
as
ice
before
the
sun
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
solemn
and
an
awful
thing
to
see
.
 
<EOS>
Dyspeptic
individuals
bolted
their
food
in
wedges
;
feeding
,
not
themselves
,
but
broods
of
nightmares
,
who
were
continually
standing
at
livery
within
them
.
 
<EOS>
Spare
men
,
with
lank
and
rigid
cheeks
,
came
out
unsatisfied
from
the
destruction
of
heavy
dishes
,
and
glared
with
watchful
eyes
upon
the
pastry
.
 
<EOS>
What
Mrs
Pawkins
felt
each
day
at
dinner
-
time
is
hidden
from
all
human
knowledge
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
had
one
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
soon
over
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
colonel
had
finished
his
dinner
,
which
event
took
place
while
Martin
,
who
had
sent
his
plate
for
some
turkey
,
was
waiting
to
begin
,
he
asked
him
what
he
thought
of
the
boarders
,
who
were
from
all
parts
of
the
Union
,
and
whether
he
would
like
to
know
any
particulars
concerning
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
who
is
that
sickly
little
girl
opposite
,
with
the
tight
round
eyes
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
see
anybody
here
,
who
looks
like
her
mother
,
or
who
seems
to
have
charge
of
her
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
the
matron
in
blue
,
sir
?
"
asked
the
colonel
,
with
emphasis
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
Mrs
Jefferson
Brick
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
<EOS>
I
mean
the
little
girl
,
like
a
doll
;
directly
opposite
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
"
cried
the
colonel
.
 
<EOS>
"
THAT
is
Mrs
Jefferson
Brick
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
glanced
at
the
colonel
's
face
,
but
he
was
quite
serious
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
I
suppose
there
will
be
a
young
Brick
then
,
one
of
these
days
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
are
two
young
Bricks
already
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
colonel
.
   
<EOS>
The
matron
looked
so
uncommonly
like
a
child
herself
,
that
Martin
could
not
help
saying
as
much
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
colonel
,
"
but
some
institutions
develop
human
natur
;
others
re
---
tard
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jefferson
Brick
,
"
he
observed
after
a
short
silence
,
in
commendation
of
his
correspondent
,
"
is
one
of
the
most
remarkable
men
in
our
country
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
had
passed
almost
in
a
whisper
,
for
the
distinguished
gentleman
alluded
to
sat
on
Martin
's
other
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
Mr
Brick
,
"
said
Martin
,
turning
to
him
,
and
asking
a
question
more
for
conversation
's
sake
than
from
any
feeling
of
interest
in
its
subject
,
"
who
is
that
;
"
he
was
going
to
say
"
young
"
but
thought
it
prudent
to
eschew
the
word
---
"
that
very
short
gentleman
yonder
,
with
the
red
nose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
Pro
---
fessor
Mullit
,
sir
,
"
replied
Jefferson
.
   
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
what
he
is
professor
of
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
education
,
sir
,
"
said
Jefferson
Brick
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
sort
of
schoolmaster
,
possibly
?
<EOS>
"
Martin
ventured
to
observe
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
of
fine
moral
elements
,
sir
,
and
not
commonly
endowed
,
"
said
the
war
correspondent
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
felt
it
necessary
,
at
the
last
election
for
President
,
to
repudiate
and
denounce
his
father
,
who
voted
on
the
wrong
interest
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
since
written
some
powerful
pamphlets
,
under
the
signature
of
"
Suturb
,
"
or
Brutus
reversed
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
one
of
the
most
remarkable
men
in
our
country
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
seem
to
be
plenty
of
'
em
,
"
thought
Martin
,
"
at
any
rate
.
"
   
<EOS>
Pursuing
his
inquiries
Martin
found
that
there
were
no
fewer
than
four
majors
present
,
two
colonels
,
one
general
,
and
a
captain
,
so
that
he
could
not
help
thinking
how
strongly
officered
the
American
militia
must
be
;
and
wondering
very
much
whether
the
officers
commanded
each
other
;
or
if
they
did
not
,
where
on
earth
the
privates
came
from
.
 
<EOS>
There
seemed
to
be
no
man
there
without
a
title
;
for
those
who
had
not
attained
to
military
honours
were
either
doctors
,
professors
,
or
reverends
.
 
<EOS>
Three
very
hard
and
disagreeable
gentlemen
were
on
missions
from
neighbouring
States
;
one
on
monetary
affairs
,
one
on
political
,
one
on
sectarian
.
 
<EOS>
Among
the
ladies
,
there
were
Mrs
Pawkins
,
who
was
very
straight
,
bony
,
and
silent
;
and
a
wiry
-
faced
old
damsel
,
who
held
strong
sentiments
touching
the
rights
of
women
,
and
had
diffused
the
same
in
lectures
;
but
the
rest
were
strangely
devoid
of
individual
traits
of
character
,
<EOS>
insomuch
that
any
one
of
them
might
have
changed
minds
with
the
other
,
and
nobody
would
have
found
it
out
.
 
<EOS>
These
,
by
the
way
,
were
the
only
members
of
the
party
who
did
not
appear
to
be
among
the
most
remarkable
people
in
the
country
.
   
<EOS>
Several
of
the
gentlemen
got
up
,
one
by
one
,
and
walked
off
as
they
swallowed
their
last
morsel
;
pausing
generally
by
the
stove
for
a
minute
or
so
to
refresh
themselves
at
the
brass
spittoons
.
 
<EOS>
A
few
sedentary
characters
,
however
,
remained
at
table
full
a
quarter
of
an
hour
,
and
did
not
rise
until
the
ladies
rose
,
when
all
stood
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
they
going
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Martin
,
in
the
ear
of
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
their
bedrooms
,
sir
.
"
   
"
Is
there
no
dessert
,
or
other
interval
of
conversation
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Martin
,
who
was
disposed
to
enjoy
himself
after
his
long
voyage
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
a
busy
people
here
,
sir
,
and
have
no
time
for
that
,
"
was
the
reply
.
   
<EOS>
So
the
ladies
passed
out
in
single
file
;
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
and
such
other
married
gentlemen
as
were
left
,
acknowledging
the
departure
of
their
other
halves
by
a
nod
;
and
there
was
an
end
of
THEM
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
thought
this
an
uncomfortable
custom
,
but
he
kept
his
opinion
to
himself
for
the
present
,
being
anxious
to
hear
,
and
inform
himself
by
,
the
conversation
of
the
busy
gentlemen
,
who
now
lounged
about
the
stove
as
if
a
great
weight
had
been
taken
off
their
minds
by
the
withdrawal
of
the
other
sex
;
and
who
made
a
plentiful
use
of
the
spittoons
and
their
toothpicks
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
rather
barren
of
interest
,
to
say
the
truth
;
and
the
greater
part
of
it
may
be
summed
up
in
one
word
.
 
<EOS>
Dollars
.
 
<EOS>
All
their
cares
,
hopes
,
joys
,
affections
,
virtues
,
and
associations
,
seemed
to
be
melted
down
into
dollars
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
the
chance
contributions
that
fell
into
the
slow
cauldron
of
their
talk
,
they
made
the
gruel
thick
and
slab
with
dollars
.
 
<EOS>
Men
were
weighed
by
their
dollars
,
measures
gauged
by
their
dollars
;
life
was
auctioneered
,
appraised
,
put
up
,
and
knocked
down
for
its
dollars
.
 
<EOS>
The
next
respectable
thing
to
dollars
was
any
venture
having
their
attainment
for
its
end
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
of
that
worthless
ballast
,
honour
and
fair
-
dealing
,
which
any
man
cast
overboard
from
the
ship
of
his
Good
Name
and
Good
Intent
,
the
more
ample
stowage
-
room
he
had
for
dollars
.
 
<EOS>
Make
commerce
one
huge
lie
and
mighty
theft
.
 
<EOS>
Deface
<EOS>
the
banner
of
the
nation
for
an
idle
rag
;
pollute
it
star
by
star
;
and
cut
out
stripe
by
stripe
as
from
the
arm
of
a
degraded
soldier
.
 
<EOS>
Do
anything
for
dollars
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
a
flag
to
THEM
!
   
<EOS>
One
who
rides
at
all
hazards
of
limb
and
life
in
the
chase
of
a
fox
,
will
prefer
to
ride
recklessly
at
most
times
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
was
with
these
gentlemen
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
the
greatest
patriot
,
in
their
eyes
,
who
brawled
the
loudest
,
and
who
cared
the
least
for
decency
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
their
champion
who
,
in
the
brutal
fury
of
his
own
pursuit
,
could
cast
no
stigma
upon
them
for
the
hot
knavery
of
theirs
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
,
Martin
learned
in
the
five
minutes
'
straggling
talk
about
the
stove
,
that
to
carry
pistols
into
legislative
assemblies
,
and
swords
in
sticks
,
and
other
such
peaceful
toys
;
to
seize
opponents
by
the
throat
,
as
dogs
or
rats
might
do
;
to
bluster
,
bully
,
and
overbear
by
personal
assailment
;
were
glowing
deeds
.
 
<EOS>
Not
thrusts
and
stabs
at
Freedom
,
striking
far
deeper
into
her
House
of
Life
than
any
sultan
's
scimitar
could
reach
;
but
rare
incense
on
her
altars
,
having
a
grateful
scent
in
patriotic
nostrils
,
and
curling
upward
to
the
seventh
heaven
of
Fame
.
   
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
,
when
there
was
a
pause
,
Martin
asked
such
questions
as
naturally
occurred
to
him
,
being
a
stranger
,
about
the
national
poets
,
the
theatre
,
literature
,
and
the
arts
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
information
which
these
gentlemen
were
in
a
condition
to
give
him
on
such
topics
,
did
not
extend
beyond
the
effusions
of
such
master
-
spirits
of
the
time
as
Colonel
Diver
,
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
,
and
others
;
renowned
,
as
it
appeared
,
for
excellence
in
the
achievement
of
a
peculiar
style
of
broadside
essay
called
"
a
screamer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
a
busy
people
,
sir
,
"
said
one
of
the
captains
,
who
was
from
the
West
,
"
and
have
no
time
for
reading
mere
notions
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
n't
mind
'em
if
they
come
to
us
in
newspapers
along
with
almighty
strong
stuff
of
another
sort
,
but
darn
your
books
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
general
,
who
appeared
to
grow
quite
faint
at
the
bare
thought
of
reading
anything
which
was
neither
mercantile
nor
political
,
and
was
not
in
a
newspaper
,
inquired
"
if
any
gentleman
would
drink
some
?
"
 
<EOS>
Most
of
the
company
,
considering
this
a
very
choice
and
seasonable
idea
,
lounged
out
,
one
by
one
,
to
the
bar
-
room
in
the
next
block
.
 
<EOS>
Thence
<EOS>
they
probably
went
to
their
stores
and
counting
-
houses
;
thence
to
the
bar
-
room
again
,
to
talk
once
more
of
dollars
,
and
enlarge
their
minds
with
the
perusal
and
discussion
of
screamers
;
and
thence
each
man
to
snore
in
the
bosom
of
his
own
family
.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
would
seem
,
"
said
Martin
,
pursuing
the
current
of
his
own
thoughts
,
"
to
be
the
principal
recreation
they
enjoy
in
common
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
fell
a
-
musing
again
on
dollars
,
demagogues
,
and
bar
-
rooms
;
debating
within
himself
whether
busy
people
of
this
class
were
really
as
busy
as
they
claimed
to
be
,
or
only
had
an
inaptitude
for
social
and
domestic
pleasure
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
difficult
question
to
solve
;
and
the
mere
fact
of
its
being
strongly
presented
to
his
mind
by
all
that
he
had
seen
and
heard
,
was
not
encouraging
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
down
at
the
deserted
board
,
and
becoming
more
and
more
despondent
,
as
he
thought
of
all
the
uncertainties
and
difficulties
of
his
precarious
situation
,
sighed
heavily
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
there
had
been
at
the
dinner
-
table
a
middle
-
aged
man
with
a
dark
eye
and
a
sunburnt
face
,
who
had
attracted
Martin
's
attention
by
having
something
very
engaging
and
honest
in
the
expression
of
his
features
;
but
of
whom
he
could
learn
nothing
from
either
of
his
neighbours
,
who
seemed
to
consider
him
quite
beneath
their
notice
.
<EOS>
He
had
taken
no
part
in
the
conversation
round
the
stove
,
nor
had
he
gone
forth
with
the
rest
;
and
now
,
when
he
heard
Martin
sigh
for
the
third
or
fourth
time
,
he
interposed
with
some
casual
remark
,
as
if
he
desired
,
without
obtruding
himself
upon
a
stranger
's
notice
,
to
engage
him
in
cheerful
conversation
if
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
His
motive
was
so
obvious
,
and
yet
so
delicately
expressed
,
that
Martin
felt
really
grateful
to
him
,
and
showed
him
so
in
the
manner
of
his
reply
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
ask
you
,
"
said
this
gentleman
with
a
smile
,
as
he
rose
and
moved
towards
him
,
"
how
you
like
my
country
,
for
I
can
quite
anticipate
your
feeling
on
that
point
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
am
an
American
,
and
consequently
bound
to
begin
with
a
question
,
I
'll
ask
you
how
you
like
the
colonel
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
very
frank
,
"
returned
Martin
,
"
that
I
have
no
hesitation
in
saying
I
do
n't
like
him
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Though
I
must
add
that
I
am
beholden
to
him
for
his
civility
in
bringing
me
here
---
and
arranging
for
my
stay
,
on
pretty
reasonable
terms
,
by
the
way
,
"
he
added
,
remembering
that
the
colonel
had
whispered
him
to
that
effect
,
before
going
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
much
beholden
,
"
said
the
stranger
drily
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
colonel
occasionally
boards
packet
-
ships
,
I
have
heard
,
to
glean
the
latest
information
for
his
journal
;
and
he
occasionally
brings
strangers
to
board
here
,
I
believe
,
with
a
view
to
the
little
percentage
which
attaches
to
those
good
offices
;
and
which
the
hostess
deducts
from
his
weekly
bill
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
offend
you
,
I
hope
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
seeing
that
Martin
reddened
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
sir
,
"
returned
Martin
,
as
they
shook
hands
,
"
how
is
that
possible
!
<EOS>
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
I
---
am
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
said
the
gentleman
,
sitting
down
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
rather
at
a
loss
,
since
I
must
speak
plainly
,
"
said
Martin
,
getting
the
better
of
his
hesitation
,
"
to
know
how
this
colonel
escapes
being
beaten
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
beaten
once
or
twice
,
"
remarked
the
gentleman
quietly
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
one
of
a
class
of
men
,
in
whom
our
own
Franklin
,
so
long
ago
as
ten
years
before
the
close
of
the
last
century
,
foresaw
our
danger
and
disgrace
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
do
n't
know
that
Franklin
,
in
very
severe
terms
,
published
his
opinion
that
those
who
were
slandered
by
such
fellows
as
this
colonel
,
having
no
sufficient
remedy
in
the
administration
of
this
country
's
laws
or
in
the
decent
and
right
-
minded
feeling
of
its
people
,
were
justified
in
retorting
on
such
public
nuisances
by
means
of
a
stout
cudgel
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
aware
of
that
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
but
I
am
very
glad
to
know
it
,
and
I
think
it
worthy
of
his
memory
;
especially
"
---
here
he
hesitated
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
,
"
said
the
other
,
smiling
as
if
he
knew
what
stuck
in
Martin
's
throat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Especially
,
"
pursued
Martin
,
"
as
I
can
already
understand
that
it
may
have
required
great
courage
,
even
in
his
time
,
to
write
freely
on
any
question
which
was
not
a
party
one
in
this
very
free
country
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Some
courage
,
no
doubt
,
"
returned
his
new
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
it
would
require
any
to
do
so
,
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
think
it
would
;
and
not
a
little
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
.
 
<EOS>
So
very
right
<EOS>
,
that
I
believe
no
satirist
could
breathe
this
air
.
 
<EOS>
If
another
Juvenal
or
Swift
could
rise
up
among
us
to
-
morrow
,
he
would
be
hunted
down
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
knowledge
of
our
literature
,
and
can
give
me
the
name
of
any
man
,
American
born
and
bred
,
who
has
anatomized
our
follies
as
a
people
,
and
not
as
this
or
that
party
;
and
who
has
escaped
the
foulest
and
most
brutal
slander
,
the
most
inveterate
hatred
and
intolerant
pursuit
;
it
will
be
a
strange
name
in
my
ears
,
believe
me
.
 
<EOS>
In
some
cases
I
could
name
to
you
,
where
a
native
writer
has

"
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

Nothing

<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
Why

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Feeling
(

was
,

)

in

,

<EOS>
So

had
done

that

,

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bevan

at

a

neat

,
from
the

of

,

were

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
quickly

by
a
man
with
such

Irish

,
that
it

as
if
he
ought
,
as

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
Commending

to

<EOS>
Mr

which

,
to

Mr

as

England
,
whose

he
had

.
 
<EOS>
They
gave

in
all

and

;
and

'

very

by

,

.
   
<EOS>
There
were
two
young

---
one

;
the

---
both
very

,

;
their

,

,

Martin
thought
much

ought

;
and
their

,
a

woman
,
who
seemed
to
have
got
past
that
stage
,
and
to

again
.
<EOS>
Besides

,

young

'

,

'

;
the

;
the

,

;

,
in

,
like

,

.
 
<EOS>
Which
was
no
great

,
for
it
soon

that
he
was
their
near
relation
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
could
not
help
tracing
the
family

from
the
two
young
ladies
,
because
they
were
foremost
in
his

;
not
only
from
being
,
as
aforesaid
,
very
pretty
,
but
by
reason
of
their

miraculously

,
and
the
thinnest
possible

;
the
which
their
rocking
-

developed
to
a

.
   
<EOS>
There

no

it
was
a

comfortable

to
be
sitting
in
a
snug
,

-

,

by

,
and
full

,

four
small

,
and
the

,
and
---
yes
,
why

?
---
<EOS>
the
feet

therein

.
 
<EOS>
And

Martin
was

in
that
light
,

his

of

Screw
,

's

.
 
<EOS>
The

that
he
made

very

;

tea

(

,

)
,

,
and
much

.
   
<EOS>
Another

circumstance
turned
up
before

first

was

.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
family
had
been
in
England
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
pleasant
thing
!
 
<EOS>
But
Martin
was
not

this
,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
However
,

,

,

,
"

?
"
<EOS>

,
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

"

"

,

<EOS>
"

"
Oh

,

,

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
In

"

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
it

THEM
;

"
which

)

Mrs
Norris
the
mother
had
said
to
the
marchioness
,
and
of
what
the
marquess
and
marchioness
had
both
said
,
when
they
said
that
upon
their
words
and
honours
they
wished
Mr
Norris
the
father
and
Mrs
Norris
the
mother
,
and
the
Misses
Norris
the
daughters
,
and
Mr
Norris
Junior
,
the
son
,
would
only
take
up
their
permanent
residence
in
England
,
and
give
them
the
pleasure
of
their
everlasting
friendship
,
occupied
a
very
considerable
time
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
thought
it
rather
stange
,
and
in
some
sort
inconsistent
,
that
during
the
whole
of
these
narrations
,
and
in
the
very
meridian
of
their
enjoyment
thereof
,
both
Mr
Norris
the
father
,
and
Mr
Norris
Junior
,
the
son
(
who
corresponded
,
every
post
,
with
four
members
of
the
English
Peerage
)
,
enlarged
upon
the
inestimable
advantage
of
having
no
such
arbitrary
distinctions
in
that
enlightened
land
,
where
there
were
no
noblemen
but
nature
's
noblemen
,
and
where
all

was
based
on
one
broad
level
of
brotherly
love
and
natural
equality
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Mr
Norris
the
father
gradually
expanding
into
an
oration
on
this
swelling
theme
,
was
becoming
tedious
,
when
Mr
Bevan
diverted
his
thoughts
by
happening
to
make
some
causal

relative
to
the
occupier
of
the
next
house
;
in

to

,
this
same
Mr
Norris
the
father
observed
,
that
"
that
person
entertained
religious
opinions
of
which
he
could
n't
approve
;
and
therefore
he
had
n't
the
honour
of
knowing
the
gentleman
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Norris
the
mother
added
another
reason
of
her
own
,
the
same
in
effect
,
but
varying
in
words
;
to
wit
,
that
she
believed
the
people
were
well
enough
in
their
way
,
but
they
were
not
genteel
.
   
<EOS>
Another
little
trait
came
out
,
which
impressed
itself
on
Martin
forcibly
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bevan
told
them
about
Mark
and
the
negro
,
and
then
it
appeared
that
all
the
Norrises
were
abolitionists
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
relief
to
hear
this
,
and
Martin
was
so
much
encouraged
on
finding
himself
in
such
company
,
that
he
expressed
his
sympathy
with
the
oppressed
and
wretched
blacks
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
one
of
the
young
ladies
---
the
prettiest
and
most
delicate
---
was
mightily
amused
at
the
earnestness
with
which
he
spoke
;
and
on
his
craving
leave
to
ask
her
why
,
was
quite
unable
for
a
time
to
speak
for
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
however
as
she
could
,
she
told

that
the
negroes
were
such
a
funny
people
,
so
excessively
ludicrous
in
their
manners
and
appearance
,
that
it
was
wholly
impossible
for
those
who
knew
them
well
,
to
associate
any
serious
ideas
with
such
a
very
absurd
part
of
the
creation
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Norris
the
father
,
and
Mrs
Norris
the
mother
,
and
Miss
Norris
the
sister
,
and
Mr
Norris
Junior
the
brother
,
and

Mrs
Norris
Senior
the

,
were
all

this

,
and
laid

down
as

---
as

nothing
in
suffering
and
slavery
,
grim
enough
to
cast

solemn

on
any

;
though

were
as

,

,

,

,
as
the
mildest
Nimrod
among
tuft

!
   
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
"
said
Mr
Norris
the
father
,
settling

question
comfortably
,
"
there
is
a
natural
antipathy
between
the
races
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Extending
,
"
said
Martin
's

,
in

,
"
to
the
cruellest
of

,
and
the
bargain
and

of

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Norris
the
son
said
nothing
,
but
he
made
a

,
and
dusted
his

as
Hamlet
might
after
getting
rid
of
Yorick
's

;
just
as
though
he
had
that
moment
touched
a

,
and
some

black
had
come

.
   
<EOS>
In

might

,
Martin

the

,
with

that
it
would
be
a

theme
to
revive
under
the
best

;
and
again
addressed
himself
to
the
young
ladies
,
who
were
very

attired
in
very

,
and
had
every
article
of
dress
on
the
same

as
the
little
shoes
and
the
thin

.
 
<EOS>
This
suggested
to
him
that
they
were
great
proficients
in
the
French
fashions
,
which
soon
turned
out
to
be
the
case
,
for
though
their
information
appeared
to
be
none
of
the
newest
,
it
was
very
extensive
;
and
the
eldest
sister
in
particular
,
who
was
distinguished
by
a
talent
for
metaphysics
,
the
laws
of
hydraulic
pressure
,
and
the
rights
of
human
kind
,
had
a
novel
way
of
combining
these
acquirements
and
bringing
them
to
bear
on
any
subject
from
Millinery
to
the
Millennium
,
both
inclusive
,
which
was
at
once
improving
and
remarkable
;
so
much
so
,
in
short
,
that
it
was
usually
observed
to
reduce
foreigners
to
a
state
of
temporary
insanity
in
five
minutes
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
felt
his
reason
going
;
and
as
a
means
of
saving
himself
,
besought
the
other
sister
(
seeing
a
piano
in
the
room
)
to
sing
.
<EOS>
With
this
request
she
willingly
complied
;
and
a
bravura
concert
,
solely
sustained
by
the
Misses
Noriss
,
presently
began
.
 
<EOS>
They
sang
in
all
languages
---
except
their
own
.
 
<EOS>
German
,
French
,
Italian
,
Spanish
,
Portuguese
,
Swiss
;
but
nothing
native
;
nothing
so
low
as
native
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
in
this
respect
,
languages
are
like
many
other
travellers
---
ordinary
and
commonplace
enough
at
home
,
but
"
specially
genteel
abroad
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
little
doubt
that
in
course
of
time
the
Misses
Norris
would
have
come
to
Hebrew
,
if

from
the
Irishman
,
who
,

,

---
    
"
Jiniral
Fladdock
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
!
"
cried
the
sisters
,
desisting
suddenly
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
general
come
back
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
they
made
the
exclamation
,
the
general
,
attired
in
full
uniform
for
a
ball
,
came
darting
in
with
such

that
,
hitching
his
boot
in
the

,
and
getting
his

between

,
he
came
down

,
and
presented
a
curious
little

place
on
the

of

to
the

the
astonished
company
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was

the
worst
of
it
;
for
being
rather
corpulent
and
very
tight
,
the
general
being
down
,
could
not
get
up
again
,
but
lay
there
writing
and
doing
such
things
with
his
boots
,
as
there
is
no
other
instance
of
in
military
history
.
   
<EOS>
Of
course
there
was
an
immediate
rush
to
his
assistance
;
and
the
general
was
promptly
raised
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
uniform
was
so
fearfully
and
wonderfully
made
,
that
he
came
up
stiff
and
without
a
bend
in
him
like
a
dead
Clown
,
and
had
no
command
<EOS>
whatever
of
himself
until
he
was
put
quite
flat
upon
the
soles
of
his
feet
,
when
he
became
animated
as
by
a
miracle
,
and
moving
edgewise
that
he
might
go
in
a
narrower
compass
and
be
in
less
danger
of
fraying
the
gold

on

by
brushing
them
against
anything
,
advanced
with
a
smiling

to
salute
the
lady
of
the
house
.
   
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
it
would
have

impossible

to
testify
purer

and
joy
than
at
this
unlooked
-
for

General
Fladdock
!
 
<EOS>
The
general
was
as

as
if
New
York
had

in

and
no

was
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
shook
hands
with
the
Norrises
three

,
and
then
reviewed

from
a

as
a

,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,
"
cried

,
"
once

the

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr
Norris
the
father
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here

,
general
.
"
   
<EOS>
Then

Norrises
pressed
round
the

,

how

,

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

"
---
he

"
among

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,
the

that

-

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

Norris
the

,

"
I
ca
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
would
if
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
limited

a

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
sighed

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
Norris
,

,

YOU
could

,
without

!
"
   
<EOS>

Never
,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Too

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

!
"
<EOS>

Norris
the

,

.
<EOS>
"
Surely

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
so

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Possible
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Only

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

seemed
at

in

,

,

"
<EOS>
A

-
passenger

<EOS>
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Of

?
"
<EOS>

;
"
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
never
seen
Martin
,
but
Martin
had
seen

,
and
recognized

,
now
that

,
as
the

who

towards

,
and
walked

with

.
   
<EOS>
Everybody
looked
at
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
help
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
truth
must
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
over
in
the
same
ship
as
the
general
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
but
not

.
 
<EOS>
It

for
me
to
observe
strict

,
I
took

passage
in
the
steerage
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
the
general
had
been
carried
up

to
a

,
and
required
to
let
it
off
that
moment
,
he
could
not

.
 
<EOS>
He
,
Fladdock
---
Fladdock
in
full

,
Fladdock
<EOS>
the
General
,
Fladdock
,
the
caressed
of
foreign
noblemen
---
expected

know
a
fellow
who
had
come

the

of
line
-
of
-

,
at

four
pound

!
 
<EOS>
And
meeting
that
fellow
in
the

New
York

,
and
nestling
in
the

of
the
New
York
aristocracy
!
 
<EOS>
He
almost
laid
his

upon

.
   
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
If

get
wind
,
their

relation
had
,
by
his
imprudence
,
for

.
 
<EOS>
They
were
the
bright
particular
stars
of
an
exalted
New
York
sphere
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
other
fashionable
spheres
above

,
and
other
fashionable
spheres
below
,
and
none
of
the
stars
in
any
one

these
spheres
had
anything
to
say
to
the

any

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

all

spheres
it
would

that
the
Norrises
,
deceived
by

and

,
had
,

their

,
"
received
"
a

.
 
<EOS>
O
guardian
eagle
of
the
pure
Republic
,
had
they
lived

this
!
   
<EOS>
"
You
will
allow
me
,
"
said
Martin
,
after
a

,
"
to
take
my
leave
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
that
I
am
the
cause
of
at
least
as

here
,
as
I
have
brought
upon
myself
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
bound
,
before
I
go
,
to
exonerate
this
gentleman
,
who
,
in
introducing
me
to
such
society
,
was
quite
ignorant
of
my
unworthiness
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
made
his
bow
to
the
Norrises
,
and
walked
out
like
a
man
of
snow
;
very
cool
externally
,
but
pretty
hot
within
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
"
said
Mr
Norris
the
father
,
looking
with
a
pale
face
on
the
assembled
circle
as
Martin
closed
the
door
<EOS>
,
"
the
young
man
has
this
night
beheld
a
refinement
of
social
manner
,
and
an
easy
magnificence
of
social
decoration
,
to
which
he
is
a
stranger
in
his
own
country
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
hope
it
may
awake
a
moral
sense
within
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
that
peculiarly
transatlantic
article
,
a
moral
sense
---
for
,
if
native
statesmen
,
orators
,
and
pamphleteers
,
are
to
be
believed
,
America
quite
monopolises
the
commodity
---
if
that
peculiarly
transatlantic
article
be
supposed
to
include
a
benevolent
love
of
all
mankind
,
certainly
Martin
's
would
have
borne
,
just
then
,
<EOS>
a
deal
of
waking
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
strode
along
the
street
,
with
Mark
at
his
heels
,
his
immoral
sense
was
in
active
operation
;
prompting
him
to
the
utterance
of
some
rather
sanguinary
remarks
,
which
it
was
well
for
his
own
credit
that
nobody
overheard
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
so
far
cooled
down
,
however
,
that
he
had
begun
to
laugh
at
the
recollection
of
these
incidents
,
when
he
heard
another
step
behind
him
,
and
turning
round
encountered
his
friend
Bevan
,
quite
out
of
breath
.
   
<EOS>
He
drew
his
arm
through
Martin
's
,
and
entreating
him
to
walk
slowly
,
was
silent
for
some
minutes
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
exonerate
me
in
another
sense
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
mean
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
acquit
me
of
intending
or
foreseeing
the
termination
of
our
visit
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
scarcely
need
ask
you
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Scarcely
indeed
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
the
more
beholden
to
you
for
your
kindness
,
when
I
find
what
kind
of
stuff
the
good
citizens
here
are
made
of
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
reckon
,
"
his
friend
returned
,
"
that
they
are
made
of
pretty
much
the
same
stuff
as
other
folks
,
if
they
would
but
own
it
,
and
not
set
up
on
false
pretences
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
good
faith
,
that
's
true
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
,
"
resumed
his
friend
,
"
you
might
have
such
a
scene
as
that
in
an
English
comedy
,
and
not
detect
any
gross
improbability
or
anomaly
in
the
matter
of
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Doubtless
it
is
more
ridiculous
here
than
anywhere
else
,
"
said
his
companion
;
"
but
our
professions
are
to
blame
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
as
I
myself
am
concerned
,
I
may
add
that
I
was
perfectly
aware
from
the
first
that
you
came
over
in
the
steerage
,
for
I
had
seen
the
list
of
passengers
,
and
knew
it
did
not
comprise
your
name
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
more
obliged
to
you
than
before
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Norris
is
a
very
good
fellow
in
his
way
,
"
observed
Mr
Bevan
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
he
?
"
said
Martin
drily
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
<EOS>
there
are
a
hundred
good
points
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
or
anybody
else
addressed
him
as
another
order
of
being
,
and
sued
to
him
IN
FORMA
PAUPERIS
,
he
would
be
all
kindness
and
consideration
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
need
n't
have
travelled
three
thousand
miles
from
home
to
find
such
a
character
as
THAT
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
he
nor
his
friend
said
anything
more
on
the
way
back
;
each
appearing
to
find
sufficient
occupation
in
his
own
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
The
tea
,
or
the
supper
,
or
whatever
else
<EOS>
they
called
the
evening
meal
,
was
over
when
they
reached
the
Major
's
;
but
the
cloth
,
ornamented
with
a
few
additional
smears
and
stains
,
was
still
upon
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
At
one
end
of
the
board
Mrs
Jefferson
Brick
and
two
other
ladies
were
drinking
tea
;
out
of
the
ordinary
course
,
evidently
,
for
they
were
bonneted
and
shawled
,
and
seemed
to
have
just
come
home
.
 
<EOS>
By
the
light
of
three
flaring
candles
of
different
lengths
,
in
as
many
candlesticks
of
different
patterns
,
the
room
showed
to
almost
as
little
advantage
as
in
broad
day
.
   
<EOS>
These
ladies
were
all
three
talking
together
in
a
very
loud
tone
when
Martin
and
his
friend
entered
;
but
seeing
those
gentlemen
,
they
stopped
directly
,
and
became
excessively
genteel
,
not
to
say
frosty
.
<EOS>
As
they
went
on
to
exchange
some
few
remarks
in
whispers
,
the
very
water
in
the
teapot
might
have
fallen
twenty
degrees
in
temperature
beneath
their
chilling
coldness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
to
meeting
,
Mrs
Brick
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Martin
's
friend
,
with
something
of
a
roguish
twinkle
in
his
eye
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
lecture
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
go
to
meeting
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
Here
the
lady
on
the
right
of
Mrs
Brick
gave
a
pious
cough
as
much
as
to
say
"
I
do
!
"
<EOS>
---
as
,
indeed
,
she
did
nearly
every
night
in
the
week
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
good
discourse
,
ma'am
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Mr
Bevan
,
addressing
this
lady
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
raised
her
eyes
in
a
pious
manner
,
and
answered
"
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
had
been
much
comforted
by
some
good
,
strong
,
peppery
doctrine
,
which
satisfactorily
disposed
of
all
her
friends
and
acquaintances
,
and
quite
settled
their
business
.
 
<EOS>
Her
bonnet
,
too
,
had
far
outshone
every
bonnet
in
the
congregation
;
so
she
was
tranquil
on
all
accounts
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
course
of
lectures
are
you
attending
now
,
ma'am
?
"
said
Martin
's
friend
,
turning
again
to
Mrs
Brick
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Philosophy
of
the
Soul
,
on
Wednesdays
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
Mondays
?
"
   
"
The
Philosophy
of
Crime
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
On
Fridays
?
"
   
"
The
Philosophy
of
Vegetables
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
forgotten
Thursdays
;
the
Philosophy
of
Government
,
my
dear
,
"
observed

third

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mrs
Brick
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
Tuesdays
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
!
"
cried
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Philosophy
of
Matter
on
Thursdays
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
our
ladies
are
fully
employed
,
"
said
Bevan
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
you
have
reason
to
say
so
,
"
answered
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Between
these
very
grave
pursuits
abroad
,
and
family
duties
at
home
,
their
time
must
be
pretty
well
engrossed
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
stopped
here
,
for
he
saw
that
the
ladies
regarded
him
with
no
very
great
favour
,
though
what
he
had
done
to
deserve
the
disdainful
expression
which
appeared
in
their
faces
<EOS>
he
was
at
a
loss
to
divine
.
<EOS>
But
on
their
going
upstairs
to
their
bedrooms
---
which
they
very
soon
did
---
Mr
Bevan
informed
him
that
domestic
drudgery
was
far
beneath
the
exalted
range
of
these
Philosophers
,
and
that
the
chances
were
a
hundred
to
one
that
not
one
of
the
three
could
perform
the
easiest
woman
's
work
for
herself
,
or
make
the
simplest
article
of
dress
for
any
of
her
children
.
   
<EOS>
"
Though
whether
they
might
not
be
better
employed
with
such
blunt
instruments
as
knitting
-
needles
than
with
these
edge
-
tools
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
another
question
;
but
I
can
answer
for
one
thing
---
they
do
n't
often
cut
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Devotions
and
lectures
are
our
balls
and
concerts
.
 
<EOS>
They
go
to
these
places
of
resort
,
as
an
escape
from
monotony
;
look
at
each
other
's
clothes
;
and
come
home
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
say
"
home
,
"
do
you
mean
a
house
like
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
often
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
see
you
are
tired
to
death
,
and
will
wish
you
good
night
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
discuss
your
projects
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
not
but
feel
already
that
it
is
useless
staying
here
,
with
any
hope
of
advancing
them
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
have
to
go
further
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
to
fare
worse
?
"
said
Martin
,
pursuing
the
old
adage
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
hope
not
.
 
<EOS>
But
sufficient
for
the
day
<EOS>
,
you
know
---
good
night
<EOS>
"
   
They
shook
hands
heartily
and
separated
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Martin
was
left
alone
,
the
excitement
of
novelty
and
change
which
had
sustained
him
through
all
the
fatigues
of
the
day
,
departed
;
and
he
felt
so
thoroughly
dejected
and
worn
out
,
that
he
even
lacked
the
energy
to
crawl
upstairs
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
In
twelve
or
fifteen
hours
,
how
great
a
change
had
fallen
on
his
hopes
and
sanguine
plans
!
 
<EOS>
New
and
strange
as
he
was
to
the
ground
on
which
he
stood
,
and
to
the
air
he
breathed
,
he
could
not
---
 
recalling
all
that
he
had
crowded
into
that
one
day
---
but
entertain
a
strong
misgiving
that
his
enterprise
was
doomed
.
 
<EOS>
Rash
and
ill
-
considered
as
it
had
often
looked
on
shipboard
,
but
had
never
seemed
on
shore
<EOS>
,
it
wore
a
dismal
aspect
,
now
,
that
frightened
him
.
<EOS>
Whatever
thoughts
he
called
up
to
his
aid
,
they
came
upon
him
in
depressing
and
discouraging
shapes
,
and
gave
him
no
relief
.
 
<EOS>
Even
the
diamonds
on
his
finger
sparkled
with
the
brightness
of
tears
,
and
had
no
ray
of
hope
in
all
their
brilliant
lustre
.
   
<EOS>
He
continued
to
sit
in
gloomy
rumination
by
the
stove
,
unmindful
of
the
boarders
who
dropped
in
one
by
one
from
their
stores
and
counting
-
houses
,
or
the
neighbouring
bar
-
rooms
,
and
,
after
taking
long
pulls
from
a
great
white
waterjug
upon
the
sideboard
,
and
lingering
with
a
kind
of
hideous
fascination
near
the
brass
spittoons
,
lounged
heavily
to
bed
;
until
at
length
Mark
Tapley
came
and
shook
him
by
the
arm
,
supposing
him
asleep
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mark
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
starting
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
sir
,
"
said
that
cheerful
follower
,
snuffing
with
his
fingers
the
candle
he
bore
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't
a
very
large
bed
,
your'n
,
sir
;
and
a
man
as
was
n't
thirsty
might
drink
,
afore
breakfast
,
all
the
water
you
've
got
to
wash
in
,
and
afterwards
eat
the
towel
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
'll
sleep
without
rocking
to
-
night
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
as
if
the
house
were
on
the
sea
"
said
Martin
,
staggering
when
he
rose
;
"
and
am
utterly
wretched
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
'm
as
jolly
as
a
sandboy
,
myself
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
Lord
,
I
have
reason
to
be
!
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
been
born
here
;
that
's
my
opinion
.
 
<EOS>
Take
care
how
you
go
"
<EOS>
---
for
they
were
now
ascending
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
recollect
the
gentleman
aboard
the
Screw
as
had
the
very
small
trunk
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
valise
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
there
's
been
a
delivery
of
clean
clothes
from
the
wash
to
-
night
,
and
they
're
put
outside
