doors
here
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
take
notice
as
we
go
up
,
what
a
very
few
shirts
there
are
,
and
what
a
many
fronts
<EOS>
,
you
'll
penetrate
the
mystery
of
his
packing
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
Martin
was
too
weary
and
despondent
to
take
heed
of
anything
,
so
had
no
interest
in
this
discovery
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
,
nothing
dashed
by
his
indifference
,
conducted
him
to
the
top
of
the
house
,
and
into
the
bed
-
chamber
prepared
for
his
reception
;
which
was
a
very
little
narrow
room
,
with
half
a
window
in
it
;
a
bedstead
like
a
chest
without
a
lid
;
two
chairs
;
<EOS>
a
piece
of
carpet
,
such
as
shoes
are
commonly
tried
upon
at
a
ready
-
made
establishment
in
England
;
a
little
looking
-
glass
nailed
against
the
wall
;
and
a
washing
-
table
,
with
a
jug
and
ewer
,
that
might
have
been
mistaken
for
a
milk
-
pot
and
slop
-
basin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
they
polish
themselves
with
a
dry
cloth
in
this
country
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
've
certainly
got
a
touch
of
the
"
phoby
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
pull
off
my
boots
for
me
,
"
said
Martin
,
dropping
into
one
of
the
chairs
<EOS>
"
I

---
<EOS>
dead

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

morrow
<EOS>
morning

;
"

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
But

---
 
and

that

.
   
<EOS>

;

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
,

"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Leaving

the

afar

,

of

,
be

this

---
a

---
as
rapidly
to
change

,
and
cross
the

to

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
18
.
<EOS>
Does
business
with
the
house
of
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
and
son
,
from
which
one
of
the
partners
retires
unexpectedly
 
Change
begets
change
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
propagates
so
fast
.
 
<EOS>
If
a
man
habituated
to
a
narrow
circle
of
cares
and
pleasures
,
out
of
which
he
seldom
travels
,
step
beyond
it
,
though
for
never
so
brief
a
space
,
his
departure
from
the
monotonous
scene
on
which
he
has
been
an
actor
of
importance
,
would
seem
to
be
the
signal
for
instant
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
As
if
,
in
the
gap
he
had
left
,
the
wedge
of
change
were
driven
to
the
head
,
rending
what
was
a
solid
mass
to
fragments
,
things
cemented
and
held
together
by
the
usages
of
years
,
burst
asunder
in
as
many
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
The
mine
which
Time
has
slowly
dug
beneath
familiar
objects
is
sprung
in
an
instant
;
and
what
was
rock
before
,
becomes
but
sand
and
dust
.
   
<EOS>
Most
men
,
at
one

or

,
have
proved
this
in
some

.
 
<EOS>
The

to

the
natural
laws
of
change
asserted
their

in
that
limited
sphere
of
action
which
Martin
had

,
shall

faithfully

down
in
these
pages
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
cold
spring
it
is
!
"
<EOS>

Anthony
,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
Possibly

,

,

,

,

,
and
drawing
the
old
man
's
arm
still
further
through
his
own
,
shook
his
trembling
fingers
towards
the
spot
where
Jonas
sat
,
as
though
he
would
wave
him
off
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Anthony
remaining
quite
still
and
silent
,
he
relaxed
his
hold
by
slow
degrees
and
lapsed
into
his
usual
niche
in
the
corner
;
merely
putting
forth
his
hand
at
intervals
and
touching
his
old
employer
gently
on
the
coat
,
as
with
the
design
of
assuring
himself
that
he
was
yet
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
was
so
very
much
amazed
by
these
proceedings
that
he
could
do
nothing
but
stare
at
the
two
old
men
,
until
Chuffey
had
fallen
into
his
usual
state
,
and
Anthony
had
sunk
into
a
doze
;
when
he
gave
some
vent
to
his
emotions
by
going
close
up
to
the
former
personage
,
and
making
as
though
he
would
,
in
vulgar
parlance
,
"
punch
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
've
been
carrying
on
this
game
,
"
thought
Jonas
in
a
brown
study
,
"
for
the
last
two
or
three
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
saw
my
father
take
so
much
notice
of
him
as
he
has
in
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
legacy
hunting
,
are
you
,
Mister
Chuff
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
Chuffey
was
as
little
conscious
of
the
thought
as
of
the
bodily
advance
of
Mr
Jonas
's
clenched
fist
,
which
hovered
fondly
about
his
ear
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
scowled
at
him
to
his
heart
's
content
,
Jonas
took
the
candle
from
the
table
,
and
walking
into
the
glass
office
,
produced
a
bunch
of
keys
from
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
With
one
of
these
he
opened
a
secret
drawer
in
the
desk
;
peeping
stealthily
out
,
as
he
did
so
,
to
be
certain
that
the
two
old
men
were
still
before
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
All
as
right
as
ever
,
"
said
Jonas
,
propping
the
lid
of
the
desk
open
with
his
forehead
,
and
unfolding
a
paper
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
will
,
Mister
Chuff
.
 
<EOS>
Thirty
pound
a
year
for
your
maintenance
,
old
boy
,
and
all
the
rest
to
his
only
son
,
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
trouble
yourself
to
be
too
affectionate
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
get
anything
by
it
.
<EOS>
What
's
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
WAS
startling
,
certainly
.
 
<EOS>
A
face
on
the
other
side
of
the
glass
partition
looking
curiously
in
;
and
not
at
him
but
at
the
paper
in
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
eyes
were
attentively
cast
down
upon
the
writing
,
and
were
swiftly
raised
when
he
cried
out
.
 
<EOS>
Then
they
met
his
own
,
and
were
as
the
eyes
of
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
Suffering
the
lid
of
the
desk
to
fall
with
a
loud
noise
,
but
not
forgetting
even
then
to
lock
it
,
Jonas
,
pale
and
breathless
,
gazed
upon
this
phantom
.
 
<EOS>
It
moved
,
opened
the
door
,
and
walked
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
,
falling
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Where
do
you
come
from
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Matter
!
"
cried
the
voice
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as
Pecksniff
in
the
flesh
smiled
amiably
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
matter
,
Mr
Jonas
!
"
   
"
What
are
you
prying
and
peering
about
here
for
?
"
said
Jonas
,
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
coming
up
to
town
in
this
way
,
and
taking
one
unawares
?
 
<EOS>
It
's
precious
odd
a
man
ca
n't
read
the
---
the
newspaper
---
in
his
own
office
without
being
startled
out
of
his
wits
by
people
coming
in
without
notice
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
you
knock
at
the
door
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
did
,
Mr
Jonas
,
"
answered
Pecksniff
,
"
but
no
one
heard
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
curious
,
"
he
added
in
his

laid
his
hand
upon
the
young

's

,
"
to
find
out
what
part
of
the
newspaper
interested
you
so
much
;
but
the
glass
was
too
dim
and
dirty
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
glanced
in
haste
at
the
partition
.
 
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
n't
very
clean
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
he
spoke
the
truth
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
it
poetry
now
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shaking
the
forefinger
of
his
right
hand
with
an
air
of
cheerful
banter
.
 
<EOS>
"
Or
was
it
politics
?
<EOS>
Or
was
it
the
price
of
stock
?
 
<EOS>
The
main
chance
,
Mr
Jonas
,
the
main
chance
,
I
suspect
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
ai
n't
far
from
the
truth
,
"
answered
Jonas
,
recovering
himself
and
snuffing
the
candle
;
"
but
how
the
deuce
do
you
come
to
be
in
London
again
?
 
<EOS>
Ecod
!
<EOS>
it
's
enough
to
make
a
man
stare
,
to
see
a
fellow
looking
at
him
all
of
a
sudden
,
who
he
thought
was
sixty
or
seventy
mile
away
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
of
it
,
my
dear
Mr
Jonas
.
<EOS>
For
while
the
human
mind
is
constituted
as
it
is
---
"
   
"
Oh
,
bother
the
human
mind
,
"
interrupted
Jonas
with
impatience
"
what
have
you
come
up
for
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
matter
of
business
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
which
has
arisen
quite
unexpectedly
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
cried
Jonas
,
"
is
that
all
?
 
<EOS>
Well
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
father
in
the
next
room
.
 
<EOS>
Hallo
father
,
here
's
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
He
gets
more
addle
-
pated
every
day
he
lives
,
I
do
believe
,
"
muttered
Jonas
,
shaking
his
honoured
parent
roundly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
I
tell
you
Pecksniff
's
here
,
stupid
-
head
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
combined
effects
of
the
shaking
and
this
loving
remonstrance
soon
awoke
the
old
man
,
who
gave
Mr
Pecksniff
a
chuckling
welcome
which
was
attributable
in
part
to
his
being
glad
to
see
that
gentleman
,
and
in
part
to
his
unfading
delight
in
the
recollection
of
having
called
him
a
hypocrite
.
 
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pecksniff
had
not
yet
taken
tea
(
indeed
he
had
,
but
an
hour
before
,
arrived
in
London
)
<EOS>
the
remains
of
the
late
collation
,
with
a
rasher
of
bacon
,
were
served
up
for
his
entertainment
;
and
as
Mr
Jonas
had
a
business
appointment
in
the
next
street
,
he
stepped
out
to
keep
it
;
promising
to
return
before
Mr
Pecksniff
could
finish
his
repast
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
my
good
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
to
Anthony
;
"
now
that
we
are
alone
,
pray
tell
me
what
I
can
do
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
alone
,
because
I
believe
that
our
dear
friend
Mr
Chuffey
is
,
metaphysically
speaking
,
a
---
shall
I
say
a
dummy
?
"
asked
Mr
Pecksniff
with
his
sweetest
smile
,
and
his
head
very
much
on
one
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
neither
hears
us
,
"
replied
Anthony
,
"
nor
sees
us
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
I
will
be
bold
to
say
,
with
the
utmost
sympathy
for
his
afflictions
,
and
the

of
those
excellent

which
do
equal
honour
to
his

and

,
that
he
is
what
is
playfully

dummy
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
going
to
observe
,
my
dear
sir
---
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
going
to
make
any
observation
that
I
know
of
,
"
replied
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
YOU
were
?
 
<EOS>
What
was
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
never
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
previously
rising
to
see
that
the
door
was
shut
,
and
arranging
his
chair
when
he
came

,
so
that
it
could
not
be
opened
in
the
least
without
his
immediately
becoming
aware
of
the

;
"
that
I
never
in
my
life
was
so
astonished
as
by
the
receipt
of
your
letter
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
That
you
should
do
me
the
honour
to
wish
to
take
counsel
with
me
on
any
matter
,
amazed
me
;
but
that
you
should
desire
to
do
so
,
to
the
exclusion
even
of
Mr
Jonas
,
showed
an
amount
of
confidence
in
one
to
whom
you
had
done
a
verbal

---
merely
a
verbal
injury
,
you
were
anxious
to
repair
---
which
gratified
,
which
moved
,
which
overcame
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
always
a
glib
speaker
,
but
he
delivered
this
short
address
very
glibly
;
having
been
at
some
pains
to
compose
it
outside
the
coach
.
   
<EOS>
Although
he
paused
for
a
reply
,
and
truly
said
that
he
was
there
at
Anthony
's
request
,
the
old
man
sat
gazing
at
him
in
profound
silence
and
with
a
perfectly
blank
face
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
seem
to
have
the
least
desire
or
impulse
to
pursue
the
conversation
,
though
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
towards
the
door
,
and
pulled
out
his
watch
,
and
gave
him
many
other
hints
that
their
time
was
short
,
and
Jonas
,
if
he
kept
his
word
,
would
soon
return
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
strangest
incident
in
all
this
strange

was
,
that
of
a
sudden
,
in
a

,
so
swiftly
that
it
was
impossible
to
trace
how
,
or
to
observe
any
process
of
change
,
his
features
fell
into
their
old

,
and
he
cried
,
striking
his

passionately
upon
the
table
as

no
interval
at
all
had
taken
place
:
   
"
<EOS>
Will
you
hold
your
tongue
,
sir
,
and
let
me
speak
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
deferred
to
him
with
a
submissive
bow
;
and
said
within
himself
,
"
I
knew
his
hand
was
changed
,
and
that
his
writing
staggered
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
so
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
Ahem
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jonas
is
sweet
upon
your
daughter
,
Pecksniff
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
in
his
usual
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
spoke
of
that
,
if
you
remember
,
sir
,
at
Mrs
Todgers
's
,
"
replied
the
courteous

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
speak
so
loud
,
"
retorted
Anthony
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
so
deaf
as
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
certainly
raised
his
voice
pretty
high
;
not
so
much
because
he
thought
Anthony
was
deaf
,
as
because
he
felt
convinced
that
his
perceptive

were
waxing
dim
;
but
this
quick
resentment
of
his
considerate
behaviour
greatly
disconcerted
him
,
and
,
not
knowing
what
tack
to
shape

course
upon
,
he
made
another
inclination
of
the
head
,
yet
more
submissive
that
the
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
,
"
repeated
the
old
man
,
"
that
Jonas
is
sweet
upon
your
daughter
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
charming
girl
,
sir
,
"
murmured
Mr
Pecksniff
,
seeing
that
he
waited
for
an
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
dear
girl
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
though
I
say
it
,
who
should
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
better
,
"
cried
the
old
man
,
advancing
his
weazen
face
at
least
a
yard
,
and
starting
forward
in
his
chair
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
lie
!
 
<EOS>
What
,
you
WILL
be
a
hypocrite
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
sir
,
"
Mr
Pecksniff
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
call
me
a
good
sir
,
"
retorted
Anthony
,
"
and
do
n't
claim
to
be
one
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
If
your
daughter
was
what
you
would
have
me
believe
,
she
would
n't
do
for
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
Being
what
she
is
,
I
think
she
will
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
be
deceived
in
a
wife
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
run
riot
,
contract
debts
,
and
waste
his
substance
.
 
<EOS>
Now
when
I
am
dead
---
"
   
His
face
altered
so
horribly
as
he
said
the
word
,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
really
was
fain
to
look
another
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
It
will
be
worse
for
me
to
know
of
such
doings
,
than
if
I
was
alive
;
for
to
be
tormented
for
getting
that
together
,
which
even
while
I
suffer
for
its
acquisition
,
is
flung
into
the
very
kennels
of
the
streets
,
would
be
insupportable
torture
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
"
said
<EOS>
the
old
man
,
hoarsely
,
"
let
that
be
saved
at
least
;
let
there
be
something
gained
,
and
kept
fast
hold
of
,
when
so
much
is
lost
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
"
these
are
unwholesome
fancies
;
quite
unnecessary
,
sir
,
quite
uncalled
for
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
The
truth
is
,
my
dear
sir
,
that
you
are
not
well
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
dying
though
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Anthony
,
with
something
like
the
snarl
of
a
wild
animal
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
!
 
<EOS>
There
are
years
of
life
in
me
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
look
at
him
,
"
pointing
to
his
feeble
clerk
.
 
<EOS>
"
Death
has
no
right
to
leave
him
standing
,
and
to
mow
me
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
so
much
afraid
of
the
old
man
,
and
so
completely
taken
aback
by
the
state
in
which
he
found
him
,
that
he
had
not
even
presence
of
mind
enough
to
call
up
a
scrap
of
morality
from
the
great
storehouse
within
his
own
breast
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
he
stammered
out
that
no
doubt
it
was
,
in
fairness
and
decency
,
Mr
Chuffey
's
turn
to
expire
;
and
that
from
all
he
had
heard
of
Mr
Chuffey
,
and
the
little
he
had
the
pleasure
of
knowing
of
that
gentleman
,
personally
,
he
felt
convinced
in
his
own
mind
that
he
would
see
the
propriety
of
expiring
with
as
little
delay
as
possible
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
here
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
old
man
,
beckoning
him
to
draw
nearer
.
 
<EOS>
"
Jonas
will
be
my
heir
,
Jonas
will
be
rich
,
and
a
great
catch
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
is
sweet
upon
your
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
too
,
"
thought
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
for
you
have
said
it
often
enough
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
might
get
more
money
than
with
her
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
but
she
will
help
him
to
take
care
of
what
they
have
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
not
too
young
or
heedless
,
and
comes
of
a
good
hard
griping
stock
.
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
you
play
too
fine
a
game
.
 
<EOS>
She
only
holds
him
by
a
thread
;
and
if
you
draw
it
too
tight
<EOS>
(
I
know
his
temper
)
<EOS>
it
'll
snap
.
 
<EOS>
Bind
him
when
he
's
in
the
mood
,
Pecksniff
;
bind
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
too
deep
.
 
<EOS>
In
your
way
of
leading
him
on
,
you
'll
leave
him
miles
behind
.
 
<EOS>
Bah
,
you
man
of
oil
,
have
I
no
eyes
to
see
how
you
have
angled
with
him
from
the
first
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
wonder
,
"
thought
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
at
him
with
a
wistful
face
,
"
whether
this
is
all
he
has
to
say
?
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Anthony
rubbed
his
hands
and
muttered
to
himself
;
complained
again
that
he
was
cold
;
drew
his
chair
before
the
fire
;
and
,
sitting
with
his
back
to
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
his
chin
sunk
down
upon
his
breast
,
was
,
in
another
minute
,
quite
regardless
or
forgetful
of
his
presence
.
   
<EOS>
Uncouth
and
unsatisfactory
as
this
short
interview
had
been
<EOS>
,
it
had
furnished
Mr
Pecksniff
with
a
hint
which
,
supposing
nothing
further
were
imparted
to
him
,
repaid
the
journey
up
and
home
again
.
 
<EOS>
For
the
good
gentleman
had
never
(
for
want
of
an
opportunity
)
dived
into
the
depths
of
Mr
Jonas
's
nature
;
and
any
recipe
for
catching
such
a
son
-
in
-
law
(
much
more
one
written
on
a
leaf
out
of
his
own
father
's
book
)
was
worth
the
having
.
 
<EOS>
In
order
that
he
might
lose
no
chance
of
improving
so
fair
an
opportunity
by
allowing
Anthony
to
fall
asleep
before
he
had
finished
all
he
had
to
say
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
the
disposal
of
the
refreshments
on
the
table
,
a
work
to
which
he
now
applied
himself
in
earnest
,
resorted
to
many
ingenious
contrivances
for
attracting
his
attention
;
such
as
coughing
,
sneezing
,
clattering
the
teacups
,
sharpening
the
knives
,
dropping
the
loaf
,
and
so
forth
.
 
<EOS>
But
all
in
vain
,
for
Mr
Jonas
returned
,
and
Anthony
had
said
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
My
father
asleep
again
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
as
he
hung
up
his
hat
,
and
cast
a
look
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
and
snoring
.
 
<EOS>
Only
hear
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
snores
very
deep
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Snores
deep
?
"
repeated
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
let
him
alone
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
snore
for
six
,
at
any
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
,
Mr
Jonas
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
"
that
I
think
your
father
is
---
do
n't
let
me
alarm
you
---
breaking
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
is
he
though
?
"
<EOS>
replied
Jonas
,
with
a
shake
of
the
head
which
expressed
the
closeness
of
his
dutiful
observation
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,
you
do
n't
know
how
tough
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
He
ai
n't
upon
the
move
yet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
struck
me
that
he
was
changed
,
both
in
his
appearance
and
manner
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
you
know
about
it
,
"
returned
Jonas
,
seating
himself
with
a
melancholy
air
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
never
was
better
than
he
is
now
.
 
<EOS>
How
are
they
all
at
home
?
 
<EOS>
How
's
Charity
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Blooming
,
Mr
Jonas
,
blooming
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
the
other
one
;
how
's
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Volatile
trifler
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
fondly
musing
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
is
well
,
she
is
well
.
 
<EOS>
Roving
from
parlour
to
bedroom
,
Mr
Jonas
,
like
a
bee
,
skimming
from
post
to
pillar
,
like
the
butterfly
;
<EOS>
dipping
her
young
beak
into
our
currant
wine
,
like
the
humming
-
bird
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
were
she
a
little
less
giddy
than
she
is
;
and
had
she
but
the
sterling
qualities
of
Cherry
,
my
young
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
she
so
very
giddy
,
then
?
"
asked
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
great
feeling
;
"
let
me
not
be
hard
upon
my
child
.
 
<EOS>
Beside
her
sister
Cherry
<EOS>
she
appears
so
.
 
<EOS>
A
strange
noise
that
,
Mr
Jonas
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Something
wrong
in
the
clock
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Jonas
,
glancing
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
the
other
one
ai
n't
your
favourite
,
ai
n't
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
fond
father
was
about
to
reply
,
and
had
already
summoned
into
his
face
a
look
of
most
intense
sensibility
,
when
the
sound
he
had
already
noticed
was
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
Mr
Jonas
,
that
is
a
very
extraordinary
clock
,
"
said
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
,
if
it
had
made
the
noise
which
startled
them
;
but
another
kind
of
time
-
piece
was
fast
running
down
,
and
from
that
the
sound
proceeded
.
 
<EOS>
A
scream
from
Chuffey
,
rendered
a
hundred
times
more
loud
and
formidable
by
his
silent
habits
,
made
the
house
ring
from
roof
to
cellar
;
and
,
looking
round
,
they
saw
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
extended
on
the
floor
,
with
the
old
clerk
upon
his
knees
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
fallen
from
his
chair
in
a
fit
,
and
lay
there
,
battling
for
each
gasp
of
breath
,
with
every
shrivelled
vein
and
sinew
starting
in
its
place
,
as
if
it
were
bent
on
bearing
witness
to
his
age
,
and
sternly
pleading
with
Nature
against
his
recovery
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
frightful
to
see
how
the
principle
of
life
,
shut
up
within
his
withered
frame
,
fought
like
a
strong
devil
,
mad
to
be
released
,
and
rent
its
ancient
prison
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
A
young
man
in
the
fullness
of
his
vigour
,
struggling
with
so
much
strength
of
desperation
,
would
have
been
a
dismal
sight
;
but
an
old
,
old
,
shrunken
body
,
endowed
with
preternatural
might
,
and
giving
the
lie
in
every
motion
of
its
every
limb
and
joint
to
its
enfeebled
aspect
,
was
a
hideous
spectacle
indeed
.
   
<EOS>
They
raised
him
up
,
and
fetched
a
surgeon
with
all
haste
,
who
bled
the
patient
and
applied
some
remedies
;
but
the
fits
held
him
so
long
that
it
was
past
midnight
when
they
got
him
---
quiet
now
,
but
quite
unconscious
and
exhausted
---
into
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
,
"
said
Jonas
,
putting
his
ashy
lips
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
ear
and
whispered
across
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
mercy
you
were
present
when
he
was
taken
ill
.
 
<EOS>
Some
one
might
have
said
it
was
my
doing
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
YOUR
doing
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
but
they
might
,
"
he
replied
,
wiping
the
moisture
from
his
white
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
People
say
such
things
.
 
<EOS>
How
does
he
look
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
used
to
joke
,
you
know
,
"
said
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
:
"
<EOS>
but
I
---
<EOS>
I
never
wished
him
dead
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
he
's
very
bad
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
doctor
said
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
You
heard
,
"
was
Mr
Pecksniff
's
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
but
he
might
say
that
to
charge
us
more
,
in
case
of
his
getting
well
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
go
away
,
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Now
it
's
come
to
this
,
I
would
n't
be
without
a
witness
for
a
thousand
pound
.
"
   
<EOS>
Chuffey
said
not
a
word
,
and
heard
not
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
sat
himself
down
in
a
chair
at
the
bedside
,
and
there
he
remained
,
motionless
;
except
that
he
sometimes
bent
his
head
over
the
pillow
,
and
seemed
to
listen
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
changed
in
this
.
 
<EOS>
Though
once
in
the
dreary
night
Mr
Pecksniff
,
having
dozed
,
awoke
with
a
confused
impression
that
he
had
heard
him
praying
,
and
strangely
mingling
figures
---
not
of
speech
,
but
arithmetic
---
with
his
broken
prayers
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
sat
there
,
too
,
all
night
;
not
where
his
father
could
have
seen
him
,
had
his
consciousness
returned
,
but
<EOS>
hiding
,
as
it
were
,
behind
him
,
and
only
reading
how
he
looked
,
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
eyes
.
<EOS>
HE
,
the
coarse
upstart
,
who
had
ruled
the
house
so
long
---
that
craven
cur
,
who
was
afraid
to
move
,
and
shook
so
,
that
his
very
shadow
fluttered
on
the
wall
!
   
<EOS>
It
was
broad
,
bright
,
stirring
day
when
,
leaving
the
old
clerk
to
watch
him
,
they
went
down
to
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
People
hurried
up
and
down
the
street
;
windows
and
doors
were
opened
;
thieves
and
beggars
took
their
usual
posts
;
workmen
bestirred
themselves
;
tradesmen
set
forth
their
shops
;
bailiffs
and
constables
were
on
the
watch
;
all
kinds
of
human
creatures
strove
,
in
their
several
ways
,
as
hard
to
live
,
as
the
one
sick
old
man
who
combated
for
every
grain
of
sand
in
his
fast
-
emptying
glass
,
as
eagerly
as
if
it
were
an
empire
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
anything
happens
Pecksniff
,
"
said
Jonas
,
"
you
must
promise
me
to
stop
here
till
it
's
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
see
that
I
do
what
's
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
you
will
do
what
's
right
,
Mr
Jonas
,
"
said
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
yes
,
<EOS>
but
I
wo
n't
be
doubted
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
shall
have
it
in
his
power
to
say
a
syllable
against
me
,
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
how
people
will
talk
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
if
he
was
n't
old
,
or
I
had
the
secret
of
keeping
him
alive
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
promised
that
he
would
remain
,
if
circumstances
should
render
it
,
in
his
esteemed
friend
's
opinion
,
desirable
;
they
were
finishing
their
meal
in
silence
,
when
suddenly
an
apparition
stood
before
them
,
so
ghastly
to
the
view
that
Jonas
shrieked
aloud
,
and
both
recoiled
in
horror
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Anthony
,
dressed
in
his
usual
clothes
,
was
in
the
room
---
beside
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
leaned
upon
the
shoulder
of
his
solitary
friend
;
and
on
his
livid
face
,
and
on
his
horny
hands
,
and
in
his
glassy
eyes
,
and
traced
by
an
eternal
finger
in
the
very
drops
of
sweat
upon
his
brow
,
was
one
word
---
Death
.
   
<EOS>
He
spoke
to
them
---
in
something
of
his
own
voice
too
,
but
sharpened
and
made
hollow
,
like
a
dead
man
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
What
he
would
have
said
,
God
knows
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
utter
words
,
but
they
were
such
as
man
had
never
heard
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
most
fearful
circumstance
of
all
,
to
see
him
standing
there
,
gabbling
in
an
unearthly
tongue
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
better
now
,
"
said
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Better
now
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
sit
in
his
old
chair
,
and
he
'll
be
well
again
.
 
<EOS>
I
told
him
not
to
mind
.
 
<EOS>
I
said
so
,
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
They
put
him
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
and
wheeled
it
near
the
window
;
then
<EOS>
,
swinging
open
the
door
,
exposed
him
to
the
free
current
of
morning
air
.
 
<EOS>
But
not
all
the
air
that
is
,
nor
all
the
winds
that
ever
blew
'
twixt
Heaven
and
Earth
,
could
have
brought
new
life
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
Plunge
him
to
the
throat
in
golden
pieces
now
,
and
his
heavy
fingers
shall
not
close
on
one
!
    
Chapter
19
.
<EOS>
The
reader
is
brought
into
communication
with
some
professional
persons
,
and
sheds
a
tear
over
the
filail
piety
of
good
Mr
Jonas
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
in
a
hackney
cabriolet
,
for
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
had
said
"
Spare
no
expense
.
"
 
<EOS>
Mankind
is
evil
in
its
thoughts
and
in
its
base
constructions
,
and
Jonas
was
resolved
it
should
not
have
an
inch
to
stretch
into
an
ell
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
never
should
be
charged
upon
his
father
's
son
that
he
had
grudged
the
money
for
his
father
's
funeral
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
,
until
the
obsequies
should
be
concluded
,
Jonas
had
taken
for
his
motto
"
Spend
,
and
spare
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
been
to
the
undertaker
,
and
was
now
upon
his
way
to
another
officer
in
the
train
of
mourning
---
a
female
functionary
,
a
nurse
,
and
watcher
,
and
performer
of
nameless
offices
about
the
persons
of
the
dead
---
whom
he
had
recommended
.
 
<EOS>
Her
name
,
as
Mr
Pecksniff
gathered
from
a
scrap
of
writing
in
his
hand
,
was
Gamp
;
her
residence
in
Kingsgate
Street
,
High
Holborn
.
 
<EOS>
So
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
a
hackney
cab
,
was
rattling
over
Holborn
stones
,
in
quest
of
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
This
lady
lodged
at
a
bird
-
fancier
's
,
next
door
but
one
to
the
celebrated
mutton
-
pie
shop
,
and
directly
opposite
to
the
original
cat's
-
meat
warehouse
;
the
renown
of
which
establishments
was
duly
heralded
on
their
respective
fronts
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
house
,
and
this
was
the
more
convenient
;
for
Mrs
Gamp
being
,
in
her
highest
walk
of
art
,
a
monthly
nurse
,
or
,
as
her
sign
-
board
boldly
had
it
,
"
Midwife
,
"
and
lodging
in
the
first
-
floor
front
,
was
easily
assailable
at
night
by
pebbles
,
walking
-
sticks
,
and
fragments
of
tobacco
-
pipe
;
all
much
more
efficacious
than
the
street
-
door
knocker
,
which
was
so
constructed
as
to
wake
the
street
with
ease
,
and
even
spread
alarms
of
fire
in
Holborn
,
without
making
the
smallest
impression
on
the
premises
to
which
it
was
addressed
.
   
<EOS>
It
chanced
on
this
particular
occasion
,
that
Mrs
Gamp
had
been
up
all
the
previous
night
,
in
attendance
upon
a
ceremony
to
which
the
usage
of
gossips
has
given
that
name
which
expresses
,
in
two
syllables
,
the
curse
pronounced
on
Adam
.
 
<EOS>
It
chanced
that
Mrs
Gamp
had
not
been
regularly
engaged
,
but
had
been
called
in
at
a
crisis
,
in
consequence
of
her
great
repute
,
to
assist
another
professional
lady
with
her
advice
;
and
thus
it
happened
that
,
all
points
of
interest
in
the
case
being
over
,
Mrs
Gamp
had
come
home
again
to
the
bird
-
fancier
's
and
gone
to
bed
.
 
<EOS>
So
when
Mr
Pecksniff
drove
up
in
the
hackney
cab
,
Mrs
Gamp
's
curtains
were
drawn
close
,
and
Mrs
Gamp
was
fast
asleep
behind
them
.
   
<EOS>
If
the
bird
-
fancier
had
been
at
home
,
as
he
ought
to
have
been
,
there
would
have
been
no
great
harm
in
this
;
but
he
was
out
,
and
his
shop
was
closed
.
 
<EOS>
The
shutters
were
down
certainly
;
and
in
every
pane
of
glass
there
was
at
least
one
tiny
bird
in
a
tiny
bird
-
cage
,
twittering
and
hopping
his
little
ballet
of
despair
,
and
knocking
his
head
against
the
roof
;
while
one
unhappy
goldfinch
who
lived
outside
a
red
villa
with
his
name
on
the
door
,
drew
the
water
for
his
own
drinking
,
and
mutely
appealed
to
some
good
man
to
drop
a
farthing's
-
worth
of
poison
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
the
door
was
shut
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
tried
the
latch
,
and
shook
it
,
causing
a
cracked
bell
inside
to
ring
most
mournfully
;
but
no
one
came
.
 
<EOS>
The
bird
-
fancier
was
an
easy
shaver
also
,
and
a
fashionable
hair
-
dresser
also
,
and
perhaps
he
had
been
sent
for
,
express
,
from
the
court
end
of
the
town
,
to
trim
a
lord
,
or
cut
and

a
lady
;
but
however
that
might
be
,
there
,
upon
his
own

,
he
was
not
;
nor
was

any
more

trace
of
him
to

the
imagination
of
an
inquirer
,
than
a
professional
print
or
emblem
of
his
calling
(
much
favoured
in
the
trade
)
,
representing
a
hair
-

of
easy
manners
curling
a
lady
of

fashion
,
in
the

of
a
patent

grand

.
   
<EOS>
Noting
these

,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
the
innocence
of
his
heart
,
applied
himself
to
the
knocker
;
but
at
the

knock
every
window
in
the
street
became

with
female

;
and
before

could
repeat
the
performance
whole

of
married

(
some
about
to
trouble
Mrs
Gamp
themselves
very

)
<EOS>
came

round

steps
,
all

one

,
and
with
uncommon

,
"
Knock
at
the
winder
,

,

the

.
<EOS>
Lord

,
do
n't

time
than
you

---
knock
at
the
winder
!
"
   
<EOS>
Acting

,

Pecksniff

the
first

Gamp
,
whose

---

---

"
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's

,
"

<EOS>
"
So

,

's
the

,
"

<EOS>
A

(

)

for

Mrs
Gamp
,

HER
.
   
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs

,
for
,

<EOS>
,

,

"
Is

Perkins
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
A

;

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As

,

had
a
face

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

took
it

ill
that
Mr

's

;
and
the

rated

in

,

meant

"
with

;
"
and
giving

her

that
he
was
quite

.
 
<EOS>
The

were
not
at

behind

;
and

,
of

now

,

Mr
Pecksniff
quite

.
 
<EOS>
So

Mrs
Gamp
appeared
,
the
unoffending

was
glad
to
hustle
her
with
very
little

into
the
cabriolet
,
and
drive

,
overwhelmed
with
popular
execration
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
had
a
large
bundle
with
her
,
a
pair
of
pattens
,
and
a
species
of
gig
umbrella
;
the
latter
article
in
colour
like
a
faded
leaf
,
except
where
a
circular
patch
of
a
lively
blue
had
been
dexterously
let
in
at
the
top
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
much
flurried
by
the
haste
she
had
made
,
and
laboured
under
the
most
erroneous
views
of
cabriolets
,
which
she
appeared
to
confound
with
mail
-
coaches
or
stage
-
wagons
,
inasmuch
as
she
was
constantly
endeavouring
for
the
first
half
mile
to
force
her
luggage
through
the
little
front
window
,
and
clamouring
to
the
driver
to
"
put
it
in
the
boot
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
When
she
was
disabused
of
this
idea
,
her
whole
being
resolved
itself
into
an
absorbing
anxiety
about
her
pattens
,
with
which
she
played
innumerable
games
at
quoits
on
Mr
Pecksniff
's
legs
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
they
were
close
upon
the
house
of
mourning
that
she
had
enough
composure
to
observe
---
    
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
the
gentleman
's
dead
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
The
more
's
the
pity
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
did
n't
even
know
his
name
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
what
we
must
all
come
to
.
<EOS>
It
's
as
certain
as
being
born
,
except
that
we
ca
n't
make
our
calculations
as
exact
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
a
fat
old
woman
,
this
Mrs
Gamp
,
with
a
husky
voice
and
a
moist
eye
,
which
she
had
a
remarkable
power
of
turning
up
,
and
only
showing
the
white
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Having
very
little
neck
,
it
cost
her
some
trouble
to
look
over
herself
,
if
one
may
say
so
,
at
those
to
whom
she
talked
.
 
<EOS>
She
wore
a
very
rusty
black
gown
,
rather
the
worse
for
snuff
,
and
a
shawl
and
bonnet
to
correspond
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
dilapidated
articles
of
dress
she
had
,
on
principle
,
arrayed
herself
,
time
out
of
mind
,
on
such
occasions
as
the
present
;
for
this
at
once
expressed
a
decent
amount
of
veneration
for
the
deceased
,
and
invited
the
next
of
kin
to
present
her
with
a
fresher
suit
of
weeds
;
an
appeal
so
frequently
successful
,
that
the
very
fetch
and
ghost
of
Mrs
Gamp
,
bonnet
and
all
,
might
be
seen
hanging
up
,
any

day
,
in

dozen
of

second

hand

about
Holborn
.
 
<EOS>
The
face
of
Mrs
Gamp
---
the
nose
in
particular
---
was
somewhat
red
and
swollen
,
and
it
was
difficult
to
enjoy
her
society
without
becoming
conscious
of
a
smell
of
spirits
.
 
<EOS>
Like
most
persons
who
have
attained
to
great
eminence
in
their
profession
,
she
took
to
hers
very
kindly
;
insomuch
that
,
setting
aside
her
natural
predilections
as
a
woman
,
she
went
to
a
lying
-
in
or
a
laying
-

with
equal
zest
and
relish
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
repeated
Mrs
Gamp
;
for
it
was
always
a
safe
sentiment
in
cases
of
mourning
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
dear
!
 
<EOS>
When
Gamp
was
summoned
to
his
long
home
,
and
I
see

a
-

Guy
's

,
and
his

under

arm
<EOS>
,
I
thought
I
should
have

.
 
<EOS>
But
I
bore
up
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
certain

current
in
the
Kingsgate
Street
circles
had
any

,
she
had
indeed
borne
up
surprisingly
;
and
had
exerted
such
uncommon

as
to
dispose
of
Mr
Gamp
's
remains
for
the

of
science
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
should
be
added
,
in

,
that
this
had
happened
twenty
years
before
;
and
that
Mr
and
Mrs
Gamp
had
long
been
separated
on
the
ground
of

of

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
become
indifferent
since
then
,
I

?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Use
is
second
nature
,
Mrs
Gamp
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
well
say
second
nater
,
sir
,
"
returned
that

.
 
<EOS>
"
One
's
first
ways
is
to
find
sich
things
a
trial
to
the
feelings
,
and
so
is

's

.
 
<EOS>
If

was
n't
for
the
nerve
a
little
sip

gives
me
(
I
never
was

to
do

)
,
I
never
could

through

I

.
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Harris
,
"
I

,

as

,

,
"
Mrs
Harris
<EOS>
,
"
I

,
"
leave

,

,
but

to

I
am
so
dispoged
,
and
then
I
will
do
what
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Gamp
,
"
she

,

"

be

,

---
 
<EOS>
night

,
"
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
with
emphasis
,
"
"

extra

---
you
are
that
inwallable
person
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Harris
,
"
I

,
"
do

,

,

,
sich

.
 
<EOS>

,
Mrs
Harris
"
"
---
here

---
"
"

,
is
,

wo

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
The
conclusion
of
this
affecting
narrative
brought

to

house
.
 
<EOS>
In

they
encountered
Mr
Mould
the
undertaker
;
a

,

,
and
in

;
with

was

;
so
that

as

man

might
,
who
,
in

choice

,
tried

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Mrs
Gamp
,

,
Mrs
Gamp
?
<EOS>
"

this

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pretty
well
,
I

,

,
"
dropping

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll

,
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
This

,

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
There

NO

"

<EOS>
I

;

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
In

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

<EOS>
"
I

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
But

;

;

<EOS>

Ah
!

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
as

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs

;

,

,

to

,

,
from

.
   
<EOS>
He
found
that
example
to

,

,

<EOS>

,

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

"

their

,

,

Spies

.
"
   
<EOS>

,

,

,

"
<EOS>
It

,

,

;
particular

-

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Some

,
"

,

,

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Them

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"

,
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Whatever

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Three
score
and
ten
,
"
said
Chuffey
,
"
ought
and
carry
seven
.
 
<EOS>
Some
men
are
so
strong
that
they
live
to
four
score
<EOS>
---
four

's
an
ought
,
four

two
's
an

---
eighty
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
why
---
why
---
why
did
n't
he
live
to
four
times
ought
's
an
ought
,
and
four
times
two
's
an
eight
,
eighty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
a
wale
of

!
"
cried
Mrs
Gamp
,
possessing

of

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
did
he
die
before
his
poor
old
crazy

?
"
said
Chuffey
,
clasping

hands
and
looking
up

.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
him
from
me
,
and
what

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jonas
,
"
returned
Pecksniff
,
"
Mr
Jonas
,
my
good
friend
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
loved
him
,
"
cried

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
good
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
We
learnt
Tare
and
Tret
together
at
school
.
 
<EOS>
I
took
him
down
once
,
six
boys
in
the
arithmetic

.
 
<EOS>
God
forgive
me
!
 
<EOS>
Had
I
the
heart
to
take
him
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Mr
Chuffey
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Summon
up

,
Mr
Chuffey
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
will
,
"
returned
the
old
clerk
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
sum
up
my
forty
 
<EOS>
---
How
many
times
forty
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
Chuzzlewit
and
Son
---
Your
own
son
Mr
Chuzzlewit
;
your
own
son
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
yielded
to
the
hand
that
guided
him
,
as
he
lapsed
into
this
familiar
expression
,
and
submitted
to
be
led
away
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
,
with
the
bottle
on
one
knee
,
and
the
glass
on
the
other
,
sat
upon
a
stool
,
shaking
her
head
for
a
long
time
,
until
,
in
a
moment
of
abstraction
,
she
poured
out
a
dram
of
spirits
,
and
raised
it
to
her
lips
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
succeeded
by
a
second
,
and
by
a
third
,
and
then
her
eyes
---
either
in
the
sadness
of
her
reflections
upon
life
and
death
,
or
in
her
admiration
of
the
liquor
---
were
so
turned
up
,
as
to
be
quite
invisible
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
shook
her
head
still
.
   
<EOS>
Poor
Chuffey
was
conducted
to
his
accustomed
corner
,
and
there
he
remained
,
silent
and
quiet
,
save
at
long
intervals
,
when
he
would
rise
,
and
walk
about
the
room
,
and
wring
his
hands
,
or
raise
some
strange
and
sudden
cry
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
whole
week
they
all
three
sat
about
the
hearth
and
never
stirred
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
would
have
walked
out
in
the
evening
time
,
but
Mr
Jonas
was
so
averse
to
his
being
absent
for
a
minute
,
that
he
abandoned
the
idea
,
and
so
,
from
morning
until
night
,
they
brooded
together
in
the
dark
room
,
without
relief
or
occupation
.
   
<EOS>
The
weight
of
that
which
was
stretched
out
,
stiff
and
stark
,
in
the
awful
chamber
above
-
stairs
,
so
crushed
and
bore
down
Jonas
,
that
he
bent
beneath
the
load
.
 
<EOS>
During
the
whole
long
seven
days
and
nights
,
he
was
always
oppressed
and
haunted
by
a
dreadful
sense
of
its
presence
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
Did
the
door
move
,
he
looked
towards
it
with
a
livid
face
and
starting
eye
,
as
if
he
fully
believed
that
ghostly
fingers
clutched
the
handle
.
 
<EOS>
Did
the
fire
fiicker
in
a
draught
of
air
,
he
glanced
over
his
shoulder
,
as
almost
dreading
to
behold
some
shrouded
figure
fanning
and
flapping
at
it
with
its
fearful
dress
.
<EOS>
The
lightest
noise
disturbed
him
;
and
once
,
in
the
night
,
at
the
sound
of
a
footstep
overhead
,
he
cried
out
that
the
dead
man
was
walking
---
tramp
,
tramp
,
tramp
---
about
his
coffin
.
   
<EOS>
He
lay
at
night
upon
a
mattress
on
the
floor
of
the
sitting
-
room
;
his
own
chamber
having
been
assigned
to
Mrs
Gamp
;
and
Mr
Pecksniff
was
similarly
accommodated
.
 
<EOS>
The
howling
of
a
dog
before
the
house
,
filled
him
with
a
terror
he
could
not
disguise
.
 
<EOS>
He
avoided
the
reflection
in
the
opposite
windows
of
the
light
that
burned
above
,
as
though
it
had
been
an
angry
eye
.
 
<EOS>
He
often
,
in
every
night
,
rose
up
from
his
fitful
sleep
,
and
looked
and
longed
for
dawn
;
all
directions
and
arrangements
,
even
to
the
ordering
of
their
daily
meals
,
he
abandoned
to
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
That
excellent
gentleman
,
deeming
that
the
mourner
wanted
comfort
,
and
that
high
feeding
was
likely
to
do
him
infinite
service
,
availed
himself
of
these
opportunities
to
such
good
purpose
,
that
they
kept
quite
a
dainty
table
during
this
melancholy
season
;
with
sweetbreads
,
stewed
kidneys
,
oysters
,
and
other
such
light
viands
for
supper
every
night
;
over
which
,
and
sundry
jorums
of
hot
punch
,
Mr
Pecksniff
delivered
such
moral
reflections
and
spiritual
consolation
as
might
have
converted
a
Heathen
---
especially
if
he
had
had
but
an
imperfect
acquaintance
with
the
English
tongue
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
did
Mr
Pecksniff
alone
indulge
in
the
creature
comforts
during
this
sad
time
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
proved
to
be
very
choice
in
her
eating
,
and
repudiated
hashed
mutton
with
scorn
.
 
<EOS>
In
her
drinking
too
,
she
was
very
punctual
and
particular
,
requiring
a
pint
of
mild
porter
at
lunch
,
a
pint
at
dinner
,
half
-
a
-
pint
as
a
species
of
stay
or
holdfast
between
dinner
and
tea
,
and
a
pint
of
the
celebrated
staggering
ale
,
or
Real
Old
Brighton
Tipper
,
at
supper
;
besides
the
bottle
on
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
such
casual
invitations
to
refresh
herself
with
wine
as
the
good
breeding
of
her
employers
might
prompt
them
to
offer
.
 
<EOS>
In
like
manner
,
Mr
Mould
's
men
found
it
necessary
to
drown
their
grief
,
like
a
young
kitten
in
the
morning
of
its
existence
,
for
which
reason
they
generally
fuddled
themselves
before
they
began
to
do
anything
,
lest
it
should
make
head
and
get
the
better
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
whole
of
that
strange
week
was
a
round
of
dismal
joviality
and
grim
enjoyment
;
and
every
one
,
except
poor
Chuffey
,
who
came
within
the
shadow
of
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
's
grave
,
feasted
like
a
Ghoul
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
the
day
of
the
funeral
,
pious
and
truthful
ceremony
that
it
was
,
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Mould
,
with
a
glass
of
generous
port
between
his
eye
and
the
light
,
leaned
against
the
desk
in
the
little
glass
office
with
his
gold
watch
in
his
unoccupied
hand
,
and
conversed
with
Mrs
Gamp
;
two
mutes
were
at
the
house
-
door
,
looking
as
mournful
as
could
be
reasonably
expected
of
men
with
such
a
thriving
job
in
hand
;
the
whole
of
Mr
Mould
's
establishment
were
on
duty
within
the
house
or
without
;
feathers
waved
,
horses
snorted
,
silk
and
velvets
fluttered
;
in
a
word
,
as
Mr
Mould
emphatically
said
,
"
Everything
that
money
could
do
was
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
can
do
more
,
Mrs
Gamp
?
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
the
undertaker
as
he
emptied
his
glass
and
smacked
his
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
in
the
world
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
in
the
world
,
"
repeated
Mr
Mould
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
right
,
Mrs
.
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
people
spend
more
money
"
---
here
he
filled
his
glass
again
---
"
upon
a
death
,
Mrs
Gamp
,
than
upon
a
birth
?
 
<EOS>
Come
,
that
's
in
your
way
;
you
ought
to
know
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
account
for
that
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
is
because
an
undertaker
's
charges
comes
dearer
than
a
nurse
's
charges
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
tittering
,
and
smoothing
down
her
new
black
dress
with
her
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
"
laughed
Mr
Mould
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
breakfasting
at
somebody
's
expense
this
morning
,
Mrs
Gamp
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
seeing
,
by
the
aid
of
a
little
shaving
-
glass
which
hung
opposite
,
that
he
looked
merry
,
he
composed
his
features
and
became
sorrowful
.
   
<EOS>
"
Many
's
the
time
that
I
've
not
breakfasted
at
my
own
expense
along
of
your
recommending
,
sir
;
and
many
's
the
time
I
hope
to
do
the
same
in
time
to
come
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
with
an
apologetic
curtsey
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
be
it
,
"
replied
Mr
Mould
,
"
please
Providence
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
Mrs
Gamp
;
I
'll
tell
you
why
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
because
the
laying
out
of
money
with
a
well
-
conducted
establishment
,
where
the
thing
is
performed
upon
the
very
best
scale
,
binds
the
broken
heart
,
and
sheds
balm
upon
the
wounded
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
Hearts
want
binding
,
and
spirits
want
balming
when
people
die
;
not
when
people
are
born
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
this
gentleman
to
-
day
;
look
at
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
An
open
-
handed
gentleman
?
"
cried
Mrs
Gamp
,
with
enthusiasm
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
the
undertaker
;
"
not
an
open
-
handed
gentleman
in
general
,
by
any
means
.
 
<EOS>
There
you
mistake
him
;
but
an
afflicted
gentleman
,
an
affectionate
gentleman
,
who
knows
what
it
is
in
the
power
of
money
to
do
,
in
giving
him
relief
,
and
in
testifying
his
love
and
veneration
for
the
departed
.
 
<EOS>
It
can
give
him
,
"
said
Mr
Mould
,
waving
his
watch
-
chain
slowly
round
and
round
,
so
that
he
described
one
circle
after
every
item
;
"
it
can
give
him
four
horses
to
each
vehicle
;
it
can
give
him
velvet
trappings
;
it
can
give
him
drivers
in
cloth
cloaks
and
top
-
boots
;
it
can
give
him
the
plumage
of
the
ostrich
,
dyed
black
;
it
can
give
him
any
number
of
walking
attendants
,
dressed
in
the
first
style
of
funeral
fashion
,
and
carrying
batons
tipped
with
brass
;
it
can
give
him
a
handsome
tomb
;
it
can
give
him
a
place
in
Westminster
Abbey
itself
,
if
he
choose
to
invest
it
in
such
a
purchase
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
do
not
let
us
say
that
gold
is
dross
,
when
it
can
buy
such
things
as
these
,
Mrs
Gamp
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
what
a
blessing
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
"
that
there
are
such
as
you
,
to
sell
or
let
'em
out
on
hire
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
Mrs
Gamp
,
you
are
right
,
"
rejoined
the
undertaker
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
should
be
an
honoured
calling
.
 
<EOS>
We
do
good
by
stealth
,
and
blush
to
have
it
mentioned
in
our
little
bills
.
 
<EOS>
How
much
consolation
may
I
---
even
I
,
"
cried
Mr
Mould
,
"
have
diffused
among
my
fellow
-
creatures
by
means
of
my
four
long
-
tailed
prancers
,
never
harnessed
under
ten
pund
ten
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
had
begun
to
make
a
suitable
reply
,
when
she
was
interrupted
by
the
appearance
of
one
of
Mr
Mould
's
assistants
---
his
chief
mourner
in
fact
---
an
obese
person
,
with
his
waistcoat
in
closer
connection
with
his
legs
than
is
quite
reconcilable
with
the
established
ideas
of
grace
;
with
that
cast
of
feature
which
is
figuratively
called
a
bottle
nose
;
and
with
a
face
covered
all
over
with
pimples
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
tender
plant
once
upon
a
time
,
but
from
constant
blowing
in
the
fat
atmosphere
of
funerals
,
had
run
to
seed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Tacker
,
"
said
Mr
Mould
,
"
is
all
ready
below
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
beautiful
show
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Tacker
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
horses
are
prouder
and
fresher
than
ever
I
see
'em
;
and
toss
their
heads
,
they
do
,
as
if
they
knowed
how
much
their
plumes
cost
.
 
<EOS>
One
,
two
,
three
,
four
,
"
said
Mr
Tacker
,
heaping
that
number
of
black
cloaks
upon
his
left
arm
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Tom
there
,
with
the
cake
and
wine
?
"
asked
Mr
Mould
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ready
to
come
in
at
a
moment
's
notice
,
sir
,
"
said
Tacker
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Mould
,
putting
up
his
watch
,
and
glancing
at
himself
in
the
little
shaving
-
glass
,
that
he
might
be
sure
his
face
had
the
right
expression
on
it
;
"
then
I
think
we
may
proceed
to
business
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
the
paper
of
gloves
,
Tacker
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
what
a
man
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
Tacker
,
Tacker
,
what
a
man
he
was
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tacker
,
who
from
his
great
experience
in
the
performance
of
funerals
,
would
have
made
an
excellent
pantomime
actor
,
winked
at
Mrs
Gamp
without
at
all
disturbing
the
gravity
of
his
countenance
,
and
followed
his
master
into
the
next
room
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
point
with
Mr
Mould
,
and
a
part
of
his
professional
tact
,
not
to
seem
to
know
the
doctor
;
though
in
reality
they
were
near
neighbours
,
and
very
often
,
as
in
the
present
instance
,
worked
together
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
advanced
to
fit
on
his
black
kid
gloves
as
if
he
had
never
seen
him
in
all
his
life
;
while
the
doctor
,
on
his
part
,
looked
as
distant
and
unconscious
as
if
he
had
heard
and
read
of
undertakers
,
and
had
passed
their
shops
,
but
had
never
before
been
brought
into
communication
with
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
Gloves
,
eh
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pecksniff
after
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
think
of
it
,
"
returned
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
taking
a
pair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
,
as
I
was
saying
---
I
was
called
up
to
attend
that
case
at
about
half
-
past
one
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
Cake
and
wine
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Which
is
port
?
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
took
some
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
At
about
half
-
past
one
o'clock
in
the
morning
,
sir
,
"
resumed
the
doctor
,
"
I
was
called
up
to
attend
that
case
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
first
pull
of
the
night
-
bell
<EOS>
I
turned
out
,
threw
up
the
window
,
and
put
out
my
head
.
 
<EOS>
Cloak
,
eh
?
 
Do
n't
tie
it
too
tight
.
 
<EOS>
That
'll
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
having
been
likewise
inducted
into
a
similar
garment
,
the
doctor
resumed
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
put
out
my
head
---
hat
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
My
good
friend
,
that
is
not
mine
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
,
I
beg
your
pardon
,
but
I
think
we
have
unintentionally
made

exchange
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
sir
,
I
was
going
to
tell
you
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
quite
ready
,
"
interrupted
Mould
in
a
low

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ready
,
eh
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
I
'll
take
an

of
relating
the
rest
in
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
rather
curious
.
 
<EOS>
Ready
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
No
rain
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Quite
fair
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mould
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
afraid
the
ground
would
have
been
wet
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
for
my
glass
fell
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
We
may
congratulate
ourselves
upon
our
good
fortune
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
seeing
by
this
time
that
Mr
Jonas
and
Chuffey
were
going
out
at
the
door
,
he
put
a
white
pocket

his

as

of
grief
had
suddenly
come
upon
him
,
and
walked
down
side
by
side
with
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Mould
and
his
men
had
not
exaggerated
the
grandeur
of
the
arrangements
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
splendid
.
 
<EOS>
The
four
hearse
-
horses
,
especially
,
reared
and
pranced
,
and
showed
their
highest
action
,
as
if
they
knew
a
man
was
dead
,
and
triumphed
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
break
us
,
drive
us
,
ride
us
;
ill
-
treat
,
abuse
,
and
maim
us
for
their
pleasure
---
But
they
die
;
Hurrah
,
they
die
!
"
   
<EOS>
So
through
the
narrow
streets
and
winding
city
ways
,
went
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
's
funeral
;
Mr
Jonas
glancing
stealthily
out
of
the
coach
-
window
now
<EOS>
and
then
,
to
observe
its
effect
upon
the
crowd
;
Mr
Mould
as
he
walked
along
,
listening
with
a
sober
pride
to
the
exclamations
of
the
bystanders
;
the
doctor
whispering
his
story
to
Mr
Pecksniff
,
without
appearing
to
come
any
nearer
the
end
of
it
;
and
poor
old
Chuffey
sobbing
unregarded
in
a
corner
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
greatly
scandalized
Mr
Mould
at
an
early
stage
of
the
ceremony
by
carrying
his
handkerchief
in
his
hat
in
a
perfectly
informal
manner
,
and
wiping
his
eyes
with
his

.
 
<EOS>
And
as
Mr
Mould
himself
had
said
already
,
his
behaviour
was
indecent
,
and
quite
unworthy
of
such
an
occasion
;
and
he
never
ought
to
have
been
there
.
   
<EOS>
There
he
was
,
however
;
and
in
the
churchyard
there
he
was
,
also
,
conducting
himself
in
a
no
less
unbecoming
manner
,
and
leaning
for
support
on
Tacker
,
who
plainly
told
him
that
he
was
fit
for
nothing
better
than
a
walking
funeral
.
 
<EOS>
But
Chuffey
,
Heaven
help
him
!
<EOS>
heard
no
sound
but
<EOS>
the
echoes
,
lingering
in
his
own
heart
,
of
a
voice
for
ever

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
loved
him
,
"
cried
the
old
man
,
sinking
down
upon
the
grave
when
all

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
very
good
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
dear
old
friend
and
master
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
Mr

,
"
said

,
"
<EOS>
this
wo
n't
do
;
it
's
a

,
Mr
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
n't
,
really
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

"
he

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Be

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Be

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
my

,
"

,

,

,
"
this

.
 
<EOS>
This

,

,

,
Mr
Chuffey
.
<EOS>
You

take

from

,
my

.
 
<EOS>
You
forget
that
you
were
not

by

blood
with
our
deceased

;
and
that

a

,
Mr

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
His
own
,
own
,
only
son
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
not
right
in
his
head
,

know
,
"
said
Jonas
,
turning
pale
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
to
mind
anything
he
says
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
n't
wonder
if
he
was
to
talk
some

.
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
you
mind
him
,
any
of
you
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
My
father
left
him
to
my

;
and
whatever
he
says
or
does
,
that
's
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
take
care
of
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
hum
of
admiration
rose
from
the
mourners
(
including
Mr
Mould
and
his
merry
men
)
at
this
new
instance
of
magnanimity
and
kind
feeling
on
the
part
of
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
But
Chuffey
put
it
to
the
test
no
farther
.
<EOS>
He
said
not
a
word
more
,
and
being
left
to
himself
for
a
little
while
,
crept
back
again
to
the
coach
.
   
<EOS>
It
has
been
said
that
Mr
Jonas
turned
pale
when
the
behaviour
of
the
old
clerk
attracted
general
attention
;
his
discomposure
,
however
,
was
but
momentary
,
and
he
soon
recovered
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
were
not
the
only
changes
he
had
exhibited
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
curious
eyes
of
Mr
Pecksniff
had
observed
that
as
soon
as
they
left
the
house
upon
their
mournful
errand
,
he
began
to
mend
;
that
as
the
ceremonies
proceeded
he
gradually
,
by
little
and
little
,
recovered
his
old
condition
,
his
old
looks
,
his
old
bearing
,
his
old
agreeable
characteristics
of
speech
and
manner
,
and
became
,
in
all
respects
,
his
old
pleasant
self
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
that
they
were
seated
in
the
coach
on
their
return
home
;
and
more
when
they
got
there
,
and
found
the
windows
open
,
the
light
and
air
admitted
,
and
all
traces
of
the
late
event
removed
;
he
felt
so
well
convinced
that
Jonas
was
again
the
Jonas
he
had
known
a
week
ago
,
and
not
the
Jonas
of
the
intervening
time
,
that
he
voluntarily
gave
up
his
recently
-
acquired
power
without
one
faint
attempt
to
exercise
it
,
and
at
once
fell
back
into
his
former
position
of
mild
and
deferential

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
went
home
to
the
bird
-
fancier
's
,
and
was
knocked
up
again
that
very
night
for
a
birth
of
twins
;
Mr
Mould
dined
gaily
in
the
bosom
of
his
family
,
and
passed
the
evening
facetiously
at
his
club
;
the
hearse
,
after
standing
for
a
long
time
at
the
door
of
a
roistering
public
-
house
,
repaired
to
its
stables
with
the
feathers
inside
and
twelve
red
-
nosed
undertakers
on
the
roof
,
each
holding
on
by
a
dingy
peg
,
to
which
,
in
times
of
state
,
a
waving
plume
was
fitted
;
the
various
trappings
of
sorrow
were
carefully
laid
by
in
presses
for
the
next
hirer
;
the
fiery
steeds
were
quenched
and
quiet
in
their
stalls
;
the
doctor
got
merry
with
wine
at
a
wedding
-
dinner
,
and
forgot
the
middle
of
the
story
which
had
no
end
to
it
;
the
pageant
of
a
few
short
hours
ago
was
written
nowhere
half
so
legibly
as
in
the
undertaker
's
books
.
   
<EOS>
Not
in
the
churchyard
?
 
<EOS>
Not
even
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
gates
were
closed
;
the
night
was
dark
and
wet
;
the
rain
fell
silently
,
among
the
stagnant
weeds
and
nettles
.
 
<EOS>
One
new
mound
was
there
which
had
not
been
there
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
Time
,
burrowing
like
a
mole
below
the
ground
,
had
marked
his
track
by
throwing
up
another
heap
of
earth
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
was
all
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
20
.
<EOS>
Is
a
chapter
of
love
 
"
Pecksniff
,
"
said
Jonas
,
taking
off
his
hat
,
to
see
that

black
crape
band
was
all
right
;
and
finding
that

was
,
putting

on
again
,
complacently
;
"
what
do
you
mean
to
give
your
daughters
when
they
marry
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mr
Jonas
,
"
cried
the
affectionate
parent
,
with

,
"
what
a
very
singular

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do

you
mind

's

or
a

,
"
retorted

,
eyeing
Mr
Pecksniff
with
no

,
"
but
answer

,
or
let
it
alone
.
 
<EOS>
One
or
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hum
!
 
<EOS>
The
question
,
my
dear
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
laying

upon
his

's

,
"
is
involved
with
many
considerations
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
I
give

?
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
what
would
you
give
'
em
?
"
<EOS>
repeated
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
would
naturally
depend
in
a
great
measure
upon
the
kind

husbands
they
might
choose
,
my
dear
young
friend
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
was
evidently
disconcerted
,
and
at
a
loss
how
to
proceed
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
good
answer
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
a
deep
one
,
but
such
is
the
wisdom
of
simplicity
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
standard
for
the
merits
I
would
require
in
a
son
-
in
-
law
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
after

,
"
is
a
high
one
.
 
<EOS>
Forgive
me
,
my
dear
Mr
Jonas
,
"
he

,
greatly
moved
,
"
if
I

that
you
have
spoiled

,
and
made
it
a

one
;
an

;
a

one
,
if
I

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
?
"
growled
Jonas
,
looking
at
him
with
increased
disfavour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
my
dear
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
you
may
well
inquire
.
<EOS>
The
heart
is
not
always
a
royal
mint
,
with
patent
machinery
to
work
its
metal
into
current
coin
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
it
throws

out
in
strange

,
not

as
coin

all
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
sterling
gold
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
at
least
that
merit
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
sterling
gold
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
?
"
<EOS>
grumbled
Jonas
,
with
a
doubtful
shake
of
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
warming
with
his
subject
<EOS>
"
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
To
be
plain
with
you
,
Mr
Jonas
,
if
I
could
find
two
such
sons
-
in
-
law
as
you
will
one
day
make
to
some
deserving
man
,
capable
of
appreciating
a
nature
such
as
yours
,
I
would
---
forgetful
of
myself
---
<EOS>
bestow
upon
my
daughters
portions
reaching
to
the
very
utmost
limit
of
my
means
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
strong
language
,
and
it
was
earnestly
delivered
.
 
<EOS>
But
who
can
wonder
that
such
a
man
as
Mr
Pecksniff
,
after
all
he
had
seen
and
heard
of
Mr
Jonas
,
should
be
strong
and
earnest
upon
such
a
theme
;
a
theme
that
touched
even
the
worldly
lips
of
undertakers
with
the
honey
of
eloquence
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
was
silent
,
and
looked
thoughtfully
at
the
landscape
.
 
<EOS>
For
they
were
seated
on
the
outside
of
the
coach
,
at
the
back
,
and
were
travelling
down
into
the
country
.
 
<EOS>
He
accompanied
Mr
Pecksniff
home
for
a
few
days
'
change
of
air
and
scene
after
his
recent
trials
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"
he
said
,
at
last
,
with
captivating
bluntness
,
"
suppose
you
got
one
such
son
-
in
-
law
as
me
,
what
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
regarded
him
at
first
with
inexpressible
surprise
;
then
gradually
breaking
into
a
sort
of
dejected
vivacity
,
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Then
well
I
know
whose
husband
he
would
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whose
?
"
asked
Jonas
,
drily
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
eldest
girl
's
,
Mr
Jonas
,
"
replied
Pecksniff
,
with
moistening

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Cherry
's
;
my
staff
,
my
scrip
,
my
treasure
,
Mr
Jonas
.
<EOS>
A
hard
struggle
,
but
it
is
in
the
nature
of
things
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
one
day
part
with
her
to
a
husband
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
it
,
my
dear
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
prepared
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
<EOS>
you
've
been
prepared
for
that
a
pretty
long
time
,
I
should
think
,
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Many
have
sought
to
bear
her
from
me
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
have
failed
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
give
my
hand
,
papa
"
---
those
were
her
words
---
"
unless
my
heart
is
won
.
"
 
<EOS>
She
has
not
been
quite
so
happy
as
she
used
to
be
,
of
late
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
why
.
"
   
<EOS>
Again
Mr
Jonas
looked
at
the
landscape
;
then
at
the
coachman
;
then
at
the
luggage
on
the
roof
;
finally
at
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
'll
have
to
part
with
the
other
one
,
some
of
these
days
?
"
<EOS>
he
observed
,
as
he
caught
that
gentleman
's
eye
.
   
<EOS>
"
Probably
,
"
said
the
parent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Years
will
tame
down
the
wildness
of
my
foolish
bird
,
and
then
it
will
be
caged
.
 
<EOS>
But
Cherry
,
Mr
Jonas
,
Cherry
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
ah
!
"
interrupted
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Years
have
made
her
all
right
enough
.
<EOS>
Nobody
doubts
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
have
n't
answered
what
I
asked
you
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
,
you
're
not
obliged
to
do
it
,
you
know
,
if
you
do
n't
like
.
<EOS>
You
're
the
best
judge
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
warning
sulkiness
in
the
manner
of
this
speech
,
which
admonished
Mr
Pecksniff
that
his
dear
friend
was
not
to
be
trifled
with
or
fenced
off
,
and
that
he
must
either
return
a
straight
-
forward
reply
to
his
question
,
or
plainly
give
him
to
understand
that
he
declined
to
enlighten
him
upon
the
subject
to
which
it
referred
.
 
<EOS>
Mindful
in
this
dilemma
of
the
caution
<EOS>
old
Anthony
had
given
him
almost
with
his
latest
breath
,
he
resolved
to
speak
to
the
point
,
and
so
told
Mr
Jonas
(
enlarging
upon
the
communication
as
a
proof
of
his
great
attachment
and
confidence
)
,
that
in
the
case
he
had
put
;
to
wit
,
in
the
event
of
such
a
man
as
he
proposing
for
his
daughter
's
hand
,
he
would
endow
her
with
a
fortune
of
four
thousand
pounds
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
sadly
pinch
and
cramp
myself
to
do
so
,
"
was
his
fatherly
remark
;
"
but
that
would
be
my
duty
,
and
my
conscience
would
reward
me
.
 
<EOS>
For
myself
,
my
conscience
is
my
bank
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
trifle
invested
there
---
a
mere
trifle
,
Mr
Jonas
---
<EOS>
but
I
prize
it
as
a
store
of
value
,
I
assure
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
good
man
's
enemies
would
have
divided
upon
this
question
into
two
parties
.
 
<EOS>
One
would
have
asserted
without
scruple
that
if
Mr
Pecksniff
's
conscience
were
his
bank
,
and
he
kept
a
running
account
there
,
he
must
have
overdrawn
it
beyond
all
mortal
means
of
computation
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
would
have
contended
that
it
was
a
mere
fictitious
form
;
a
perfectly
blank
book
;
or
one
in
which
entries
were
only
made
with
a
peculiar
kind
of
invisible
ink
to
become
legible
at
some
indefinite
time
;
and
that
he
never
troubled
it
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
sadly
pinch
and
cramp
me
,
my
dear
friend
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
but
Providence
---
<EOS>
perhaps
I
may
be
permitted
to
say
a
special
Providence
---
has
blessed
my
endeavours
,
and
I
could
guarantee
to
make
the
sacrifice
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
question
of
philosophy
arises
here
,
whether
Mr
Pecksniff
had
or
had
not
good
reason
to
say
that
he
was
specially
patronized
and
encouraged
in
his
undertakings
.
 
<EOS>
All
his
life
long
he
had
been
walking
up
and
down
the
narrow
ways
and
by
-
places
,
with
a
hook
in
one
hand
and
a
crook
in
the
other
,
scraping
all
sorts
of
valuable
odds
and
ends
into
his
pouch
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
there
being
a
special
Providence
in
the
fall
of
a
sparrow
<EOS>
,
it
follows
(
so
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
only
such
admirable
men
,
would
have
reasoned
)
,
that
there
must
also
be
a
special
Providence
in
the
alighting
of
the
stone
or
stick
,
or
other
substance
which
is
aimed
at
the
sparrow
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Pecksniff
's
hook
,
or
crook
,
having
invariably
knocked
the
sparrow
on
the
head
and
brought
him
down
,
that
gentleman
may
have
been
led
to
consider
himself
as
specially
licensed
to
bag
sparrows
,
and
as
being
specially
seized
and
possessed
of
all
the
birds
he
had
got
together
.
 
<EOS>
That
many
undertakings
,
national
as
well
as
individual
---
but
especially
the
former
---
are
held
to
be
specially
brought
to
a
glorious
and
successful
issue
,
which
never
could
be
so
regarded
on
any
other
process
of
reasoning
,
<EOS>
must
be
clear
to
all
men
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
the
precedents
would
seem
to
show
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
(
as
things
go
)
good
argument
for
what
he
said
and
might
be
permitted
to
say
it
,
and
did
not
say
it
presumptuously
,
vainly
,
or
arrogantly
,
but
in
a
spirit
of
high
faith
and
great
wisdom
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
,
not
being
much
accustomed
to
perplex
his
mind
with
theories
of
this
nature
,
expressed
no
opinion
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
receive
his
companion
's
announcement
with
one
solitary
syllable
,
good
,
bad
,
or
indifferent
.
 
<EOS>
He
preserved
this
taciturnity
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
at
least
,
and
during
the
whole
of
that
time
appeared
to
be
steadily
engaged
in
subjecting
some
given
amount
to
the
operation
of
every
known
rule
in
figures
;
adding
to
it
,
taking
from
it
,
multiplying
it
,
reducing
it
by
long
and
short
division
;
working
it
by
the
rule
-
of
-
three
direct
and
inversed
;
exchange
or
barter
;
practice
;
simple
interest
;
compound
interest
;
and
other
means
of
arithmetical
calculation
.
 
<EOS>
The
result
of
these
labours
appeared
to
be
satisfactory
,
for
when
he
did
break
silence
,
it
was
as
one
who
had
arrived
at
some
specific
result
,
and
freed
himself
from
a
state
of
distressing
uncertainty
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
old
Pecksniff
!
"
<EOS>
---
Such
was
his
jocose
address
,
as
he
slapped
that
gentleman
on
the
back
,
at
the
end
of
the
stage
---
"
let
's
have
something
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
With
all
my
heart
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
's
treat
the
driver
,
"
cried
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
it
wo
n't
hurt
the
man
,
or
render
him
discontented
with
his
station
---
certainly
,
"
faltered
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
only
laughed
at
this
,
and
getting
down
from
the
coach
-
top
with
great
alacrity
,
cut
a
cumbersome
kind
of
caper
in
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
After
which
,
he
went
into
the
public
-
house
,
and
there
ordered
spirituous
drink
to
such
an
extent
,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
some
doubts
of
his
perfect
sanity
,
until
Jonas
set
them
quite
at
rest
by
saying
,
when
the
coach
could
wait
no
longer
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
been
standing
treat
for
a
whole
week
and
more
,
and
letting
you
have
all
the
delicacies
of
the
season
.
 
<EOS>
YOU
shall
pay
for
this
Pecksniff
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
joke
either
,
as
Mr
Pecksniff
at
first
supposed
;
for
he
went
off
to
the
coach
without
further
ceremony
,
and
left
his
respected
victim
to
settle
the
bill
.
   
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
was
a
man
of
meek
endurance
,
and
Mr
Jonas
was
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Moreover
,
his
regard
for
that
gentleman
was
founded
,
as
we
know
,
on
pure
esteem
,
and
a
knowledge
of
the
excellence
of
his
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
came
out
from
the
tavern
with
a
smiling
face
,
and
even
went
so
far
as
to
repeat
the
performance
,
on
a
less
expensive
scale
,
at
the
next
ale
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
certain
wildness
in
the
spirits
of
Mr
Jonas
(
not
usually
a
part
of
his
character
)
which
was
far
from
being
subdued
by
these
means
,
and
,
for
the
rest
of
the
journey
,
he
was
so
very
buoyant
---
it
may
be
said
,
boisterous
---
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
some
difficulty
in
keeping
pace
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
not
expected
---
<EOS>
oh
dear
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
proposed
in
London
to
give
the
girls
a
surprise
,
and
had
said
he
would
n't
write
a
word
to
prepare
them
on
any
account
,
in
order
that
he
and
Mr
Jonas
might
take
them
unawares
,
and
just
see
what
they
were
doing
,
when
they
thought
their
dear
papa
was
miles
and
miles
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
consequence
of
this
playful
device
,
there
was
nobody
to
meet
them
at
the
finger
-
post
,
but
that
was
of
small
consequence
,
for
they
had
come
down
by
the
day
coach
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
had
only
a
carpetbag
,
while
Mr
Jonas
had
only
a
portmanteau
.
 
<EOS>
They
took
the
portmanteau
between
them
,
put
the
bag
upon
it
,
and
walked
off
up
the
lane
without
delay
;
Mr
Pecksniff
already
going
on
tiptoe
as
if
,
without
this
precaution
,
his
fond
children
,
being
then
at
a
distance
of
a
couple
of
miles
or
so
,
would
have
some
filial
sense
of
his
approach
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
lovely
evening
in
the
spring
-
time
of
the
year
;
and
in
the
soft
stillness
of
the
twilight
,
all
nature
was
very
calm
and
beautiful
.
 
<EOS>
The
day
had
been
fine
and
warm
;
but
at
the
coming
on
of
night
,
the
air
grew
cool
,
and
in
the
mellowing
distance
smoke
was
rising
gently
from
the
cottage
chimneys
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
thousand
pleasant
scents
diffused
around
,
from
young
leaves
and
fresh
buds
;
the
cuckoo
had
been
singing
all
day
long
,
and
was
but
just
now
hushed
;
the
smell
of
earth
newly
-
upturned
,
first
breath
of
hope
to
the
first
labourer
after
his
garden
withered
,
was
fragrant
in
the
evening
breeze
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
time
when
most
men
cherish
good
resolves
,
and
sorrow
for
the
wasted
past
;
when
most
men
,
looking
on
the
shadows
as
they
gather
,
think
of
that
evening
which
must
close
on
all
,
and
that
to
-
morrow
which
has
none
beyond
.
   
<EOS>
"
Precious
dull
,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
looking
about
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
enough
to
make
a
man
go
melancholy
mad
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
have
lights
and
a
fire
soon
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
need
'em
by
the
time
we
get
there
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
the
devil
do
n't
you
talk
?
 
<EOS>
What
are
you
thinking
of
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
tell
you
the
truth
,
Mr
Jonas
,
"
said
Pecksniff
with
great
solemnity
,
"
my
mind
was
running
at
that
moment
on
our
late
dear
friend
,
your
departed
father
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
immediately
let
his
burden
fall
,
and
said
,
threatening
him
with
his
hand
:
   
<EOS>
"
Drop
that
,
Pecksniff
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
not
exactly
knowing
whether
allusion
was
made
to
the
subject
or
the
portmanteau
,
stared
at
his
friend
in
unaffected
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drop
it
,
I
say
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
,
fiercely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
hear
?
 
<EOS>
Drop
it
,
now
and
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
,
I
give
you
notice
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
quite
a
mistake
,
"
urged
Mr
Pecksniff
,
very
much
dismayed
;
"
though
I
admit
it
was
foolish
.
 
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
it
was
a
tender
string
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
about
tender
strings
,
"
said
Jonas
,
wiping
his
forehead
with
the
cuff
of
his
coat
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
going
to
be
crowed
over
by
you
,
because
I
do
n't
like
dead
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
got
out
the
words
"
Crowed
over
,
Mr
Jonas
!
"
<EOS>
when
that
young
man
,
with
a
dark
expression
in
his
countenance
,
cut
him
short
once
more
:
   
"
Mind
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
have
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
advise
you
not
to
revive
the
subject
,
neither
to
me
nor
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
take
a
hint
,
if
you
choose
as
well
as
another
man
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
enough
said
about
it
.
<EOS>
Come
along
!
"
   
<EOS>
Taking
up
his
part
of
the
load
again
,
when
he
had
said
these
words
,
he
hurried
on
so
fast
that
Mr
Pecksniff
,
at
the
other
end
of
the
portmanteau
,
found
himself
dragged
forward
,
in
a
very
inconvenient
and
ungraceful
manner
,
to
the
great
detriment
of
what
is
called
by
fancy
gentlemen
"
the
bark
"
upon
his
shins
,
which
were
most
unmercifully
bumped
against
the
hard
leather
and
the
iron
buckles
.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
a
few
minutes
,
however
,
Mr
Jonas
relaxed
his
speed
,
and
suffered
his
companion
to
come
up
with
him
,
and
to
bring
the
portmanteau
into
a
tolerably
straight
position
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
pretty
clear
that
he
regretted
his
late
outbreak
,
and
that
he
mistrusted
its
effect
on
Mr
Pecksniff
;
for
as
often
as
that
gentleman
glanced
towards
Mr
Jonas
,
he
found
Mr
Jonas
glancing
at
him
,
which
was
a
new
source
of
embarrassment
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
but
a
short
-
lived
one
,
though
,
for
Mr
Jonas
soon
began
to
whistle
,
whereupon
Mr
Pecksniff
,
taking
his
cue
from
his
friend
,
began
to
hum
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty

there
,
ai

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Close

"

<EOS>
"
What

"

<EOS>
"
Impossible

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Giddy

!
 
<EOS>
They

<EOS>
I

---
he

<EOS>
he

<EOS>
he

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

---

<EOS>
See

<EOS>
From

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
   
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
but

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

Ah
!

sister
best
.
 
<EOS>
We
all

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes

was
;
you

was
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Any

is

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
You

I

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

;
"
at

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Let

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
"
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
We

,

<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
Now
whether
Mr
Pecksniff

;

divined

---

;

,

might

<EOS>

contrast
<EOS>

so

!
<EOS>
"

,

,

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
On

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
Without

<EOS>
,

"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless

,

"
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
her
,

---

.
 
<EOS>
The

who
was
ill
at
the
Dragon
,
sir
,
last
winter
;
and
the
young
lady
who
attended

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
's
teeth
chattered
in
his

,
and
he
positively
staggered
with
amazement
,
at
witnessing
the
extraordinary
effect
produced
on
Mr
Pecksniff
by
these

.
 
<EOS>
The
dread
of
losing
the
old
man
's

almost
as
soon
as
they
were
reconciled
,
through
the
mere

of
having
Jonas
in
the
house
;
the
impossibility
of
dismissing
Jonas
,
or

,
or

and

in

,
without
offending
him
beyond

;
the
horrible
discordance
prevailing
in
the

,
and
the
impossibility
of
reducing
it
to
decent
harmony
with
Charity
in
loud

,
Mercy
in
the
utmost
disorder
,
Jonas
in
the

,
and
Martin
Chuzzlewit
and
his
young

upon

very

;
the
total
hopelessness
of
being
able
to
disguise
or
feasibly
explain
this
state
of
rampant

;
the
sudden
accumulation
over
his
devoted
head
of
every
complicated
perplexity
and
entanglement
for
his
extrication
from
which
he
had
trusted
to
time
,
good
fortune
,
chance
,
and
his
own
plotting
,
so
filled
the
entrapped
architect
with
dismay
,
that
if
Tom
could
have
been
a
Gorgon
staring
at
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
could
have
been
a
Gorgon
staring
at
Tom
,
they
could
not
have
horrified
each
other
half
so
much
as
in
their
own

.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
"
what
have
I
done
?
 
<EOS>
I
hoped

would
be
a
pleasant

,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
would
like
to
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
at
that
moment
a
loud
knocking
was
heard
at
the
hall
door
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
21
.
<EOS>
More
American
experiences
,
Martin
takes
a
partner
,
and
makes
a
purchase
.
 
<EOS>
Some
account
of
Eden
,
as
it
appeared
on
paper
.
 
<EOS>
Also
of
the
British
Lion
.
 
<EOS>
Also
of
the
kind
of
sympathy
professed
and
entertained
by
the
Watertoast
Association
of
United
Sympathisers
 
<EOS>
The
knocking
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
door
,
though
loud
enough
,
bore
no
resemblance
whatever
to
the
noise
of
an
American
railway
train
at
full
speed
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
well
to
begin
the
present
chapter
with
this
frank
admission
,
lest
the
reader
should
imagine
that
the
sounds
now
deafening
this
history
's
ears
have
any
connection
with
the
knocker
on
Mr
Pecksniff
's
door
,
or
with
the
great
amount
of
agitation
pretty
equally
divided
between
that
worthy
man
and
Mr
Pinch
,
of
which
its
strong
performance
was
the
cause
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
is
more
than
a
thousand
leagues
away
;
and
again
this
happy
chronicle
has
Liberty
and
Moral
Sensibility
for
its
high
companions
.
 
<EOS>
Again
it
breathes
the
blessed
air
of
Independence
;
again
it
contemplates
with
pious
awe
that
moral
sense
which
renders
unto
Ceasar
nothing
that
is
his
;
again
inhales
that
sacred
atmosphere
which
was
the
life
of
him
---
oh
noble
patriot
,
with
many
followers
!
<EOS>
---
who
dreamed
of
Freedom
in
a
slave
's
embrace
,
and
waking
sold
her
offspring
and
his
own
in
public
markets
.
   
<EOS>
How
the
wheels
clank
and
rattle
,
and
the
tram
-
road
shakes
,
as
the
train
rushes
on
!
 
<EOS>
And
now
the
engine
yells
,
as
it
were
lashed
and
tortured
like
a
living
labourer
,
and
writhed
in
agony
.
 
<EOS>
A
poor
fancy
;
for
steel
and
iron
are
of
infinitely
greater
account
,
in
this
commonwealth
,
than
flesh
and
blood
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
cunning
work
of
man
be
urged
beyond
its
power
of
endurance
,
it
has
within
it
the
elements
of
its
own
revenge
;
whereas
the
wretched
mechanism
of
the
Divine
Hand
is
dangerous
with
no
such
property
,
but
may
be
tampered
with
,
and
crushed
,
and
broken
,
at
the
driver
's
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
that
engine
!
 
<EOS>
It
shall
cost
a
man
more
dollars
in
the
way
of
penalty
and
fine
,
and
satisfaction
of
the
outraged
law
,
to
deface
in
wantonness
that
senseless
mass
of
metal
,
than
to
take
the
lives
of
twenty
human
creatures
!
 
<EOS>
Thus
the
stars
wink
upon
the
bloody
stripes
;
and
Liberty
pulls
down
her
cap
upon
her
eyes
,
and
owns
Oppression
in
its
vilest
aspect
,
for
her
sister
.
   
<EOS>
The
engine
-
driver
of
the
train
whose
noise
awoke
us
to
the
present
chapter
was
certainly
troubled
with
no
such
reflections
as
these
;
nor
is
it
very
probable
that
his
mind
was
disturbed
by
any
reflections
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
leaned
with
folded
arms
and
crossed
legs
against
the
side
of
the
carriage
,
smoking
;
and
,
except
when
he
expressed
,
by
a
grunt
as
short
as
his
pipe
,
his
approval
of
some
particularly
dexterous
aim
on
the
part
of
his
colleague
,
the
fireman
,
who
beguiled
his
leisure
by
throwing
logs
of
wood
from
the
tender
at
the
numerous
stray
cattle
on
the
line
,
he
preserved
a
composure
so
immovable
,
and
an
indifference
so
complete
,
that
if
the
locomotive
had
been
a
sucking
-
pig
,
he
could
not
have
been
more
perfectly
indifferent
to
its
doings
.
 
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
the
tranquil
state
of
this
officer
,
and
his
unbroken
peace
of
mind
,
the
train
was
proceeding
with
tolerable
rapidity
;
and
the
rails
being
but
poorly
laid
,
the
jolts
and
bumps
it
met
with
in
its
progress
were
neither
slight
nor
few
.
   
<EOS>
There
were
three
great
caravans
or
cars
attached
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
'
car
,
the
gentlemen
's
car
,
and
the
car
for
negroes
;
the
latter
painted
black
,
as
an
appropriate
compliment
to
its
company
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
and
Mark
Tapley
were
in
the
first
,
as
it
was
the
most
comfortable
;
and
,
being
far
from
full
,
received
other
gentlemen
who
,
like
them
,
were
unblessed
by
the
society
of
ladies
of
their
own
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
seated
side
by
side
,
and
were
engaged
in
earnest
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
Mark
,
"
said
Martin
,
looking
at
him
with
an
anxious
expression
,
"
<EOS>
and
so
you
are
glad
we
have
left
New
York
far
behind
us
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Precious
glad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Were
you
not
"
jolly
"
there
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrairy
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
jolliest
week
as
ever
I
spent
in
my
life
,
was
that
there
week
at
Pawkins
's
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think

our

?
"
<EOS>
inquired

,
with
an
air
that
plainly

had
avoided

for
some

.
   
<EOS>
"
Uncommon
bright
,
sir
,
"

Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
for
a
place
to
have
a
better
name
,
sir
,
than
the
Walley
of
Eden
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
could
n't
think
of
settling
in
a

than
the
Walley
of
Eden
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
'm

,
"

,

,
"
as
there
's
lots
of
serpents
there
,
so
we
shall
come
out
,
quite
complete

reg'lar
.
"
   
<EOS>
So

dwelling

agreeable

with

,
Mark
's
face
grew
radiant
as

called

to

;
<EOS>
so
very
radiant
,
that
a
stranger
might
have
supposed
he
had
all

life
been
yearning
for
the
society
of
serpents
,
and
now
hailed

the
approaching

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
told
you
that
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Martin
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Confound
you
for
a

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
military

?
 
<EOS>
You
know
they
spring

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
thick

in

,

"

,
"
which
is
a
sort

milita
themselves
,

entirely
coat

,
with

.
 
<EOS>
Ha

---
Do

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca

.
 
<EOS>
Why

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

?

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

,

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

I

,

,
"

,
<EOS>

,

;
"
anyhow
,

,

,

.
"

Live
!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
's
easy
to
say

;
but
if
we
should
happen
not
to
wake
when

are

of
themselves
upon

,

to
do

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
a
fact
,
"
said
a

so
close
in
his
ear
that
it
tickled

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
dreadful
true
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
looked
round
,
and
found
that
a
gentleman
,
on
the
seat
behind
,
had
thrust
his
head
between
himself
and
Mark
,
and
sat
with
his
chin
resting
on
the
back
rail
of
their
little
bench
,
entertaining
himself
with
their
conversation
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
as
languid
and
listless
in
his
looks
as
most
of
the
gentlemen
they
had
seen
;
his
cheeks
were
so
hollow
that
he
seemed
to
be
always
sucking
them
in
;
and
the
sun
had
burnt
him
,
not
a
wholesome
red
or
brown
,
but
dirty
yellow
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
bright
dark
eyes
,
which
he
kept
half
closed
;
<EOS>
only
peeping
out
of
the
corners
,
and
even
then
with
a
glance
that
seemed
to
say
,
"
Now
you
wo
n't
overreach
me
;
you
want
to
,
but
you
wo
n't
.
"
 
<EOS>
His
arms
rested
carelessly
on
his
knees
as
he
leant
forward
;
in
the
palm
of
his
left
hand
,
as
English
rustics
have
their
slice
of
cheese
,
he
had
a
cake
of
tobacco
;
in
his
right
a
penknife
.
 
<EOS>
He
struck
into
the
dialogue
with
as
little
reserve
as
if
he
had
been
specially
called
in
,
days
before
,
to
hear
the
arguments
on
both

,
and
favour
them
with
his

;
and
he
no
more
contemplated
or
cared
for
the
possibility
of
their
not

of

or

than
if

been

or

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
"
he

,
nodding
condescendingly
to
Martin
,
as
to
an
outer
