,
"
is
dreadful
true
.
 
<EOS>
Darn
all
manner
of
vermin
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
could
not
help
frowning
for
a
moment
,
as
if
he
were
disposed
to
insinuate
that
the

had
unconsciously
"
darned
"

.
<EOS>
But
remembering
the
wisdom
of
doing
at
Rome
as
Romans
do
,
he
smiled
with
the
pleasantest
expression
he
could
assume
upon
so
short

notice
.
   
<EOS>
Their
new
friend
said
no
more
just
then
,
being
busily
employed
in
cutting
a
quid
or
plug
from
his
cake
of
tobacco
,
and
whistling
softly
to
himself
the
while
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
shaped
it
to
his
liking
,
he
took
out
his
old
plug
,
and
deposited
the
same
on
the
back
of
the
seat
between
Mark
and
Martin
,
while
he
thrust
the
new
one
into
the
hollow
of
his
cheek
,
where
it
looked
like
a
large
walnut
,
or
tolerable
pippin
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
it
quite
satisfactory
,
he
stuck
the
point
of
his
knife
into
the
old
plug
,
and
holding
it
out
for
their
inspection
,
remarked
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
not
lived
in

,
that
it
was
"
used
up
considerable
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
he

;

;

;

of

on
Martin
's

,
reached

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do

this

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"
In

,

"

<EOS>
"

wo

No

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

wo

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

's

.
 
<EOS>
Close

,

,

"
NATIONAL

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

many
pairs
of
boots
and
shoes
,
and
the
smoke
of
a
great
many
cigars
,
but
no
other
evidences
of
human
habitation
.
 
<EOS>
By
slow
degrees
,
however
,
some
heads
and
shoulders
appeared
,
and
connecting
themselves
with
the
boots
and
shoes
,
led
to
the
discovery
that
certain
gentlemen
boarders
,
who
had
a
fancy
for
putting
their
heels
where
the
gentlemen
boarders
in
other
countries
usually
put
their
heads
,
were
enjoying
themselves
after
their
own
manner
in
the
cool
of
the
evening
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
great
bar
-
room
in
this
hotel
,
and
a
great
public
room
in
which
the
general
table
was
being
set
out
for
supper
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
interminable
whitewashed
staircases
,
long
whitewashed
galleries
upstairs
and
downstairs
,
scores
of
little
whitewashed
bedrooms
,
and
a
four
-
sided
verandah
to
every
story
in
the
house
,
which
formed
a
large
brick
square
with
an
uncomfortable
courtyard
in
the
centre
,
where
some
clothes
were
drying
.
 
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
some
yawning
gentlemen
lounged
up
and
down
with
their
hands
in
their
pockets
;
but
within
the
house
and
without
,
wherever
half
a
dozen
people
were
collected
together
,
there
,
in
their
looks
,
dress
,
morals
,
manners
,
habits
,
intellect
,
and
conversation
,
were
Mr
Jefferson
Brick
,
Colonel
Diver
,
Major
Pawkins
,
General
Choke
,
and
Mr
La
Fayette
Kettle
,
over
,
and
over
,
and
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
They
did
the
same
things
;
said
the
same
things
;
judged
all
subjects
by
,
and
reduced
all
subjects
to
,
the
same
standard
.
 
<EOS>
Observing
how
they
lived
,
and
how
they
were
always
in
the
enchanting
company
of
each
other
,
Martin
even
began
to
comprehend
their
being
the
social
,
cheerful
,
winning
,
airy
men
they
were
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
sounding
of
a
dismal
gong
,
this
pleasant
company
went
trooping
down
from
all
parts
of
the
house
to
the
public
room
;
while
from
the
neighbouring
stores
other
guests
came
flocking
in
,
in
shoals
;
for
half
the
town
,
married
folks
as
well
as
single
,
resided
at
the
National
Hotel
.
 
<EOS>
Tea
,
coffee
,
dried
meats
,
tongue
,
ham
,
pickles
,
cake
,
toast
,
preserves
,
and
bread
and
butter
,
were
swallowed
with
the
usual
ravaging
speed
;
and
then
,
as
before
,
the
company
dropped
off
by
degrees
,
and
lounged
away
to
the
desk
,
the
counter
,
or
the
bar
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
ladies
had
a
smaller
ordinary
of
their
own
,
to
which
their
husbands
and
brothers
were
admitted
if
they
chose
;
and
in
all
other
respects
they
enjoyed
themselves
as
at
Pawkins
's
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mark
,
my
good
fellow
,
said
Martin
,
closing
the
door
of
his
little
chamber
,
"
we
must
hold
a
solemn
council
,
for
our
fate
is
decided
to
-
morrow
morning
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
determined
to
invest
these
savings
of
yours
in
the
common
stock
,
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
n't
been
determined
to
make
that
wentur
,
sir
,
"
answered
Mr
Tapley
,
"
I
should
n't
have
come
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
much
is
there
here
,
did
you
say
"
asked
Martin
,
holding
up
a
little
bag
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thirty
-
seven
pound
ten
and
sixpence
.
 
<EOS>
The
Savings
'
Bank
said
so
at
least
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
counted
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
THEY
know
,
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mark
,
with
a
shake
of
the
head
expressive
of
his
unbounded
confidence
in
the
wisdom
and
arithmetic
of
those
Institutions
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
money
we
brought
with
us
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
is
reduced
to
a
few
shillings
less
than
eight
pounds
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
smiled
,
and
looked
all
manner
of
ways
,
that
he
might
not
be
supposed
to
attach
any
importance
to
this
fact
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
the
ring
---
HER
ring
,
Mark
,
"
said
Martin
,
looking
ruefully
at
his
empty
finger
---
    
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
sighed
Mr
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
sir
.
"
   
"
---
We
raised
,
in
English
money
,
fourteen
pounds
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
even
with
that
,
your
share
of
the
stock
is
still
very
much
the
larger
of
the
two
you
see
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
Mark
,
"
said
Martin
,
in
his
old
way
,
just
as
he
might
have
spoken
to
Tom
Pinch
,
"
I
have
thought
of
a
means
of
making
this
up
to
you
---
more
than
making
it
up
to
you
,
I
hope
---
and
very
materially
elevating
your
prospects
in
life
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
n't
talk
of
that
,
you
know
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
no
elevating
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
all
right
enough
,
sir
,
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
but
hear
me
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
because
this
is
very
important
to
you
,
and
a
great
satisfaction
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
,
you
shall
be
a
partner
in
the
business
;
an
equal
partner
with
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
put
in
,
as
my
additional
capital
,
my
professional
knowledge
and
ability
;
and
half
the
annual
profits
,
as
long
as
it
is
carried
on
,
shall
be
yours
.
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Martin
!
 
<EOS>
For
ever
building
castles
in
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
For
ever
,
in
his
very
selfishness
,
forgetful
of
all
but
his
own
teeming
hopes
and
sanguine
plans
.
 
<EOS>
Swelling
,
at
that
instant
,
with
the
consciousness
of
patronizing
and
most
munificently
rewarding
Mark
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
sir
,
"
Mark
rejoined
,
much
more
sadly
than
his
custom
was
,
though
from
a
very
different
cause
than
Martin
supposed
,
"
what
I
can
say
to
this
,
in
the
way
of
thanking
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
stand
by
you
,
sir
,
to
the
best
of
my
ability
,
and
to
the
last
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
quite
understand
each
other
,
my
good
fellow
,
"
said
Martin
rising
in
self
-
approval
and
condescension
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
are
no
longer
master
and
servant
,
but
friends
and
partners
;
and
are
mutually
gratified
.
 
<EOS>
If
we
determine
on
Eden
,
the
business
shall
be
commenced
as
soon
as
we
get
there
.
 
<EOS>
Under
the
name
,
"
said
Martin
,
who
never
hammered
upon
an
idea
that
was
n't
red
hot
,
"
under
the
name
of
Chuzzlewit
and
Tapley
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lord
love
you
,
sir
,
"
cried
Mark
,
"
do
n't
have
my
name
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
acquainted
with
the
business
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
be
Co.
<EOS>
,
I
must
.
<EOS>
I
've
often
thought
,
"
he
added
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
as
I
should
like
to
know
a
Co.
;
but
I
little
thought
as
ever
I
should
live
to
be
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
your
own
way
,
Mark
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
country
gentleman
thereabouts
,
in
the
public
way
,
or
otherwise
,
wanted
such
a
thing
as
a
skittle
-
ground
made
,
I
could
take
that
part
of
the
bis'ness
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Against
any
architect
in
the
States
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
a
couple
of
sherry
-
cobblers
,
Mark
,
and
we
'll
drink
success
to
the
firm
.
"
   
<EOS>
Either
he
forgot
already
(
and
often
afterwards
)
,
that
they
were
no
longer
master
and
servant
,
or
considered
this
kind
of
duty
to
be
among
the
legitimate
functions
of
the
Co.
 
<EOS>
But
Mark
obeyed
with
his
usual
alacrity
;
and
before
they
parted
for
the
night
,
it
was
agreed
between
them
that
they
should
go
together
to
the
agent
's
in
the
morning
,
but
that
Martin
should
decide
the
Eden
question
,
on
his
own
sound
judgment
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mark
made
no
merit
,
even
to
himself
in
his
jollity
,
of
this
concession
;
perfectly
well
knowing
that
the
matter
would
come
to
that
in
the
end
,
any
way
.
   
<EOS>
The
General
was
one
of
the
party
at
the
public
table
next
day
,
and
after
breakfast
suggested
that
they
should
wait
upon
the
agent
without
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
They
,
desiring
nothing
more
,
agreed
;
so
off
they
all
four
started
for
the
office
of
the
Eden
Settlement
,
which
was
almost
within
rifle
-
shot
of
the
National
Hotel
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
small
place
---
something
like
a
turnpike
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
great
deal
of
land
may
be
got
into
a
dice
-
box
,
and
why
may
not
a
whole
territory
be
bargained
for
in
a
shed
?
 
<EOS>
It
was
but
<EOS>
a
temporary
office
too
;
for
the
Edeners
were
"
going
"
to
build
a
superb
establishment
for
the
transaction
of
their
business
,
and
had
already
got
so
far
as
to
mark
out
the
site
.
 
<EOS>
Which
is
a
great
way
in
America
.
 
<EOS>
The
office
-
door
was
wide
open
,
and
in
the
doorway
was
the
agent
;
no
doubt
a
tremendous
fellow
to
get
through
his
work
,
for
he
seemed
to
have
no
arrears
,
but
was
swinging
backwards
and
forwards
in
a
rocking
-
chair
,
with
one
of
his
legs
planted
high
up
against
the
door
-
post
,
and
the
other
doubled
up
under
him
,
as
if
he
were
hatching
his
foot
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
gaunt
man
in
a
huge
straw
hat
,
and
a
coat
of
green
stuff
.
<EOS>
The
weather
being
hot
,
he
had
no
cravat
,
and
wore
his
shirt
collar
wide
open
;
so
that
every
time
he
spoke
something
was
seen
to
twitch
and
jerk
up
in
his
throat
,
like
the
little
hammers
in
a
harpsichord
when
the
notes
are
struck
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
the
Truth
feebly
endeavouring
to
leap
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
it
never
reached
them
.
   
<EOS>
Two
grey
eyes
lurked
deep
within
this
agent
's
head
,
but
one
of
them
had
no
sight
in
it
,
and
stood
stock
still
.
 
<EOS>
With
that
side
of
his
face
he
seemed
to
listen
to
what
the
other
side
was
doing
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
each
profile
had
a
distinct
expression
;
and
when
the
movable
side
was
most
in
action
,
the
rigid
one
was
in
its
coldest
state
of
watchfulness
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
like
turning
the
man
inside
out
,
to
pass
to
that
view
of
his
features
in
his
liveliest
mood
,
and
see
how
calculating
and
intent
they
were
.
   
<EOS>
Each
long
black
hair
upon
his
head
hung
down
as
straight
as
any
plummet
line
;
but
rumpled
tufts
were
on
the
arches
of
his
eyes
,
as
if
the
crow
whose
foot
was
deeply
printed
in
the
corners
had
pecked
and
torn
them
in
a
savage
recognition
of
his
kindred
nature
as
a
bird
of
prey
.
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
man
whom
they
now
approached
,
and
whom
the
General
saluted
by
the
name
of
Scadder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Gen'ral
,
"
he
returned
,
"
and
how
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ac
-
tive
and
spry
,
sir
,
in
my
country
's
service
and
the
sympathetic
cause
.
 
<EOS>
Two
gentlemen
on
business
,
Mr
Scadder
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
shook
hands
with
each
of
them
---
nothing
is
done
in
America
without
shaking
hands
---
then
went
on
rocking
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
know
what
bis'ness
you
have
brought
these
strangers
here
upon
,
then
,
Gen'ral
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
expect
you
may
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
air
a
tongue
-
y
person
,
Gen'ral
.
 
<EOS>
For
you
talk
too
much
,
and
that
's
fact
,
"
said
Scadder
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
speak
a
-
larming
well
in
public
,
but
you
did
n't
ought
to
go
ahead
so
fast
in
private
.
 
<EOS>
Now
!
"
   
"
If
I
can
realise
your
meaning
,
ride
me
on
a
rail
!
"
returned
the
General
,
after
pausing
for
consideration
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
know
we
did
n't
wish
to
sell
the
lots
off
right
away
to
any
loafer
as
might
bid
,
"
said
Scadder
;
"
but
had
con
-
cluded
to
reserve
'em
for
Aristocrats
of
Natur
'
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
they
are
here
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
General
with
warmth
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
here
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
they
air
here
,
"
returned
the
agent
,
in
reproachful
accents
,
"
that
's
enough
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
did
n't
ought
to
have
your
dander
ris
with
ME
,
Gen'ral
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
General
whispered
Martin
that
Scadder
was
the
honestest
fellow
in
the
world
,
and
that
he
would
n't
have
given
him
offence
designedly
,
for
ten
thousand
dollars
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
my
duty
;
and
I
raise
the
dander
of
my
feller
critters
,
as
I
wish
to
serve
,
"
said
Scadder
in
a
low
voice
,
looking
down
the
road
and
rocking
still
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
rile
up
rough
,
along
of
my
objecting
to
their
selling
Eden
off
too
cheap
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
human
natur
'
!
 
<EOS>
Well
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Scadder
,
"
said
the
General
,
assuming
his
oratorical
deportment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Sir
!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
my
hand
,
and
here
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
I
esteem
you
,
sir
,
and
ask
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
These
gentlemen
air
friends
of
mine
,
or
<EOS>
I
would
not
have
brought
'em
here
,
sir
,
being
well
aware
,
sir
,
that
the
lots
at
present
go
entirely
too
cheap
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
air
friends
,
sir
;
these
air
partick'ler
friends
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Scadder
was
so
satisfied
by
this
explanation
,
that
he
shook
the
General
warmly
by
the
hand
,
and
got
out
of
the
rocking
-
chair
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
invited
the
General
's
particular
friends
to
accompany
him
into
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
the
General
,
he
observed
,
with
his
usual
benevolence
,
that
being
one
of
the
company
,
he
would
n't
interfere
in
the
transaction
on
any
account
;
so
he
appropriated
the
rocking
-
chair
to
himself
,
and
looked
at
the
prospect
,
like
a
good
Samaritan
waiting
for
a
traveller
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heyday
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
as
his
eye
rested
on
a
great
plan
which
occupied
one
whole
side
of
the
office
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
office
had
little
else
in
it
,
but
some
geological
and
botanical
specimens
,
one
or
two
rusty
ledgers
,
a
homely
desk
,
and
a
stool
.
 
<EOS>
"
Heyday
!
<EOS>
what
's
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
Eden
,
"
said
Scadder
,
picking
his
teeth
with
a
sort
of
young
bayonet
that
flew
out
of
his
knife
when
he
touched
a
spring
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
had
no
idea
<EOS>
it
was
a
city
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Had
n't
you
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
it
's
a
city
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
flourishing
city
,
too
!
 
<EOS>
An
architectural
city
!
 
<EOS>
There
were
banks
,
churches
,
cathedrals
,
market
-
places
,
factories
,
hotels
,
stores
,
mansions
,
wharves
;
an
exchange
,
a
theatre
;
public
buildings
of
all
kinds
,
down
to
the
office
of
the
Eden
Stinger
,
a
daily
journal
;
all
faithfully
depicted
in
the
view
before
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
really
a
most
important
place
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
turning
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
's
very
important
,
"
observed
the
agent
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
Martin
,
glancing
again
at
the
Public
Buildings
,
"
that
there
's
nothing
left
for
me
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
it
ai
n't
all
built
,
"
replied
the
agent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
quite
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
great

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
market
-
place
,
now
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
built
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
That
?
"
said
the
agent
,
sticking
his
toothpick
into
the
weathercock
on
the
top
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
No
;
that
ai
n't
built
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rather
a
good
job
to
begin
with
---
eh
,
Mark
?
<EOS>
"
whispered
Martin
nudging
him
with
his

.
   
<EOS>
Mark
,
who
,
with
a
very
stolid
countenance
had
been
eyeing
the
plan
and
the
agent
by
turns
,
merely
rejoined
"
Uncommon
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
dead
silence
ensued
,
Mr
Scadder
in
some
short
recesses
or
vacations
of
his
toothpick
,
whistled
a
few
bars
of
Yankee
Doodle
,
and
blew
the
dust
off
the
roof
of
the
Theatre
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
said
Martin
,
feigning
to
look
more
narrowly
at
the
plan
,
but
showing
by
his

voice
how
much
depended
,
in
his
mind
,
upon
the
answer
;
"
I
suppose
there
are
---
several
architects
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
ai
n't
a
single
one
,
"
said
Scadder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mark
,
"
whispered
Martin
,
pulling
him
by

,
"
do
you
hear
that
?
 
<EOS>
But
whose
work
is
all
this
before
us
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
he

aloud
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
soil
being
very
fruitful
,
public
buildings
grows
spontaneous
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
on
the
agent
's
dark
side
as
he
said

;
but
Scadder
instantly
changed
his
place
,
and
brought
his

to

upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
Feel
of
my
hands
,
young
man
,
"
he
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
for
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Mark
,
declining
.
   
<EOS>
"
Air
they
dirty
,
or
air
they
clean
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
said
Scadder
,
holding
them
out
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
physical
point
of
view
they
were
decidedly
dirty
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
being
obvious
that
Mr
Scadder
offered
them
for
examination
in
a
figurative
sense
,
as
emblems
of
his
moral
character
,
Martin
hastened
to
pronounce
them
pure
as
the
driven
snow
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
entreat
,
Mark
,
"
he
said
,
with
some

,
"
that
you
will
not
obtrude
remarks
of
that
nature
,
which
,
however
harmless
and
well
-
intentioned
,
are
quite
out
of
place
,
and
can
not
be
expected
to
be
very
agreeable
to
strangers
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
quite
surprised
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
Co.
's
a
-
putting
his
foot
in
it
already
,
"
thought
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
a
sleeping
partner
---
fast
asleep
and
snoring
---
<EOS>
Co.
must
;
I
see
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Scadder
said
nothing
,
but
he
set
his
back
against
the
plan
,
and
thrust
his
toothpick
into
the
desk
some
twenty
times
;
looking
at
Mark
all
the
while
as
if
he
were
stabbing
him
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
said
whose
work
it
is
,
"
Martin
ventured
to
observe
at
length
,
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
never
mind
whose
work
it
is
,
or
is

,
"
said
the
agent
sulkily
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
matter
how
it
did
eventuate
.
 
<EOS>
P'raps
he
cleared
off
,
handsome
,
with
a
heap
of
dollars
;
p'raps
he
was
n't
worth
a
cent
.
<EOS>
P'raps
he
was
a
loafin
'
rowdy
;
p'raps
a
ring
-
tailed
roarer
.
 
<EOS>
Now
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
All
your
doing
,
Mark
!
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
P'raps
,
"
pursued
the
agent
,
"
them
ai
n't
plants
of
Eden
's
raising
.
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
P'raps
that
desk
and
stool
ai
n't
made
from
Eden
lumber
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
P'raps
<EOS>
no
end
of
squatters
ai

.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
P'raps
<EOS>
there
ai
n't
no
such
location
in
the
territoary
of
the
Great
U
-
nited
States
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
're
satisfied
with
the
success
of
your
joke
,
Mark
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
But
here
,
at
a
most

and
happy

,
the
General
interposed
,
and
called

to
Scadder
from

to
give
his

the

of
that
little
lot
of
fifty
acres
with
the
house
upon
it
;
which
,
having
belonged
to
the
company
formerly
,
had
lately
lapsed
again
into
their
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
air
a
deal
too
open
-
handed
,
Gen'ral
,
"
was
the
answer
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
lot
as
should
be
rose
in
price
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
grumblingly
opened
his
books
notwithstanding
,
and
always
keeping
his
bright
side
towards
Mark
,
no
matter
at
what
amount
of
inconvenience
to
himself
,
displayed
a
certain
leaf
for
their
perusal
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
read
it
greedily
,
and
then
inquired
:
   
"
Now
where
upon
the
plan
may
this
place
be
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
the
plan
?
"
said
Scadder
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
turned
towards
it
,
and
reflected
for
a
short
time
,
as
if
,
having
been
put
upon
his
mettle
,
he
was
resolved
to
be
particular
to
the
very
minutest
hair
's
breadth
of
a
shade
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
after
wheeling
his
toothpick
slowly
round
and
round
in
the
air
,
as
if
it
were
a
carrier
pigeon
just
thrown
up
,
he
suddenly
made
a
dart
at
the
drawing
,
and
pierced
the
very
centre
of
the
main
wharf
,
through
and
through
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
he
said
,
leaving
his

quivering
in
the
wall
;
"
that
's
where
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
glanced
with
sparkling
eyes
upon
his
Co.
,
and
his
Co.
saw
that
the
thing
was
done
.
   
<EOS>
The
bargain
was
not
concluded
as
easily
as
might
have
been
expected
though
,
for
Scadder
was
caustic
and
ill
-
humoured
,
and
cast
much
unnecessary
opposition
in
the
way
;
at
one
time
requesting
them
to
think
of
it
,
and
call
again
in
a
week
or
a

;
at
another
,
predicting
that
they
would
n't
like
it
;
at
another
,
offering
to
retract
and
let
them
off
,
and
muttering
strong
imprecations
upon
the
folly
of
the
General
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
whole
of
the
astoundingly
small
sum
total
of
purchase
-
money
<EOS>
---
it
was
only
one
hundred
and
fifty

,
or
something
more
than
thirty
pounds
of
the
capital
brought
by
Co.
into
the
architectural
concern
---
was
ultimately
paid
down
;
and
Martin
's
head
was
<EOS>
two
inches
nearer
the
roof
of
the
little
wooden
office
,
with
the
consciousness
of
being
a
landed
proprietor
in
the
thriving
city
of
Eden
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
should
n't
happen
to
fit
,
"
said
Scadder
,
as
he
gave
Martin
the
necessary

on
recepit
of

,
"
do
n't
blame
me
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
he
replied
merrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
not
blame
you
.
 
<EOS>
General
,
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
at
your
service
,
sir
;
and
I
wish
you
,
"
said
the
General
,
giving
him
his
hand
with
grave
cordiality
,
"
joy
of
your
po
-
ssession
.
<EOS>
You
air
now
,
sir
,
a
denizen
of
the
most
powerful
and
highly
-
civilised
dominion
that
has
ever
graced
the
world
;
a
do
-
minion
,
sir
,
where
man
is
bound
to
man
in
one
vast
bond
of
equal
love
and
truth
.
<EOS>
May
you
,
sir
,
be
worthy
of
your
a
-
dopted
country
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
thanked
him
,
and
took
leave
of
Mr
Scadder
;
who
had
resumed
his
post
in
the
rocking
-
chair
,
immediately
on
the
General
's
rising
from
it
,
and
was
once
more
swinging
away
as
if
he
had
never
been
disturbed
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
looked
back
several
times
as
they
went
down
the
road
towards
the
National
Hotel
,
but
now
his
blighted
profile
was
towards
them
,
and
nothing
but
attentive
thoughtfulness
was
written
on
it
.
 
<EOS>
Strangely
different
to
the
other
side
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
man
much
given
to
laughing
,
and
never
laughed
outright
;
but
every
line
in
the
print
of
the
crow
's
foot
,
and
every
little
wiry
vein
in
that
division
of
his
head
,
was
wrinkled
up
into
a
grin
!
 
<EOS>
The
compound
figure
of
Death
and
the
Lady
at
the
top
of
the
old
ballad
was
not
divided
with
a
greater
nicety
,
and
had
n't
halves
more
monstrously
unlike
each
other
,
than
the
two
profiles
of
Zephaniah
Scadder
.
   
<EOS>
The
General
posted
along
at
a
great
rate
,
for
the
clock
was
on
the
stroke
of
twelve
;
and
at
that
hour
precisely
,
the
Great
Meeting
of
the
Watertoast
Sympathisers
was
to
be
holden
in
the
public
room
of
the
National
Hotel
.
 
<EOS>
Being
very
curious
to
witness
the
demonstration
,
and
know
what
it
was
all
about
,
Martin
kept
close
to
the
General
;
and
,
keeping
closer
than
ever
when
they
entered
the
Hall
,
got
by
that
means
upon
a
little
platform
of
tables
at
the
upper
end
;
where
an
armchair
was
set
for
the
General
,
and
Mr
La
Fayette
Kettle
,
as
secretary
,
was
making
a
great
display
of
some
foolscap
documents
.
 
<EOS>
Screamers
,
no
doubt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
as
he
shook
hands
with
Martin
,
"
here
is
a
spectacle
calc'lated
to
make
the
British
Lion
put
his
tail
between
his
legs
,
and
howl
with
anguish
,
I
expect
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
certainly
thought
it
possible
that
the
British
Lion
might
have
been
rather
out
of
his
element
in
that
Ark
;
but
he
kept
the
idea
to
himself
.
 
<EOS>
The
General
was
then
voted
to
the
chair
,
on
the
motion
of
a
pallid
lad
of
the
Jefferson
Brick
school
;
who
forthwith
set
in
for
a
high
-
spiced
speech
,
with
a
good
deal
about
hearths
and
homes
in
it
,
and
unriveting
the
chains
of
Tyranny
.
   
<EOS>
Oh
<EOS>
but
it
was
a
clincher
for
the
British
Lion
,
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
The
indignation
of
the
glowing
young
Columbian
knew
no
bounds
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
could
only
have
been
one
of
his
own
forefathers
,
he
said
,
would
n't
he
have
peppered
that
same
Lion
,
and
been
to
him
as
another
Brute
Tamer
with
a
wire
whip
,
teaching
him
lessons
not
easily
forgotten
.
"
<EOS>
Lion
!
<EOS>
(
cried
that
young
Columbian
)
<EOS>
where
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
Who
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
What
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
Show
him
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
have
him
here
.
 
<EOS>
Here
!
"
said
the
young
Columbian
,
in
a
wrestling
attitude
,
"
upon
this
sacred
altar
.
<EOS>
Here
!
"
cried
the
young
Columbian
,
idealising
the
dining
-
table
,
"
upon
ancestral
ashes
,
cemented
with
the
glorious
blood
poured
out

our
native

Chickabiddy

!
 
<EOS>
Bring
forth
that
Lion
!
"
said
the
young

.
 
<EOS>
"
Alone
,
I

!
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
that
Freedom

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Who
is

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

on

,

<EOS>
It

an

:
"
Perhaps

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

,

;

,

---

;

of
its

always
,

only

because
of
their

,
which

;
labour

in

.
 
<EOS>
This

what
grounds

sympathy
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
The

"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
that

<EOS>
one

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
These

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

"
Tut
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
22
.
<EOS>
From

.
 
<EOS>
Together

reason
why

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
47

,
   
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
(
Private
)
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
---
I
was
raised
in
those
interminable
solitudes
where
our
mighty
Mississippi
(
or
Father
of
Waters
)
rolls

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
young
,
and
ardent
.
 
<EOS>
For
there
is
a
poetry
in
wildness
,
and
every
alligator
basking
in
the
slime
is
in
himself
an
Epic
,
self
-
contained
.
 
<EOS>
I
aspirate
for
fame
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
my
yearning
and
my
thirst
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
,
sir
,
aware
of
any

of

in

,
who

,

?
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
something
within
me
which
gives

this

would
not

.
 
<EOS>
In

;

,

,

;
in

or

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
May

,

"

,

,
"
by
the
Right
Honourable
Lord
Byron
?
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
Sir
,
   
<EOS>
"
Yours
(
forgive
me
if
I
add
,
soaringly
)
,
   
"
<EOS>
PUTNAM
SMIF
   
<EOS>
"
PS
.
---
Address
your
answer
to
America
Junior
,
Messrs.
Hancock
&
Floby
,
Dry
Goods
Store
,
as
above
.
"
   
<EOS>
Both
of
which
letters
,
together
with
Martin
's
reply
to
each
,
were
,
according
to
a
laudable
custom
,
much
tending
to
the
promotion
of
gentlemanly
feeling
and
social
confidence
,
published
in
the
next
number
of
the
Watertoast
Gazette
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
got
through
this
correspondence
when
Captain
Kedgick
,
the
landlord
,
kindly
came
upstairs
to
see
how
he
was
getting
on
.
 
<EOS>
The
Captain
sat
down
upon
the
bed
before
he
spoke
;
and
finding
it
rather
hard
,
moved
to
the
pillow
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
"
said
the
Captain
,
putting
his
hat
a
little
more
on
one
side
,
for
it
was
rather
tight
in
the
crown
:
"
You
're
quite
a
public
man
I
calc'late
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
it
seems
,
"
retorted
Martin
,
who
was
very
tired
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
citizens
,
sir
,
"
pursued
the
Captain
,
"
intend
to
pay
their
respects
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
have
to
hold
a
sort
of
le
-
vee
,
sir
,
while
you
're
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Powers
above
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
"
I
could
n't
do
that
,
my
good
fellow
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
reckon
you
MUST
then
,
"
said
the
Captain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Must
is
not
a
pleasant
word
,
Captain
,
"
urged
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
fix
the
mother
language
,
and
I
ca
n't
unfix
it
,
"
said
the
Captain
coolly
;
"
else
I
'd
make
it
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
re
-
ceive
.
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
why
should
I
receive
people
who
care
as
much
for
me
as
I
care
for
them
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
because
I
have
had
a
muniment
put
up
in
the
bar
,
"
returned
the
Captain
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
what
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
muniment
,
"
rejoined
the
Captain
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
looked
despairingly
at
Mark
,
who
informed
him
that
the
Captain
meant
a
written
notice
that
Mr
Chuzzlewit
would
receive
the
Watertoasters
that
day
,
at
and
after
two
o'clock
which
was
in
effect
then
hanging
in
the
bar
,
as
Mark
,
from
ocular
inspection
of
the
same
,
could
testify
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't
be
unpop'lar
,
I
know
,
"
said
the
Captain
,
paring
his
nails
.
 
<EOS>
"
Our
citizens
an't
long
of
riling
up
,
I
tell
you
;
and
our
Gazette
could
flay
you
like
a
wild
cat
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
going
to
be
very
wroth
,
but
he
thought
better
of
it
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
In
Heaven
's
name
let
them
come
,
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
THEY'll
come
,
"
returned
the
Captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
the
big
room
fixed
a'purpose
,
with
my
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
will
you
,
"
said
Martin
,
seeing
that
the
Captain
was
about
to
go
;
"
will
you
at
least
tell
me
this
?
 
<EOS>
What
do
they
want
to
see
me
for
?
<EOS>
what
have
I
done
?
<EOS>
and
how
do
they
happen
to
have
such
a
sudden
interest
in
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Captain
Kedgick
put
a
thumb
and
three

to
each
side
of
the
brim
of
his
hat
;
lifted
it
a
little

off

;
put
it
on
again
carefully
;
passed
one
hand
all
down
his
face
,
beginning
at
the
forehead
and
ending
at

chin
;
looked
at
Martin
;
then
at
Mark
;
then
at
Martin
again
;
winked
,
and
walked
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
life
,
now
!
"
said
Martin
,
bringing
his
hand
heavily
upon
the
table
;
"
such
a
perfectly
unaccountable
fellow
as
that
,
I
never
saw
.
<EOS>
Mark
,
what
do
you
say
to
this
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
returned
his
partner
,
"
my
opinion
is
that
we
must
have
got
to
the
MOST
remarkable
man
in
the
country
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
So
I
hope
there
's
an
end
to
the
breed
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
this
made
Martin
laugh
,
it
could
n't
keep
off
two
o'clock
.
<EOS>
Punctually
,
as
the
hour
struck
,
Captain
Kedgick
returned
to
hand
him
to
the
room
of
state
;
and
he
had
no
sooner
got
him
safe
there
,
than
he
bawled
down
the
staircase
to
his
fellow
-
citizens
below
,
that
Mr
Chuzzlewit
was
"
receiving
.
"
   
<EOS>
Up
<EOS>
they
came
with
a
rush
.
 
<EOS>
Up
<EOS>
they
came
until
the
room
was
full
,
and
,
through
the
open
door
,
a
dismal
perspective
of
more
to
come
,
was
shown
upon
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
One
after
another
,
one
after
another
,
dozen
after
dozen
,
score
after
score
,
more
,
more
,
more
,
up
they
came
;
all
shaking
hands
with
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Such
varieties
of
hands
,
the
thick
,
the
thin
,
the
short
,
the
long
,
the
fat
,
the
lean
,
the
coarse
,
the
fine
;
such
differences
of
temperature
,
the
hot
,
the
cold
,
the
dry
,
the
moist
,
the
flabby
;
such
diversities
of
grasp
,
the
tight
,
the
loose
,
the
short
-
lived
,
and
the
lingering
!
 
<EOS>
Still
up
,
up
,
up
,
more
,
more
,
more
;
and
ever
and
anon
the
Captain
's
voice
was
heard
above
the
crowd
---
<EOS>
"
There
's
more
below
!
<EOS>
there
's
more
below
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
gentlemen
you
that
have
been
introduced
to
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
<EOS>
will
you
clear
gentlemen
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
clear
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
be
so
good
as
clear
,
gentlemen
,
and
make
a
little
room
for
more
?
"
   
<EOS>
Regardless
of
the
Captain
's
cries
,
they
did
n't
clear
at
all
,
but
stood
there
,
bolt
upright
and
staring
.
 
<EOS>
Two
gentlemen
connected
with
the
Watertoast
Gazette
had
come
express
to
get
the
matter
for
an
article
on
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
agreed
to
divide
the
labour
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
took
him
below
the
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
One
above
.
 
<EOS>
Each
stood
directly
in
front
of
his
subject
with
his
head
a
little
on
one
side
,
intent
on
his
department
.
 
<EOS>
If
Martin
put
one
boot
before
the
other
,
the
lower
gentleman
was
down
upon
him
;
he
rubbed
a
pimple
on
his
nose
,
and
the
upper
gentleman
booked
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
opened
his
mouth
to
speak
,
and
the
same
gentleman
was
on
one
knee
before
him
,
looking
in
at
his
teeth
,
with
the
nice
scrutiny
of
a
dentist
.
 
<EOS>
Amateurs
in
the
physiognomical
and
phrenological
sciences
roved
about
him
with
watchful
eyes
and
itching
fingers
,
and
sometimes
one
,
more
daring
than
the
rest
,
made
a
mad
grasp
at
the
back
of
his
head
,
and
vanished
in
the
crowd
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
him
in
all
points
of
view
:
in
front
,
in
profile
,
three
-
quarter
face
,
and
behind
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
were
not
professional
or
scientific
,
audibly
exchanged
opinions
on
his
looks
.
 
<EOS>
New
lights
shone
in
upon
him
,
in
respect
of
his
nose
.
<EOS>
Contradictory
rumours
were
abroad
on
the
subject
of
his
hair
.
 
<EOS>
And
still
the
Captain
's
voice
was
heard
---
<EOS>
so
stifled
by
the
concourse
,
that
he
seemed
to
speak
from
underneath
a
feather
-
bed
---
exclaiming
---
 
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
you
that
have
been
introduced
to
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
WILL
you
clear
?
"
   
<EOS>
Even
when
they
began
to
clear
it
was
no
better
;
for
then
a
stream
of
gentlemen
,
every
one
with
a
lady
on
each
arm
(
exactly
like
the
chorus
to
the
National
Anthem
when
Royalty
goes
in
state
to
the
play
)
,
came
gliding
in
---
every
new
group
fresher
than
the
last
,
and
bent
on
staying
to
the
latest
moment
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
spoke
to
him
,
which
was
not
often
,
they
invariably
asked
the
same
questions
,
in
the
same
tone
;
with
no
more
remorse
,
or
delicacy
,
or
consideration
,
than
if
he
had
been
a
figure
of
stone
,
purchased
,
and
paid
for
,
and
set
up
there
for
their
delight
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
,
in
the
slow
course
of
time
,
these
died
off
,
it
was
as
bad
as
ever
,
if
not
worse
;
for
then
the
boys
grew
bold
,
and
came
in
as
a
class
of
themselves
,
and
did
everything
that
the
grown
-
up
people
had
done
.
 
<EOS>
Uncouth
stragglers
,
too
,
appeared
;
men
of
a
ghostly
kind
,
who
being
in
,
did
n't
know
how
to
get
out
again
;
insomuch
that
one
silent
gentleman
with
glazed
and
fishy
eyes
and
only
one
button
on
his
waistcoat
(
which
was
a
very
large
metal
one
,
and
shone
prodigiously
)
,
got
behind
the
door
,
and
stood
there
,
like
a
clock
,
long
after
everybody
else
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
felt
,
from
pure
fatigue
,
and
heat
,
and
worry
,
as
if
he
could
have
fallen
on
the
ground
and
willingly
remained
there
,
if
they
would
but
have
had
the
mercy
to
leave
him
alone
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
letters
and
messages
,
threatening
his
public
denouncement
if
he
did
n't
see
the
senders
,
poured
in
like
hail
;
and
as
more
visitors
came
while
he
took
his
coffee
by
himself
;
and
as
Mark
,
with
all
his
vigilance
,
was
unable
to
keep
them
from
the
door
;
he
resolved
to
go
to
bed
---
<EOS>
not
that
he
felt
at
all
sure
of
bed
being
any
protection
,
but
that
he
might
not
leave
a
forlorn
hope
untried
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
communicated
this
design
to
Mark
,
and
was
on
the
eve
of
escaping
,
when
the
door
was
thrown
open
in
a
great
hurry
,
and
an
elderly
gentleman
entered
;
bringing
with
him
a
lady
who
certainly
could
not
be
considered
young
---
that
was
matter
of
fact
;
and
probably
could
not
be
considered
handsome
---
but
that
was
matter
of
opinion
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
straight
,
very
tall
,
and
not
at
all
flexible
in
face
or
figure
.
 
<EOS>
On
her
head
she
wore
a
great
straw
bonnet
,
with
trimmings
of
the
same
,
in
which
she
looked
as
if
she
had
been
thatched
by
an
unskillful
labourer
;
and
in
her
hand
she
held
a
most
enormous
fan
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
I
believe
?
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
my
name
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
I
am
pressed
for
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
God
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
go
back
<EOS>
Toe
<EOS>
my
home
,
sir
,
"
pursued

,
"
by

,

.
 
<EOS>
Start
is
not

word
you
use
in
your
country
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
it
is
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
air
mistaken
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
gentleman
,
with

:
"
but
we

,
lest

should
awake

preju
---
dice
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
,
Mrs
Hominy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Hominy
,

,
is
the
lady
of
Major
Hominy
,
one
of
our
chicest

;
and

Toe

.
 
<EOS>
You
air
,
p'raps
,
acquainted
,

,
with
Mrs
Hominy
's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
could
n't

was
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
much
Toe
learn
,
and
Toe
enjoy
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Hominy
is
going
<EOS>
Toe

Fall
,
sir
,
with
her
married
daughter
at

New

,
three

this

Eden
.
 
<EOS>
Any

,

,

Toe

Hominy
upon

,
will
be
very
grateful
<EOS>
Toe

-

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Hominy
,
I
wish

,

,

pro
-
gress
on

!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
could
scarcely
believe
it
;
but
he
had
gone
,
and
Mrs
Hominy
was
drinking

.
   
<EOS>
"
A'most
used
-
up
I
am
,
I
do
declare
!
"
<EOS>
she
observed
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
jolting
in
the
cars
is
pretty
nigh
as
bad
as
if
the
rail
was
full
of
snags
and

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Snags
and
sawyers
,
ma'am
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
I
do
suppose

'll
hardly

,

,
"
said

Hominy
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
!
 
<EOS>
Only
think
!
 
<EOS>
DO
tell
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
did
not
appear
that
these

,
although
they
seemed
to

,
stood
in

;
for
Mrs

,
untying

strings
,
<EOS>
observed
that
she
would
withdraw
to
lay
that
article
of
dress
aside
,
and
would

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mark
!
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Touch

,

.
 
<EOS>
Am

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hominy

,

,
"

"
Broad

!
 
<EOS>
Just
the

,

<EOS>
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
very

<EOS>

<EOS>
Martin

<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
"

,

"

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

---

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Mrs

<EOS>
Mrs

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

sound
<EOS>

in

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
Farmers

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Chapter
23
.
<EOS>
Martin
and
his

take

.
 
<EOS>
The
joyful

involves

of
Eden
 
There

on

<EOS>
several

,

Martin

;

.
 
<EOS>
They
released

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

Intellect

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Having

,

bad
ones
,
"
returned
Mr
Tapley
,
"
would
look
as
if
they
was
rather
a
poor
sort
of
carpenters
,
sir
,
would

it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
nodded
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
if
their
work
were
infinitely
above
their
powers
and
purpose
,
Mark
;
and
they
botched
it
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
best
on
it
is
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
that
when
they
do
happen
to
make

decent
stroke
;
such
as
better
workmen
,
with
no

,
make
every

of

and
think
nothing
of
---
they
begin
to
sing
out
so
surprising

.
 
<EOS>
Take
notice
of
my
words
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
If

the
defaulting
part
of
this
here

pays

---
along
of
finding
that
not

'em
wo

do
in
a
commercial

,
you
see
,
and
is
inconvenient
in
its
consequences
<EOS>
---
they

,

,
that

suppose
no

afore
,

.
 
<EOS>
That
's

gammon

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
<EOS>
,
I
know
'em
.
 
<EOS>
Take
notice
of
my
words
,
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
seem
to
be
growing
profoundly

!
"
<EOS>
cried

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Whether

,
"
thought

,
"
because
I
'm
a
day
's

nearer
Eden
,
and
am
brightening
up
afore
<EOS>
I
die
,
I
ca

say
.
 
<EOS>
P'rhaps

get

I
shall
have
growed
into
a
prophet
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
gave
no
utterance
to
these
sentiments
;
but
the
excessive
joviality
they
inspired
within
him
,
and
the

they
brought
upon
his
shining
face
,
were
quite
enough
for
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
might
sometimes
profess
to
make
light
of
his
partner
's
inexhaustible
cheerfulness
,
and
might
sometimes
,
as
in
the

of
Zephaniah
Scadder

too

commentator
,
he
was
always
sensible
of
the
effect
of
his
example
in
rousing
him
to
hopefulness
and
courage
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
were
in
the
humour
to
profit
by
it
,
mattered
not
a
jot
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
contagious
,
and
he
could
not
choose
but
be
affected
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
they
parted
with
some
of
their
passengers
once
or
twice
a
day
,
and
took
in
others
to
replace
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
by
degrees
,
the
towns
upon
their
route
became
more
thinly
scattered
;
and
for
many
hours
together
they
would
see
no
other
habitations
than
the
huts
of
the
wood
-

,
where
the
vessel
stopped
for
fuel
.
 
<EOS>
Sky
,
wood
,
and
water
all
the
livelong
day
;
and
heat
that
blistered
everything
it
touched
.
   
<EOS>
On
they
toiled
through
great
solitudes
,
where
the
trees
upon
the
banks
grew
thick
and
close
;
and
floatad
in
the
stream
;
and
held
up
shrivelled
arms
from
out
the
river
's
depths
;
and
slid
down
from
the
margin
of
the
land
,
half
growing
,
half
decaying
,
in
the
miry
water
.
<EOS>
On
through
the
weary
day
and
melancholy

;
beneath
the
burning

,
and
in
the
mist
and

of
the
evening
;
on
,
until
return
appeared
impossible
,
and
restoration
to
their
home
a

dream
.
   
<EOS>
They
had
now
<EOS>
but
few
people
on
board
,
and
these
few
were
as
flat
,
as

,
and
stagnant
,
as
the
vegetation
that
oppressed
their
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
No
sound
of
cheerfulness
or
hope
was
heard
;
no
pleasant
talk
beguiled
the
tardy

;
no
little
group
made
common
cause
against
the
full
depression
of
the
scene
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
,

,
they
swallowed
food
together
from
a
common
trough
<EOS>
,

might
have
been
old
Charon
's
boat
,
conveying
melancholy

to
judgment
.
   
<EOS>
At
length
they
drew
near
New
Thermopylae
;
where
,
that

,
Mrs
Hominy
would

.
 
<EOS>
A

of

sunk
into
Martin
's

this
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
needed
none
;
but
he
was
not

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
almost
night
when
they
came
alongside
the

-

.
 
<EOS>
A
steep
bank
with
an

like

on
the

;
a

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

here
to
-

,
and
go

in

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
!
<EOS>
ai

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
Martin

;

"

<EOS>
"
THAT

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
that
;

,

,
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Martin
gratefully

their

to
regale
himself
at
their
house
during
the
half

of
the
vessel
's

;
and

Mrs

and
the
red
pocket
-

(
which

)
safely

,

in

as

.
   
<EOS>
Mark
,

,

in

from

;
anxious

,

that

before

,
so
that

blow

might

.
 
<EOS>
But

sometimes

erections
on

,
he
gave

no

what

in

,
until

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mark
,
"

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
None

,

.
 
<EOS>
Most

,

you

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>
More

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

---
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

?
"
observed

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ai

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Even
Eden
,
you

,
ai

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

Eden

.
 
<EOS>
Are

?
 
<EOS>
There
---
God

!
---
<EOS>
do

!
"
   
<EOS>
After

,

,
and

to

upon
the
deck
full

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

,

,
"
until

;
nor

,
but

.
   
<EOS>
As
they
proceeded
further
on
their
track
,
and
came
more
and
more
towards
their
journey
's
end
,
the
monotonous

of
the
scene
increased
to
that

,
that
for
any
redeeming
feature
it

to

,
they
might
have
entered
,
in
the
body
,
on
the
grim

of
Giant
Despair
.
 
<EOS>
A
flat
morass
,
bestrewn
with
fallen
timber
<EOS>
;
a
marsh
on
which
the
good
growth
of
the
earth
seemed
to
have
been
wrecked
and
cast
away
,
that
from
its
decomposing
ashes
vile
and
ugly
things
might
rise
;
where
the
very
trees
took
the
aspect
of
huge
weeds
,
begotten
of
the
slime
from
which
they
sprung
,
by
the
hot
sun
that
burnt
them
up
;
where
fatal
maladies
,
seeking
whom
they
might
infect
,
came
forth
at

in
misty

,
and
creeping
out
upon
the
water
,
hunted
them
like
spectres
until

;
where
even

,

of

and

,
became
a
horror
;
this
was
the
realm
of
Hope
through
which
they
moved
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
they
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
At
Eden
too
.
 
<EOS>
The
waters
of
the
Deluge
might
have
left
it
but
a
week
before
;
so
choked
with
slime
and
matted
growth
was
the
hideous
swamp
which
bore
that
name
.
   
<EOS>
There
being
no
depth
of
water
close
in
shore
,
they
landed
from
the
vessel
's
boat
,
with
all
their

beside

.
 
<EOS>
There
were
a
few
log
-
houses
visible
among
the
dark
trees
;
the
best
,
a

-

or

;
but
for
the
wharves
,
the

-

,
the

---
    
<EOS>
"
Here

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
'll

to

.
 
<EOS>
Keep

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hallo
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
man
advanced

through

,
very

;

.
 
<EOS>
As

drew

,
they

was

,
and
that

<EOS>
His

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

his

,
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Strangers
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
very

,
"

Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
How

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
had
the
fever
very

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
stood

these
many

.
 
<EOS>
Those

your
notions
I

,
"
pointing

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
You
could

---

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

---

<EOS>

"

"

,

<EOS>
"

,
"
knocking

"

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Them

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
night

ai

,

?
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"
was

's

.
   
<EOS>
Mark

no

than
if

had
been
commended

as

;
but

the

his

,
and
as

explained
to

the

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Close
to
his
own
log
-

,
he

;
so
close
that
he
had
used

as
a

for
some

;
they
must

that

,
but
he
would
endeavour
to
get
it
taken
out
upon
the
morrow
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
gave
them
to
understand
,
as
an
additional
scrap
of
local
chit
-
chat
,
that
he
had
buried
the
last
proprietor
with
his
own
hands
;
a
piece
of
information
which
Mark
also
received
without
the
least
abatement
of
his
equanimity
.
   
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
he
conducted
them
to
a
miserable
cabin
,
rudely
constructed
of
the
trunks
of
trees
;
the
door
of
which
had
either
fallen
down
or
been
carried
away
long
ago
;
and
which
was
consequently
open
to
the
wild
landscape
and
the
dark
night
.
 
<EOS>
Saving
for
the
little
store
he
had
mentioned
,
it
was
perfectly
bare
of
all
furniture
;
but
they
had
left
a
chest
upon
the
landing
-
place
,
and
he
gave
them
a
rude
torch
in
lieu
of
candle
.
 
<EOS>
This
latter
acquisition
Mark
planted
in
the
earth
,
and
then
declaring
that
the
mansion
"
looked
quite
comfortable
,
"
hurried
Martin
off
again
to
help
bring
up
the
chest
.
 
<EOS>
And
all
the
way
to
the
landing
-
place
and
back
,
Mark
talked
incessantly
;
as
if
he
would
infuse
into
his
partner
's
breast
some
faint
belief
that
they
had
arrived
under
the
most
auspicious
and
cheerful
of
all
imaginable
circumstances
.
   
<EOS>
But
many
a
man
who
would
have
stood
within
a
home
dismantled
,
strong
in
his
passion
and
design
of
vengeance
,
has
had
the
firmness
of
his
nature
conquered
by
the
razing
of
an
air
-
built
castle
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
log
-
hut
received
them
for
the
second
time
,
Martin
laid
down
upon
the
ground
,
and
wept
aloud
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
love
you
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Tapley
,
in
great
terror
;
"
Do
n't
do
that
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
do
that
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Anything
but
that
!
 
<EOS>
It
never
helped
man
,
woman
,
or
child
,
over
the
lowest
fence
yet
,
sir
,
and
it
never
will
.
<EOS>
Besides
its
being
of
no
use
to
you
,
it
's
worse
than
of
no
use
to
me
,
for
the
least
sound
of
it
will
knock
me
flat
down
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
stand
up
agin
it
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Anything
but
that
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
is
no
doubt
he
spoke
the
truth
,
for
the
extraordinary
alarm
with
which
he
looked
at
Martin
as

paused
upon

the
chest
,
in

,
to

,
sufficiently
confirmed

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your
forgiveness
a
thousand
times
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
have
helped
it
,
if
death
had
been
the
penalty
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
my
forgiveness
!
"
<EOS>
said
Mark
,
with
his
accustomed
cheerfulness
,
as
he
proceeded
to
unpack
the
chest
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
head
partner
a
-
asking
forgiveness
of
Co.
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
There
must
be
something
wrong
in
the
firm
when
that
happens
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
the
books
inspected
and
the
accounts
gone
over
immediate
.
 
<EOS>
Here
we
are
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
in
its
proper
place
.
<EOS>
Here
's
the
salt
pork
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
biscuit
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
whiskey
.
<EOS>
Uncommon
good
it
smells
too
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
tin
pot
.
 
<EOS>
This
tin
pot
's
a
small
fortun
"
in
itself
!
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
blankets
.
 
<EOS>
Here
's
the
axe
.
 
<EOS>
Who
says
we
ai
n't
got
a
first
-
rate
fit
out
?
 
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
I
was
a
cadet
gone
out
to
Indy
,
and
my
noble
father
was
chairman
of
the
Board
of
Directors
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
when
I
've
got
some
water
from
the
stream
afore
the
door
and
mixed
the
grog
,
"
cried
Mark
,
running

to
suit
the
action
to

word
,
"
there
's
a
supper
ready
,
comprising
every

of
the
season
.
 
<EOS>
Here
we
are
,
sir
,
all
complete
.
 
<EOS>
For
what
we
are
going
to
receive
,
et
cetrer
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
bless
you
,
sir
<EOS>
,
it
's
very
like
a
gipsy
party
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
not
to
take
heart
,
in
the
company
of
such
a
man
as
this
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
sat
upon
the
ground
beside
the
box
;
took
out
his
knife
;
and
ate
and
drank
sturdily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
you
see
,
"
said
Mark
,
when
they
had
made
a
hearty
meal
;
"
with
your
knife
and
mine
,
I
sticks
this
blanket
right
afore
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Or
where
,
in
a
state
of
high
civilization
,
the
door
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
And
very
neat
<EOS>
it
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
stops
the
aperture
below
,
by
putting
the
chest
agin
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
very
neat
<EOS>
THAT
looks
.
 
<EOS>
Then
there
's
your
blanket
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Then
here
's
mine
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
's
to
hinder
our
passing
a
good
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
For
all
his
light
-
hearted
speaking
,
it
was
long
before
he
slept
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
wrapped
his
blanket
round
him
,
put
the
axe
ready
to
his
hand
,
and
lay
across
the
threshold
of
the
door
;
too
anxious
and
too
watchful
to
close
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
The
novelty
of
their
dreary
situation
,
the
dread
of
some
rapacious
animal
or
human
enemy
,
the
terrible
uncertainty
of
their
means
of
subsistence
,
the
apprehension
of
death
,
the
immense
distance
and
the
hosts
of
obstacles
between
themselves
and
England
,
were
fruitful
sources
of
disquiet
in
the
deep
silence
of
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Though
Martin
would
have
had
him
think
<EOS>
otherwise
,
Mark
felt
that
he
was
waking
also
,
and
a
prey
to
the
same
reflections
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
almost
worse
than
all
,
for
if
he
began
to
brood
over
their
miseries
instead
of
trying
to
make
head
against
them
there
could
be
little
doubt
that
such
a
state
of
mind
would
powerfully
assist
the
influence
of
the
pestilent
climate
.
 
<EOS>
Never
had
the
light
of
day
been
half
so
welcome
to
his
eyes
,
<EOS>
as
when
awaking
from
a
fitful
doze
,
Mark
saw
it
shining
through
the
blanket
in
the
doorway
.
   
<EOS>
He
stole
out
gently
,
for
his
companion
was
sleeping
now
;
and
having
refreshed
himself
by
washing
in
the
river
,
where
it
snowed
before
the
door
,
took
a
rough
survey
of
the
settlement
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
not
above
a
score
of
cabins
in
the
whole
;
half
of
these
appeared
untenanted
;
all
were
rotten
and
decayed
.
 
<EOS>
The
most
tottering
,
abject
,
and
forlorn
among
them
was
called
,
with
great
propriety
,
the
Bank
,
and
National
Credit
Office
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
some
feeble
props
about
it
,
but
was
settling
deep
down
in
the
mud
,
past
all
recovery
.
   
<EOS>
Here
and
there
an
effort
had
been
made
to
clear
the
land
,
and
something
like
a
field
had
been
marked
out
,
where
,
among
the
stumps
and
ashes
of
burnt
trees
,
a
scanty
crop
of
Indian
corn
was
growing
.
<EOS>
In
some
quarters
,
a
snake
or
zigzag
fence
had
been
begun
,
but
in
no
instance
had
it
been
completed
;
and
the
felled
logs
,
half
hidden
in
the
soil
,
lay
mouldering
away
.
 
<EOS>
Three
or
four
meagre
dogs
,
wasted
and
vexed
with
hunger
;
some
long
-
legged
pigs
,
wandering
away
into
the
woods
in
search
of
food
;
some
children
,
nearly
naked
,
gazing
at
him
from
the
huts
;
were
all
the
living
things
he
saw
.
 
<EOS>
A
fetid
vapour
,
hot
and
sickening
as
the
breath
of
an
oven
,
rose
up
from
the
earth
,
and
hung
on
everything
around
;
and
as
his
foot
-
prints
sunk
into
the
marshy
ground
,
a
black
ooze
started
forth
to
blot
them
out
.
   
<EOS>
Their
own
land
was
mere
forest
.
 
<EOS>
The
trees
had
grown
so
think
and
close
that
they
shouldered
one
another
out
of
their
places
,
and
the
weakest
,
forced
into
shapes
of
strange
distortion
,
languished
like
cripples
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
were
stunted
,
from
the
pressure
and
the
want
of
room
;
and
high
about
the
stems
of
all
grew
long
rank
grass
,
dank
weeds
,
and
frowsy
underwood
;
not
divisible
into
their
separate
kinds
,
but
tangled
all
together
in
a
heap
;
a
jungle
deep
and
dark
,
with
neither
earth
nor
water
at
its
roots
,
but
putrid
matter
,
formed
of
the
pulpy
offal
of
the
two
,
and
of
their
own
corruption
.
   
<EOS>
He
went
down
to
the
landing
-
place
where
they
had
left
their
goods
last
night
;
and
there
he
found
some
half
-
dozen
men
---
wan
and
forlorn
to
look
at
,
but
ready
enough
to
assist
---
who
helped
him
to
carry
them
to
the
log
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
They
shook
their
heads
in
speaking
of
the
settlement
,
and
had
no
comfort
to
give
him
.
 
<EOS>
Those
who
had
the
means
of
going
away
had
all
deserted
it
.
 
<EOS>
They
who
were
left
had
lost
their
wives
,
their
children
,
friends
,
or
brothers
there
,
and
suffered
much
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Most
of
them
were
ill
then
;
none
were
the
men
they
had
been
once
.
 
<EOS>
They
frankly
offered
their
assistance
and
advice
,
and
,
leaving
him
for
that
time
,
went
sadly
off
upon
their
several
tasks
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
by
this
time
stirring
;
but
he
had
greatly
changed
,
even
in
one
night
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
pale
and
languid
;
he
spoke
of
pains
and
weakness
in
his
limbs
,
and
complained
that
his
sight
was
dim
,
and
his
voice
feeble
.
 
<EOS>
Increasing
in
his
own
briskness
as
the
prospect
grew
more
and
more
dismal
,
Mark
brought
away
a
door
from
one
of
the
deserted
houses
,
and
fitted
it
to
their
own
habitation
;
then
went
back
again
for
a
rude
bench
he
had
observed
,
with
which
he
presently
returned
in
triumph
;
and
having
put
this
piece
of
furniture
outside
the
house
,
arranged
the
notable
tin
pot
and
other
such
movables
upon
it
,
that
it
might
represent
a
dresser
or
a
sideboard
.
 
<EOS>
Greatly
satisfied
with
this
arrangement
,
he
next
rolled
their
cask
of
flour
into
the
house
and
set
it
up
on
end
in
one
corner
,
where
it
served
for
a
side
-
table
.
 
<EOS>
No
better
dining
-
table
could
be
required
than
the
chest
,
which
he
solemnly
devoted
to
that
useful
service
thenceforth
.
<EOS>
Their
blankets
,
clothes
,
and
the
like
<EOS>
,
he
hung
on
pegs
and
nails
.
<EOS>
And
lastly
,
he
brought
forth
a
great
placard
(
which
Martin
in
the
exultation
of
his
heart
had
prepared
with
his
own

at
the
National
Hotel
)
bearing
the
inscription
,
CHUZZLEWIT
&
CO
.
,
ARCHITECTS
AND
SURVEYORS
,
which
he

upon
the
most

,
with

as
if
the
thriving
city
of
Eden
had
a
real
existence
,
and
they
expected
to
be
overwhelmed
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
These
here
tools
,
"
said
Mark
,
bringing
forward
Martin
's
case
of

and
sticking
the

upright
in
a
stump
before
the
door
,
"
shall
be
set
out
in
the
open
air
to
show
that
we
come
provided
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
if
any
gentleman
wants
a
house
built
,
he
'd
better
give
his
orders
<EOS>
,
afore
we
're
other
ways
bespoke
.
"
   
<EOS>
Considering
the
intense
heat
of
the
weather
,
this
was
not
a
bad
morning
's
work
;
but
without
pausing
for
a
moment
,
though
he
was
streaming
at
every
pore
,
Mark
vanished
into
the
house
again
,
and
presently
reappeared
with
a
hatchet
;
intent
on
performing
some
impossibilities
with
that
implement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Here
's
ugly
old
tree
in
the
way
,
sir
,
"
he
observed
,
"
which'll
be
all
the
better
down
.
 
<EOS>
We
can
build
the
oven
in
the
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
There
never
was
such
a
handy
spot
for
clay
as
Eden
is
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
convenient
,
anyhow
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
Martin
gave
him
no
answer
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
sat
the
whole
time
with
his
head
upon
his
hands
,
gazing
at
the
current
as
it
rolled
swiftly
by
;
thinking
,
perhaps
,
how
fast
it
moved
towards
the
open
sea
,
the
high
road
to
the
home
he
never
would
behold
again
.
   
<EOS>
Not
even
the
vigorous
strokes
which
Mark
dealt
at
the
tree
awoke
him
from
his
mournful
meditation
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
all
his
endeavours
to
rouse
him
of
no
use
,
Mark
stopped
in
his
work
and
came
towards
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
give
in
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mark
,
"
returned
his
friend
,
"
what
have
I
done
in
all
my
life
that
has
deserved
this
heavy
fate
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
,
"
for
the
matter
of
that
<EOS>
,
everybody
as
is
here
might
say
the
same
thing
;
many
of
'em
with
better
reason
p'raps
than
you
or
me
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
up
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Do
something
.
 
<EOS>
Could
n't
you
ease
your
mind
,
now
,
do
n't
you
think
,
by
making
some
personal
obserwations
in
a
letter
to
Scadder
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Martin
,
shaking
his
head
sorrowfully
:
"
I
am
past
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
're
past
that
already
,
"
returned
Mark
,
"
you
must
be
ill
,
and
ought
to
be
attended

<EOS>
"

eyes
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
gazed
at
him
for
a
moment
with
a
look
of
wonder
,
repeating
to
himself
,
"
Here
now
!
 
<EOS>
In
this
house
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
mastered
his
surprise
,
and
said
,
after
a
pause
:
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
a
friendly
spirit
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Forgive
me
,
sir
<EOS>
but
he
is
in
the
receipt
of
my
humble
hospitality
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
"
replied
the
old
man
,
"
let
me
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
were
disposed
to
regard
him
in
any
other
than
a
friendly
spirit
,
I
should
have
said
keep
us
apart
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Certainly
,
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
So
you
would
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
frankness
itself
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
break
this
happiness
to
him
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as
he
left
the
room
,
"
if
you
will
excuse
me
for
a
minute
---
gently
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
paved
the
way
to
the
disclosure
so
very
gently
,
<EOS>
that
a
quarter
of
an
hour
elapsed
before
he
returned
with
Mr
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
the
young
ladies
had
made
their
appearance
,
and
the
table
had
been
set
out
for
the
refreshment
of
the
travellers
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
however
well
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
his
morality
,
had
taught
Jonas
the
lesson
of
dutiful
behaviour
to
his
uncle
,
and
however
perfectly
Jonas
,
in
the
cunning
of
his
nature
,
had
learnt
it
,
that
young
man
's
bearing
,
when
presented
to
his
father
's
brother
,
was
anything
but
manly
or
engaging
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
indeed
,
so
singular
a
mixture
of
defiance
and
obsequiousness
,
of
fear
and
hardihood
,
of
dogged

and
an
attempt
at
enraging
and
propitiation
,
never
was
expressed
in
any
one
human
figure
as
in
that
of
Jonas
<EOS>
,
when
,
having
raised
his
downcast
eyes
to
Martin
's
face
,
he
let
them
fall
again
,
and
uneasily
closing
and
unclosing
his
hands
without
a
moment
's
intermission
,
stood
swinging
himself
from
side
to
side
,
waiting
to
be
addressed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nephew
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
been
a
dutiful
son
,
I
hear
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
dutiful
as
sons
in
general
,
I
suppose
,
"
returned
Jonas
,
looking
up
and
down
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
brag
to
have
been
any
better
than
other
sons
;
but
I
have
n't
been
any
worse
,
I
dare
say
.
"
   
"
A
pattern
to
all
sons
,
I
am
told
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
glancing
towards
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
"
said
Jonas
,
looking
up
again
for
a
moment
,
and
shaking
his
head
,
"
I
've
been
as
good
a
son
as
ever
<EOS>
you
were
a
brother
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
pot
and
the
kettle
,
if
you
come
to
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
speak
bitterly
,
in
the
violence
of
your
regret
,
"
said
Martin
,
after
a
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
me
your
hand
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
did
so
,
and
was
almost
at
his
ease
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pecksniff
,
"
he
whispered
,
as
they
drew
their
chairs
about
the
table
;
"
I
gave
him
as
good
as
he
brought
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
He
had
better
look
at
home
,
before
he
looks
out
of
window
,
I
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
only
answered
by
a
nudge
of
the
elbow
,
which
might
either
be
construed
into
an
indignant
remonstrance
or
a
cordial
assent
;
but
which
,
in
any
case
,
was
an
emphatic
admonition
to
his
chosen
son
-
in
-
law
to
be
silent
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
proceeded
to
do
the
honours
of
the
house
with
his
accustomed
ease
and
amiability
.
   
<EOS>
But
not
even
Mr
Pecksniff
's
guileless
merriment
could
set
such
a
party
at
their
ease
,
or
reconcile
materials
so
utterly
discordant
and
conflicting
as
those
with
which
he
had
to
deal
.
 
<EOS>
The
unspeakable
jealously
and
hatred
which
that
night
's
explanation
had
sown
in
Charity
's
breast
,
was
not
to
be
so
easily
kept
down
;
and
more
than
once
it
showed
itself
in
such
intensity
,
as
seemed
to
render
a
full
disclosure
of
all
the
circumstances
then
and
there
,
impossible
to
be
avoided
.
 
<EOS>
The
beauteous
Merry
,
too
,
with
all
the
glory
of
her
conquest
fresh
upon
her
,
so
probed
and
lanced
the
rankling
disappointment
of
her
sister
by
her
capricious
airs
and
thousand
little
trials
of
Mr
Jonas
's
obedience
,
that
she
almost
goaded
her
into
a
fit
of
madness
,
and
obliged
her
to
retire
from
table
in
a
burst
of
passion
,
hardly
less
vehement
than
that
to
which
she
had
abandoned
herself
in
the
first
tumult
of
her
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
The
constraint
imposed
upon
the
family
by
the
presence
among
them
for
the
first
time
of
Mary
Graham
(
for
by
that
name
old
Martin
Chuzzlewit
had
introduced
her
)
did
not
at
all
improve
this
state
of
things
;
gentle
and
quiet
though
her
manner
was
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
situation
was
peculiarly
trying
;
for
,
<EOS>
what
with
having
constantly
to
keep
the
peace
between
his
daughters
;
to
maintain
a
reasonable
show
of
affection
and
unity
in
his
household
;
to
curb
the
growing
ease
and
gaiety
of
Jonas
,
which
vented
itself
in
sundry
insolences
towards
Mr
Pinch
,
and
an
indefinable
coarseness
of
manner
in
reference
to
Mary
(
they
being
the
two
dependants
)
;
to
make
no
mention
at
all
of
his
having
perpetually
to
conciliate
his
rich
old
relative
,
and
to
smooth
down
,
or
explain
away
,
some
of
the
ten
thousand
bad
appearances
and
combinations
of
bad
appearances
,
by
which
they
were
surrounded
on
that
unlucky
evening
---
<EOS>
what
with
having
to
do
this
,
and
it
would
be
difficult
to
sum
up
how
much
more
,
without
the
least
relief
or
assistance
from
anybody
,
it
may
be
easily
imagined
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
in
his
enjoyment
something
more
than
that
usual
portion
of
alloy
which
is
mixed
up
with
the
best
of
men
's
delights
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
had
never
in
his
life
felt
such
relief
as
when
old
Martin
,
looking
at
his
watch
,
announced
that
it
was
time
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
rooms
,
"
he
said
,
"
at
the
Dragon
,
for
the
present
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
fancy
for
the
evening
walk
.
 
<EOS>
The
nights
are
dark
just
now
;
perhaps
Mr
Pinch
would
not
object
to
light
us
home
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
sir
!
"
cried
Pecksniff
,
"
I
shall
be
delighted
.
 
<EOS>
Merry
,
my
child
,
the
lantern
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
lantern
,
if
you
please
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Martin
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
could
n't
think
of
taking
your
father
out
of
doors
to
-
night
;
and
,
to
be
brief
,
I
wo
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
already
had
his
hat
in
his
hand
,
but
it
was
so
emphatically
said
that
he
paused
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
Mr
Pinch
,
or
go
alone
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Which
shall

be
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
Thomas
,
sir
,
"
cried
Pecksniff
,
"
since
you
are
so
resolute
upon

.
 
<EOS>
Thomas
,
my
friend
,
be
very

,
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
in
some
need
of
this
injunction
,
for
he
felt
so
nervous
,
and
trembled
to
such
a

,
that
he

difficult
to
hold

.
 
<EOS>
How

when
,
at
the
old
man
's

she
drew
her
hand
through
his
---
Tom
Pinch
's
---
arm
!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Martin
,
<EOS>
on
the
way
,
"
you
are
very
comfortably
situated
here
;
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
answered
,
with
even
more
than
his
usual
enthusiasm
,
that
he
was
under
obligations
to
Mr
Pecksniff
which
the
devotion
of
a
lifetime
would
but
imperfectly
repay
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
long
have
you
known
my
nephew
?
"

Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
nephew
,

?
"
faltered
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
,
"
said
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
yes
,
"
cried
Tom
,
greatly
relieved
,
for
his
mind
was
running
upon
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Certainly
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
spoke
to
him
before
to
-
night
,
sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
half
a
lifetime
will
suffice
for
the
acknowledgment
of
HIS
kindness
,
"
observed
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
felt
that
this
was
a
rebuff
for
him
,
and
could
not
but
understand
it
as
a
left
-
handed
hit
at
his
employer
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
was
silent
.
 
<EOS>
Mary
felt
that
Mr
Pinch
was
not
remarkable
for
presence
of
mind
,
and
that
he
could
not
say
too
little
under
existing
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
So
SHE
was
silent
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
disgusted
by
what
in
his
suspicious
nature
he
considered
a
shameless
and
fulsome
puff
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
which
was
a
part
of
Tom
's
hired
service
and
in
which
he
was
determined
to
persevere
,
set
him
down
at
once
for
a
deceitful
,
servile
,
miserable
fawner
.
 
<EOS>
So
HE
was
silent
.
 
<EOS>
And
though
they
were
all
sufficiently
uncomfortable
,
it
is
fair
to
say
that
Martin
was
perhaps
the
most
so
;
for
he
had
felt
kindly
towards
Tom
at
first
,
and
had
been
interested
by
his
seeming
simplicity
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
like
the
rest
,
"
he
thought
,
glancing
at
the
face
of
the
unconscious
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
had
nearly
imposed
upon
me
,
but
you
have
lost
your
labour
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
too
zealous
<EOS>
a
toad
-
eater
,
and
betray
yourself
,
Mr
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
During
the
whole
remainder
of
the
walk
,
not
another
word
was
spoken
.
<EOS>
First
among
the
meetings
to
which
Tom
had
long
looked
forward
with
a
beating
heart
,
it
was
memorable
for
nothing
but
embarrassment
and
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
They
parted
at
the
Dragon
door
;
and
sighing
as
he
extinguished
the
candle
in
the
lantern
,
Tom
turned
back
again
over
the
gloomy
fields
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
approached
the
first
stile
,
which
was
in
a
lonely
part
,
made
very
dark
by
a
plantation
of
young
firs
,
a
man
slipped
past
him
and
went
on
before
.
 
<EOS>
Coming
to
the
stile
he
stopped
,
and
took
his
seat
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
was
rather
startled
,
and
for
a
moment
stood
still
,
but
he
stepped
forward
again
immediately
,
and
went
close
up
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Jonas
;
swinging
his
legs
to
and
fro
,
sucking
the
head
of
a
stick
,
and
looking
with
a
sneer
at
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
me
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Tom
,
"
who
would
have
thought
of
its
being
you
!
 
<EOS>
You
followed
us
,
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
to
you
?
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
to
the
devil
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
very
civil
,
I
think
,
"
remarked
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Civil
enough
for
YOU
,
"
retorted
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
One
who
has
as
good
a
right
to
common
consideration
as
another
,
"
said
Tom
mildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
liar
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
a
right
to
any
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
n't
a
right
to
anything
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
a
pretty
sort
of
fellow
to
talk
about
your
rights
,
upon
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
---
 
Rights
,
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
proceed
in
this
way
,
"
returned
Tom
,
reddening
,
"
you
will
oblige
me
to
talk
about
my
wrongs
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
hope
your
joke
is
over
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
way
with
you
curs
,
"
said
Mr
Jonas
,
"
that
when
you
know
a
man
's
in
real
earnest
,
you
pretend
to
think
he
's
joking
,
so
that
you
may
turn
it
off
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
wo
n't
do
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
too
stale
.
 
<EOS>
Now
just
attend
to
me
for
a
bit
,
Mr
Pitch
,
or
Witch
,
or
Stitch
,
or
whatever
your
name
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Pinch
,
"
observed
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
the
goodness
to
call
me
by
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
 
<EOS>
You
must
n't
even
be
called
out
of
your
name
,
must
n't
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pauper
"
prentices
are
looking
up
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
Ecod
,
we
manage
'em
a
little
better
in
the
city
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
what
you
do
in
the
city
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
got
to
say
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
this
,
Mister
Pinch
,
"
retorted
Jonas
,
thrusting
his

so
close
to
Tom
's
that
Tom
was
obliged
to
retreat
a
