.
 
<EOS>
"
I
advise
you
to
keep
your
own
counsel
,
and
to
avoid
title
-
tattle
,
and
not
to
cut
in
where
you
're
not
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
heard
something
of
you
,
my
friend
,
and
your
meek
ways
;
and
I
recommend
you
to
forget
'em
till
I
am
married
to
one
of
Pecksniff
's
gals
,
and
not
to
curry
favour
among
my
relations
,
but
to
leave
the
course
clear
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
,
when
curs
wo
n't
leave
the
course
clear
,
they
're
whipped
off
;
so
this
is
kind
advice
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
?
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
 
<EOS>
Damme
,
who
are
you
,
"
cried
Jonas
,
with
increased
contempt
,
"
that
you
should
walk
home
with
THEM
,
unless
it
was
behind
'em
,
like
any
other
servant
out
of
livery
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
"
<EOS>
I
see
that
you
had
better
get
off
the
stile
,
and
let
me
pursue
my
way
home
.
 
<EOS>
Make
room
for
me
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
think
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
Jonas
,
spreading
out
his
legs
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
till
I
choose
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
do
n't
choose
now
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
afraid
of
my
making
you
split
upon
some
of
your
babbling
just
now
,
are
you
,
Sneak
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
afraid
of
many
things
,
I
hope
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
and
certainly
not
of
anything
that
you
will
do
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
a
tale
-
bearer
,
and
I
despise
all
meanness
.
 
<EOS>
You
quite
mistake
me
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Tom
,
indignantly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
this
manly
from
one
in
your
position
to
one
in
mine
?
 
<EOS>
Please
to
make
room
for
me
to
pass
.
 
<EOS>
The
less
I
say
,
the
better
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
less
you
say
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Jonas
,
dangling
his
legs
the
more
,
and
taking
no
heed
of
this
request
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
say
very
little
,
do
n't
you
?
<EOS>
Ecod
,
I
should
like
to
know
what
goes
on
between
you
and
a
vagabond
member
of
my
family
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
very
little
in
that
too
,
I
dare
say
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
no
vagabond
member
of
your
family
,
"
cried
Tom
,
stoutly
,
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
!
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Your
uncle
's
namesake
,
if
you
mean
him
,
is
no
vagabond
.
 
<EOS>
Any
comparison
between
you
and
him
"
---
Tom
snapped
his
fingers
at
him
,
for
he
was
rising
fast
in
wrath
---
"
is
immeasurably
to
your
disadvantage
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
indeed
!
"
sneered
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
think
of
his
deary
---
 
<EOS>
his
beggarly
leavings
,
eh
,
Mister
Pinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
to
say
another
word
,
or
stay
here
another
instant
,
"
replied
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
I
told
you
before
,
you
're
a
liar
,
"
said
Jonas
,
coolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
stay
here
till
I
give
you
leave
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
keep
where
you
are
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
flourished
his
stick
over
Tom
's
head
;
but
in
a
moment
it
was
spinning
harmlessly
in
the
air
,
and
Jonas
himself
lay
sprawling
in
the
ditch
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
momentary
struggle
for
the
stick
,
Tom
had
brought
it
into
violent
contact
with
his
opponent
's
forehead
;
and
the
blood
welled
out
profusely
from
a
deep
cut
on
the
temple
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
was
first
apprised
of
this
by
seeing
that
he
pressed
his
handkerchief
to
the
wounded
part
,
and
staggered
as
he
rose
,
being
stunned
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
hurt
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
Lean
on
me
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
do
that
without
forgiving
me
,
if
you
still
bear
me
malice
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
know
why
;
for
I
never
offended
you
before
we
met
on
this
spot
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
made
him
no
answer
;
not
appearing
at
first
to
understand
him
,
or
even
to
know
that
he
was
hurt
,
though
he
several
times
took
his
handkerchief
from
the
cut
to
look
vacantly
at
the
blood
upon
it
.
<EOS>
After
one
of
these
examinations
,
he
looked
at
Tom
,
and
then
there
was
an
expression
in
his
features
,
which
showed
that
he
understood
what
had
taken
place
,
and
would
remember
it
.
   
<EOS>
Nothing
more
passed
between
them
as
they
went
home
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
kept
a
little
in
advance
,
and
Tom
Pinch
sadly
followed
,
thinking
of
the
grief
which
the
knowledge
of
this
quarrel
must
occasion
his
excellent
benefactor
.
 
<EOS>
When
Jonas
knocked
at
the
door
,
Tom
's
heart
beat
high
;
higher
when
Miss
Mercy
answered
it
,
and
seeing
her
wounded
lover
,
shireked
aloud
;
higher
,
when
he
followed
them
into
the
family
parlour
;
higher
than
at
any
other
time
,
when
Jonas
spoke
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
make
a
noise
about
it
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing
worth
mentioning
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
know
the
road
;
the
night
's
very
dark
;
and
just
as
I
came
up
with
Mr
Pinch
"
---
he
turned
his
face
towards
Tom
,
but
not
his
eyes
---
"
<EOS>
I
ran
against
a
tree
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
only
skin
deep
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cold
water
,
Merry
,
my
child
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Brown
paper
!
<EOS>
Scissors
!
 
<EOS>
A
piece
of
old
linen
!
 
<EOS>
Charity
,
my
dear
,
make
a
bandage
.
<EOS>
Bless
me
,
Mr
Jonas
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
bother
YOUR
nonsense
,
"
returned
the
gracious
son
-
in
-
law
elect
.
<EOS>
"
Be
of
some
use
if
you
can
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ca
n't
,
get
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
,
though
called
upon
to
lend
her
aid
,
sat
upright
in
one
corner
,
with
a
smile
upon
her
face
,
and
did
n't
move
a
finger
.
<EOS>
Though
Mercy
laved
the
wound
herself
;
and
Mr
Pecksniff
held
the
patient
's
head
between
his
two
hands
,
as
if
without
that
assistance
it
must
inevitably
come
in
half
;
and
Tom
Pinch
,
in
his
guilty
agitation
,
shook
a
bottle
of
Dutch
Drops
until
they
were
nothing
but
English
Froth
,
and
in
his
other
hand
sustained
a
formidable
carving
-
knife
,
really
intended
to
reduce
the
swelling
,
but
apparently
designed
for
the
ruthless
infliction
of
another
wound
as
soon
as
that
was
dressed
;
Charity
rendered
not
the
least
assistance
,
nor
uttered
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
Mr
Jonas
's
head
was
bound
up
,
and
he
had
gone
to
bed
,
and
everybody
else
had
retired
,
and
the
house
was
quiet
,
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
as
he
sat
mournfully
on
his
bedstead
,
ruminating
,
heard
a
gentle
tap
at
his
door
;
and
opening
it
,
saw
her
,
to
his
great
astonishment
,
standing
before
him
with
her
finger
on
her
lip
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pinch
,
"
she
whispered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mr
Pinch
!
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
the
truth
!
<EOS>
You
did
that
?
 
<EOS>
There
was
some
quarrel
between
you
,
and
you
struck
him
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
of
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
she
had
ever
spoken
kindly
to
Tom
,
in
all
the
many
years
they
had
passed
together
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
stupefied
with
amazement
.
   
<EOS>
"
Was
it
so
,
or
not
?
"
<EOS>
she
eagerly
demanded
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
very
much
provoked
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
it
was
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Charity
,
with
sparkling
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ye
-
yes
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
a
struggle
for
the
path
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
did
n't
mean
to
hurt
him
so
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
so
much
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
repeated
,
clenching
her
hand
and
stamping
her
foot
,
to
Tom
's
great
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
brave
of
you
.
<EOS>
I
honour
you
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
should
ever
quarrel
again
,
do
n't
spare
him
for
the
world
,
but
beat
him
down
and
set
your
shoe
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Not
a
word
of
this
to
anybody
.
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Pinch
,
I
am
your
friend
from
tonight
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
always
your
friend
from
this
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
turned
her
flushed
face
upon
Tom
to
confirm
her
words
by
its
kindling
expression
;
and
seizing
his
right
hand
,
pressed
it
to
her
breast
,
and
kissed
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
was
nothing
personal
in
this
to
render
it
at
all
embarrassing
,
for
even
Tom
,
whose
power
of
observation
was
by
no
means
remarkable
,
knew
from
the
energy
with
which
she
did
it
that
she
would
have
fondled
any
hand
,
no
matter
how
bedaubed
or
dyed
,
that
had
broken
the
head
of
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
went
into
his
room
,
and
went
to
bed
,
full
of
uncomfortable
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
That
there
should
be
any
such
tremendous
division
in
the
family
as
he
knew
must
have
taken
place
to
convert
Charity
Pecksniff
into
his
friend
,
for
any
reason
,
but
,
above
all
,
for
that
which
was
clearly
the
real
one
;
that
Jonas
,
who
had
assailed
him
with
such
exceeding
coarseness
,
should
have
been
sufficiently
magnanimous
to
keep
the
secret
of
their
quarrel
;
and
that
any
train
of
circumstances
should
have
led
to
the
commission
of
an
assault
and
battery
by
Thomas
Pinch
upon
any
man
calling
himself
the
friend
of
Seth
Pecksniff
;
were
matters
of
such
deep
and
painful
cogitation
that
he
could
not
close
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
His
own
violence
,
in
particular
,
so
preyed
upon
the
generous
mind
of
Tom
,
that
coupling
it
with
the
many
former
occasions
on
which
he
had
given
Mr
Pecksniff
pain
and
anxiety
(
occasions
of
which
that
gentleman
often
reminded
him
)
,
he
really
began
to
regard
himself
as
destined
by
a
mysterious
fate
to
be
the
evil
genius
and
bad
angel
of
his
patron
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
fell
asleep
at
last
,
and
dreamed
---
new
source
of
waking
uneasiness
---
that
he
had
betrayed
his
trust
,
and
run
away
with
Mary
Graham
.
   
<EOS>
It
must
be
acknowledged
that
,
asleep
or
awake
,
Tom
's
position
in
reference
to
this
young
lady
was
full
of
uneasiness
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
he
saw
of
her
,
the
more
he
admired
her
beauty
,
her
intelligence
,
the
amiable
qualities
that
even
won
on
the
divided
house
of
Pecksniff
,
and
in
a
few
days
restored
,
at
all
events
,
the
semblance
of
harmony
and
kindness
between
the
angry
sisters
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
spoke
,
Tom
held
his
breath
,
so
eagerly
he
listened
;
when
she
sang
,
he
sat
like
one
entranced
.
 
<EOS>
She
touched
his
organ
,
and
from
that
bright
epoch
even
it
,
the
old
companion
of
his
happiest
hours
,
incapable
as
he
had
thought
of
elevation
,
began
a
new
and
deified
existence
.
   
<EOS>
God
's
love
upon
thy
patience
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
Who
,
that
had
beheld
thee
,
for
three
summer
weeks
,
poring
through
half
the
deadlong
night
over
the
jingling
anatomy
of
that
inscrutable
old
harpsichord
in
the
back
parlour
,
could
have
missed
the
entrance
to
thy
secret
heart
:
albeit
it
was
dimly
known
to
thee
?
 
<EOS>
Who
that
had
seen
the
glow
upon
thy
cheek
when
leaning
down
to
listen
,
after
hours
of
labour
,
for
the
sound
of
one
incorrigible
note
,
thou
foundest
that
it
had
a
voice
at
last
,
and
wheezed
out
a
flat
something
,
distantly
akin
to
what
it
ought
to
be
,
would
not
have
known
that
it
was
destined
for
no
common
touch
,
but
one
that
smote
,
though
gently
as
an
angel
's
hand
,
upon
the
deepest
chord
within
thee
!
 
<EOS>
And
if
a
friendly
glance
---
aye
,
even
though
it
were
as
guileless
as
thine
own
,
Dear
Tom
---
could
have
but
pierced
the
twilight
of
that
evening
,
when
,
in
a
voice
well
tempered
to
the
time
,
sad
,
sweet
,
and
low
,
yet
hopeful
,
she
first
sang
to
the
altered
instrument
,
and
wondered
at
the
change
;
and
thou
,
sitting
apart
at
the
open
window
,
kept
a
glad
silence
and
a
swelling
heart
---
 
<EOS>
must
not
that
glance
have
read
perforce
the
dawning
of
a
story
,
Tom
,
that
it
were
well
for
thee
had
never
been
begun
!
   
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
's
situation
was
not
made
the
less
dangerous
or
difficult
by
the
fact
of
no
one
word
passing
between
them
in
reference
to
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Honourably
mindful
of
his
promise
,
Tom
gave
her
opportunities
of
all
kinds
.
 
<EOS>
Early
and
late
he
was
in
the
church
;
in
her
favourite
walks
;
in
the
village
,
in
the
garden
,
in
the
meadows
;
and
in
any
or
all
of
these
places
he
might
have
spoken
freely
.
 
<EOS>
But
no
;
at
all
such
times
she
carefully
avoided
him
,
or
never
came
in
his
way
unaccompanied
.
 
<EOS>
It
could
not
be
that
she
disliked
or
distrusted
him
,
for
by
a
thousand
little
delicate
means
,
too
slight
for
any
notice
but
<EOS>
his
own
,
she
singled
him
out
when
others
were
present
,
and
showed
herself
the
very
soul
of
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
Could
it
be
that
she
had
broken
with
Martin
,
or
had
never
returned
his
affection
,
save
in
his
own
bold
and
heightened
fancy
?
 
<EOS>
Tom
's
cheek
grew
red
with
self
-
reproach
as
he
dismissed
the
thought
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
old
Martin
came
and
went
in
his
own
strange
manner
,
or
sat
among
the
rest
absorbed
within
himself
,
and
holding
little
intercourse
with
any
one
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
was
unsocial
,
he
was
not
willful
in
other
things
,
or
troublesome
,
or
morose
;
being
never
better
pleased
than
when
they
left
him
quite
unnoticed
at
his
book
,
and
pursued
their
own
amusements
in
his
presence
,
unreserved
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
discern
in
whom
he
took
an
interest
,
or
whether
he
had
an
interest
in
any
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
Unless
they
spoke
to
him
directly
,
he
never
showed
that
he
had
ears
or
eyes
for
anything
that
passed
.
   
<EOS>
One
day
the
lively
Merry
,
sitting
with
downcast
eyes
under
a
shady
tree
in
the
churchyard
,
whither
she
had
retired
after
fatiguing
herself
by
the
imposition
of
sundry
trials
on
the
temper
of
Mr
Jonas
,
felt
that
a
new
shadow
came
between
her
and
the
sun
.
 
<EOS>
Raising
her
eyes
in
the
expectation
of
seeing
her
betrothed
,
she
was
not
a
little
surprised
to
see
old
Martin
instead
.
 
<EOS>
Her
surprise
was
not
diminished
when
he
took
his
seat
upon
the
turf
beside
her
,
and
opened
a
conversation
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
When
are
you
to
be
married
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
my
goodness
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
Not
yet
awhile
,
I
hope
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
hope
?
"
said
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
very
gravely
said
,
but
she
took
it
for
banter
,
and
giggled
excessively
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
old
man
,
with
unusual
kindness
,
"
you
are
young
,
good
-
looking
,
and
I
think
good
-
natured
!
 
<EOS>
Frivolous
you
are
,
and
love
to
be
,
undoubtedly
;
but
you
must
have
some
heart
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
given
it
all
away
<EOS>
,
I
can
tell
you
,
"
said
Merry
,
nodding
her
head
shrewdly
,
and
plucking
up
the
grass
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
parted
with
any
of
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
threw
the
grass
about
,
and
looked
another
way
,
but
said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
repeated
his
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lor
,
my
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
!
<EOS>
really
you
must
excuse
me
!
 
<EOS>
How
very
odd
you
are
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
be
odd
in
me
to
desire
to
know
whether
you
love
the
young
man
whom
I
understand
you
are
to
marry
,
I
AM
very
odd
,
"
said
Martin
.
<EOS>
"
For
that
is
certainly
my
wish
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
such
a
monster
,
you
know
,
"
said
Merry
,
pouting
.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
you
do
n't
love
him
?
"
returned
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
your
meaning
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
I
'm
sure
I
tell
him
a
hundred
times
a
day
that
I
hate
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
must
have
heard
me
tell
him
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Often
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
I
do
,
"
cried
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
positively
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Being
at
the
same
time
engaged
to
marry
him
,
"
observed
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
"
said
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
told
the
wretch
---
<EOS>
my
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
I
told
him
when
he
asked
me
---
that
if
I
ever
did
marry
him
,
it
should
only
be
that
I
might
hate
and
tease
him
all
my
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
a
suspicion
that
the
old
man
regarded
Jonas
with
anything
but
favour
,
and
intended
these
remarks
to
be
extremely
captivating
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
appear
,
however
,
to
regard
them
in
that
light
by
any
means
;
for
when
he
spoke
again
,
it
was
in
a
tone
of
severity
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
about
you
,
"
he
said
,
pointing
to
the
graves
;
"
and
remember
that
from
your
bridal
hour
to
the
day
which
sees
you
brought
as
low
as
these
,
and
laid
in
such
a
bed
,
there
will
be
no
appeal
against
him
.
 
<EOS>
Think
,
and
speak
,
and
act
,
for
once
,
like
an
accountable
creature
.
 
<EOS>
Is
any
control
put
upon
your
inclinations
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
forced
into
this
match
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
insidiously
advised
or
tempted
to
contract
it
,
by
any
one
?
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
ask
by
whom
;
by
any
one
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Merry
,
shrugging
her
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
I
am
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
know
that
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
Are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nobody
ever
said
anything
to
me
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
one
had
tried
to
make
me
have
him
,
I
would
n't
have
had
him
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
told
that
he
was
at
first
supposed
to
be
your
sister
's
admirer
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
good
gracious
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
it
would
be
very
hard
to
make
him
,
though
he
IS
a
monster
,
accountable
for
other
people
's
vanity
,
"
said
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
poor
dear
Cherry
is
the
vainest
darling
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
her
mistake
,
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
was
,
"
cried
Merry
;
"
but
,
all
along
,
the
dear
child
has
been
so
dreadfully
jealous
,
and
SO
cross
,
that
,
upon
my
word
and

,
it
's
impossible
to
please
her
,
and
it
's
of
no
use
trying
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Not
forced
,
persuaded
,
or
controlled
,
"
said
Martin
,
thoughtfully
.
<EOS>
"
And
that
's
true
,
I
see
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
one
chance
yet
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
have
lapsed
into
this
engagement
in
very
giddiness
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
the
wanton

of

.
 
<EOS>
Is

so
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
simpered
Merry
,
"
<EOS>
as
to
light
-
headedness
,
there
never
was
such
a
feather
of

head
as
mine
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
perfect
balloon
,
I
declare
!
 
<EOS>
You
never
DID
,
you
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
waited
quietly
till
she
had
finished
,
and
then
said
,
steadily

,
and
in

,

:
   
"
<EOS>
Have
you
any
wish
---
or
is

within

that
whispers
you
may
form
the
wish
,
if
you
have
time
to
think
---
to
be
released
from
this
engagement
?
"
   
<EOS>
Again
Miss
Merry
pouted
,
and
looked
down
,
and

the
grass
,
and
shrugged
her
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
did
n't
know
that
she
had
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
pretty
sure
she
had
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
sure
,
she
might
say
.
 
<EOS>
She
"
did
n't
mind
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has
it
ever
occurred
to
you
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
that
your
married
life
may
perhaps
be
miserable
,
full
of
bitterness
,
and
most
unhappy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Merry
looked
down
again
;
and
now
she
tore
the
grass
up
by
the
roots
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
what
shocking

!
 
<EOS>
Of

,
I
shall
quarrel
with

.
 
<EOS>
I
should
quarrel

any

.
 
<EOS>
Married
people
always

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
But
as

,
and

,

all

,
you

,
why
I

n't

that
,

always

;

I

.
 
<EOS>
I
always
do
now
,
"
cried
Merry
,
nodding

and

;
"
for
I
make
a
perfect
slave
of
the
creature
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Let
it
go

,
"
said
Martin
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Let

!
 
<EOS>
I
sought

,
my

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Joy
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
looking
full
upon

,

Jonas
entered
at

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
without

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
"
cried

.
<EOS>
"
What

,

!
 
<EOS>
Do

come
here
,
Griffin
,
or
<EOS>
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
was
the
Griffin
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat

,
in

,

:
   
<EOS>
"
What
's

been
a
-

?
"
   
"
About

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
We

.
 
<EOS>
He
means

some

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
THAT
he
did
n't
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Merry
,
most

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
stingy
old
dog
<EOS>
he

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
   
"
Griffin
!
"
cried

,
in

;
"
what

,
Griffin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
 
<EOS>
You
make

so

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
withdrew

arm
,
and
for

at

more

than

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

:
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Mel
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

,

---
<EOS>
you
low

?
<EOS>
"
cried

fair

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
is
it
to

?
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
afford
to
go
on
dawdling
about
here
half
my
life
<EOS>
,
I
need
n't
tell
you
,

Pecksniff

's

makes

;

we

down

,

so

,

.
 
<EOS>
As

(

,

)
,

,

,

,

'd
nothing

.
 
<EOS>
So
,
Mel
,
"

,

;
"

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
next
week
!
 
<EOS>
If

,
I
should

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
did
n't

next
quarter
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
said
next
week
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Griffin
,
"
cried

Merry
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

!
<EOS>
not

.
 
<EOS>
It
sha
n't
be
till
I
choose
,
and
I
may
not

for

.
 
<EOS>
There
!
"
   
<EOS>
He

her

,

Tom
Pinch
;

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No

Griffin
with

or

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
   
<EOS>
Still
Mr
Jonas
held
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
next
month
,
that
shall

;

wo
n't

shall

till

-
morrow
;
and

,
it
shall
never

at

,
"
said
Merry
;
"
and
if
you
follow

about

wo

alone
,
it
shall
never

at

.
 
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

!
"
   
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
Mr
Mould
was
surrounded
by
his
household
gods
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
enjoying
the
sweets
of
domestic
repose
,
and
gazing

with
a
calm

.
 
<EOS>
The
day
being
sultry
,
and
the
window
open
,
the

of
Mr
Mould
were
on
the
window

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Over

,
to

from

.
 
<EOS>
The
room
was
fragrant

the

of
punch
,
<EOS>
a
tumbler
of
which

compound
stood
upon

,

Mr
Mould
;
so

as

another

behind

,
looked
up

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Deep

City
,
and

ward

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
His

,

<EOS>
In

Mr

now

;
gazing
,
a

,
upon

.
 
<EOS>
If
,

,

,

might

,

strings
before

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

of
his
life
,
and
daughters
twain
,

Mr

's

.
 
<EOS>
Plump
as
any

each
Miss
Mould
,
and
Mrs
M
was
plumper
than

.
 
<EOS>
So

,

the

'

,

,

<EOS>

ought

<EOS>
The

,

for

played
,

<EOS>
Mr

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
So

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>

two
young
ladies
as
I
know'd
afore
a
tooth
in
their
pretty
heads
was
cut
,
and
have
many
a
day
seen
---
ah
,
the
sweet
creeturs
!
<EOS>
---
playing
at
berryins
down
in
the
shop
,
and
follerin
'
the
order

book
to
its
long
home
in
the

!
 
<EOS>
But
that
's
all
past
and
over
,
Mr
Mould
;
"

that

;
<EOS>
"
That
's

past

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Changes
,
Mrs
Gamp
,
changes
!
"
returned

.
   
<EOS>
"
More
changes

,
to
come
,
afore

've

changes
,

,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Young

with
such
faces
thinks

,

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
I

"

,

"
<EOS>
Not

Gamp
,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

,

!
"

,
"
and

Mould
,
your
'
ansome

,

;

,

daughter
was

;
which
,

,
Gamp

,

with

,
and
arterward

the
child

in

;

truly

,

ev'ry
individgle

that

at
toss
or
buy
for

ones
;
and
come
home
arterwards

,

,

if

.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Oh

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
There

?

<EOS>
Mr

,

"
<EOS>
No

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

.
 
<EOS>

,
Mrs

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>
Nonsense
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Devilish

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ca
-

!
"
<EOS>
---

<EOS>
"
My

"
---

"
<EOS>
Mrs

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Mrs

,

<EOS>
"
A

"

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Harris

,

?

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Telling

sick

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
"

,

,
"

,
"
is

;

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

;
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

"

,

<EOS>
"
Jest

,

,
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

'
<EOS>
Mrs

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

The

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Easy

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

,
"

---

"

,

<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

"
that

ve
-

.
<EOS>
That

woman
whose

to

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
woman
who

in

.
 
<EOS>
She
's
the
sort
of
woman
now
,
"
said
Mould
,
<EOS>
drawing
his

over

again
,
and
composing

for
a
nap
"
one
would
almost
feel
disposed
to
bury
for
nothing
;
and
do
it
neatly
,
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Mould
and
her
daughters
fully
concurred
in
these
remarks
;
the
subject
of
which
had
by
this
time
reached
the
street
,
where
she
experienced
so
much
inconvenience
from
the
air
,
that
she
was
obliged
to
stand
under
an
archway
for
a
short
time
,
to
recover
herself
.
<EOS>
Even
after
this
precaution
,
she
walked
so
unsteadily
as
to
attract
the
compassionate
regards
of
divers
kind
-
hearted
boys
,
who
took
the
liveliest
interest
in
her
disorder
;
and
in
their
simple
language
bade
her
be
of
good
cheer
,
for
she
was
"
only
a
little
screwed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Whatever
she
was
,
or
whatever
name
the
vocabulary
of
medical
science
would
have
bestowed
upon
her
malady
,
Mrs
Gamp
was
perfectly
acquainted
with
the
way
home
again
;
and
arriving
at
the
house
of
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
&
Son
,
lay
down
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
Remaining
there
until
seven
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
and
then
persuading
poor
old
Chuffey
to
betake
himself
to
bed
,
she
sallied
forth
upon
her
new
engagement
.
<EOS>
First
,
she
went
to
her
private
lodgings
in
Kingsgate
Street
,
for
a
bundle
of
robes
and
wrappings
comfortable
in
the
night
season
;
and
then
repaired
to
the
Bull
in
Holborn
,
which
she
reached
as
the
clocks
were
striking
eight
.
   
<EOS>
As
she
turned
into
the
yard
,
she
stopped
;
for
the
landlord
,
landlady
,
and
head
chambermaid
,
were
all
on
the
threshold
together
talking
earnestly
with
a
young
gentleman
who
seemed
to
have
just
come
or
to
be
just
going
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
first
words
that
struck
upon
Mrs
Gamp
's
ear
obviously
bore
reference
to
the
patient
;
and
it
being
expedient
that
all
good
attendants
should
know
as
much
as
possible
about
the
case
on
which
their
skill
is
brought
to
bear
,
Mrs
Gamp
listened
as
a
matter
of
duty
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
better
,
then
?
"
observed
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Worse
!
"
said
the
landlord
.
   
<EOS>
"
Much
worse
,
"
added
the
landlady
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
a
deal
badder
,
"
cried
the
chambermaid
from
the
background
,
opening
her

very

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
fellow
!
"
said
the
gentleman
,
"
I
am
sorry
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
worst
of
it
is
,
that
I
have
no
idea
<EOS>
what
friends
or
relations
he
has
,
or
where
they
live
,
except
that
it
certainly
is
not
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
looked
at
the
landlady
;
the
landlady
looked
at
the
landlord
;
and
the
chambermaid
remarked
,
hysterically
,
"
that
of
all
the
many
wague

she
had
ever
seen
or
heerd
of
(
<EOS>
and
they
was
n't
few
in
an
hotel
)
,
THAT
was
the
waguest
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
you
see
,
"
pursued
the
gentleman
,
"
as
I
told
you
yesterday
when
you
sent
to
me
,
I
really
know
very
little
about
him
.
<EOS>
We
were
school
-
fellows
together
;
but
since
that
time
I
have
only
met
him
twice
.
 
<EOS>
On
both

I
was
in
London
for
a
boy
's

(
having
come
up
for
a
week
or

from
Wiltshire
)
,

.
 
<EOS>
The
letter
bearing
my
name
and

which
you

upon

,
and
which
led
to
your

to
me
,
is
in

,
you
will
observe
,
to
one
he
wrote
from
this
house
the
very

he
was
taken
ill
,
making
an
appointment
with
him
at
his
own
request
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
his
letter
,
if
you
wish
to
see
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
read
it
;
the
landlady
looked
over

.
 
<EOS>
The
chambermaid
,
in
the
background
,
made
out
as
much
of
it
as
she
could
,
and
invented
the
rest
;
believing
it
all
from
that
time
forth
as
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
very
little

,
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
observed

gentleman
,
who
was
no

,
John
Westlock
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
but
a
portmanteau
,
"
said
the
landlord
;
"
and
very
little
in
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
few
pounds
in

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
It
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
made

,

you
're

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
John
,
"
<EOS>
as
the
medical
gentleman
says
the
fever
must
take
its
course
,
and
nothing
can

done
just
now
beyond
giving
him
his

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Can

?
<EOS>
"
   
"
N
---
 
<EOS>
no
,
"

,
"

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Except
,
who
's
to
pay
,
I

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
hesitated

,
"
it
would

as
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
as
well
,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Not

to
remember
the
servants
,
"
said

in

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
is
but
reasonable
,
I
fully

,
"
said
John
Westlock
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
all

,
you
have

upon
for
the

;
and
I

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
cried
Mrs
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
rayal
gentleman
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
groaned
her
admiration
so

,
that
they
all
turned
round
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
felt
the
necessity
of
advancing
,
bundle
in

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
night
-
nurse
,
"
she
observed
,
"
from
Kingsgate
Street
,
well

Mrs
Prig
the
day

,
and
the
best
of

.
 
<EOS>
How
is
the
poor
dear

to
-
night
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
an't
no
better
yet
,
still
that

.
 
<EOS>
It
an't
the
fust
time
by
a
many
score
,

,
"

,
"

Mrs
Prig

me
has
nussed

,
turn

,
one

,
one

.
 
<EOS>
We
knows
each

's
ways
,
and
often
gives

when
others
fail
.
 
<EOS>
Our
charges
is
but
low
,
sir
"
<EOS>
---
Mrs
Gamp
addressed

to
John
on
this

---
"
considerin
'
the
nater
of
our
painful

.
 
<EOS>
If
they
wos
made
accordin
'
to
our
wishes
,
they
would
be
easy
paid
.
"
   
<EOS>
Regarding
herself
as
having
now
delivered
her

address
,
Mrs
Gamp
curtseyed
all
round
,
and
signified
her

to

the
scene
of
her
official

.
 
<EOS>
The
chambermaid
led
her
,
through
a
variety
of
intricate

,
to
the
top
of
the
house
;
and
pointing
at
length
to
a

door
at
the
end

a
gallery
,
informed
her
that
yonder
was
the
chamber
where
the
patient
lay
.
<EOS>
That
done
,
she
hurried
off
with
all
the
speed
she
could
make
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
traversed
the
gallery
in
a
great
heat
from
having
carried
her
large
bundle
up
so
many
stairs
,
and
tapped
at
the
door
which
was
immediately
opened
by
Mrs
Prig
,
bonneted
and
shawled
and
all
impatience
to
be
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Prig
was
of
the
Gamp
build
,
but
not
so
fat
;
and
her
voice
was
deeper
and
more
like
a
man
's
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
also
a
beard
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
began
to
think
you
warn't
a
-
coming
!
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Prig
observed
,
in
some
displeasure
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
made
good
to
-
morrow
night
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
<EOS>
"
Honorable
.
<EOS>
I
had
to
go
and
fetch
my
things
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
She
had

to

in

to

position
of
the
patient
and
his
overhearing

---
for

a

before

---
when
Mrs
Prig
settled
that

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
"
he
's

,

his
wits

.
 
<EOS>
It
an't
<EOS>
no

wot
you
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Anythin
'
to
tell
afore

goes
,

?
"

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
pickled

,
"
Mrs
Prig

,
"
is
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
can
partlck'ler
recommend

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't

nothink
to
say
to
the

,

it
tastes
of

.
 
<EOS>
The
drinks
is
all

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
expressed

much

.
   
<EOS>
"
The
physic
and
them
things
is
on

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
took

.
 
<EOS>
The

an't
soft

.
 
<EOS>
You

piller
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

thanked

for

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Having

of
seeing

,

shut

,

,
took

,

,
and
entered

of

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
little
dull
,
but
not
so
bad
as
might

,
"
Mrs
Gamp
remarked
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
to
see
a
parapidge
,
in
case
of
fire
,
and
lots
of
roofs
and

-
pots
to
walk
upon
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
will
be
seen
from
these

that
Mrs
Gamp
was
looking
out
of
window
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
had
exhausted
the
prospect
,
she
tried
the
easy
-
chair
,
which
she
indignantly
declared
was
"
harder
than
a
brickbadge
.
"
 
<EOS>
Next
she
pursued
her
researches
among
the
physic
-
bottles
,
glasses
,
jugs
,
and
tea
-
cups
;
and
when
she
had
entirely

her

on
all
these
subjects
of
investigation
,
she
untied
her
bonnet
-
strings
and
strolled
up
to
the
bedside
to
take
a
look
at
the
patient
.
   
<EOS>
A
young
man
---
dark
and
not
ill
-
looking
---
with
long
black
hair
,
that
seemed
the
blacker
for
the
whiteness
of
the
bed
-
clothes
.
 
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
partly
open
,
and
he
never
ceased
to
roll
his
head
from
side
to
side
upon
the
pillow
,
keeping
his
body
almost
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
utter
words
;
but
every
now
and
then
gave
vent
to
an
expression
of
impatience
or
fatigue
,
sometimes
of
surprise
;
and
still
his
restless
head
---
<EOS>
oh
,
weary
,
weary
hour
!
<EOS>
---
went
to
and
fro
without
a
moment
's
intermission
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
solaced
herself
with
a
pinch
of
snuff
,
and
stood
looking
at
him
with
her
head
inclined
a
little
sideways
,
as
a
connoisseur
might
gaze
upon
a

work
of
art
.
 
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
a
horrible
remembrance
of
one
branch
of
her
calling
took
possession
of
the
woman
;
and
stooping
down
,
she
pinned
his
wandering
arms
against
his
sides
,
to
see
how
he
would
look
if
laid
out
as
a
dead
man
.
 
<EOS>
Her
fingers
itched
to
compose
his
limbs
in
that
last
marble
attitude
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
walking
away
from
the
bed
,
"
he
'd
make
a
lovely
corpse
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
now
proceeded
to
unpack
her
bundle
;
lighted
a
candle
with
the
aid
of
a
fire
-
box
on
the

;
filled
a
small
kettle
,
as
a
preliminary
to
refreshing
herself
with
a
cup
of
tea
in
the
course
of
the
night
;
laid
what
she
called
"
a
little
bit
of
fire
,
"
for
the
same
philanthropic
purpose
;
and
also
set
forth
a
small
tea
-
board
,
that
nothing
might
be
wanting
for
her
comfortable
enjoyment
.
 
<EOS>
These
preparations
occupied
so
long
,
that
when
they
were
brought
to
a
conclusion
it
was
high
time
to
think
about
supper
;
so
she
rang
the
bell
and
ordered
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
young
woman
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
to
the
assistant
chambermaid
,
in
a
tone
expressive
of
weakness
,
"
that
I
could
pick
a
little
bit
of
pickled
salmon
,
with
a
nice
little
sprig
of
fennel
,
and
a

of
white
pepper
.
 
<EOS>
I
takes
new
bread
,
my
dear
,
with
just
a
little
pat
of
fresh
butter
,
and
a
mossel
of
cheese
.
 
<EOS>
In
case
there
should
be
such
a
thing
as
a
cowcumber
in
the
'
ouse
,
will
you
be
so
kind
as
bring
it
,
<EOS>
for
I
'm
rather
partial
to
'em
,
and
they
does
a
world
of
good
in
a
sick
room
.
 
<EOS>
If
they
draws
the
Brighton
Old
Tipper
here
,
I
takes
THAT
ale
at
night
,
my
love
,
it
bein
'
considered
wakeful
by
the
doctors
.
 
<EOS>
And
whatever
you
do
,
young
woman
,
do
n't
bring
more
than
a
shilling's
-
worth
of
gin
and
water
-
warm
when
I
rings
the
bell
a
second
time
;
for
that
is
always
my
allowance
,
and
I
never
takes
a
drop
beyond
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
preferred
these
moderate
requests
,
Mrs
Gamp
observed
that
she
would
stand
at
the
door
until
the
order
was
executed
,
to
the
end
that
the
patient
might
not
be
disturbed
by
her
opening
it
a
second
time
;
and
therefore
she
would
thank
the
young
woman
to
"
look
sharp
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
tray
was
brought
with
everything
upon
it
,
even
to
the
cucumber
and
Mrs
Gamp
accordingly
sat
down
to
eat
and
drink
in
high
good
humour
.
<EOS>
The
extent
to
which
she
availed
herself
of
the
vinegar
,
and
supped
up
that
refreshing
fluid
with
the
blade
of
her
knife
,
can
scarcely
be
expressed
in
narrative
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
sighed
Mrs
Gamp
,
as
she
meditated
over
the
warm
shilling's
-
worth
,
"
what
a
blessed
thing
it
is
---
living
in
a
wale
---
to
be
contented
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
blessed
thing
it
is
to
make
sick
people
happy
in
their
beds
,
and
never
mind
one
's
self
as
long
as
one
can
do
a
service
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
a
finer
cowcumber
was
ever
<EOS>
grow'd
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
I
never
see
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
moralised
in
the
same
vein
until
her
glass
was
empty
,
and
then
admistered
the
patient
's
medicine
,
by
the
simple
process
of
clutching
his
windpipe
to
make
him
gasp
,
and
immediately
pouring
it
down
his
throat
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
a'most
forgot
the
piller
,
I
declare
!
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
drawing
it
away
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
!
 
<EOS>
Now
he
's
comfortable
as
he
can
be
,
I
'm
sure
!
 
<EOS>
I
must
try
to
make
myself
as
much
so
as
I
can
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
she
went
about
the
construction
of
an
extemporaneous
bed
in
the
easy
-
chair
,
with
the
addition
of
the
next
easy
one
for
her
feet
.
 
<EOS>
Having
formed
the
best
couch
that
the
circumstances
admitted
of
,
she
took
out
of
her
bundle
a
yellow
night
-
cap
,
of
prodigious
size
,
in
shape
resembling
a
cabbage
;
which
article
of
dress
she
fixed
and
tied
on
with
the
utmost
care
,
previously
divesting
herself
of
a
row
of
bald
old
curls
that
could
scarcely
be
called
false
,
they
were
so
very
innocent
of
anything
approaching
to
deception
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
same
repository
she
brought
forth
a
night
-
jacket
,
in
which
she
also
attired
herself
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
,
she
produced
a
watchman
's
coat
which
she
tied
round
her
neck
by
the
sleeves
,
so
that
she
become
two
people
;
and
looked
,
behind
,
as
if
she
were
in
the
act
of
being
embraced
by
one
of
the
old
patrol
.
   
<EOS>
All
these
arrangements
made
,
she
lighted
the
rush
-
light
,
coiled
herself
up
on
her
couch
,
and
went
to
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Ghostly
and
dark
the
room
became
,
and
full
of
lowering
shadows
.
 
<EOS>
The
distant
noises
in
the
streets
were
gradually
hushed
;
the
house
was
quiet
as
a
sepulchre
;
the
dead
of
might
was
coffined
in
the
silent
city
.
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
weary
,
weary
hour
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
haggard
mind
,
groping
darkly
through
the
past
;
incapable
of
detaching
itself
from
the
miserable
present
;
dragging
its
heavy
chain
of
care
through
imaginary
feasts
and
revels
,
and
scenes
of
awful
pomp
;
seeking
but
a
moment
's
rest
among
the
long
-
forgotten
haunts
of
childhood
,
and
the
resorts
of
yesterday
;
and
dimly
finding
fear
and
horror
everywhere
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
weary
,
weary
hour
!
 
<EOS>
What
were
the
wanderings
of
Cain
,
to
these
!
   
<EOS>
Still
,
without
a
moment
's
interval
,
the
burning
head
tossed
to
and
fro
.
 
<EOS>
Still
,
from
time
to
time
,
fatigue
,
impatience
,
suffering
,
and
surprise
,
found
utterance
upon
that
rack
,
and
plainly
too
,
though
never
once
in
words
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
in
the
solemn
hour
of
midnight
,
he
began
to
talk
;
waiting
awfully
for
answers
sometimes
;
as
though
invisible
companions
were
about
his
bed
;
and
so
replying
to
their
speech
and
questioning
again
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
awoke
,
and
sat
up
in
her
bed
;
presenting
on
the
wall
the
shadow
of
a
gigantic
night
constable
,
struggling
with
a
prisoner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Hold
your
tongue
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
in
sharp
reproof
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
make
none
of
that
noise
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
alteration
in
the
face
,
or
in
the
incessant
motion
of
the
head
,
but
he
talked
on
wildly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
coming
out
of
the
chair
with
an
impatient
shiver
;
"
I
thought
I
was
a
-
sleepin
'
too
pleasant
to
last
!
 
<EOS>
The
devil
's
in
the
night
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
it
's
turned
so
chilly
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
drink
so
much
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
sick
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
'll
ruin
us
all
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
how
the
fountain
sinks
?
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
mark
where
the
sparkling
water
was
just
now
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sparkling
water
,
indeed
!
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
have
a
sparkling
cup
<EOS>
o
'
tea
<EOS>
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
'd
hold
your
noise
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
burst
into
a
laugh
,
which
,
being
prolonged
,
fell
off
into
a
dismal
wail
.
 
<EOS>
Checking
himself
,
with
fierce
inconstancy
<EOS>
he
began
to
count
---
fast
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
---
two
---
three
---
four
---
five
---
six
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
One
,
two
,
buckle
my
shoe
,
"
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
who
was
now
on
her
knees
,
lighting
the
fire
,
"
three
,
four
,
shut
the
door
,
"
<EOS>
---
I
wish
you
'd
shut
your
mouth
,
young
man
---
"
five
,
six
,
picking
up
sticks
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
'd
got
a
few
handy
,
I
should
have
the
kettle
boiling
all
the
sooner
.
"
   
<EOS>
Awaiting
this
desirable
consummation
,
she
sat
down
so
close
to
the
fender
(
which
was
a
high
one
)
that
her
nose
rested
upon
it
;
and
for
some
time
she
drowsily
amused
herself
by
sliding
that
feature
backwards
and
forwards
along
the
brass
top
,
as
far
as
she
could
,
without
changing
her
position
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
She
maintained
,
all
the
while
,
a
running
commentary
upon
the
wanderings
of
the
man
in
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
makes
five
hundred
and
twenty
-
one
men
,
all
dressed
alike
,
and
with
the
same
distortion
on
their
faces
,
that
have
passed
in
at
the
window
,
and
out
at
the
door
,
"
he
cried
,
anxiously
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
there
!
<EOS>
Five
hundred
and
twenty
-
two
---
twenty
-
three
---
twenty
-
four
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
them
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
see
'
em
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
;
"
all
the
whole
kit
of
'em
numbered
like
hackney
-
coaches
,
an't
they
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Touch
me
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
be
sure
of
this
.
 
<EOS>
Touch
me
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
your
next
draught
when
I
've
made
the
kettle
bile
,
"
retorted
Mrs
Gamp
,
composedly
,
"
and
you
'll
be
touched
then
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
be
touched
up
,
too
,
if
you
do
n't
take
it
quiet
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Five
hundred
and
twenty
-
eight
,
five
hundred
and
twenty
-
nine
,
five
hundred
and
thirty
.
<EOS>
---
Look
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
now
?
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
're
coming
four
abreast
,
each
man
with
his
arm
entwined
in
the
next
man
's
,
and
his
hand
upon
his
shoulder
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
that
upon
the
arm
of
every
man
,
and
on
the
flag
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Spiders
,
p'raps
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
Crape
!
 
<EOS>
Black
crape
!
 
<EOS>
Good
God
!
<EOS>
why
do
they
wear
it
outside
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
have
'em
carry
black
crape
in
their
insides
?
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Gamp
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
noise
,
hold
your
noise
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
fire
beginning
by
this
time
to
impart
a
grateful
warmth
<EOS>
,
Mrs
Gamp
became
silent
;
gradually
rubbed
her
nose
more
and
more
slowly
along
the
top
of
the
fender
;
and
fell
into
a
heavy
doze
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
awakened
by
the
room
ringing
(
as
she
fancied
)
with
a
name
she
knew
:
   
"
Chuzzlewit
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
sound
was
so
distinct
and
real
,
and
so
full
of
agonised
entreaty
,
that
Mrs
Gamp
jumped
up
in
terror
,
and
ran
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
She
expected
to
find
the
passage
filled
with
people
,
come
to
tell
her
that
the
house
in
the
city
had
taken
fire
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
place
was
empty
;
not
a
soul
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
She
opened
the
window
,
and
looked
out
.
<EOS>
Dark
,
dull
,
dingy
,
and
desolate
house
-
tops
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
passed
to
her
seat
again
,
she
glanced
at
the
patient
.
 
<EOS>
Just
the
same
;
but
silent
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
was
so
warm
now
,
that
she
threw
off
the
watchman
's
coat
,
and
fanned
herself
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
seemed
to
make
the
wery
bottles
ring
,
"
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
could
I
have
been
a
-
dreaming
of
?
 
<EOS>
That
dratted
Chuffey
,
I
'll
be
bound
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
supposition
was
probable
enough
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
a
pinch
of
snuff
,
and
the
song
of
the
steaming
kettle
,
quite
restored
the
tone
of
Mrs
Gamp
's
nerves
,
which
were
none
of
the
weakest
.
 
<EOS>
She
brewed
her
tea
;
made
some
buttered
toast
;
and
sat
down
at
the
tea
-
board
,
with
her
face
to
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
When
once
again
,
in
a
tone
more
terrible
than
that
which
had
vibrated
in
her
slumbering
ear
,
these
words
were
shrieked
out
:
   
<EOS>
"
Chuzzlewit
!
 
Jonas
!
 
<EOS>
No
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
dropped
the
cup
she
was
in
the
act
of
raising
to
her
lips
,
and
turned
round
with
a
start
that
made
the
little
tea
-
board
leap
.
<EOS>
The
cry
had
come
from
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
bright
morning
<EOS>
the
next
time
Mrs
Gamp
looked
out
of
the
window
,
and
the
sun
was
rising
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
Lighter
and
lighter
grew
the
sky
,
and
noisier
the
streets
;
and
high
into
the
summer
air
uprose
the
smoke
of
newly
kindled
fires
,
until
the
busy
day
was
broad
awake
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Prig
relieved
punctually
,
having
passed
a
good
night
at
her
other
patient
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Westlock
came
at
the
same
time
,
but
he
was
not
admitted
,
the
disorder
being
infectious
.
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
came
too
.
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
shook
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
he
could
do
,
under
the
circumstances
,
and
he
did
it
well
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
sort
of
a
night
,
nurse
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Restless
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
Talk
much
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Middling
,
sir
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
to
the
purpose
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
bless
you
,
no
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Only
jargon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
doctor
,
"
we
must
keep
him
quiet
;
keep
the
room
cool
;
give
him
his
draughts
regularly
;
and
see
that
he
's
carefully
looked
to
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
as
long
as
Mrs
Prig
and
me
waits
upon
him
,
sir
,
no
fear
of
that
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
observed
Mrs
Prig
,
when
they
had
curtseyed
the
doctor
out
;
"
there
's
nothin'
new
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothin'
at
all
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
rather
wearin
'
in
his
talk
from
making
up
a
lot
of
names
;
elseways
you
need
n't
mind
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
sha
n't
mind
him
,
"
Mrs
Prig
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
somethin'
else
to
think
of
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
pays
my
debts
to
-
night
,
you
know
,
my
dear
,
and
comes
afore
my
time
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
Betsy
Prig
"
---
speaking
with
great
feeling
,
and
laying
her
hand
upon
her
arm
---
<EOS>
"
try
the
cowcumbers
,
God
bless
you
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
26
.
<EOS>
An
unexpected
meeting
,
and
a
promising
prospect
 
<EOS>
The
laws
of
sympathy
between
beards
and
birds
,
and
the
secret
source
of
that
attraction
which
frequently
impels
a
shaver
of
the
one
to
be
a
dealer
in
the
other
,
are
questions
for
the
subtle
reasoning
of
scientific
bodies
;
not
the
less
so
,
because
their
investigation
would
seem
calculated
to
lead
to
no
particular
result
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
enough
to
know
that
the
artist
who
had
the
honour
of
entertaining
Mrs
Gamp
as
his
first
-
floor
lodger
,
united
the
two
pursuits
of
barbering
and
bird
-
fancying
;
and
that
it
was
not
an
original
idea
of
his
,
but
one
in
which
he
had
,
dispersed
about
the
by
-
streets
and
suburbs
of
the
town
,
a
host
of
rivals
.
   
<EOS>
The
name
of
the
householder
was
Paul
Sweedlepipe
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
commonly
called
Poll
Sweedlepipe
;
and
was
not
uncommonly
believed
to
have
been
so
christened
,
among
his
friends
and
neighbours
.
   
<EOS>
With
the
exception
of
the
staircase
,
and
his
lodger
's
private
apartment
,
Poll
Sweedlepipe
's
house
was
one
great
bird
's
nest
.
<EOS>
Gamecocks
resided
in
the
kitchen
;
pheasants
wasted
the
brightness
of
their
golden
plumage
on
the
garret
;
bantams
roosted
in
the
cellar
;
owls
had
possession
of
the
bedroom
;
and
specimens
of
all
the
smaller
fry
of
birds
chirrupped
and
twittered
in
the
shop
.
 
<EOS>
The
staircase
was
sacred
to
rabbits
.
 
<EOS>
There
in
hutches
of
all
shapes
and
kinds
,
made
from
old
packing
-
cases
,
boxes
,
drawers
,
and
tea
-
chests
,
they
increased
in
a
prodigious
degree
,
and
contributed
their
share
towards
that
complicated
whiff
which
,
quite
impartially
,
and
without
distinction
of
persons
,
saluted
every
nose
that
was
put
into
Sweedlepipe
's
easy
shaving
-
shop
.
   
<EOS>
Many
noses
found
their
way
there
,
for
all
that
,
especially
on
Sunday
morning
,
before
church
-
time
.
 
<EOS>
Even
archbishops
shave
,
or
must
be
shaved
,
on
a
Sunday
,
and
beards
WILL
grow
after
twelve
o'clock
on
Saturday
night
,
though
it
be
upon
the
chins
of
base
mechanics
;
who
,
not
being
able
to
engage
their
valets
by
the
quarter
,
hire
them
by
the
job
,
and
pay
them
---
<EOS>
oh
,
the
wickedness
of
copper
coin
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
in
dirty
pence
.
 
<EOS>
Poll
Sweedlepipe
,
the
sinner
,
shaved
all
comers
at
a
penny
each
,
and
cut
the
hair
of
any
customer
for
twopence
;
and
being
a
lone
unmarried
man
,
and
having
some
connection
in
the
bird
line
,
Poll
got
on
tolerably
well
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
a
little
elderly
man
,
with
a
clammy
cold
right
hand
,
from
which
even
rabbits
and
birds
could
not
remove
the
smell
of
shaving
-
soap
.
 
<EOS>
Poll
had
something
of
the
bird
in
his
nature
;
not
of
the
hawk
or
eagle
,
but
of
the
sparrow
,
that
builds
in
chimney
-
stacks
and
inclines
to
human
company
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
quarrelsome
,
though
,
like
the
sparrow
;
but
peaceful
,
like
the
dove
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
walk
he
strutted
;
and
,
in
this
respect
,
he
bore
a
faint
resemblance
to
the
pigeon
,
as
well
as
in
a
certain
prosiness
of
speech
,
which
might
,
in
its
monotony
,
be
likened
to
the
cooing
of
that
bird
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
inquisitive
;
and
when
he
stood
at
his
shop
-
door
in
the
evening
-
tide
,
watching
the
neighbours
,
with
his
head
on
one
side
,
and
his
eye
cocked
knowingly
,
there
was
a
dash
of
the
raven
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
there
was
no
more
wickedness
in
Poll
than
in
a
robin
.
 
<EOS>
Happily
,
too
,
when
any
of
his
ornithological
properties
were
on
the
verge
of
going
too
far
,
they
were
quenched
,
dissolved
,
melted
down
,
and
neutralised
in
the
barber
;
just
as
his
bald
head
---
<EOS>
otherwise
,
as
the
head
of
a
shaved
magpie
---
 
lost
itself
in
a
wig
of
curly
black
ringlets
,
parted
on
one
side
,
and
cut
away
almost
to
the
crown
,
to
indicate
immense
capacity
of
intellect
.
   
<EOS>
Poll
had
a
very
small
,
shrill
treble
voice
,
which
might
have
led
the
wags
of
Kingsgate
Street
to
insist
the
more
upon
his
feminine
designation
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
tender
heart
,
too
;
for
,
when
he
had
a
good
commission
to
provide
three
or
four
score
sparrows
for
a
shooting
-
match
,
he
would
observe
,
in
a
compassionate
tone
,
how
singular
it
was
that
sparrows
should
have
been
made
expressly
for
such
purposes
.
<EOS>
The
question
,
whether
men
were
made
to
shoot
them
,
never
entered
into
Poll
's
philosophy
.
   
<EOS>
Poll
wore
,
in
his
sporting
character
,
a
velveteen
coat
,
a
great
deal
of
blue
stocking
,
ankle
boots
,
a
neckerchief
of
some
bright
colour
,
and
a
very
tall
hat
.
 
<EOS>
Pursuing
his
more
quiet
occupation
of
barber
,
he
generally
subsided
into
an
apron
not
over
-
clean
,
a
flannel
jacket
,
and
corduroy

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
this
latter

,
but
with
his
apron
girded
round
his
waist
,
as
a
token
of
his
having
shut
up
shop
for
the
night
,
that
he
closed
the
door
one

,
some
weeks
after
the
occurrences
detailed
in
the
last
chapter
,
and
stood
upon

steps
in
Kingsgate
Street
,
listening
until
the
little
cracked
bell
within
should
leave

.
 
<EOS>
For
until
it
did
---
 
<EOS>
this
was
Mr
Sweedlepipe
's
reflection
---
the
place
never
seemed
quiet
enough
to
be
left
to
itself
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
greediest
little
bell
to
ring
,
"
said

,
"
that
ever
was
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
quiet
at
last
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
rolled
his

up
a
little

as
he
said
these

,
and

down
the

.
 
<EOS>
Just

he
was
turning
into
Holborn
,
he
ran

a
young

in

.
 
<EOS>
This

was
bold
,
though
small
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
STOO
-
PID
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca

a

---

?
 
<EOS>
Ca

-

---

?
<EOS>
What

---

?
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Now

!
<EOS>
"
   
The

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

What
!
 
<EOS>
Polly

<EOS>
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
ca

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Paul
Sweedlepipe
,
the

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

<EOS>

,
and
worked
on
their
belief
in
defiance
of
all
natural
laws
.
 
<EOS>
He
walked
along
the
tangible
and
real
stones
of
Holborn
Hill
,
an
undersized
boy
;
and
yet
he
winked
the
winks
,
and
thought
the
thoughts
,
and
did
the
deeds
,
and
said
the
sayings
of
an
ancient
man
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
principle
within
him
,
and
a
young
surface
without
.
 
<EOS>
He
became
an
inexplicable
creature
;
a
breeched
and
booted
Sphinx
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
course
open
to
the
barber
,
but
to
go
distracted
himself
,
or
to
take
Bailey
for
granted
;
and
he
wisely
chose
the
latter
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
was
good
enough
to
continue
to
bear
him
company
,
and
to
entertain
him
,
as
they
went
,
with
easy

on
various

;
especially
on
the
comparative
merits
,
as
a
general
principle
,
of
horses
with
white

,
and
horses
without
.
 
<EOS>
In
regard
to
the
style
of
tail
to

preferred
,
Mr
Bailey
had
opinions
of
his
own
,
which
he
explained
,
but
begged
they
might
by
no

influence
his
friend
's
,
as
here
he
knew
he
had
the
misfortune
to
differ
from
some
excellent
authorities
.
 
<EOS>
He
treated
Mr
Sweedlepipe
to
a
dram
,
compounded
agreeably
to
his
own
directions
,
which
he
informed
him
had
been

by
a

of
the
Jockey
Club
;
and
,

by

,
he
observed
that
,
as

an

,

the
parties
,
he

,

Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
Paul

at
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
's
;
and
,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

HOME
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
27
.
<EOS>
Showing
that
old
friends
may
not

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
That
people
are
prone
to
bite
,
and
that
biters
may
sometimes
be
bitten
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
,
Junior
---
for
the
sporting
character
,
whilom
of
general
utility
at
Todgers
's
,
had
now
regularly
set
up
in
life
under
that
name
,
without
troubling
himself
to
obtain
from
the

a
direct

in
the
form
of
a
Private
Bill
,
which
of
all
kinds
and
classes
of
bills
is
without
exception
the
most
unreasonable
in
its
charges
---
Mr
Bailey
,
Junior
,
just
tall
enough
to
be
seen
by
an
inquiring
eye
,
gazing
indolently
at
society
from
beneath
the

of
his
master
's

,
drove

up
and
down
Pall
Mall
,
about
the
hour
of
noon
,
in
waiting
for
his
"
Governor
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
horse
of
distinguished
family
,
who
had
Capricorn
for

,
and
Cauliflower
for
his

,
showed

worthy
of
his
high
relations
by
champing
at
the
bit
until
his
chest
was
white
with

,
and
rearing
like

horse
in

;
the

in
the

;
pedestrians
admired
;
Mr
Bailey
was
complacent
,
but

.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
say
,
"
A
barrow
,
good
people
,
a
mere

;
nothing
to
what

could
do
,
if

!
"
<EOS>
and

,

green

outside

,
as

were

to

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
had
a
great
opinion
of
Brother
to
Cauliflower
,
and
estimated
his
powers
highly
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
never
told

so
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
it
was
his
practice
,
in

,
to
assail

with
disrespectful
,
if
not
injurious
,
expressions
,
as
,
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
would
you
!
"
<EOS>
"
Did
you
think
it
,
then
?
"
"
Where
are
you
going
to
now
?
"
"
No
,
you
wo
n't
,
my
lad
!
"
and
similar
fragmentary
remarks
.
 
<EOS>
These
being
usually
accompanied
by
a
jerk
of
the
rein
,
or
a
crack
of
the
whip
,
led
to
many
trials
of
strength
between
them
,
and
to
many
contentions
for
the
upper
-
hand
,
terminating
,
now
and
then
,
in
china
-
shops
,
and
other
unusual
goals
,
as
Mr
Bailey
had
already
hinted
to
his
friend
Poll
Sweedlepipe
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
Mr
Bailey
,
being
in
spirits
,
was
more
than
commonly
hard
upon
his
charge
;
in
consequence
of
which
that
fiery
animal
confined
himself
almost
entirely
to
his
hind
legs
in
displaying
his
paces
,
and
constantly
got
himself
into
positions
with
reference
to
the
cabriolet
that
very
much
amazed
the
passengers
in
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Bailey
,
not
at
all
disturbed
,
had
still
a
shower
of
pleasantries
to
bestow
on
any
one
who
crossed
his
path
;
as
,
calling
to
a
full
-
grown
coal
-
heaver
in
a
wagon
,
who
for
a
moment
blocked
the
way
,
"
Now
,
young
'
un
,
who
trusted
YOU
with
a
cart
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
inquiring
of
elderly
ladies
who
wanted
to
cross
,
and
ran
back
again
,
"
Why
they
did
n't
go
to
the
workhouse
and
get
an
order
to
be
buried
?
"
<EOS>
tempting
boys
,
with
friendly
words
,
to
get
up
behind
,
and
immediately
afterwards
cutting
them
down
;
and
the
like
flashes
of
a
cheerful
humour
,
which
he
would
occasionally
relieve
by
going
round
St.
James
's
Square
at
a
hand
gallop
,
and
coming
slowly
into
Pall
Mall
by
another
entry
,
as
if
,
in
the
interval
,
his
pace
had
been
a
perfect
crawl
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
these
amusements
had
been
very
often
repeated
,
and
the
apple
-
stall
at
the
corner
had
sustained
so
many
miraculous
escapes
as
to
appear
impregnable
,
that
Mr
Bailey
was
summoned
to
the
door
of
a
certain
house
in
Pall
Mall
,
and
turning
short
,
obeyed
the
call
and
jumped
out
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
had
held
the
bridle
for
some
minutes
longer
,
every
jerk
of
Cauliflower
's
brother
's
head
,
and
every
twitch
of
Cauliflower
's
brother
's
nostril
,
taking
him
off
his
legs
in
the
meanwhile
,
that
two
persons
entered
the
vehicle
,
one
of
whom
took
the
reins
and
drove
rapidly
off
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
until
Mr
Bailey
had
run
after
it
some
hundreds
of
yards
in
vain
,
that
he
managed
to
lift
his
short
leg
into
the
iron
step
,
and
finally
to
get
his
boots
upon
the
little
footboard
behind
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
indeed
,
he
became
a
sight
to
see
;
and
---
standing
now
on
one
foot
and
now
upon
the
other
,
now
trying
to
look
round
the
cab
on
this
side
,
now
on
that
,
and
now
endeavouring
to
peep
over
the
top
of
it
,
as
it
went
dashing
in
among
the
carts
and
coaches
---
was
from
head
to
heel
Newmarket
.
   
<EOS>
The
appearance
of
Mr
Bailey
's
governor
as
he
drove
along
fully
justified
that
enthusiastic
youth
's
description
of
him
to
the
wondering
Poll
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
world
of
jet
-
black
shining
hair
upon
his
head
,
upon
his
cheeks
,
upon
his
chin
,
upon
his
upper
lip
.
 
<EOS>
His
clothes
,
symmetrically
made
,
were
of
the
newest
fashion
and
the
costliest
kind
.
 
<EOS>
Flowers
of
gold
and
blue
,
and
green
and
blushing
red
,
were
on
his
waistcoat
;
precious
chains
and
jewels
sparkled
on
his
breast
;
his
fingers
,
clogged
with
brilliant
rings
,
were
as
unwieldly
as
summer
flies
but
newly
rescued
from
a
honey
-
pot
.
 
<EOS>
The
daylight
mantled
in
his
gleaming
hat
and
boots
as
in
a
polished
glass
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
,
though
changed
his
name
,
and
changed
his
outward
surface
,
it
was
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
Though
turned
and
twisted
upside
down
,
and
inside
out
,
as
great
men
have
been
sometimes
known
to
be
;
though
no
longer
Montague
Tigg
,
but
Tigg
Montague
;
still
it
was
Tigg
;
the
same
Satanic
,
gallant
,
military
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
The
brass
was
burnished
,
lacquered
,
newly
stamped
;
yet
it
was
the
true
Tigg
metal
notwithstanding
.
   
<EOS>
Beside
him
sat
a
smiling
gentleman
,
of
less
pretensions
and
of
business
looks
,
whom
he
addressed
as
David
.
 
<EOS>
Surely
not
the
David
of
the
---
how
shall
it
be
phrased
?
---
the
triumvirate
of
golden
balls
?
 
<EOS>
Not
David
,
tapster
at
the
Lombards
'
Arms
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
secretary
's
salary
,
David
,
"
said
Mr
Montague
,
"
the
office
being
now
established
,
is
eight
hundred
pounds
per
annum
,
with
his
house
-
rent
,
coals
,
and
candles
free
.
 
<EOS>
His
five
-
and
-
twenty
shares
he
holds
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Is
that
enough
?
"
   
<EOS>
David
smiled
and
nodded
,
and
coughed
behind
a
little
locked
portfolio
which
he
carried
;
with
an
air
that
proclaimed
him
to
be
the
secretary
in
question
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
that
's
enough
,
"
said
Montague
,
"
I
will
propose
it
at
the
Board
to
-
day
,
in
my
capacity
as
chairman
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
secretary
smiled
again
;
laughed
,
indeed
,
this
time
;
and
said
,
rubbing
his
nose
slily
with
one
end
of
the
portfolio
:
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
capital
thought
,
was
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
was
a
capital
thought
,
David
?
"
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
inquired
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Anglo
-
Bengalee
,
"
tittered
the
secretary
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Company
is
rather
a
capital
concern
,
I
hope
,
David
,
"
said
Montague
.
   
<EOS>
"
Capital
indeed
!
"
cried
the
secretary
,
with
another

---
"
in
one
sense
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
only
important
one
,
"
observed
the
chairman
;
"
which
is
number
one
,
David
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
"
asked
the
secretary
,
bursting
into
another
laugh
,
"
what
will
be
the
paid
up
capital
,
according
to
the
next
prospectus
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
figure
of
two
,
and
as
many
oughts
after
it
as
the
printer
can
get
into
the
same
line
,
"
replied
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
!
"
   
At
this
they
both
laughed
;
the
secretary
so
vehemently
,
that
in
kicking
up
his
feet
,
he
kicked
the
apron
open
,
and
nearly
started
Cauliflower
's
brother
into
an
oyster
shop
;
not
to
mention
Mr
Bailey
's
receiving
such

swing
,
that
he
held
on
for
a
moment
quite
a
young
Fame
,
by
one
strap
and
no
legs
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
chap
you
are
!
"
exclaimed
David
admiringly
,
when
this
little
alarm
had
subsided
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
,
genius
,
David
,
genius
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
"
Well
,
upon
my
soul
,
you
ARE
a
genius
then
,
"
said
David
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
always
knew
you
had
the
gift
of
the
gab
,
of
course
;
but
I
never
believed
you
were
half
the
man
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
How
could
I
?
"
   
"
I
rise
with
circumstances
,
David
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
point
of
genius
in
itself
,
"
said
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
were
to
lose
a
hundred
pound
wager
to
me
at
this
minute
David
,
and
were
to
pay
it
(
<EOS>
which
is
most
confoundedly
improbable
)
,
I
should
rise
,
in
a
mental
point
of
view
,
directly
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
due
to
Mr
Tigg
to
say
that
he
had
really
risen
with
his
opportunities
;
and
,
peculating
on
a
grander
scale
,
he
had
become
a
grander
man
altogether
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
"
cried
the
secretary
,
laying
his
hand
,
with
growing
familiarity
,
upon
the
chairman
's
arm
.
 
<EOS>
"
When
I
look
at
you
,
and
think
of
your
property
in
Bengal
being
---
ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
---
"
   
The
half
-
expressed
idea
seemed
no
less
ludicrous
to
Mr
Tigg
than
to
his
friend
,
for
he
laughed
too
,
heartily
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
Being
,
"
resumed
David
,
"
being
amenable
---
<EOS>
your
property
in
Bengal
being
amenable
---
to
all
claims
upon
the
company
;
when
I
look
at
you
and
think
of
that
,
you
might
tickle
me
into
fits
by
waving
the
feather
of
a
pen
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
you
might
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
a
devilish
fine
property
,
"
said
Tigg
Montague
,
"
to
be
amenable
to
any
claims
.
 
<EOS>
The
preserve
of
tigers
alone
is
worth
a
mint
of
money
,
David
.
"
   
<EOS>
David
could
only
reply
in
the
intervals
of
his
laughter
,
"
Oh
,
what
a
chap
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
and
so
continued
to
laugh
,
and
hold
his
sides
,
and
wipe
his
eyes
,
for
some
time
,
without
offering
any
other
observation
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
capital
idea
?
"
said
Tigg
,
returning
after
a
time
to
his
companion
's
first
remark
;
"
no
doubt
it
was
a
capital
idea
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
my
idea
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
my
idea
,
"
said
David
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hang
it
,
let
a
man
have
some
credit
.
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
I
say
to
you
that
I
'd
saved
a
few
pounds
?
---
"
   
"
You
said
!
 
<EOS>
Did

I
say
to
you
,
"
interposed
Tigg
,
"
that
I
had
come
into
a
few
pounds
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
you
did
,
"
returned
David
,
warmly
,
"
but
that
's
not
the
idea
.
 
<EOS>
Who
said
,
that
if
we
put
the
money
together
we
could
furnish
an
office
,
and
make
a
show
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
who
said
,
"
retorted
Mr
Tigg
,
"
that
,
provided
we
did
it
on
a
sufficiently
large
scale
,
we
could
furnish
an
office
and
make
a
show
,
without
any
money
at
all
?
 
<EOS>
Be
rational
,
and
just
,
and
calm
,
and
tell
me
whose
idea
was
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
there
,
"
David
was
obliged
to
confess
,
"
you
had
the
advantage
of
me
,
I
admit
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
put
myself
on
a
level
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
want
a
little
credit
in
the
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
the
credit
you
deserve
to
have
,
"
said
Tigg
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
plain
work
of
the
company
,
David
---
figures
,
books
,
circulars
,
advertisements
,
pen
,
ink
,
and
paper
,
sealing
-
wax
and

---
is

by
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
a
first
-
rate
groveller
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
dispute
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
ornamental
department
,
David
;
the
inventive
and
poetical
department
---
"
   
"
Is
entirely
yours
,
"
said
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
question
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
with
such
a
swell
turnout
as
this
,
and
all

you
've

about
you
,

the

you
lead
,
I
mean

say
it
's

precious
comfortable

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Does
it
gain

?
 
<EOS>
Is

Anglo
-
Bengalee
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
David
.
   
<EOS>
"
Could
you
undertake

?
"
demanded

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
David
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
"
laughed
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
be
contented
with
your
station
and
your
profits
,
David
,
my
fine
fellow
,
and
bless
the
day
that
made

acquainted
across
the
counter
of
our
common
uncle
,
for
it
was
a
golden
day
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
will
have
been
already
gathered
from
the
conversation
of
these
worthies
,
that
they
were
embarked
in
an
enterprise
of
some
magnitude
,
in
which
they
addressed
the
public
in
general
from
the
strong
position
of
having
everything
to
gain
and
nothing
at
all
to
lose
;
and
which
,
based
upon
this
great
principle
,
was
thriving
pretty
comfortably
.
   
<EOS>
The
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Company
started
into
existence
one
morning
,
not
an
Infant
Institution
,
but
a
Grown
-
up
Company
running
alone
at
a
great
pace
,
and
doing
business
right
and
left
:
with
a
"
branch
"
in
a
first
floor
over
a
tailor
's
at
the
west
-
end
of
the
town
,
and
main
offices
in
a
new
street
in
the
City
,
comprising
the
upper
part
of
a
spacious
house
resplendent
in
stucco
and
plate
-
glass
,
with
wire
-
blinds
in
all
the
windows
,
and
"
Anglo
-
Bengalee
"
worked
into
the
pattern
of
every
one
of
them
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
doorpost
was
painted
again
in
large
letters
,
"
offices
of
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Company
,
"
and
on
the
door
was
a
large
brass
plate
with
the
same
inscription
;
always
kept
very
bright
,
as
courting
inquiry
;
staring
the
City
out
of
countenance
after
office
hours
on
working
days
,
and
all
day
long
on
Sundays
;
and
looking
bolder
than
the
Bank
.
 
<EOS>
Within
,
the
offices
were
newly
plastered
,
newly
painted
,
newly
papered
,
newly
countered
,
newly
floor
-
clothed
,
newly
tabled
,
newly
chaired
,
newly
fitted
up
in
every
way
,
with
goods
that
were
substantial
and
expensive
,
and
designed
(
like
the
company
)
to
last
.
 
<EOS>
Business
!
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
green
ledgers
with
red
backs
,
like
strong
cricket
-
balls
beaten
flat
;
the
court
-
guides
directories
,
day
-
books
,
almanacks
,
letter
-
boxes
,
weighing
-
machines
for
letters
,
rows
of
fire
-
buckets
for
dashing
out
a
conflagration
in
its
first
spark
,
and
saving
the
immense
wealth
in
notes
and
bonds
belonging
to
the
company
;
look
at
the
iron
safes
,
the
clock
,
the
office
seal
---
in
its
capacious
self
,
security
for
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Solidity
!
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
massive
blocks
of
marble
in
the
chimney
-
pieces
,
and
the
gorgeous
parapet
on
the
top
of
the
house
!
<EOS>
Publicity
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
company
is
painted
on
the
very
coal
-
scuttles
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
repeated
at
every
turn
until
the
eyes
are
dazzled
with
it
,
and
the
head
is
giddy
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
engraved
upon
the
top
of
all
the
letter
paper
,
and
it
makes
a
scroll
-
work
round
the
seal
,
and
it
shines
out
of
the
porter
's
buttons
,
and
it
is
repeated
twenty
times
in
every
circular
and
public
notice
wherein
one
David
Crimple
,
Esquire
,
Secretary
and
resident
Director
,
takes
the
liberty
of
inviting
your
attention
to
the
accompanying
statement
of
the
advantages
offered
by
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Company
;
and
fully
proves
to
you
that
any
connection
on
your
part
with
that
establishment
must
result
in
a
perpetual
Christmas
Box
and
constantly
increasing
Bonus
to
yourself
,
and
that
nobody
can
run
any
risk
by
the
transaction
except
the
office
,
which
,
in
its
great
liberality
is
pretty
sure
to
lose
.
 
<EOS>
And
this
,
David
Crimple
,
Esquire
,
submits
to
you
(
and
the
odds
are
heavy
you
believe
him
)
<EOS>
,
is
the
best
guarantee
that
can
reasonably
be
suggested
by
the
Board
of
Management
for
its
permanence
and
stability
.
   
<EOS>
This
gentleman
's
name
,
by
the
way
,
had
been
originally
Crimp
;
but
as
the
word
was
susceptible
of
an
awkward
construction
and
might
be
misrepresented
,
he
had
altered
it
to
Crimple
.
   
<EOS>
Lest
with
all
these
proofs
and
confirmations
,
any
man
should
be
suspicious
of
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
company
;
should
doubt
in
tiger
,
cab
,
or
person
,
Tigg
Montague
,
Esquire
,
(
of
Pall
Mall
and
Bengal
)
,
or
any
other
name
in
the
imaginative
List
of
Directors
;
there
was
a
porter
on
the
premises
---
a
wonderful
creature
,
in
a
vast
red
waistcoat
and
a
short
-
tailed
pepper
-
and
-
salt
coat
---
who
carried
more
conviction
to
the
minds
of
sceptics
than
the
whole
establishment
without
him
.
 
<EOS>
No
confidences
existed
between
him
and
the
Directorship
;
nobody
knew
where
he
had
served
last
;
no
character
or
explanation
had
been
given
or
required
.
 
<EOS>
No
questions
had
been
asked
on
either
side
.
 
<EOS>
This
mysterious
being
,
relying
solely
on
his
figure
,
had
applied
for
the
situation
,
and
had
been
instantly
engaged
on
his
own
terms
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
high
;
but
he
knew
,
doubtless
,
that
no
man
could
carry
such
an
extent
of
waistcoat
as
himself
,
and
felt
the
full
value
of
his
capacity
to
such
an
institution
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
sat
upon
a
seat
erected
for
him
in
a
corner
of
the
office
,
with
his
glazed
hat
hanging
on
a
peg
over
his
head
,
it
was
impossible
to
doubt
the
respectability
of
the
concern
.
 
<EOS>
It
went
on
doubling
itself
with
every
square
inch
of
his
red
waistcoat
until
,
like
the
problem
of
the
nails
in
the
horse
's
shoes
,
the
total
became
enormous
.
 
<EOS>
People
had
been
known
to
apply
to
effect
an
insurance
on
their
lives
for
a
thousand
pounds
,
and
looking
at
him
,
to
beg
,
before
the
form
of
proposal
was
filled
up
,
that
it
might
be
made
two
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
was
not
a
giant
.
 
<EOS>
His
coat
was
rather
small
than
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
The
whole
charm
was
in
his
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
Respectability
,
competence
,
property
in
Bengal
or
anywhere
else
,
responsibility
to
any
amount
on
the
part
of
the
company
that
employed
him
,
were
all
expressed
in
that
one
garment
.
   
<EOS>
Rival
offices
had
endeavoured
to
lure
him
away
;
Lombard
Street
itself
had
beckoned
to
him
;
rich
companies
had
whispered
"
Be
a
Beadle
!
"
<EOS>
but
he
still
continued
faithful
to
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
.
<EOS>
Whether
he
was
a
deep
rogue
,
or
a
stately
simpleton
,
it
was
impossible
to
make
out
,
but
he
appeared
to
believe
in
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
grave
with
imaginary
cares
of
office
;
and
having
nothing
whatever
to
do
,
and
something
less
to
take
care
of
,
would
look
as
if
the
pressure
of
his
numerous
duties
,
and
a
sense
of
the
treasure
in
the
company
's
strong
-
room
,
made
him
a
solemn
and
a
thoughtful
man
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
cabriolet
drove
up
to
the
door
,
this
officer
appeared
bare
-
headed
on
the
pavement
,
crying
aloud
"
Room
for
the
chairman
,
room
for
the
chairman
,
if
you
please
!
"
<EOS>
much
to
the
admiration
of
the
bystanders
,
who
,
it
is
needless
to
say
,
had
their
attention
directed
to
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Company
thenceforth
,
by
that
means
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
leaped
gracefully
out
,
followed
by
the
Managing
Director
(
who
was
by
this
time
very
distant
and
respectful
)
,
and
ascended
the
stairs
,
still
preceded
by
the
porter
,
who
cried
as
he
went
,
"
By
your
leave
there
!
<EOS>
by
your
leave
!
 
<EOS>
The
Chairman
of
the
Board
,
Gentle
---
MEN
!
 
<EOS>
In
like
manner
,
but
in
a
still
more
stentorian
voice
,
he
ushered
the
chairman
through
the
public
office
,
where
some
humble
clients
were
transacting
business
,
into
an
awful
chamber
,
labelled
Board
-
room
;
the
door
of
which
sanctuary
immediately
closed
,
and
screened
the
great
capitalist
from
vulgar
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
The
board
-
room
had
a
Turkey
carpet
in
it
,
a
sideboard
,
a
portrait
of
Tigg
Montague
,
Esquire
,
as
chairman
;
a
very
imposing
chair
of
office
,
garnished
with
an
ivory
hammer
and
a
little
hand
-
bell
;
and
a
long
table
,
set
out
at
intervals
with
sheets
of
blotting
-
paper
,
foolscap
,
clean
pens
,
and
inkstands
.
 
<EOS>
The
chairman
having
taken
his
seat
with
great
solemnity
,
the
secretary
supported
him
on
his
right
hand
,
and
the
porter
stood
bolt
upright
behind
them
,
forming
a
warm
background
of
waistcoat
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
the
board
:
<EOS>
everything
else
being
a
light
-
hearted
little
fiction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bullamy
!
"
said
Mr
Tigg
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
replied
the
porter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
the
Medical
Officer
know
,
with
my
compliments
,
that
I
wish
to
see
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Bullamy
cleared
his
throat
,
and
bustled
out
into
the
office
,
crying
"
The
Chairman
of
the
Board
wishes
to
see
the
Medical
Officer
.
 
<EOS>
By
your
leave
there
!
 
<EOS>
By
your
leave
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
soon
returned
with
the
gentleman
in
question
;
and
at
both
openings
of
the
board
-
room
door
---
 
at
his
coming
in
and
at
his
going
out
---
simple
clients
were
seen
to
stretch
their
necks
and
stand
upon
their
toes
,
thirsting
to
catch
the
slightest
glimpse
of
that
mysterious
chamber
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jobling
,
my
dear
friend
!
"
said
Mr
Tigg
,
"
how
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
Bullamy
,
wait
outside
.
 
<EOS>
Crimple
,
do
n't
leave
us
.
 
<EOS>
Jobling
,
my
good
fellow
<EOS>
,
I
am
glad
to
see
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
are
you
,
Mr
Montague
,
eh
?
"
said
the
Medical
Officer
,
throwing
himself
luxuriously
into
an
easy
-
chair
(
they
were
all
easy
-
chairs
in
the
board
-
room
)
,
and
taking
a
handsome
gold
snuff
-
box
from
the

of

black
satin

.
 
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
A
little
worn
with
business
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
rest
.
 
<EOS>
A
little
feverish
from
wine
,
humph
?
 
<EOS>
If
so
,
water
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
at
all
the
matter
,
and
quite
comfortable
?
 
<EOS>
Then
take
some
lunch
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
wholesome
thing
at
this
time
of
day
to
strengthen
the
gastric
juices
with
lunch
,
Mr
Montague
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
Medical
Officer
<EOS>
(
he
was
the
same
medical
officer
who
had
followed
poor
old
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
to
the
grave
,
and
who
had
attended
Mrs
Gamp
's
patient
at
the
Bull
)
smiled
in
saying
these
words
;
and
casually
added
,
as
he
brushed
some
grains
of
snuff
from
his
shirt
-
frill
,
"
I
always
take
it
myself
about
this
time
of
day
,
do
you
know
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bullamy
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
Chairman
,
ringing
the
little
bell
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Lunch
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
on
my
account
,
I
hope
?
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
quite
ashamed
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
if
I
had
been
a
sharp
practitioner
,
Mr
Montague
,
I
should
n't
have
mentioned
it
without
a
fee
;
for
you
may
depend
upon
it
,
my
dear
sir
,
that
if
you
do
n't
make
a
point
of
taking
lunch
,
you
'll
very
soon
come
under
my
hands
.
<EOS>
Allow
me
to
illustrate
this
.
 
<EOS>
In
Mr
Crimple
's
leg
---
"
   
The
resident
Director
gave
an
involuntary
start
,
for
the
doctor
,
in
the
heat
of
his
demonstration
,
caught
it
up
and
laid
it
across
his
own
,
as
if
he
were
going
to
take
it
off
,
then
and
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
Mr
Crimple
's
leg
,
you
'll
observe
,
"
pursued
the
doctor
,
turning
back
his
cuffs
and
spanning
the
limb
with
both
hands
,
"
where
Mr
Crimple
's
knee
fits
into
the
socket
,
here
<EOS>
,
there
is
---
that
is
to
say
,
between
the
bone
and
the
socket
---
a
certain
quantity
of
animal
oil
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
pick
MY
leg
out
for
?
"
said
Mr
Crimple
,
looking
with
something
of
an
anxious
expression
at
his
limb
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
same
with
other
legs
,
ai
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
,
my
good
sir
,
"
returned
the
doctor
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
whether
it
is
the
same
with
other
legs
,
or
not
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
mind
,
"
said
David
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
a
particular
case
,
Mr
Montague
,
"
returned
the
doctor
,
"
as
illustrating
my
remark
,
you
observe
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
portion
of
Mr
Crimple
's
leg
,
sir
,
there
is
a
certain
amount
of
animal
oil
.
 
<EOS>
In
every
one
of
Mr
Crimple
's
joints
,
sir
,
there
is
more
or
less
of
the
same
deposit
.
 
<EOS>
Very
good
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Crimple
neglects
his
meals
,
or
fails
to
take
his
proper
quantity
of
rest
,
that
oil
wanes
,
and
becomes
exhausted
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
consequence
?
 
<EOS>
Mr
Crimple
's
bones
sink
down
into
their
sockets
,
sir
,
and
Mr
Crimple
becomes
a
weazen
,
puny
,
stunted
,
miserable
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
doctor
let
Mr
Crimple
's
leg
fall
suddenly
,
as
if
he
were
already
in
that
agreeable
condition
;
turned
down
his
wristbands
again
,
and
looked
triumphantly
at
the
chairman
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
know
a
few
secrets
of
nature
in
our
profession
,
sir
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
Of
course
we
do
.
 
<EOS>
We
study
for
that
;
we
pass
the
Hall
and
the
College
for
that
;
and
we
take
our
station
in
society
BY
that
.
<EOS>
It
's
extraordinary
how
little
is
known
on
these
subjects
generally
.
<EOS>
Where
do
you
suppose
,
now
"
---
the
doctor
closed
one
eye
,
as
he
leaned
back
smilingly
in
his
chair
,
and
formed
a
triangle
with
his
hands
,
of
which
his
two
thumbs
composed
the
base
---
<EOS>
"
where
do
you
suppose
Mr
Crimple
's
stomach
is
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Crimple
,
more
agitated
than
before
,
clapped
his
hand
immediately
below
his
waistcoat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
"
cried
the
doctor
;
"
not
at
all
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
a
popular
mistake
!
 
<EOS>
My
good
sir
,
you
're
altogether
deceived
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
feel
it
there
,
when
it
's
out
of
order
;
that
's
all
I
know
,
"
said
Crimple
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
you
do
,
"
replied
the
doctor
;
"
but
science
knows
better
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
patient
of
mine
once
,
"
touching
one
of
the
many
mourning
rings
upon
his
fingers
,
and
slightly
bowing
his
head
,
"
a
gentleman
who
did
me
the
honour
to
make
a
very
handsome
mention
of
me
in
his
will
---
"
in
testimony
,
"
as
he
was
pleased
to
say
,
"
of
the
unremitting
zeal
,
talent
,
and
attention
of
my
friend
and
medical
attendant
,
John
Jobling
,
Esquire
,
M*R*C*S
,
"
---
who
was
so
overcome
by
the
idea
of
having
all
his
life
laboured
under
an
erroneous
view
of
the
locality
of
this
important
organ
,
that
when
I
assured
him
on
my
professional
reputation
,
he
was
mistaken
,
he
burst
into
tears
,
put
out
his
hand
,
and
said
,
"
Jobling
,
God
bless
you
!
"
 
<EOS>
Immediately
afterwards
he
became
speechless
,
and
was
ultimately
buried
at
Brixton
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
your
leave
there
!
"
cried
Bullamy
,
without
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
your
leave
!
<EOS>
Refreshment
for
the
Board
-
room
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
,
jocularly
,
as
he
rubbed
his
hands
,
and
drew
his
chair
nearer
to
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
true
Life
Assurance
,
Mr
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
The
best
Policy
in
the
world
,
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
We
should
be
provident
,
and
eat
and
drink
whenever
we
can
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
,
Mr
Crimple
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
resident
Director
acquiesced
rather
sulkily
,
as
if
the
gratification
of
replenishing
his
stomach
had
been
impaired
by
the
unsettlement
of
his
preconceived
opinions
in
reference
to
its
situation
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
appearance
of
the
porter
and
under
-
porter
with
a
tray
covered
with
a
snow
-
white
cloth
,
which
,
being
thrown
back
,
displayed
a
pair
of
cold
roast
fowls
,
flanked
by
some
potted
meats
and
a
cool
salad
,
quickly
restored
his
good
humour
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
enhanced
still
further
by
the
arrival
of
a
bottle
of
excellent
madeira
,
and
another
of
champagne
;
and
he
soon
attacked
the
repast
with
an
appetite
scarcely
inferior
to
that
of
the
medical
officer
.
   
<EOS>
The
lunch
was
handsomely
served
,
with
a
profusion
of
rich
glass
plate
,
and
china
;
which
seemed
to
denote
that
eating
and
drinking
on
a
showy
scale
formed
no
unimportant
item
in
the
business
of
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Directorship
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
proceeded
,
the
Medical
Officer
grew
more
and
more
joyous
and
red
-
faced
,
insomuch
that
every
mouthful
he
ate
,
and
every
drop
of
wine
he
swallowed
,
seemed
to
impart
new
lustre
to
his
eyes
,
and
to
light
up
new
sparks
in
his
nose
and
forehead
.
   
<EOS>
In
certain
quarters
of
the
City
and
its
neighbourhood
,
Mr
Jobling
was
,
as
we
have
already
seen
in
some
measure
,
a
very
popular
character
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
portentously
sagacious
chin
,
and
a
pompous
voice
,
with
a
rich
huskiness
in
some
of
its
tones
that
went
directly
to
the
heart
,
like
a
ray
of
light
shining
through
the
ruddy
medium
of
choice
old
burgundy
.
 
<EOS>
His
neckerchief
and
shirt
-
frill
were
ever
of
the
whitest
,
his
clothes
of
the
blackest
and
sleekest
,
his
gold
watch
-
chain
of
the
heaviest
,
and
his
seals
of
the
largest
.
 
<EOS>
His
boots
,
which
were
always
of
the
brightest
,
creaked
as
he
walked
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
could
shake
his
head
,
rub
his
hands
,
or
warm
himself
before
a
fire
,
better
than
any
man
alive
;
and
he
had
a
peculiar
way
of
smacking
his
lips
and
saying
,
"
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
at
intervals
while
patients
detailed
their
symptoms
,
which
inspired
great
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
express
,
"
I
know
what
you
're
going
to
say
better
than
you
do
;
but
go
on
,
go
on
.
"
 
<EOS>
As
he
talked
on
all
occasions
whether
he
had
anything
to
say
or
not
,
it
was
unanimously
observed
of
him
that
he
was
"
full
of
anecdote
;
"
and
his
experience
and
profit
from
it
were
considered
,
for
the
same
reason
,
to
be
something
much
too
extensive
for
description
.
 
<EOS>
His
female
patients
could
never
praise
him
too
highly
;
and
the
coldest
of
his
male
admirers
would
always
say
this
for
him
to
their
friends
,
"
that
whatever
Jobling
's
professional
skill
might
be
(
and
it
could
not
be
denied
that
he
had
a
very
high
reputation
)
,
he
was
one
of
the
most
comfortable
fellows
you
ever
saw
in
your
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jobling
was
for
many
reasons
,
and
not
last
in
the
list
because
his
connection
lay
principally
among
tradesmen
and
their
families
,
exactly
the
sort
of
person
whom
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Company
wanted
for
a
medical
officer
.
 
<EOS>
But
Jobling
was
far
too
knowing
to
connect

with
the
company
in
any
closer
ties
than
as
a
paid
(
and
well
paid
)
functionary
,
or
to
allow
his
connection
to
be
misunderstood
abroad
,
if
he
could
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
Hence
he
always
stated
the
case
to
an
inquiring
patient
,
after
this
manner
:
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
