,
with

to
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
,
my

,

,

;
very

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
the
medical

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
The

is

of

;
BIS
DAT
QUI
CITO
DAT
"
---
(
"
classical

,
Jobling
!
<EOS>
"
thinks
the
patient
,
"
well
-

man
!
"
)
---
"
and
I

.
 
<EOS>
Therefore

bound
,

,
to
speak

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
"
Nothing

Jobling
's
conduct
,
"
thinks

,
who

's

.
)
 
<EOS>
"
If

,

,
"

,
"

,
there

;

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Delicacy
---
your

me

---

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
"
Nothing

,
"

.
)
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
Property
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
House

,

.
 
<EOS>
Costly

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

.
 
<EOS>
I

a

.
 
<EOS>
If

's

,

;

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
My

<EOS>
Nothing

.
 
<EOS>
Caution

side
<EOS>
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
That

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

"

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

"
Talk

<EOS>

<EOS>

I

,
"

<EOS>
The

into
the
outer

,
and

with
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Montague
,
"
said
Jobling
.
 
<EOS>
"
Allow
me
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
---
our
chairman
.
 
<EOS>
Now
do
you
know
,
"
he
added
checking
himself
with
infinite
policy
,
and
looking
round
with
a

;
"
that
's
a
very
singular
instance
of
the
force
of
example
.
 
<EOS>
It
really
is
a
very
remarkable
instance
of
the
force
of
example
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
OUR
chairman
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
I
say
our
chairman
?
 
<EOS>
Because
he
is
not
MY
chairman
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
connection
with
the
company
,
farther
than
giving
them
,
for
a
certain
fee
and
reward
,
my
poor
opinion
as
a
medical
man
,
precisely
as
I
may
give
it
any
day
to
Jack
Noakes
or
Tom
Styles
.
 
<EOS>
Then
why
do
I
say
our
chairman
?
 
<EOS>
Simply
because
I
hear
the
phrase
constantly
repeated
about
me
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
the
involuntary
operation
of
the
mental
faculty
in
the
imitative
biped
man
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Crimple
,
I
believe
you
never
take
snuff
?
 
<EOS>
Injudicious
.
 
<EOS>
You
should
.
"
   
<EOS>
Pending
these
remarks
on
the
part
of
the
doctor
,
and
the
lengthened
and
sonorous
pinch
with
which
he
followed
them
up
,
Jonas
took
a
seat
at
the
board
;
as
ungainly
a
man
as
ever
he
has
been
within
the
reader
's
knowledge
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
too
common
with
all

us
,
but
it
is
especially
in
the
nature
of
a
mean

,
to
be
overawed
by
fine
clothes
and
fine
furniture
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
a
very
decided
influence
on
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
you
two
gentlemen
have
business
to
discuss
,
I

,
"
said

doctor
,
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
So
is

;
for
several

for
me
in
the

room
,
and
I
have

to

---
after
I

.
 
<EOS>
Having
had
the

to
introduce
you
to

other
,
I

go
about

.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
But
allow

,
Mr
Montague
,
before

,
to

of

:
That

,
sir
,
"
rapping
his

-
box
solemnly
,
"
to
reconcile
me
to
human
nature
,
than
any
man
alive
or

.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
Jobling
bolted
abruptly
out
of
the
room
,
and
proceeded
in
his
own
official
department
,
to
impress
the
lives
in
waiting
with
a
sense
of
his
keen
conscientiousness
in
the
discharge
of
his
duty
,
and
the
great
difficulty
of
getting
into
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
;
by
feeling
their
pulses
,
looking
at
their
tongues
,
listening
at
their
ribs
,
poking
them
in
the
chest
,
and
so
forth
;
though
,
if
he
did
n't
well
know
beforehand
that
whatever
kind
of
lives
they
were
,
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
would
accept
them
readily
,
he
was
far
from
being
the
Jobling
that
his
friend
considered
him
;
and
was
not
the
original
Jobling
,
but
a
spurious
imitation
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Crimple
also
departed
on
the
business
of
the
morning
;
and
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
and
Tigg
were
left
alone
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
learn
from
our
friend
,
"
said
Tigg
,
drawing
his
chair
towards
Jonas
with
a
winning
ease
of
manner
,
"
that
you
have
been
thinking
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Ecod
<EOS>
then
he
'd
no
right
to
say
so
,
"
cried
Jonas
,
interrupting
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
tell
HIM
my
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
took
it
into
his
head
that
I
was
coming
here
for
such
or
such
a
purpose
,
why
,
that
's
his
lookout
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
stand
committed
by
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
said
this
offensively
enough
;
for
over
and
above
the
habitual
distrust
of
his
character
,
it
was
in
his
nature
to
seek
to
revenge
himself
on
the
fine
clothes
and
the
fine
furniture
,
in
exact
proportion
as
he
had
been
unable
to
withstand
their
influence
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I
come
here
to
ask
a
question
or
two
,
and
get
a
document
or
two
to
consider
of
,
I
do
n't
bind
myself
to
anything
.
 
<EOS>
Let
's
understand
that
,
you
know
,
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
fellow
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tigg
,
clapping
him
on
the
shoulder
,
"
I
applaud
your
frankness
.
 
<EOS>
If
men
like
you
and
I
speak
openly
at
first
,
all
possible
misunderstanding
is
avoided
.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
I
disguise
what
you
know
so
well
,
but
what
the
crowd
never
dream
of
?
<EOS>
We
companies
are
all
birds
of
prey
;
mere
birds
of
prey
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
question
is
,
whether
in
serving
our
own
turn
,
we
can
serve
yours
too
;
whether
in
double
-
lining
our
own
nest
,
we
can
put
a
single
living
into
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
're
in
our
secret
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
behind
the
scenes
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
make
a
merit
of
dealing
plainly
with
you
,
when
we
know
we
ca
n't
help
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
remarked
,
on
the
first
introduction
of
Mr
Jonas
into
these
pages
<EOS>
,
that
there
is
a
simplicity
of
cunning
no
less
than
a
simplicity
of
innocence
,
and
that
in
all
matters
involving
a
faith
in
knavery
,
he
was
the
most
credulous
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Tigg
had
preferred
any
claim
to
high
and
honourable
dealing
,
Jonas
would
have
suspected
him
though
he
had
been
a
very
model
of
probity
;
but
when
he
gave
utterance
to
Jonas
's
own
thoughts
of
everything
and
everybody
,
Jonas
began
to
feel
that
he
was
a
pleasant
fellow
,
and
one
to
be
talked
to
freely
.
   
<EOS>
He
changed
his
position
in
the
chair
,
not
for
a
less
awkward
,
but
for
a
more
boastful
attitude
;
and
smiling
in
his
miserable
conceit
rejoined
:
   
"
<EOS>
You
an't
a
bad
man
of
business
,
Mr
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
how
to
set
about
it
,
I
WILL
say
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Tut
,
tut
,
"
said
Tigg
,
nodding
confidentially
,
and
showing
his
white

;
"
we
are
not
children
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
;
we
are
grown
men
,
I
hope
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
assented
,
and
said
after
a
short

,
first
spreading
out
his
legs
,
and
sticking
one
arm
akimbo
to
show
how
perfectly
at
home
he
was
,
   
<EOS>
"
The
truth
is
---
"
   
"
Do
n't
say
,
the
truth
,
"
interposed
Tigg
,
with
another

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
so
like
humbug
.
"
   
<EOS>
Greatly
charmed
by
this
,
Jonas
began
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
long
and
the
short
of
it
is
---
"
   
"
Better
,
"
muttered
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
better
!
"
   
"
---
That
I
did
n't
consider
myself
very
well
used
by
one

two
of
the
old
companies
in
some

I
have
had
with

---
once
had
,
I

.
 
<EOS>
They
started
objections
they
had
no
right
to
start
,
and
put
questions
they
had
no
right
to
put
,
and
carried
things
much
too
high
for
my
taste
.
"
   
<EOS>
As

made

he
cast
down

,
and
looked
curiously
at
the
carpet
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tigg
looked
curiously
at
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
made
so
long
a
pause
,
that
Tigg
came
to

,
and
said
,
in
his

:
   
<EOS>
"
Take
a
glass

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
returned
Jonas
,
with

cunning

;
"
none
of
that
,
thankee
.
 
<EOS>
No
wine
over
business
.
 
<EOS>
All

for
you
,
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

old

,

!
"
said

,

,

.
   
<EOS>

You

;
"

"

.
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,
"

;
"

.
 
<EOS>

;

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
Sweet

<EOS>
,

!

quarters

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

;

's

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
No

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

In
Pecksniff
's

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

---
"
   
"
Yes
,
"

,

<EOS>

Well

,

<EOS>
"
He

,

<EOS>
"
Dead
,

<EOS>
Venerable

,

<EOS>
You
're
very

.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
received
this

with
anything
but

,
perhaps

own

in

;

Montague

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
From

,
Mr

's

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do

at
all

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak

.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas

hard

and

;
and

"
Rather
,
ecod
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Precious

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Neat
;

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mine
.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
It

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
Mine

.
 
<EOS>
Why
do

you
"
---
he

,

<EOS>
"
why
do

?
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
Join

!
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
,
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

;

Pyramids
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
Join

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

you
,
"
said
Tigg
in

,
"
how

,
effect

,
bring

<EOS>
Not

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,

!
"

<EOS>
"
Yah
!
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
Dine

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Done
!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
See
,
"

<EOS>
"
B

,

<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
B

.
 
<EOS>
Say
fifty
or
a
hundred
pound
;
perhaps
more
;
no

.
 
<EOS>
B
proposes
self
and
two
securities
.
 
<EOS>
B
is
accepted
.
 
<EOS>
Two
securities
give
a
bond
.
 
<EOS>
B

his
own

for
double

,
and
brings
two

'

---
just

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Is
that
a
good

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,

's

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
B
's

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
 
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
B

---
"
   
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Right
!
<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

is
upon
the

that

so
confoundedly
down
upon
us
unfortunate

;
when
it

good
interest
for
itself
from

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
The
law

,

're

upon
B
;
for
besides

B

,

B
's

,

B
's

'

,

,

,

"
inquiries
"
(

,

)
,

B
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ha

,

!
 
<EOS>
I

B
,

,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas

.
 
<EOS>
It

in

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

Montague
,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ha

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
Ha

,

!
"

"

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Then

Life

;

.
 
<EOS>
Very

,

.
 
<EOS>
Money

,

;

;

!
"

"
But

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Brought

?

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

-

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
Whenever

;

"

.

"
Bolt
.
<EOS>
"

.

Seven
.

.

.

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Bullamy
!
"
   
<EOS>
Obedient

and
the
little
bell
<EOS>
,

appeared
.
<EOS>
Being

to

Jonas
out
,

went

;
and
the

within

cried
,

,
"
By

there
,
by

!
<EOS>
Gentleman

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
being
left
alone
,
pondered
for
some
moments
,
and
then
said
,
raising
his
voice
:
   
"
<EOS>
Is
Nadgett
in
the
office
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
sir
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
he
promptly
entered
;
shutting
the
board
-
room
door
after
him
,
as
carefully
as
if
he
were
about
to
plot
a
murder
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
the
man
at
a
pound
a
week
who
made
the
inquiries
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
no
virtue
or
merit
in
Nadgett
that
he
transacted
all
his
Anglo
-
Bengalee
business
secretly
and
in
the
closest
confidence
;
for
he
was
born
to
be
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
short
,
dried
-
up
,
withered
old
man
,
who
seemed
to
have
secreted
his
very
blood
;
for
nobody
would
have
given
him
credit
for
the
possession
of
six
ounces
of
it
in
his
whole
body
.
<EOS>
How
he
lived
was
a
secret
;
where
he
lived
was
a
secret
;
and
even
what
he
was
,
was
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
musty
old
pocket
-
book
he
carried
contradictory
cards
,
in
some
of
which
he
called
himself
a
coal
-
merchant
,
in
others
<EOS>
a
wine
-
merchant
,
in
others
a
commission
-
agent
,
in
others
<EOS>
a
collector
,
in
others
an
accountant
;
as
if
he
really
did
n't
know
the
secret
himself
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
keeping
appointments
in
the
City
,
and
the
other
man
never
seemed
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
sit
on
"
Change
for
hours
,
looking
at
everybody
who
walked
in
and
out
,
and
would
do
the
like
at
Garraway
's
,
and
in
other
business
coffee
-
rooms
,
in
some
of
which
he
would
be
occasionally
seen
drying
a
very
damp
pocket
-
handkerchief
before
the
fire
,
and
still
looking
over
his
shoulder
for
the
man
who
never
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
mildewed
,
threadbare
,
shabby
;
always
had
flue
upon
his
legs
and
back
;
and
kept
his
linen
so
secretly
buttoning
up
and
wrapping
over
,
that
he
might
have
had
none
---
perhaps
he
had
n't
.
 
<EOS>
He
carried
one
stained
beaver
glove
,
which
he
dangled
before
him
by
the
forefinger
as
he
walked
or
sat
;
but
even
its
fellow
was
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
Some
people
said
he
had
been
a
bankrupt
,
others
that
he
had
gone
an
infant
into
an
ancient
Chancery
suit
which
was
still
depending
,
but
it
was
all
a
secret
.
<EOS>
He
carried
bits
of
sealing
-
wax
and
a
hieroglyphical
old
copper
seal
in
his
pocket
,
and
often
secretly
indited
letters
in
corner
boxes
of
the
trysting
-
places
before
mentioned
;
but
they
never
appeared
to
go
to
anybody
,
for
he
would
put
them
into
a
secret
place
in
his
coat
,
and
deliver
them
to
himself
weeks
afterwards
,
very
much
to
his
own
surprise
,
quite
yellow
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
that
sort
of
man
that
if
he
had
died
worth
a
million
of
money
,
or
had
died
worth
<EOS>
twopence
halfpenny
<EOS>
,
everybody
would
have
been
perfectly
satisfied
,
and
would
have
said
it
was
just
as
they
expected
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
belonged
to
a
class
;
a
race
peculiar
to
the
City
;
who
are
secrets
as
profound
to
one
another
,
as
they
are
to
the
rest
of
mankind
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Nadgett
,
"
said
Montague
,
copying
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
's
address
upon
a
piece
of
paper
,
from
the
card
which
was
still
lying
on
the
table
,
"
any
information
about
this
name
,
I
shall
be
glad
to
have
myself
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
mind
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Any
you
can
scrape
together
,
bring
me
.
<EOS>
Bring
it
to
me
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nadgett
put
on
his
spectacles
,
and
read
the
name
attentively
;
then
looked
at
the
chairman
over
his
glasses
,
and
bowed
;
then
took
them
off
,
and
put
them
in
their
case
;
and
then
put
the
case
in
his
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
done
so
,
he
looked
,
without
his
spectacles
,
at
the
paper
as
it
lay
before
him
,
and
at
the
same
time
produced
his
pocket
-
book
from
somewhere
about
the
middle
of
his
spine
.
 
<EOS>
Large
as
it
was
,
it
was
very
full
of
documents
,
but
he
found
a
place
for
this
one
;
and
having
clasped
it
carefully
,
passed
it
by
a
kind
of
solemn
legerdemain
into
the
same
region
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
He
withdrew
with
another
bow
and
without
a
word
;
opening
the
door
no
wider
than
was
sufficient
for
his
passage
out
;
and
shutting
it
as
carefully
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
The
chairman
of
the
board
employed
the
rest
of
the
morning
in
affixing
his
sign
-
manual
of
gracious
acceptance
to
various
new
proposals
of
annuity
-
purchase
and
assurance
.
 
<EOS>
The
Company
was
looking
up
,
for
they
flowed
in
gaily
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
28
.
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
at
home
 
<EOS>
There
were
many
powerful
reasons
for
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
being
strongly
prepossessed
in
favour
of
the
scheme
which
its
great
originator
had
so
boldly
laid
open
to
him
;
but
three
among
them
stood
prominently
forward
.
 
<EOS>
Firstly
,
there
was
money
to
be
made
by
it
.
 
<EOS>
Secondly
,
the
money
had
the
peculiar
charm
of
being
sagaciously
obtained
at
other
people
's
cost
.
 
<EOS>
Thirdly
,
it
involved
much
outward
show
of
homage
and
distinction
:
a
board
being
an
awful
institution
in
its
own
sphere
,
and
a
director
a
mighty
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
make
a
swingeing
profit
,
have
a
lot
of
chaps
to
order
about
,
and
get
into
regular
good
society
by
one
and
the
same
means
,
and
them
so
easy
to
one
's
hand
,
ai
n't
such
a
bad
look
-
out
,
"
thought
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
The
latter
considerations
were
only
second
to
his
avarice
;
for
,
conscious
that
there
was
nothing
in
his
person
,
conduct
,
character
,
or
accomplishments
,
to
command
respect
,
he
was
greedy
of
power
,
and
was
,
in
his
heart
,
as
much
a
tyrant
as
any
laureled
conqueror
on
record
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
determined
to
proceed
with
cunning
and
caution
,
and
to
be
very
keen
on
his
observation
of
the
gentility
of
Mr
Montague
's
private
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
no
more
occurred
to
this
shallow
knave
that
Montague
wanted
him
to
be
so
,
or
he
would
n't
have
invited
him
while
his
decision
was
yet
in
abeyance
,
than
the
possibility
of
that
genius
being
able
to
overreach
him
in
any
way
,
pierced
through
his
self
-
deceit
by
the
inlet
of
a
needle
's
point
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
said
,
in
the
outset
,
that
Jonas
was
too
sharp
for
him
;
and
Jonas
,
who
would
have
been
sharp
enough
to
believe
him
in
nothing
else
,
though
he
had
solemnly
sworn
it
,
believed
him
in
that
,
instantly
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
with
a
faltering
hand
,
and
yet
with
an
imbecile
attempt
at
a
swagger
,
that
he
knocked
at
his
new
friend
's
door
in
Pall
Mall
when
the
appointed
hour
arrived
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
quickly
answered
to
the
summons
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
proud
and
was
kindly
disposed
to
take
notice
of
Jonas
;
but
Jonas
had
forgotten
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Montague
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
hope
he
wos
at
home
,
and

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
hold

,

"

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

Wolf

<EOS>
To

<EOS>

mentioning
in
Shakspeare
's
plays
,
are
there
,
Pip
?
 
<EOS>
Juliet
,
Desdemona
,
Lady
Macbeth
,
and
all
the
rest
of
'em
,
whatever
their
names
are
,
might
as
well
have
no
legs
at
all
,
for
anything
the
audience
know
about
it
,
Pip
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
in
that
respect
they
're
all
Miss
Biffins
to
the
audience
,
Pip
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
people
call
dramatic
poetry
is
a
collection
of
sermons
.
 
<EOS>
Do
I
go
to
the
theatre
to
be
lectured
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
Pip
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
wanted
that
,
I
'd
go
to
church
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
legitimate
object
of
the
drama
,
Pip
?
 
<EOS>
Human
nature
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
legs
?
<EOS>
Human
nature
.
 
<EOS>
Then
let
us
have
plenty
of
leg
pieces
,
Pip
,
and
I
'll
stand
by
you
,
my
buck
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
and
I
am
proud
to
say
,
"
added

,
"
that
he
DID
stand
by
me
,
handsomely
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
conversation
now
becoming
general
,
Mr
Jonas
's
opinion
was
requested
on
this
subject
;
and
as
it
was
in
full
accordance
with
the
sentiments
of
Mr
Pip
,
that
gentleman
was
extremely

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
both
himself
and
Wolf
had
so
much
in
common
with
Jonas
,
that
they
became
very
amicable
;
and
between
their
increasing
friendship
and
the
fumes
of
wine
,
Jonas
grew
talkative
.
   
<EOS>
It
does
not
follow
in
the
case
of
such
a
person
that
the
more
talkative
he
becomes
,
the
more
agreeable
he
is
;
on
the
contrary
,
his
merits
show
to
most
advantage
,
perhaps
,
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
Having
no
means
,
as
he
thought
,
of
putting
himself
on
an
equality
with
the
rest
,
but
by
the
assertion
of
that
depth
and
sharpness
on
which
he
had
been
complimented
,
Jonas
exhibited
that
faculty
to
the
utmost
;
and
was
so
deep
and
sharp
that
he
lost
himself
in
his
own
profundity
,
and
cut
his
fingers
with
his
own
edge
-
tools
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
especially
in
his
way
and
character
to
exhibit
his
quality
at
his
entertainer
's
expense
;
and
while
he
drank
of
his
sparkling
wines
,
and
partook
of
his
monstrous
profusion
,
to
ridicule
the
extravagance
which
had
set
such
costly
fare
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
Even
at
such
a
wanton
board
,
and
in
such
more
than
doubtful
company
,
this
might
have
proved
a
disagreeable
experiment
,
but
that
Tigg
and
Crimple
,
studying
to
understand
their
man
thoroughly
,
gave
him
what
license
he
chose
:
knowing
that
the
more
he
took
,
the
better
for
their
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
while
the
blundering
cheat
---
gull
that
he
was
,
for
all
his
cunning
---
thought
himself
rolled
up
hedgehog
fashion
,
with
his
sharpest
points
towards
them
<EOS>
,
he
was
,
in
fact
,
betraying
all
his
vulnerable
parts
to
their

.
   
<EOS>
Whether
the
two

who

so

to
the

's

(
by

,
the
doctor
slipped

,

usual

)
had
had

distinctly
from

,
or

,
they
acted

very

.
 
<EOS>
They
solicited

of
Jonas
's

;
trusted
that

would
have
the

into
that

in

so

shine
;
and
informed

,
in
the

that
the

their

were

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
they
said
"
Be

!
"
 
<EOS>
And
Jonas
said
he
was

,

;

,
that
so

"
stood
treat
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
After

,

in
the

,

a

(
mainly

)

;
rather

.
 
<EOS>
When

flagged
,
Jonas
took

up

in
appraising
the

;
inquiring
whether
such

article
was

;
what

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
he
was
,
as

,
desperately
hard
on
Montague
,
and
very

.
   
<EOS>
Some
Champagne
Punch
gave
a

to
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
For
after
leading
to
some
noisy

,
which

,

the

the
two

of

,

upon

.
   
<EOS>
As
he
could
not

made

understand
where

was
,
Mr
Bailey
received

to
call

-

,

him
home
;
which
that
young
gentleman
roused

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
   
<EOS>
"
Is

hooked
,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
With

.
<EOS>
Has

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Hallo

<EOS>
Why

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

;
the

having

,

.
   
<EOS>
Arriving

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Going

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
To

,

skipped

to
the

,

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
merry
one
herself
.
 
<EOS>
But
sadly
,

!
 
<EOS>
So

,
<EOS>
so

,

;
that

.
   
<EOS>
She

,

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
Then

<EOS>

Aha
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

?
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
Ai

you
<EOS>
well
,

?

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

,

.
   
<EOS>

Do

<EOS>
"
There

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
come
from
Mrs
Todgers
's
?
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Todgers
's
,

!
 
<EOS>
No

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Did

<EOS>

No

"

<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Jonas

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"
said
the
sobbing
girl
.
 
<EOS>
"
Much
more
so
than
I
ever
thought
to
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
laughed
in
his
drunken
exultation
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
you
're
finding
it
out
,
are
you
!
 
<EOS>
Patience
,
and
you
will
in
time
!
 
<EOS>
Griffins
have
claws
,
my
girl
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
not
a
pretty
slight
you
ever
put
upon
me
,
nor
a
pretty
trick
you
ever
played
me
,
nor
a
pretty
insolence
you
ever
showed
me
,
that
I
wo
n't
pay
back
a
hundred
-
fold
.
 
<EOS>
What
else
did
I
marry
you
for
?
 
<EOS>
YOU
,
too
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
with
coarse
contempt
.
   
<EOS>
It
might
have
softened
him
---
indeed
it
might
---
to
hear
her
turn
a
little
fragment
of
a
song
he
used
to
say
he
liked
;
trying
,
with
a
heart
so
full
,
to
win
him
back
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
"
you
're
deaf
,
are
you
?
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
hear
me
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
So
much
the
better
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
myself
,
for
having
,
been
fool
enough
to
strap
a
pack
upon
my
back
for
the
pleasure
of
treading
on
it
whenever
I
choose
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
things
have
opened
to
me
,
now
,
so
that
I
might
marry
almost
where
I
liked
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
would
n't
;
I
'd
keep
single
.
 
<EOS>
I
ought
to
be
single
,
among
the
friends
I
know
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
that
,
here
I
am
,
tied
like
a
log
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Pah
!
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
show
your
pale
face
when
I
come
home
?
 
<EOS>
Am
I
never
to
forget
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
late
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
cheerfully
,
opening
the
shutter
after
an
interval
of
silence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Broad
day
,
Jonas
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Broad
day
or
black
night
,
what
do
I
care
!
"
was
the
kind
rejoinder
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
night
passed
quickly
,
too
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
sitting
up
,
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sit
up
for
me
again
,
if
you
dare
!
"
<EOS>
growled
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
reading
,
"
she
proceeded
,
"
all
night
long
.
 
<EOS>
I
began
when
you
went
out
,
and
read
till
you
came
home
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
strangest
story
,
Jonas
!
 
<EOS>
And
true
,
the
book
says
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
it
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
was
it
?
"
said
Jonas
,
doggedly
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
the
book
says
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Was
there
anything
in
it
,
about
a
man
's

determined
to
conquer

wife
,
break
her
spirit
,
bend

,
crush
all

humours
like
so
many
nut
-

---
kill
her
,
for
aught
I
know
?
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
Not
a
word
,
"
she
answered
quickly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
he
returned
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
'll
be
a
true
story
though
,
before
long
;
for
all
the
book
says
nothing
about

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
lying
book
<EOS>
,
I
see
.
<EOS>
A
fit
book
for
a
lying
reader
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
're
deaf
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
interval
of
silence
;
and
the
boy
was
stealing
away
,
when
he
heard
her
footstep
on
the
floor
,
and
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
She
went
up
to
him
,
as
it
seemed
,
and
spoke
lovingly
;
saying
that
she
would
defer
to
him
in
everything
and
would
consult
his
wishes
and
obey
them
,
and
they
might
be
very
happy
if
he
would
be
gentle
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
answered
with
an
imprecation
,
and
---
    
Not
with
a
blow
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
Stern
truth
against
the
base
-
souled
villain
;
with
a
blow
.
   
<EOS>
No
angry
cries
;
no
loud

.
 
<EOS>
Even
her
weeping
and
her
sobs
were
stifled
by
her
clinging
round
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
only
said
,
repeating
it
in
agony
of
heart
,
how
could
he
,
could
he
,
could
he
---
and
lost
utterance
in
tears
.
   
<EOS>
Oh
woman
,
God
beloved
in
old
Jerusalem
!
 
<EOS>
The
best
among
us
need
deal
lightly
with
thy
faults
,
if
only
for
the
punishment
thy
nature
will
endure
,
in
bearing
heavy
evidence
against
us
,
on
the
Day
of
Judgment
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
29
.
<EOS>
In
which
some
people
are
precocious
,
others
professional
,
and
others
mysterious
;
all
in
their
several
ways
 
It
may
have
been
the
restless
remembrance
of
what
he
had
seen
and
heard
overnight
,
or
it
may
have
been
no
deeper
mental
operation
than
the
discovery
that
he
had
nothing
to
do
,
which
caused
Mr
Bailey
,
on
the
following
afternoon
,
to
feel
particularly
disposed
for
agreeable
society
,
and
prompted
him
to
pay
a
visit
to
his
friend
Poll
Sweedlepipe
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
little
bell
giving
clamorous
notice
of
a
visitor
's

(
for
Mr
Bailey
came
in
at
the

with
a

,
to

of
the
bell
as

)
,
Poll
Sweedlepipe
desisted
from
the

of
a
favourite
owl
,
and
gave
his
young
friend
hearty
welcome
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
look
smarter
by

,
"
said
Poll
,
"
than
you
do
by
candle
-
light
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
see
such
a
tight
young
dasher
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Reether
so
,
Polly
.
 
<EOS>
How
's
our
fair
friend
,
Sairah
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
she
's
pretty
well
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
's
at

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

the
remains
of
a
fine
woman
about
Sairah
,
Poll
,
"
observed
Mr
Bailey
,
with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
thought
Poll
,
"
he
's
old
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
be
very
old
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Too
much
crumb
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr
Bailey
;
"
too
fat
,
Poll
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
's
many
worse
at
her
time
of
life
"
   
"
<EOS>
The
very
owl
's
a
-
opening
his
eyes
!
"
thought
Poll
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
wonder
at
it
in
a
bird
of
his
opinions
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
happened
to
have
been
sharpening
his
razors
,
which
were
lying
open
in
a
row
,
while
a

.
 
<EOS>
Glancing

,
Mr
Bailey
stroked
his
chin
,
and
a
thought
appeared
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Poll
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
ai
n't
as
neat
as
I
could
wish
about
the
gills
.
<EOS>
Being
here
,
I
may
as
well
have
a
shave
,
and
get
trimmed
close
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
barber
stood
aghast
;
but
Mr
Bailey
divested
himself
of
his
neck
-
cloth
,
and
sat
down
in
the
easy
shaving
chair
with
all
the
dignity
and
confidence
in
life
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
resisting
his
manner
.
 
<EOS>
The
evidence
of
sight
and
touch
became
as
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
His
chin
was
as
smooth
as
a

-

egg
or

Dutch

;
but
Poll
Sweedlepipe
would
n't

to

,
on

,
that
he
had
the
beard
of

Jewish

.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
WITH
the

,
Poll
,
all
round
,

,
"
said
Mr
Bailey
,
screwing
up

for
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
do
wot
you
like
with
the
bits
of
whisker
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
for
'
em
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
meek
little
barber
stood

with

and

,

by

.
 
<EOS>
At

made

at
Mr

's

.
 
<EOS>
Then

again
,
as

;
but

,

"
Go

,
"
he

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
smiled
through

suds
in

.
"
<EOS>
Gently
over
the
stones
,
Poll
.
 
<EOS>
Go
a
tip
-
toe
over
the
pimples
!
"
   
<EOS>
Poll
Sweedlepipe
obeyed
,
and
scraped
the
lather
off
again
with
particular
care
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
squinted
at
every
successive

,
as
it
was

on
a
cloth
on
his
left

,
and

,

,
to

some

in

;
for
he
murmured
more

"
Reether
redder
than
I
could
wish
,
Poll
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
operation
being
concluded
,
Poll

,

Mr
Bailey
,

,

,
"
<EOS>
that
arter
late
hours
nothing
freshened

so

as

easy
shave
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
was

at
the
glass
,
without

,
and
Poll
had

,
ready
for
the
next

,
when
Mrs
Gamp
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Feeling

,
in

which

,

with

.
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
<EOS>

,
"
Sairah
!
 
<EOS>
I

how

,

.
 
<EOS>
All
a

;
ai

,

?

<EOS>

Why
,

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

!
 
<EOS>
I

n't

that
creetur
's
mother
not

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
regarded

as

of
her

,
and
a

that
no

.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
flattered
.
 
<EOS>
Disinterested
affection
is
always
flattering
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
dear
!
<EOS>
"
moaned
Mrs
Gamp
,

,
"
that
there

Bull
,
Mr
Sweedlepipe
,
has
done
his
wery

to
conker

.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
the
trying
inwalieges
in
this

of
the
shadder
,
that
one
beats
'em
black
and
blue
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was

of
Mrs
Gamp
and
her
friends
in
the

,
to
say
this
of
all
the
easy

;
as

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Talk

!
"
<EOS>

Gamp

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
person
's
constitooshun
need

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Harris

,

t'other

,
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
Sairey
Gamp
,
"
she

<EOS>
"
Mrs

,

.
 
<EOS>
Vich

!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

a
-

twenty

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

wos

<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

was

;

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>

"

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,

"
   
<EOS>
"
Do

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Be

"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Poll

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
30
.
<EOS>
Proves
that
changes

,
and

major
 
<EOS>
As

's

the

,

,

Mercy
,

.
   
<EOS>
And

Mr
Pecksniff
it

,

that

,

;

;

,
and
spreading

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
is

in

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
,
being
a

more

,
appeared
to
think

his

was
to
live
;
and
having

,

.
   
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

Cherry
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
she
led

parent
what
is

,

,
the

.
 
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
Tom

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
Her

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

indeed
!
"
cried
Cherry
.
 
<EOS>
"
State
the
real
cause
,
Pa
,
or
I
'll
state
it
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Mind
!
 
<EOS>
I
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
energy
with
which
she
said
this
was
infectious
.
 
<EOS>
However
that
may
be
,
Mr
Pecksniff
changed
his
tone
and
the
expression
of
his
face
for
one
of
anger
,
if
not

,
when
he
said
:
   
"
You
will
!
<EOS>
you
have
.
 
<EOS>
You
did
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
always
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
no
decency
;
you
make
no
secret
of
your
temper
;
you
have
exposed
yourself
to
Mr
Chuzzlewit
a
hundred
times
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Myself
!
"
cried
Cherry
,
with
a
bitter

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Me
,
too
,
then
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
His
daughter
answered
with
a
scornful

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
since
we
have
come
to
an

,
Charity
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
rolling

,
"
let
me
tell
you
that
I
wo
n't
allow
it
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
your
nonsense
,
Miss
!
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
permit
it
to
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
do
,
"
said
Charity
,
rocking
her
chair
backwards
and
forwards
,
and
raising
her

to
a

,
"
I
shall
do
,
Pa
,
what
I
please
and
what
I
have
done
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
to
be
crushed
in
everything
,
depend
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
been
more
shamefully
used
than
anybody
ever
was
in
this
world
,
"
here
she
began
to
cry
and

,
"
and
may
expect
the
worse
treatment
from
you
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
care
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
I
do
n't
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
made
so
desperate
by
the
loud
tone
in
which
she
spoke
,
that
,
after
looking
about
him
in
frantic

for
some

of

,
he
rose
and
shook
her
until
the
ornamental
bow
of
hair
upon
her
head
nodded
like
a
plume
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
so
very
much
astonished
by
this
assault
,
that
it
really
had
the
desired
effect
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
do
it
again
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as
he
resumed
his
seat
and
fetched
his
breath
,
"
if
you
dare
to
talk
in
that
loud
manner
.
 
<EOS>
How
do
you
mean
about
being
shamefully
used
?
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Jonas
chose
your
sister
in
preference
to
you
,
who
could
help
it
,
I
should
wish
to
know
?
 
<EOS>
What
have
I
to
do
with
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Was
n't
I
made
a
convenience
of
?
 
<EOS>
Were

my
feelings
trifled
with
?
<EOS>
Did

he
address

to
me

?
"
<EOS>
sobbed
Cherry
,
clasping

;
"
and
oh
,
good

,
that
I
should
live
to

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
live
to

,
"
returned
her
parent
,
"
if
you
drive
me
to
that
means
of
maintaining

of
this
humble

.
<EOS>
You
surprise
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
you
have
not
more
spirit
.
 
<EOS>
If
Mr
Jonas
did

care
for
you
,
how
could

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
have
him
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Cherry
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to

,
Pa
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Then
what

making

this

for
,
"
retorted

father
,
"
if

did

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
was
treated

,
"
said

;
"
and
because

and

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not

with
HER
,
"
said
Cherry
;
looking

than

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
pity

.
 
<EOS>
I
'm

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

that

,

Wretch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jonas
will

a

,
<EOS>
my
child
,
I

,
"
said

Pecksniff
,
with

;
"
but

what

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,
Pa
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
That

.
 
<EOS>
I
wo

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
No
;
I
wo

,
Pa
!
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
All

,
I
wo
n't
submit
to
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Whatever
she
meant
,
she
shook
Mr
Pecksniff
now
;
for
his
lame
attempt
to
seem
composed
was
melancholy
in
the
last
degree
.
 
<EOS>
His
anger
changed
to
meekness
,
and
his
words
were
mild
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
he
said
;
"
if

the
short

of
an
angry
moment
I
resorted
to
an
unjustifiable
means
of
suppressing
a
little
outbreak
calculated
to
injure
you
as
well
as
myself
---
it
's
possible
<EOS>
I
may
have
done
so
<EOS>
;
perhaps
I
did
---
I
ask
your
pardon
.
 
<EOS>
A
father
asking
pardon
of
his
child
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
is
,
I

,
a

to

the
most

.
"
   
<EOS>
But

did
n't

Miss
Pecksniff
<EOS>
;
perhaps
because
her
nature
was
not
rugged
enough
.
 
<EOS>
On
the

,
she
persisted
in

,
over

,
that
she
was
n't
quite

,
and
was

,

would

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
labour
under
some
mistake
,
my

!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
but
I
will
not
ask
you
what

is
;
I
do
n't

.
 
<EOS>
No
,
pray
!
"
<EOS>
he

,

,
"

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
about

room
,
and
said
,
"
A
home
,
my
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Another
home
,
papa
,
"
said
Cherry
,
with
increasing
stateliness
<EOS>
"
Place
me
at
Mrs
Todgers
's
or

,
on
an
independent

;
but
I
will
not
live
here
,
if

to

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
possible
that
Miss
Pecksniff
saw
in
Mrs
Todgers
's
a
vision
of
enthusiastic
men
,
pining
to
fall
in

at

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
possible
that
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
his
new
-
born

,
saw
,
in
the
suggestion
of
that
same
establishment
,
an
easy
means
of
relieving
himself
from
an
irksome
charge
in
the
way
of
temper
and

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
undoubtedly
a
fact
that
in
the
attentive
ears
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
the
proposition
did
not
sound
quite
like
the
dismal
knell
of
all
his
hopes
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
man
of
great
feeling
and
acute

;
and
he
squeezed
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
against
his
eyes
with
both
hands
---
 
as
such
men
always
do
,
especially
when
they
are
observed
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
of
my
birds
,
"
Mr
Pecksniff
said
,
"
has
left
me
for
the
stranger
's

;
the
other
would
take
wing
to
Todgers
's
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
well
,
what
am
I
?
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
I
am
,
exactly
.
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
!
"
   
<EOS>
Even
this
remark
,
made
more
pathetic
perhaps
by
his
breaking
down
in
the
middle

it
,
had
no
effect
upon
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
grim
,
rigid
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
have
ever
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
sacrificed
my
children
's
happiness
to
my
own
<EOS>
---
I
mean
my
own
happiness
to
my
children
's
---
and
I
will
not
begin
to
regulate
my
life
by
other
rules
of
conduct
now
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
be

at
Mrs
Todgers
's
than

father
's
house
,
my
dear
,
go
to
Mrs
Todgers
's
!
 
<EOS>
Do
not

me
,
my
girl
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
with
emotion
;
<EOS>
"
I
shall
get
on
pretty
well
,
no
doubt
.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Charity
,
who
knew
he
had
a
secret
pleasure
in
the
contemplation
of
the
proposed
change
,
suppressed
her
own
,
and
went
on
to
negotiate
the
terms
.
 
<EOS>
His
views
upon
this
subject
were
at
first
so
very
limited
that
another
difference
,
involving
possibly
another
shaking
,
threatened
to
ensue
;
but
by
degrees
they
came
to
something
like
an
understanding
,
and
the
storm
blew
over
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Miss
Charity
's
idea
was
so
agreeable
to
both
,
that
it
would
have
been
strange
if
they
had
not
come
to
an
amicable
agreement
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
soon
arranged
between
them
that
the
project
should
be
tried
,
and
that
immediately
;
and
that
Cherry
's
not
being
well
,
and
needing
change
of
scene
,
and
wishing
to
be
near
her
sister
,
<EOS>
should
form
the
excuse
for
her
departure
to
Mr
Chuzzlewit
and
Mary
,
to
both
of
whom
she
had
pleaded
indisposition
for
some
time
past
.
 
<EOS>
These
premises
agreed
on
,
Mr
Pecksniff
gave
her
his
blessing
,
with
all
the
dignity
of
a
self
-
denying
man
who
had
made
a
hard
sacrifice
,
but
comforted
himself
with
the
reflection
that
virtue
is
its
own
reward
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
they
were
reconciled
for
the
first
time
since
that
not
easily
forgiven
night
,
when
Mr
Jonas
,
repudiating
the
elder
,
had
confessed
his
passion
for
the
younger
sister
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
had
abetted
him
on
moral
grounds
.
   
<EOS>
But
how
happened
it
---
in
the
name
of
an
unexpected
addition
to
that
small
family
,
the
Seven
Wonders
of
the
World
,
whatever
and
wherever
they
may
be
,
how
happened
it
---
that
Mr
Pecksniff
and
his
daughter
were
about
to
part
?
 
<EOS>
How
happened
it
that
their
mutual
relations
were
so
greatly
altered
?
 
<EOS>
Why
was
Miss
Pecksniff
so
clamorous
to
have
it
understood
that
she
was
neither
blind
nor
foolish
,
and
she
would
n't
bear
it
?
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
possible
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
any
thoughts
of
marrying
again
;
or
that
his
daughter
,
with
the
sharp
eye
of
a
single
woman
,
fathomed
his
design
!
   
<EOS>
Let
us
inquire
into
this
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as
a
man
without
reproach
,
from
whom
the
breath
of
slander
passed
like
common
breath
from
any
other
polished
surface
,
could
afford
to
do
what
common
men
could
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
the
purity
of
his
own
motives
;
and
when
he
had
a
motive
worked
at
it
as
only
a
very
good
man
(
or
a
very
bad
one
)
can
.
 
<EOS>
Did
he
set
before
himself
any
strong
and
palpable
motives
for
taking
a
second
wife
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
;
and
not
one
or
two
of
them
,
but
a
combination
of
very
many
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
Chuzzlewit
had
gradually
undergone
an
important
change
.
<EOS>
Even
upon
the
night
when
he
made
such
an
ill
-
timed
arrival
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
,
he
was
comparatively
subdued
and
easy
to
deal
with
.
 
<EOS>
This
Mr
Pecksniff
attributed
,
at
the
time
,
to
the
effect
his
brother
's
death
had
had
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
from
that
hour
his
character
seemed
to
have
modified
by
regular
degrees
,
and
to
have
softened
down
into
a
dull
indifference
for
almost
every
one
but
Mr
Pecksniff
.
<EOS>
His
looks
were
much
the
same
as
ever
,
but
his
mind
was
singularly
altered
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
this
or
that
passion
stood
out
in
brighter
or
in
dimmer
hues
;
but
that
the
colour
of
the
whole
man
was
faded
.
<EOS>
As
one
trait
disappeared
,
no
other
trait
sprung
up
to
take
its
place
.
 
<EOS>
His
senses
dwindled
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
less
keen
of
sight
;
was
deaf
sometimes
;
took
little
notice
of
what
passed
before
him
;
and
would
be
profoundly
taciturn
for
days
together
.
 
<EOS>
The
process
of
this
alteration
was
so
easy
that
almost
as
soon
as
it
began
to
be
observed
it
was
complete
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
saw
it
first
,
and
having
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
fresh
in
his
recollection
,
saw
in
his
brother
Martin
the
same
process
of
decay
.
   
<EOS>
To
a
gentleman
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
tenderness
,
this
was
a
very
mournful
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
but
foresee
the
probability
of
his
respected
relative
being
made
the
victim
of
designing
persons
,
and
of
his
riches
falling
into
worthless
hands
.
 
<EOS>
It
gave
him
so
much
pain
that
he
resolved
to
secure
the
property
to
himself
;
to
keep
bad
testamentary
suitors
at
a
distance
;
to
wall
up
the
old
gentleman
,
as
it
were
,
for
his
own
use
.
 
<EOS>
By
little
and
little
,
therefore
,
he
began
to
try
whether
Mr
Chuzzlewit
gave
any
promise
of
becoming
an
instrument
in
his
hands
,
and
finding
that
he
did
,
and
indeed
that
he
was
very
supple
in
his
plastic
fingers
,
he
made
it
the
business
of
his
life
---
kind
soul
!
---
to
establish
an
ascendancy
over
him
;
and
every
little
test
he
durst
apply
meeting
with
a
success
beyond
his
hopes
<EOS>
,
he
began
to
think
he
heard
old
Martin
's
cash
already
chinking
in
his
own
unworldly
pockets
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
Mr
Pecksniff
pondered
on
this
subject
(
as
,
in
his
zealous
way
,
he
often
did
)
,
and
thought
with
an
uplifted
heart
of
the
train
of
circumstances
which
had
delivered
the
old
gentleman
into
his
hands
for
the
confusion
of
evil
-
doers
and
the
triumph
of
a
righteous
nature
<EOS>
,
he
always
felt
that
Mary
Graham
was
his
stumbling
-
block
.
<EOS>
Let
the
old
man
say
what
he
would
,
Mr
Pecksniff
knew
he
had
a
strong
affection
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
showed
it
in
a
thousand
little
ways
;
that
he
liked
to
have
her
near
him
,
and
was
never
quite

when
she
was
absent
long
.
 
<EOS>
That
he
had
ever
really
sworn
to
leave
her
nothing
in
his

,
Mr
Pecksniff
greatly
doubted
.
 
<EOS>
That
even
if
he
had
,
there
were
many
ways
by
which
he
could
evade
the
oath
and
satisfy

conscience
,
Mr
Pecksniff
knew
.
 
<EOS>
That
her
unprotected
state
was
no
light

on
the
old
man
's
mind
<EOS>
,
he
also
knew
,
for
Mr
Chuzzlewit
had
plainly
told

so
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
"
<EOS>
what
if
I
married
her
!
 
<EOS>
What
,
"
repeated
Mr
Pecksniff
,
sticking
up
his
hair
and
glancing
at
his
bust
by
Spoker
;
"
what
<EOS>
if
,
making
sure
of
his
approval
first
---
he
is
nearly
imbecile
,
poor
gentleman
---
I
married
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
a
lively
sense
of
the
Beautiful
;
especially
in
women
.
 
<EOS>
His
manner
towards
the
sex
was
remarkable
for
its
insinuating
character
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
recorded
of
him
in
another
part
of
these
pages
,
that
he
embraced
Mrs
Todgers
on
the
smallest
provocation
;
and
it
was
a
way
he
had
;
it
was
a
part
of
the
gentle

of
his

.
 
<EOS>
Before
any
thought
of
matrimony
was
in
his
mind
,
he
had
bestowed
on
Mary
many
little
tokens
of
his
spiritual

.
 
<EOS>
They
had
been
indignantly
received
,
but
that
was
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
True
,
as
the
idea
expanded
within

,
these
had
become
too
ardent
to
escape
the
piercing

of
Cherry
,
who
read
his
scheme
at
once
;
but
he
had
always
felt
the
power
of
Mary
's
charms
.
<EOS>
So
Interest
and
Inclination
made
a
pair
,
and
drew
the
curricle
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
plan
.
   
<EOS>
As
to
any

of
revenging
himself
on
young
Martin
for

when

,
and
of
shutting
him
out
still
more
effectually
from
any
hope
of

with
his
grandfather
,
Mr
Pecksniff
was
much
too
meek
and
forgiving
to
be
suspected
of
harbouring
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
being
refused
by
Mary
,
Mr
Pecksniff
was
quite
satisfied
that
in
her
position
she
could
never
hold
out
if
he
and
Mr
Chuzzlewit
were
both
against
her
.
 
<EOS>
As
to
consulting
the
wishes
of
her
heart
in
such

,
it
formed
no
part
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's

;
for
he
knew
what
a
good
man
he
was
,
and
what

he
must
be
to

.
 
<EOS>
His
daughter
having
broken
the
ice
,
and
the
murder
being
out
between
them
,
Mr
Pecksniff
had
now
only
to
pursue
his
design
as
cleverly
as
he
could
,
and
by
the
craftiest
approaches
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
good

,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,

Martin
in
the

,
for
it

to

in

,

;
"

<EOS>
how

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"

Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
one
of

deaf

,

.
 
<EOS>
Could

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

meant
Mary
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I

.
 
<EOS>
Quite

.
 
<EOS>
I

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think

deserves

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,
"
think
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
speaking
,
I

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Speak

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
getting
deafer
than

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
that
I

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

SHE

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

I

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
child

-

.
"
 
<EOS>
After

,

"
She

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
has
n't
her
health
by

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
She
misses
her

,

dear

;

.
 
<EOS>
And

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

in

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

,
taking

's

,

;
"
Why
,

,
ca

?
 
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
lowly

---

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

(

.

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
You

;

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The

,
"
Mr

,
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
Then

,

?
 
<EOS>
Here

.
 
<EOS>
Here

,

Thomas
Pinch
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Our

;

"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
understand

,
my

,
I

!
<EOS>
---
I
can
wind

,
"
he

,
with

,
"
round

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
leave

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Since

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
know
I
always
desire

.
 
<EOS>
I
wish

,

.
 
<EOS>
Not

,
Pecksniff
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
architect
was
too
much
overcome
to

.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
drop
a
tear
upon
his
patron
's

,
but
could
n't

one
in
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
May
that
day
be
very
distant
!
<EOS>
"
was
his
pious

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
If
I
could
say
how
deep
an
interest
I
have
in
you
and
yours
!
<EOS>
I
allude
to
our
beautiful
young
friend
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
True
.
 
<EOS>
She
need
have
some
one
interested
in
her
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
her
wrong
to
train
her
as
I
did
.
 
<EOS>
Orphan
though
she
was
,
she
would
have
found
some
one
to
protect
her
whom
she
might
have
loved
again
.
 
<EOS>
When
she
was
a
child
,
I
pleased
myself
with
the
thought
that
in
gratifying
my
whim
of
placing
her
between
me
and
false
-
hearted

,
I
had
done
her
a
kindness
.
 
<EOS>
Now
she
is
a
woman
,
I
have
no
such
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
no
protector
but
herself
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
put
her
at
such
odds
with
the
world
,
that
any
dog
may
bark
or
fawn
upon
her
at
his

.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
she
stands
in
need
of
delicate
consideration
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
;
indeed
she
does
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
her
position
could
be
altered
and
defined
,

?
"
Mr
Pecksniff

.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can

?
 
<EOS>
Should
I
make
a
seamstress
of
her
,
or
a
governess
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Heaven
forbid
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear

,

other

.
 
<EOS>
There

.
 
<EOS>
But
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Permit

another

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
unwell
?
"

Martin

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
"

Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
.
 
Permit
me
to
resume
it
at
another
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
walk
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
blessed
him
in
return
,
and
squeezed
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
turned
away
,
and
slowly
walked
towards
the
house
,
Mr
Pecksniff
stood
gazing
after
him
;
being
pretty
well
recovered
from
his
late
emotion
,
which
,
in
any

man
,
one
might
have
thought
had
been
assumed
as
a
machinery
for
feeling
Martin
's
pulse
.
 
<EOS>
The
change
in
the
old
man
found
such
a
slight
expression
in
his
figure
,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
after
him
,
could
not
help
saying
to
himself
:
   
<EOS>
"
And
I
can
wind
him
round
my
little
finger
!
 
<EOS>
Only
think
!
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
happening
to
turn
his
head
,
saluted
him
affectionately
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
returned
the
gesture
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the
time
was
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
;
"
and
not
long
ago
,
when
he
would
n't
look
at
me
!
 
<EOS>
How
soothing
is
this
change
.
 
<EOS>
Such
is
the
delicate
texture
of
the
human
heart
;
so
complicated
is
the
process
of
its
being
softened
!
 
<EOS>
Externally
he
looks
the
same
,
and
I
can
wind
him
round
my
little
finger
.
 
<EOS>
Only
think
!
"
   
<EOS>
In
sober
truth
,
there
did
appear
to
be
nothing
on
which
Mr
Pecksniff
might
not
have
ventured
with
Martin
Chuzzlewit
;
for
whatever
Mr
Pecksniff
said
or
did
was
right
,
and
whatever
he
advised
was
done
.
<EOS>
Martin
had
escaped
so
many
snares
from
needy
fortune
-
hunters
,
and
had
withered
in
the
shell
of
his
suspicion
and
distrust
for
so
many
years
,
but
to
become
the
good
man
's
tool
and
plaything
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
happiness
of
this
conviction
painted
on
his
face
,
the
architect
went
forth
upon
his
morning
walk
.
   
<EOS>
The
summer
weather
in
his
bosom
was
reflected
in
the
breast
of
Nature
.
 
<EOS>
Through
deep
green
vistas
where
the
boughs
arched
overhead
,
and
showed
the
sunlight
flashing
in
the
beautiful
perspective
;
through
dewy
fern
from
which
the
startled
hares
leaped
up
,
and
fled
at
his
approach
;
by
mantled
pools
,
and
fallen
trees
,
and
down
in
hollow
places
,
rustling
among
last
year
's
leaves
whose
scent
woke
memory
of
the
past
;
the
placid
Pecksniff
strolled
.
 
<EOS>
By
meadow
gates
and
hedges
fragrant
with
wild
roses
;
and
by
thatched
-
roof
cottages
whose
inmates
humbly
bowed
before
him
as
a
man
both
good
and
wise
;
the
worthy
Pecksniff
walked
in
tranquil
meditation
.
 
<EOS>
The
bee
passed
onward
,
humming
of
the
work
he
had
to
do
;
the
idle
gnats
for
ever
going
round
and
round
in
one
contracting
and
expanding
ring
,
yet
always
going
on
as
fast
as
he
,
danced
merrily
before
him
;
the
colour
of
the
long
grass
came
and
went
,
as
if
the
light
clouds
made
it
timid
as
they
floated
through
the
distant
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
birds
,
so
many
Pecksniff
consciences
,
sang
gaily
upon
every
branch
;
and
Mr
Pecksniff
paid
HIS
homage
to
the
day
by
ruminating
on
his
projects
as
he
walked
along
.
   
<EOS>
Chancing
to
trip
,
in
his
abstraction
,
over
the
spreading
root
of
an
old
tree
,
he
raised
his
pious
eyes
to
take
a
survey
of
the
ground
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
startled
him
to
see
the
embodied
image
of
his
thoughts
not
far
ahead
.
 
<EOS>
Mary
herself
.
 
<EOS>
And
alone
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
Mr
Pecksniff
stopped
as
if
with
the
intention
of
avoiding
her
;
but
his
next
impulse
was
to
advance
,
which
he
did
at
a
brisk
pace
;
caroling
as
he
went
so
sweetly
and
with
so
much
innocence
that
he
only
wanted
feathers
and
wings
to
be
a
bird
.
   
<EOS>
Hearing
notes
behind
her
,
not
belonging
to
the
songsters
of
the
grove
,
she
looked
round
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
kissed
his
hand
,
and
was
at
her
side
immediately
.
   
<EOS>
"
Communing
with
nature
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
am
I.
"
   
<EOS>
She
said
the
morning
was
so
beautiful
that
she
had
walked
further
than
she
intended
,
and
would
return
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
said
it
was
exactly
his
case
,
and
he
would
return
with
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Take
my
arm
,
sweet
girl
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
Mary
declined
it
,
and
walked
so
very
fast
that
he
remonstrated
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
loitering
when
I
came
upon
you
,
"
Mr
Pecksniff
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
be
so
cruel
as
to
hurry
now
?
 
<EOS>
You
would
not
shun
me
,
would
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
would
,
"
she
answered
,
turning
her
glowing
cheek
indignantly
upon
him
,
"
you
know
I
would
.
 
<EOS>
Release
me
,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Your
touch
is
disagreeable
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
touch
!
 
<EOS>
What
?
 
<EOS>
That
chaste
patriarchal
touch
which
Mrs
Todgers
---
 
surely
a
discreet
lady
---
had
endured
,
not
only
without
complaint
,
but
with
apparent
satisfaction
!
 
<EOS>
This
was
positively
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
sorry
to
hear
her
say
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
not
observed
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
that
it
is
so
<EOS>
,
pray
take
assurance
from
my
lips
,
and
do
not
,
as
you
are
a
gentleman
,
continue
to
offend
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
mildly
,
"
<EOS>
I
feel
that
I
might
consider
this
becoming
in
a
daughter
of
my
own
,
and
why
should
I
object
to
it
in
one
so
beautiful
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
harsh
.
 
<EOS>
It
cuts
me
to
the
soul
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
can
not
quarrel
with
you
,
Mary
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
tried
to
say
she
was
sorry
to
hear
it
,
but
burst
into
tears
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
now
repeated
the
Todgers
performance
on
a
comfortable
scale
,
as
if
he
intended
it
to
last
some
time
;
and
in
his
disengaged
hand
,
catching
hers
,
employed
himself
in
separating
the
fingers
with
his
own
,
and
sometimes
kissing
them
,
as
he
pursued
the
conversation
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
we
met
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
glad
we
met
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
able
now
to
ease
my
bosom
of
a
heavy
load
,
and
speak
to
you
in
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Mary
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
in
his
tenderest
tones
,
indeed
they
were
so
very
tender
that
he
almost
squeaked
:
"
<EOS>
My
soul
!
 
<EOS>
I
love
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
fantastic
thing
,
that
maiden
affectation
!
 
<EOS>
She
made
believe
to
shudder
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
love
you
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
my
gentle
life
,
with
a
devotion
which
is
quite
surprising
,
even
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
suppose
that
the
sensation
was
buried
in
the
silent
tomb
of
a
lady
,
only
second
to
you
in
qualities
of
the
mind
and
form
;
but
I
find
I
am
mistaken
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
tried
to
disengage
her
hand
,
but
might
as
well
have
tried
to
free
herself
from
the
embrace
of
an
affectionate
boa
-
constrictor
;
if
anything
so
wily
may
be
brought
into
comparison
with
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Although
I
am
a
widower
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
examining
the
rings
upon
her
fingers
,
and
tracing
the
course
of
one
delicate
blue
vein
with
his
fat
thumb
,
"
a
widower
with
two
daughters
<EOS>
,
still
I
am
not
encumbered
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
One
of
them
,
as
you
know
,
is
married
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
,
by
her
own
desire
,
but
with
a
view
,
I
will
confess
---
<EOS>
why
not
?
 
<EOS>
---
to
my
altering
my
condition
,
is
about
to
leave
her
father
's
house
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
character
,
I
hope
.
 
<EOS>
People
are
pleased
to
speak
well
of
me
,
I
think
.
 
<EOS>
My
person
and
manner
are
not
absolutely
those
of
a
monster
,
I
trust
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
naughty
Hand
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
apostrophizing
the
reluctant
prize
,
"
why
did
you
take
me
prisoner
?
<EOS>
Go
,
go
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
slapped
the
hand
to
punish
it
;
but
relenting
,
folded
it
in
his
waistcoat
to
comfort
it
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
Blessed
in
each
other
,
and
in
the
society
of
our
venerable
friend
,
my
darling
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
we
shall
be
happy
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
is
wafted
to
a
haven
of
rest
,
we
will
console
each
other
.
 
<EOS>
My
pretty
primrose
,
what
do
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
possible
,
"
Mary
answered
,
in
a
hurried
manner
,
"
that
I
ought
to
feel
grateful
for
this
mark
of
your
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
I
do
,
but
I
am
willing
to
suppose
you
may
deserve
my
thanks
.
<EOS>
Take
them
;
and
pray
leave
me
,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
good
man
smiled
a
greasy
smile
;
and
drew
her
closer
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
pray
release
me
,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
listen
to
your
proposal
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
receive
it
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
many
to
whom
it
may
be
acceptable
,
but
it
is
not
so
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
As
an
act
of
kindness
and
an
act
of
pity
,
leave
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
walked
on
with
his
arm
round
her
waist
,
and
her
hand
in
his
,
as
contentedly
as
if
they
had
been
all
in
all
to
each
other
,
and
were
joined
in
the
bonds
of
truest
love
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
force
me
by
your
superior
strength
,
"
said
Mary
,
who
finding
that
good
words
had
not
the
least
effect
upon
him
,
made
no
further
effort
to
suppress
her
indignation
;
"
if
you
force
me
by
your
superior
strength
to
accompany
you
back
,
and
to
be
the
subject
of
your
insolence
upon
the
way
,
you
can
not
constrain
the
expression
of
my
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
I
hold
you
in
the
deepest
abhorrence
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
your
real
nature
and
despise
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
sweetly
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
what
arts
or
unhappy
chances
you
have
gained
your
influence
over
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
I
do
not
know
,
"
said
Mary
;
"
it
may
be
strong
enough
to
soften
even
this
,
but
he
shall
know
of
this
,
trust
me
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
raised
his
heavy
eyelids
languidly
,
and
let
them
fall
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
saying
with
perfect
coolness
,
"
Aye
,
aye
!
 
<EOS>
Indeed
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
Is
it
not
enough
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
that
you
warp
and
change
his
nature
,
adapt
his
every
prejudice
to
your
bad
ends
,
and
harden
a
heart
naturally
kind
by
shutting
out
the
truth
and
allowing
none
but
false
and
distorted
views
to
reach
it
<EOS>
;
is
it
not
enough
that
you
have
the
power
of
doing
this
,
and
that
you
exercise
it
,
but
must
you
also
be
so
coarse
,
so
cruel
,
and
so
cowardly
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
Still
Mr
Pecksniff
led
her
calmly
on
,
and
looked
as
mild
as
any
lamb
that
ever
pastured
in
the
fields
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
nothing
move
you
,
sir
?
"
cried
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
a
placid
leer
,
"
a
habit
of
self
-
examination
,
and
the
practice
of
---
<EOS>
shall
I
say
of
virtue
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
hypocrisy
,
"
said
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
resumed
Mr
Pecksniff
,
chafing
the
captive
hand
reproachfully
,
"
of
virtue
---
have
enabled
me
to
set
such
guards
upon
myself
,
that
it
is
really
difficult
to
ruffle
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
curious
fact
,
but
it
is
difficult
,
do
you
know
,
for
any
one
to
ruffle
me
.
<EOS>
And
did
she
think
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
a
playful
tightening
of
his
grasp
"
that
SHE
could
!
 
<EOS>
How
little
did
she
know
his
heart
!
"
   
<EOS>
Little
,
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
Her
mind
was
so
strangely
constituted
that
she
would
have
preferred
the
caresses
of
a
toad
,
an
adder
,
or
a
serpent
---
nay
,
the
hug
of
a
bear
---
to
the
endearments
of
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
"
said
that
good
gentleman
,
"
a
word
or
two
will
set
this
matter
right
,
and
establish
a
pleasant
understanding
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
angry
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
YOU
angry
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
I
am
not
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
so
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
are
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
beating
heart
beneath
his
hand
that
told
another
story
though
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
are
not
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
:
"
and
I
will
tell
you
why
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
two
Martin
Chuzzlewits
,
my
dear
;
and
<EOS>
your
carrying
your
anger
to
one
might
have
a
serious
effect
---
who
knows
!
<EOS>
---
upon
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
n't
wish
to
hurt
him
,
would
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
trembled
violently
,
and
looked
at
him
with
such
a
proud
disdain
that
he
turned
his
eyes
away
.
 
<EOS>
No
doubt
lest
he
should
be
offended
with
her
in
spite
of
his
better
self
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
passive
quarrel
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
may
be
changed
into
an
active
one
,
remember
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
sad
to
blight
even
a
disinherited
young
man
in
his
already
blighted
prospects
;
but
how
easy
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
how
easy
!
 
<EOS>
HAVE
I
influence
with
our
venerable
friend
,
do
you
think
?
 
<EOS>
Well
,
perhaps
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
raised
his
eyes
to
hers
;
and
nodded
with
an
air
of
banter
that
was
charming
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
continued
,
thoughtfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
Upon
the
whole
,
my
sweet
,
if
I
were
you
I
'd
keep
my
secret
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at
all
sure
---
very
far
from
it
---
that
it
would
surprise
our
friend
in
any
way
,
for
he
and
I
have
had
some
conversation
together
only
this
morning
,
and
he
is
anxious
,
very
anxious
,
to
establish
you
in
some
more
settled
manner
.
 
<EOS>
But
whether
he
was
surprised
or
not
surprised
,
the
consequence
of
your
imparting
it
might
be
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
junior
might
suffer
severely
.
 
<EOS>
I
'd
have
compassion
on
Martin
junior
,
<EOS>
do
you
know
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
a
persuasive
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
He
do
n't
deserve
it
,
but
I
would
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
wept
so
bitterly
now
,
and
was
so
much
distressed
,
that
he
thought
it
prudent
to
unclasp
her
waist
,
and
hold
her
only
by
the
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
our
own
share
in
the
precious
little
mystery
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
we
will
keep
it
to
ourselves
,
and
talk
of
it
between
ourselves
,
and
you
shall
think
it
over
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
consent
,
my
love
;
you
will
consent
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
you
may
think
;
you
will
.
 
<EOS>
I
seem
to
remember
to
have
heard
---
I
really
do
n't
know
where
,
or
how
"
---
he
added
,
with
bewitching
frankness
,
"
that
you
and
Martin
junior
,
when
you
were
children
,
had
a
sort
of
childish
fondness
for
each
other
.
<EOS>
When
we
are
married
,
you
shall
have
the
satisfaction
of
thinking
that
it
did
n't
last
to
ruin
him
,
but
passed
away
to
do
him
good
;
for
we
'll
see
then
what
we
can
do
to
put
some
trifling
help
in
Martin
junior
's
way
.
 
<EOS>
HAVE
I
any
influence
with
our
venerable
friend
?
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
have
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
have
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
outlet
from
the
wood
in
which
these
tender
passages
occurred
,
was
close
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
now
so
near
it
that
he
stopped
,
and
holding
up
her
little
finger
,
said
in
playful
accents
,
as
a
parting
fancy
:
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
bite
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Receiving
no
reply
he
kissed
it
instead
;
and
then
stooping
down
,
inclined
his
flabby
face
to
hers
---
he
had
a
flabby
face
,
although
he
WAS
a
good
man
---
and
with
a
blessing
,
which
from
such
a
source
was
quite
enough
to
set
her
up
in
life
,
and
prosper
her
from
that
time
forth
permitted
her
to
leave
him
.
   
<EOS>
Gallantry
in
its
true
sense
is
supposed
to
ennoble
and
dignify
a
man
;
and
love
has
shed
refinements
on
innumerable
Cymons
.
 
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pecksniff
---
perhaps
because
to
one
of
his
exalted
nature
these
were
mere
grossnesses
---
certainly
did
not
appear
to
any
unusual
advantage
,
now
that
he
was
left
alone
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
he
seemed
to
be
shrunk
and
reduced
;
to
be
trying
to
hide
himself
within
himself
;
and
to
be
wretched
at
not
having
the
power
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
shoes
looked
too
large
;
his
sleeve
looked
too
long
;
his
hair
looked
too
limp
;
his
features
looked
too
mean
;
his
exposed
throat
looked
as
if
a
halter
would
have
done
it
good
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
minute
or
two
,
in
fact
,
he
was
hot
,
and
pale
,
and
mean
,
and
shy
,
and
slinking
,
and
<EOS>
consequently
not
at
all
Pecksniffian
.
 
<EOS>
But
after
that
,
he
recovered
himself
,
and
went
home
with
as
beneficent
an
air
as
if
he
had
been
the
High
Priest
of
the
summer
weather
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
arranged
to
go
,
Papa
,
"
said
Charity
,
"
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
soon
,
my
child
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
go
too
soon
,
"
said
Charity
,
"
under
the
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
written
to
Mrs
Todgers
to
propose
an
arrangement
,
and
have
requested
her
to
meet
me
at
the
coach
,
at
all
events
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
be
quite
your
own
master
now
,
Mr
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
just
gone
out
of
the
room
,
and
Tom
had
just
come
into
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
own
master
!
"
repeated
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
'll
have
nobody
to
interfere
with
you
,
"
said
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
At
least
I
hope
you
wo
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
changing
world
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
are
YOU
going
to
be
married
,
Miss
Pecksniff
?
"
asked
Tom
in
great
surprise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
exactly
,
"
faltered
Cherry
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
made
up
my
mind
to
be
.
<EOS>
I
believe
I
could
be
,
if
I
chose
,
Mr
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
could
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
said
it
in
perfect
good
faith
.
 
<EOS>
He
believed
it
from
the
bottom
of
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Cherry
,
"
I
am
not
going
to
be
married
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
is
,
that
I
know
of
.
 
<EOS>
Hem
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
going
to
live
with
Papa
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
my
reasons
,
but
it
's
all
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
always
feel
very
kindly
towards
you
<EOS>
,
I
assure
you
,
for
the
boldness
you
showed
that
night
.
<EOS>
As
to
you
and
me
,
Mr
Pinch
,
WE
part
the
best
friends
possible
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
thanked
her
for
her
confidence
,
and
for
her
friendship
,
but
there
was
a
mystery
in
the
former
which
perfectly
bewildered
him
.
<EOS>
In
his
extravagant
devotion
to
the
family
,
he
had
felt
the
loss
of
Merry
more
than
any
one
but
those
who
knew
that
for
all
the
slights
he
underwent
he
thought
his
own
demerits
were
to
blame
,
could
possibly
have
understood
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
reconciled
himself
to
that
when
here
was
Charity
about
to
leave
them
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
grown
up
,
as
it
were
,
under
Tom
's
eye
.
 
<EOS>
The
sisters
were
a
part
of
Pecksniff
,
and
a
part
of
Tom
;
items
in
Pecksniff
's
goodness
,
and
in
Tom
's
service
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
bear
it
;
<EOS>
not
two
hours
'
sleep
had
Tom
that
night
,
through
dwelling
in
his
bed
upon
these
dreadful
changes
.
   
<EOS>
When
morning
dawned
he
thought
he
must
have
dreamed
this
piece
of
ambiguity
;
but
no
,
on
going
downstairs
he
found
them
packing
trunks
and
cording
boxes
,
and
making
other
preparations
for
Miss
Charity
's
departure
,
which
lasted
all
day
long
.
 
<EOS>
In
good
time
for
the
evening
coach
,
Miss
Charity
deposited
her
housekeeping
keys
with
much
ceremony
upon
the
parlour
table
;
took
a
gracious
leave
of
all
the
house
;
and
quitted
her
paternal
roof
---
a
blessing
for
which
the
Pecksniffian
servant
was
observed
by
some
profane
persons
to
be
particularly
active
in
the
thanksgiving
at
church
next
Sunday
.
    
Chapter
31
.
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
is
discharged
of
a
duty
which
he
never
owed
to
anybody
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
discharges
a
duty
which
he
owes
to
society
 
<EOS>
The
closing
words
of
the
last
chapter
lead
naturally
to
the
commencement
of
this
,
its
successor
;
for
it
has
to
do
with
a
church
.
<EOS>
With
the
church
,
so
often
mentioned
heretofore
,
in
which
Tom
Pinch
played
the
organ
for
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
One
sultry
afternoon
,
about
a
week
after
Miss
Charity
's
departure
for
London
,
Mr
Pecksniff
being
out
walking
by
himself
,
took
it
into
his
head
to
stray
into
the
churchyard
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
was
lingering
among
the
tombstones
,
endeavouring
to
extract
an
available
sentiment
or
two
from
the
epitaphs
---
for
he
never
lost
an
opportunity
of
making
up
a
few
moral
crackers
,
to
be
let
off
as
occasion
served
---
Tom
Pinch
began
to
practice
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
could
run
down
to
the
church
and
do
so
whenever
he
had
time
to
spare
;
for
it
was
a
simple
little
organ
,
provided
with
wind
by
the
action
of
the
musician
's
feet
;
and
he
was
independent
,
even
of
a
bellows
-
blower
.
 
<EOS>
Though
if
Tom
had
wanted
one
at
any
time
,
there
was
not
a
man
or
boy
in
all
the
village
,
and
away
to
the
turnpike
(
tollman
included
)
,
but
would
have
blown
away
for
him
till
he
was
black
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
no
objection
to
music
;
not
the
least
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
tolerant
of
everything
;
he
often
said
so
.
 
<EOS>
He
considered
it
a
vagabond
kind
of
trifling
,
in
general
,
just
suited
to
Tom
's
capacity
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
regard
to
Tom
's
performance
upon
this
same
organ
,
he
was
remarkably
lenient
,
singularly
amiable
;
for
when
Tom
played
it
on
Sundays
,
Mr
Pecksniff
in
his
unbounded
sympathy
felt
as
if
he
played
it
himself
,
and
were
a
benefactor
to
the
congregation
.
 
<EOS>
So
whenever
it
was
impossible
to
devise
any
other
means
of
taking
the
value
of
Tom
's
wages
out
of
him
,
Mr
Pecksniff
gave
him
leave
to
cultivate
this
instrument
.
 
<EOS>
For
which
mark
of
his
consideration
<EOS>
Tom
was
very
grateful
.
   
<EOS>
The
afternoon
was
remarkably
warm
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
had
been
strolling
a
long
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
what
may
be
called
a
fine
ear
for
music
,
but
he
knew
when
it
had
a
tranquilizing
influence
on
his
soul
;
and
that
was
the
case
now
,
for
it
sounded
to
him
like
a
melodious
snore
.
 
<EOS>
He
approached
the
church
,
and
looking
through
the
diamond
lattice
of
a
window
near
the
porch
,
saw
Tom
,
with
the
curtains
in
the
loft
drawn
back
,
playing
away
with
great
expression
and
tenderness
.
   
<EOS>
The
church
had
an
inviting
air
of
coolness
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
oak
roof
supported
by
cross
-
beams
,
the
hoary
walls
,
the
marble
tablets
,
and
the
cracked
stone
pavement
,
were
refreshing
to
look
at
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
leaves
of
ivy
tapping
gently
at
the
opposite
windows
;
and
the
sun
poured
in
through
only
one
;
leaving
the
body
of
the
church
in
tempting
shade
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
most
tempting
spot
of
all
,
was
one
red
-
curtained
and
soft
-
cushioned
pew
,
wherein
the
official
dignitaries
of
the
place
(
of
whom
Mr
Pecksniff
was
the
head
and
chief
)
<EOS>
enshrined
themselves
on
Sundays
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
seat
was
in
the
corner
;
a
remarkably
comfortable
corner
;
where
his
very
large
Prayer
-
Book
was
at
that
minute
making
the
most
of
its
quarto
self
upon
the
desk
.
 
<EOS>
He
determined
to
go
in
and
rest
.
   
<EOS>
He
entered
very
softly
;
in
part
because
it
was
a
church
;
in
part
because
his
tread
was
always
soft
;
in
part
because
Tom
played
a
solemn
tune
;
in
part
because
he
thought
he
would
surprise
him
when
he
stopped
.
 
<EOS>
Unbolting
the
door
of
the
high
pew
of
state
,
he
glided
in
and
shut
it
after
him
;
then
sitting
in
his
usual
place
,
and
stretching
out
his
legs
upon
the
hassocks
,
he
composed
himself
to
listen
to
the
music
.
   
<EOS>
It
is
an
unaccountable
circumstance
that
he
should
have
felt
drowsy
there
,
where
the
force
of
association
might
surely
have
been
enough
to
keep
him
wide
awake
;
but
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
in
the
snug
little
corner
five
minutes
before
he
began
to
nod
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
recovered
himself
one
minute
before
he
began
to
nod
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
very
act
of
opening
his
eyes
indolently
,
he
nodded
again
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
very
act
of
shutting
them
,
he
nodded
again
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
fell
out
of
one
nod
into
another
until
<EOS>
at
last
he
ceased
to
nod
at
all
,
and
was
as
fast
as
the
church
itself
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
a
consciousness
of
the
organ
,
long
after
he
fell
asleep
,
though
as
to
its
being
an
organ
he
had
no
more
idea
of
that
than
he
had
of
its
being
a
bull
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
while
he
began
to
have
at
intervals
the
same
dreamy
impressions
of
voices
;
and
awakening
to
an
indolent
curiosity
upon
the
subject
,
opened
his
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
so
indolent
,
that
after
glancing
at
the
hassocks
and
the
pew
,
he
was
already
half
-
way
off
to
sleep
again
,
when
it
occurred
to
him
that
there
really
were
voices
in
the
church
;
low
voices
,
talking
earnestly
hard
by
;
while
the
echoes
seemed
to
mutter
responses
.
 
<EOS>
He
roused
himself
,
and
listened
.
   
<EOS>
Before
he
had
listened
half
a
dozen
seconds
,
he
became
as
broad
awake
as
ever
he
had
been
in
all
his
life
.
 
<EOS>
With
eyes
,
and
ears
,
and
mouth
,
wide
open
,
he
moved
himself
a
very
little
with
the
utmost
caution
,
and
gathering
the
curtain
in
his
hand
,
peeped
out
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
and
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
recognized
their
voices
,
and
already
knew
the
topic
they
discussed
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
like
the
small
end
of
a
guillotined
man
,
with
his
chin
on
a
level
with
the
top
of
the
pew
,
so
that
he
might
duck
down
immediately
in
case
of
either
of
them
turning
round
,
he
listened
.
 
<EOS>
Listened
with
such
concentrated
eagerness
,
that
his
very
hair
and
shirt
-
collar
stood
bristling
up
to
help
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
letters
have
ever
reached
me
,
except
that
one
from
New
York
.
 
<EOS>
But
do
n't
be
uneasy
on
that
account
,
<EOS>
for
it
's
very
likely
they
have
gone
away
to
some
far
-
off
place
,
where
the
posts
are
neither
regular
nor
frequent
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
in
that
very
letter
that
it
might
be
so
,
even
in
that
city
to
which
they
thought
of
travelling
---
<EOS>
Eden
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
great
weight
upon
my
mind
,
"
said
Mary
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
you
must
n't
let
it
be
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
true
saying
that
nothing
travels
so
fast
as
ill
news
;
and
if
the
slightest
harm
had
happened
to
Martin
,
you
may
be
sure
you
would
have
heard
of
it
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
often
wished
to
say
this
to
you
,
<EOS>
"
Tom
continued
with
an
embarrassment
that
became
him
very
well
,
"
but
you
have
never
given
me
an
opportunity
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
sometimes
been
almost
afraid
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
that
you
might
suppose
I
hesitated
to
confide
in
you
,
Mr
Pinch
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
Tom
stammered
,
"
I
<EOS>
---
I
am
not
aware
that
I
ever
supposed
that
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
that
if
I
have
,
I
have
checked
the
thought
directly
,
as
an
injustice
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
feel
the
delicacy
of
your
situation
in
having
to
confide
in
me
at
all
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
but
I
would
risk
my
life
to
save
you
from
one
day
's
uneasiness
;
indeed
I
would
!
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
Tom
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
dreaded
sometimes
,
"
Tom
continued
,
"
that
I
might
have
displeased
you
by
---
by
having
the
boldness
to
try
and
anticipate
your
wishes
now
and
then
.
 
<EOS>
At
other
times
I
have
fancied
that
your
kindness
prompted
you
to
keep
aloof
from
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
very
foolish
;
very
presumptuous
and
ridiculous
,
to
think
so
,
"
Tom
pursued
;
"
but
I
feared
you
might
suppose
it
possible
that
I
---
I
---
should
admire
you
too
much
for
my
own
peace
;
and
so
denied
yourself
the
slight
assistance
you
would
otherwise
have
accepted
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
If
such
an
idea
has
ever
presented
itself
to
you
,
"
faltered
Tom
,
"
pray
dismiss
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
easily
made
happy
;
and
I
shall
live
contented
here
long
after
you
and
Martin
have
forgotten
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
poor
,
shy
,
awkward
creature
;
not
at
all
a
man
of
the
world
;
and
you
should
think
no
more
of
me
,
bless
you
,
than
if
I
were
an
old
friar
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If
friars
bear
such
hearts
as
thine
,
Tom
,
let
friars
multiply
;
though
they
have
no
such
rule
in
all
their
stern
arithmetic
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Mr
Pinch
!
"
said
Mary
,
giving
him
her
hand
;
"
I
can
not
tell
you
how
your
kindness
moves
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
wronged
you
by
the
lightest
doubt
,
and
have
never
for
an
instant
ceased
to
feel
that
you
were
all
---
much
more
than
all
---
that
Martin
found
you
.
 
<EOS>
Without
the
silent
care
and
friendship
I
have
experienced
from
you
,
my
life
here
would
have
been
unhappy
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
have
been
a
good
angel
to
me
;
filling
me
with
gratitude
of
heart
,
hope
,
and
courage
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
little
like
an
angel
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
replied
Tom
,
shaking
his
head
,
"
as
any
stone
cherubim
among
the
grave
-
stones
;
and
I
do
n't
think
there
are
many
real
angels
of
THAT
pattern
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
should
like
to
know
(
if
you
will
tell
me
)
why
you
have
been
so
very

about
Martin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Because
I
have
been
afraid
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
of
injuring
you
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of
injuring
me
!
"
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
doing
you
an
injury
with
your
employer
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
in
question
dived
.
   
<EOS>
"
With
Pecksniff
!
"
rejoined
Tom
,
with
cheerful
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
,
he
'd
never
think
of
us
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
the
best
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
The
more
at

you
were
,
the
happier
he
would
be
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
you
need
n't
be
afraid
of
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
not
a
spy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Many
a
man
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
place
,
if
he
could
have
dived
through
the
floor
of
the
pew
of
state
and
come
out
at
Calcutta
or
any
inhabited
region
on
the
other
side
of
the
earth
,
would
have
done

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
sat
down
upon
a
hassock
,
and
listening
more
attentively
than
ever
,
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
Mary
seemed
to
have
expressed
some
dissent
in
the
meanwhile
,
for
Tom
went
on
to
say
,
with
honest
energy
:
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
but
it
always
happens
,
whenever
I
express
myself
in
this

to

almost
,
that
I
find
they
wo
n't
do
justice
to
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
one
of
the
most
extraordinary
circumstances
that
ever
came
within

,
but
it
is
so
.
<EOS>
There
's
John
Westlock
,
who
used
to
be
a
pupil
here
,
one
of
the
best
-
hearted
young
men
in
the
world
,
in
all
other
matters
<EOS>
---
I
really
believe
John
would
have
Pecksniff
flogged
at
the
cart
's
tail
if
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
And
John
is
not
a
solitary
case
,
for
every
pupil
we
have
had
in
my
time
has
gone
away
with
the
same

of
him
.
<EOS>
There

Mark
Tapley
,
too
,
quite
in
another
station
of

,
"
said
Tom
;
"
the
mockery
he
used
to
make
of
Pecksniff
when
he
was
at
the
Dragon
was
shocking
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
too
:
<EOS>
Martin
was
worse
than
any
of
'em
.
<EOS>
But
I
forgot
.
 
<EOS>
He
prepared
you
to
dislike
Pecksniff
,
of

.
 
<EOS>
So
you
came
with
a
prejudice
,
you
know
,
Miss
Graham
,
and
are
not
a
fair
witness
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
triumphed
very
much
in
this
discovery
,
and
rubbed
his
hands
with
great
satisfaction
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
you
mistake
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
YOU
mistake
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
"
he
added
,
with
a
rapid
change
in
his
tone
,
"
what
is
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
Miss
Graham
,
what
is
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
brought
up
to
the
top
of
the
pew
,
by
slow
degrees
,
his
hair
,
his
forehead
,
his
eyebrow
,
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
sitting
on
a
bench
beside
the
door
with
her
hands
before
her
face
;
and
Tom
was
bending
over
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Have
I
said
anything
to
hurt
you
?
<EOS>
Has
any

anything
to
hurt
you
?
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
cry
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
tell
me
what
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
bear
to
see
you
so

.
 
<EOS>
Mercy
on
us
,
I
never
was
so
surprised
and

in
all
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
kept
his
eye
in

same
place
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
have
moved
it
now
for
nothing
short
of
a
gimlet
or
a
red
-

wire
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would

told

,

Pinch
,
"

,
"
if

;
but

,
and

so

that

;
that

;
and

that

am

;
that
no

.
 
<EOS>
I
came
here
purposely
to
tell

,
but
I

have
wanted
courage
if
you
had
not
chanced
to
lead

so
directly
to
the
object
of
my

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
gazed
at
her
steadfastly
,
and
seemed

say
,
"
What
else
?
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
said
not
a

.
   
<EOS>
"
That
person
whom
you
think
the
best
of
men
,
"
said
Mary
,
looking

,
and
speaking

.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
me
!
"
<EOS>
muttered

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Wait
a
moment
.
<EOS>
That
person
whom
I
think
the
best
of
men
!
 
<EOS>
You
mean
Pecksniff
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
see
you
mean
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Good
gracious
me
,
do
n't
speak
without

.
 
<EOS>
What
has
he
done
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
is
not
the
best
of
men
,
what
is

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
worst
.
 
<EOS>
The
falsest
,
craftiest
,
meanest
,
cruellest
,
most
sordid
,
most
shameless
,
"
said
the
trembling
girl
---
trembling
with
her
indignation
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
sat
down
on
a
seat
,
and
clasped
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
is
he
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
who
receiving
me
in
his
house
as
his
guest
;
his
unwilling

;
knowing
my
history
,
and
how
defenceless
and
alone
I
am
,
presumes
before
his
daughters
to
affront
me
so
,
that
if
I
had
a
brother
but
a
child
,
who
saw
it
,
he
would
instinctively
have
helped
me
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
scoundrel
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whoever
he
may
be
,
he
is
a
scoundrel
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
dived
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
is
he
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
who
,
when
my
only
friend
---
a
dear
and
kind
one
,
too
---
was
in
full
health
of
mind
,
humbled
himself
before
him
,
but
was
spurned
away
(
for
he
knew
him
then
)
like
a
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Who
,
in
his
forgiving
spirit
,
now
that
that
friend
is
sunk
into
a
failing
state
,
can
crawl
about
him
again
,
and
use
the
influence
he
basely
gains
for
every
base
and
wicked
purpose
,
and
not
for
one
---
not
one
---
that
's
true
or
good
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
he
is
a
scoundrel
!
"
answered
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
what
is
he
---
<EOS>
oh
,
Mr
Pinch
,
what
IS
he
---
<EOS>
who
,
thinking
he
could
compass
these
designs
the
better
if
I
were
his
wife
,
assails
me
with
the
coward
's
argument
that
if
I
marry
him
,
Martin
,
on
whom
I
have
brought
so
much
misfortune
,
shall
be
restored
to
something
of
his
former
hopes
;
and
if
I
do
not
,
shall
be
plunged
in
deeper
ruin
?
<EOS>
What
is
he
who
makes
my
very
constancy
to
one
I
love
with
all
my
heart
a
torture
to
myself
and
wrong
to
him
;
who
makes
me
,
do
what
I
will
,
the
instrument
to
hurt
a
head
I
would
heap
blessings
on
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
he
who
,
winding
all
these
cruel
snares
about
me
,
explains
their
purpose
to
me
,
with
a
smooth
tongue
and
a
smiling
face
,
in
the
broad
light
of
day
;
dragging
me
on
,
the
while
,
in
his
embrace
,
and
holding
to
his
lips
a
hand
,
"
pursued
the
agitated
girl
,
extending
