,
"
which
I
would
have
struck
off
,
if
with
it
I
could
lose
the
shame
and
degradation
of
his
touch
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
cried
Tom
,
in
great
excitement
,
"
he
is
a
scoundrel
and
a
villain
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
who
he
is
,
I
say
he
is
a
double
-
dyed
and
most
intolerable
villain
!
"
   
<EOS>
Covering
her
face
with
her
hands
again
,
as
if
the
passion
which
had
sustained
her
through
these
disclosures
lost
itself
in
an
overwhelming
sense
of
shame
and
grief
,
she
abandoned
herself
to
tears
.
   
<EOS>
Any
sight
of
distress
was
sure
to
move
the
tenderness
of
Tom
,
but
this
especially
.
 
<EOS>
Tears
and
sobs
from
her
were
arrows
in
his
heart
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
comfort
her
;
sat
down
beside
her
;
expended
all
his
store
of
homely
eloquence
;
and
spoke
in
words
of
praise
and
hope
of
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Aye
,
though
he
loved
her
from
his
soul
with
such
a
self
-
denying
love
as
woman
seldom
wins
;
he
spoke
from
first
to
last
of
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
wealth
of
the
rich
Indies
would
have
tempted
Tom
to
shirk
one
mention
of
her
lover
's
name
.
   
<EOS>
When
she
was
more
composed
,
she
impressed
upon
Tom
that
this
man
she
had
described
,
was
Pecksniff
in
his
real
colours
;
and
word
by
word
and
phrase
by
phrase
,
as
well
as
she
remembered
it
,
related
what
had
passed
between
them
in
the
wood
:
which
was
no
doubt
a
source
of
high
gratification
to
that
gentleman
himself
,
who
in
his
desire
to
see
and
his
dread
of
being
seen
,
was
constantly
diving
down
into
the
state
pew
,
and
coming
up
again
like
the
intelligent
householder
in
Punch
's
Show
,
who
avoids
being
knocked
on
the
head
with
a
cudgel
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
concluded
her
account
,
and
had
besought
Tom
to
be
very
distant
and
unconscious
in
his
manner
towards
her
after
this
explanation
,
and
had
thanked
him
very
much
,
they
parted
on
the
alarm
of
footsteps
in
the
burial
-
ground
;
and
Tom
was
left
alone
in
the
church
again
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
full
agitation
and
misery
of
the
disclosure
came
rushing
upon
Tom
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
The
star
of
his
whole
life
from
boyhood
had
become
,
in
a
moment
,
putrid
vapour
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
Pecksniff
,
Tom
's
Pecksniff
,
had
ceased
to
exist
,
but
that
he
never
had
existed
.
<EOS>
In
his
death
Tom
would
have
had
the
comfort
of
remembering
what
he
used
to
be
,
but
in
this
discovery
,
he
had
the
anguish
of
recollecting
what
he
never
was
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
as
Tom
's
blindness
in
this
matter
had
been
total
and
not
partial
,
so
was
his
restored
sight
.
<EOS>
HIS
Pecksniff
could
never
have
worked
the
wickedness
of
which
he
had
just
now
heard
,
but
any
other
Pecksniff
could
;
and
the
Pecksniff
who
could
do
that
could
do
anything
,
and
no
doubt
had
been
doing
anything
and
everything
except
the
right
thing
,
all
through
his
career
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
lofty
height
on
which
poor
Tom
had
placed
his
idol
it
was
tumbled
down
headlong
,
and
     
Not
all
the
king
's
horses
,
nor
all
the
king
's
men
,
     
Could
have
set
Mr
Pecksniff
up
again
.
   
<EOS>
Legions
of
Titans
could
n't
have
got
him
out
of
the
mud
;
and
serve
him
right
!
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
he
who
suffered
;
it
was
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
His
compass
was
broken
,
his
chart
destroyed
,
his
chronometer
had
stopped
,
his
masts
were
gone
by
the
board
;
his
anchor
was
adrift
,
ten
thousand
leagues
away
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
watched
him
with
a
lively
interest
,
for
he
divined
the
purpose
of
Tom
's
ruminations
,
and
was
curious
to
see
how
he
conducted
himself
.
 
<EOS>
For
some
time
,
Tom
wandered
up
and
down
the
aisle
like
a
man
demented
,
stopping
occasionally
to
lean
against
a
pew
and
think
it
over
;
then
he
stood
staring
at
a
blank
old
monument
bordered
tastefully
with
skulls
and
cross
-
bones
,
as
if
it
were
the
finest
work
of
Art
he
had
ever
seen
,
although
at
other
times
he
held
it
in
unspeakable
contempt
;
then
he
sat
down
;
then
walked
to
and
fro
again
;
then
went
wandering
up
into
the
organ
-
loft
,
and
touched
the
keys
.
 
<EOS>
But
their
minstrelsy
was
changed
,
their
music
gone
;
and
sounding
one
long
melancholy
chord
<EOS>
,
Tom
drooped
his
head
upon
his
hands
and
gave
it
up
as
hopeless
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
have
cared
,
"
said
Tom
Pinch
,
rising
from
his
stool
and
looking
down
into
the
church
as
if
he
had
been
the
Clergyman
,
"
I
would
n't
have
cared
for
anything
he
might
have
done
to
Me
,
for
I
have
tried
his
patience
often
,
and
have
lived
upon
his
sufferance
and
have
never
been
the
help
to
him
that
others
could
have
been
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
minded
,
Pecksniff
,
"
Tom
continued
,
little
thinking
who
heard
him
,
"
if
you
had
done
Me
any
wrong
;
I
could
have
found
plenty
of
excuses
for
that
;
and
though
you
might
have
hurt
me
,
could
have
still
gone
on
respecting
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
why
did
you
ever
fall
so
low
as
this
in
my
esteem
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
Pecksniff
,
Pecksniff
<EOS>
,
there
is
nothing
I
would
not
have
given
,
to
have
had
you
deserve
my
old
opinion
of
you
;
nothing
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
sat
upon
the
hassock
pulling
up
his
shirt
-
collar
,
while
Tom
,
touched
to
the
quick
,
delivered
this
apostrophe
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
pause
he
heard
Tom
coming
down
the
stairs
,
jingling
the
church
keys
;
and
bringing
his
eye
to
the
top
of
the
pew
again
,
saw
him
go
slowly
out
and
lock
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
durst
not
issue
from
his
place
of
concealment
;
for
through
the
windows
of
the
church
he
saw
Tom
passing
on
among
the
graves
,
and
sometimes
stopping
at
a
stone
,
and
leaning
there
as
if
he
were
a
mourner
who
had
lost
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
he
had
left
the
churchyard
,
Mr
Pecksniff
still
remained
shut
up
;
not
being
at
all
secure
but
that
in
his
restless
state
of
mind
Tom
might
come
wandering
back
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
he
issued
forth
,
and
walked
with
a
pleasant
countenance
into
the
vestry
;
where
he
knew
there
was
a
window
near
the
ground
,
by
which
he
could
release
himself
by
merely
stepping
out
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
in
a
curious
frame
of
mind
,
Mr
Pecksniff
;
being
in
no
hurry
to
go
,
but
rather
inclining
to
a
dilatory
trifling
with
the
time
,
which
prompted
him
to
open
the
vestry
cupboard
,
and
look
at
himself
in
the
parson
's
little
glass
that
hung
within
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Seeing
that
his
hair
was
rumpled
,
he
took
the
liberty
of
borrowing
the
canonical
brush
and
arranging
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
also
took
the
liberty
of
opening
another
cupboard
;
but
he
shut
it
up
again
quickly
,
being
rather
startled
by
the
sight
of
a
black
and
a
white
surplice
dangling
against
the
wall
;
which
had
very
much
the
appearance
of
two
curates
who
had
committed
suicide
by
hanging
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
Remembering
that
he
had
seen
in
the
first
cupboard
a
port
-
wine
bottle
and
some
biscuits
,
he
peeped
into
it
again
,
and
helped
himself
with
much
deliberation
;
cogitating
all
the
time
though
,
in
a
very
deep
and
weighty
manner
,
as
if
his
thoughts
were
otherwise
employed
.
   
<EOS>
He
soon
made
up
his
mind
,
if
it
had
ever
been
in
doubt
;
and
putting
back
the
bottle
and
biscuits
,
opened
the
casement
.
 
<EOS>
He
got
out
into
the
churchyard
without
any
difficulty
;
shut
the
window
after
him
;
and
walked
straight
home
.
   
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr
Pinch
indoors
?
"
asked
Mr
Pecksniff
of
his
serving
-
maid
.
   
<EOS>
"
Just
come
in
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
come
in
,
eh
?
"
repeated
Mr
Pecksniff
,
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
gone
upstairs
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Yes
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Gone
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
call
him
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
no
.
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
call
him
,
Jane
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
Jane
.
 
<EOS>
How
are
your
relations
,
Jane
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
,
I
thank
you
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
know
I
asked
about
them
,
Jane
.
 
<EOS>
Is
Mr
Chuzzlewit
in
the
way
,
Jane
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
in
the
parlour
,
reading
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
in
the
parlour
,
reading
,
is
he
,
Jane
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
.
 
<EOS>
Then
I
think
I
'll
go
and
see
him
,
Jane
.
"
   
<EOS>
Never
had
Mr
Pecksniff
been
beheld
in
a
more
pleasant
humour
!
   
<EOS>
But
when
he
walked
into
the
parlour
where
the
old
man
was
engaged
as
Jane
had
said
;
with
pen
and
ink
and
paper
on
a
table
close
at
hand
(
for
Mr
Pecksniff
was
always
very
particular
to
have
him
well
supplied
with
writing
materials
)
,
he
became
less
cheerful
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
angry
,
he
was
not
vindictive
,
he
was
not
cross
,
he
was
not
moody
,
but
he
was
grieved
;
he
was
sorely
grieved
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
sat
down
by
the
old
man
's
side
,
two
tears
---
not
tears
like
those
with
which
recording
angels
blot
their
entries
out
,
but
drops
so
precious
that
they
use
them
for
their
ink
---
stole
down
his
meritorious
cheeks
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
asked
old
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pecksniff
,
what
ails
you
,
man
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
interrupt
you
,
my
dear
sir
,
and
I
am
still
more
sorry
for
the
cause
.
 
<EOS>
My
good
,
my
worthy
friend
,
I
am
deceived
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
deceived
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
an
agony
,
"
deceived
in
the
tenderest
point
.
 
<EOS>
Cruelly
deceived
in
that
quarter
,
sir
,
in
which
I
placed
the
most
unbounded
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
Deceived
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
by
Thomas
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
bad
,
bad
,
bad
!
"
said
Martin
,
laying
down
his
book
.
 
<EOS>
"
Very
bad
!
<EOS>
I
hope
not
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
certain
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certain
,
my
good
sir
!
 
<EOS>
My
eyes
and
ears
are
witnesses
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
believed
it
otherwise
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
believed
it
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
if
a
Fiery
Serpent
had
proclaimed
it
from
the
top
of
Salisbury
Cathedral
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
have
said
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
that
the
Serpent
lied
.
 
<EOS>
Such
was
my
faith
in
Thomas
Pinch
,
that
I
would
have
cast
the
falsehood
back
into
the
Serpent
's
teeth
,
and
would
have
taken
Thomas
to
my
heart
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
a
Serpent
,
sir
,
myself
<EOS>
,
I
grieve
to
say
,
and
no
excuse
or
hope
is
left
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
greatly
disturbed
to
see
him
so
much
agitated
,
and
to
hear
such
unexpected
news
.
 
<EOS>
He
begged
him
to
compose
himself
,
and
asked
upon
what
subject
Mr
Pinch
's
treachery
had
been
developed
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
almost
the
worst
of
all
,
sir
,
"
Mr
Pecksniff
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
on
a
subject
nearly
concerning
YOU
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
is
it
not
enough
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
upward
,
"
that
these
blows
must
fall
on
me
,
but
must
they
also
hit
my
friends
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
alarm
me
,
"
cried
the
old
man
,
changing
colour
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
so
strong
as
I
was
.
 
<EOS>
You
terrify
me
,
Pecksniff
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Cheer
up
,
my
noble
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
taking
courage
,
"
and
we
will
do
what
is
required
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
know
all
,
sir
,
and
shall
be
righted
.
 
<EOS>
But
first
excuse
me
,
sir
,
excuse
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
duty
to
discharge
,
which
I
owe
to
society
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
rang
the
bell
,
and
Jane
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
"
Send
Mr
Pinch
here
,
if
you
please
,
Jane
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
came
.
 
<EOS>
Constrained
and
altered
in
his
manner
,
downcast
and
dejected
,
visibly
confused
;
not
liking
to
look
Pecksniff
in
the
face
.
   
<EOS>
The
honest
man
bestowed
a
glance
on
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
as
who
should
say
"
You
see
!
"
and
addressed
himself
to
Tom
in
these
terms
:
   
"
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
I
have
left
the
vestry
-
window
unfastened
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
do
me
the
favour
to
go
and
secure
it
;
then
bring
the
keys
of
the
sacred
edifice
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
vestry
-
window
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
understand
me
,
Mr
Pinch
,
I
think
,
"
returned
his
patron
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr
Pinch
,
the
vestry
-
window
.
 
<EOS>
I
grieve
to
say
that
sleeping
in
the
church
after
a
fatiguing
ramble
,
I
overheard
just
now
some
fragments
,
"
he
emphasised
that
word
,
"
of
a
dialogue
between
two
parties
;
and
one
of
them
locking
the
church
when
he
went
out
,
I
was
obliged
to
leave
it
myself
by
the
vestry
-
window
.
 
<EOS>
Do
me
the
favour
to
secure
that
vestry
-
window
,
Mr
Pinch
,
and
then
come
back
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
No
physiognomist
that
ever
dwelt
on
earth
could
have
construed
Tom
's
face
when
he
heard
these
words
.
 
<EOS>
Wonder
was
in
it
,
and
a
mild
look
of
reproach
,
but
certainly
no
fear
or
guilt
,
although
a
host
of
strong
emotions
struggled
to
display
themselves
.
 
<EOS>
He
bowed
,
and
without
saying
one
word
,
good
or
bad
,
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pecksniff
,
"
cried
Martin
,
in
a
tremble
,
"
what
does
all
this
mean
?
<EOS>
You
are
not
going
to
do
anything
in
haste
,
you
may
regret
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
good
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
firmly
,
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
a
duty
to
discharge
which
I
owe
to
society
;
and
it
shall
be
discharged
,
my
friend
,
at
any
cost
!
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
late
-
remembered
,
much
-
forgotten
,
mouthing
,
braggart
duty
,
always
owed
,
and
seldom
paid
in
any
other
coin
than
punishment
and
wrath
,
when
will
mankind
begin
to
know
thee
!
 
<EOS>
When
will
men
acknowledge
thee
in
thy
neglected
cradle
,
and
thy
stunted
youth
,
and
not
begin
their
recognition
in
thy
sinful
manhood
and
thy
desolate
old
age
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
ermined
Judge
whose
duty
to
society
is
,
now
,
to
doom
the
ragged
criminal
to
punishment
and
death
,
hadst
thou
<EOS>
never
,
Man
,
a
duty
to
discharge
in
barring
up
the
hundred
open
gates
that
wooed
him
to
the
felon
's
dock
,
and
throwing
but
ajar
the
portals
to
a
decent
life
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
prelate
,
prelate
,
whose
duty
to
society
it
is
to
mourn
in
melancholy
phrase
the
sad
degeneracy
of
these
bad
times
in
which
thy
lot
of
honours
has
been
cast
,
did
nothing
go
before
thy
elevation
to
the
lofty
seat
,
from
which
thou
dealest
out
thy
homilies
to
other
tarriers
for
dead
men
's
shoes
,
whose
duty
to
society
has
not
begun
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
magistrate
,
so
rare
a
country
gentleman
and
brave
a
squire
,
had
you
no
duty
to
society
,
before
the
ricks
were
blazing
and
the
mob
were
mad
;
or
did
it
spring
up
,
armed
and
booted
from
the
earth
,
a
corps
of
yeomanry
full
-
grown
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
's
duty
to
society
could
not
be
paid
till
Tom
came
back
.
<EOS>
The
interval
which
preceded
the
return
of
that
young
man
,
he
occupied
in
a
close
conference
with
his
friend
;
so
that
when
Tom
did
arrive
,
he
found
the
two
quite
ready
to
receive
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mary
was
in
her
own
room
above
<EOS>
,
whither
Mr
Pecksniff
,
always
considerate
,
had
besought
old
Martin
to
entreat
her
to
remain
some
half
-
hour
longer
,
that
her
feelings
might
be
spared
.
   
<EOS>
When
Tom
came
back
,
he
found
old
Martin
sitting
by
the
window
,
and
Mr
Pecksniff
in
an
imposing
attitude
at
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
On
one
side
of
him
was
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
;
and
on
the
other
a
little
heap
(
a
very
little
heap
)
of
gold
and
silver
,
and
odd
pence
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
saw
,
at
a
glance
,
that
it
was
his
own
salary
for
the
current
quarter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
you
fastened
the
vestry
-
window
,
Mr
Pinch
?
"
said
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
Put
down
the
keys
if
you
please
,
Mr
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
placed
them
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
the
bunch
by
the
key
of
the
organ
-
loft
(
though
it
was
one
of
the
smallest
)
,
and
looked
hard
at
it
as
he
laid
it
down
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
been
an
old
,
old
friend
of
Tom
's
;
a
kind
companion
to
him
,
many
and
many
a
day
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
shaking
his
head
;
"
<EOS>
oh
,
Mr
Pinch
!
 
<EOS>
I
wonder
you
can
look
me
in
the
face
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
did
it
though
;
and
notwithstanding
that
he
has
been
described
as
stooping
generally
,
he
stood
as
upright
then
as
man
could
stand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
taking
up
his
handkerchief
,
as
if
he
felt
that
he
should
want
it
soon
,
"
I
will
not
dwell
upon
the
past
.
<EOS>
I
will
spare
you
,
and
I
will
spare
myself
,
that
pain
at
least
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
's
was
not
a
very
bright
eye
,
but
it
was
a
very
expressive
one
when
he
looked
at
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
glad
you
will
not
refer
to
the
past
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
present
is
enough
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
dropping
a
penny
,
"
and
the
sooner
THAT
is
past
,
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
,
I
will
not
dismiss
you
without
a
word
of
explanation
.
 
<EOS>
Even
such
a
course
would
be
quite
justifiable
under
the
circumstances
;
but
it
might
wear
an
appearance
of
hurry
,
and
I
will
not
do
it
;
for
I
am
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
knocking
down
another
penny
,
"
perfectly
self
-
possessed
.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
will
say
to
you
,
what
I
have
already
said
to
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
glanced
at
the
old
gentleman
,
who
nodded
now
<EOS>
and
then
as
approving
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
sentences
and
sentiments
,
but
interposed
between
them
in
no
other
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
fragments
of
a
conversation
which
I
overheard
in
the
church
,
just
now
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
"
between
yourself
and
Miss
Graham
<EOS>
---
I
say
fragments
,
because
I
was
slumbering
at
a
considerable
distance
from
you
,
when
I
was
roused
by
your
voices
---
and
from
what
I
saw
,
I
ascertained
<EOS>
(
I
would
have
given
a
great
deal
not
to
have
ascertained
,
Mr
Pinch
)
that
you
,
forgetful
of
all
ties
of
duty
and
of
honour
,
sir
;
regardless
of
the
sacred
laws
of
hospitality
,
to
which
you
were
pledged
as
an
inmate
of
this
house
;
have
presumed
to
address
Miss
Graham
with
unreturned
professions
of
attachment
and
proposals
of
love
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
looked
at
him
steadily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
deny
it
,
sir
?
"
asked
Mr
Pecksniff
,
dropping
one
pound
two
and
fourpence
,
and
making
a
great
business
of
picking
it
up
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
replied
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
glancing
at
the
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
Oblige
me
by
counting
this
money
,
Mr
Pinch
,
and
putting
your
name
to
this
receipt
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
not
?
"
   
<EOS>
No
,
Tom
did
not
.
 
<EOS>
He
scorned
to
deny
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
that
Mr
Pecksniff
having
overheard
his
own
disgrace
,
cared
not
a
jot
for
sinking
lower
yet
in
his
contempt
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
that
he
had
devised
this
fiction
as
the
readiest
means
of
getting
rid
of
him
at
once
,
but
that
it
must
end
in
that
any
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
saw
that
Mr
Pecksniff
reckoned
on
his
not
denying
it
,
because
his
doing
so
and
explaining
would
incense
the
old
man
more
than
ever
against
Martin
and
against
Mary
;
while
Pecksniff
himself
would
only
have
been
mistaken
in
his
"
fragments
.
<EOS>
"
Deny
it
!
 
<EOS>
No
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
find
the
amount
correct
,
do
you
,
Mr
Pinch
?
"
said
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
correct
,
sir
,
"
answered
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
person
is
waiting
in
the
kitchen
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
to
carry
your
luggage
wherever
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
We
part
,
Mr
Pinch
,
at
once
,
and
are
strangers
from
this
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
Something
without
a
name
;
compassion
,
sorrow
,
old
tenderness
,
mistaken
gratitude
,
habit
;
none
of
these
,
and
yet
all
of
them
;
<EOS>
smote
upon
Tom
's
gentle
heart
at
parting
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
such
soul
as
Pecksniff
's
in
that
carcase
;
and
yet
,
though
his
speaking
out
had
not
involved
the
compromise
of
one
he
loved
,
he
could
n't
have
denounced
the
very
shape
and
figure
of
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
Not
even
then
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
say
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shedding
tears
,
"
what
a
blow
this
is
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
how
much
it
tries
me
;
how
it
works
upon
my
nature
;
how
it
grates
upon
my
feelings
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
care
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
endure
as
well
as
another
man
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
I
have
to
hope
,
and
what
you
have
to
hope
,
Mr
Pinch
(
otherwise
a
great
responsibility
rests
upon
you
)
,
is
,
that
this
deception
may
not
alter
my
ideas
of
humanity
;
that
it
may
not
impair
my
freshness
,
or
contract
,
if
I
may
use
the
expression
,
my
Pinions
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
will
not
;
I
do
n't
think
it
will
.
 
<EOS>
It
may
be
a
comfort
to
you
,
if
not
now
,
at
some
future
time
,
to
know
that
I
shall
endeavour
not
to
think
the
worse
of
my
fellow
-
creatures
in
general
,
for
what
has
passed
between
us
.
<EOS>
Farewell
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
had
meant
to
spare
him
one
little
puncturation
with
a
lancet
,
which
he
had
it
in
his
power
to
administer
,
but
he
changed
his
mind
on
hearing
this
,
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
left
something
in
the
church
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
aware
that
I
did
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
your
double
eye
-
glass
,
I
believe
?
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
cried
Pecksniff
,
with
some
degree
of
confusion
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
obliged
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
Put
it
down
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
found
it
,
"
said
Tom
,
slowly
---
"
when
I
went
to
bolt
the
vestry
-
window
---
in
the
pew
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
he
had
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
taken
it
off
when
he
was
bobbing
up
and
down
,
lest
it
should
strike
against
the
panelling
;
and
had
forgotten
it
.
 
<EOS>
Going
back
to
the
church
with
his
mind
full
of
having
been
watched
,
and
wondering
very
much
from
what
part
,
Tom
's
attention
was
caught
by
the
door
of
the
state
pew
standing
open
.
 
<EOS>
Looking
into
it
he
found
the
glass
.
 
<EOS>
And
thus
he
knew
,
and
by
returning
it
gave
Mr
Pecksniff
the
information
that
he
knew
,
where
the
listener
had
been
;
and
that
instead
of
overhearing
fragments
of
the
conversation
,
he
must
have
rejoiced
in
every
word
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
he
's
gone
,
"
said
Martin
,
drawing
a
long
breath
when
Tom
had
left
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
IS
a
relief
,
"
assented
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
great
relief
.
<EOS>
But
having
discharged
---
I
hope
with
tolerable
firmness
---
the
duty
which
I
owed
to
society
,
I
will
now
,
my
dear
sir
,
if
you
will
give
me
leave
,
retire
to
shed
a
few
tears
in
the
back
garden
,
as
an
humble
individual
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
went
upstairs
;
cleared
his
shelf
of
books
;
packed
them
up
with
his
music
and
an
old
fiddle
in
his
trunk
;
got
out
his
clothes
<EOS>
(
they
were
not
so
many
that
they
made
his
head
ache
)
;
put
them
on
the
top
of
his
books
;
and
went
into
the
workroom
for
his
case
of
instruments
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
ragged
stool
there
,
with
the
horsehair
all
sticking
out
of
the
top
like
a
wig
:
<EOS>
a
very
Beast
of
a
stool
in
itself
;
on
which
he
had
taken
up
his
daily
seat
,
year
after
year
,
during
the
whole
period
of
his
service
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
grown
older
and
shabbier
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
Pupils
had
served
their
time
;
seasons
had
come
and
gone
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
and
the
worn
-
out
stool
had
held
together
through
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
That
part
of
the
room
was
traditionally
called
"
Tom
's
Corner
.
<EOS>
"
It
had
been
assigned
to
him
at
first
because
of
its
being
situated
in
a
strong
draught
,
and
a
great
way
from
the
fire
;
and
he
had
occupied
it
ever
since
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
portraits
of
him
on
the
walls
,
with
all
his
weak
points
monstrously
portrayed
.
 
<EOS>
Diabolical
sentiments
,
foreign
to
his
character
,
were
represented
as
issuing
from
his
mouth
in
fat
balloons
.
 
<EOS>
Every
pupil
had
added
something
,
even
unto
fancy
portraits
of
his
father
with
one
eye
,
and
of
his
mother
with
a
disproportionate
nose
,
and
especially
of
his
sister
;
who
always
being
presented
as
extremely
beautiful
,
made
full
amends
to
Tom
for
any
other
jokes
.
 
<EOS>
Under
less
uncommon
circumstances
,
it
would
have
cut
Tom
to
the
heart
to
leave
these
things
and
think
that
he
saw
them
for
the
last
time
;
but
it
did
n't
now
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
Pecksniff
;
there
never
had
been
a
Pecksniff
;
and
all
his
other
griefs
were
swallowed
up
in
that
.
   
<EOS>
So
,
when
he
returned
into
the
bedroom
,
and
,
having
fastened
his
box
and
a
carpet
-
bag
,
put
on
his
walking
gaiters
,
and
his
great
-
coat
,
and
his
hat
,
and
taken
his
stick
in
his
hand
,
looked
round
it
for
the
last
time
.
 
<EOS>
Early
on
summer
mornings
,
and
by
the
light
of
private
candle
-
ends
on
winter
nights
,
he
had
read
himself
half
blind
in
this
same
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
tried
in
this
same
room
to
learn
the
fiddle
under
the
bedclothes
,
but
yielding
to
objections
from
the
other
pupils
,
had
reluctantly
abandoned
the
design
.
 
<EOS>
At
any
other
time
he
would
have
parted
from
it
with
a
pang
,
thinking
of
all
he
had
learned
there
,
of
the
many
hours
he
had
passed
there
;
for
the
love
of
his
very
dreams
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
Pecksniff
;
there
never
had
been
a
Pecksniff
,
and
the
unreality
of
Pecksniff
extended
itself
to
the
chamber
,
in
which
,
sitting
on
one
particular
bed
,
the
thing
supposed
to
be
that
Great
Abstraction
had
often
preached
morality
with
such
effect
that
Tom
had
felt
a
moisture
in
his
eyes
,
while
hanging
breathless
on
the
words
.
   
<EOS>
The
man
engaged
to
bear
his
box
---
Tom
knew
him
well
:
a
Dragon
man
---
 
came
stamping
up
the
stairs
,
and
made
a
roughish
bow
to
Tom
(
to
whom
in
common
times
he
would
have
nodded
with
a
grin
)
as
though
he
were
aware
of
what
had
happened
,
and
wished
him
to
perceive
it
made
no
difference
to
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
clumsily
done
;
he
was
a
mere
waterer
of
horses
;
but
Tom
liked
the
man
for
it
,
and
felt
it
more
than
going
away
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
would
have
helped
him
with
the
box
,
but
he
made
no
more
of
it
,
though
it
was
a
heavy
one
,
than
an
elephant
would
have
made
of
a
castle
;
just
swinging
it
on
his
back
and
bowling
downstairs
as
if
,
being
naturally
a
heavy
sort
of
fellow
,
he
could
carry
a
box
infinitely
better
than
he
could
go
alone
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
took
the
carpet
-
bag
,
and
went
downstairs
along
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
outer
door
stood
Jane
,
crying
with
all
her
might
;
and
on
the
steps
was
Mrs
Lupin
,
sobbing
bitterly
,
and
putting
out
her
hand
for
Tom
to
shake
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
coming
to
the
Dragon
,
Mr
Pinch
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
walk
to
Salisbury
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
stay
here
.
 
<EOS>
For
goodness
'
sake
,
do
n't
make
me
so
unhappy
,
Mrs
Lupin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
'll
come
to
the
Dragon
,
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
's
only
for
tonight
.
<EOS>
To
see
me
,
you
know
;
not
as
a
traveller
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
wiping
his

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
kindness
of
people
is
enough
to
break
one
's
heart
!
 
<EOS>
I
mean
to
go
to
Salisbury
to
-
night
,
my
dear
good
creature
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
'll
take

my

for
me
till
I
write
for
it
,
I
shall
consider

can

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
,
"

Lupin
,
"
there
were
twenty
boxes
,
Mr
Pinch
,
that
I
might
have
'em

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
like
you
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
"
   
<EOS>
There
were
several
people
,
young
and
old
,
standing
about
the
door
,
some

cried
with
Mrs
Lupin
;
while

,
as
Tom
did
;
and
others
were
absorbed
in
admiration
of
Mr
Pecksniff
---
a
man
who
could
build
a
church
,
as
one
may
say
,
by
squinting
at
a
sheet
of
paper
;
and
others
were
divided
between
that
feeling
and
sympathy
with
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
appeared
on
the
top
of
the
steps
,
simultaneously
with
his
old
pupil
,
and
while
Tom
was
talking
with
Mrs
Lupin
kept

stretched
out
,
as
though
he
said
"
Go
forth
!
"
 
<EOS>
When
Tom
went
forth
,
and
had

the
corner
Mr
Pecksniff
shook
his
head
,
shut
his
eyes
,
and
heaving

deep

,
shut
the

.
 
<EOS>
On
which
,
the
best
of
Tom
's
supporters
said
he
must
have
done
some
dreadful
deed
,
or
such
a
man
as
Mr
Pecksniff
never
could
have
felt
like
that
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
a
common
quarrel
(
they
observed
)
,
he
would
have
said
something
,
but
when
he
did
n't
,
Mr
Pinch
must
have
shocked
him
dreadfully
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
out
of
hearing
of
their
shrewd

,
and
plodded
on
as
steadily
as
he
could
go
,
until
he
came
within

of
the
turnpike
where
the
tollman
's
family
had
cried
out
"
Mr
Pinch
!
"
<EOS>
that
frosty
morning
,
when
he
went
to

young
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
got
through
the
village
,
and
this
toll
-
bar
was
his
last
trial
;
but
when

came

,
he
had
half

mind
to
run
for

,
and
make

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
deary
Mr
Pinch
!
<EOS>
oh
,
deary

!
<EOS>
"
cried

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

for

to
be
a
-
going
this

bag
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
goodness
,

's
the
gig
,

?
"
cried

's

,

,
as

might
have
been
upset
without

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
got
it
,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
<EOS>
"
he
could

evade
it
;
he
felt
she
would
have

in

next

,
if
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
left
Mr
Pecksniff
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
tollman
---
a
crusty
customer
,
always
smoking
solitary

in
a
Windsor
chair
,
inside
,
set
artfully

two
little

that

,
so
that

coming

he
might

on

toll
to

,
and
when
he

,
might

on
having

---
the

was

.
   
<EOS>
"
Left

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"
left

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,
uncertain

.
<EOS>
Astonishment

,
he

,

into

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
left
Mr
Pecksniff
!
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
as
soon
have
thought
of
his

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
said
Tom
,
"
<EOS>
so

I
,
yesterday
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
If

heavy
drove
of
oxen
had
n't
come
by

,
the
tollman
would
have
gone
down
to
the
village
straight
,
to
inquire
into
it
.
<EOS>
As
things
turned
out
,
he
smoked
another
pipe
,
and
took
his
wife
into
his
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
But
their
united
sagacity
could
make
nothing
of
it
,
and
they
went
to
bed
---
metaphorically
---
in
the

.
 
<EOS>
But
several
times
that
night
,
when

through
,
and

driver
asked
the
tollkeeper
<EOS>
"
What
news
?
<EOS>
"
he

man

,
to

had

in

,

,

:
   
<EOS>
"
You
've
heerd

down

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
sure

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
of
his
young

Mr
Pinch
,
p'raps
?
"
   
"
Ah
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
've
parted
.
"
   
<EOS>
After
every
one
of
these
disclosures
,
the
tollman
plunged
into
his
house
again
,
and
was
seen
no
more
,
while
the
other
side
went
on
in
great

.
   
<EOS>
But
this
was
long
after
Tom
was
abed
,
and
Tom
was
now
with
his
face
towards
Salisbury
,
doing
his
best
to
get
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
evening
was
beautiful
at
first
,
but
it
became
cloudy
and
dull
at
sunset
,
and
the
rain
fell
heavily
soon
afterwards
.
 
<EOS>
For
ten
long
miles
he
plodded
on
,
wet
through
,
until
at
last
the
lights
appeared
,
and
he
came
into
the
welcome
precincts
of
the
city
.
   
<EOS>
He
went
to
the
inn
where
he
had
waited
for
Martin
,
and
briefly
answering
their
inquiries
after
Mr
Pecksniff
,
ordered
a
bed
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
no
heart
for
tea
or
supper
,
meat
or
drink
of
any
kind
,
but
sat
by
himself
before
an
empty
table
in
the
public
room
while
the
bed
was
getting
ready
,
revolving
in
his
mind
all
that
had
happened
that
eventful
day
,
and
wondering
what
he
could
or
should
do
for
the
future
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
relief
when
the
chambermaid
came
in
,
and
said
the
bed
was
ready
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
low
four
-
poster
,
shelving
downward
in
the
centre
like
a
trough
,
and
the
room
was
crowded
with
impracticable
tables
and
exploded
chests
of
drawers
,
full
of
damp
linen
.
 
<EOS>
A
graphic
representation
in
oil
of
a
remarkably
fat
ox
hung
over
the
fireplace
,
and
the
portrait
of
some
former
landlord
(
who
might
have
been
the
ox
's
brother
<EOS>
,
he
was
so
like
him
)
stared
roundly
in
,
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
.
 
<EOS>
A
variety
of
queer
smells
were
partially
quenched
in
the
prevailing
scent
of
very
old
lavender
;
and
the
window
had
not
been
opened
for
such
a
long
space
of
time
that
it
pleaded
immemorial
usage
,
and
would
n't
come
open
now
.
   
<EOS>
These
were
trifles
in
themselves
,
but
they
added
to
the
strangeness
of
the
place
,
and
did
not
induce
Tom
to
forget
his
new
position
.
<EOS>
Pecksniff
had
gone
out
of
the
world
---
had
never
been
in
it
---
and
it
was
as
much
as
Tom
could
do
to
say
his
prayers
without
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
felt
happier
afterwards
,
and
went
to
sleep
,
and
dreamed
about
him
as
he
Never
Was
.
    
Chapter
32
.
<EOS>
Treats
of
Todger
's
again
;
and
of
another
blighted
plant
besides
the
plants
upon
the
leads
 
Early
on
the
day
next
after
that
on
which
she
bade
adieu
to
the
halls
of
her
youth
and
the
scenes
of
her
childhood
,
Miss
Pecksniff
,
arriving
safely
at
the
coach
-
office
in
London
,
was
there
received
,
and
conducted
to
her
peaceful
home
beneath
the
shadow
of
the
Monument
,
by
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
M
Todgers
looked
a
little
worn
by
cares
of
gravy
and
other
such
solicitudes
arising
out
of
her
establishment
,
but
displayed
her
usual
earnestness
and
warmth
of
manner
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
,
my
sweet
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
said
she
,
<EOS>
"
how
is
your
princely
pa
?
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
signified
(
in
confidence
)
that
he
contemplated
the
introduction
of
a
princely
ma
;
and
repeated
the
sentiment
that
she
was
n't
blind
,
and
was
n't
quite
a
fool
,
and
would
n't
bear
it
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
was
more
shocked
by
the
intelligence
than
any
one
could
have
expected
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
quite
bitter
.
 
<EOS>
She
said
there
was
no
truth
in
man
and
that
the
warmer
he
expressed
himself
,
as
a
general
principle
,
the
falser
and
more
treacherous
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
She
foresaw
with
astonishing
clearness
that
the
object
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
attachment
was
designing
,
worthless
,
and
wicked
;
and
receiving
from
Charity
the
fullest
confirmation
of
these
views
,
protested
with
tears
in
her
eyes
that
she
loved
Miss
Pecksniff
like
a
sister
,
and
felt
her
injuries
as
if
they
were
her
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
real
darling
sister
,
I
have
not
seen
her
more
than
once
since
her
marriage
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
and
then
I
thought
her
looking
poorly
.
 
<EOS>
My
sweet
Miss
Pecksniff
,
I
always
thought
that
you
was
to
be
the
lady
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Cherry
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
Mrs
Todgers
.
<EOS>
Thank

.
 
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
not
for
any

he

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
dare

right
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
feared

all

.
 
<EOS>
But

we

had

that

,
here

,
in

,
my

Miss
Pecksniff
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Lor
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Awful
,

!
"

Mrs
Todgers
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
recollect

youngest
gentleman
,
my
dear
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Of

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,
"

;

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

that

,
"
I
have

him
again

,

,

his

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
never

!
"
<EOS>

;
"
that
's

I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
when
the

took
place
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
,
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

of

,
my

Miss
Pecksniff
;
the

he
expressed
upon

;

;

;

;

never

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
pity

n't

,

,
"
observed
Miss
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
Himself
!
"
said

Todgers
,
"
it

another

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
for

other

then
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
chaffing
going
on
<EOS>
---
I
hope
you
do
n't
consider
that
a
low
expression
,
Miss
Pecksniff
;
it
is
always
in
our
gentlemen
's
mouths
---
a
little
chaffing
going
on
,
my
dear
,
among
'em
,
all
in
good
nature
,
when
suddenly
he
rose

,
foaming

,
and
<EOS>
but
for
being

by
three
would
have
had
Mr
Jinkins
's
life
with
a

.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
's
face
expressed
supreme
indifference
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
now
he
is
the
meekest
of
men
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
almost
bring
the
tears
into
his

by
looking

.
 
<EOS>
He
sits
with
me
the
whole
day
long
on
Sundays
,
talking
in
such
a
dismal
way
that
I
find
it
next
to
impossible
to
keep
my
spirits
up
equal
to
the

.
 
<EOS>
His
only

is
in
female

.
 
<EOS>
He
takes
me
half
-
price
to
the
play
,
to
an
extent
which
I
sometimes
fear

beyond

;
and
I
see
the
tears
a
-
standing
in
his
eyes
during
the
whole
performance
---
particularly
if
it
is
anything
of
a
comic
nature
.
 
<EOS>
The
turn
I
experienced
only
yesterday
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
putting
her

to

side
,
"
when
the
house
-
maid
threw
his
bedside
carpet
out
of
the

his
room
,
while
I
was
sitting
here
,
no
one
can

.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
was
him
,
and
that
he
had
done
it
at
last
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
contempt
with
which
Miss
Charity
received
this
pathetic
account
of
the
state
to
which
the
youngest
gentleman
in
company
was
reduced
,
did
not
say
much
for
her
power
of
sympathising
with
that
unfortunate
character
.
 
<EOS>
She
treated
it
with
great
levity
,
and
went
on
to
inform
herself
,
then
and
afterwards
,
whether
any
other
changes
had
occurred
in
the
commercial
boarding
-
house
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
was
gone
,
and
had
been
succeeded
(
such
is
the
decay
of
human
greatness
!
)
<EOS>
by
an
old
woman
whose
name
was
reported
to
be
Tamaroo
---
which
seemed
an
impossibility
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
it
appeared
in
the
fullness
of
time
that
the
jocular
boarders
had
appropriated
the
word
from
an
English
ballad
,
in
which
it
is
supposed
to
express
the
bold
and
fiery
nature
of
a
certain
hackney

;
and
that
it
was
bestowed
upon
Mr
Bailey
's
successor
by
reason
of
her
having
nothing
fiery
about
her
,
except
an
occasional
attack
of
that
fire
which
is
called
St.
Anthony
's
.
 
<EOS>
This
ancient
female
had
been
engaged
,
in
fulfillment
of
a
vow
,
registered
by
Mrs
Todgers
,
that
no
more
boys
should
darken
the
commercial

;
and
she
was
chiefly
remarkable
for
a
total
absence
of
all

upon
every
subject
<EOS>
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
perfect
Tomb
for
messages
and
small
parcels
;
and
when
dispatched
to
the
Post
Office
with
letters
,
had
been
frequently
seen
endeavouring
to
insinuate

into
casual

in
private
doors
,
under
the
delusion
that
any
door
with
a
hole
in
it
would
answer
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
a
very
little
old
woman
,
and
always
wore
a
very
coarse
apron
with
a
bib
before
and
a
loop
behind
,
together
with
bandages
on
her
wrists
,
which
appeared
to
be
afflicted
with
an
everlasting
sprain
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
on
all
occasions
chary
of
opening
the
street
door
,
and
ardent
to
shut
it
again
;
and
she
waited
at
table
in
a
bonnet
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
only
great
change
over
and
above
the
change
which
had
fallen
on
the
youngest
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
As
for
him
,
he
more
than
corroborated
the
account
of
Mrs
Todgers
;
possessing
greater
sensibility
than
even
she

credit
for
.
 
<EOS>
He
entertained
some
terrible
notions
of
Destiny
,
among
other
matters
,
and
talked
much
about
people
's
"
Missions
"
;
upon
which
he
seemed
to
have
some
private
information
not
generally
attainable
,
as
he
knew
it
had
been
poor
Merry
's
mission
to
crush
him
in
the
bud
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
frail
and
tearful
;
for
being
aware
that
a
shepherd
's
mission
was
to
pipe
to
his
flocks
,
and
that
a
boatswain
's
mission
was
to
pipe
all
hands
,
and
that
one
man
's
mission
was
to
be
a
paid
piper
,
and
another
man
's
mission
was
to
pay
the
piper
,
so
he
had
got
it
into
his
head
that
his
own
peculiar
mission
was
to
pipe
his
eye
.
 
<EOS>
Which
he
did
perpetually
.
   
<EOS>
He
often
informed
Mrs
Todgers
that
the
sun
had
set
upon
him
;
that
the
billows
had
rolled
over

;
that
the

of
Juggernaut
had

,
and
also
that

deadly
Upas

of
Java
had

.
 
<EOS>
His
name
was
Moddle
.
   
<EOS>
Towards
this
most
unhappy
Moddle
,
Miss
Pecksniff
conducted
herself
at
first
with
distant

,
being
in
no

to
be

with

.
 
<EOS>
The
poor
young
gentleman
was
additionally
crushed
by
this
,
and
remonstrated
with
Mrs
Todgers
on

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Even
she
turns

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Cheerful
,

!
<EOS>
cheerful
!
<EOS>
"

youngest

;
"
when
she

of
days
for

,
Mrs

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,
"

,
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Her

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Her

,

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
It

so
like
;
"
here

.
 
<EOS>
"
it
's
so
like
hers
who
is
Another
's
,
Mrs

!
"
   
<EOS>
The

did
not

report

to
Charity
,
who
laughed
at

,
but

Mr

that

,

presented

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

was
not
less

than

;
was

,

;
but

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only

,

,
"

<EOS>

,

,
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
This

to
Charity
,
who
talked

next
evening
in
her
most
engaging

,
and
rallying
Mr
Moddle
on
the

,

.
<EOS>
Mr
Moddle
taking
up
the
gauntlet
,
they
played
several
rubbers
for
sixpences
,
and
Charity
won
them
all
.
 
<EOS>
This
may
have
been
partially

to
the
gallantry
of
the
youngest

,
but
it
was
certainly

to
the
state
of
his
feelings
also
;
for
his
eyes
being
frequently
dimmed
by
tears
<EOS>
,
he
thought
that
aces
were
tens
,
and
knaves
queens
,
which
at
times
occasioned
some
confusion
in
his
play
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
seventh
night
of
cribbage
,
when
Mrs
Todgers
,

,
proposed
that

they

for
"
love
,
"
Mr
Moddle
was
seen
to
change

.
 
<EOS>
On
the
fourteenth
night
,
he
kissed
Miss
Pecksniff
's
snuffers
,
in
the
passage
,
when
she
went
upstairs
to
bed
;
meaning
to
have
kissed
her
hand
,
but
missing

.
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
Mr
Moddle
began
to
be
impressed
with
the
idea
that
Miss
Pecksniff
's
mission
was
to
comfort

;
and
Miss

began
to
speculate
on
the
probability
of
its
being
her
mission
to
become
ultimately
Mrs
Moddle
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
gentleman
(
Miss
Pecksniff
was
not
a
very
young
lady
)
with
rising
prospects
,
and
"
almost
"
enough
to
live
on
.
 
<EOS>
Really
it
looked
very
well
.
   
<EOS>
Besides
---
besides
---
he
had
been
regarded
as
devoted
to
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
Merry
had
joked
about
him
,
and
had
once
spoken
of
it
to
her

as
a
conquest
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
better
looking
,
better
shaped
,
better
spoken
,
better

,
better

than
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
easy
to
manage
,
could
be
made
to
consult
the
humours
of
his
Betrothed
,
and
could
be
shown
off
like
a
lamb
when
Jonas
was
a
bear
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
the
rub
!
   
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
the
cribbage
went
on
,
and
Mrs
Todgers
went
off
;
for
the
youngest
gentleman
,
dropping
her
society
,
began
to
take
Miss
Pecksniff
to
the
play
.
 
<EOS>
He
also
began
,
as
Mrs
Todgers
said
,
to
slip
home
"
in
his
dinner
-
times
,
"
and
to
get

"
the
office
"
at

;
and
twice
,
as
he
informed
Mrs
Todgers
himself
,

anonymous

,

cards
from
Furniture
Warehouses
---
clearly

act
of
that
ungentlemanly
ruffian
Jinkins
;
only

had
n't
evidence
enough

call

out

.
 
<EOS>
All

,

Mrs
Todgers
told
Miss
Pecksniff
,

as

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

Miss
Pecksniff
,
you
may

upon
it
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
that
he
is

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
goodness
me
,
why
do

he
then
?
"
cried
Cherry
.
   
<EOS>
"
Men
are
so

,

,
"

Mrs

.
 
<EOS>
"
They
baulk

.
 
<EOS>
I
saw
the
words
on
Todgers
's

for
months

and

,

'

.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss

submitted

Todgers
might

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

,

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

days
<EOS>
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Also

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
And

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
And

,

---

,

"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

he

to
cry
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
admitted
that
he
might
do
better
than
that
;
and
might
undoubtedly
profit
by
the

of
the
great

's

.
 
<EOS>
Still
,

,
he

,
or
,
not

mince

,
would

,
if
Miss
Pecksniff
took

,
and
plainly

him
that
it
must
be
done
.
   
<EOS>
Determining
to
regulate
her
conduct
by
this
opinion
,
the
young
lady
received
Mr
Moddle
,
on
the
earliest

occasion
,
with
an
air
of
constraint
;
and
gradually
leading
him
to
inquire
,
in
a
dejected

,
why
she
was
so
changed
,
confessed
to
him
that
she
felt
it
necessary
for
their
mutual
peace
and
happiness
to
take
a
decided
step
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
been
much
together
lately
,
she
observed
,
much
together
,
and
had
tasted
the
sweets
of
a
genuine
reciprocity
of
sentiment
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
could
forget
him
,
nor
could
she
ever
cease
to
think
of
him
with
feelings
of
the
liveliest
friendship
,
but
people
had
begun
to
talk
,
the
thing
had
been
observed
,
and
it
was
necessary
that
they
should
be
nothing
more
to
each
other
,
than
any
gentleman
and
lady
in
society
usually
are
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
glad
she
had
had
the
resolution
to
say
thus
much
before
her
feelings
had
been
tried
too
far
;
they
had
been
greatly
tried
,
she
would
admit
;
but
though
she
was
weak
and
silly
,
she
would
soon
get
the
better
of
it
,
she
hoped
.
   
<EOS>
Moddle
,
who
had
by
this
time
become
in
the
last
degree
maudlin
,
and
wept
abundantly
,
inferred
from
the
foregoing
avowal
,
that
it
was
his
mission
to
communicate
to
others
the

had

;

,
he

had

to

,

.
<EOS>
Miss

controverting
this
opinion
as
sinful
<EOS>
,
Moddle
was
goaded
on
to

;
and
it
appearing
on
further

that
she

be
,
plighted
his
dismal

,
which
was
accepted
and

.
   
<EOS>
He
bore
his
good

with
the

.
 
<EOS>
Instead

being

,
he

than

;
and

:
   
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what

!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

to
the
office
this

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
trying

this
has
been
!
 
<EOS>
Good
Gracious
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
33
.
<EOS>
Further
proceedings
in
Eden
,
and
a

.
 
<EOS>
Martin
makes
a
discovery
of
some
importance
 
From
Mr
Moddle
to
Eden
is
an
easy
and
natural
transition
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Moddle
,
living
in
the
atmosphere
of
Miss
Pecksniff
's
love
,
dwelt
(
if

had
but

)

.
 
<EOS>
The
thriving
city
of
Eden
was
also
a
terrestrial
Paradise
,
upon
the
showing
of
its
proprietors
.
 
<EOS>
The
beautiful
Miss
Pecksniff
might
have
been
poetically
described
as
a
something
too
good
for
man
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
That
was
exactly

of
the
thriving
city
of
Eden
,
as
poetically
heightened
by
Zephaniah
Scadder
,
General
Choke
,
and
other
worthies
;
part

the

that

,
which
is
always

sky

,
and
never
,
no
never
,
never
,

.
   
<EOS>
When
Mark
Tapley
,
leaving
Martin
in

,
had

in

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,
"

,
and

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>
Now

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

-

.
 
<EOS>
I

-

<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
What

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.

ai

ai

"

<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

;

?
"

"
Why
,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
We

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,
"

"

.
"

But

"
Do

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
Before

,
Mark

;

.
   
<EOS>
They

Martin

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Mark
's

an

kind

,

ague
;
which

,

which

to
-

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Eden
for

!
"
   
<EOS>
They

;

Mark

,

.
 
<EOS>

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Hope

.
 
<EOS>
The

;
the
settlement
a

.
<EOS>
His
child
died
that

;
and
Mark
,
keeping

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
With

(
who

exacting
in

,
the

)
,
Mark

,

;
and

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
Not

,

,

,

,

,

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
"

Martin

,

,

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

as

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

,
"

,

the

,

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

?

<EOS>

<EOS>
Silent

cool
<EOS>
,
as
if
the
house
were
his
;
smoking
away
like

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chollop
was
,
of
course
,
one
of
the
most
remarkable
men
in
the
country
;
but
he
really
was
a
notorious
person
besides
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
usually
described
by
his
friends
,
in
the
South
and
West
,
as
"
a
splendid
sample
of
our
na
-
tive
raw
material
,
sir
,
"
and
was
much
esteemed
for
his
devotion
to
rational
Liberty
;
for
the
better
propagation
whereof
he
usually
carried
a
brace
of
revolving
pistols
in
his
coat

,
with
seven
barrels
a
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
He
also
carried
,
amongst
other

,
a
sword
-
stick
,
which
he
called
his
"
Tickler
.
"
and
a
great
knife
,
which
(
for
he
was
a
man
of
a
pleasant
turn
of
humour
)
<EOS>
he
called
"
Ripper
,
"
in
allusion
to
its
usefulness
as
a
means
of
ventilating
the
stomach
of
any
adversary
in
a
close
contest
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
used
these
weapons
with
distinguished
effect
in
several
instances
,
all
duly
chronicled
in
the
newspapers
;
and
was
greatly
beloved
for
the
gallant
manner
in
which
he
had
"
jobbed
out
"
the
eye
of
one
gentleman
,
as
he
was
in
the
act
of
knocking
at
his
own
street
-
door
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chollop
was
a
man
of
a
roving
disposition
;
and
,
in
any
less
advanced
community
,
might
have
been
mistaken
for
a
violent
vagabond
.
<EOS>
But
his
fine
qualities
being
perfectly
understood
and
appreciated
in
those
regions
where
his
lot
was
cast
,
and
where
he
had
many
kindred
spirits
to
consort
with
,
he
may
be
regarded
as
having
been
born
under
a
fortunate
star
,
which
is
not
always
the
case
with
a
man
so
much
before
the
age
in
which
he
lives
.
 
<EOS>
Preferring
,
with
a
view
to
the
gratification
of
his
tickling
and
ripping
fancies
,
to
dwell
upon
the
outskirts
of
society
,
and
in
the
more
remote
towns
and
cities
,
he
was
in
the
habit
of
emigrating
from
place
to
place
,
and
establishing
in
each
some
business
---
usually
a
newspaper
---
which
he
presently
sold
;
for
the
most
part
closing
the
bargain
by
challenging
,

,
pistolling
,
or
gouging
the
new
editor
,
before
he
had
quite
taken

of

property
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
Eden
on
a
speculation
of
this
kind
,
but
had
abandoned
it
,
and
was
about
to
leave
.
 
<EOS>
He
always
introduced
himself
to
strangers
as
a
worshipper
of
Freedom
;
was
the
consistent
advocate
of
Lynch
law
,
and
slavery
;
and
invariably
recommended
,
both
in
print
and

,
the
"
tarring

feathering
"
of
any

person

.
 
<EOS>
He
called
this
"
planting
the
standard
of
civilization
in
the
wilder

of
My
country
.
"
   
<EOS>
There

little

that
Chollop
would
have
planted
this
standard
in
Eden
at
Mark
's

,
in

for
his
plainness

(
for

Freedom

dumb
,
save

)
,

,

.
 
<EOS>

one

-

,

.

"

ai

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Europian

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
Not

"
   
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
How

?
"
   
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Co.
<EOS>
And
me
,

,
"

,
"
are

piece
.
<EOS>
He

slicked
up
pretty

to

between

Old

the
New
,
I

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
So

had
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

I

,

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

!
 
Not

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,
of
Scadder

?
"

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
Scadder

,

?
 
<EOS>
He

?
 
<EOS>
He

a
man
as
will
come
up'ards
,
<EOS>
right

,

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr

the
other

.
   
<EOS>
"
He
should
have
his
right

very
high
up
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
As

as

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chollop
was
so

at

of
his

having
been
too
much
for

Britisher
,
and

's
resenting

,
that
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

of

was
in
the
other
---
the

-

---

,

had
draw'd
<EOS>

,

-

.
"
   
<EOS>
After

,
Mr
Hannibal
Chollop
sat

,

;

for

to

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
At

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

a
-
going

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mark

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
Afore
I
go
,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
You

darnation
"
cute
,

.
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca

-

"

"

<EOS>
"
We

"

,

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
,

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>
I

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

A

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
After

;
with
Ripper
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Come

,

,
"

,
"
he
's
gone
.
<EOS>
What
's
this
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
softly
;

his

's

,
and
taking

hot

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
come
of

?
 
<EOS>
He
's
wandering
in
his
mind
to
-
night
,
and
do
n't
know
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
indeed
was
dangerously
ill
;
very
near
his
death
.
 
<EOS>
He
lay
in
that
state
many
days
,
during
which
time
Mark
's
poor
friends
,
regardless
of
themselves
,
attended
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
,
fatigued
in
mind
and
body
;
working
all
the
day
and
sitting
up
at
night
;
worn
with
hard
living
and
the
unaccustomed
toil
of
his
new
life
;
surrounded
by
dismal
and
discouraging
circumstances
of
every
kind
;
never
complained
or
yielded
in
the
least
degree
.
 
<EOS>
If
ever
he
had
thought
Martin
selfish
or
inconsiderate
,
or
had
deemed
him
energetic
only
by
fits
and
starts
,
and
then
too
passive
for
their
desperate
fortunes
,
he
now
forgot
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
remembered
nothing
but
the
better
qualities
of
his
fellow
-
wanderer
,
and
was
devoted
to
him
,
heart
and
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Many
weeks
elapsed
before
Martin
was
strong
enough
to
move
about
with
the
help
of
a
stick
and
Mark
's

;
and
even
then
his
recovery
,
for
want
of
wholesome
air
and
proper

,
was
very
slow
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
yet
in
a
feeble
and
weak
condition
,
when
the
misfourtune
he
had
so
much
dreaded
fell
upon
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
was
taken
ill
.
   
<EOS>
Mark
fought
against
it
;
but
the
malady
fought
harder
,
and
his
efforts
were
in
vain
.
   
<EOS>
"
Floored
for
the
present
,
sir
,
"
he
said
one
morning
,
sinking
back
upon
his
bed
;
"
but
jolly
!
"
   
<EOS>
Floored
indeed
,
and
by
a
heavy
blow
!
 
<EOS>
As
any
one
<EOS>
but
Martin
might
have
known
beforehand
.
   
<EOS>
If
Mark
's
friends
had
been
kind
to
Martin
<EOS>
(
and
they
had
been
very
)
,
they
were
twenty
times
kinder
to
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
it
was
Martin
's
turn
to
work
,
and
sit
beside
the
bed
and
watch
,
and
listen
through
the
long
,
long
nights
,
to
every

in
the

;
and
hear

Mr
Tapley
,
in
his

,
playing

in
the
Dragon
,

to
Mrs

,
getting

-

on

Screw
,

old
Tom
Pinch
on
English

,
and
burning

of

in
Eden
,
all
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
But
whenever
Martin
gave
him
drink
or
medicine
,
or
tended
him
in
any
way
,
or
came
into
the
house

from
some

without
,
the
patient
Mr
Tapley
brightened
up
and
cried
:
"
I
'm
jolly
,
sir
;
"
I
'm
jolly
!
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
when
Martin
began
to
think
of
this
,
and
to
look
at
Mark
as
he
lay
there
;
never
reproaching

by
so
much

;
never

;
always

;
he
began
to
think
,
how
was
it
that
this
man
who
had
had
so
few

,
was
so
much
better
than
he
who
had
had
so
many
?
 
<EOS>
And
attendance
upon
a
sick
bed
,
but
especially
the
sick
bed
of
one
whom
we
have
been
accustomed
to
see
in
full
activity
and

,
<EOS>
being
a
great
breeder
of
reflection
,
he
began
to
ask
himself
in
what
they
differed
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
assisted
in
coming
to
a
conclusion
on
this
head
by
the
frequent
presence
of
Mark
's
friend
,
their
fellow
-
passenger
across
the
ocean
,
which
suggested
to
him
that
in
regard
to
having
aided
her
,
for
example
,
they
had
differed
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Somehow
he
coupled
Tom
Pinch
with
this
train
of
reflection
;
and
thinking
that
Tom
would
be
very
likely
to
have
struck
up
the
same
sort
of

under
similar

,
began
to
think
in
what
respects
two
people
so
extremely
different
were
like
each
other
,
and
were
unlike
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
sight
there
was
nothing
very
distressing
in
these
meditations
,
but
they
did
undoubtedly
distress
him
for
all
that
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
's
nature
was
a
frank
and
generous
one
;
but
he
had
been
bred
up
in
his
grandfather
's
house
;
and
it
will
usually
be
found
that
the
meaner
domestic
vices
propagate
themselves
to
be
their
own
antagonists
.
 
<EOS>
Selfishness
does
this
especially
;
so
do
suspicion
,
cunning
,
stealth
,
and
covetous
propensities
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
had
unconsciously
reasoned
as
a
child
,
"
My
guardian
takes
so
much
thought
of
himself
,
that
unless
I
do
the
like
by
MYself
,
I
shall
be
forgotten
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
he
had
grown
selfish
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
had
never
known
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
any
one
had
taxed
him
with
the
vice
,
he
would
have
indignantly
repelled
the
accusation
,
and
conceived
himself
unworthily
aspersed
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
would
have
known
it
,
but
that
being
newly
risen
from
a
bed
of
dangerous
sickness
,
to
watch
by
such
another
couch
,
he
felt
how
nearly
Self
had
dropped
into
the
grave
,
and
what
a
poor
dependent
,
miserable
thing
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
natural
for
him
to
reflect
---
he
had
months
to
do
it
in
---
upon
his
own
escape
,
and
Mark
's
extremity
.
 
<EOS>
This
led
him
to
consider
which
of
them
could
be
the
better
spared
,
and
why
?
 
<EOS>
Then
the
curtain
slowly
rose
a
very
little
way
;
and
Self
,
Self
,
Self
,
was
shown
below
.
   
<EOS>
He
asked
himself
,
besides
,
when
dreading
Mark
's
decease
(
as
all
men
do
and
must
,
at
such
a
time
)
,
whether
he
had
done
his
duty
by
him
,
and
had
deserved
and
made
a
good
response
to
his
fidelity
and
zeal
.
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
Short
as
their
companionship
had
been
,
he
felt
in
many
,
many
instances
,
that
there
was
blame
against
himself
;
and
still
inquiring
why
,
the
curtain
slowly
rose
a
little
more
,
and
Self
,
Self
,
Self
,
dilated
on
the
scene
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
long
before
he
fixed
the
knowledge
of
himself
so
firmly
in
his
mind
that
he
could
thoroughly
discern
the
truth
;
but
in
the
hideous
solitude
of
that
most
hideous
place
,
with
Hope
so
far
removed
,
Ambition
quenched
,
and
Death
beside
him
rattling
at
the
very
door
,
reflection
came
,
as
in
a
plague
-
beleaguered
town
;
and
so
he
felt
and
knew
the
failing
of
his
life
,
and
saw
distinctly
what
an
ugly
spot
it
was
.
   
<EOS>
Eden
was
a
hard
school
to
learn
so
hard
a
lesson
in
;
but
there
were
teachers
in
the
swamp
and
thicket
,
and
the
pestilential
air
,
who
had
a
searching
method
of
their
own
.
   
<EOS>
He
made
a
solemn
resolution
that
when
his
strength
returned
he
would
not
dispute
the
point
or
resist
the
conviction
,
but
would
look
upon
it
as
an
established
fact
,
that
selfishness
was
in
his
breast
,
and
must
be
rooted
out
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
doubtful
(
and
with
justice
)
of
his
own
character
,
that
he
determined
not
to
say
one
word
of
vain
regret
or
good
resolve
to
Mark
,
but
steadily
to
keep
his
purpose
before
his
own
eyes
solely
;
and
there
was
not
a
jot
of
pride
in
this
;
nothing
but
humility
and
steadfastness
;
the
best
armour
he
could
wear
.
 
<EOS>
So
low
had
Eden
brought
him
down
.
 
<EOS>
So
high
had
Eden
raised
him
up
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
long
and
lingering
illness
(
in
certain
forlorn
stages
of
which
,
when
too
far
gone
to
speak
,
he
had
feebly
written
"
jolly
!
"
<EOS>
on
a
slate
)
,
Mark
showed
some
symptoms
of
returning
health
.
 
<EOS>
They
came
and
went
,
and
flickered
for
a
time
;
but
he
began
to
mend
at
last
decidedly
;
and
after
that
continued
to
improve
from
day
to
day
.
   
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
was
well
enough
to
talk
without
fatigue
,
Martin
consulted
him
upon
a
project
he
had
in
his
mind
,
and
which
a
few
months
back
he
would
have
carried
into
execution
without
troubling
anybody
's
head
but
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ours
is
a
desperate
case
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Plainly
.
 
<EOS>
The
place
is
deserted
;
its
failure
must
have
become
known
;
and
selling
what
we
have
bought
to
any
one
,
for
anything
,
is
hopeless
,
even
if
it
were

.
 
<EOS>
We
left
home
on
a
mad
enterprise
,
and
have
failed
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
hope
left
us
,
the
only
one
end
for
which
we
have
now
to
try
,
is
to
quit
this
settlement
for
ever
,
and
get
back
to
England
.
 
<EOS>
Anyhow
!
<EOS>
by
any
means
!
<EOS>
only
to
get
back
there
,
Mark
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
,
sir
,
"
returned

Tapley
,
with
a
significant
stress
upon
the
words
;
"
only
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
upon

water
,
"

,
"
we
have
<EOS>
but
one
friend

can

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
of

you

ill
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
But

,
I

,
"
Martin

"

.
 
<EOS>
Shall

Bevan

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
a

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,
"
resumed

;
"
and

.
 
<EOS>
But

ca

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's

to

,
"

,

"
and
pigs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Shall

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
to

,
"

:
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

do

,

---
<EOS>
"
   
"
Mind
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

to

for

,
and
I

to

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
If

had
taken
your
opinion
sooner
,
Mark
,
we
never
should
have

here
,
I
am

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
was
very
much
surprised
at
this
admission
,
but
protested
,
with
great

,
that
they
would
have
been
there

;
and
that
he
had
set
his
heart
upon
coming
to
Eden
,
from
the
first
word
he
had
ever
heard
of

.
   
<EOS>
Martin
then
read
him
a
letter
to
Mr
Bevan
,
which
he
had
already
prepared
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
frankly
and
ingenuously
written
,
and
described
their
situation
without
the
least
concealment
;
plainly
stated
the
miseries
they
had
undergone
;
and
preferred
their
request
in
modest

.
 
<EOS>
Mark
highly
commended
it
;
and
they
determined
to
dispatch
it
by
the
next
steamboat
going
the
right
way
,
that
might
call
to
take
in
wood
at
Eden
---
where
there
was
plenty
of
wood
to
spare
.
 
<EOS>
Not
knowing
how
to
address
Mr
Bevan
at
his
own
place
of
abode
,
Martin
superscribed
it
to
the
care
of
the
memorable
Mr
Norris
of
New
York
,
and
wrote
upon
the
cover
an
entreaty
that
it
might
be
forwarded
without
delay
.
   
<EOS>
More
than
a
week
elapsed
before
a
boat
appeared
;
but
at
length
they
were
awakened
very
early
one
morning
by
the
high
-
pressure
snorting
of
the
"
Esau
Slodge
;
"
named
after
one
of
the
most

men
in
the
country
,
who
had
been
very
eminent
somewhere
.
 
<EOS>
Hurrying
down
to
the
landing
-
place
,
they
got
it
safe
on
board
;
and
waiting
anxiously
to
see
the
boat
depart
,
stopped
up
the
gangway
;
an
instance
of
neglect
which
caused
the
"
Capting
"
of
the
Esau
Slodge
to
"
wish
he
might
be
sifted
fine
as
flour
,
and
whittled
small

chips
;
that
if
they
did
n't
come
off
<EOS>
that
there
fixing
right
smart
too
,
he
'd
spill
'em
in
the
drink
;
"
whereby
the
Capting
metaphorically
said
he
'd
throw
them
in
the
river
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
not
likely
to
receive
an
answer
for
eight
or

weeks
at
the

.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
they
devoted
such
strength
as
they
had
to
the
attempted

of
their

;
to
clearing
some

it
,
and
preparing

for

.
 
<EOS>
Monstrously
defective
<EOS>
as
their

was
,
still
it
was
better
than
their
neighbours
'
;
for
Mark
had
some

of
such

,
and
Martin
learned
of
him
;
whereas
the
other
settlers
who
remained
upon
the
putrid

(
a
mere
handful
,
and
those
withered
by

)
,
appeared
to
have
wandered
there
with
the
idea
that

was

natural

of
all

.
 
<EOS>
They
helped
each
other
after
their
own

in
these

,
and
in
all
others
;
but
they
worked
as
hopelessly
and

as
a
gang
of
convicts
in
a

.
   
<EOS>
Often
at
night
when
Mark
and
Martin

alone
,
and
lying

to

,
they
spoke
of
home
,
familiar
places
,
houses
,
roads
,
and
people
whom
they
knew
;
sometimes
in
the
lively
hope
of
seeing

again
,
and
sometimes
with
a

,
as

were

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a

great
amazement
to
Mark
Tapley
to
find
,
pervading
all

,
a
singular

in
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

what
to
make
of

,
"
he
thought
one

,
"
he
ai

what
I

.
 
<EOS>
He
do

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
Asleep
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

Mr

gets

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Weak

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Plays

,

.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

He

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
Mark
.
"
   
<EOS>
He

his

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>

it

she

.
 
<EOS>
She

;

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Upon

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

,
"

,
"

ARE

.
 
<EOS>
That

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Which

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
She

;

;

<EOS>
(
Heaven

!
 
<EOS>
Proud
!
)

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
my

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

,
and

,

I
parted

,
when

of

have

!
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
late
,
"
said
Martin
,
checking

,
"

you
are

,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
You
only
talk
to
cheer
me
up
.
 
<EOS>
Good
night
!
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
,
Mark
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
'm
reg'larly
defrauded
,
"
thought
Mr
Tapley
,
turning
round
with
a
happy
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
swindle
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
entered
for
this
sort
of
service
.
 
<EOS>
There
'll
be
no
credit
in
being
jolly
with
HIM
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
time
wore
on
,
and
other
steamboats
coming
from
the
point
on
which
their
hopes
were
fixed
,
arrived
to
take
in
wood
;
but
still
no
answer
to
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
Rain
,
heat
,
foul
slime
,
and
noxious
vapour
,
with
all
the
ills
and
filthy
things
they
bred
,
prevailed
.
 
<EOS>
The
earth
,
the
air
,
the
vegetation
,
and
the
water
that
they
drank
,
all
teemed
with
deadly
properties
.
 
<EOS>
Their
fellow
-
passenger
had
lost
two
children
long
before
;
and
buried
now
her
last
.
 
<EOS>
Such
things
are
much
too
common
to
be
widely
known
or
cared
for
.
 
<EOS>
Smart
citizens
grow
rich
,
and
friendless
victims
smart
and
die
,
and
are
forgotten
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
all
.
   
<EOS>
At
last
a
boat
came
panting
up
the
ugly
river
,
and
stopped
at
Eden
.
<EOS>
Mark
was
waiting
at
the
wood
hut
when
it
came
,
and
had
a
letter
handed
to
him
from
on
board
.
 
<EOS>
He
bore
it
off
to
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
They
looked
at
one
another
,
trembling
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
feels
heavy
,
"
faltered
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
And
opening
it
a
little
roll
of
dollar
-
notes
fell
out
upon
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
What
either
of
them
said
,
or
did
,
or
felt
,
at
first
,
neither
of
them
knew
.
 
<EOS>
All
Mark
could
ever
tell
was
,
that
he
was
at
the
river
's
bank
again
out
of
breath
,
before
the
boat
had
gone
,
inquiring
when
it
would
retrace
its
track
and
put
in
there
.
   
<EOS>
The
answer
was
,
in
ten
or
twelve
days
;
notwithstanding
which
they
began
to
get
their
goods
together
and
to
tie
them
up
that
very
night
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
stage
of
excitement
was
passed
,
each
of
them
believed
(
they
found
this
out
,
in
talking
of
it
afterwards
)
that
he
would
surely
die
before
the
boat
returned
.
   
<EOS>
They
lived
,
however
,
and
it
came
,
after
the
lapse
of
three
long
crawling
weeks
.
 
<EOS>
At
sunrise
,
on
an
autumn
day
,
they
stood
upon
her
deck
.
   
<EOS>
"
Courage
!
 
<EOS>
We
shall
meet
again
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
waving
his
hand
to
two
thin
figures
on
the
bank
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
the
Old
World
!
"
   
"
Or
in
the
next
one
,
"
added
Mark
below
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
To
see
them
standing
side
by
side
,
so
quiet
,
is
a'most
the
worst
of
all
!
"
   
<EOS>
They
looked
at
one
another
as
the
vessel
moved
away
,
and
then
looked
backward
at
the
spot
from
which
it
hurried
fast
.
 
<EOS>
The
log
-
house
,
with
the
open
door
,
and
drooping
trees
about
it
;
the
stagnant
morning
mist
,
and
red
sun
<EOS>
,
dimly
seen
beyond
;
the
vapour
rising
up
from
land
and
river
;
the
quick
stream
making
the
loathsome
banks
it
washed
more
flat
and
dull
;
how
often
they
returned
in
dreams
!
 
<EOS>
How
often
it
was
happiness
to
wake
and
find
them
Shadows
that
had
vanished
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
34
.
<EOS>
In
which
the
travellers
move
homeward
,
and
encounter
some
distinguished
characters
upon
the
way
 
Among
the
passengers
on
board
the
steamboat
,
there
was
a
faint
gentleman
sitting
on
a
low
camp
-
stool
,
with
his
legs
on
a
high
barrel
of
flour
,
as
if
he
were
looking
at
the
prospect
with
his
ankles
,
who
attracted
their
attention
speedily
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
straight
black
hair
,
parted
up
the
middle
of
his
head
and
hanging
down
upon
his
coat
;
a
little
fringe
of
hair
upon
his
chin
;
wore
no
neckcloth
;
a
white
hat
;
a
suit
of
black
,
long
in
the
sleeves
and
short
in
the
legs
;
soiled
brown
stockings
and
laced
shoes
.
 
<EOS>
His
complexion
,
naturally
muddy
,
was
rendered
muddier
by
too
strict
an
economy
of
soap
and
water
;
and
the
same
observation
will
apply
to
the
washable
part
of
his
attire
,
which
he
might
have
changed
with
comfort
to
himself
and
gratification
to
his
friends
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
about
five
and
thirty
;
was
crushed
and
jammed
up
in
a
heap
,
under
the
shade
of
a
large
green
cotton
umbrella
;
and
ruminated
over
his
tobacco
-
plug
like
a
cow
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
not
singular
,
to
be
sure
,
in
these
respects
;
for
every
gentleman
on
board
appeared
to
have
had
a
difference
with
his
laundress
and
to
have
left
off
washing
himself
in
early
youth
.
<EOS>
Every
gentleman
,
too
,
was
perfectly
stopped
up
with
tight
plugging
,
and
was
dislocated
in
the
greater
part
of
his
joints
.
 
<EOS>
But
about
this
gentleman
there
was
a
peculiar
air
of
sagacity
and
wisdom
,
which
convinced
Martin
that
he
was
no
common
character
;
and
this
turned
out
to
be
the
case
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
sir
?
"
said
a
voice
in
Martin
's
ear
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
sir
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
tall
thin
gentleman
who
spoke
to
him
,
with
a
carpet
-
cap
on
,
and
a
long
loose
coat
of
green
baize
,
ornamented
about
the
pockets
with
black
velvet
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
air
from
Europe
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
air
fortunate
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
thought
so
too
;
but
he
soon
discovered
that
the
gentleman
and
he
attached
different
meanings
to
this
remark
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
air
fortunate
,
sir
,
in
having
an
opportunity
of
beholding
our
Elijah
Pogram
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
Elijahpogram
!
"
said
Martin
,
thinking
it
was
all
one
word
,
and
a
building
of
some
sort
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
tried
to
look
as
if
he
understood
him
,
but
he
could
n't
make
it
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
repeated
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
our
Elijah
Pogram
,
sir
,
is
,
at
this
minute
,
identically
settin
'
by
the
en
-
gine
biler
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
under
the
umbrella
put
his
right
forefinger
to
his
eyebrow
,
as
if
he
were
revolving
schemes
of
state
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
Elijah
Pogram
,
is
it
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
replied
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
Elijah
Pogram
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
astonished
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
the
least
idea
who
this
Elijah
Pogram
was
<EOS>
;
having
never
heard
the
name
in
all
his
life
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
the
biler
of
this
vessel
was
Toe
bust
,
sir
,
"
said
his
new
acquaintance
,
"
and
<EOS>
Toe
bust
now
,
this
would
be
a
festival
day
in
the
calendar
of
despotism
;
pretty
nigh
equallin
'
,
sir
,
in
its
effects
upon
the
human
race
,
our
Fourth
of
glorious
July
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
,
that
is
the
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
,
Member
of
Congress
;
one
of
the
master
-
minds
of
our
country
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
brow
,
sir
,
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
remarkable
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Our
own
immortal
Chiggle
,
sir
,
is
said
to
have
observed
,
when
he
made
the
celebrated
Pogram
statter
in
marble
,
which
rose
so
much
con
-
test
and
preju
-
dice
in
Europe
,
that
the
brow
was
more
than
mortal
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
before
the
Pogram
Defiance
,
and
was
,
therefore
,
a
pre
-
diction
,
cruel
smart
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
Pogram
Defiance
?
"
asked
Martin
,
thinking
,
perhaps
<EOS>
,
it
was
the
sign
of
a
public
-
house
.
   
<EOS>
"
An
o
-
ration
,
sir
,
"
returned
his
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
to
be
sure
,
"
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
thinking
of
!
 
<EOS>
It
defied
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
It
defied
the
world
,
sir
,
"
said
the
other
,
gravely
.
 
<EOS>
"
Defied
the
world
in
general
to
com
-
pete
with
our
country
upon
any
hook
;
and
devellop'd
<EOS>
our
internal
resources
for
making
war
upon
the
universal
airth
.
 
<EOS>
You
would
like
to
know
Elijah
Pogram
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pogram
,
"
said
the
stranger
---
<EOS>
Mr
Pogram
having
overheard
every
word
of
the
dialogue
---
"
this
is
a
gentleman
from
Europe
,
sir
;
from
England
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
But
gen'rous
ene
-
mies
may
meet
upon
the
neutral
sile
of
private
life
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
languid
Mr
Pogram
shook
hands
with
Martin
,
like
a
clock
-
work
figure
that
was
just
running
down
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
made
amends
by
chewing
like
one
that
was
just
wound
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pogram
,
"
said
the
introducer
,
"
is
a
public
servant
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
When
Congress
is
recessed
,
he
makes
himself
acquainted
with
those
free
United
States
,
of
which
he
is
the
gifted
son
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
occurred
to
Martin
that
if
the
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
had
stayed
at
home
,
and
sent
his
shoes
upon
a
tour
,
they
would
have
answered
the
same
purpose
;
for
they
were
the
only
part
of
him
in
a
situation
to
see
anything
.
   
<EOS>
In
course
of
time
,
however
,
Mr
Pogram
rose
;
and
having
ejected
certain
plugging
consequences
which
would
have
impeded
his
articulation
,
took
up
a
position
where
there
was
something
to
lean
against
,
and
began
to
talk
to
Martin
;
shading
himself
with
the
green
umbrella
all
the
time
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
began
with
the
words
,
"
How
do
you
like
---
?
"
 
<EOS>
Martin
took
him
up
and
said
:
   
"
<EOS>
The
country
,
I
presume
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
said
Elijah
Pogram
.
 
<EOS>
A
knot
of
passengers
gathered
round
to
hear
what
followed
;
and
Martin
heard
his
friend
say
,
as
he
whispered
to
another
friend
,
and
rubbed
his
hands
,
"
Pogram
will
smash
him
into
sky
-
blue
fits
,
I
know
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
said
Martin
,
after
a
moment
's
hesitation
,
"
I
have
learned
by
experience
,
that
you
take
an
unfair
advantage
of
a
stranger
,
when
you
ask
that
question
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mean
it
to
be
answered
,
except
in
one
way
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
do
n't
choose
to
answer
it
in
that
way
,
for
I
can
not
honestly
answer
it
in
that
way
.
 
<EOS>
And
therefore
,
I
would
rather
not
answer
it
at
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
Mr
Pogram
was
going
to
make
a
great
speech
in
the
next
session
about
foreign
relations
,
and
was
going
to
write
strong
articles
on
the
subject
;
and
as
he
greatly
favoured
the
free
and
independent
custom
(
a
very
harmless
and
agreeable
one
)
of
procuring
information
of
any
sort
in
any
kind
of
confidence
,
and
afterwards
perverting
it
publicly
in
any
manner
that
happened
to
suit
him
,
he
had
determined
to
get
at
Martin
's
opinions
somehow
or
other
.
 
<EOS>
For
if
he
could
have
got
nothing
out
of
him
,
he
would
have
had
to
invent
it
for
him
,
and
that
would
have
been
laborious
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
a
mental
note
of
his
answer
,
and
went
in
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
from
Eden
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
How
did
you
like
Eden
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
said
what
he
thought
of
that
part
of
the
country
,
in
pretty
strong
terms
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
,
"
said
Pogram
,
looking
round
upon
the
group
,
"
this
hatred
of
our
country
,
and
her
Institutions
!
 
<EOS>
This
national
antipathy
is
deeply
rooted
in
the
British
mind
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
,
sir
,
"
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
the
Eden
Land
Corporation
,
with
Mr
Scadder
at
its
head
,
and
all
the
misery
it
has
worked
,
at
its
door
,
an
Institution
of
America
?
 
<EOS>
A
part
of
any
form
of
government
that
ever
was
known
or
heard
of
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
con
-
sider
the
cause
of
this
to
be
,
"
said
Pogram
,
looking
round
again
and
taking
himself
up
where
Martin
had
interrupted
him
,
"
<EOS>
partly
jealousy
and
pre
-
judice
,
and
partly
the
nat'ral
unfitness
of
the
British
people
to
appreciate
the
ex
-
alted
Institutions
of
our
native
land
.
 
<EOS>
I
expect
,
sir
,
"
turning

Martin

,
"
that
a
gentleman
named
Chollop
happened
in
upon
you
during
your
lo
-
cation
in
the
