of
Eden
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
answered
Martin
;
"
but
my
friend
can
answer
this
better
than
I
can
,
for
I
was
very
ill
at
the
time
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
!
 
<EOS>
The
gentleman
is
speaking
of
Mr
Chollop
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
,
"
observed
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
splendid
example
of
our
na
-
tive
raw
material
,
sir
?
"
said
Pogram
,
interrogatively
.
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
sir
!
"
cried
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
The
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
glanced
at
his
friends
as
though
he
would
have
said
,
"
Observe
this
!
 
<EOS>
See
what
follows
!
"
<EOS>
and
they
rendered
tribute
to
the
Pogram
genius
by
a
gentle
murmur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
fellow
-
countryman
is
a
model
of
a
man
,
quite
fresh
from
Natur
's
mould
!
<EOS>
"
said
Pogram
,
with
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
true
-
born
child
of
this
free
hemisphere
!
 
<EOS>
Verdant
as
the
mountains
of
our
country
;
bright
and
flowing
as
our
mineral
Licks
;
unspiled
by
withering
conventionalities
as
air
our
broad
and
boundless
Perearers
!
 
<EOS>
Rough
he
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
So
air
our
Barrs
.
 
<EOS>
Wild
he
may
be
.
 
<EOS>
So
air
our
Buffalers
.
<EOS>
But
he
is
a
child
of
Natur
'
,
and
a
child
of
Freedom
;
and
his
boastful
answer
to
the
Despot
and
the
Tyrant
is
,
that
his
bright
home
is
in
the
Settin
Sun
.
"
   
<EOS>
Part
of
this
referred
to
Chollop
,
and
part
to
a
Western
postmaster
,
who
,
being
a
public
defaulter
not
very
long
before
(
a
character
not
at
all
uncommon
in
America
)
,
had
been
removed
from
office
;
and
on
whose
behalf
Mr
Pogram
(
he
voted
for
Pogram
)
had
thundered
the
last
sentence
from
his
seat
in
Congress
,
at
the
head
of
an
unpopular
President
.
 
<EOS>
It
told
brilliantly
;
for
the
bystanders
were
delighted
,
and
one
of
them
said
to
Martin
,
"
that
he
guessed
he
had
now
seen
something
of
the
eloquential
aspect
of
our
country
,
and
was
chawed
up
pritty
small
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pogram
waited
until
his
hearers
were
calm
again
,
before
he
said
to
Mark
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
seem
to
coincide
,
sir
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
I
did
n't
like
him
much
;
and
that
's
the
truth
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
he
was
a
bully
;
and
I
did
n't
admire
his
carryin
'
them
murderous
little
persuaders
,
and
being
so
ready
to
use
'
em
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
singler
!
"
said
Pogram
,
lifting
his
umbrella
high
enough
to
look
all
round
from
under
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
strange
!
 
<EOS>
You
observe
the
settled
opposition
to
our
Institutions
which
pervades
the
British
mind
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
an
extraordinary
people
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
Mr
Chollop
and
the
class
he
represents
,
an
Institution
here
?
 
<EOS>
Are
pistols
with
revolving
barrels
,
sword
-
sticks
,
bowie
-
knives
,
and
such
things
,
Institutions
on
which
you
pride
yourselves
?
 
<EOS>
Are
bloody
duels
,
brutal
combats
,
savage
assaults
,
shooting
down
and
stabbing
in
the
streets
,
your
Institutions
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
I
shall
hear
next
that
Dishonour
and
Fraud
are
among
the
Institutions
of
the
great
republic
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
moment
the
words
passed
his
lips
,
the
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
looked
round
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
morbid
hatred
of
our
Institutions
,
"
he
observed
,
"
is
quite
a
study
for
the
psychological
observer
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
alludin
'
to
Repudiation
now
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you
may
make
anything
an
Institution
if
you
like
,
"
said
Martin
,
laughing
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
confess
you
had
me
there
,
for
you
certainly
have
made
that
one
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
greater
part
of
these
things
are
one
Institution
with
us
,
and
we
call
it
by
the
generic
name
of
Old
Bailey
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
bell
being
rung
for
dinner
at
this
moment
,
everybody
ran
away
into
the
cabin
,
whither
the
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
fled
with
such
precipitation
that
he
forgot
his
umbrella
was
up
,
and
fixed
it
so
tightly
in
the
cabin
door
that
it
could
neither
be
let
down
nor
got
out
.
 
<EOS>
For
a
minute
or
so
this
accident
created
a
perfect
rebellion
among
the
hungry
passengers
behind
,
who
,
seeing
the
dishes
,
and
hearing
the
knives
and
forks
at
work
,
well
knew
what
would
happen
unless
they
got
there
instantly
,
and
were
nearly
mad
;
while
several
virtuous
citizens
at
the
table
were
in
deadly
peril
of
choking
themselves
in
their
unnatural
efforts
to
get
rid
of
all
the
meat
before
these
others
came
.
   
<EOS>
They
carried
the
umbrella
by
storm
,
however
,
and
rushed
in
at
the
breach
.
 
<EOS>
The
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
and
Martin
found
themselves
,
after
a
severe
struggle
,
side
by
side
,
as
they
might
have
come
together
in
the
pit
of
a
London
theatre
;
and
for
four
whole
minutes
afterwards
,
Pogram
was
snapping
up
great
blocks
of
everything
he
could
get
hold
of
,
like
a
raven
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
taken
this
unusually
protracted
dinner
,
he
began
to
talk
to
Martin
;
and
begged
him
not
to
have
the
least
delicacy
in
speaking
with
perfect
freedom
to
him
,
for
he
was
a
calm
philosopher
.
 
<EOS>
Which
Martin
was
extremely
glad
to
hear
;
for
he
had
begun
to
speculate
on
Elijah
being
a
disciple
of
that
other
school
of
republican
philosophy
,
whose
noble
sentiments
are
carved
with
knives
upon
a
pupil
's
body
,
and
written
,
not
with
pen
and
ink
,
but
tar
and
feathers
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
my
countrymen
who
are
present
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Elijah
Pogram
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
very
pleasant
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
a
very
pleasant
party
.
 
<EOS>
No
man
had
spoken
a
word
;
every
one
had
been
intent
,
as
usual
,
on
his
own
private
gorging
;
and
the
greater
part
of
the
company
were
decidedly
dirty
feeders
.
   
<EOS>
The
Honourable
Elijah
Pogram
looked
at
Martin
as
if
he
thought
"
You
do
n't
mean
that
,
I
know
!
"
<EOS>
and
he
was
soon
confirmed
in
this
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
Sitting
opposite
to
them
was
a
gentleman
in
a
high
state
of
tobacco
,
who
wore
quite
a
little
beard
,
composed
of
the
overflowing
of
that
weed
,
as
they
had
dried
about
his
mouth
and
chin
<EOS>
;
so
common
an
ornament
that
it
would
scarcely
have
attracted
Martin
's
observation
,
but
that
this
good
citizen
,
burning
to
assert
his
equality
against
all
comers
,
sucked
his
knife
for
some
moments
,
and
made
a
cut
with
it
at
the
butter
,
just
as
Martin
was
in
the
act
of
taking
some
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
juiciness
about
the
deed
that
might
have
sickened
a
scavenger
.
   
<EOS>
When
Elijah
Pogram
(
to
whom
this
was
an
every
-
day
incident
)
saw
that
Martin
put
the
plate
away
,
and
took
no
butter
,
he
was
quite
delighted
,
and
said
,
   
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
The
morbid
hatred
of
you
British
to
the
Institutions
of
our
country
is
as
-
TONishing
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
life
!
"
cried
Martin
,
in
his
turn
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
most
wonderful
community
that
ever
existed
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
deliberately
makes
a
hog
of
himself
,
and
THAT
'S
an
Institution
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
have
no
time
to
ac
-
quire
forms
,
sir
,
"
said
Elijah
Pogram
.
   
<EOS>
"
Acquire
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
not
a
question
of
acquiring
anything
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
question
of
losing
the
natural
politeness
of
a
savage
,
and
that
instinctive
good
breeding
which
admonishes
one
man
not
to
offend
and
disgust
another
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
that
man
over
the
way
,
for
instance
,
naturally
knows
better
,
but
considers
it
a
very
fine
and
independent
thing
to
be
a
brute
in
small

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
na
-
tive
of
our
country
,
and
is
nat'rally
bright
and
spry
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mr
Pogram
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
observe
what
this
comes
to
,
Mr
Pogram
,
"
pursued
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
mass
of
your
countrymen
begin
by
stubbornly
neglecting
little
social
observances
,
which
have
nothing
to
do
with
gentility
,
custom
,
usage
,
government
,
or
country
,
but
are
acts
of
common
,
decent
,
natural
,
human
politeness
.
 
<EOS>
You
abet
them
in
this
,
by
resenting
all
attacks
upon
their
social
offences
as
if
they
were
a
beautiful
national
feature
.
 
<EOS>
From
disregarding
small
obligations
they
come
in
regular
course
to
disregard
great
ones
;
and
so
refuse
to
pay
their
debts
.
<EOS>
What
they
may
do
,
or
what
they
may
refuse
to
do
next
,
I
do
n't
know
;
but
any
man
may
see
if
he
will
,
that
it
will
be
something
following
in
natural
succession
,
and
a
part
of
one
great
growth
,
which
is
rotten
at
the
root
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
mind
of
Mr
Pogram
was
too
philosophical
to
see
this
;
so
they
went
on
deck
again
,
<EOS>
where
,
resuming
his
former
post
,
he
chewed
until
he
was
in
a
lethargic
state
,
amounting
to
insensibility
.
   
<EOS>
After
a
weary
voyage
of
several
days
,
they
came
again
to
that
same
wharf
where
Mark
had
been
so
nearly
left
behind
,
on
the
night
of
starting
for
Eden
.
 
<EOS>
Captain
Kedgick
,
the
landlord
,
was
standing
there
,
and
was
greatly
surprised
to
see

coming
from
the
boat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
"
tarnal
!
"
cried
the
Captain
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
admire
at
this
,
I
do
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
can
stay
at
your
house
until
to
-
morrow
,
Captain
,
I

?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
reckon
you
can
stay
there
for
a
twelvemonth
if

,
"
retorted
Kedgick
coolly
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
our

wo
n't
best
like

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't

,
Captain
Kedgick
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
They
did
ex
-
pect
<EOS>
you

a
-

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
They
've

took
in
,

ca
n't

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
ought
to
have
received
'
em
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No

did

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"
returned

,
"

?
 
<EOS>
Was

?
 
<EOS>
Did

,

---

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
when
our

's
frills
is

,

're
starched

stiff
,
I

!
"
   
<EOS>
With

,

into

to

,
while
Martin

Elijah
Pogram
went
on
to
the
National
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
've

back

,
you

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't
the
thing
I
did

,
"
the
Captain

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
man
ai
n't
got

to

,
unless
he
meets
the
public
views
.
 
<EOS>
Our
fashionable
people
would
n't
have
attended
his
le
-
vee
,
if
they
had
know'd
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Nothing

Captain
,
who

in
taking
it
very
ill
that

not
both
died
in
Eden
.
 
<EOS>
The
boarders
at
the
National
felt
strongly
on
the
subject
too
;
but
it
happened
by
good

that

,

Elijah

,

HIM

le
-

.
   
<EOS>
As

house
was
over
before

boat
,

,

,

,

entered
to
announce

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
said
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pogram
!
"
cried

.
   
<EOS>
The

thus

.
 
<EOS>
"
Doctor
Ginery

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
He

jined

,

,

,

,
I
do

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Julius
Bib
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Julius
Washington
Merryweather
Bib
,
"
said

himself
TO
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Excuse

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Julius
Washington
Merryweather
Bib
,

;

.
 
<EOS>
Colonel

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pro

,

.
 
<EOS>
My

,

,

Oscar
Buffum
.
"
   
<EOS>
Each

;

Elijah
Pogram
with

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

being

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pogram
!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
said

,

,
"
you

so

,
Dr.
Ginery
Dunkle
,
as

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
As

nothing

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr

!
 
<EOS>
Sir
!
 
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

,
wish

,

,

---
"
   
"
Air
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Which
air
so
peculiarly
the
lot
,

,

our
great

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
!
 
<EOS>
Hear
him
!
<EOS>
Good
!
"

And

,

"

A

Vee
,

<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
,

!
 
<EOS>
Good
!

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your

My

My

.
 
<EOS>
At

;

'

,

,

---

"
Good
,

!
 
<EOS>
Hear

!
 
<EOS>
Hear

!
"

<EOS>
"
The

Pogram
will

jine

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
My

,

,
"
<EOS>
He
was

,

ac
-
Tive

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
"
The
Com
-

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

My

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

shook

with
him
,
and
everybody
else
,
once

;
and
when

came
back
again
at
five
minutes
before
eight
,
they
said
,
one

,
in

,
"
How
do

do
,
sir
?
"
and
shook
hands
with
Mr
Pogram
all
over

,
as
if
he
had
been
abroad
for
a
twelvemonth
in
the
meantime
,
and

met
,
now
,
at

funeral
.
   
<EOS>
But
by
this
time
Mr
Pogram
had
freshened
himself
up
,
and
had
composed
his
hair
and

after
the
Pogram
statue
,
so
that
any
one
with
half
an
eye
might
cry
out
,
"
There
he
is
!
<EOS>
as
he
delivered
the
Defiance
!
"
 
<EOS>
The
Committee
were
embellished
also
;
and
when
they
entered
the
ladies
'
ordinary
in
a
body
,
there
was
much
clapping
of
hands
from
ladies
and
gentlemen
,

by
cries
of
"
Pogram
!
Pogram
!
"
<EOS>
and
some

<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Which

to

<EOS>
"
We

<EOS>

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

the
Pogram

would
n't

.
   
<EOS>
The

of
the

.
 
<EOS>
Gentlemen

,

,

;

,

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

through

,
and
said

,
"
I
wish

'd

.
 
<EOS>
Why
do

?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,

to

!
"
 
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
But

;

,

<EOS>

,

some

;

.
 
<EOS>
Martin
,
who

,

!
"
   
"

,

.
 
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
For

,

<EOS>
Their

of

,
for
Mrs
Hominy
felt
her

,
and
knew

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
H
was
hard
upon
him
at

;
and

in

,
which
she

,
to

purpose
in

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
which
,

,

flouting

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

on

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

"
<EOS>
My
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
oh

(

<EOS>

The

.

,

,
<EOS>
a

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Howls

,

.
 
<EOS>
To

.

<EOS>

.

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
How

,

.
<EOS>
Suffice

,
that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

.
 
<EOS>
Tears

;

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

,

.
 
<EOS>
To

repaired
without
a
moment
's
delay
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
the
satisfaction
of
finding
him
within
;
and
of
being
received
by
their
good
friend
,
with
his
own
warmth
and
heartiness
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
truly
sorry
and
ashamed
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
to
have
begged
of
you
.
<EOS>
But
look
at
us
.
 
<EOS>
See
what
we
are
,
and
judge
to
what
we
are
reduced
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
far
from
claiming
to
have
done
you
any
service
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
I
reproach
myself
with
having
been
,
unwittingly
,
<EOS>
the
original
cause
of
your
misfortunes
.
 
<EOS>
I
no
more
supposed
you
would
go
to
Eden
on
such

as
you
received
;
or
,
indeed
,
that
you
would
do
anything
but

,
by
the
readiest

,
of
your
idea
that
fortunes
were
so
easily
made
here
;
than
I
thought
of
going
to
Eden
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
I
closed
with
the
thing
in
a
mad

sanguine

,
"
said
Martin
,
"
and
the
less
said
about
it
the
better
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
,
here
,
had
n't
a
voice
in
the
matter
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
but
he
had
n't
a
voice
in
any
other
matter
,
had
he
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Mr
Bevan
;
laughing
with
an
air
that
showed
his
understanding
of
Mark
and
Martin
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
a
very
powerful
one
,
I
am
afraid
,
"
said
Martin
with
a
blush
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
live
and
learn
,
Mr
Bevan
!
 
<EOS>
Nearly
die
and
learn
;
we
learn
the
quicker
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
their
friend
,
"
about
your
plans
.
 
<EOS>
You
mean
to
return
home
at
once
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
think
so
,
"
returned
Martin
hastily
,
for
he
turned
pale
at
the
thought
of
any
other
suggestion
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
your
opinion
too
,
I
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unquestionably
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
do
n't
know
why
you
ever
came
here
;
though
it
's
not
such
an
unusual
case
,
I
am
sorry
to

,
that
we
need

any
farther

that
.
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
know
that
the
ship
in
which
you
came
over
with
our
friend
General
Fladdock
,
is
in
port
,
of
course
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
And
is
advertised
to
sail
to
-
morrow
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
tempting
news
,
but
tantalising
too
;
for
Martin
knew
that
his
getting
any
employment
on
board
a
ship
of
that
class
was
hopeless
.
 
<EOS>
The
money
in
his
pocket
would
not
pay
one
-
fourth
of
the
sum
he
had
already

,
and
if
it
had
been
enough
for
their
passage
-
money
,
he
could
hardly

resolved
to
spend

.
 
<EOS>
He
explained
this
to
Mr
Bevan
,
and
stated
what
their
project
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
's
as
wild
as
Eden
every
bit
,
"
returned
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
take
your
passage
like

Christian
;
at
least
,
as
like

Christian
as
a
fore
-

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
If
Mark

,
and

you

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
You

will
look

in
the
meantime
(
we
wo
n't
call
at
the
Norris
's
unless
you

)
,
and
we

the

.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
had
nothing
to
express
but
gratitude
,
and
so
it
was
arranged
.
<EOS>
But
he
went
out
of
the
room
after
Mark
,
and
advised
him
to
take
their
passage
in
the
Screw
,
though
they
lay
upon

bare

;
which
Mr
Tapley
,
who
needed
no

on
the

to

.
   
<EOS>
When
he
and
Martin
met
again
,
and
were
alone
,
he
was
in
high
spirits
,
and
evidently
had
something
to
communicate
,
in
which
he
gloried
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
've
done
Mr
Bevan
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Done
Mr
Bevan
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
cook
of
the
Screw
went
and
got
married
yesterday
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
looked
at
him
for
farther

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
when
I
got
on
board
,
and
the
word
was
passed
that
it
was
me
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
the
mate
he
comes

asks

whether
I
'd

to
take
this
<EOS>
said
cook
's

upon
the
passage
home
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
you
're
used

,
"
he

;
"
you
were
always
a
-
cooking
for
everybody
on
your
passage
out
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
so
I
was
,
"
said
Mark
,
"
although
I
never
cooked
before
,
I
'll
take
my
oath
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
say
?
"
demanded

.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
I

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

's

,
"
says

,
"
why
,

rum
;
"
which

.
 
<EOS>
And
my
wages
,

,
"
said
Mark
in

,
"
pays

;
and
I
've

rolling

pin
in

berth
to
take
it
<EOS>
(
it

the

up

corner
)
;
and
there
we
are
,
Rule
Britannia
,
and
Britons

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
such

good

as
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
seizing

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
what
do
you
mean
by
"
doing
"
Mr
Bevan
,
Mark
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
do

see
?
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

,
but
we
do
n't

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
?
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
's

in
this
idea
was
not

to
Mark
's
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
all
done
as
he
proposed
.
 
<EOS>
They
passed
a
cheerful
evening
;
slept
at
the

;
left
the
letter
as

;
and
went

to
the
ship
betimes
next
morning
,
with
such
light
hearts
as
the
weight
of
their
past
miseries
engendered
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
a
hundred
thousand
times
<EOS>
good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Martin
to

friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
shall
I
remember
all

!
 
<EOS>
How
shall
I
ever

you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

rich

,
or

one
,
"
returned

friend
,
"
you
shall
try
to
make
your
Government
more
careful
of
its

when
they
roam

to

.
 
<EOS>
Tell
it
what
you
know
of
emigration
in
your
own
case
,
and
impress
upon
it
how
much
suffering
may
be
prevented
with
a
little

!
"
   
<EOS>
Cheerily
,
lads
,
cheerily
!
 
<EOS>
Anchor
weighed
.
 
<EOS>
Ship
in
full
sail
.
 
<EOS>
Her
sturdy
bowsprit
pointing
true
to
England
.
 
<EOS>
America
a
cloud
upon
the
sea
behind
them
!
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Cook
!
<EOS>
what
are
you
thinking
of
so
steadily
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
was
a
-
thinking
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
,
"
that
if
I
was
a
painter
and
was
called
upon
to
paint
the
American
Eagle
,
how
should
I
do
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Paint
it
as
like
an
Eagle
as
you
could
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
would
n't
do
for
me
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
want
to
draw
it
like
a
Bat
,
for
its
short
-
sightedness
;
like
a
Bantam
,
for
its
bragging
;
like
a
Magpie
,
for
its
honesty
;
like
a
Peacock
,
for
its
vanity
;
like
a
ostrich
,
for
its
putting
its
head
in
the
mud
,
and
thinking
nobody
sees
it
---
"
   
"
And
like
a
Phoenix
,
for
its
power
of
springing
from
the
ashes
of
its
faults
and
vices
,
and
soaring
up
anew
into
the
sky
!
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
hope
so
.
"
    
Chapter
35
.
<EOS>
Arriving
in
England
,
Martin
witnesses
a
ceremony
,
from
which
he
derives
the
cheering
information
that
he
has
not
been
forgotten
in
his
absence
 
<EOS>
It
was
mid
-
day
,
and
high
water
in
the
English
port
for
which
the
Screw
was
bound
,
<EOS>
when
,
borne
in
gallantly
upon
the
fullness
of
the
tide
,
she
let
go
her
anchor
in
the
river
.
   
<EOS>
Bright
as
the
scene
was
;
fresh
,
and
full
of
motion
;
airy
,
free
,
and
sparkling
;
it
was
nothing
to
the
life
and
exultation
in
the
breasts
of
the
two
travellers
,
at
sight
of
the
old
churches
,
roofs
,
and
darkened
chimney
stacks
of
Home
.
 
<EOS>
The
distant
roar
that
swelled
up
hoarsely
from
the
busy
streets
,
was
music
in
their
ears
;
the
lines
of
people
gazing
from
the
wharves
,
were
friends
held
dear
;
the
canopy
of
smoke
that
overhung
the
town
was
brighter
and
more
beautiful
to
them
than
if
the
richest
silks
of
Persia
had
been
waving
in
the
air
.
 
<EOS>
And
though
the
water
going
on
its
glistening
track
,
turned
,
ever
and
again
,
aside
to
dance
and
sparkle
round
great
ships
,
and
heave
them
up
;
and
leaped
from
off
the
blades
of
oars
,
a
shower
of
diving
diamonds
;
and
wantoned
with
the
idle
boats
,
and
swiftly
passed
,
in
many
a
sportive
chase
,
through
obdurate
old
iron
rings
,
set
deep
into
the
stone
-
work
of
the
quays
;
not
even
it
was
half
so
buoyant
,
and
so
restless
,
as
their
fluttering
hearts
,
when
yearning
to
set
foot
,
once
more
,
on
native
ground
.
   
<EOS>
A
year
had
passed
since
those
same
spires
and
roofs
had
faded
from
their
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
them
,
a
dozen
years
.
 
<EOS>
Some
trifling
changes
,
here
and
there
,
they
called
to
mind
;
and
wondered
that
they
were
so
few
and
slight
.
 
<EOS>
In
health
and
fortune
,
prospect
and
resource
,
they
came
back
poorer
men
than
they
had
gone
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
though
home
is
a
name
,
a
word
,
it
is
a
strong
one
;
stronger
than
magician
ever
spoke
,
or
spirit
answered
to
,
in
strongest
conjuration
.
   
<EOS>
Being
set
ashore
,
with
very
little
money
in
their
pockets
,
and
no
definite
plan
of
operation
in
their
heads
,
they
sought
out
a
cheap
tavern
,
where
they
regaled
upon
a
smoking
steak
,
and
certain
flowing
mugs
of
beer
,
as
only
men
just
landed
from
the
sea
can
revel
in
the
generous
dainties
of
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
had
feasted
,
as
two
grateful
-
tempered
giants
might
have
done
,
they
stirred
the
fire
,
drew
back
the
glowing
curtain
from
the
window
,
and
making
each
a
sofa
for
himself
,
by
union
of
the
great
unwieldy
chairs
,
gazed
blissfully
into
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
Even
the
street
was
made
a
fairy
street
,
by
being
half
hidden
in
an
atmosphere
of
steak
,
and
strong
,
stout
,
stand
-
up
English
beer
.
 
<EOS>
For
on
the
window
-
glass
hung
such
a
mist
,
that
Mr
Tapley
was
obliged
to
rise
and
wipe
it
with
his
handkerchief
,
before
the
passengers
appeared
like
common
mortals
.
 
<EOS>
And
even
then
,
a
spiral
little
cloud
went
curling
up
from
their
two
glasses
of
hot
grog
,
which
nearly
hid
them
from
each
other
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
unaccountable
little
rooms
which
are
never
seen
anywhere
but
in
a
tavern
,
and
are
supposed
to
have
got
into
taverns
by
reason
of
the
facilities
afforded
to
the
architect
for
getting
drunk
while
engaged
in
their
construction
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
more
corners
in
it
than
the
brain
of
an
obstinate
man
;
was
full
of
mad
closets
,
into
which
nothing
could
be
put
that
was
not
specially
invented
and
made
for
that
purpose
;
had
mysterious
shelvings
and
bulkheads
,
and
indications
of
staircases
in
the
ceiling
;
and
was
elaborately
provided
with
a
bell
that
rung
in
the
room
itself
,
about
two
feet
from
the
handle
,
and
had
no
connection
<EOS>
whatever
with
any
other
part
of
the
establishment
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
below
the
pavement
,
and
abutted
close
upon
it
;
so
that
passengers
grated
against
the
window
-
panes
with
their
buttons
,
and
scraped
it
with
their
baskets
;
and
fearful
boys
suddenly
coming
between
a
thoughtful
guest
and
the
light
,
derided
him
,
or
put
out
their
tongues
as
if
he
were
a
physician
;
or
made
white
knobs
on
the
ends
of
their
noses
by
flattening
the
same
against
the
glass
,
and
vanished
awfully
,
like
spectres
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
and
Mark
sat
looking
at
the
people
as
they
passed
,
debating
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
what
their
first
step
should
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
want
to
see
Miss
Mary
,
of
course
,
"
said
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
know
where
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
Not
having
had
the
heart
to
write
in
our
distress
---
you
yourself
thought
silence
most
advisable
---
and
consequently
,
never
having
heard
from
her
since
we
left
New
York
the
first
time
,
I
do
n't
know
where
she
is
,
my
good
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
opinion
is
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
,
"
that
what
we
've
got
to
do
is
to
travel
straight
to
the
Dragon
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
no
need
for
you
to
go
there
,
where
you
're
known
,
unless
you
like
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
stop
ten
mile
short
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
go
on
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Lupin
will
tell
me
all
the
news
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
will
give
me
every
information
that
we
want
;
and
right
glad
Mr
Pinch
will
be
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
proposal
is
:
To
set
off
walking
this
afternoon
.
 
<EOS>
To
stop
when
we
are
tired
.
 
<EOS>
To
get
a
lift
when
we
can
.
<EOS>
To
walk
when
we
ca
n't
.
 
<EOS>
To
do
it
at
once
,
and
do
it
cheap
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Unless
we
do
it
cheap
,
we
shall
have
some
difficulty
in
doing
it
at
all
,
"
said
Martin
,
pulling
out
the
bank
,
and
telling
it
over
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
greater
reason
for
losing
no
time
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mark
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Whereas
,
when
you
've
seen
the
young
lady
;
and
know
what
state
of
mind
<EOS>
the
old
gentleman
's
in
,
and
all
about
it
;
then
you
'll
know
what
to
do
next
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
raising
their
glasses
to
their
lips
,
when
their
hands
stopped
midway
,
and
their
gaze
was
arrested
by
a
figure
which
slowly
,
very
slowly
,
and
reflectively
,
passed
the
window
at
that
moment
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Placid
,
calm
,
but
proud
.
 
<EOS>
Honestly
proud
.
 
<EOS>
Dressed
with
peculiar
care
,
smiling
with
even
more
than
usual
blandness
,
pondering
on
the
beauties
of
his
art
with
a
mild
abstraction
from
all
sordid
thoughts
,
and
gently
travelling
across
the
disc
,
as
if
he
were
a
figure
in
a
magic
lantern
.
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pecksniff
passed
,
a
person
coming
in
the
opposite
direction
stopped
to
look
after
him
with
great
interest
and
respect
,
almost
with
veneration
;
and
the
landlord
bouncing
out
of
the
house
,
as
if
he
had
seen
him
too
,
joined
this
person
,
and
spoke
to
him
,
and
shook
his
head
gravely
,
and
looked
after
Mr
Pecksniff
likewise
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
and
Mark
sat
staring
at
each
other
,
as
if
they
could
not
believe
it
;
but
there
stood
the
landlord
,
and
the
other
man
still
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
the
indignation
with
which
this
glimpse
of
Mr
Pecksniff
had
inspired
him
,
Martin
could
not
help
laughing
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
could
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
must
inquire
into
this
!
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ask
the
landlord
in
,
Mark
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
retired
for
that
purpose
,
and
immediately
returned
with
their
large
-
headed
host
in
safe
convoy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
landlord
!
<EOS>
"
said
Martin
,
"
who
is
that
gentleman
who
passed
just
now
,
and
whom
you
were
looking
after
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
landlord
poked
the
fire
as
if
,
in
his
desire
to
make
the
most
of
his
answer
,
he
had
become
indifferent
even
to
the
price
of
coals
;
and
putting
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
said
,
after
inflating
himself
to
give
still
further
effect
to
his
reply
:
   
"
<EOS>
That
,
gentlemen
,
is
the
great
Mr
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
The
celebrated
architect
,
gentlemen
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
from
one
to
the
other
while
he
said
it
,
as
if
he
were
ready
to
assist
the
first
man
who
might
be
overcome
by
the
intelligence
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
great
Mr
Pecksniff
,
the
celebrated
architect
,
gentlemen
.
"
said
the
landlord
,
"
has
come
down
here
,
to
help
to
lay
the
first
stone
of
a
new
and
splendid
public
building
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
it
to
be
built
from
his
designs
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
great
Mr
Pecksniff
,
the
celebrated
architect
,
gentlemen
,
"
returned
the
landlord
,
who
seemed
to
have
an
unspeakable
delight
in
the
repetition
of
these
words
,
"
carried
off
the
First
Premium
,
and
will
erect
the
building
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
lays
the
stone
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Our
member
has
come
down
express
,
"
returned
the
landlord
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
scrubs
would
do
for
no
such
a
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
less
would
satisfy
our
Directors
than
our
member
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
who
is
returned
upon
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
interest
is
that
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
do
n't
you
know
!
"
returned
the
landlord
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
quite
clear
the
landlord
did
n't
.
 
<EOS>
They
always
told
him
at
election
time
,
that
it
was
the
Gentlemanly
side
,
and
he
immediately
put
on
his
top
-
boots
,
and
voted
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
does
the
ceremony
take
place
?
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
day
,
"
replied
the
landlord
.
 
<EOS>
Then
pulling
out
his
watch
,
he
added
,
impressively
,
"
almost
this
minute
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
hastily
inquired
whether
there
was
any
possibility
of
getting
in
to
witness
it
;
and
finding
that
there
would
be
no
objection
to
the
admittance
of
any
decent
person
,
unless
indeed
the
ground
were
full
,
hurried
off
with
Mark
,
as
hard
as
they
could
go
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
fortunate
enough
to
squeeze
themselves
into
a
famous
corner
on
the
ground
,
where
they
could
see
all
that
passed
,
without
much
dread
of
being
beheld
by
Mr
Pecksniff
in
return
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
a
minute
too
soon
,
for
as
they
were
in
the
act
of
congratulating
each
other
<EOS>
,
a
great
noise
was
heard
at
some
distance
,
and
everybody
looked
towards
the
gate
.
 
<EOS>
Several
ladies
prepared
their
pocket
handkerchiefs
for
waving
;
and
a
stray
teacher
belonging
to
the
charity
school
being
much
cheered
by
mistake
,
was
immensely
groaned
at
when
detected
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
has
Tom
Pinch
with
him
,
"
Martin
whispered
Mr
Tapley
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
rather
too
much
of
a
treat
for
him
,
would
n't
it
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
whispered
Mr
Tapley
in
return
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
no
time
to
discuss
the
probabilities
either
way
,
for
the
charity
school
,
in
clean
linen
,
came
filing
in
two
and
two
,
so
much
to
the
self
-
approval
of
all
the
people
present
who
did
n't
subscribe
to
it
,
that
many
of
them
shed
tears
.
 
<EOS>
A
band
of
music
followed
,
led
by
a
conscientious
drummer
who
never
left
off
.
 
<EOS>
Then
came
a
great
many
gentlemen
with
wands
in
their
hands
,
and
bows
on
their
breasts
,
whose
share
in
the
proceedings
did
not
appear
to
be
distinctly
laid
down
,
and
who
trod
upon
each
other
,
and
blocked
up
the
entry
for
a
considerable
period
.
 
<EOS>
These
were
followed
by
the
Mayor
and
Corporation
,
all
clustering
round
the
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
;
who
had
the
great
Mr
Pecksniff
,
the
celebrated
architect
on
his
right
hand
,
and
conversed
with
him
familiarly
as
they
came
along
.
 
<EOS>
Then
the
ladies
waved
their
handkerchiefs
,
and
the
gentlemen
their
hats
,
and
the
charity
children
shrieked
,
and
the
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
bowed
.
   
<EOS>
Silence
being
restored
,
the
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
rubbed
his
hands
,
and
wagged
his
head
,
and
looked
about
him
pleasantly
;
and
there
was
nothing
this
member
did
,
at
which
some
lady
or
other
did
not
burst
into
an
ecstatic
waving
of
her
pocket
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
looked
up
at
the
stone
,
they
said
how
graceful
!
<EOS>
when
he
peeped
into
the
hole
,
they
said
how
condescending
!
<EOS>
when
he
chatted
with
the
Mayor
,
they
said
how
easy
!
<EOS>
when
he
folded
his
arms
they
cried
with
one
accord
,
how
statesman
-
like
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was
observed
too
,
closely
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
talked
to
the
Mayor
,
they
said
,
Oh
,
really
,
what
a
courtly
man
he
was
!
 
<EOS>
When
he
laid
his
hand
upon
the
mason
's
shoulder
,
giving
him
directions
,
how
pleasant
his
demeanour
to
the
working
classes
;
just
the
sort
of
man
who
made
their
toil
a
pleasure
to
them
,
poor
dear
souls
!
   
<EOS>
But
now
a
silver
trowel
was
brought
;
and
when
the
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
,
tucking
up
his
coat
-
sleeve
,
did
a
little
sleight
of
hand
with
the
mortar
<EOS>
,
the
air
was
rent
,
so
loud
was
the
applause
.
 
<EOS>
The
workman
-
like
manner
in
which
he
did
it
was
amazing
.
<EOS>
No
one
could
conceive
where
such
a
gentlemanly
creature
could
have
picked
the
knowledge
up
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
had
made
a
kind
of
dirt
-
pie
under
the
direction
of
the
mason
,
they
brought
a
little
vase
containing
coins
,
the
which
the
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
jingled
,
as
if
he
were
going
to
conjure
.
 
<EOS>
Whereat
they
said
how
droll
,
how
cheerful
,
what
a
flow
of
spirits
!
 
<EOS>
This
put
into
its
place
,
an
ancient
scholar
read
the
inscription
,
which
was
in
Latin
;
not
in
English
;
that
would
never
do
.
 
<EOS>
It
gave
great
satisfaction
;
especially
every
time
there
was
a
good
long
substantive
in
the
third
declension
,
ablative
case
,
with
an
adjective
to
match
;
at
which
periods
the
assembly
became
very
tender
,
and
were
much
affected
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
stone
was
lowered
down
into
its
place
,
amidst
the
shouting
of
the
concourse
.
 
<EOS>
When
it
was
firmly
fixed
,
the
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
struck
upon
it
thrice
with
the
handle
of
the
trowel
,
as
if
inquiring
,
with
a
touch
of
humour
,
whether
anybody
was
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
then
unrolled
his
Plans
(
prodigious
plans
they
were
)
,
and
people
gathered
round
to
look
at
and
admire
them
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
,
who
had
been
fretting
himself
---
quite
unnecessarily
,
as
Mark
thought
---
during
the
whole
of
these
proceedings
,
could
no
longer
restrain
his
impatience
;
but
stepping
forward
among
several
others
,
looked
straight
over
the
shoulder
of
the
unconscious
Mr
Pecksniff
,
at
the
designs
and
plans
he
had
unrolled
.
 
<EOS>
He
returned
to
Mark
,
boiling
with
rage
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
what
's
the
matter
,
sir
?
"
cried
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Matter
!
 
<EOS>
This
is
MY
building
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
building
,
sir
!
"
said
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
grammar
-
school
.
 
<EOS>
I
invented
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
it
all
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
only
put
four
windows
in
,
the
villain
,
and
spoilt
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mark
could
hardly
believe
it
at
first
,
but
being
assured
that
it
was
really
so
,
actually
held
him
to
prevent
his
interference
foolishly
,
until
his
temporary
heat
was
past
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
the
member
addressed
the
company
on
the
gratifying
deed
which
he
had
just
performed
.
   
<EOS>
He
said
that
since
he
had
sat
in
Parliament
to
represent
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
of
that
town
;
and
he
might
add
,
the
Lady
Interest
,
he
hoped
,
besides
(
pocket
handkerchiefs
)
;
it
had
been
his
pleasant
duty
to
come
among
them
,
and
to
raise
his
voice
on
their
behalf
in
Another
Place
(
pocket
handkerchiefs
and
laughter
)
,
often
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
never
come
among
them
,
and
had
never
raised
his
voice
,
with
half
such
pure
,
such
deep
,
such
unalloyed
delight
,
as
now
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
present
occasion
,
"
he
said
,
"
will
ever
be
memorable
to
me
;
not
only
for
the
reasons
I
have
assigned
,
but
because
it
has
afforded
me
an
opportunity
of
becoming
personally
known
to
a
gentleman
---
"
   
<EOS>
Here
he
pointed
the
trowel
at
Mr
Pecksniff
,
who
was
greeted
with
vociferous
cheering
,
and
laid
his
hand
upon
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
a
gentleman
who
,
I
am
happy
to
believe
,
will
reap
both
distinction
and
profit
from
this
field
;
whose
fame
had
previously
penetrated
to
me
---
as
to
whose
ears
has
it
not
!
<EOS>
---
but
whose
intellectual
countenance
I
never
had
the
distinguished
honour
to
behold
until
this
day
,
and
whose
intellectual
conversation
<EOS>
I
had
never
before
the
improving
pleasure
to
enjoy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Everybody
seemed
very
glad
of
this
,
and
applauded
more
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
hope
my
Honourable
Friend
,
"
said
the
Gentlemanly
member
<EOS>
---
of
course
he
added
"
if
he
will
allow
me
to
call
him
so
,
"
and
of
course
Mr
Pecksniff
bowed
---
"
will
give
me
many
opportunities
of
cultivating
the
knowledge
of
him
;
and
that
I
may
have
the
extraordinary
gratification
of
reflecting
in
after
-
time
that
I
laid
on
this
day
two
first
stones
,
both
belonging
to
structures
which
shall
last
my
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
Great
cheering
again
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Martin
was
cursing
Mr
Pecksniff
up
hill
and
down
dale
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
friends
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
duty
is
to
build
,
not
speak
;
to
act
,
not
talk
;
to
deal
with
marble
,
stone
,
and
brick
;
not
language
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
much
affected
.
 
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
address
,
pumped
out
apparently
from
Mr
Pecksniff
's
very
heart
,
brought
the
enthusiasm
to
its
highest
pitch
.
 
<EOS>
The
pocket
handkerchiefs
were
waved
again
;
the
charity
children
were
admonished
to
grow
up
Pecksniffs
,
every
boy
among
them
;
the
Corporation
,
gentlemen
with
wands
,
member
for
the
Gentlemanly
Interest
,
all
cheered
for
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Three
cheers
for
Mr
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
Three
more
for
Mr
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
Three
more
for
Mr
Pecksniff
,
gentlemen
,
if
you
please
!
 
<EOS>
One
more
,
gentlemen
,
for
Mr
Pecksniff
,
and
let
it
be
a
good
one
to
finish
with
!
   
<EOS>
In
short
,
Mr
Pecksniff
was
supposed
to
have
done
a
great
work
and
was
very
kindly
,
courteously
,
and
generously
rewarded
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
procession
moved
away
,
and
Martin
and
Mark
were
left
almost
alone
upon
the
ground
,
his
merits
and
a
desire
to
acknowledge
them
formed
the
common
topic
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
only
second
to
the
Gentlemanly
member
.
   
<EOS>
"
Compare
the
fellow
's
situation
to
-
day
with
ours
!
"
said
Martin
bitterly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lord
bless
you
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mark
,
"
what
's
the
use
?
 
<EOS>
Some
architects
are
clever
at
making
foundations
,
and
some
architects
are
clever
at
building
on
'em
when
they
're
made
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
'll
all
come
right
in
the
end
,
sir
;
it
'll
all
come
right
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
in
the
meantime
---
"
began
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
meantime
,
as
you
say
,
sir
,
we
have
a
deal
to
do
,
and
far
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
So
sharp
's
the
word
,
and
Jolly
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
best
master
in
the
world
,
Mark
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
and
I
will
not
be
a
bad
scholar
if
I
can
help
it
<EOS>
,
I
am
resolved
!
 
<EOS>
So
come
!
<EOS>
Best
foot
foremost
,
old
fellow
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
36
.
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
departs
to
seek
his
fortune
.
 
<EOS>
What
he
finds
at
starting
 
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
What
a
different
town
Salisbury
was
in
Tom
Pinch
's
eyes
to
be
sure
,
when
the
substantial
Pecksniff
of
his
heart
melted
away
into
an
idle
dream
!
 
<EOS>
He
possessed
the
same
faith
in
the
wonderful
shops
,
the
same
intensified
appreciation
of
the
mystery
and
wickedness
of
the
place
;
made
the
same
exalted
estimate
of
its
wealth
,
population
,
and
resources
;
and
yet
it
was
not
the
old
city
nor
anything
like
it
.
<EOS>
He
walked
into
the
market
while
they
were
getting
breakfast
ready
for
him
at
the
Inn
;
and
though
it
was
the
same
market
as
of
old
,
crowded
by
the
same
buyers
and
sellers
;
brisk
with
the
same
business
;
noisy
with
the
same
confusion
of
tongues
and
cluttering
of
fowls
in
coops
;
fair
with
the
same
display
of
rolls
of
butter
,
newly
made
,
set
forth
in
linen
cloths
of
dazzling
whiteness
;
green
with
the
same
fresh
show
of
dewy
vegetables
;
<EOS>
dainty
with
the
same
array
in
higglers
'
baskets
of
small
shaving
-
glasses
,
laces
,
braces
,
trouser
-
straps
,
and
hardware
;
savoury
with
the
same
unstinted
show
of
delicate
pigs
'
feet
,
and
pies
made
precious
by
the
pork
that
once
had
walked
upon
them
;
still
it
was
strangely
changed
to
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
in
the
centre
of
the
market
-
place
,
he
missed
a
statue
he
had
set
up
there
as
in
all
other
places
of
his
personal
resort
;
and
it
looked
cold
and
bare
without
that
ornament
.
   
<EOS>
The
change
lay
no
deeper
than
this
,
for
Tom
was
far
from
being
sage
enough
to
know
,
that
,
having
been
disappointed
in
one
man
,
it
would
have
been
a
strictly
rational
and
eminently
wise
proceeding
to
have
revenged
himself
upon
mankind
in
general
,
by
mistrusting
them
one
and
all
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
this
piece
of
justice
,
though
it
is
upheld
by
the
authority
of
divers
profound
poets
and
honourable
men
,
bears
a
nearer
resemblance
to
the
justice
of
that
good
Vizier
in
the
Thousand
-
and
-
one
Nights
,
who
issues
orders
for
the
destruction
of
all
the
Porters
in
Bagdad
because
one
of
that
unfortunate
fraternity
is
supposed
to
have
misconducted
himself
,
than
to
any
logical
,
not
to
say
Christian
,
system
of
conduct
,
known
to
the
world
in
later
times
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
had
so
long
been
used
to
steep
the
Pecksniff
of
his
fancy
in
his
tea
,
and
spread
him
out
upon
his
toast
,
and
take
him
as
a
relish
with
his
beer
,
that
he
made
but
a
poor
breakfast
on
the
first
morning
after
his
expulsion
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
much
improve
his
appetite
for
dinner
by
seriously
considering
his
own
affairs
,
and
taking
counsel
thereon
with
his
friend
the
organist
's
assistant
.
   
<EOS>
The
organist
's
assistant
gave
it
as
his
decided
opinion
that
whatever
Tom
did
,
he
must
go
to
London
;
for
there
was
no
place
like
it
.
 
<EOS>
Which
may
be
true
in
the
main
,
though
hardly
,
perhaps
,
in
itself
,
a
sufficient
reason
for
Tom
's
going
there
.
   
<EOS>
But
Tom
had
thought
of
London
before
,
and
had
coupled
with
it
thoughts
of
his
sister
,
and
of
his
old
friend
John
Westlock
,
whose
advice
he
naturally
felt
disposed
to
seek
in
this
important
crisis
of
his
fortunes
.
 
<EOS>
To
London
,
therefore
,
he
resolved
to
go
;
and
he
went
away
to
the
coach
-
office
at
once
,
to
secure
his
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
coach
being
already
full
,
he
was
obliged
to
postpone
his
departure
until
the
next
night
;
but
even
this
circumstance
had
its
bright
side
as
well
as
its
dark
one
,
for
though
it
threatened
to
reduce
his
poor
purse
with
unexpected
country
charges
,
it
afforded
him
an
opportunity
of
writing
to
Mrs
Lupin
and
appointing
his
box
to
be
brought
to
the
old
finger
-
post
at
the
old
time
;
which
would
enable
him
to
take
that
treasure
with
him
to
the
metropolis
,
and
save
the
expense
of
its
carriage
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
,
"
said
Tom
,
<EOS>
comforting
himself
,
"
it
's
very
nearly
as
broad
as
it
's
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
it
can
not
be
denied
that
,
when
he
had
made
up
his
mind
to
even
this
extent
,
he
felt
an
unaccustomed
sense
of
freedom
---
a
vague
and
indistinct
impression
of
holiday
-
making
---
which
was
very
luxurious
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
moments
of
depression
and
anxiety
,
and
they
were
,
with
good
reason
,
pretty
numerous
;
but
still
,
it
was
wonderfully
pleasant
to
reflect
that
he
was
his
own
master
,
and
could
plan
and
scheme
for
himself
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
startling
,
thrilling
,
vast
,
difficult
to
understand
;
it
was
a
stupendous
truth
,
teeming
with
responsibility
and
self
-
distrust
;
but
in
spite
of
all
his
cares
,
it
gave
a
curious
relish
to
the
viands
at
the
Inn
,
and
interposed
a
dreamy
haze
between
him
and
his
prospects
,
in
which
they
sometimes
showed
to
magical
advantage
.
   
<EOS>
In
this
unsettled
state
of
mind
,
Tom
went
once
more
to
bed
in
the
low
four
-
poster
,
to
the
same
immovable
surprise
of
the
effigies
of
the
former
landlord
and
the
fat
ox
;
and
in
this
condition
,
passed
the
whole
of
the
succeeding
day
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
coach
came
round
at
last
with
"
London
"
blazoned
in
letters
of
gold
upon
the
boot
,
it
gave
Tom
such
a
turn
,
that
he
was
half
disposed
to
run
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
did
n't
do
it
;
for
he
took
his
seat
upon
the
box
instead
,
and
looking
down
upon
the
four
greys
,
felt
as
if
he
were
another
grey
himself
,
or
,
at
all
events
,
a
part
of
the
turn
-
out
;
and
was
quite
confused
by
the
novelty
and
splendour
of
his
situation
.
   
<EOS>
And
really
it
might
have
confused
a
less
modest
man
than
Tom
to
find
himself
sitting
next
that
coachman
;
for
of
all
the
swells
that
ever
flourished
a
whip
professionally
,
he
might
have
been
elected
emperor
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
handle
his
gloves
like
another
man
,
but
put
them
on
---
even
when
he
was
standing
on
the
pavement
,
quite
detached
from
the
coach
---
as
if
the
four
greys
were
,
somehow
or
other
,
at
the
ends
of
the
fingers
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
same
with
his
hat
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
things
with
his
hat
,
which
nothing
but
an
unlimited
knowledge
of
horses
and
the
wildest
freedom
of
the
road
,
could
ever
have
made
him
perfect
in
.
<EOS>
Valuable
little
parcels
were
brought
to
him
with
particular
instructions
,
and
he
pitched
them
into
this
hat
,
and
stuck
it
on
again
;
as
if
the
laws
of
gravity
did
not
admit
of
such
an
event
as
its
being
knocked
off
or
blown
off
,
and
nothing
like
an
accident
could
befall
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
guard
,
too
!
 
<EOS>
Seventy
breezy
miles
a
day
were
written
in
his
very
whiskers
.
 
<EOS>
His
manners
were
a
canter
;
<EOS>
his
conversation
a
round
trot
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
fast
coach
upon
a
down
-
hill
turnpike
road
;
he
was
all
pace
.
 
<EOS>
A
waggon
could
n't
have
moved
slowly
,
with
that
guard
and
his
key
-
bugle
on
the
top
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
These
were
all
foreshadowings
of
London
,
<EOS>
Tom
thought
,
as
he
sat
upon
the
box
,
and
looked
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
Such
a
coachman
,
and
such
a
guard
,
never
could
have
existed
between
Salisbury
and
any
other
place
.
 
<EOS>
The
coach
was
none
of
your
steady
-
going
,
yokel
coaches
,
but
a
swaggering
,
rakish
,
dissipated
London
coach
;
up
all
night
,
and
lying
by
all
day
,
and
leading
a
devil
of
a
life
.
 
<EOS>
It
cared
no
more
for
Salisbury
than
if
it
had
been
a
hamlet
.
 
<EOS>
It
rattled
noisily
through
the
best
streets
,
defied
the
Cathedral
,
took
the
worst
corners
sharpest
,
went
cutting
in
everywhere
,
making
everything
get
out
of
its
way
;
and
spun
along
the
open
country
-
road
,
blowing
a
lively
defiance
out
of
its
key
-
bugle
,
as
its
last
glad
parting
legacy
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
charming
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Mild
and
bright
.
 
<EOS>
And
even
with
the
weight
upon
his
mind
which
arose
out
of
the
immensity
and
uncertainty
of
London
,
Tom
could
not
resist
the
captivating
sense
of
rapid
motion
through
the
pleasant
air
.
 
<EOS>
The
four
greys
skimmed
along
,
as
if
they
liked
it
quite
as
well
as
Tom
did
;
the
bugle
was
in
as
high
spirits
as
the
greys
;
the
coachman
chimed
in
sometimes
with
his
voice
;
the
wheels
hummed
cheerfully
in
unison
;
the
brass
work
on
the
harness
was
an
orchestra
of
little
bells
;
and
thus
,
as
they
went
clinking
,
jingling
,
rattling
smoothly
on
,
the
whole
concern
,
from
the
buckles
of
the
leaders
'
coupling
-
reins
to
the
handle
of
the
hind
boot
,
was
one
great
instrument
of
music
.
   
<EOS>
Yoho
,
past
hedges
,
gates
,
and
trees
;
past
cottages
and
barns
,
and
people
going
home
from
work
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
,
past
donkey
-
chaises
,
drawn
aside
into
the
ditch
,
and
empty
carts
with
rampant
horses
,
whipped
up
at
a
bound
upon
the
little
watercourse
,
and
held
by
struggling
carters
close
to
the
five
-
barred
gate
,
until
the
coach
had
passed
the
narrow
turning
in
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
,
by
churches
dropped
down
by
themselves
in
quiet
nooks
,
with
rustic
burial
-
grounds
about
them
,
where
the
graves
are
green
,
and
daisies
sleep
---
for
it
is
evening
---
on
the
bosoms
of
the
dead
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
,
past
streams
,
in
which
the
cattle
cool
their
feet
,
and
where
the
rushes
grow
;
past
paddock
-
fences
,
farms
,
and
rick
-
yards
;
past
last
year
's
stacks
,
cut
,
slice
by
slice
,
away
,
and
showing
,
in
the
waning
light
,
like
ruined
gables
,
old
and
brown
.
<EOS>
Yoho
,
down
the
pebbly
dip
,
and
through
the
merry
water
-
splash
and
up
at
a
canter
to
the
level
road
again
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
   
<EOS>
Was
the
box
there
,
when
they
came
up
to
the
old
finger
-
post
?
 
<EOS>
The
box
!
 
<EOS>
Was
Mrs
Lupin
herself
?
 
<EOS>
Had
she
turned
out
magnificently
as
a
hostess
should
,
in
her
own
chaise
-
cart
,
and
was
she
sitting
in
a
mahogany
chair
,
driving
her
own
horse
Dragon
(
who
ought
to
have
been
called
Dumpling
)
,
and
looking
lovely
?
 
<EOS>
Did
the
stage
-
coach
pull
up
beside
her
,
shaving
her
very
wheel
,
and
even
while
the
guard
helped
her
man
up
with
the
trunk
,
did
he
send
the
glad
echoes
of
his
bugle
careering
down
the
chimneys
of
the
distant
Pecksniff
,
as
if
the
coach
expressed
its
exultation
in
the
rescue
of
Tom
Pinch
?
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
kind
indeed
!
"
said
Tom
,
bending
down
to
shake
hands
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
mean
to
give
you
this
trouble
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Trouble
,
Mr
Pinch
!
"
cried
the
hostess
of
the
Dragon
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
pleasure
to
you
,
I
know
,
"
said
Tom
,
squeezing
her
hand
heartily
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
there
any
news
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
hostess
shook
her
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
you
saw
me
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
and
that
I
was
very
bold
and
cheerful
,
and
not
a
bit
down
-
hearted
;
and
that
I
entreated
her
to
be
the
same
,
for
all
is
certain
to
come
right
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
write
when
you
get
settled
,
Mr
Pinch
?
"
said
Mrs
Lupin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
When
I
get
settled
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
with
an
involuntary
opening
of
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
'll
write
when
I
get
settled
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
had
better
write
before
,
because
I
may
find
that
it
takes
a
little
time
to
settle
myself
;
not
having
too
much
money
,
and
having
only
one
friend
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
give
your
love
to
the
friend
,
by
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
always
great
with
Mr
Westlock
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs
Lupin
,
hastily
producing
a
basket
with
a
long
bottle
sticking
out
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Take
this
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
want
me
to
carry
it
to
London
for
you
?
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
already
turning
the
chaise
-
cart
round
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
said
Mrs
Lupin
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
a
little
something
for
refreshment
on
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
Sit
fast
,
Jack
.
 
<EOS>
Drive
on
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
All
right
!
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
a
quarter
of
a
mile
off
,
before
Tom
collected
himself
;
and
then
he
was
waving
his
hand
lustily
;
and
so
was
she
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
the
last
of
the
old
finger
-
post
,
"
thought
Tom
,
straining
his
eyes
,
"
where
I
have
so
often
stood
to
see
this
very
coach
go
by
,
and
where
I
have
parted
with
so
many
companions
!
 
<EOS>
I
used
to
compare
this
coach
to
some
great
monster
that
appeared
at
certain
times
to
bear
my
friends
away
into
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
it
's
bearing
me
away
,
to
seek
my
fortune
<EOS>
,
Heaven
knows
where
and
how
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
made
Tom
melancholy
to
picture
himself
walking
up
the
lane
and
back
to
Pecksniff
's
as
of
old
;
and
being
melancholy
,
he
looked
downwards
at
the
basket
on
his
knee
,
which
he
had
for
the
moment
forgotten
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
the
kindest
and
most
considerate
creature
in
the
world
,
"
thought
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
I
KNOW
that
she
particularly
told
that
man
of
hers
not
to
look
at
me
,
on
purpose
to
prevent
my
throwing
him
a
shilling
!
 
<EOS>
I
had
it
ready
for
him
all
the
time
,
and
he
never
once
looked
towards
me
;
whereas
that
man
naturally
,
(
for
I
know
him
very
well
,
)
would
have
done
nothing
but
grin
and
stare
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
the
kindness
of
people
perfectly
melts
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
he
caught
the
coachman
's
eye
.
 
<EOS>
The
coachman
winked
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Remarkable
fine
woman
for
her
time
of
life
,
"
said
the
coachman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
quite
agree
with
you
,
"
returned
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
she
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Finer
than
many
a
young
'
un
,
I
mean
to
say
,
"
observed
the
coachman
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
"
   
"
Than
many
a
young
one
,
"
Tom
assented
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
for
'em
myself
when
they
're
too
young
,
"
remarked
the
coachman
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
a
matter
of
taste
,
which
Tom
did
not
feel
himself
called
upon
to
discuss
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'll
seldom
find
'em
possessing
correct
opinions
about
refreshment
,
for
instance
,
when
they
're
too
young
,
you
know
,
"
said
the
coachman
;
"
a
woman
must
have
arrived
at
maturity
,
before
her
mind
's
equal
to
coming
provided
with
a
basket
like
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
would
like
to
know
what
it
contains
?
"
said
Tom
,
smiling
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
coachman
only
laughed
,
and
as
Tom
was
curious
himself
,
he
unpacked
it
,
and
put
the
articles
,
one
by
one
,
upon
the
footboard
.
<EOS>
A
cold
roast
fowl
,
a
packet
of
ham
in
slices
,
a
crusty
loaf
,
a
piece
of
cheese
,
a
paper
of
biscuits
,
half
a
dozen
apples
,
a
knife
,
some
butter
,
a
screw
of
salt
,
and
a
bottle
of
old
sherry
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
letter
besides
,
which
Tom
put
in
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
The
coachman
was
so
earnest
in
his
approval
of
Mrs
Lupin
's
provident
habits
,
and
congratulated
Torn
so
warmly
on
his
good
fortune
,
that
Tom
felt
it
necessary
,
for
the
lady
's
sake
,
to
explain
that
the
basket
was
a
strictly
Platonic
basket
,
and
had
merely
been
presented
to
him
in
the
way
of
friendship
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
made
the
statement
with
perfect
gravity
;
for
he
felt
it
incumbent
on
him
to
disabuse
the
mind
of
this
lax
rover
of
any
incorrect
impressions
on
the
subject
;
he
signified
that
he
would
be
happy
to
share
the
gifts
with
him
,
and
proposed
that
they
should
attack
the
basket
in
a
spirit
of
good
fellowship
at
any
time
in
the
course
of
the
night
which
the
coachman
's
experience
and
knowledge
of
the
road
might
suggest
,
as
being
best
adapted
to
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
From
this
time
they
chatted
so
pleasantly
together
,
that
although
Tom
knew
infinitely
more
of
unicorns
than
horses
,
the
coachman
informed
his
friend
the
guard
at
the
end
of
the
next
stage
,
"
that
rum
as
the
box
-
seat
looked
,
he
was
as
good
a
one
to
go
,
in
pint
of
conversation
,
as
ever
he
'd
wish
to
sit
by
.
"
   
<EOS>
Yoho
,
among
the
gathering
shades
;
making
of
no
account
the
deep
reflections
of
the
trees
,
but
scampering
on
through
light
and
darkness
,
all
the
same
,
as
if
the
light
of
London
fifty
miles
away
,
were
quite
enough
to
travel
by
,
and
some
to
spare
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
,
beside
the
village
green
,
where
cricket
-
players
linger
yet
,
and
every
little
indentation
made
in
the
fresh
grass
by
bat
or
wicket
,
ball
or
player
's
foot
,
sheds
out
its
perfume
on
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Away
with
four
fresh
horses
from
the
Bald
-
faced
Stag
,
where
topers
congregate
about
the
door
admiring
;
and
the
last
team
with
traces
hanging
loose
,
go
roaming
off
towards
the
pond
,
until
observed
and
shouted
after
by
a
dozen
throats
,
while
volunteering
boys
pursue
them
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
with
a
clattering
of
hoofs
and
striking
out
of
fiery
sparks
,
across
the
old
stone
bridge
,
and
down
again
into
the
shadowy
road
,
and
through
the
open
gate
,
and
far
away
,
away
,
into
the
wold
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
   
<EOS>
Yoho
,
behind
there
,
stop
that
bugle
for
a
moment
!
 
<EOS>
Come
creeping
over
to
the
front
,
along
the
coach
-
roof
,
guard
,
and
make
one
at
this
basket
!
 
<EOS>
Not
that
we
slacken
in
our
pace
the
while
,
not
we
;
we
rather
put
the
bits
of
blood
upon
their
metal
,
for
the
greater
glory
of
the
snack
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
long
since
this
bottle
of
old
wine
was
brought
into
contact
with
the
mellow
breath
of
night
,
you
may
depend
,
and
rare
good
stuff
it
is
to
wet
a
bugler
's
whistle
with
.
 
<EOS>
Only
try
it
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
afraid
of
turning
up
your
finger
,
Bill
,
another
pull
!
 
<EOS>
Now
,
take
your
breath
,
and
try
the
bugle
,
Bill
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
music
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
a
tone
!
"
<EOS>
over
the
hills
and
far
away
,
"
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
 
<EOS>
The
skittish
mare
is
all
alive
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
   
<EOS>
See
the
bright
moon
!
 
<EOS>
High
up
before
we
know
it
;
making
the
earth
reflect
the
objects
on
its
breast
like
water
.
 
<EOS>
Hedges
,
trees
,
low
cottages
,
church
steeples
,
blighted
stumps
and
flourishing
young
slips
,
have
all
grown
vain
upon
the
sudden
,
and
mean
to
contemplate
their
own
fair
images
till
morning
.
 
<EOS>
The
poplars
yonder
rustle
that
their
quivering
leaves
may
see
themselves
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Not
so
the
oak
<EOS>
;
trembling
does
not
become
HIM
;
and
he
watches
himself
in
his
stout
old
burly
steadfastness
,
without
the
motion
of
a
twig
.
<EOS>
The
moss
-
grown
gate
,
ill
-
poised
upon
its
creaking
hinges
,
crippled
and
decayed
swings
to
and
fro
before
its
glass
,
like
some
fantastic
dowager
;
while
our
own
ghostly
likeness
travels
on
,
Yoho
!
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
<EOS>
through
ditch
and
brake
,
upon
the
ploughed
land
and
the
smooth
,
along
the
steep
hillside
and
steeper
wall
,
as
if
it
were
a
phantom
-
Hunter
.
   
<EOS>
Clouds
too
!
 
<EOS>
And
a
mist
upon
the
Hollow
!
 
<EOS>
Not
a
dull
fog
that
hides
it
,
but
a
light
airy
gauze
-
like
mist
,
which
in
our
eyes
of
modest
admiration
gives
a
new
charm
to
the
beauties
it
is
spread
before
;
as
real
gauze
has
done
ere
now
,
and
would
again
,
so
please
you
,
though
we
were
the
Pope
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
 
<EOS>
Why
now
we
travel
like
the
Moon
herself
.
<EOS>
Hiding
this
minute
in
a
grove
of
trees
;
next
minute
in
a
patch
of
vapour
;
emerging
now
upon
our
broad
clear
course
;
withdrawing
now
,
but
always
dashing
on
,
our
journey
is
a
counter
-
part
of
hers
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
!
<EOS>
A
match
against
the
Moon
!
   
<EOS>
The
beauty
of
the
night
is
hardly
felt
,
when
Day
comes
rushing
up
.
<EOS>
Yoho
!
 
<EOS>
Two
stages
,
and
the
country
roads
are
almost
changed
to
a
continuous
street
.
 
<EOS>
Yoho
,
past
market
-
gardens
,
rows
of
houses
,
villas
,
crescents
,
terraces
,
and
squares
;
past
waggons
,
coaches
,
carts
;
past
early
workmen
,
late
stragglers
,
drunken
men
,
and
sober
carriers
of
loads
;
past
brick
and
mortar
in
its
every
shape
;
and
in
among
the
rattling
pavements
,
where
a
jaunty
-
seat
upon
a
coach
is
not
so
easy
to
preserve
!
 
<EOS>
Yoho
,
down
countless
turnings
,
and
through
countless
mazy
ways
,
until
an
old
Innyard
is
gained
,
and
Tom
Pinch
,
getting
down
quite
stunned
and
giddy
,
is
in
London
!
   
<EOS>
"
Five
minutes
before
the
time
,
too
!
"
said
the
driver
,
as
he
received
his
fee
of
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
should
not
have
minded
very
much
,
if
we
had
been
five
hours
after
it
;
for
at
this
early
hour
I
do
n't
know
where
to
go
,
or
what
to
do
with
myself
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
they
expect
you
then
?
"
inquired
the
driver
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
them
,
"
returned
the
driver
.
   
<EOS>
His
mind
was
so
clearly
running
on
the
assumption
of
Tom
's
having
come
to
town
to
see
an
extensive
circle
of
anxious
relations
and
friends
,
that
it
would
have
been
pretty
hard
work
to
undeceive
him
.
<EOS>
Tom
did
not
try
.
 
<EOS>
He
cheerfully
evaded
the
subject
,
and
going
into
the
Inn
,
fell
fast
asleep
before
a
fire
in
one
of
the
public
rooms
opening
from
the
yard
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
awoke
,
the
people
in
the
house
were
all
astir
,
so
he
washed
and
dressed
himself
;
to
his
great
refreshment
after
the
journey
;
and
,
it
being
by
that
time
eight
o'clock
,
went
forth
at
once
to
see
his
old
friend
John
.
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
lived
in
Furnival
's
Inn
,
High
Holborn
,
which
was
within
a
quarter
of
an
hour
's
walk
of
Tom
's
starting
-
point
,
but
seemed
a
long
way
off
,
by
reason
of
his
going
two
or
three
miles
out
of
the
straight
road
to
make
a
short
cut
.
 
<EOS>
When
at
last
he
arrived
outside
John
's
door
,
two
stories
up
,
he
stood
faltering
with
his
hand
upon
the
knocker
,
and
trembled
from
head
to
foot
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
was
rendered
very
nervous
by
the
thought
of
having
to
relate
what
had
fallen
out
between
himself
and
Pecksniff
;
and
he
had
a
misgiving
that
John
would
exult
fearfully
in
the
disclosure
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
must
be
made
,
"
thought
Tom
,
"
sooner
or
later
;
and
I
had
better
get
it
over
.
"
   
<EOS>
Rat
tat
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
that
's
not
a
London
knock
,
"
thought
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
did
n't
sound
bold
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
that
's
the
reason
why
nobody
answers
the
door
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
quite
certain
that
nobody
came
,
and
that
Tom
stood

the

;
wondering

the
neighbourhood
a

,
who
was

to
somebody
"
Come
in
!
"
<EOS>
with
all
his
might
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Tom
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
lives
here
,
and
is
calling
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Can

open

door
from
the
outside
,
I
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
to
be
sure
I
can
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
To
be

could
,
by

;
and
to

he
did

the

,

"
Why
do

?
 
<EOS>
Come

,

?
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
<EOS>
---
 
quite

.
   
<EOS>
Tom

,

(

<EOS>
"
Why
,

"

<EOS>
"
Tom

"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
No

,

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"
Good

!
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Boar

,

.

<EOS>
What

<EOS>
I

.

<EOS>
While

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Now

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Imprimis

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
put

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
   
"

"
   
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Not

!
 
<EOS>
What

!
"

"

!

,

<EOS>
the

<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
As

.
"
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
John
Westlock
took
the
French
rolls
out
of
his

,
and
put
his
boots
on
,
and
dressed

;
giving
Tom
the
paper
to
read
in
the
meanwhile
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
returned
,
equipped
for
walking
,
he
found
Tom
in
a
brown
study
,
with
the
paper
in
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dreaming
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr
Pinch
,
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
looking
over
the
advertising
sheet
,
thinking
there
might
be
something
in
it
which
would
be
likely
to
suit
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
often
think
,
the
strange
thing
seems
to
be
that
nobody
is
suited
.
 
<EOS>
Here
are
all
kinds
of
employers
wanting
all
sorts
of
servants
,
and
all
sorts
of
servants
wanting
all
kinds
of
employers
,
and
they
never
seem
to
come
together
.
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
gentleman
in
a
public
office
in
a
position
of
temporary

,
who
wants
to
borrow
five
hundred
pounds
;
and
in
the
very
next
advertisement
here
is
another
gentleman
who
has
got
exactly
that
sum
to

.
 
<EOS>
But
he
'll
never
lend
it
to
him
,
John
,
you
'll

!
 
<EOS>
Here
is
a
lady
possessing
a
moderate

,
who
wants
to
board

with
a
quiet
,

;
and
here
is
a
family
describing

in
those

words
,
"
a
quiet
,

family
,
"
who
want
exactly

to
come

live

.
 
<EOS>
But
she
'll
never
go
,
John
!
 
<EOS>
Neither
do
any
of
these
single
gentlemen
who
want
an
airy

,
with
the
occasional

of
a

,
ever
appear
to
come
to
terms
with
these
other

who
live
in
a
rural
situation
remarkable
for
its
bracing

,
within
five
minutes
'
walk
of
the
Royal
Exchange
.
 
<EOS>
Even
those
letters
of
the
alphabet
who
are
always
running
away
from
their
friends
and
being
entreated
at
the
tops
of
columns
to
come
back
,
never
DO
come
back
,
if
we
may
judge
from
the
number
of
times
they
are
asked
to
do
it
and
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
It
really
seems
,
"
said
Tom
,
relinquishing

,
"
as
if
people
had
the
same
gratification
in
printing

as

making

known
by
word

;
as

found

a

and

to
proclaim
<EOS>
"
I
want
such
and
such
a
thing
,
and
I
ca
n't
get
it
,
and
<EOS>
I
do
n't
expect
I
ever
shall
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
John
Westlock
laughed
at
the
idea
,
and
they
went
out
together
.
 
<EOS>
So
many
years
had
passed
since
Tom
was
last
in
London
,
and
he
had
known
so
little
of

then
,
that
his
interest
in
all
he
saw
was
very
great
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
particularly
anxious
,
among
other
notorious
localities
,
to
have
those
streets
pointed
out
to
him
which
were
appropriated
to
the
slaughter
of
countrymen
;
and
was
quite
disappointed
to
find
,
after
half
-
an
-
hour
's
walking
,
that
he
had
n't
had
his
pocket
picked
.
 
<EOS>
But
on
John
Westlock
's
inventing
a
pickpocket
for
his
gratification
,
and
pointing
out
a
highly
respectable
stranger
as
one
of
that
fraternity
,
he
was
much
delighted
.
   
<EOS>
His
friend
accompanied
him
to
within
a
short
distance
of
Camberwell
and
having
put
him
beyond
the
possibility
of
mistaking
the
wealthy
brass
-
and
-
copper
founder
's
,
left
him
to
make
his
visit
.
 
<EOS>
Arriving
before
the
great
bell
-
handle
,
Tom
gave
it
a
gentle
pull
.
 
<EOS>
The
porter
appeared
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
does
Miss
Pinch
live
here
?
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Pinch
is
governess
here
,
"
replied
the
porter
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
he
looked
at
Tom
from
head
to
foot
,
as
if
he
would
have
said
,
"
You
are
a
nice
man
,
YOU
are
;
where
did
YOU
come
from
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
same
young
lady
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
right
.
 
<EOS>
Is
she
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
rejoined
the
porter
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
you
could
have
the
goodness
to
ascertain
?
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
He
had
quite
a
delicacy
in
offering
the
suggestion
,
for
the
possibility
of
such
a
step
did
not
appear
to
present
itself
to
the
porter
's
mind
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
The
fact
was
that
the
porter
in
answering
the
gate
-
bell
had
,
according
to
usage
,
rung
the
house
-
bell
(
for
it
is
as
well
to
do
these
things
in
the
Baronial
style
while
you
are
about
it
)
,
and
that
there
the
functions
of
his
office
had
ceased
.
 
<EOS>
Being
hired
to
open
and
shut
the
gate
,
and
not
to
explain
himself
to
strangers
,
he
left
this
little
incident
to
be
developed
by
the
footman
with
the
tags
,
who
,
at
this
juncture
,
called
out
from
the
door
steps
:
   
<EOS>
"
Hollo
,
there
!
<EOS>
wot
are
you
up
to
?
 
<EOS>
This
way
,
young
man
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Tom
,
hurrying
towards
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
observe
that
there
was
anybody
else
.
 
<EOS>
Pray
is
Miss
Pinch
at
home
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
IN
,
"
replied
the
footman
.
 
<EOS>
As
much
as
to
say
to
Tom
:
"
But

you
think
she
has
anything
to
do
with

of
this

you
had

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to
see
her
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
The
footman
,
being
a
lively
young
man
,
happened
to
have
his
attention
caught
at
that
moment
by
the
flight
of
a

,
in
which
he
took
so
warm

interest
that
his
gaze
was
rivetted
on
the
bird
until
it
was
quite
out

sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
invited
Tom
to
come
in
,
and
showed
him
into
a
parlour
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hany
neem
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
young
man
,
pausing
languidly
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
good
thought
;
because
without
providing
the
stranger
,
in
case
he
should
happen
to
be
of
a
warm
temper
,
<EOS>
with
a
sufficient
excuse
for
knocking
him
down
,
it
implied
this
young
man
's
estimate
of
his
quality
,
and
relieved
his
breast
of
the
oppressive
burden
of
rating
him
in
secret
as

nameless
and

.
   
<EOS>
"
Say
her
brother
,
if
you
please
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mother
?
"
drawled
the
footman
.
   
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
repeated
Tom
,
slightly
raising
his
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
if
you
will
say
,
in
the
first

,
a
gentleman
,
and
then
say
her
brother
,
I
shall
be
obliged
to
you
,
as
she
does
not
expect
me
or
know
I
am
in
London
,
and
I
do
not
wish
to
startle
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
young
man
's
interest
in
Tom
's
observations
had
ceased
long
before
this
time
,
but
he
kindly
waited
until
now
;
when
,
shutting
the
door
,
he
withdrew
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
very
disrespectful
and
uncivil
behaviour
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
these
are
new
servants
here
,
and
that
Ruth
is
very
differently
treated
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
cogitations
were
interrupted
by
the
sound
of
voices
in
the
adjoining
room
.
 
<EOS>
They
seemed
to
be
engaged
in
high
dispute
,
or
in
indignant
reprimand
of
some
offender
;
and
gathering
strength
occasionally
,
broke
out
into
a
perfect
whirlwind
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
one
of
these
gusts
,
as
it
appeared
to
Tom
,
that
the
footman
announced
him
;
for
an
abrupt
and
unnatural
calm
took
place
,
and
then
a
dead
silence
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
standing
before
the
window
,
wondering
what
domestic
quarrel
might
have
caused
these
sounds
,
and
hoping
Ruth
had
nothing
to
do
with
it
,
when
the
door
opened
,
and
his
sister
ran
into
his
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
looking
at
her
with
great
pride
,
when
they
had
tenderly
embraced
each
other
,
"
how
altered
you
are
Ruth
!
 
<EOS>
I
should
scarcely
have
known
you
,
my
love
,
if
I
had
seen
you
anywhere
else
,
I
declare
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
so
improved
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
inexpressible

;
"
you
are
so
womanly
;
you
are
so
---
<EOS>
positively
,
you
know
,
you
are
so
handsome
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
YOU
think
so
Tom
---
"
   
"
Oh
,
but
everybody
must
think
so
,
you
know
,
"
said
Tom
,
gently

down

.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
matter
of
fact
;
not

.
 
<EOS>
But
what
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
looking
at
her
more

,
"
how
flushed

are
!
<EOS>
and
you
have
been

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
have
not
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
"
said
her
brother
stoutly
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
story
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
tell

!
 
<EOS>
I
know

.
 
<EOS>
What

it
,
dear
?
 
<EOS>
I
'm
not
with
Mr
Pecksniff
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
try
and
settle
myself
in
London
;
and

(

,

have
been

with
the

)
you
shall
not
remain
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
!
 
<EOS>
Tom
's
blood
was
rising
;
mind
that
!
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
Boar
's
Head
had
something
to
do
with
it
,
but

footman

.
 
<EOS>
So

sight

his
pretty
sister
---
a

.
 
<EOS>
Tom
could
bear
a
good
deal
himself
,
but
he
was
proud
of
her
,
and
pride
is
a

.
 
<EOS>
He

,
"
there

Pecksniffs
than
one
,

,
"
and
by

that

,
Tom
was

all

!
   
<EOS>
"
We
will
talk

,
Tom
,
"
said

,
giving

to

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

not

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Can

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why

,
you
shall
not
,
my
love
.
 
<EOS>
Heyday
!
<EOS>
You
are
not

!
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
stopped
in

by

,
who
brought
a

from

,
importing

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Show
the
way
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
wait
upon

at

.
"
   
<EOS>
Accordingly
they
entered
the
adjoining
room
from
which
the
noise
of
altercation
had
proceeded
;
and
there
they
found
a
middle

,
with

,

-

,
with
what
may

termed

excisable

,
or
one

which

and

were
decidedly
employed
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
likewise
present
<EOS>
that
eldest
pupil
of
Miss
Pinch
,
whom
Mrs
Todgers
,
on
a

,
had
called
a

,
and
who
was
now

and

.
   
<EOS>
"
My
brother
,
sir
,
"
said
Ruth
Pinch
,
timidly

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"

,
surveying

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
really
are
Miss
Pinch
's
brother
,
I

?
 
<EOS>
You
will

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
observe
any
resemblance
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Miss
Pinch
has
a
brother
,
I
know
,
"
observed

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Pinch

brother
,
when

ought

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sophia
!
 
<EOS>
Hold
your
tongue
!
"
<EOS>
observed
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
if
you
please
,
"
addressing
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
Tom

down
,
looking
from
one

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Remain
here
,
if
you
please
,
Miss
Pinch
,
"
pursued
the
gentleman
,
looking
slightly
over

.
   
<EOS>
Tom
interrupted
him
here
,
by
rising
to
place
a
chair
for
his
sister
.
<EOS>
Having

he

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
chance
to
have
called

your
sister
to
-
day
,

,
"
resumed

-

-

.
 
<EOS>
"
For

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

Pinch

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sophia
!
"
cried

.
 
<EOS>
"
Hold
your

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"
said

gentleman
,
"
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't

as

;
but
I

.
 
<EOS>
Your

has
not

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
Although

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Miss

's

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
"
said

,

to

table
<EOS>
:
"
I

!
 
<EOS>
You
,

,

---
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
at
all

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

that
there

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heavens
!
"

,

,
"

the

!
<EOS>
what

!
 
<EOS>
What

"
   
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

<EOS>
"
Which

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
A

.
 
<EOS>
A

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Most

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

just

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
just
,

,
"
said
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
So
just
,
that
,
but

to

,

,

<EOS>
,
I

,
as
I
assured
Miss
Pinch
,
upon
my
veracity
and
personal
character
,
a
few
minutes
ago
,
I
would
have
severed
the
connection
between
us
at
that
moment
and
from
that
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
rising
from
his
seat
;
for
he
was
now
unable
to
contain
himself
any
longer
;
"
do
n't
allow
such
considerations
as
those
to
influence
you
,
pray
.
 
<EOS>
They
do
n't
exist
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
not
unprotected
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
ready
to
depart
this
instant
.
<EOS>
Ruth
,
my
dear
,
get
your
bonnet
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
a
pretty
family
!
"
cried
the
lady
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
he
's
her
brother
!
<EOS>
There
's
no
doubt
about
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
As
little
doubt
,
madam
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
as
that
the
young
lady
yonder
is
the
child
of
your
teaching
,
and
not
my
sister
's
.
 
<EOS>
Ruth
,
my
dear
,
get
your
bonnet
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
say
,
young
man
,
"
interposed
the
brass
-
and
-
copper
founder
,
haughtily
,
"
with
that
impertinence
which
is
natural
to
you
,
and
which
I
therefore
do
not
condescend
to
notice
further
,
that
the
young
lady
,
my
eldest
daughter
,
has
been
educated
by
any
one
but
Miss
Pinch
,
you
---
I
need
n't
proceed
.
 
<EOS>
You
comprehend
me
fully
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
you
are
used
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
after
regarding
him
in
silence
for
some
little
time
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
not
understand
what
I
mean
,
I
will
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
understand
what
I
mean
,
I
beg
you
not
to
repeat
that
mode
of
expressing
yourself
in
answer
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
meaning
is
,
that
no
man
can
expect
his
children
to
respect
what
he
degrades
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
laughed
the
gentleman
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
nt
!
<EOS>
ca
nt
!
 
<EOS>
The
common
ca
nt
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
common
story
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
;
"
the
story
of
a
common
mind
.
<EOS>
Your
governess
can
not
win
the
confidence
and
respect
of
your
children
,
forsooth
!
 
<EOS>
Let
her
begin
by
winning
yours
,
and
see
what
happens
then
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Miss
Pinch
is
getting
her
bonnet
on
,
I
trust
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
trust
she
is
,
"
said
Tom
,
forestalling
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
she
is
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
I
address
myself
to
you
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
You
made
your
statement
to
me
,
sir
;
you
required
to
see
me
for
that
purpose
;
and
I
have
a
right
to
answer
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
loud
or
turbulent
,
"
said
Tom
,
which
was
quite
true
,
"
though
I
can
scarcely
say
as
much
for
you
,
in
your
manner
of
addressing
yourself
to
me
.
<EOS>
And
I
wish
,
on
my
sister
's
behalf
,
to
state
the
simple
truth
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
may
state
anything
you
like
,
young
man
,
"
returned
the
gentleman
,
affecting
to
yawn
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
Miss
Pinch
's
money
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
tell
me
,
"
resumed
Tom
,
who
was
not
the
less
indignant
for
keeping
himself
quiet
,
"
that
my
sister
has
no
innate
power
of
commanding
the
respect
of
your
children
,
I
must
tell
you
it
is
not
so
;
and
that
she
has
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
as
well
bred
,
as
well
taught
,
as
well
qualified
by
nature
to
command
respect
,
<EOS>
as
any
hirer
of
a
governess
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
you
place
her
at
a
disadvantage
in
reference
to
every
servant
in
your
house
,
how
can
you
suppose
,
if
you
have
the
gift
of
common
sense
,
that
she
is
not
in
a
tenfold
worse
position
in
reference
to
your
daughters
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pretty
well
!
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
"
exclaimed
the
gentleman
,
"
this
is
pretty
well
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
ill
,
sir
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
bad
and
mean
,
and
wrong
and
cruel
.
 
<EOS>
Respect
!
 
<EOS>
I
believe
young
people
are
quick
enough
to
observe
and
imitate
;
and
why
or
how
should
they
respect
whom
no
one
else
respects
,
and
everybody
slights
?
 
<EOS>
And
very
partial
they
must
grow
---
oh
,
very
partial
!
<EOS>
---
to
their
studies
,
when
they
see
to
what
a
pass
proficiency
in
those
same
tasks
has
brought
their
governess
!
 
<EOS>
Respect
!
 
<EOS>
Put
anything
the
most
deserving
of
respect
before
your
daughters
in
the
light
in
which
you
place
her
,
and
you
will
bring
it
down
as
low
,
no
matter
what
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
speak
with
extreme
impertinence
,
young
man
,
"
observed
the
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
speak
without
passion
,
but
with
extreme
indignation
and
contempt
for
such
a
course
of
treatment
,
and
for
all
who
practice
it
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
can
you
,
as
an
honest
gentleman
,
profess
displeasure
or
surprise
at
your
daughter
telling
my
sister
she
is
something
beggarly
and
humble
,
when
you
are
for
ever
telling
her
the
same
thing
yourself
in
fifty
plain
,
outspeaking
ways
,
though
not
in
words
;
and
when
your
very
porter
and
footman
make
the
same
delicate
announcement
to
all
comers
?
 
<EOS>
As
to
your
suspicion
and
distrust
of
her
;
even
of
her
word
;
if
she
is
not
above
their
reach
,
you
have
no
right
to
employ
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
right
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
brass
-
and
-
copper
founder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Distinctly
not
,
"
Tom
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
imagine
that
the
payment
of
an
annual
sum
of
money
gives
it
to
you
,
you
immensely
exaggerate
its
power
and
value
.
 
<EOS>
Your
money
is
the
least
part
of
your
bargain
in
such
a
case
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
be
punctual
in
that
to
half
a
second
on
the
clock
,
and
yet
be
Bankrupt
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
more
to
say
,
"
said
Tom
,
much
flushed
and
flustered
,
now
that
