was
over
,
"
except
to
crave
permission
to
stand
in
your
garden
until
my
sister
is
ready
.
"
   
<EOS>
Not
waiting
to
obtain
it
,
Tom
walked
out
.
   
<EOS>
Before
he
had
well
begun
to
cool
,
his
sister
joined
him
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
crying
;
and
Tom
could
not
bear
that
any
one
about
the
house
should
see
her
doing
that
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
will
think
you
are
sorry
to
go
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
sorry
to
go
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Tom
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
anxious
to
go
for
a
very
long
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
then
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
cry
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
sorry
for
YOU
,
dear
,
"
sobbed
Tom
's
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
ought
to
be
glad
on
my
account
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
twice
as
happy
with
you
for
a
companion
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
up
your
head
.
 
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
Now
we
go
out
as
we
ought
.
 
<EOS>
Not
blustering
,
you
know
,
but
firm
and
confident
in
ourselves
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
idea
of
Tom
and
his
sister
blustering
,
under
any
circumstances
,
was
a
splendid
absurdity
.
 
<EOS>
But
Tom
was
very
far
from
feeling
it
to
be
<EOS>
so
,
in
his
excitement
;
and
passed
out
at
the
gate
with
such
severe
determination
written
in
his
face
that
the
porter
hardly
knew
him
again
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
they
had
walked
some
short
distance
,
and
Tom
found
himself
getting
cooler
and
more
collected
,
that
he
was
quite
restored
to
himself
by
an
inquiry
from
his
sister
,
who
said
in
her
pleasant
little
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are
we
going
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
stopping
,
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
you
---
do
n't
you
live
anywhere
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Tom
's
sister
looking
wistfully
in
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
at
present
.
 
<EOS>
Not
exactly
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
arrived
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
have
some
lodgings
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
n't
tell
her
that
he
had
been
going
to
stay
with
his
friend
John
,
and
could
on
no
account
think
of
billeting
two
inmates
upon
him
,
of
whom
one
was
a
young
lady
;
for
he
knew
that
would
make
her
uncomfortable
,
and
would
cause
her
to
regard
herself
as
being
an
inconvenience
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
did
he
like
to
leave
her
anywhere
while
he
called
on
John
,
and
told
him
of
this
change
in
his
arrangements
;
for
he
was
delicate
of
seeming
to
encroach
upon
the
generous
and
hospitable
nature
of
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
he
said
again
,
"
We
must
have
some
lodgings
,
of
course
;
"
and
said
it
as
stoutly
as
if
he
had
been
a
perfect
Directory
and
Guide
-
Book
to
all
the
lodgings
in
London
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
shall
we
go
and
look
for
'
em
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
's
sister
was
not
much
wiser
on
such
a
topic
than
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
So
she
squeezed
her
little
purse
into
his
coat
-
pocket
,
and
folding
the
little
hand
with
which
she
did
so
on
the
other
little
hand
with
which
she
clasped
his
arm
,
said
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
ought
to
be
a
cheap
neighbourhood
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
and
not
too
far
from
London
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
 
<EOS>
Should
you
think
Islington
a
good
place
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
was
an
excellent
place
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
used
to
be
called
Merry
Islington
,
once
upon
a
time
,
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
's
merry
now
;
if
so
,
it
's
all
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
not
too
dear
,
"
said
Tom
's
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
if
it
's
not
too
dear
,
"
assented
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
where
IS
Islington
?
 
<EOS>
We
ca
n't
do
better
than
go
there
,
I
should
think
.
 
<EOS>
Let
's
go
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
's
sister
would
have
gone
anywhere
with
him
;
so
they
walked
off
,
arm
in
arm
,
as
comfortably
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
Finding
,
presently
,
that
Islington
was
not
in
that
neighbourhood
,
Tom
made
inquiries
respecting
a
public
conveyance
thither
;
which
they
soon
obtained
.
<EOS>
As
they
rode
along
they
were
very
full
of
conversation
indeed
,
Tom
relating
what
had
happened
to
him
,
and
<EOS>
Tom
's
sister
relating
what
had
happened
to
her
,
and
both
finding
a
great
deal
more
to
say
than
time
to
say
it
in
;
for
they
had
only
just
begun
to
talk
,
in
comparison
with
what
they
had
to
tell
each
other
,
when
they
reached
their
journey
's
end
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
we
must
first
look
out
for
some
very
unpretending
streets
,
and
then
look
out
for
bills
in
the
windows
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
they
walked
off
again
,
quite
as
happily
as
if
they
had
just
stepped
out
of
a
snug
little
house
of
their
own
,
to
look
for
lodgings
on
account
of
somebody
else
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
's
simplicity
was
unabated
,
Heaven
knows
;
but
now
that
he
had
somebody
to
rely
upon
him
,
he
was
stimulated
to
rely
a
little
more
upon
himself
,
and
was
,
in
his
own
opinion
,
quite
a
desperate
fellow
.
   
<EOS>
After
roaming
up
and
down
for
hours
,
looking
at
some
scores
of
lodgings
,
they
began
to
find
it
rather
fatiguing
,
especially
as
they
saw
none
which
were
at
all
adapted
to
their
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
however
,
in
a
singular
little
old
-
fashioned
house
,
up
a
blind
street
,
they
discovered
two
small
bedrooms
and
a
triangular
parlour
,
which
promised
to
suit
them
well
enough
.
 
<EOS>
Their
desiring
to
take
possession
immediately
was
a
suspicious
circumstance
,
but
even
this
was
surmounted
by
the
payment
of
their
first
week
's
rent
,
and
a
reference
to
John
Westlock
,
Esquire
,
Furnival
's
Inn
,
High
Holborn
.
   
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
goodly
sight
,
when
this
important
point
was
settled
,
to
behold
Tom
and
his
sister
trotting
round
to
the
baker
's
,
and
the
butcher
's
,
and
the
grocer
's
,
with
a
kind
of
dreadful
delight
in
the
unaccustomed
cares
of
housekeeping
;
taking
secret
counsel
together
as
they
gave
their
small
orders
,
and
distracted
by
the
least
suggestion
on
the
part
of
the
shopkeeper
!
 
<EOS>
When
they
got
back
to
the
triangular
parlour
,
and
Tom
's
sister
,
bustling
to
and
fro
,
busy
about
a
thousand
pleasant
nothings
,
stopped
every
now
and
then
to
give
old
Tom
a
kiss
or
smile
upon
him
,
<EOS>
Tom
rubbed
his
hands
as
if
all
Islington
were
his
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
late
in
the
afternoon
now
,
though
,
and
high
time
for
Tom
to
keep
his
appointment
.
 
<EOS>
So
,
after
agreeing
with
his
sister
that
in
consideration
of
not
having
dined
,
they
would
venture
on
the
extravagance
of
chops
for
supper
at
nine
,
he
walked
out
again
to
narrate
these
marvellous
occurrences
to
John
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
a
family
man
all
at
once
,
"
thought
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I
can
only
get
something
to
do
,
how
comfortable
Ruth
and
<EOS>
I
may
be
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
that
if
!
<EOS>
But
it
's
of
no
use
to
despond
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
but
do
that
,
when
I
have
tried
everything
and
failed
;
and
even
then
it
wo
n't
serve
me
much
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
"
thought
Tom
,
quickening
his
pace
,
"
I
do
n't
know
what
John
will
think
has
become
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
begin
to
be
afraid
I
have
strayed
into
one
of
those
streets
where
the
countrymen
are
murdered
;
and
that
I
have
been
made
meat
pies
of
,
or
some
such
horrible
thing
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
37
.
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
,
going
astray
,
finds
that
he
is
not
the
only
person
in
that
predicament
.
 
<EOS>
He
retaliates
upon
a
fallen
foe
 
<EOS>
Tom
's
evil
genius
did
not
lead
him
into
the
dens
of
any
of
those
preparers
of
cannibalic
pastry
,
who
are
represented
in
many
standard
country
legends
as
doing
a
lively
retail
business
in
the
Metropolis
;
nor
did
it
mark
him
out
as
the
prey
of
ring
-
droppers
,
pea
and
thimble
-
riggers
,
duffers
,
touters
,
or
any
of
those
bloodless
sharpers
,
who
are
,
perhaps
,
a
little
better
known
to
the
Police
.
 
<EOS>
He
fell
into
conversation
with
no
gentleman
who
took
him
into
a
public
-
house
,
where
there
happened
to
be
another
gentleman
who
swore
he
had
more
money
than
any
gentleman
,
and
very
soon
proved
he
had
more
money
than
one
gentleman
by
taking
his
away
from
him
;
neither
did
he
fall
into
any
other
of
the
numerous
man
-
traps
which
are
set
up
without
notice
,
in
the
public
grounds
of
this
city
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
lost
his
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
very
soon
did
that
;
and
in
trying
to
find
it
again
he
lost
it
more
and
more
.
   
<EOS>
Now
,
Tom
,
in
his
guileless
distrust
of
London
,
thought
himself
very
knowing
in
coming
to
the
determination
that
he
would
not
ask
to
be
directed
to
Furnival
's
Inn
,
if
he
could
help
it
;
unless
,
indeed
,
he
should
happen
to
find
himself
near
the
Mint
,
or
the
Bank
of
England
;
in
which
case
he
would
step
in
,
and
ask
a
civil
question
or
two
,
confiding
in
the
perfect
respectability
of
the
concern
.
 
<EOS>
So
on
he
went
,
looking
up
all
the
streets
he
came
near
,
and
going
up
half
of
them
;
and
thus
,
by
dint
of
not
being
true
to
Goswell
Street
,
and
filing
off
into
Aldermanbury
,
and
bewildering
himself
in
Barbican
,
and
being
constant
to
the
wrong
point
of
the
compass
in
London
Wall
,
and
then
getting
himself
crosswise
into
Thames
Street
,
by
an
instinct
that
would
have
been
marvellous
if
he
had
had
the
least
desire
or
reason
to
go
there
,
he
found
himself
,
at
last
,
hard
by
the
Monument
.
   
<EOS>
The
Man
in
the
Monument
was
quite
as
mysterious
a
being
to
Tom
as
the
Man
in
the
Moon
.
 
<EOS>
It
immediately
occurred
to
him
that
the
lonely
creature
who
held
himself
aloof
from
all
mankind
in
that
pillar
like
some
old
hermit
was
the
very
man
of
whom
to
ask
his
way
.
 
<EOS>
Cold
,
he
might
be
;
little
sympathy
he
had
,
perhaps
,
with
human
passion
---
the
column
seemed
too
tall
for
that
;
but
if
Truth
did
n't
live
in
the
base
of
the
Monument
,
notwithstanding
Pope
's
couplet
about
the
outside
of
it
,
where
in
London
(
thought
Tom
)
was
she
likely
to
be
found
!
   
<EOS>
Coming
close
below
the
pillar
,
it
was
a
great
encouragement
to
Tom
to
find
that
the
Man
in
the
Monument
had
simple
tastes
;
that
stony
and
artificial
as
his
residence
was
,
he
still
preserved
some
rustic
recollections
;
that
he
liked
plants
,
hung
up
bird
-
cages
,
was
not
wholly
cut
off
from
fresh
groundsel
,
and
kept
young
trees
in
tubs
.
<EOS>
The
Man
in
the
Monument
,
himself
,
was
sitting
outside
the
door
---
his
own
door
:
the
Monument
-
door
:
what
a
grand
idea
!
<EOS>
---
and
was
actually
yawning
,
as
if
there
were
no
Monument
to
stop
his
mouth
,
and
give
him
a
perpetual
interest
in
his
own
existence
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
advancing
towards
this
remarkable
creature
,
to
inquire
the
way
to
Furnival
's
Inn
,
when
two
people
came
to
see
the
Monument
.
<EOS>
They
were
a
gentleman
and
a
lady
;
and
the
gentleman
said
,
"
How
much
a
-
piece
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
Man
in
the
Monument
replied
,
"
A
Tanner
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
a
low
expression
,
compared
with
the
Monument
.
   
<EOS>
The
gentleman
put
a
shilling
into
his
hand
,
and
the
Man
in
the
Monument
opened
a
dark
little
door
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
gentleman
and

had
passed
out

,
he
shut

again
,
and
came
slowly
back
to

.
   
<EOS>
He
sat
down
and
laughed
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
do
n't
know
what
a
many
steps
there
is
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
worth
twice
the
money
to
stop
here
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
eye
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
Man
in
the
Monument
was
a
Cynic
;
a
worldly
man
!
 
<EOS>
Tom
could
n't
ask
his
way
of
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
prepared
to
put
no
confidence
in
anything
he
said
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
gracious
!
<EOS>
"
cried
a
well
-
known
voice
behind
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
to
be
sure
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
he
was
poked
in

back
by

.
 
<EOS>
Turning
round
to
inquire
into
this

,
he

the
eldest
daughter
of
his
late

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Pecksniff
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
goodness
,
Mr
Pinch
!
"
cried
Cherry
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
are
you

here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
rather

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have

,
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

quite

you
had
,
when
my
Papa
so
far

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But

was

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tcha
,

!
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tom

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
N
---
 
<EOS>
no
!
"
said

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
---
<EOS>
but

's

.
 
<EOS>
Wo

walk
in
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
live

,

?
"
said
Tom
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

;
"

,
AT
PRESENT
.
"
   
<EOS>
The

.
 
<EOS>
So

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Only

!
 
<EOS>
Are

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
A

---
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Not

!
"

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

your

"
at

"
"
---
Tom

.
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,

!
 
<EOS>
I

so

,

Pinch
,
"

,

,
"

---
<EOS>
oh

!
<EOS>
---
wo

in
?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
mentioned
,
to

,
that

Furnival
's
Inn
,
and
that

Islington
he

,

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
simpered
very
much
when
he

her
if
she
knew
the
way
to
Furnival
's
Inn
,
and
at
length

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
gentleman
who
is
a

of
mine
,

at
least

is

much

---
<EOS>
Oh
upon

,
I
hardly

I

,

;
you

n't

;

,

as

---
is
going
to
Furnival
's
Inn
immediately
<EOS>
,
I
believe
upon
a
little
business
,
and
I
am
sure
he
would

very

to

,
so
as
to
prevent

wrong
again
.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
walk
in
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
very
likely
find
my
sister
Merry
here
,
"
she
said
with
a
curious

of

,
and
anything
but

agreeable

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
,
I
think
,
I
'll
endeavour
to

alone
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
for
I
fear
she

not

.
 
<EOS>
That
unfortunate

,
in

you

I
had
some

together
,
in
private
,
is
not
likely
to
have
impressed
her
with
any
friendly
feeling
towards
me
.
 
<EOS>
Though
it
really
was
not
my
fault
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
has
never
heard
of
that
,
you
may
depend
,
"
said
Cherry
,
gathering
up
the

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
far
from
sure
that
she
would
bear
you
any
mighty
ill
will
for
it
,
if
she

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
?
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
who
was
really
concerned
by
this

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
nothing
,
"
said
Charity
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
I

not
already
known
what
shocking

treachery

are
in

,
Mr

,
I

from

they
meet

---
from
the

meet
with
.
"
 
<EOS>
Here

as

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
say
anything
.
 
<EOS>
On
the

,
I
should
scorn

.
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
walk
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
something
hidden
here
,
which
piqued
Tom
's
interest
and
troubled
his
tender
heart
.
 
<EOS>
When
,
in
a
moment
's
irresolution
,
he
looked
at
Charity
,
he
could
not
but
observe
a
struggle
in
her
face
between
a
sense
of
triumph
and
a
sense
of
shame
;
nor
could
he
but
remark
<EOS>
how
,
meeting
even
his
eyes
,
which
she
cared
so
little
for
,
she
turned
away
her
own
,
for
all
the
splenetic
defiance
in
her
manner
.
   
<EOS>
An
uneasy
thought
entered
Tom
's
head
;
a
shadowy
misgiving
that
the
altered
relations
between
himself
and
Pecksniff
were
somehow
to
involve
an
altered
knowledge
on
his
part
of
other
people
,
and
were
to
give
him
an
insight
into
much
of
which
he
had
had
no
previous
suspicion
.
 
<EOS>
And
yet
he
put
no
definite
construction
upon
Charity
's
proceedings
.
 
<EOS>
He
certainly
had
no
idea
that
as
he
had
been
the
audience
and
spectator
of
her
mortification
,
she
grasped
with
eager

at
any

of
reproaching
her
sister
with
his
presence
in
HER
far
deeper
misery
;
for
he
knew
nothing
of
it
,
and
only
pictured
that
sister
as
the
same
giddy
,
careless
,
trivial
creature
she
always
had
been
,
with
the
same
slight
estimation
of
himself
which
she
had
never
been
at
the
least
pains
to
conceal
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
,
he
had
merely
a
confused
impression
that
Miss
Pecksniff
was
not
quite
sisterly
or
kind
;
and
being
curious
to
set
it
right
,
accompanied
her
as
she
desired
.
   
<EOS>
The
house
-
door
being
opened
,
she
went
in
before
Tom
,
requesting
him
to
follow
her
;
and
led

to
the

.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Merry
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
looking
in
,
"
I
am
so
glad
you
have
not
gone
home
.
 
<EOS>
Who
do
you
think
I
have
met
in
the
street
,
and
brought
to
see
you
!
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pinch
!
 
<EOS>
There
.
 
<EOS>
Now
you
ARE
surprised
,
I
am
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
Not
more
surprised
than
Tom
was
,
when
he
looked
upon
her
.
 
<EOS>
Not
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
Not
half
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Pinch
has
left
Papa
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Cherry
,
"
and
his
prospects
are
quite
flourishing
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
promised
that
Augustus
,
who
is
going
that
way
,
shall
escort
him
to
the
place
he
wants
.
 
<EOS>
Augustus
,
my
child
,
where
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
With
these
words
Miss
Pecksniff
screamed
her
way
out
of
the
parlour
,
calling
on
Augustus
Moddle
to
appear
;
and
left
Tom
Pinch
alone
with
her
sister
.
   
<EOS>
If
she
had
always
been
his
kindest
friend
;
if
she
had
treated
him
through
all
his
servitude
with
such
consideration
as
was
never
yet
received
by
struggling
man
;
if
she
had
lightened
every
moment
of
those
many
years
,
and
had
ever
spared
and
never
wounded
him
;
his
honest
heart
could
not
have
swelled
before
her
with
a
deeper
pity
,
or
a
purer
freedom
from
all
base
remembrance
than
it
did
then
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
gracious
me
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
really
the
last
person
in
the
world
I
should
have
thought
of
seeing
,
I
am
sure
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
sorry
to
hear
her
speaking
in
her
old
manner
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
not
expected
that
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
he
did
not
feel
it
a
contradiction
that
he
should
be
sorry
to
see
her
<EOS>
so
unlike
her
old
self
,
and
sorry
at
the
same
time
to
hear
her
speaking
in
her
old
manner
.
 
<EOS>
The
two
things
seemed
quite
natural
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
you
find
any
gratification
in
coming
to
see
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
think
what
put
it
in
your
head
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
had
much
in
seeing
you
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
love
lost
between
us
,
Mr
Pinch
,
at
any
time
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Her
bonnet
lay
beside
her
on
the
sofa
,
and
she
was
very
busy
with
the
ribbons
as
she
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
Much
too
busy
to
be
conscious
of
the
work
her
fingers
did
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
never
quarrelled
,
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
---
Tom
was
right
in
that
,
for
one
person
can
no
more
quarrel
without
an
adversary
,
than
one
person
can
play
at
chess
,
or
fight
a
duel
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hoped
you
would
be
glad
to
shake
hands
with
an
old
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
us
rake
up
bygones
,
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
ever
offended
you
,
forgive
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
for
a
moment
;
dropped
her
bonnet
from
her
hands
;
spread
them
before
her
altered
face
,
and
burst
into
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr
Pinch
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
although
I
never
used
you
well
,
I
did
believe
your
nature
was
forgiving
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
not
think
you
could
be
cruel
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
spoke
as
little
like
her
old
self
now
,
for
certain
,
as
Tom
could
possibly
have
wished
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
seemed
to
be
appealing
to
him
reproachfully
,
and
he
did
not
understand
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
seldom
showed
it
---
never
---
I
know
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
had
that
belief
in
you
,
that
if
I
had
been
asked
to
name
the
person
in
the
world
least
likely
to
retort
upon
me
,
I
would
have
named
you
,
confidently
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
have
named
me
!
"
<EOS>
Tom
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
with
energy
,
"
and
I
have
often
thought
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
moment
's
reflection
,
Tom
sat
himself
upon
a
chair
beside
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
believe
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
<EOS>
oh
,
can
you
think
,
that
what
I
said
just
now
,
I
said
with
any
but
the
true
and
plain
intention
which
my
words
professed
?
 
<EOS>
I
mean
it
,
in
the
spirit
and
the
letter
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
ever
offended
you
,
forgive
me
;
I
may
have
done
so
,
many
times
.
 
<EOS>
You
never
injured
or
offended
me
.
 
<EOS>
How
,
then
,
could
I
possibly
retort
,
if
even
I
were
stern
and
bad
enough
to
wish
to
do
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
a
little
while
she
thanked
him
,
through
her
tears
and
sobs
,
and
told
him
she
had
never
been
at
once
so
sorry
and
so
comforted
,
since
she
left
home
.
 
<EOS>
Still
she
wept
bitterly
;
and
it
was
the
greater
pain
to
Tom
to
see
her
weeping
,
from
her
standing
in
especial
need
,
just
then
,
of
sympathy
and
tenderness
.
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
!
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
"
you
used
to
be
as
cheerful
as
the
day
was
long
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
used
!
<EOS>
"
she
cried
,
in
such
a
tone
as
rent
Tom
's
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
will
be
again
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
never
more
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
never
,
never
more
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
should
talk
with
old
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
at
any
time
,
"
she
added
,
looking
hurriedly
into
his
face
---
"
<EOS>
I
sometimes
thought
he
liked
you
,
but
suppressed
it
---
will
you
promise
me
to
tell
him
that
you
saw
me
here
,
and
that
I
said
I
bore
in
mind
the
time
we
talked
together
in
the
churchyard
?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
promised
that
he
would
.
   
<EOS>
"
Many
times
since
then
,
when
I
have
wished
I
had
been
carried
there
before
that
day
,
I
have
recalled
his
words
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
that
he
should
know
how
true
they
were
,
although
the
least
acknowledgment
to
that
effect
has
never
passed
my
lips
and
never
will
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
promised
this
,
conditionally
too
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
tell
her
how
improbable
it
was
that
he
and
the
old
man
would
ever
meet
again
,
because
he
thought
it
might
disturb
her
more
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
he
should
ever
know
this
,
through
your
means
,
dear
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Mercy
,
"
tell
him
that
I
sent
the
message
,
not
for
myself
,
but
that
he
might
be
more
forbearing
and
more
patient
,
and
more
trustful
to
some
other
person
,
in
some
other
time
of
need
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
if
he
could
know
how
my
heart
trembled
in
the
balance
that
day
,
and
what
a
very
little
would
have
turned
the
scale
,
his
own
would
bleed
with
pity
for
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
appeared
to
him
the
most
unworthy
of
his
help
,
I
was
---
I
know
I
was
,
for
I
have
often
,
often
,
thought
about
it
since
---
the
most
inclined
to
yield
to
what
he
showed
me
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
if
he
had
relented
but
a
little
more
;
if
he
had
thrown
himself
in
my
way
for
but
one
other
quarter
of
an
hour
;
if
he
had
extended
his
compassion
for
a
vain
,
unthinking
,
miserable
girl
,
in
but
the
least
degree
;
he
might
,
and
I
believe
he
would
,
have
saved
her
!
 
<EOS>
Tell
him
that
I
do
n't
blame
him
,
but
am
grateful
for
the
effort
that
he
made
;
but
ask
him
for
the
love
of
God
,
and
youth
,
and
in
merciful
consideration
for
the
struggle
which
an
ill
-
advised
and
unwakened
nature
makes
to
hide
the
strength
it
thinks
its
weakness
---
ask
him
never
,
never
,
to
forget
this
,
when
he
deals
with
one
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
Although
Tom
did
not
hold
the
clue
to
her
full
meaning
,
he
could
guess
it
pretty
nearly
.
 
<EOS>
Touched
to
the
quick
,
he
took
her
hand
and
said
,
or
meant
to
say
,
some
words
of
consolation
.
 
<EOS>
She
felt
and
understood
them
,
whether
they
were
spoken
or
no
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
quite
certain
,
afterwards
,
but
that
she
had
tried
to
kneel
down
at
his
feet
,
and
bless
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
found
that
he
was
not
alone
in
the
room
when
she
had
left
it
.
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
was
there
,
shaking
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
had
never
seen
Mrs
Todgers
,
it
is
needless
to
say
,
but
he
had
a
perception
of
her
being
the
lady
of
the
house
;
and
he
saw
some
genuine
compassion
in
her
eyes
,
that
won
his
good
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
an
old
friend
,
I
see
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
,
"
quoth
Mrs
Todgers
,
shutting
the
door
softly
<EOS>
,
"
she
has
n't
told
you
what
her
troubles
are
,
I
'm
certain
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
struck
by
these
words
,
for
they
were
quite
true
.
 
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
"
he
said
,
"
she
has
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
never
would
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
if
you
saw
her
daily
.
 
<EOS>
She
never
makes
the
least
complaint
to
me
,
or
utters
a
single
word
of
explanation
or
reproach
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
know
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
drawing
in
her
breath
,
"
I
know
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
nodded
sorrowfully
,
"
So
do
I.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
fully
believe
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
taking
her
pocket
-
handkerchief
from
the
flat
reticule
,
"
that
nobody
can
tell
one
half
of
what
that
poor
young
creature
has
to
undergo
.
 
<EOS>
But
though
she
comes
here
,
constantly
,
to
ease
her
poor
full
heart
without
his
knowing
it
;
and
saying
,
"
Mrs
Todgers
,
I
am
very
low
to
-
day
;
I
think
that
I
shall
soon
be
dead
,
"
sits
crying
in
my
room
until
the
fit
is
past
;
I
know
no
more
from
her
.
 
<EOS>
And
,
I
believe
,
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
,
putting
back
her
handkerchief
again
,
"
that
she
considers
me
a
good
friend
too
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
might
have
said
her
best
friend
.
 
<EOS>
Commercial
gentlemen
and
gravy
had
tried
Mrs
Todgers
's
temper
;
the
main
chance
---
it
was
such
a
very
small
one
in
her
case
,
that
she
might
have
been
excused
for
looking
sharp
after
it
,
lest
it
should
entirely
vanish
from
her
sight
---
had
taken
a
firm
hold
on
Mrs
Todgers
's
attention
.
 
<EOS>
But
in
some
odd
nook
in
Mrs
Todgers
's
breast
,
up
a
great
many
steps
,
and
in
a
corner
easy
to
be
overlooked
,
there
was
a
secret
door
,
with
"
Woman
"
written
on
the
spring
,
which
,
at
a
touch
from
Mercy
's
hand
,
had
flown
wide
open
,
and
admitted
her
for
shelter
.
   
<EOS>
When
boarding
-
house
accounts
are
balanced
with
all
other
ledgers
,
and
the
books
of
the
Recording
Angel
are
made
up
for
ever
,
perhaps
there
may
be
seen
an
entry
to
thy
credit
,
lean
Mrs
Todgers
,
which
shall
make
thee
beautiful
!
   
<EOS>
She
was
growing
beautiful
so
rapidly
in
Tom
's
eyes
;
for
he
saw
that
she
was
poor
,
and
that
this
good
had
sprung
up
in
her
from
among
the
sordid
strivings
of
her
life
;
that
she
might
have
been
a
very
Venus
in
a
minute
more
,
if
Miss
Pecksniff
had
not
entered
with
her
friend
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Thomas
Pinch
!
<EOS>
"
said
Charity
,
performing
the
ceremony
of
introduction
with
evident
pride
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mr
Moddle
.
 
<EOS>
Where
's
my
sister
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Gone
,
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
Mrs
Todgers
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
had
appointed
to
be
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Charity
,
looking
at
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
greatly
altered
since
she
's
been
Anoth
---
since
she
's
been
married
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
<EOS>
observed
Moddle
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Augustus
!
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
in
a
low
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
verily
believe
you
have
said
that
fifty
thousand
times
,
in
my
hearing
.
<EOS>
What
a
Prose
you
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
succeeded
by
some
trifling
love
passages
,
which
appeared
to
originate
with
,
if
not
to
be
wholly
carried
on
by
Miss
Pecksniff
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
Mr
Moddle
was
much
slower
in
his
responses
than
is
customary
with
young
lovers
,
and
exhibited
a
lowness
of
spirits
which
was
quite
oppressive
.
   
<EOS>
He
did
not
improve
at
all
when
Tom
and
he
were
in
the
streets
,
but
sighed
so
dismally
that
it
was
dreadful
to
hear
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
a
means
of
cheering
him
up
,
Tom
told
him
that
he
wished
him
joy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Joy
!
"
cried
Moddle
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
!
"
   
"
What
an
extraordinary
young
man
!
<EOS>
"
thought
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
Scorner
has
not
set
his
seal
upon
you
.
 
<EOS>
YOU
care
what
becomes
of
you
?
"
said
Moddle
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
admitted
that
it
was
a
subject
in
which
he
certainly
felt
some
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
,
"
said
Mr
Moddle
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
Elements
may
have
me
when
they
please
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
ready
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
inferred
from
these
,
and
other

of

same

,
that
he
was
jealous
.
 
<EOS>
Therefore
he
allowed

to

;
which
was
such

,
that

a
load

.
   
<EOS>
It

John
Westlock
's

;

's

.
<EOS>
The

;

;

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Tom
,

,

?
 
<EOS>
Your

.
<EOS>
Get

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

I
ca

,

,
"

Tom
Pinch
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
stay
!
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

the

.
 
<EOS>
I
must

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
But

Islington
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
was

,

.
 
<EOS>
So
Tom

,

;
to

.
   
<EOS>
He
knew
Tom
too

,
and

too

,
to

.
 
<EOS>
He

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Tom
's

sup

that
night
<EOS>
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And

Tom
,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
 
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

n't

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
With

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
My

,

If

,
John
,

,

that

,
Mrs

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

!
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Never

.
 
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
John
Westlock
,

,

,

,
would

to

.
   
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
she
WAS
a
cheerful
little
thing
;
and
had
a
quaint
,
bright

about
her
that
was
infinitely

.
 
<EOS>
Surely
she
was
the
best

for
chops
ever

.
 
<EOS>
The
potatoes
seemed
to
take

in

before
her
;
the
froth
upon
the

of
porter
pouted
to

.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
all
in

.
 
<EOS>
She
saw
nothing
but
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
was
the
first
and
last
thing
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
As
she
sat

Tom
at

,

one

Tom
's
pet
tunes
upon
the
table

cloth
,
and
smiling
in
his

,
he
had
never
been
so
happy
in
his
life
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
38
.
<EOS>
Secret
service
 
<EOS>
In
walking
from
the
city
with
his
sentimental
friend
,
Tom
Pinch
had
looked
into
the
face
,
and
brushed
against
the
threadbare
sleeve
,
of
Mr
Nadgett
,
man
of
mystery
to
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Company
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
naturally
passed
away
from
Tom
's
remembrance
as
he
passed
out
of
his
view
;
for
he
did
n't
know
him
,
and
had
never
heard
his
name
.
   
<EOS>
As
there
are
a
vast
number
of
people
in
the
huge
metropolis
of
England
who
rise
up
every
morning
not
knowing
where
their
heads
will
rest
at
night
,
so
there
are
a
multitude
who
shooting
arrows
over
houses
as
their
daily
business
,
never
know
on
whom
they
fall
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
might
have
passed
Tom
Pinch
ten
thousand
times
;
might
even
have
been
quite
familiar
with
his
face
,
his
name
,
pursuits
,
and
character
;
yet
never
once
have
dreamed
that
Tom
had
any
interest
in
any
act
or
mystery
of
his
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
might
have
done
the
like
by
him
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
same
private
man
out
of
all
the
men
alive
,
was
in
the
mind
of
each
at
the
same
moment
;
was
prominently
connected
though
in
a
different
manner
,
with
the
day
's
adventures
of
both
;
and
formed
,
when
they
passed
each
other
in
the
street
,
the
one
absorbing
topic
of
their
thoughts
.
   
<EOS>
Why
Tom
had
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
in
his
mind
requires
no
explanation
.
<EOS>
Why
Mr
Nadgett
should
have
had
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
in
his
,
is
quite
another
thing
.
   
<EOS>
But
,
somehow
or
other
,
that
amiable
and
worthy
orphan
had
become
a
part
of
the
mystery
of
Mr
Nadgett
's
existence
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
took
an
interest
in
his
lightest
proceedings
;
and
it
never
flagged
or
wavered
.
 
<EOS>
He
watched
him
in
and
out
of
the
Assurance
Office
,
where
he
was
now
formally
installed
as
a
Director
;
he
dogged
his
footsteps
in
the
streets
;
he
stood
listening
when
he
talked
;
he
sat
in
coffee
-
rooms
entering
his
name
in
the
great
pocket
-
book
,
over
and
over
again
;
he
wrote
letters
to
himself
about
him
constantly
;
and
,
when
he
found
them
in
his
pocket
,
put
them
in
the
fire
,
with
such
distrust
and
caution
that
he
would
bend
down
to
watch
the
crumpled
tinder
while
it
floated
upwards
,
as
if
his
mind
misgave
him
,
that
the
mystery
it
had
contained
might
come
out
at
the
chimney
-
pot
.
   
<EOS>
And
yet
all
this
was
quite
a
secret
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
kept
it
to
himself
,
and
kept
it
close
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
had
no
more
idea
that
Mr
Nadgett
's
eyes
were
fixed
on
him
,
than
he
had
that
he
was
living
under
the
daily
inspection
and
report
of
a
whole
order
of
Jesuits
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
Mr
Nadgett
's
eyes
were
seldom
fixed
on
any
other
objects
than
the
ground
,
the
clock
,
or
the
fire
;
but
every
button
on
his
coat
might
have
been
an
eye
,
he
saw
so
much
.
   
<EOS>
The
secret
manner
of
the
man
disarmed
suspicion
in
this
wise
;
suggesting
,
not
that
he
was
watching
any
one
,
but
that
he
thought
some
other
man
was
watching
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
about
so
stealthily
,
and
kept
himself
so
wrapped
up
in
himself
,
that
the
whole
object
of
his
life
appeared
to
be
,
to
avoid
notice
and
preserve
his
own
mystery
.
<EOS>
Jonas
sometimes
saw
him
in
the
street
,
hovering
in
the
outer
office
,
waiting
at
the
door
for
the
man
who
never
came
,
or
slinking
off
with
his
immovable
face
and
drooping
head
,
and
the
one
beaver
glove
dangling
before
him
;
but
he
would
as
soon
have
thought
of
the
cross
upon
the
top
of
St.
Paul
's
Cathedral
taking
note
of
what
he
did
,
or
slowly
winding
a
great
net
about
his
feet
,
as
of
Nadgett
's
being
engaged
in
such
an
occupation
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
made
a
mysterious
change
about
this
time
in
his
mysterious
life
:
for
whereas
he
had
,
until
now
,
been
first
seen
every
morning
coming
down
Cornhill
,
so
exactly
like
the
Nadgett
of
the
day
before
as
to
occasion
a
popular
belief
that
he
never
went
to
bed
or
took
his
clothes
off
,
he
was
now
first
seen
in
Holborn
,
coming
out
of
Kingsgate
Street
;
and
it
was
soon
discovered
that
he
actually
went
every
morning
to
a
barber
's
shop
in
that
street
to
get
shaved
;
and
that
the
barber
's
name
was
Sweedlepipe
.
 
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
make
appointments
with
the
man
who
never
came
,
to
meet
him
at
this
barber
's
;
for
he
would
frequently
take
long
spells
of
waiting
in
the
shop
,
and
would
ask
for
pen
and
ink
,
and
pull
out
his
pocket
-
book
,
and
be
very
busy
over
it
for
an
hour
at
a
time
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
and
Mr
Sweedlepipe
had
many
deep
discoursings
on
the
subject
of
this
mysterious
customer
;
but
they
usually
agreed
that
he
had
speculated
too
much
and
was
keeping
out
of
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
He
must
have
appointed
the
man
who
never
kept
his
word
,
to
meet
him
at
another
new
place
too
;
for
one
day
he
was
found
,
for
the
first
time
,
by
the
waiter
at
the
Mourning
Coach
-
Horse
,
the
House
-
of
-
call
for
Undertakers
,
down
in
the
City
there
,
making
figures
with
a
pipe
-
stem
in
the
sawdust
of
a
clean
spittoon
;
and
declining
to
call
for
anything
,
on
the
ground
of
expecting
a
gentleman
presently
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
gentleman
was
not
honourable
enough
to
keep
his
engagement
,
he
came
again
next
day
,
with
his
pocket
-
book
in
such
a
state
of
distention
that
he
was
regarded
in
the
bar
as
a
man
of
large
property
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
he
repeated
his
visits
every
day
,
and
had
so
much
writing
to
do
,
that
he
made
nothing
of
emptying
a
capacious
leaden
inkstand
in
two
sittings
.
 
<EOS>
Although
he
never
talked
much
,
still
,
by
being
there
among
the
regular
customers
,
he
made
their
acquaintance
.
 
<EOS>
and
in
course
of
time
became
quite
intimate
with
Mr
Tacker
,
Mr
Mould
's
foreman
;
and
even
with
Mr
Mould
himself
,
who
openly
said
he
was
a
long
-
headed
man
,
a
dry
one
,
a
salt
fish
,
a
deep
file
,
a
rasper
;
and
made
him
the
subject
of
many
other
flattering
encomiums
.
   
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
,
too
,
he
told
the
people
at
the
Assurance
Office
,
in
his
own
mysterious
way
,
that
there
was
something
wrong
(
secretly
wrong
,
of
course
)
in
his
liver
,
and
that
he
feared
he
must
put
himself
under
the
doctor
's
hands
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
delivered
over
to
Jobling
upon
this
representation
;
and
though
Jobling
could
not
find
out
where
his
liver
was
wrong
,
wrong
Mr
Nadgett
said
it
was
;
observing
that
it
was
his
own
liver
,
and
he
hoped
he
ought
to
know
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
he
became
Mr
Jobling
's
patient
;
and
detailing
his
symptoms
in
his
slow
and
secret
way
,
was
in
and
out
of
that
gentleman
's
room
a
dozen
times
a
day
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
pursued
all
these
occupations
at
once
;
and
all
steadily
;
and
all
secretly
;
and
never
slackened
in
his
watchfulness
of
everything
that
Mr
Jonas
said
and
did
,
and
left
unsaid
and
undone
;
it
is
not
improbable
that
they
were
,
secretly
,
essential
parts
of
some
great
scheme
which
Mr
Nadgett
had
on
foot
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
on
the
morning
of
this
very
day
on
which
so
much
had
happened
to
Tom
Pinch
,
that
Nadgett
suddenly
appeared
before
Mr
Montague
's
house
in
Pall
Mall
<EOS>
---
he
always
made
his
appearance
as
if
he
had
that
moment
come
up
a
trap
---
when
the
clocks
were
striking
nine
.
 
<EOS>
He
rang
the
bell
in
a
covert
under
-
handed
way
,
as
though
it
were
a
treasonable
act
;
and
passed
in
at
the
door
,
the
moment
it
was
opened
wide
enough
to
receive
his
body
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
shut
it
immediately
with
his
own
hands
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
,
taking
up
his
name
without
delay
,
returned
with
a
request
that
he
would
follow
him
into
his
master
's
chamber
.
 
<EOS>
The
chairman
of
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Board
was
dressing
,
and
received
him
as
a
business
person
who
was
often
backwards
and
forwards
,
and
was
received
at
all
times
for
his
business
'
sake
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr
Nadgett
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
put
his
hat
upon
the
ground
and
coughed
.
 
<EOS>
The
boy
having
withdrawn
and
shut
the
door
,
he
went
to
it
softly
,
examined
the
handle
,
and
returned
to
within
a
pace
or
two
of
the
chair
in
which
Mr
Montague
sat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Any
news
,
Mr
Nadgett
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
we
have
some
news
at
last
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
to
hear
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
began
to
fear
you
were
off
the
scent
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
grows
cold
occasionally
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
sometimes
.
 
<EOS>
We
ca
n't
help
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
truth
itself
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
report
a
great
success
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
depends
upon
your
judgment
and
construction
of
it
,
"
was
his
answer
,
as
he
put
on
his
spectacles
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of
it
yourself
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
pleased
yourself
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
rubbed
his
hands
slowly
,
stroked
his
chin
,
looked
round
the
room
,
and
said
,
"
Yes
,
yes
,
I
think
it
's
a
good
case
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
disposed
to
think
it
's
a
good
case
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
go
into
it
at
once
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
.
"
   
Mr
Nadgett
picked
out
a
certain
chair
from
among
the
rest
,
and
having
planted
it
in
a
particular
spot
,
as
carefully
as
if
he
had
been
going
to
vault
over
it
,
placed
another
chair
in
front
of
it
;
leaving
room
for
his
own
legs
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
sat
down
in
chair
number
two
,
and
laid
his
pocket
-
book
,
very
carefully
,
on
chair
number
one
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
untied
the
pocket
-
book
,
and
hung
the
string
over
the
back
of
chair
number
one
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
drew
both
the
chairs
a
little
nearer
Mr
Montague
,
and
opening
the
pocket
-
book
spread
out
its
contents
.
 
<EOS>
Finally
he
selected
a
certain
memorandum
from
the
rest
,
and
held
it
out
to
his
employer
,
who
,
during
the
whole
of
these
preliminary
ceremonies
,
had
been
making
violent
efforts
to
conceal
his
impatience
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
n't
be
so
fond
of
making
notes
,
my
excellent
friend
,
"
said
Tigg
Montague
with
a
ghastly
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
consent
to
give
me
their
purport
by
word
of
mouth
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
word
of
mouth
,
"
said
Mr
Nadgett
gravely
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
never
know
who
's
listening
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
was
going
to
retort
,
when
Nadgett
handed
him
the
paper
,
and
said
,
with
quiet
exultation
in
his
tone
,
"
We
'll
begin
at
the
beginning
,
and
take
that
one
first
,
if
you
please
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
chairman
cast
his
eyes
upon
it
,
coldly
,
and
with
a
smile
which
did
not
render
any
great
homage
to
the
slow
and
methodical
habits
of
his
spy
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
read
half
-
a
-
dozen
lines
when
the
expression
of
his
face
began
to
change
,
and
before
he
had
finished
the
perusal
of
the
paper
,
it
was
full
of
grave
and
serious
attention
.
   
<EOS>
"
Number
Two
,
"
said
Mr
Nadgett
,
handing
him
another
,
and
receiving
back
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
"
Read
Number
Two
,
sir
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
more
interest
as
you
go
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tigg
Montague
leaned
backward
in
his
chair
,
and
cast
upon
his
emissary
such
a
look
of
vacant
wonder
(
not
unmingled
with
alarm
)
,
that
Mr
Nadgett
considered
it
necessary
to
repeat
the
request
he
had
already
twice
preferred
;
with
the
view
to
recalling
his
attention
to
the
point
in
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Profiting
by
the
hint
,
Mr
Montague
went
on
with
Number
Two
,
and
afterwards
with
Numbers
Three
,
and
Four
,
and
Five
,
and
so
on
.
   
<EOS>
These
documents
were
all
in
Mr
Nadgett
's
writing
,
and
were
apparently
a
series
of
memoranda
,
jotted
down
from
time
to
time
upon
the
backs
of
old
letters
,
or
any
scrap
of
paper
that
came
first
to
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Loose
straggling
scrawls
they
were
,
and
of
very
uninviting
exterior
;
but
they
had
weighty
purpose
in
them
,
if
the
chairman
's
face
were
any
index
to
the
character
of
their
contents
.
   
<EOS>
The
progress
of
Mr
Nadgett
's
secret
satisfaction
arising
out
of
the
effect
they
made
,
kept
pace
with
the
emotions
of
the
reader
.
 
<EOS>
At
first
,
Mr
Nadgett
sat
with
his
spectacles
low
down
upon
his
nose
,
looking
over
them
at
his
employer
,
and
nervously
rubbing
his
hands
.
<EOS>
After
a
little
while
,
he
changed
his
posture
in
his
chair
for
one
of
greater
ease
,
and
leisurely
perused
the
next
document
he
held
ready
as
if
an
occasional
glance
at
his
employer
's
face
were
now
enough
and
all
occasion
for
anxiety
or
doubt
were
gone
.
 
<EOS>
And
finally
he
rose
and
looked
out
of
the
window
,
where
he
stood
with
a
triumphant
air
until
Tigg
Montague
had
finished
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
this
is
the
last
,
Mr
Nadgett
!
<EOS>
"
said
that
gentleman
,
drawing
a
long
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
,
sir
,
is
the
last
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
wonderful
man
,
Mr
Nadgett
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
a
pretty
good
case
,
"
he
returned
as
he
gathered
up
his
papers
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
cost
some
trouble
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
trouble
shall
be
well
rewarded
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
"
 
<EOS>
Nadgett
bowed
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
deeper
impression
of
Somebody
's
Hoof
here
,
than
I
had
expected
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
congratulate
myself
upon
your
being
such
a
good
hand
at
a
secret
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
nothing
has
an
interest
to
me
that
's
not
a
secret
,
"
replied
Nadgett
,
as
he
tied
the
string
about
his
pocket
-
book
,
and
put
it
up
.
<EOS>
"
It
always
takes
away
any
pleasure
I
may
have
had
in
this
inquiry
even
to
make
it
known
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
most
invaluable
constitution
,
"
Tigg
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
great
gift
for
a
gentleman
employed
as
you
are
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
Much
better
than
discretion
;
though
you
possess
that
quality
also
in
an
eminent
degree
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
I
heard
a
double
knock
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
put
your
head
out
of
window
,
and
tell
me
whether
there
is
anybody
at
the
door
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
softly
raised
the
sash
,
and
peered
out
from
the
very
corner
,
as
a
man
might
who
was
looking
down
into
a
street
from
whence
a
brisk
discharge
of
musketry
might
be
expected
at
any
moment
.
 
<EOS>
Drawing
in
his
head
with
equal
caution
,
he
observed
,
not
altering
his
voice
or
manner
:
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thought
so
,
"
Tigg
retorted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
go
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
had
better
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
though
!
 
<EOS>
No
!
remain
here
,
Mr
Nadgett
,
if
you
please
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
remarkable
how
pale
and
flurried
he
had
become
in
an
instant
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
to
account
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
His
eye
had
fallen
on
his
razors
;
but
what
of
them
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
was
announced
.
   
<EOS>
"
Show
him
up
directly
.
 
<EOS>
Nadgett
!
<EOS>
do
n't
you
leave
us
alone
together
.
<EOS>
Mind
you
do
n't
,
now
!
 
<EOS>
By
the
Lord
!
"
<EOS>
he
added
in
a
whisper
to
himself
:
"
We
do
n't
know
what
may
happen
.
"
   
<EOS>
Saying
this
,
he
hurriedly
took
up
a
couple
of
hair
-
brushes
,
and
began
to
exercise
them
on
his
own
head
,
as
if
his
toilet
had
not
been
interrupted
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
withdrew
to
the
stove
,
in
which
there
was
a
small
fire
for
the
convenience
of
heating
curling
-
irons
;
and
taking
advantage
of
so
favourable
an
opportunity
for
drying
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
produced
it
without
loss
of
time
.
 
<EOS>
There
he
stood
,
during
the
whole
interview
,
holding
it
before
the
bars
,
and
sometimes
,
but
not
often
,
glancing
over
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
Chuzzlewit
!
"
cried
Montague
,
as
Jonas
entered
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
rise
with
the
lark
.
 
<EOS>
Though
you
go
to
bed
with
the
nightingale
,
you
rise
with
the
lark
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
superhuman
energy
,
my
dear
Chuzzlewit
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
<EOS>
"
said
Jonas
,
with
an
air
of
langour
and
ill
-
humour
,
as
he
took
a
chair
,
"
I
should
be
very
glad
not
to
get
up
with
the
lark
,
if
I
could
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
a
light
sleeper
;
and
it
's
better
to
be
up
than
lying
awake
,
counting
the
dismal
old
church
-
clocks
,
in
bed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
light
sleeper
!
"
cried
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
what
is
a
light
sleeper
?
<EOS>
I
often
hear
the
expression
,
but
upon
my
life
I
have
not
the
least
conception
what
a
light
sleeper
is
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
said
Jonas
,
"
<EOS>
Who
's
that
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
old
what's
-
his
-
name
:
looking
(
as
usual
)
as
if
he
wanted
to
skulk
up
the
chimney
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
he
does
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
not
wanted
here
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
may
go
,
may
n't
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
let
him
stay
,
let
him
stay
!
"
said
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
mere
piece
of
furniture
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
making
his
report
,
and
is
waiting
for
further
orders
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
been
told
,
"
said
Tigg
,
raising
his
voice
,
"
not
to
lose
sight
of
certain
friends
of
ours
,
or
to
think
that
he
has
done
with
them
by
any
means
.
 
<EOS>
He
understands
his
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
need
,
"
replied
Jonas
;
"
for
of
all
the
precious
old
dummies
in
appearance
that
I
ever
saw
,
he
's
about
the
worst
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
afraid
of
me
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
belief
,
"
said
Tigg
,
"
that
you
are
Poison
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
Nadgett
!
<EOS>
give
me
that
towel
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
as
little
occasion
for
a
towel
as
Jonas
had
for
a
start
.
 
<EOS>
But
Nadgett
brought
it
quickly
;
and
,
having
lingered
for
a
moment
,
fell
back
upon
his
old
post
by
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
my
dear
fellow
,
"
resumed
Tigg
,
"
you
are
too
---
<EOS>
what
's
the
matter
with
your
lips
?
 
<EOS>
How
white
they
are
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
took
some
vinegar
just
now
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
had
oysters
for
my
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Where
are
they
white
?
"
<EOS>
he
added
,
muttering
an
oath
,
and
rubbing
them
upon
his
handkerchief
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
they
ARE
white
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Now
I
look
again
,
they
are
not
,
"
replied
his
friend
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
coming
right
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Say
what
you
were
going
to
say
,
"
cried
Jonas
angrily
,
"
and
let
my
face
be
!
 
<EOS>
As
long
as
I
can
show
my
teeth
when
I
want
to
<EOS>
(
and
I
can
do
that
pretty
well
)
,
the
colour
of
my
lips
is
not
material
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
true
,
"
said
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
only
going
to
say
that
you
are
too
quick
and
active
for
our
friend
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
too
shy
to
cope
with
such
a
man
as
you
,
but
does
his
duty
well
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
very
well
!
 
<EOS>
But
what
is
a
light
sleeper
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hang
a
light
sleeper
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Jonas
pettishly
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
interrupted
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
not
do
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
light
sleeper
ai
n't
a
heavy
one
,
"
said
Jonas
in
his
sulky
way
;
"
do
n't
sleep
much
,
and
do
n't
sleep
well
,
and
do
n't
sleep
sound
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
dreams
,
"
said
Tigg
,
"
and
cries
out
in
an
ugly
manner
;
and
when
the
candle
burns
down
in
the
night
,
is
in
an
agony
;
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
!
"
   
<EOS>
They
were
silent
for
a
little
time
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Jonas
spoke
:
   
"
Now
we
've
done
with
child
's
talk
<EOS>
,
I
want
to
have
a
word
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
have
a
word
with
you
before
we
meet
up
yonder
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
satisfied
with
the
state
of
affairs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Whatever

;

<EOS>
Chapter
39
.
<EOS>
Containing
some

of
the

;
with
strange
news
from
the
city
,
narrowly
concerning
tom
 
<EOS>
Pleasant
little
Ruth
!
 
<EOS>
Cheerful
,

,

,
quiet

Ruth
!
<EOS>
No
doll
's
house
ever
yielded
greater

to
its
young

,
than
little
Ruth
derived
from
her

over
the
triangular

and
the
two
small

.
   
<EOS>
To
be
Tom
's
housekeeper
.
 
<EOS>
What
dignity
!
 
<EOS>
Housekeeping
,
upon
the
commonest
terms
,
associated
itself
with
elevated
responsibilities
of
all
sorts
and
kinds
;
but
housekeeping
for
Tom
implied
the
utmost
complication
of
grave
trusts
and
mighty
charges
.
 
<EOS>
Well
might
she
take
the
keys
out
of
the
little
chiffonier
which
held
the
tea
and
sugar
;
and
out
of
the
two
little

down
by

,
where
the
very
black

got
mouldy
,
and
had
the
shine
taken
out
of
their
backs
by
envious

;
and
jingle

upon

before
Tom
's

when

!
 
<EOS>
Well
might
she
,
laughing

,
put
them
up
in
that

of
hers
with
a

!
 
<EOS>
For
it
was
such
a
grand
novelty
to
be

of
anything
,
that
if

been
the
most

,
she
might
have

just

,

.
   
<EOS>
So

,

,

about

of

,

Tom

.
 
<EOS>
And

,

"

"
as

after

,

grew
quite

,
and
rallied

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
Tom
,
"

,

"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

"

"

,
<EOS>
you

,
Tom
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
The
serious
way

;

Tom

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"

"

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>
So

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>
,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
And
Tom
was
right
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
precisely
that
sort
of
person
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
ought
to
have
been
able
to
resist
her
coaxing

;
and
nobody

to
try
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
she
never
seemed
to
know

was
her
manner

all
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
best
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
she
washed
up
the
breakfast
cups
,
chatting
away
the
whole
time
,
and
telling
Tom
all
sorts
of

about
the
brass
-
and
-
copper
founder
;
put
everything
in

;
made

room
as

;
<EOS>
---
you
must
not

half

hers
though
,

anything

---
and

's
old
hat
round
and

round

,
until

Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Then
she

,
all
in

,
that
Tom
's

was

;
and

,

with
her

,
and

;
never

into

,
although

was

pet

from
first
to
last
,
and
beating

with

upon

.
<EOS>
She
had
no

,
than

again
;
and

,

,

into
an
equally

;
intent

to
the

's
,
without

's
loss
of
time
;
and
inviting
Tom
to
come
and
see
the
steak
cut
,
with
his
own
eyes
.
<EOS>
As
to
Tom
,
he
was
ready
to
go
anywhere
;
so
off
they
trotted
,
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
as
nimbly
as
you
please
;
saying
to
each
other
what
a
quiet
street
<EOS>
it
was
to
lodge
in
,
and
how
very
cheap
,
and
what
an
airy
situation
.
   
<EOS>
To
see
the
butcher
slap
the
steak
,
before
he
laid
it
on
the
block
,
and
give
his
knife
a
sharpening
,
was
to
forget
breakfast
instantly
.
<EOS>
It
was
agreeable
,
too
<EOS>
---
it
really
was
---
to
see
him
cut
it
off
,
so
smooth
and
juicy
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
savage
in
the
act
,
although
the
knife
was
large
and
keen
;
it
was
a
piece
of
art
,
high
art
;
there
was
delicacy
of
touch
,
clearness
of
tone
,
skillful
handling
of
the
subject
,
fine
shading
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
triumph
of
mind
over
matter
;
quite
.
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
greenest
cabbage
-
leaf
ever
grown
in
a
garden
was
wrapped
about
this
steak
,
before
it
was
delivered
over
to
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
butcher
had
a
sentiment
for
his
business
,
and
knew
how
to
refine
upon
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
saw
Tom
putting
the
cabbage
-
leaf
into
his
pocket
awkwardly
,
he
begged
to
be
allowed
to
do
it
for
him
;
"
for
meat
,
"
he
said
with
some
emotion
,
"
must
be
humoured
,
not
drove
.
"
   
<EOS>
Back
they
went
to
the
lodgings
again
,
after
they
had
bought
some
eggs
,
and
flour
,
and
such
small
matters
;
and
Tom
sat
gravely
down
to
write
at
one
end
of
the
parlour
table
,
while
Ruth
prepared
to
make
the
pudding
at
the
other
end
;
for
there
was
nobody
in
the
house
but
an
old
woman
<EOS>
(
the
landlord
being
a
mysterious
sort
of
man
,
who
went
out
early
in
the
morning
,
and
was
scarcely
ever
seen
)
;
and
saving
in
mere
household
drudgery
,
they
waited
on
themselves
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
writing
,
Tom
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
his
sister
,
laying
her
hand
upon
his
shoulder
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
see
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Tom
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
and
looking
up
in
her
face
,
"
I
am
very
anxious
,
of
course
,
to
obtain
some
suitable
employment
;
and
before
Mr
Westlock
comes
this
afternoon
,
I
think
I
may
as
well
prepare
a
little
description
of
myself
and
my
qualifications
;
such
as
he
could
show
to
any
friend
of
his
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
do
the
same
for
me
,
Tom
,
also
,
"
said
his
sister
,
casting
down
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
dearly
like
to
keep
house
for
you
and
take
care
of
you
always
,
Tom
;
but
we
are
not
rich
enough
for
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
rich
,
"
returned
Tom
,
"
certainly
;
and
we
may
be
much
poorer
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
will
not
part
if
we
can
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
;
we
will
make
up
our
minds
Ruth
,
that
unless
we
are
so
very
unfortunate
as
to
render
me
quite
sure
that
you
would
be
better
off
away
from
me
than
with
me
,
we
will
battle
it
out
together
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
certain
we
shall
be
happier
if
we
can
battle
it
out
together
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
we
shall
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Think
,
Tom
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
tut
,
tut
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Tom
,
tenderly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
must
n't
cry
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
I
wo
n't
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
ca
n't
afford
it
,
dear
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
know
that
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
are
we
to
know
that
,
yet
awhile
,
and
without
trying
?
 
<EOS>
Lord
bless
my
soul
!
"
<EOS>
---
Tom
's
energy
became
quite
grand
---
"
there
is
no
knowing
what
may
happen
,
if
we
try
hard
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
am
sure
we
can
live
contentedly
upon
a
very
little
---
if
we
can
only
get
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
that
I
am
sure
we
can
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
we
must
try
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
friend
,
John
Westlock
,
is
a
capital
fellow
,
and
very
shrewd
and
intelligent
.
<EOS>
I
'll
take
his
advice
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
talk
it
over
with
him
---
both
of
us
together
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
like
John
very
much
,
<EOS>
when
you
come
to
know
him
,
I
am
certain
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
cry
,
do
n't
cry
.
 
<EOS>
YOU
make
a
beef
-
steak
pudding
,
indeed
!
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
giving
her
a
gentle
push
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
have
n't
boldness
enough
for
a
dumpling
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
WILL
call
it
a
pudding
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Mind
!
 
<EOS>
I
told
you
not
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
may
as
well
call
it
that
,
till
it
proves
to
be
something
else
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
are
going
to
work
in
earnest
,
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Aye
,
aye
!
 
<EOS>
That
she
was
.
 
<EOS>
And
in
such
pleasant
earnest
,
moreover
,
that
Tom
's
attention
wandered
from
his
writing
every
moment
.
 
<EOS>
First
,
she
tripped
downstairs
into
the
kitchen
for
the
flour
,
then
for
the
pie
-
board
,
then
for
the
eggs
,
then
for
the
butter
,
then
for
a
jug
of
water
,
then
for
the
rolling
-
pin
,
then
for
a
pudding
-
basin
,
then
for
the
pepper
,
then
for
the
salt
;
making
a
separate
journey
for
everything
,
and
laughing
every
time
she
started
off
afresh
.
 
<EOS>
When
all
the
materials
were
collected
she
was
horrified
to
find
she
had
no
apron
on
,
and
so
ran
UPstairs
by
way
of
variety
,
to
fetch
it
.
<EOS>
She
did
n't
put
it
on
upstairs
,
but
came
dancing
down
with
it
in
her
hand
;
and
being
one
of
those
little
women
to
whom
an
apron
is
a
most
becoming
little
vanity
<EOS>
,
it
took
an
immense
time
to
arrange
;
having
to
be
carefully
smoothed
down
beneath
---
<EOS>
Oh
,
heaven
,
what
a
wicked
little
stomacher
!
<EOS>
---
and
to
be
gathered
up
into
little
plaits
by
the
strings
before
it
could
be
tied
,
and
to
be
tapped
,
rebuked
,
and
wheedled
,
at
the
pockets
,
before
it
would
set
right
,
which
at
last
it
did
,
and
when
it
did
---
but
never
mind
;
this
is
a
sober
chronicle
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
there
were
her
cuffs
to
be
tucked
up
,
for
fear
of
flour
;
and
she
had
a
little
ring
to
pull
off
her
finger
,
which
would
n't
come
off
(
foolish
little
ring
!
)
;
and
during
the
whole
of
these
preparations
she
looked
demurely
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
at
Tom
,
from
under
her
dark
eyelashes
,
as
if
they
were
all
a
part
of
the
pudding
,
and
indispensable
to
its
composition
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
life
and
soul
of
him
,
Tom
could
get
no
further
in
his
writing
than
,
"
<EOS>
A
respectable
young
man
,
aged
thirty
-
five
,
"
and
this
,
notwithstanding
the
show
she
made
of
being
supernaturally
quiet
,
and
going
about
on
tiptoe
,
lest
she
should
disturb
him
;
which
only
served
as
an
additional
means
of
distracting
his
attention
,
and
keeping
it
upon
her
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
she
said
at
last
,
in
high
glee
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tom
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
now
?
"
said
Tom
,
repeating
to
himself
,
"
aged
thirty
-
five
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
look
here
a
moment
,
please
?
"
   
<EOS>
As
if
he
had
n't
been
looking
all
the
time
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
begin
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
wonder
why
I
butter
the
inside
of
the
basin
?
"
said
his
busy
little
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
more
than
you
do
,
I
dare
say
,
"
replied
Tom
,
laughing
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
I
believe
you
do
n't
know
anything
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
an
infidel
you
are
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
How
else
do
you
think
it
would
turn
out
easily
when
it
was
done
!
 
<EOS>
For
a
civil
-
engineer
and
land
-
surveyor
not
to
know
that
!
 
<EOS>
My
goodness
,
Tom
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
wholly
out
of
the
question
to
try
to
write
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
lined
out
"
respectable
young
man
,
aged
thirty
-
five
;
"
and
sat
looking
on
,
pen
in
hand
,
with
one
of
the
most
loving
smiles
imaginable
.
   
<EOS>
Such
a
busy
little
woman
as
she
was
!
 
<EOS>
So
full
of
self
-
importance
and
trying
so
hard
not
to
smile
,
or
seem
uncertain
about
anything
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
perfect
treat
to
Tom
to
see
her
with
her
brows
knit
,
and
her
rosy
lips
pursed
up
,
kneading
away
at
the
crust
,
rolling
it
out
,
cutting
it
up
into
strips
,
lining
the
basin
with
it
,
shaving
it
off
<EOS>
fine
round
the
rim
,
chopping
up
the
steak
into
small
pieces
,
raining
down
pepper
and
salt
upon
them
,
packing
them
into
the
basin
,
pouring
in
cold
water
for
gravy
,
and
never
venturing
to
steal
a
look
in
his
direction
,
lest
her
gravity
should
be
disturbed
<EOS>
;
until
,
at
last
,
the
basin
being
quite
full
and
only
wanting
the
top
crust
,
she
clapped
her
hands
all
covered
with
paste
and
flour
,
at
Tom
,
and
burst
out
heartily
into
such
a
charming
little
laugh
of
triumph
,
that
the
pudding
need
have
had
no
other
seasoning
to
commend
it
to
the
taste
of
any
reasonable
man
on
earth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
the
pudding
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
was
cutting
his
jokes
,
Tom
was
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
!
"
<EOS>
she
answered
,
holding
it
up
with
both
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
THAT
a
pudding
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
WILL
be
,
you
stupid
fellow
,
when
it
's
covered
in
,
"
returned
his
sister
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
still
pretending
to
look
incredulous
,
she
gave
him
a
tap
on
the
head
with
the
rolling
-
pin
,
and
still
laughing
merrily
,
had
returned
to
the
composition
of
the
top
crust
,
when
she
started
and
turned
very
red
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
started
,
too
,
for
following
her
eyes
,
he
saw
John
Westlock
in
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
goodness
,
John
!
 
<EOS>
How
did
YOU
come
in
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
pardon
,
"
said
John
---
"
your
sister
's
pardon
especially
---
<EOS>
but
I
met
an
old
lady
at
the
street
door
,
who
requested
me
to
enter
here
;
and
as
you
did
n't
hear
me
knock
,
and
the
door
was
open
,
I
made
bold
to
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
,
"
said
John
,
with
a
smile
,
"
why
any
of
us
should
be
disconcerted
at
my
having
accidentally
intruded
upon
such
an
agreeable
domestic
occupation
,
so
very
agreeably
and
skilfully
pursued
;
but
I
must
confess
that
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
,
will
you
kindly
come
to
my
relief
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
John
Westlock
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
sister
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
that
,
as
the
sister
of
so
old
a
friend
,
"
said
John
,
laughing
"
you
will
have
the
goodness
to
detach
your
first
impressions
of
me
from
my
unfortunate
entrance
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
sister
is
not
indisposed
perhaps
to
say
the
same
to
you
on
her
own
behalf
,
"
retorted
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
John
said
,
of
course
,
that
this
was
quite
unnecessary
,
for
he
had
been
transfixed
in
silent
admiration
;
and
he
held
out
his
hand
to
Miss
Pinch
;
who
could
n't
take
it
,
however
,
by
reason
of
the
flour
and
paste
upon
her
own
.
 
<EOS>
This
,
which
might
seem
calculated
to
increase
the
general
confusion
and
render
matters
worse
,
had
in
reality
the
best
effect
in
the
world
,
for
neither
of
them
could
help
laughing
;
and
so
they
both
found
themselves
on
easy
terms
immediately
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
delighted
to
see
you
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
think
of
sitting
down
on
one
condition
,
"
returned
his
friend
;
"
and
that
is
,
that
your
sister
goes
on
with
the
pudding
,
as
if
you
were
still
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
I
am
sure
she
will
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
On
one
other
condition
,
and
that
is
,
that
you
stay
and
help
us
to
eat
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
Poor
little
Ruth
was
seized
with
a
palpitation
of
the
heart
when
Tom
committed
this
appalling
indiscretion
,
for
she
felt
that
if
the
dish
turned
out
a
failure
,
she
never
would
be
able
to
hold
up
her
head
before
John
Westlock
again
.
 
<EOS>
Quite
unconscious
of
her
state
of
mind
,
John
accepted
the
invitation
with
all
imaginable
heartiness
;
and
after
a
little
more
pleasantry
concerning
this
same
pudding
,
and
the
tremendous
expectations
he
made
believe
to
entertain
of
it
,
she

,

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
"
A

"
---
The

<EOS>
That

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
She

,

;

,

always

,

"

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

"

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
oh

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

I

.
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
There

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

in

corner
,
with
MR
.
<EOS>
FIPS
painted
on
it
in
characters
which
were
meant
to
be
transparent
.
<EOS>
There
was
also
a
wicked
old
sideboard
hiding
in
the
gloom
hard
by
,
meditating
designs
upon
the
ribs

visitors
;
and
an
old
mat
,
worn

work
,
which
,
being
useless
as
a
mat
(
even
if
anybody

,

was

)
,
had

directed

into
another

,
and
regularly
tripped

Mr
Fips
's

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fips
,
hearing
a

between
a

hat

office

,
was
apprised
,
by
the
usual

"
rather

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dark

,
"
John

.
 
<EOS>
"
Not

in
<EOS>
,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom

the

;
but

Mr

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Walk

,
"

.
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
And
a
mighty
yellow

jaundiced
little
office
Mr

had
of

;
with

,

<EOS>
"

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Be

"

.
   
<EOS>
They

,

Mr

from

stuffing
<EOS>
whereof

drew

,

.
   
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Not

"

<EOS>

"
   
<EOS>
"
To

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
When

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

;

.
   
<EOS>
After

,

.
 
<EOS>
The

had

;
but
Mr
Fips
was
already
at
the
Temple
Gate
,
and
expressed

.
   
<EOS>
He
led
the
way
through
sundry

,
into

than

,
and
,

,

common

;
taking
from

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Stopping
before
a
door
upon

,
which

yellow

of

where
custom

have
placed
the

's

,

,
very

,
upon

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom

;

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
which

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
dust
lies
rather

here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Truly
,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Fips
might
have

so

to
say
,
very
thick
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
accumulated
everywhere
;
lay
deep
on
everything
,
and
in
one

,
where
a

shone

and

,

round
,

.
   
<EOS>
Dust
was

only

in

place
that
had

.
<EOS>
When
their

admitted
the

,
and

heavy
window
-

,
let
in
the
summer
air
,
he
showed
the
mouldering

,
discoloured

and

,

,

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
Close

door

stood

,

upon

;
as
if
the
last
man
who

there
had
paused
,

,

at
the
dreariness
he

behind
,
and
then
had

and

,
and

.
   
<EOS>
There
were
two

on
that

;
and

the
first

a

,

.
 
<EOS>
These

were

.
 
<EOS>
Neither

,

,

,

;
but

seemed

and

.
   
<EOS>
Movables

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
On

,
to

,

,

:

,

,

,

;

;
not

upon

which

.
<EOS>
To

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
That

,
I

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom

in

a

,

"
<EOS>
An
occupation
full

interest
for
me

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
will

,

,

Mr.
---
"
   
"
Until

---
"

as

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"

"
did

?
 
<EOS>
No
,

-

.
 
<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>
I

I

<EOS>
You
wo

?
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr

<EOS>
And

!
"
   
<EOS>
He
said
all
this
in
such
a
comfortable
,
easy
manner
,
that
Tom
could
only
rub

,

,
and

which
he
was
still
doing
,
when
Mr
Fips
walked

out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
's
gone
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
's
more
,
Tom
,
"
said
John
Westlock
,
seating

upon

,

,
"
he
is
evidently
not

back
again
;
so
here

,
installed
.
 
<EOS>
Under
rather
singular

,
Tom
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
such
an
odd
affair
throughout
,
and
Tom
standing
there
among
the
books
with

in

,

that

.
 
<EOS>
Tom

;
no

,

;
so
by

<EOS>
Tom
burst

;
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
When

,
for
give
John
an
inch
that
way
<EOS>
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>
The

a

's

,

,

<EOS>
It

,

"
Mr

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fips

;

;

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
why

?
 
<EOS>
Why

?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
,

in
that

,
adopted
this

(

)
readily
,

said

had

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

<EOS>
As

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

Fips
had

;

<EOS>
They

as

<EOS>
It

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

to

so
much

,
and
<EOS>
every

,

.
   
<EOS>
There

Ruth
's

when

in
the

,
but
there

pleasant

upon

,
and
a

shining
out

,
and

her

.
 
<EOS>
By
the
bye
,
how

they

!
 
<EOS>
Looking

for
but
<EOS>
a

,
when

,
you

,

<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>
But
,
wicked

,
too

<EOS>

,

!
   
<EOS>
The

;

nothing

how

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

Tom

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

.
 
<EOS>
However

the

,

<EOS>
Ruth

,
"
Oh
!

"
 
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
John

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

of

<EOS>
Tom
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
The
man
in

most

the

,
Every

(

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
Well

,

,

,

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Simple

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Let
the
record
stand
!
 
<EOS>
Thy
quality
of
soul
was
simple
,
simple
,
quite
contemptible
,
Tom
Pinch
!
    
<EOS>
Chapter
40
.
<EOS>
The
Pinches
make
a
new
acquaintance
,
and
have
fresh
occasion
for
surprise
and
wonder
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
ghostly
air
about
these
uninhabited
chambers
in
the
Temple
,
and
attending
every
circumstance
of
Tom
's
employment
there
,
which
had
a
strange
charm
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Every
morning
when
he
shut
his
door
at
Islington
,
he
turned
his
face
towards
an
atmosphere
of
unaccountable
fascination
,
as
surely
as
he
turned
it
to
the
London
smoke
;
and
from
that
moment
it
thickened
round
and
round

,
until
the
time
arrived
for
going
home
again
,
and
leaving

,
like

,
behind
.
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
Tom
,
every
morning
,
that
he
approached
this
ghostly
mist
,
and
became
enveloped
in
it
,
by
the
easiest

of
degrees
imaginable
.
 
<EOS>
Passing
from
the
roar
and
rattle
of
the

into
the
quiet
court
-
yards
of
the
Temple
,
was
the
first
preparation
.
<EOS>
Every
echo
of
his

sounded
to
him
like
a
sound
from
the
old
walls
and
pavements
,
wanting
language
to
relate
the
histories
of
the
dim
,

;
to
tell
him
what
lost

were
decaying
in

of
the
shut

,
from
whose
lattices
such
mouldy

came
breathing

as
he
went
past
;
to
whisper
of
dark
bins
of
rare
old

,
bricked
up

among
the

of
the
Halls
;
or

in

lower

yet

legends
of
the
cross
-
legged

,
whose
marble
effigies
were
in
the
church
.
 
<EOS>
With
the
first

of

upon
the

of
his
dusty
office
,
all
these
mysteries
increased
;
until
,
ascending
step
by
step
,
as
Tom
ascended
,
they
attained
their
full
growth
in
the
solitary

of
the
day
.
   
<EOS>
Every
day
brought
one
recurring
,
never
-
failing
source
of
speculation
.
 
<EOS>
This
employer
;
would
he
come
to
-
day
,
and
what
would
he
be
like
?
 
<EOS>
For
Tom
could
not
stop
short
at
Mr
Fips
;
he
quite
believed
that
Mr
Fips
had
spoken
truly
,
when
he
said
he
acted
for
another
;
and
what
manner
of
man
that
other
was
,
became
a
full
-
blown
flower
of
wonder
in
the
garden
of
Tom
's
fancy
,
which
never
faded
or
got
trodden
down
.
   
<EOS>
At
one
time
,
he
conceived
that
Mr
Pecksniff
,
repenting
of
his
falsehood
,
might
,
by
exertion
of
his
influence
with
some
third
person
have
devised
these
means
of
giving
him
employment
.
 
<EOS>
He
found
this
idea
so
insupportable
after
what
had
taken
place
between
that
good
man
and
himself
,
that
he
confided
it
to
John

on
the
very

;
informing
John
that
he
would
rather
ply
for
hire
as
a
porter
,
than
fall
so
low
in
his
own
esteem
as
to
accept
the
smallest

from
the
hands
of
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
But
John
assured
him
that
he
(
Tom
Pinch
)
was
far
from
doing
justice
to
the
character
of
Mr
Pecksniff
yet
,
if
he
supposed
that
gentleman
capable
of
performing
a
generous
action
;
and
that
he
might
make
his
mind
quite
easy
on
that
head
until
he
saw
the
sun
turn
green
and
the
moon
black
,
and
at
the
same
time
distinctly
perceived
with
the
naked
eye
,
twelve
first
-
rate
comets
careering
round
those
planets
.
 
<EOS>
In
which
unusual
state
of
things
,
he
said
(
and
not
before
)
,
it
might
become
not
absolutely
lunatic
to
suspect
Mr
Pecksniff
of
anything
so
monstrous
.
 
<EOS>
In
short
he
laughed
the
idea
down
completely
;
and
Tom
,
abandoning
it
,
was
thrown
upon
his
beam
-
ends
again
,
for
some
other
solution
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Tom
attended
to
his
duties
daily
,
and
made
considerable
progress
with
the
books
;
which
were
already
reduced
to
some
sort
of
order
,
and
made
a
great
appearance
in
his
fairly
-
written
catalogue
.
 
<EOS>
During
his
business
hours
,
he
indulged
himself
occasionally
with
snatches
of
reading
;
which
were
often
,
indeed
,
a
necessary
part
of
his
pursuit
;
and
as
he
usually
made
bold
to
carry
one
of
these
goblin
volumes
home
at
night
(
always
bringing
it
back
again
next
morning
,
in
case
his
strange
employer
should
appear
and
ask
what
had
become
of
it
)
,
he
led
a
happy
,
quiet
,
studious
kind
of
life
,
after
his
own
heart
.
   
<EOS>
But
though
the
books
were
never
so
interesting
,
and
never
so
full
of
novelty
to
Tom
,
they
could
not
so
enchain
him
,
in
those
mysterious
chambers
,
as
to
render
him
unconscious
,
for
a
moment
,
of
the
lightest
sound
.
 
<EOS>
Any
footstep
on
the
flags
without
set
him
listening
attentively
and
when
it
turned
into
that
house
,
and
came
up
,
up
,
up
the
stairs
,
he
always
thought
with
a
beating
heart
,
"
Now
I
am
coming
face
to
face
with
him
at
last
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
no
footstep
ever
passed
the
floor
immediately
below
:
except
his
own
.
   
<EOS>
This
mystery
and
loneliness
engendered
fancies
in
Tom
's
mind
,
the
folly
of
which
his
common
sense
could
readily
discover
,
but
which
his
common
sense
was
quite
unable
to
keep
away
,
notwithstanding
;
that
quality
being
with
most
of
us
,
in
such
a
case
,
like
the
old
French
Police
---
quick
at
detection
,
but
very
weak
as
a
preventive
power
.
 
<EOS>
Misgivings
,
undefined
,
absurd
,
inexplicable
,
that
there
was
some
one
hiding
in
the
inner
room
---
walking
softly
overhead
,
peeping
in
through
the
door
-
chink
,
doing
something
stealthy
,
anywhere
where
he
was
not
---
came
over
him
a
hundred
times
a
day
,
making
it
pleasant
to
throw
up
the
sash
,
and
hold
communication
even
with
the
sparrows
who
had
built
in
the
roof
and
water
-
spout
,
and
were
twittering
about
the
windows
all
day
long
.
   
<EOS>
He
sat
with
the
outer
door
wide
open
,
at
all
times
,
that
he
might
hear
the
footsteps
as
they
entered
,
and
turned
off
into
the
chambers
on
the
lower
floor
.
 
<EOS>
He
formed
odd
prepossessions
too
,
regarding
strangers
in
the
streets
;
and
would
say
within
himself
of
such
or
such
a
man
,
who
struck
him
as
having
anything
uncommon
in
his
dress
or
aspect
,
"
I
should
n't
wonder
,
now
,
if
that
were
he
!
"
 
<EOS>
But
it
never
was
.
 
<EOS>
And
though
he
actually
turned
back
and
followed
more
than
one
of
these
suspected
individuals
,
in
a
singular
belief
that
they
were
going
to
the
place
he
was
then
upon
his
way
from
,
he
never
got
any
other
satisfaction
by
it
,
than
the
satisfaction
of
knowing
it
was
not
the
case
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fips
,
of
Austin
Friars
,
rather
deepened
than
illumined
the
obscurity
of
his
position
;
for
on
the
first
occasion
of
Tom
's
waiting
on
him
to
receive
his
weekly
pay
,
he
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
by
the
bye
,
Mr
Pinch
,
you
need
n't
mention
it
,
if
you
please
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
thought
he
was
going
to
tell
him
a
secret
;
so
he
said
that
he
would
n't
on
any
account
,
and
that
Mr
Fips
might
entirely
depend
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
Mr
Fips
said
"
Very
good
,
"
in
reply
,
and
nothing
more
,
Tom
prompted
him
:
   
"
Not
on
any
account
,
"
repeated
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Fips
repeated
:
"
Very
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
going
to
say
"
---
Tom
hinted
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
no
!
"
cried
Fips
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
However
,
seeing
Tom
confused
,
he
added
,
"
I
mean
that
you
need
n't
mention
any
particulars
about
your
place
of
employment
,
to
people
generally
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
find
it
better
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
had
the
pleasure
of
seeing
my
employer
yet
,
sir
,
"
observed
Tom
,
putting
his
week
's
salary
in
his
pocket
.
   
<EOS>
"
Have
n't
you
?
"
said
Fips
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
suppose
you
have
though
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
thank
him
,
and
to
know
that
what
I
have
done
so
far
,
is
done
to
his
satisfaction
,
"
faltered
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
right
,
"
said
Mr
Fips
,
with
a
yawn
.
 
<EOS>
"
Highly
creditable
.
 
<EOS>
Very
proper
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
hastily
resolved
to
try
him
on
another
tack
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
soon
have
finished
with
the
books
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
that
will
not
terminate
my
engagement
,
sir
,
or
render
me
useless
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
!
"
retorted
Fips
.
 
<EOS>
"
Plenty
to
do
;
plen
-
ty
to
do
!
 
<EOS>
Be
careful
how
you
go
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
rather
dark
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
very
utmost
extent
of
information
Tom
could
ever
get
out
of
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
So
it
was
dark
enough
in
all
conscience
;
and
if
Mr
Fips
expressed
himself
with
a
double
meaning
,
he
had
good
reason
for
doing
so
.
   
<EOS>
But
now
a
circumstance
occurred
,
which
helped
to
divert
Tom
's
thoughts
from
even
this
mystery
,
and
to
divide
them
between
it
and
a
new
channel
,
which
was
a
very
Nile
in
itself
.
   
<EOS>
The
way
it
came
about
was
this
.
 
<EOS>
Having
always
been
an
early
riser
and
having
now
no
organ
to
engage
him
in
sweet
converse
every
morning
,
it
was
his
habit
to
take
a
long
walk
before
going
to
the
Temple
;
and
naturally
inclining
,
as
a
stranger
,
towards
those
parts
of
the
town
which
were
conspicuous
for
the
life
and
animation
pervading
them
,
he
became
a
great
frequenter
of
the
market
-
places
,
bridges
,
quays
,
and
especially
the
steam
-
boat
wharves
;
for
it
was
very
lively
and
fresh
to
see
the
people
hurrying
away
upon
their
many
schemes
of
business
or
pleasure
,
and
it
made
Tom
glad
to
think
that
there
was
that
much
change
and
freedom
in
the
monotonous
routine
of
city
lives
.
   
<EOS>
In
most
of
these
morning
excursions
<EOS>
Ruth
accompanied
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
their
landlord
was
always
up
and
away
at
his
business
(
whatever
that
might
be
,
no
one
seemed
to
know
)
at
a
very
early
hour
,
the
habits
of
the
people
of
the
house
in
which
they
lodged
corresponded
with
their
own
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
they
had
often
finished
their
breakfast
,
and
were
out
in
the
summer
air
,
by
seven
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
two
hours
'
stroll
they
parted
at
some
convenient
point
;
Tom
going
to
the
Temple
,
and
his
sister
returning
home
,
as
methodically
as
you
please
.
   
<EOS>
Many
and
many
a
pleasant
stroll
they
had
in
Covent
Garden
Market
;
snuffing
up
the
perfume
of
the
fruits
and
flowers
,
wondering
at
the
magnificence
of
the
pineapples
and
melons
;
catching
glimpses
down
side
avenues
,
of
rows
and
rows
of
old
women
,
seated
on
inverted
baskets
,
shelling
peas
;
looking
unutterable
things
at
the
fat
bundles
of
asparagus
with
which
the
dainty
shops
were
fortified
as
with
a
breastwork
;
and
,
at
the
herbalist
's
doors
,
gratefully
inhaling
scents
as
of
veal
-
stuffing
yet
uncooked
,
dreamily
mixed
up
with
capsicums
,
brown
-
paper
,
seeds
,
even
with
hints
of
lusty
snails
and
fine
young
curly
leeches
.
 
<EOS>
Many
and
many
a
pleasant
stroll
they
had
among
the
poultry
markets
,
where
ducks
and
fowls
,
with
necks
unnaturally
long
,
lay
stretched
out
in
pairs
,
ready
for
cooking
;
where
there
were
speckled
eggs
in
mossy
baskets
,
white
country
sausages
beyond
impeachment
by
surviving
cat
or
dog
,
or
horse
or
donkey
;
new
cheeses
to
any
wild
extent
,
live
birds
in
coops
and
cages
,
looking
much
too
big
to
be
natural
,
in
consequence
of
those
receptacles
being
much
too
little
;
rabbits
,
alive
and
dead
,
innumerable
.
 
<EOS>
Many
a
pleasant
stroll
they
had
among
the
cool
,
refreshing
,
silvery
fish
-
stalls
,
with
a
kind
of
moonlight
effect
about
their
stock
-
in
-
trade
,
excepting
always
for
the
ruddy
lobsters
.
<EOS>
Many
a
pleasant
stroll
among
the
waggon
-
loads
of
fragrant
hay
,
beneath
which
dogs
and
tired
waggoners
lay
fast
asleep
,
oblivious
of
the
pieman
and
the
public
-
house
.
 
<EOS>
But
never
half
so
good
a
stroll
as
down
among
the
steamboats
on
a
bright
morning
.
   
<EOS>
There
they
lay
,
alongside
of
each
other
;
hard
and
fast
for
ever
,
to
all
appearance
,
but
designing
to
get
out
somehow
,
and
quite
confident
of
doing
it
;
and
in
that
faith
shoals
of
passengers
,
and
heaps
of
luggage
,
were
proceeding
hurriedly
on
board
.
 
<EOS>
Little
steam
-
boats
dashed
up
and
down
the
stream
incessantly
.
 
<EOS>
Tiers
upon
tiers
of
vessels
,
scores
of
masts
,
labyrinths
of
tackle
,
idle
sails
,
splashing
oars
,
gliding
row
-
boats
,
lumbering
barges
,
sunken
piles
,
with
ugly
lodgings
for
the
water
-
rat
within
their
mud
-
discoloured
nooks
;
church
steeples
,
warehouses
,
house
-
roofs
,
arches
,
bridges
,
men
and
women
,
children
,
casks
,
cranes
,
boxes
horses
,
coaches
,
idlers
,
and
hard
-
labourers
;
there
they
were
,
<EOS>
all
jumbled
up
together
,
any
summer
morning
,
far
beyond
Tom
's
power
of
separation
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
all
this
turmoil
there
was
an
incessant
roar
from
every
packet
's
funnel
,
which
quite
expressed
and
carried
out
the
uppermost
emotion
of
the
scene
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
appeared
to
be
perspiring
and
bothering
themselves
,
exactly
as
their
passengers
did
;
they
never
left
off
fretting
and
chafing
,
in
their
own
hoarse
manner
,
once
;
but
were
always
panting
out
,
without
any
stops
,
"
Come
along
do
make
<EOS>
haste
<EOS>
I
'm
very
nervous
come
along
<EOS>
oh
<EOS>
good
gracious
<EOS>
we
shall
never
get
there
how
late
you
are
<EOS>
do
make
haste
<EOS>
I
'm
off
directly
come
along
!
"
   
<EOS>
Even
when
they
had
left
off
,
and
had
got
safely
out
into
the
current
,
on
the
smallest
provocation
they
began
again
;
for
the
bravest
packet
of
them
all
,
being
stopped
by
some
entanglement
in
the
river
,
would
immediately
begin
to
fume
and
pant
afresh
,
"
oh
here
's
a
stoppage
<EOS>
what
's
the
matter
do
go
on
there
<EOS>
I
'm
in
