hurry
it
's
done
on
purpose
<EOS>
did
you
ever
<EOS>
oh
my
goodness
DO
go
on
here
!
"
<EOS>
and
so
,
in
a
state
of
mind
bordering
on
distraction
,
would
be
last
seen
drifting
slowly
through
the
mist
into
the
summer
light
beyond
,
that
made
it
red
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
's
ship
,
however
;
or
,
at
least
,
the
packet
-
boat
in
which
Tom
and
his
sister
took
the
greatest
interest
on
one
particular
occasion
;
was
not
off
yet
,
by
any
means
;
but
was
at
the
height
of
its
disorder
.
 
<EOS>
The
press
of
passengers
was
very
great
;
another
steam
-
boat
lay
on
each
side
of
her
;
the
gangways
were
choked
up
;
distracted
women
,
obviously
bound
for
Gravesend
,
but
turning
a
deaf
ear
to
all
representations
that
this
particular
vessel
was
about
to
sail
for
Antwerp
,
persisted
in
secreting
baskets
of
refreshments
behind
bulk
-
heads
,
and
water
-
casks
,
and
under
seats
;
and
very
great
confusion
prevailed
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
so
amusing
,
that
Tom
,
with
Ruth
upon
his
arm
,
stood
looking
down
from
the
wharf
,
as
nearly
regardless
as
it
was
in
the
nature
of
flesh
and
blood
to
be
,
of
an
elderly
lady
behind
him
,
who
had
brought
a
large
umbrella
with
her
,
and
did
n't
know
what
to
do
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
This
tremendous
instrument
had
a
hooked
handle
;
and
its
vicinity
was
first
made
known
to
him
by
a
painful
pressure
on
the
windpipe
,
consequent
upon
its
having
caught
him
round
the
throat
.
<EOS>
Soon
after
disengaging
himself
with
perfect
good
humour
,
he
had
a
sensation
of
the
ferule
in
his
back
;
immediately
afterwards
,
of
the
hook
entangling
his
ankles
;
then
of
the
umbrella
generally
,
wandering
about
his
hat
,
and
flapping
at
it
like
a
great
bird
;
and
,
lastly
,
of
a
poke
or
thrust
below
the
ribs
,
which
give
him
such
exceeding
anguish
,
that
he
could
not
refrain
from
turning
round
to
offer
a
mild
remonstrance
.
   
<EOS>
Upon
his
turning
round
,
he
found
the
owner
of
the
umbrella
struggling
on
tip
-
toe
,
with
a
countenance
expressive
of
violent
animosity
,
to
look
down
upon
the
steam
-
boats
;
from
which
he
inferred
that
she
had
attacked
him
,
standing
in
the
front
row
,
by
design
,
and
as
her
natural
enemy
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
very
ill
-
natured
person
you
must
be
!
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
The
lady
cried
out
fiercely
,
"
<EOS>
Where
's
the
pelisse
!
"
<EOS>
---
meaning
the
constabulary
---
and

red
shawl
over
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
!
"
cried
his
landlord
,
pointing
eagerly
again
,
"
not
there
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
way
;
the
other
way
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
the
cabin
steps
.
 
<EOS>
To
the
left
.
 
<EOS>
They
must
be
near
the
cabin
steps
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
the
cabin
steps
?
 
<EOS>
There
's
the
bell
ringing
already
!
 
<EOS>
DO
you
see
the
steps
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
<EOS>
said
Tom
,
"
you
're
right
.
 
<EOS>
Look
!
<EOS>
there
they
go
now
.
 
<EOS>
Is
that
the
gentleman
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Descending

this

,
with
the

of
a

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
very
man
!
<EOS>
"
returned
the
other
,
not
looking
at
what
Tom
pointed
out
,
however
,
but
at
Tom
's
own

.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
do
me
a
kindness
,

,
a

?
 
<EOS>
Will

put
that
letter
in

?
 
<EOS>
Only

!
 
<EOS>
He
expects

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
charged
to
do
it
by
my
employers
,
but
I
am
late
in
finding
him
,
and
,
not

as
young
as
I
have
been
,
should
never
be
able
to
make
my
way
on
board
and
off

deck
again
in
time
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
pardon
my
boldness
,
and
do
me
that
great
kindness
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
hands
shook
,
and
his
face
bespoke
the
utmost
interest
and

,
as
he
pressed
the
letter
upon
Tom
,
and
pointed
to
its
destination
,
like
the
Tempter
in

.
   
<EOS>
To
hesitate
in
the
performance
of
a
good
-
natured
or
compassionate
office
was
not
in
Tom
's
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
the
letter
;
whispered
Ruth
to
wait
till
he
returned
,
which
would
be
immediately
;
and
ran
down
the
steps
with
all
the
expedition
he
could
make
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
so
many
people
going
down
,
so
many
others
coming

,
such
heavy
goods
in
course
of
transit
to
and
fro
,
such
a
ringing
of
bell
,
blowing
-
off
of

,
and

of
men
's

,
that
he
had
much
ado
to
force
his
way
,
or
keep
in
mind
to
which
boat
he
was
going
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
reached
the
right
one
with
good
speed
,
and
going
down
the
cabin
-
stairs
immediately
,
described
the
object
of
his
search
standing
at
the
upper
end
of
the
saloon
,
with
his
back
towards
him
,
reading
some
notice
which
was
hung
against

wall
.
 
<EOS>
As
Tom
advanced
to
give
him
the
letter
,
he
started
,
hearing

,
and
turned
round
.
   
<EOS>
What
was
Tom
's
astonishment
to
find
in
him
the
man
with
whom
he
had
had
the
conflict
in
the
field
---
poor
Mercy
's

.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
!
   
<EOS>
Tom
understood
him
to
say
,
what
the
devil
did
he
want
;
but
it
was
not
easy
to
make

what
he
said
;
he
spoke
so

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
nothing
with
you
for
myself
,
"
said
Tom
;
<EOS>
"
I
was
asked
,
a
moment
since
,
to

letter
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
pointed

to
me
,
but
I
did
n't
know
you
in
your

.
 
<EOS>
Take
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
did
so
,
opened

,
and
read

writing
on
the
inside
.
 
<EOS>
The
contents
were
evidently
very
brief
;
not
more
perhaps
than
one

;
but
they
struck
upon

like

stone
from

.
 
<EOS>
He
reeled
back
as
he
read
.
   
<EOS>
His
emotion
was
so
different
from
any
Tom
had
ever
seen
before
that
he
stopped
involuntarily
.
 
<EOS>
Momentary
as
his
state
of
indecision
was
,
the
bell
ceased
while
he
stood
there
,
and
a
hoarse

calling
down

steps
,
inquired
if
there
was
any
to
go

?
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
cried
Jonas
,
"
I
---
I
am
coming
.
 
<EOS>
Give
me
time
.
 
<EOS>
Where
's
that
woman
!
 
<EOS>
Come
back
;
come
back
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
threw

another
door
as
he

,
and
dragged
,
rather

led
,
her
forth
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
pale

,
and
amazed
to
see
her
old

;
but
had
no

,
for

making

above
;
and
Jonas
drew

towards

.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
are

going
?
 
<EOS>
What

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
We
are

,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
changed
my

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Do

me
,
or
I
shall
be
the
death
of

,

some
one
else
.
 
<EOS>
Stop
there
!
 
<EOS>
Stop
!
 
<EOS>
We
're
for
the
shore
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
 
<EOS>
We
're
for
the
shore
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
turned
,
even

of

,
and
scowling

back

Tom
,
shook

at

.
 
<EOS>
There
are
not
many
human
faces
capable
of
the
expression
with
which
he
accompanied
that

.
   
<EOS>
He

her

,
and
Tom

.
 
<EOS>
Across

,
over
the
side
,
along

,
and
up

,

dragged

;
not
bestowing
any

on

,
but
gazing
upwards
all

among

.
 
<EOS>
Suddenly

turned
again
,
and
said

:
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is

?
"
   
<EOS>
Before

,
in

,

he
so
little
understood
,
a

approached
Tom
behind
,
and
saluted
Jonas
Chuzzlewit
by

.
 
<EOS>
He
has
a
gentleman
of
foreign

,
with
a
black

and

;
and
addressed

with

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Chuzzlewit
,
my

!
"
said

,
raising

in

to
Mrs
Chuzzlewit
,
"
I
ask
your
pardon
twenty
thousand

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
most
unwilling
to
interfere
between
you
and
a
domestic
trip
of
this
nature
<EOS>
(
always
so

,
I

,
although

myself
,

)
;
but
the

,

,
the

---
<EOS>
will

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
This

Mr
Montague
,
"
said

,
whom

.
   
<EOS>
"
The

,

,
"

,
"

;
but
as

friend
,
the
beehive
,
the
beehive
.
 
<EOS>
You
projected
a
short

,
my

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas

.
   
<EOS>
"
May

die
,
"
cried
Montague
,
"
but

!
 
<EOS>
Upon

I

.
 
<EOS>
But
that
confounded

of
ours
in
the
city
must

to
every

,
when

honey

;

.
 
<EOS>
Here

,
"

,
breaking

Mrs
Gamp
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
Does

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Well

,

!
"

,
"
not
forgettin
'

,

!
 
<EOS>
Wishin
'

"
<EOS>
(

"

,

me
a

fear
I

!
 
<EOS>
My

,
"
here

,

until

,
"

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
YOU

here

,

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,
there

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,

,
"

Gamp
,
dropping

,
"
as
no
bones
is
broke
by
me
and
Mrs
Harris
a
-
walkin
'
down
upon

.
 
<EOS>
Which
was

very
words
she
says
to
me
<EOS>
(

)

:
"
Sairey
,
"

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Harris
<EOS>
,
"
I

,
"

?
<EOS>
You

,

,
eight

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sairey
,
"
Mrs
Harris

,
"
contrairy
quite
.
"
 
<EOS>
And

knows

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
but
a
poor
woman
,
but
I
've
been
sought
after
,
sir
,
though
you
may

.
 
<EOS>
I
've
been
knocked

,
and
warned

by
a
many

,
in

Fire
.
 
<EOS>
I
goes

workin
'

my
bread
,
"
tis

,
but
I
maintains
my

,
with
your
kind

,
and
which
I

till

.
 
<EOS>
I
has
my
feelins
as
a
woman
,
sir
,
and
I
have
been
a
mother
likeways
;
but
touch
a
pipkin
as

,
or

on
what
I
eats

,
and

you

the

young
for'ard
hussy
of

-
gal

,
either

leaves
the

,

.
<EOS>
My

is
not

,

,
but
I

upon
.
 
<EOS>
Bless
the
babe
,
and
save
the
mother
<EOS>
,
is

,

;
but
I
makes

free
as
add

,
Do
n't

no
impogician
with
the
Nuss
,
for
she
will
not

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
concluded
by
drawing
her
shawl
tightly
over
herself
with
both
hands
,
and
,
as
usual
,
referring
to
Mrs
Harris
for
full
corroboration
of
these
particulars
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
that
peculiar
trembling
of
the
head
which
,
in
ladies
of
her
excitable
nature
,
may
be
taken
as
a
sure
indication
of
their
breaking
out
again
very
shortly
;
when
Jonas
made
a
timely

.
   
<EOS>
"
As
you
ARE
here
,
"
he
said
,
"
you
had
better
see
to
her
,
and
take
her
home
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
otherwise
engaged
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
more
;
but
looked
at
Montague
as
if
to
give
him
notice
that
he
was
ready
to
attend
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
take
you
away
,
"
said
Montague
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
gave
him
a
sinister
look
,
which
long
lived
in
Tom
's
memory
,
and
which
he
often
recalled
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
upon
my
life
,
"
said
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
make
it
necessary
?
"
   
<EOS>
With
the
same
dark
glance
as
before
,
Jonas
replied
,
after
a
moment
's
silence
:
   
<EOS>
"
The
necessity
is
none
of
my
making
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
brought
it
about
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
even
this
as
if
he
were
bound
,
and
in
the
other
's
power
,
but
had
a
sullen
and
suppressed
devil
within
him
,
which
he
could
not
quite
resist
.
 
<EOS>
His
very
gait
,
as
they
walked
away
together
,
was
like
that
of
a
fettered
man
;
but
,
striving
to
work
out
at
his
clenched
hands
,
knitted
brows
,
and
fast
-
set
lips
,
was
the
same
imprisoned
devil
still
.
   
<EOS>
They
got
into
a
handsome
cabriolet
which
was
waiting
for
them
and
drove
away
.
   
<EOS>
The
whole
of
this
extraordinary
scene
had
passed
so
rapidly
and
the
tumult
which
prevailed
around
as
so
unconscious
of
any
impression
from
it
,
that
,
although
Tom
had
been
one
of
the
chief
actors
,
it
was
like
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
had
noticed
him
after
they
had
left
the
packet
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
stood
behind
Jonas
,
and
so
near
him
,
that
he
could
not
help
hearing
all
that
passed
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
stood
there
,
with
his
sister
on
his
arm
,
expecting
and
hoping
to
have
an
opportunity
of
explaining
his
strange
share
in
this
yet
stranger
business
.
 
<EOS>
But
Jonas
had
not
raised
his
eyes
from
the
ground
;
no
one
else
had
even
looked
towards
him
;
and
before
he
could
resolve
on
any
course
of
action
,
they
were
all
gone
.
   
<EOS>
He
gazed
round
for
his
landlord
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
done
that
more
than
once
already
,
and
no
such
man
was
to
be
seen
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
still
pursuing
this
search
with
his
eyes
,
when
he
saw
a
hand
beckoning
to
him
from
a
hackney
-
coach
;
and
hurrying
towards
it
,
found
it
was
Merry
's
.
 
<EOS>
She
addressed
him
hurriedly
,
but
bent
out
of
the
window
,
that
she
might
not
be
overheard
by
her
companion
,
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
heaven
,
what
is
it
?
 
<EOS>
Why
did
he
tell
me
last
night
to
prepare
for
a
long
journey
,
and
why
have
you
brought
us
back
like
criminals
?
 
<EOS>
Dear
Mr
Pinch
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
clasped
her
hands
distractedly
,
"
be
merciful
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
this
dreadful
secret
is
,
be
merciful
,
and
God
will
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
any
power
of
mercy
lay
with
me
,
"
cried
Tom
,
"
trust
me
,
<EOS>
you
should
n't
ask
in
vain
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
far
more
ignorant
and
weak
than
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
withdrew
into
the
coach
again
,
and
he
saw
the
hand
waving
towards
him
for
a
moment
;
but
whether
in
reproachfulness
or
incredulity
or
misery
,
or
grief
,
or
sad
adieu
,
or
what
else
,
he
could
not
,
being
so
hurried
,
understand
.
 
<EOS>
SHE
was
gone
now
;
and
Ruth
and
he
were
left
to
walk
away
,
and
wonder
.
   
<EOS>
Had
Mr
Nadgett
appointed
the
man
who
never
came
,
to
meet
him
upon
London
Bridge
that
morning
?
 
<EOS>
He
was
certainly
looking
over
the
parapet
,
and
down
upon
the
steamboat
-
wharf
at
that
moment
.
 
<EOS>
It
could
not
have
been
for
pleasure
;
he
never
took
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
have
had
some
business
there
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
41
.
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
and
his
friend
,
arriving
at
a
pleasant
understanding
,
set
forth
upon
an
enterprise
 
<EOS>
The
office
of
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
Disinterested
Loan
and
Life
Assurance
Company
being
near
at
hand
,
and
Mr
Montague
driving
Jonas
straight
there
,
they
had
very
little
way
to
go
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
journey
might
have
been
one
of
several
hours
'
duration
,
without
provoking
a
remark
from
either
;
for
it
was
clear
that
Jonas
did
not
mean
to
break
the
silence
which
prevailed
between
them
,
and
that
it
was
not
,
as
yet
,
his
dear
friend
's
cue
to
tempt
them
into
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
thrown
aside
his
cloak
,
as
having
now
no
motive
for
concealment
,
and
with
that
garment
huddled
on
his
knees
,
sat
as
far
removed
from
his
companion
as
the
limited
space
in
such
a
carriage
would
allow
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
a
striking
difference
in
his
manner
,
compared
with
what
it
had
been
,
within
a
few
minutes
,
when
Tom
encountered
him
so
unexpectedly
on
board
the
packet
,
or
when
the
ugly
change
had
fallen
on
him
in
Mr
Montague
's
dressing
-
room
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
the
aspect
of
a
man
found
out
and
held
at
bay
;
of
being
baffled
,
hunted
,
and
beset
;
but
there
was
now
a
dawning
and
increasing
purpose
in
his
face
,
which
changed
it
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
gloomy
,
distrustful
,
lowering
;
pale
with
anger
and
defeat
;
it
still
was
humbled
,
abject
,
cowardly
and
mean
;
but
,
let
the
conflict
go
on
as
it
would
,
there
was
one
strong
purpose
wrestling
with
every
emotion
of
his
mind
,
and
casting
the
whole
series
down
as
they
arose
.
   
<EOS>
Not
prepossessing
in
appearance
at
the
best
of
times
,
it
may
be
readily
supposed
that
he
was
not
so
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
left
deep
marks
of
his
front
teeth
in
his
nether
lip
;
and
those
tokens
of
the
agitation
he
had
lately
undergone
improved
his
looks
as
little
as
the
heavy
corrugations
in
his
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
self
-
possessed
now
;
unnaturally
self
-
possessed
,
indeed
,
as
men
quite
otherwise
than
brave
are
known
to
be
in
desperate
extremities
;
and
when
the
carriage
stopped
,
he
waited
for
no
invitation
,
but
leapt
hardily
out
,
and
went
upstairs
.
   
<EOS>
The
chairman
followed
him
;
and
closing
the
board
-
room
door
as
soon
as
they
had
entered
,
threw
himself
upon
a
sofa
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
stood
before
the
window
,
looking
down
into
the
street
;
and
leaned
against
the
sash
,
resting
his
head
upon
his
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
not
handsome
,
Chuzzlewit
!
"
said
Montague
at
length
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
handsome
upon
my
soul
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
me
do
?
"
<EOS>
he
answered
,
looking
round
abruptly
;
"
What
do
you
expect
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Confidence
,
my
good
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
Some
confidence
!
<EOS>
"
said
Montague
in
an
injured
tone
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
 
<EOS>
You
show
great
confidence
in
me
,
"
retorted
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
I
not
?
"
said
his
companion
,
raising
his
head
,
and
looking
at
him
,
but
he
had
turned
again
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
I
not
?
 
<EOS>
Have
I
not
confided
to
you
the
easy
schemes
I
have
formed
for
our
advantage
;
OUR
advantage
,
mind
;
not
mine
alone
;
and
what
is
my
return
?
 
<EOS>
Attempted
flight
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
that
?
 
<EOS>
Who
said
I
meant
to
fly
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Who
said
?
 
<EOS>
Come
,
come
.
 
<EOS>
A
foreign
boat
,
my
friend
,
an
early
hour
,
a
figure
wrapped
up
for
disguise
!
 
<EOS>
Who
said
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
did
n't
mean
to
jilt
me
,
why
were
you
there
?
 
<EOS>
If
you
did
n't
mean
to
jilt
me
,
why
did
you
come
back
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
came
back
,
"
said
Jonas
,
"
to
avoid
disturbance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
wise
,
"
rejoined
his
friend
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
stood
quite
silent
;
still
looking
down
into
the
street
,
and
resting
his
head
upon
his
arms
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Chuzzlewit
,
"
said
Montague
,
"
notwithstanding
what
has
passed
I
will
be
plain
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
attending
to
me
there
?
 
<EOS>
I
only
see
your
back
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
that
notwithstanding
what
has
passed
,
I
will
be
plain
with
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
said
that
before
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
told
you
once
I
heard
you
say
it
.
<EOS>
Go
on
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
little
chafed
,
but
I
can
make
allowance
for
that
,
and
am
,
fortunately
,
myself
in
the
very
best
of
tempers
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
let
us
see
how
circumstances
stand
.
 
<EOS>
A
day
or
two
ago
,
I
mentioned
to
you
,
my
dear
fellow
,
that
I
thought
I
had
discovered
---
"
   
"
Will
you
hold
your
tongue
?
"
said
Jonas
,
looking
fiercely
round
,
and
glancing
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
"
said
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
"
Judicious
!
 
<EOS>
Quite
correct
!
 
<EOS>
My
discoveries
being
published
,
would
be
like
many
other
men
's
discoveries
in
this
honest
world
;
of
no
further
use
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
,
Chuzzlewit
,
how
ingenuous
and
frank
<EOS>
I
am
in
showing
you
the
weakness
of
my
own
position
!
 
<EOS>
To
return
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
,
or
think
I
make
,
a
certain
discovery
which
I
take
an
early
opportunity
of
mentioning
in
your
ear
,
in
that
spirit
of
confidence
which
I
really
hoped
did
prevail
between
us
,
and
was
reciprocated
by
you
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
there
is
something
in
it
;
perhaps
there
is
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
my
knowledge
and
opinion
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
yours
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
not
discuss
the
question
.
<EOS>
But
,
my
good
fellow
,
you
have
been
weak
;
what
I
wish
to
point
out
to
you
is
,
that
you
have
been
weak
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
desire
to
turn
this
little
incident
to
my
account
<EOS>
(
indeed
,
I
do
---
<EOS>
I
'll
not
deny
it
)
,
but
my
account
does
not
lie
in
probing
it
,
or
using
it
against
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
call
using
it
against
me
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Jonas
,
who
had
not
yet
changed
his
attitude
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
said
Montague
,
with
a
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
'll
not
enter
into
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Using
it
to
make
a
beggar
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Is
that
the
use
you
mean
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,
"
muttered
Jonas
,
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
use
in
which
your
account
DOES
lie
.
 
<EOS>
You
speak
the
truth
there
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
to
venture
<EOS>
(
it
's
a
very
safe
venture
)
<EOS>
a
little
more
with
us
,
certainly
,
and
to
keep
quiet
,
"
said
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
promised
me
you
would
;
and
you
must
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
it
plainly
,
Chuzzlewit
,
you
MUST
.
<EOS>
Reason
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
,
my
secret
is
worthless
to
me
:
and
being
so
<EOS>
,
it
may
as
well
become
the
public
property
as
mine
;
better
,
for
I
shall
gain
some
credit
,
bringing
it
to
light
.
 
<EOS>
I
want
you
,
besides
,
to
act
as
a
decoy
in
a
case
I
have
already
told
you
of
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mind
that
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
You
care
nothing
for
the
man
<EOS>
(
you
care
nothing
for
any
man
;
you
are
too
sharp
;
so
am
I
,
I
hope
)
;
and
could
bear
any
loss
of
his
with
pious
fortitude
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
tried
to
escape
from
the
first
consequence
.
 
<EOS>
You
can
not
escape
it
,
I
assure
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
shown
you
that
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
I
am
not
a
moral
man
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
the
least
in
the
world
affected
by
anything
you
may
have
done
;
by
any
little
indiscretion
you
may
have
committed
;
but
I
wish
to
profit
by
it
if
I
can
;
and
to
a
man
of
your
intelligence
I
make
that
free
confession
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
at
all
singular
in
that
infirmity
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
profits
by
the
indiscretion
of
his
neighbour
;
and
the
people
in
the
best
repute
,
the
most
.
 
<EOS>
Why
do
you
give
me
this
trouble
?
 
<EOS>
It
must
come
to
a
friendly
agreement
,
or
an
unfriendly
crash
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
former
,
you
are
very
little
hurt
.
 
<EOS>
If
the
latter
---
<EOS>
well
!
<EOS>
you
know
best
what
is
likely
to
happen
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
left
the
window
,
and
walked
up
close
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
look
him
in
the
face
;
it
was
not
his
habit
to
do
that
;
but
he
kept
his
eyes
towards
him
---
on
his
breast
,
or
thereabouts
---
and
was
at
great
pains
to
speak
slowly
and
distinctly
in
reply
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
a
man
in
a
state
of
conscious
drunkenness
might
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
Lying
is
of
no
use
now
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
DID
think
of
getting
away
this
morning
,
and
making
better
terms
with
you
from
a
distance
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
<EOS>
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
replied
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
natural
.
<EOS>
I
foresaw
that
,
and
provided
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
am
afraid
I
am
interrupting
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
the
devil
,
"
pursued
Jonas
,
with
a
still
greater
effort
,
"
you
made
choice
of
your
messenger
,
and
where
you
found
him
,
I
'll
not
ask
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
owed
him
one
good
turn
before
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
are
so
careless
of
men
in
general
,
as
you
said
you
were
just
now
,
you
are
quite
indifferent
to
what
becomes
of
such
a
crop
-
tailed
cur
as
that
,
and
will
leave
me
to
settle
my
account
with
him
in
my
own
manner
.
"
   
<EOS>
If
he
had
raised
his
eyes
to
his
companion
's
face
,
he
would
have
seen
that
Montague
was
evidently
unable
to
comprehend
his
meaning
.
<EOS>
But
continuing
to
stand
before
him
,
with
his
furtive
gaze
directed
as
before
,
and
pausing
here
only
to
moisten
his
dry
lips
with
his
tongue
,
the
fact
was
lost
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
might
have
struck
a
close
observer
that
this
fixed
and
steady
glance
of
Jonas
's
was
a
part
of
the
alteration
which
had
taken
place
in
his
demeanour
.
 
<EOS>
He
kept
it
riveted
on
one
spot
,
with
which
his
thoughts
had
manifestly
nothing
to
do
;
like
as
a
juggler
walking
on
a
cord
or
wire
to
any
dangerous
end
,
holds
some
object
in
his
sight
to
steady
him
,
and
never
wanders
from
it
,
lest
he
trip
.
   
<EOS>
Montague
was
quick
in
his
rejoinder
,
though
he
made
it
at
a
venture
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
difference
of
opinion
between
him
and
his
friend
on
THAT
point
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
least
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
great
discovery
,
"
Jonas
proceeded
,
with
a
savage
sneer
that
got
the
better
of
him
for
the
moment
,
"
may
be
true
,
and
may
be
false
.
 
<EOS>
Whichever
it
is
,
I
dare
say
I
'm
no
worse
than
other
men
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
,
"
said
Tigg
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
bit
.
 
<EOS>
We
're
all
alike
---
or
nearly
so
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
this
,
"
Jonas
went
on
to
say
;
"
is
it
your
own
?
<EOS>
You
'll
not
wonder
at
my
asking
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
own
!
"
repeated
Montague
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
returned
the
other
,
gruffly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
known
to
anybody
else
?
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
waver
about
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
Montague
,
without
the
smallest
hesitation
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
would
it
be
worth
,
do
you
think
,
unless
I
had
the
keeping
of
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Now
,
for
the
first
time
,
Jonas
looked
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
pause
,
he
put
out
his
hand
,
and
said
,
with
a
laugh
<EOS>
:
   
"
Come
!
<EOS>
make
things
easy
to
me
,
and
I
'm
yours
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
I
may
not
be
better
off
here
,
after
all
,
than
if
I
had
gone
away
this
morning
.
 
<EOS>
But
here
I
am
,
and
here
I
'll
stay
now
.
 
<EOS>
Take
your
oath
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
cleared
his
throat
,
for
he
was
speaking
hoarsely
and
said
in
a
lighter
tone
:
   
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
go
to
Pecksniff
?
 
<EOS>
When
?
 
<EOS>
Say
when
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Immediately
!
"
cried
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
can
not
be
enticed
too
soon
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
,
with
a
wild
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
some
fun
in
catching
that
old
hypocrite
.
 
<EOS>
I
hate
him
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
go
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
This
,
"
said
Montague
,
ecstatically
,
"
is
like
business
!
 
<EOS>
We
understand
each
other
now
!
 
<EOS>
To
-
night
,
my
good
fellow
,
by
all
means
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Come
with
me
,
"
cried
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
make
a
dash
;
go
down
in
state
,
and
carry
documents
,
for
he
's
a
deep
file
to
deal
with
,
and
must
be
drawn
on
with
an
artful
hand
,
or
he
'll
not
follow
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
him
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
ca
n't
take
your
lodgings
or
your
dinners
down
,
I
must
take
you
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
come
to
-
night
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
friend
appeared
to
hesitate
;
and
neither
to
have
anticipated
this
proposal
,
nor
to
relish
it
very
much
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
can
concert
our
plans
upon
the
road
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
must
not
go
direct
to
him
,
but
cross
over
from
some
other
place
,
and
turn
out
of
our
way
to
see
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
not
want
to
introduce
you
,
but
I
must
have
you
on
the
spot
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
the
man
,
I
tell
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
what
if
the
man
knows
me
?
"
said
Montague
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
know
!
"
cried
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
run
that
risk
with
fifty
men
a
day
!
 
<EOS>
Would
your
father
know
you
?
 
<EOS>
Did
I
know
you
?
 
<EOS>
Ecod
!
 
<EOS>
You
were
another
figure
when
I
saw
you
first
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
I
see
the
rents
and
patches
now
!
 
<EOS>
No
false
hair
then
,
no
black
dye
!
 
<EOS>
You
were
another
sort
of
joker
in
those
days
,
you
were
!
 
<EOS>
You
even
spoke
different
then
.
 
<EOS>
You
've
acted
the
gentleman
so
seriously
since
,
that
you
've
taken
in
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
should
know
you
,
what
does
it
matter
?
<EOS>
Such
a
change
is
a
proof
of
your
success
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
that
,
or
you
would
not
have
made
yourself
known
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
come
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
,
"
said
Montague
,
still
hesitating
,
"
I
can
trust
you
alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Trust
me
!
 
<EOS>
Ecod
,
you
may
trust
me
now
,
far
enough
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
try
to
go
away
no
more
---
no
more
!
"
 
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
and
added
in
a
more
sober
tone
,
"
I
ca
n't
get
on
without
you
.
 
<EOS>
Will
you
come
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
Montague
,
"
if
that
's
your
opinion
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
they
shook
hands
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
The
boisterous
manner
which
Jonas
had
exhibited
during
the
latter
part
of
this
conversation
,
and
which
had
gone
on
rapidly
increasing
with
almost
every
word
he
had
spoken
,
from
the
time
when
he
looked
his
honourable
friend
in
the
face
until
now
,
did
not
now
subside
,
but
,
remaining
at
its
height
,
abided
by
him
.
 
<EOS>
Most
unusual
with
him
at
any
period
;
most
inconsistent
with
his
temper
and
constitution
;
especially
unnatural
it
would
appear
in
one
so
darkly
circumstanced
;
it
abided
by
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
like
the
effect
of
wine
,
or
any
ardent
drink
,
for
he
was
perfectly
coherent
.
 
<EOS>
It
even
made
him
proof
against
the
usual
influence
of
such
means
of
excitement
;
for
,
although
he
drank
deeply
several
times
that
day
,
with
no
reserve
or
caution
,
he
remained
exactly
the
same
man
,
and
his
spirits
neither
rose
nor
fell
in
the
least
observable
degree
.
   
<EOS>
Deciding
,
after
some
discussion
,
to
travel
at
night
,
in
order
that
the
day
's
business
might
not
be
broken
in
upon
,
they
took
counsel
together
in
reference
to
the
means
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
being
of
opinion
that
four
horses
were
advisable
,
at
all
events
for
the
first
stage
,
as
throwing
a
great
deal
of
dust
into
people
's
eyes
,
in
more
senses
than
one
,
a
travelling
chariot
and
four
lay
under
orders
for
nine
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
did
not
go
home
;
observing
,
that
his
being
obliged
to
leave
town
on
business
in
so
great
a
hurry
,
would
be
a
good
excuse
for
having
turned
back
so
unexpectedly
in
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
wrote
a
note
for
his
portmanteau
,
and
sent
it
by
a
messenger
,
who
duly
brought
his
luggage
back
,
with
a
short
note
from
that
other
piece
of
luggage
,
his
wife
,
expressive
of
her
wish
to
be
allowed
to
come
and
see
him
for
a
moment
.
 
<EOS>
To
this
request
he
sent
for
answer
,
"
she
had
better
;
"
and
one
such
threatening
affirmative
being
sufficient
,
in
defiance
of
the
English
grammar
,
to
express
a
negative
,
she
kept
away
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
being
much
engaged
in
the
course
of
the
day
,
Jonas
bestowed
his
spirits
chiefly
on
the
doctor
,
with
whom
he
lunched
in
the
medical
officer
's
own
room
.
 
<EOS>
On
his
way
thither
,
encountering
Mr
Nadgett
in
the
outer
room
,
he
bantered
that
stealthy
gentleman
on
always
appearing
anxious
to
avoid
him
,
and
inquired
if
he
were
afraid
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
slyly
answered
,
"
No
,
but
he
believed
it
must
be
his
way
as
he
had
been
charged
with
much
the
same
kind
of
thing
before
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Montague
was
listening
to
,
or
,
to
speak
with
greater
elegance
,
he
overheard
,
this
dialogue
.
 
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Jonas
was
gone
he
beckoned
Nadgett
to
him
with
the
feather
of
his
pen
,
and
whispered
in
his
ear
.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
gave
him
my
letter
this
morning
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
lodger
,
sir
,
"
said
Nadgett
,
behind
the
palm
of
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
came
that
about
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
found
him
on
the
wharf
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Being
so
much
hurried
,
<EOS>
and
you
not
arrived
,
it
was
necessary
to
do
something
.
 
<EOS>
It
fortunately
occurred
to
me
,
that
if
I
gave
it
him
myself
I
could
be
of
no
further
use
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
blown
upon
immediately
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Nadgett
,
you
are
a
jewel
,
"
said
Montague
,
patting
him
on
the
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
your
lodger
's
name
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pinch
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Thomas
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
Montague
reflected
for
a
little
while
,
and
then
asked
:
   
"
From
the
country
,
do
you
know
?
"
   
"
From
Wiltshire
,
sir
,
he
told
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
parted
without
another
word
.
 
<EOS>
To
see
Mr
Nadgett
's
bow
when
Montague
and
he
next
met
,
and
to
see
Mr
Montague
acknowledge
it
,
anybody
might
have
undertaken
to
swear
that
they
had
never
spoken
to
each
other
confidentially
in
all
their
lives
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
,
Mr
Jonas
and
the
doctor
made
themselves
very
comfortable
upstairs
,
over
a
bottle
of
the
old
Madeira
and
some
sandwiches
;
for
the
doctor
having
been
already
invited
to
dine
below
at
six
o'clock
,
preferred
a
light
repast
for
lunch
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
advisable
,
he
said
,
in
two
points
of
view
:
 
First
,
as
being
healthy
in
itself
.
 
<EOS>
Secondly
as
being
the
better
preparation
for
dinner
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
you
are
bound
for
all
our
sakes
to
take
particular
care
of
your
digestion
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
my
dear
sir
,
"
said
the
doctor
smacking
his
lips
after
a
glass
of
wine
;
"
for
depend
upon
it
,
it
is
worth
preserving
.
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
in
admirable
condition
,
sir
;
perfect
chronometer
-
work
.
 
<EOS>
Otherwise
your
spirits
could
not
be
so
remarkable
.
 
<EOS>
Your
bosom
's
lord
sits
lightly
on
its
throne
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
as
what's
-
his
-
name
says
in
the
play
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
he
said
it
in
a
play
which
did
anything
like
common
justice
to
our
profession
,
by
the
bye
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
an
apothecary
in
that
drama
,
sir
,
which
is
a
low
thing
;
vulgar
,
sir
;
out
of
nature
altogether
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jobling
pulled
out
his
shirt
-
frill
of
fine
linen
,
as
though
he
would
have
said
,
"
This
is
what
I
call
nature
in
a
medical
man
,
sir
;
"
and
looked
at
Jonas
for
an
observation
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
not
being
in
a
condition
to
pursue
the
subject
,
took
up
a
case
of
lancets
that
was
lying
on
the
table
,
and
opened
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
doctor
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
"
I
always
take
'em
out
of
my
pocket
before
I
eat
.
 
<EOS>
My
pockets
are
rather
tight
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
had
opened
one
of
the
shining
little
instruments
;
and
was
scrutinizing
it
with
a
look
as
sharp
and
eager
as
its
own
bright
edge
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
steel
,
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
Good
steel
!
 
<EOS>
Eh
!
<EOS>
"
   
"
Ye
-
es
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
with
the
faltering
modesty
of
ownership
.
 
<EOS>
"
One
might
open
a
vein
pretty
dexterously
with
that
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
has
opened
a
good
many
in
its
time
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Jonas
looking
at
it
with
a
growing
interest
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
few
,
my
dear
sir
,
not
a
few
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
engaged
in
a
---
in
a
pretty
good
practice
,
I
believe
I
may
say
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
coughing
as
if
the
matter
-
of
-
fact
were
so
very
dry
and
literal
that
he
could
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
a
pretty
good
practice
,
"
repeated
the
doctor
,
putting
another
glass
of
wine
to
his
lips
.
   
<EOS>
"
Now
,
could
you
cut
a
man
's
throat
with
such
a
thing
as
this
?
"
demanded
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
certainly
,
certainly
,
if
you
took
him
in
the
right
place
,
"
returned
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
all
depends
upon
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
you
have
your
hand
now
,
hey
?
"
cried
Jonas
,
bending
forward
to
look
at
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
the
doctor
;
"
that
's
the
jugular
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
,
in
his
vivacity
,
made
a
sudden
sawing
in
the
air
,
so
close
behind
the
doctor
's
jugular
that
he
turned
quite
red
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Jonas
(
in
the
same
strange
spirit
of
vivacity
)
burst
into
a
loud
discordant
laugh
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
"
said
the
doctor
,
shaking
his
head
;
"
edge
tools
,
edge
tools
;
never
play
with
'em
.
 
<EOS>
A
very
remarkable
instance
of
the
skillful
use
of
edge
-
tools
,
by
the
way
,
occurs
to
me
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
case
of
murder
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
it
was
a
case
of
murder
,
committed
by
a
member
of
our
profession
;
it
was
so
artistically
done
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
was
that
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
sir
,
"
returned
Jobling
,
"
the
thing
lies
in
a
nutshell
.
 
<EOS>
A
certain
gentleman
was
found
,
one
morning
,
in
an
obscure
street
,
lying
in
an
angle
of
a
doorway
---
I
should
rather
say
,
leaning
,
in
an
upright
position
,
in
the
angle
of
a
doorway
,
and
supported
consequently
by
the
doorway
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
his
waistcoat
there
was
one
solitary
drop
of
blood
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
dead
and
cold
;
and
had
been
murdered
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Only
one
drop
of
blood
!
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
that
man
,
"
replied
the
doctor
,
"
had
been
stabbed
to
the
heart
.
<EOS>
Had
been
stabbed
to
the
heart
with
such
dexterity
,
sir
,
that
he
had
died
instantly
,
and
had
bled
internally
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
supposed
that
a
medical
friend
of
his
(
to
whom
suspicion
attached
)
had
engaged
him
in
conversation
on
some
pretence
;
had
taken
him
,
very
likely
,
by
the
button
in
a
conversational
manner
;
had
examined
his
ground
at
leisure
with
his
other
hand
;
had
marked
the
exact
spot
;
drawn
out
the
instrument
,
whatever
it
was
,
when
he
was
quite
prepared
;
and
---
"
   
"
And
done
the
trick
,
"
suggested
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
,
"
replied
the
doctor
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
quite
an
operation
in
its
way
,
and
very
neat
.
 
<EOS>
The
medical
friend
never
turned
up
;
and
,
as
I
tell
you
,
he
had
the
credit
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
did
it
or
not
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
say
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
having
had
the
honour
to
be
called
in
with
two
or
three
of
my
professional
brethren
on
the
occasion
,
and
having
assisted
to
make
a
careful
examination
of
the
wound
,
I
have
no
hesitation
in
saying
that
it
would
have
reflected
credit
on
any
medical
man
;
and
that
in
an
unprofessional
person
it
could
not
but
be
considered
,
either
as
an
extraordinary
work
of
art
,
or
the
result
of
a
still
more
extraordinary
,
happy
,
and
favourable
conjunction
of
circumstances
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
His
hearer
was
so
much
interested
in
this
case
,
that
the
doctor
went
on
to
elucidate
it
with
the
assistance
of
his
own
finger
and
thumb
and
waistcoat
;
and
at
Jonas
's
request
,
he
took
the
further
trouble
of
going
into
a
corner
of
the
room
,
and
alternately
representing
the
murdered
man
and
the
murderer
;
which
he
did
with
great
effect
.
 
<EOS>
The
bottle
being
emptied
and
the
story
done
,
Jonas
was
in
precisely
the
same
boisterous
and
unusual
state
as
when
they
had
sat
down
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
as
Jobling
theorized
,
his
good
digestion
were
the
cause
,
he
must
have
been
a
very
ostrich
.
   
<EOS>
At
dinner
it
was
just
the
same
;
and
after
dinner
too
;
though
wine
was
drunk
in
abundance
,
and
various
rich
meats
eaten
.
 
<EOS>
At
nine
o'clock
it
was
still
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
There
being
a
lamp
in
the
carriage
,
he
swore
they
would
take
a
pack
of
cards
,
and
a
bottle
of
wine
;
and
with
these
things
under
his
cloak
,
went
down
to
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Out
of
the
way
,
Tom
Thumb
,
and
get
to
bed
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
the
salutation
he
bestowed
on
Mr
Bailey
,
who
,
booted
and
wrapped
up
,
stood
at
the
carriage
door
to
help
him
in
.
   
<EOS>
"
To
bed
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
a
-
going
,
too
,
"
said
Bailey
.
   
<EOS>
He
alighted
quickly
,
and
walked
back
into
the
hall
,
where
Montague
was
lighting
a
cigar
;
conducting
Mr
Bailey
with
him
,
by
the
collar
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
a
-
going
to
take
this
monkey
of
a
boy
,
are
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Montague
.
   
<EOS>
He
gave
the
boy
a
shake
,
and
threw
him
roughly
aside
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
more
of
his
familiar
self
in
the
action
,
than
in
anything
he
had
done
that
day
;
but
he
broke
out
laughing
immediately
afterwards
,
and
making
a
thrust
at
the
doctor
with
his
hand
,
in
imitation
of
his
representation
of
the
medical
friend
,
went
out
to
the
carriage
again
,
and
took
his
seat
.
 
<EOS>
His
companion
followed
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Bailey
climbed
into
the
rumble
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
a
stormy
night
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
doctor
,
as
they
started
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
42
.
<EOS>
Continuation
of
the
enterprise
of
Mr
Jonas
and
his
friend
 
<EOS>
The
doctor
's
prognostication
in
reference
to
the
weather
was
speedily
verified
.
 
<EOS>
Although
the
weather
was
not
a
patient
of
his
,
and
no
third
party
had
required
him
to
give
an
opinion
on
the
case
,
the
quick
fulfilment
of
his
prophecy
may
be
taken
as
an
instance
of
his
professional
tact
;
for
,
unless
the
threatening
aspect
of
the
night
had
been
perfectly
plain
and
unmistakable
,
Mr
Jobling
would
never
have
compromised
his
reputation
by
delivering
any
sentiments
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
this
principle
in
Medicine
with
too
much
success
to
be
unmindful
of
it
in
his
commonest
transactions
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
hot
,
silent
nights
,
when
people
sit
at
windows
listening
for
the
thunder
which
they
know
will
shortly
break
;
when
they
recall
dismal
tales
of
hurricanes
and
earthquakes
;
and
of
lonely
travellers
on
open
plains
,
and
lonely
ships
at
sea
,
struck
by
lightning
.
 
<EOS>
Lightning
flashed
and
quivered
on
the
black
horizon
even
now
;
and
hollow
murmurings
were
in
the
wind
,
as
though
it
had
been
blowing
where
the
thunder
rolled
,
and
still
was
charged
with
its
exhausted
echoes
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
storm
,
though
gathering
swiftly
,
had
not
yet
come
up
;
and
the
prevailing
stillness
was
the
more
solemn
,
from
the
dull
intelligence
that
seemed
to
hover
in
the
air
,
of
noise
and
conflict
afar
off
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
very
dark
;
but
in
the
murky
sky
there
were
masses
of
cloud
which
shone
with
a
lurid
light
,
like
monstrous
heaps
of
copper
that
had
been
heated
in
a
furnace
,
and
were
growing
cold
.
 
<EOS>
These
had
been
advancing
steadily
and
slowly
,
but
they
were
now
motionless
,
or
nearly
so
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
carriage
clattered
round
the
corners
of
the
streets
,
it
passed
at
every
one
a
knot
of
persons
who
had
come
there
---
<EOS>
many
from
their
houses
close
at
hand
,
without
hats
---
to
look
up
at
that
quarter
of
the
sky
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
a
very
few
large
drops
of
rain
began
to
fall
,
and
thunder
rumbled
in
the
distance
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
sat
in
a
corner
of
the
carriage
with
his
bottle
resting
on
his
knee
,
and
gripped
as
tightly
in
his
hand
as
if
he
would
have
ground
its
neck
to
powder
if
he
could
.
 
<EOS>
Instinctively
attracted
by
the
night
,
he
had
laid
aside
the
pack
of
cards
upon
the
cushion
;
and
with
the
same
involuntary
impulse
,
so
intelligible
to
both
of
them
as
not
to
occasion
a
remark
on
either
side
,
his
companion
had
extinguished
the
lamp
.
 
<EOS>
The
front
glasses
were
down
;
and
they
sat
looking
silently
out
upon
the
gloomy
scene
before
them
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
clear
of
London
,
or
as
clear
of
it
as
travellers
can
be
whose
way
lies
on
the
Western
Road
,
within
a
stage
of
that
enormous
city
.
 
<EOS>
Occasionally
they
encountered
a
foot
-
passenger
,
hurrying
to
the
nearest
place
of
shelter
;
or
some
unwieldy
cart
proceeding
onward
at
a
heavy
trot
,
with
the
same
end
in
view
.
 
<EOS>
Little
clusters
of
such
vehicles
were
gathered
round
the
stable
-
yard
or
baiting
-
place
of
every
wayside
tavern
;
while
their
drivers
watched
the
weather
from
the
doors
and
open
windows
,
or
made
merry
within
.
<EOS>
Everywhere
the
people
were
disposed
to
bear
each
other
company
rather
than
sit
alone
;
so
that
groups
of
watchful
faces
seemed
to
be
looking
out
upon
the
night
AND
THEM
,
from
almost
every
house
they
passed
.
   
<EOS>
It
may
appear
strange
that
this
should
have
disturbed
Jonas
,
or
rendered
him
uneasy
;
but
it
did
.
 
<EOS>
After
muttering
to
himself
,
and
often
changing
his
position
,
he
drew
up
the
blind
on
his
side
of
the
carriage
,
and
turned
his
shoulder
sulkily
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
neither
looked
at
his
companion
,
nor
broke
the
silence
which
prevailed
between
them
,
and
which
had
fallen
so
suddenly
upon
himself
,
by
addressing
a
word
to
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
thunder
rolled
,
the
lightning
flashed
;
the
rain
poured
down
like
Heaven
's
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
Surrounded
at
one
moment
by
intolerable
light
,
and
at
the
next
by
pitchy
darkness
,
they
still
pressed
forward
on
their
journey
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
they
arrived
at
the
end
of
the
stage
,
and
might
have
tarried
,
they
did
not
;
but
ordered
horses
out
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
had
this
any
reference
to
some
five
minutes
'
lull
,
which
at
that
time
seemed
to
promise
a
cessation
of
the
storm
.
 
<EOS>
They
held
their
course
as
if
they
were
impelled
and
driven
by
its
fury
.
 
<EOS>
Although
they
had
not
exchanged
a
dozen
words
,
and
might
have
tarried
very
well
,
they
seemed
to
feel
,
by
joint
consent
,
that
onward
they
must
go
.
   
<EOS>
Louder
and
louder
the
deep
thunder
rolled
,
as
through
the
myriad
halls
of
some
vast
temple
in
the
sky
;
fiercer
and
brighter
became
the
lightning
,
more
and
more
heavily
the
rain
poured
down
.
 
<EOS>
The
horses
(
they
were
travelling
now
with
a
single
pair
)
plunged
and
started
from
the
rills
of
quivering
fire
that
seemed
to
wind
along
the
ground
before
them
;
but
there
these
two
men
sat
,
and
forward
they
went
as
if
they
were
led
on
by
an
invisible
attraction
.
   
<EOS>
The
eye
,
partaking
of
the
quickness
of
the
flashing
light
,
saw
in
its
every
gleam
a
multitude
of
objects
which
it
could
not
see
at
steady
noon
in
fifty
times
that
period
.
 
<EOS>
Bells
in
steeples
,
with
the
rope
and
wheel
that
moved
them
<EOS>
;
ragged
nests
of
birds
in
cornices
and
nooks
;
faces
full
of
consternation
in
the
tilted
waggons
that
came
tearing
past
;
their
frightened
teams
ringing
out
a
warning
which
the
thunder
drowned
;
harrows
and
ploughs
left
out
in
fields
;
miles
upon
miles
of
hedge
-
divided
country
,
with
the
distant
fringe
of
trees
as
obvious
as
the
scarecrow
in
the
bean
-
field
close
at
hand
;
in
a
trembling
,
vivid
,
flickering
instant
,
everything
was
clear
and
plain
;
then
came
a
flush
of
red
into
the
yellow
light
;
a
change
to
blue
;
a
brightness
so
intense
that
there
was
nothing
else
but
light
;
and
then
the
deepest
and
profoundest
darkness
.
   
<EOS>
The
lightning
being
very
crooked
and
very
dazzling
may
have
presented
or
assisted
a
curious
optical
illusion
,
which
suddenly
rose
before
the
startled
eyes
of
Montague
in
the
carriage
,
and
as
rapidly
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
he
saw
Jonas
with
his
hand
lifted
,
and
the
bottle
clenched
in
it
like
a
hammer
,
making
as
if
he
would
aim
a
blow
at
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
At
the
same
time
he
observed
(
or
so
believed
)
an
expression
in
his
face
---
a
combination
of
the
unnatural
excitement
he
had
shown
all
day
,
with
a
wild
hatred
and
fear
---
which
might
have
rendered
a
wolf
a
less
terrible
companion
.
   
<EOS>
He
uttered
an
involuntary
exclamation
,
and
called
to
the
driver
,
who
brought
his
horses
to
a
stop
with
all
speed
.
   
<EOS>
It
could
hardly
have
been
as
he
supposed
,
for
although
he
had
not
taken
his
eyes
off
his
companion
,
and
had
not
seen
him
move
,
he
sat
reclining
in
his
corner
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
that
your
general
way
of
waking
out
of
your
sleep
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
swear
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
that
I
have
not
closed
my
eyes
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
When
you
have
sworn
it
,
"
said
Jonas
,
composedly
,
"
we
had
better
go
on
again
,
if
you
have
only
stopped
for
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
uncorked
the
bottle
with
the
help
of
his
teeth
;
and
putting
it
to
his
lips
,
took
a
long
draught
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
wish
we
had
never
started
on
this
journey
.
 
<EOS>
This
is
not
,
"
said
Montague
,
recoiling
instinctively
,
and
speaking
in
a
voice
that
betrayed
his
agitation
;
"
this
is
not
a
night
to
travel
in
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
<EOS>
you
're
right
there
,
"
returned
Jonas
,
"
and
we
should
n't
be
out
in
it
but
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
had
n't
kept
me
waiting
all
day
,
we
might
have
been
at
Salisbury
by
this
time
;
snug
abed
and
fast
asleep
.
<EOS>
What
are
we
stopping
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
companion
put
his
head
out
of
window
for
a
moment
,
and
drawing
it
in
again
,
observed
(
as
if
that
were
his
cause
of
anxiety
)
,
that
the
boy
was
drenched
to
the
skin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Serve
him
right
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'm
glad
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
devil
are
we
stopping
for
?
 
<EOS>
Are
you
going
to
spread
him
out
to
dry
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
half
a
mind
to
take
him
inside
,
"
observed
the
other
with
some
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
thankee
!
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
do
n't
want
any
damp
boys
here
;
especially
a
young
imp
like
him
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
be
where
he
is
.
 
<EOS>
He
ai
n't
afraid
of
a
little
thunder
and
lightning
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
;
whoever
else
is
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
,
driver
.
 
<EOS>
We
had
better
have
HIM
inside
perhaps
,
"
he
muttered
with
a
laugh
;
"
and
the
horses
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
go
too
fast
,
"
cried
Montague
to
the
postillion
;
"
and
take
care
how
you
go
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
nearly
in
the
ditch
when
I
called
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
not
true
;
and
Jonas
bluntly
said
so
,
as
they
moved
forward
again
.
 
<EOS>
Montague
took
little
or
no
heed
of
what
he
said
,
but
repeated
that
it
was
not
a
night
for
travelling
,
and
showed
himself
,
both
then
and
afterwards
,
unusually
anxious
.
   
<EOS>
From
this
time
Jonas
recovered
his
former
spirits
,
if
such
a
term
may
be
employed
to
express
the
state
in
which
he
had
left
the
city
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
bottle
often
at
his
mouth
;
roared
out
snatches
of
songs
,
without
the
least
regard
to
time
or
tune
or
voice
,
or
anything
but
loud
discordance
;
and
urged
his
silent
friend
to
be
merry
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
the
best
company
in
the
world
,
my
good
fellow
,
"
said
Montague
with
an
effort
,
"
and
in
general
irresistible
;
but
to
-
night
 
---
<EOS>
do
you
hear
it
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
<EOS>
I
hear
and
see
it
too
,
"
cried
Jonas
,
shading
his
eyes
,
for
the
moment
,
from
the
lightning
which
was
flashing
,
not
in
any
one
direction
,
but
all
around
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
of
that
?
 
<EOS>
It
do
n't
change
you
,
nor
me
,
nor
our
affairs
.
 
<EOS>
Chorus
,
chorus
,
   
<EOS>
It
may
lighten
and
storm
,
   
<EOS>
Till
it
hunt
the
red
worm
     
<EOS>
From
the
grass
where
the
gibbet
is
driven
;
   
But
it
ca
n't
hurt
the
dead
,
   
<EOS>
And
it
wo
n't
save
the
head
     
<EOS>
That
is
doom'd
to
be
rifled
and
riven
.
   
<EOS>
That
must
be
a
precious
old
song
,
"
he
added
with
an
oath
,
as
he
stopped
short
in
a
kind
of
wonder
at
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
heard
it
since
I
was
a
boy
,
and
how
it
comes
into
my
head
now
,
unless
the
lightning
put
it
there
,
I
do
n't
know
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
hurt
the
dead
"
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
wo
n't
save
the
head
"
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
No
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
mirth
was
of
such
a
savage
and
extraordinary
character
,
and
was
,
in
an
inexplicable
way
,
at
once
so
suited
to
the
night
,
and
yet
such
a
coarse
intrusion
on
its
terrors
,
that
his
fellow
-
traveller
,
always
a
coward
,
shrunk
from
him
in
positive
fear
.
 
<EOS>
Instead
of
Jonas
being
his
tool
and
instrument
,
their
places
seemed
to
be
reversed
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
reason
for
this
too
,
Montague
thought
;
since
the
sense
of
his
debasement
might
naturally
inspire
such
a
man
with
the
wish
to
assert
a
noisy
independence
,
and
in
that
licence
to
forget
his
real
condition
.
 
<EOS>
Being
quick
enough
,
in
reference
to
such
subjects
of
contemplation
,
he
was
not
long
in
taking
this
argument
into
account
and
giving
it
its
full
weight
.
 
<EOS>
But
still
,
he
felt
a
vague
sense
of
alarm
,
and
was
depressed
and
uneasy
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
certain
he
had
not
been
asleep
;
but
his
eyes
might
have
deceived
him
;
for
,
looking
at
Jonas
now
in
any
interval
of
darkness
,
he
could
represent
his
figure
to
himself
in
any
attitude
his
state
of
mind
suggested
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
he
knew
full
well
that
Jonas
had
no
reason
to
love
him
;
and
even
taking
the
piece
of
pantomime
which
had
so
impressed
his
mind
to
be
a
real
gesture
,
and
not
the
working
of
his
fancy
,
the
most
that
could
be
said
of
it
was
,
that
it
was
quite
in
keeping
with
the
rest
of
his
diabolical
fun
,
and
had
the
same
impotent
expression
of
truth
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
he
could
kill
me
with
a
wish
,
"
thought
the
swindler
,
"
I
should
not
live
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
resolved
that
when
he
should
have
had
his
use
of
Jonas
,
he
would
restrain
him
with
an
iron
curb
;
in
the
meantime
,
that
he
could
not
do
better
than
leave
him
to
take
his
own
way
,
and
preserve
his
own
peculiar
description
of
good
-
humour
,
after
his
own
uncommon
manner
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
great
sacrifice
to
bear
with
him
;
"
for
when
all
is
got
that
can
be
got
,
"
thought
Montague
,
"
I
shall
decamp
across
the
water
,
and
have
the
laugh
on
my
side
---
and
the
gains
.
"
   
<EOS>
Such
were
his
reflections
from
hour
to
hour
;
his
state
of
mind
being
one
in
which
the
same
thoughts
constantly
present
themselves
over
and
over
again
in
wearisome
repetition
;
while
Jonas
,
who
appeared
to
have
dismissed
reflection
altogether
,
entertained
himself
as
before
.
<EOS>
They
agreed
that
they
would
go
to
Salisbury
,
and
would
cross
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
in
the
morning
;
and
at
the
prospect
of
deluding
that
worthy
gentleman
,
the
spirits
of
his
amiable
son
-
in
-
law
became
more
boisterous
than
ever
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
night
wore
on
,
the
thunder
died
away
,
but
still
rolled
gloomily
and
mournfully
in
the
distance
.
 
<EOS>
The
lightning
too
,
though
now
comparatively
harmless
,
was
yet
bright
and
frequent
.
 
<EOS>
The
rain
was
quite
as
violent
as
it
had
ever
been
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
their
ill
-
fortune
,
at
about
the
time
of
dawn
and
in
the
last
stage
of
their
journey
,
to
have
a
restive
pair
of
horses
.
 
<EOS>
These
animals
had
been
greatly
terrified
in
their
stable
by
the
tempest
;
and
coming
out
into
the
dreary
interval
between
night
and
morning
,
when
the
glare
of
the
lightning
was
yet
unsubdued
by
day
,
and
the
various
objects
in
their
view
were
presented
in
indistinct
and
exaggerated
shapes
which
they
would
not
have
worn
by
night
,
they
gradually
became
less
and
less
capable
of
control
;
until
,
taking
a
sudden
fright
at
something
by
the
roadside
,
they
dashed
off
wildly
down
a
steep
hill
,
flung
the
driver
from
his
saddle
,
drew
the
carriage
to
the
brink
of
a
ditch
,
stumbled
headlong
down
,
and
threw
it
crashing
over
.
   
<EOS>
The
travellers
had
opened
the
carriage
door
,
and
had
either
jumped
or
fallen
out
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
was
the
first
to
stagger
to
his
feet
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
sick
and
weak
,
and
very
giddy
,
and
reeling
to
a
five
-
barred
gate
,
stood
holding
by
it
;
looking
drowsily
about
as
the
whole
landscape
swam
before
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
by
degrees
,
he
grew
more
conscious
,
and
presently
observed
that
Montague
was
lying
senseless
in
the
road
,
within
a
few
feet
of
the
horses
.
   
<EOS>
In
an
instant
,
as
if
his
own
faint
body
were
suddenly
animated
by
a
demon
,
he
ran
to
the
horses
'
heads
;
and
pulling
at
their
bridles
with
all
his
force
,
set
them
struggling
and
plunging
with
such
mad
violence
as
brought
their
hoofs
at
every
effort
nearer
to
the
skull
of
the
prostrate
man
;
and
must
have
led
in
half
a
minute
to
his
brains
being
dashed
out
on
the
highway
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
did
this
,
he
fought
and
contended
with
them
like
a
man
possessed
,
making
them
wilder
by
his
cries
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whoop
!
"
cried
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Whoop
!
<EOS>
again
!
<EOS>
another
!
 
<EOS>
A
little
more
,
a
little
more
!
 
<EOS>
Up
,
ye
devils
!
 
<EOS>
Hillo
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
heard
the
driver
,
who
had
risen
and
was
hurrying
up
,
crying
to
him
to
desist
,
his
violence
increased
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hiilo
!
 
Hillo
!
"
cried
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
God
's
sake
!
"
cried
the
driver
.
 
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
---
in
the
road
---
 
he
'll
be
killed
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
same
shouts
and
the
same
struggles
were
his
only
answer
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
man
darting
in
at
the
peril
of
his
own
life
,
saved
Montague
's
,
by
dragging
him
through
the
mire
and
water
out
of
the
reach
of
present
harm
.
 
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
ran
to
Jonas
;
and
with
the
aid
of
his
knife
they
very
shortly
disengaged
the
horses
from
the
broken
chariot
,
and
got
them
,
cut
and
bleeding
,
on
their
legs
again
.
 
<EOS>
The
postillion
and
Jonas
had
now
leisure
to
look
at
each
other
,
which
they
had
not
had
yet
.
   
<EOS>
"
Presence
of
mind
,
presence
of
mind
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
,
throwing
up
his
hands
wildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
done
without
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
other
gentleman
would
have
done
badly
without
ME
,
"
returned
the
man
,
shaking

head
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
moved
him
first
.
 
<EOS>
I
gave
him
up
for
dead
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Presence
of
mind
,
you
croaker
,
presence
of
mind
"
cried
Jonas
with
a
harsh
loud
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Was
he
struck
,
do
you
think
?
"
   
<EOS>
They
both
turned
to
look
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
muttered
something
to
himself
,
when
he
saw
him
sitting
up
beneath
the
hedge
,
looking
vacantly
around
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
asked
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
anybody
hurt
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
<EOS>
"
said
Jonas
,
"
it
do
n't
seem
so
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
no
bones
broken
,
after
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
raised
him
,
and
he
tried
to
walk
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
good
deal
shaken
,
and
trembled
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
But
with
the
exception
of
a
few
cuts
and
bruises
this
was
all
the
damage
he
had
sustained
.
   
<EOS>
"
Cuts
and
bruises
,
eh
?
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
've
all
got
them
.
 
<EOS>
Only
cuts
and
bruises
,
eh
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
n't
have
given
sixpence
for
the
gentleman
's
head
in
half
-
a
-
dozen
seconds
more
,
for
all
he
's
only
cut
and
bruised
,
"
observed
the
post
-
boy
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
ever
you
're
in
an
accident
of
this
sort
again
,
sir
;
which
I
hope
you
wo
n't
be
;
never
you
pull
at
the
bridle
of
a
horse
that
's
down
,
when
there
's
a
man
's
head
in
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
That
ca
n't
be
done
twice
without
there
being
a
dead
man
in
the
case
;
it
would
have
ended
in
that
,
this
time
,
as
sure
as
ever
you
were
born
,
if
I
had
n't
come
up
just
when
I
did
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
replied
by
advising
him
with
a
curse
to
hold
his
tongue
,
and
to
go
somewhere
<EOS>
,
whither
he
was
not
very
likely
to
go
of
his
own
accord
.
 
<EOS>
But
Montague
,
who
had
listened
eagerly
to
every
word
,
himself
diverted
the
subject
,
by
exclaiming
:
"
Where
's
the
boy
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
<EOS>
I
forgot
that
monkey
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
become
of
him
?
"
 
<EOS>
A
very
brief
search
settled
that
question
.
 
<EOS>
The
unfortunate
Mr
Bailey
had
been
thrown
sheer
over
the
hedge
or
the
five
-
barred
gate
;
and
was
lying
in
the
neighbouring
field
,
to
all
appearance
dead
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
said
to
-
night
,
that
I
wished
I
had
never
started
on
this
journey
,
"
cried
his
master
,
"
I
knew
it
was
an
ill
-
fated
one
.
 
<EOS>
Look
at
this
boy
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
growled
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
call
THAT
a
sign
of
it
---
"
   
"
Why
,
what
should
I
call
a
sign
of
it
?
"
asked
Montague
,
hurriedly
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
"
said
Jonas
,
stooping
down
over
the
body
,
"
that
I
never
heard
you
were
his
father
,
or
had
any
particular
reason
to
care
much
about
him
.
 
<EOS>
Halloa
.
 
<EOS>
Hold
up
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
But
the
boy
was
past
holding
up
,
or
being
held
up
,
or
giving
any
other
sign
of
life
than
a
faint
and
fitful
beating
of
the
heart
.
<EOS>
After
some
discussion
the
driver
mounted
the
horse
which
had
been
least
injured
,
and
took
the
lad
in
his
arms
as
well
as
he
could
;
while
Montague
and
Jonas
,
leading
the
other
horse
,
and
carrying
a
trunk
between
them
,
walked
by
his
side
towards
Salisbury
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
'd
get
there
in
a
few
minutes
,
and
be
able
to
send
assistance
to
meet
us
,
if
you
went
forward
,
post
-
boy
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Trot
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
cried
Montague
;
"
we
'll
keep
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
a
chicken
you
are
!
 
<EOS>
You
are
not
afraid
of
being
robbed
;
are
you
?
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
afraid
of
anything
,
"
replied
the
other
,
whose
looks
and
manner
were
in
flat
contradiction
to
his
words
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
we
'll
keep
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
were
mighty
anxious
about
the
boy
,
a
minute
ago
,
"
said
Jonas
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
know
that
he
may
die
in
the
meantime
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
aye
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
'll
keep
together
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
it
was
clear
that
he
was
not
to
be
moved
from
this
determination
,
Jonas
made
no
other
rejoinder
than
such
as
his
face
expressed
;
and
they
proceeded
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
three
or
four
good
miles
to
travel
;
and
the
way
was
not
made
easier
by
the
state
of
the
road
,
the
burden
by
which
they
were
embarrassed
,
or
their
own
stiff
and
sore
condition
.
 
<EOS>
After
a
sufficiently
long
and
painful
walk
,
they
arrived
at
the
Inn
;
and
having
knocked
the
people
up
(
it
being
yet
very
early
in
the
morning
)
,
sent
out
messengers
to
see
to
the
carriage
and
its
contents
,
and
roused
a
surgeon
from
his
bed
to
tend
the
chief
sufferer
.
 
<EOS>
All
the
service
he
could
render
,
he
rendered
promptly
and
skilfully
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
gave
it
as
his
opinion
that
the
boy
was
labouring
under
a
severe
concussion
of
the
brain
,
and
that
Mr
Bailey
's
mortal
course
was
run
.
   
<EOS>
If
Montague
's
strong
interest
in
the
announcement
could
have
been
considered
as
unselfish
in
any
degree
,
it
might
have
been
a
redeeming
trait
in
a
character
that
had
no
such
lineaments
to
spare
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
difficult
to
see
that
,
for
some
unexpressed
reason
best
appreciated
by
himself
,
he
attached
a
strange
value
to
the
company
and
presence
of
this
mere
child
.
 
<EOS>
When
,
after
receiving
some
assistance
from
the
surgeon
himself
,
he
retired
to
the
bedroom
prepared
for
him
,
and
it
was
broad
day
,
his
mind
was
still
dwelling
on
this
theme
,
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
have
lost
,
"
he
said
,
"
a
thousand
pounds
than
lost
the
boy
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
'll
return
home
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
resolved
upon
that
.
 
<EOS>
Chuzzlewit
shall
go
forward
first
,
and
I
will
follow
in
my
own
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
have
no
more
of
this
,
"
he
added
,
wiping
his
damp
forehead
.
 
<EOS>
"
Twenty
-
four
hours
of
this
would
turn
my
hair
grey
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
examining
his
chamber
,
and
looking
under
the
bed
,
and
in
the
cupboards
,
and
even
behind
the
curtains
,
with
unusual
caution
(
although
it
was
,
as
has
been
said
,
broad
day
)
,
he
double
-
locked
the
door
by
which
he
had
entered
,
and
retired
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
another
door
in
the
room
,
but
it
was
locked
on
the
outer
side
;
and
with
what
place
it
communicated
,
he
knew
not
.
   
<EOS>
His
fears
or
evil
conscience
reproduced
this
door
in
all
his
dreams
.
<EOS>
He
dreamed
that
a
dreadful
secret
was
connected
with
it
;
a
secret
which
he
knew
,
and
yet
did
not
know
,
for
although
he
was
heavily
responsible
for
it
,
and
a
party
to
it
,
he
was
harassed
even
in
his
vision
by
a
distracting
uncertainty
in
reference
to
its
import
.
<EOS>
Incoherently
entwined
with
this
dream
was
another
,
which
represented
it
as
the
hiding
-
place
of
an
enemy
,
a
shadow
,
a
phantom
;
and
made
it
the
business
of
his
life
to
keep
the
terrible
creature
closed
up
,
and
prevent
it
from
forcing
its
way
in
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
view
Nadgett
,
and
he
,
and
a
strange
man
with
a
bloody
smear
upon
his
head
(
who
told
him
that
he
had
been
his
playfellow
,
and
told
him
,
too
,
the
real
name
of
an
old
schoolmate
,
forgotten
until
then
)
,
worked
with
iron
plates
and
nails
to
make
the
door
secure
;
<EOS>
but
though
they
worked
never
so
hard
,
it
was
all
in
vain
,
for
the
nails
broke
,
or
changed
to
soft
twigs
,
or
what
was
worse
,
to
worms
,
between
their
fingers
;
the
wood
of
the
door
splintered
and
crumbled
,
so
that
even
nails
would
not
remain
in
it
;
and
the
iron
plates
curled
up
like
hot
paper
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
the
creature
on
the
other
side
---
whether
it
was
in
the
shape
of
man
,
or
beast
<EOS>
,
he
neither
knew
nor
sought
to
know
---
 
was
gaining
on
them
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
greatest
terror
was
when
the
man
with
the
bloody
smear
upon
his
head
demanded
of
him
if
he
knew
this
creatures
name
,
and
said
that
he
would
whisper
it
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
the
dreamer
fell
upon
his
knees
,
his
whole
blood
thrilling
with
inexplicable
fear
,
and
held
his
ears
.
 
<EOS>
But
looking
at
the
speaker
's
lips
,
he
saw
that
they
formed
the
utterance
of
the
letter
"
J
"
;
and
crying
out
aloud
that
the
secret
was
discovered
,
and
they
were
all
lost
,
he
awoke
.
   
<EOS>
Awoke
to
find
Jonas
standing
at
his
bedside
watching
him
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
very
door
wide
open
.
   
<EOS>
As
their
eyes
met
,
Jonas
retreated
a
few
paces
,
and
Montague
sprang
out
of
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heyday
!
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
all
alive
this
morning
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Alive
!
"
<EOS>
the
other
stammered
,
as
he
pulled
the
bell
-
rope
violently
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
doing
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
your
room
to
be
sure
,
"
said
Jonas
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
'm
almost
inclined
to
ask
you
what
YOU
are
doing
here
?
 
<EOS>
My
room
is
on
the
other
side
of
that
door
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
told
me
last
night
not
to
open
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
it
led
into
a
passage
,
and
was
coming
out
to
order
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
 
<EOS>
---
there
's
no
bell
in
my
room
.
"
   
<EOS>
Montague
had
in
the
meantime
admitted
the
man
with
his
hot
water
and
boots
,
who
hearing
this
,
said
,
yes
,
there
was
;
and
passed
into
the
adjoining
room
to
point
it
out
,
at
the
head
of
the
bed
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
find
it
,
then
,
"
said
Jonas
;
"
it
's
all
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
order
breakfast
?
"
   
<EOS>
Montague
answered
in
the
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
When
Jonas
had
retired
,
whistling
,
through
his
own
room
,
he
opened
the
door
of
communication
,
to
take
out
the
key
and
fasten
it
on
the
inner
side
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
taken
out
already
.
   
<EOS>
He
dragged
a
table
against
the
door
,
and
sat
down
to
collect
himself
,
as
if
his
dreams
still
had
some
influence
upon
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
"
An
evil
journey
,
"
he
repeated
several
times
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
evil
journey
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
travel
home
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
have
no
more
of
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
His
presentiment
,
or
superstition
,
that
it
was
an
evil
journey
,
did
not
at
all
deter
him
from
doing
the
evil
for
which
the
journey
was
undertaken
.
 
<EOS>
With
this
in
view
,
he
dressed
himself
more
carefully
than
usual
to
make
a
favourable
impression
on
Mr
Pecksniff
;
and
,
reassured
by
his
own
appearance
,
the
beauty
of
the
morning
,
and
the
flashing
of
the
wet
boughs
outside
his
window
in
the
merry
sunshine
,
was
soon
sufficiently
inspirited
to
swear
a
few
round
oaths
,
and
hum
the
fag
-
end
of
a
song
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
still
muttered
to
himself
at
intervals
,
for
all
that
:
"
I
'll
travel
home
alone
!
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
43
.
<EOS>
Has
an
influence
on
the
fortunes
of
several
people
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
is
exhibited
in
the
plenitude
of
power
;
and
wields
the
same
with
fortitude
and
magnanimity
 
On
the
night
of
the
storm
,
Mrs
Lupin
,
hostess
of
the
Blue
Dragon
,
sat
by
herself
in
her
little
bar
.
 
<EOS>
Her
solitary
condition
,
or
the
bad
weather
,
or
both
united
,
made
Mrs
Lupin
thoughtful
,
not
to
say
sorrowful
.
 
<EOS>
As
she
sat
with
her
chin
upon
her
hand
,
looking
out
through
a
low
back
lattice
,
rendered
dim
in
the
brightest
day
-
time
by
clustering
vine
-
leaves
,
she
shook
her
head
very
often
,
and
said
,
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
,
dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
melancholy
time
,
even
in
the
snugness
of
the
Dragon
bar
.
<EOS>
The
rich
expanse
of
corn
-
field
,
pasture
-
land
,
green
slope
,
and
gentle
undulation
,
with
its
sparkling
brooks
,
its
many
hedgerows
,
and
its
clumps
of
beautiful
trees
,
was
black
and
dreary
,
from
the
diamond
panes
of
the
lattice
away
to
the
far
horizon
,
where
the
thunder
seemed
to
roll
along
the
hills
.
 
<EOS>
The
heavy
rain
beat
down
the
tender
branches
of
vine
and
jessamine
,
and
trampled
on
them
in
its
fury
;
and
when
the
lightning
gleamed
it
showed
the
tearful
leaves
shivering
and
cowering
together
at
the
window
,
and
tapping
at
it
urgently
,
as
if
beseeching
to
be
sheltered
from
the
dismal
night
.
   
<EOS>
As
a
mark
of
her
respect
for
the
lightning
,
Mrs
Lupin
had
removed
her
candle
to
the
chimney
-
piece
.
 
<EOS>
Her
basket
of
needle
-
work
stood
unheeded
at
her
elbow
;
her
supper
,
spread
on
a
round
table
not
far
off
,
was
untasted
;
and
the
knives
had
been
removed
for
fear
of
attraction
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
sat
for
a
long
time
with
her
chin
upon
her
hand
,
saying
to
herself
at
intervals
,
"
Dear
me
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
dear
,
dear
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
on
the
eve
of
saying
so
,
once
more
,
when
the
latch
of
the
house
-
door
(
closed
to
keep
the
rain
out
)
,
rattled
on
its
well
-
worn
catch
,
and
a
traveller
came
in
,
who
,
shutting
it
after
him
,
and
walking
straight
up
to
the
half
-
door
of
the
bar
,
said
,
rather
gruffly
:
   
<EOS>
"
A
pint
of
the
best
old
beer
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
some
reason
to
be
gruff
,
for
if
he
had
passed
the
day
in
a
waterfall
,
he
could
scarcely
have
been
wetter
than
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
wrapped
up
to
the
eyes
in
a
rough
blue
sailor
's
coat
,
and
had
an
oil
-
skin
hat
on
,
from
the
capacious
brim
of
which
the
rain
fell
trickling
down
upon
his
breast
,
and
back
,
and
shoulders
.
 
<EOS>
Judging
from
a
certain
liveliness
of
chin
---
he
had
so
pulled
down
his
hat
,
and
pulled
up
his
collar
,
to
defend
himself
from
the
weather
,
that
she
could
only
see
his
chin
,
and
even
across
that
he
drew
the
wet
sleeve
of
his
shaggy
coat
,
as
she
looked
at
him
---
Mrs
Lupin
set
him
down
for
a
good
-
natured
fellow
,
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
bad
night
!
"
observed
the
hostess
cheerfully
.
   
<EOS>
The
traveller
shook
himself
like
a
Newfoundland
dog
,
and
said
it
was
,
rather
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
fire
in
the
kitchen
,
"
said
Mrs
Lupin
,
"
and
very
good
company
there
.
 
<EOS>
Had
n't
you
better
go
and
dry
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
thankee
,
"
said
the
man
,
glancing
towards
the
kitchen
as
he
spoke
;
he
seemed
to
know
the
way
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
enough
to
give
you
your
death
of
cold
,
"
observed
the
hostess
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
take
my
death
easy
,
"
returned
the
traveller
;
"
or
I
should
most
likely
have
took
it
afore
to
-
night
.
 
<EOS>
Your
health
,
ma'am
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Lupin
thanked
him
;
but
in
the
act
of
lifting
the
tankard
to
his
mouth
,
he
changed
his
mind
,
and
put
it
down
again
.
 
<EOS>
Throwing
his
body
back
,
and
looking
about
him
stiffly
,
as
a
man
does
who
is
wrapped
up
,
and
has
his
hat
low
down
over
his
eyes
,
he
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
call
this
house
?
 
<EOS>
Not
the
Dragon
,
do
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Lupin
complacently
made
answer
,
"
Yes
,
the
Dragon
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
you
've
got
a
sort
of
a
relation
of
mine
here
,
ma'am
,
"
said
the
traveller
;
"
a
young
man
of
the
name
of
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
Mark
,
my
boy
!
"
<EOS>
apostrophizing
the
premises
,
"
have
I
come
upon
you
at
last
,
old
buck
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
touching
Mrs
Lupin
on
a
tender
point
.
 
<EOS>
She
turned
to
trim
the
candle
on
the
chimney
-
piece
,
and
said
,
with
her
back
towards
the
traveller
:
   
<EOS>
"
Nobody
should
be
made
more
welcome
at
the
Dragon
,
master
,
than
any
one
who
brought
me
news
of
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
's
many
and
many
a
long
day
and
month
since
he
left
here
and
England
.
 
<EOS>
And
whether
he
's
alive
or
dead
,
poor
fellow
,
Heaven
above
us
only
knows
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
shook
her
head
,
and
her
voice
trembled
;
her
hand
must
have
done
so
too
,
for
the
light
required
a
deal
of
trimming
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
did
he
go
,
ma'am
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
traveller
,
in
a
gentler
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
went
,
"
said
Mrs
Lupin
,
with
increased
distress
,
"
to
America
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
always
tender
-
hearted
and
kind
,
and
perhaps
at
this
moment
may
be
lying
in
prison
under
sentence
of
death
,
for
taking
pity
on
some
miserable
black
,
and
helping
the
poor
runaway
creetur
to
escape
.
<EOS>
How
could
he
ever
go
to
America
!
 
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
he
go
to
some
of
those
countries
where
the
savages
eat
each
other
fairly
,
and
give
an
equal
chance
to
every
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
Quite
subdued
by
this
time
,
Mrs
Lupin
sobbed
,
and
was
retiring
to
a
chair
to
give
her

free
vent
,
when
the
traveller
caught
her
in
his
arms
,
and
she
uttered
a
glad

of
recognition
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
will
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mark
,
"
another
---
one
more
---
twenty
more
!
 
<EOS>
You
did
n't
know
me
in
that
hat
and
coat
?
 
<EOS>
I
thought
you
would
have
known
me
anywheres
!
 
<EOS>
Ten
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
should
have
known
you
,
if
I
could
have
seen
you
;
but
I
could
n't
,
and
you
spoke
so
gruff
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
think
you
could
speak
gruff
to
me
,
Mark
,
at
first
coming
back
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Fifteen
more
!
"
said
Mr
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
handsome
and
how
young
you
look
!
 
<EOS>
Six
more
!
 
<EOS>
The
last
half
-
dozen
warn't
a
fair
one
,
and
must
be
done
over
again
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
bless
you
,
what
a
treat
<EOS>
it
is
to
see
you
!
 
<EOS>
One
more
!
 
<EOS>
Well
,
I
never
was
so
jolly
.
 
<EOS>
Just
a
few
more
,
on
account
of
there
not
being
any
credit
in
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
When
Mr
Tapley
stopped
in
these
calculations
in
simple
addition
,
he
did
it
,
not
because
he
was
at
all
tired
of
the

,
but
because
he
was
out
of
breath
.
 
<EOS>
The
pause
reminded
him
of
other
duties
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Martin
Chuzzlewit
's
outside
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
left
him
under
the
cartshed
,
while
I
came
on
to
see
if
there
was
anybody
here
.
 
<EOS>
We
want
to
keep
quiet
to
-
night
,
till
we
know
the
news
from
you
,
and
what
it
's
best
for
us
to
do
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
not
a
soul
in
the
house
,
except
the
kitchen
company
,
"
returned
the

.
 
<EOS>
"
If

were
to
know
you
had
come
back
,
Mark
,
they
'd
have
a
bonfire
in
the
street
,
late

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

must

to
-
night
,
my

,
"
said
Mark
;
"
so
have
the
house
shut
,
and
the
kitchen

made

;
and
when

,
put

in

,

we
'll
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
One
more
!
<EOS>
I
long
to
hear
about
old
friends
.
 
<EOS>
You
'll
tell
me
all
about
'em
,
wo
n't
you
;
Mr
Pinch
,
and
the
butcher
's
dog
down

,
and
the

,

,

.
<EOS>
When

the
church
to
-

,

would
have

,

.
 
<EOS>
One
more
!
 
<EOS>
Wo
n't
you
?
 
<EOS>
Not
a
very
little
one
to

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
had

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Go
along

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
ai
n't
foreign
,
bless

!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
"
Native
as

,
that
is
!
 
<EOS>
One
more
,
because
it
's
native
!
 
<EOS>
As

land

live

!
 
<EOS>
This
do

count

,

,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
a
-
kissing
you
now
,
you
'll
observe
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
been
among
the
patriots
;
I
'm
a
-
kissin
'
my
country
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
very
unreasonable
to
complain
of
the

his

with
which
he
followed
up
this
explanation
,
that
it
was
at
all
lukewarm
or

.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
given
full
expression
to
his

,
he
hurried
off
to
Martin
;
while
Mrs
Lupin
,
in
a

of
great
agitation
and

,
prepared
for

reception
.
   
<EOS>
The
company
soon
came
tumbling
out
;
insisting
to
each
other
that
the
Dragon
clock
was
half
an
hour
too
fast
,
and
that
the
thunder
must
have
affected
it
.
 
<EOS>
Impatient
,
wet
,
and
weary
though
they
were
,
Martin
and
Mark
were
overjoyed
to
see
these
old
faces
,
and
watched
them
with
delighted
interest
as
they
departed
from
the
house
,
and
passed
close
by
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
old
tailor
,
Mark
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
he
goes
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
A
little
bandier
than
he
was
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
sir
,
ai
n't
he
?
 
<EOS>
His
figure
's
so
far
altered
,
as
it

,
that
you
might
wheel
a

between

,

done
conveniently
when

.
 
<EOS>
There
's
Sam
a
-
coming
out
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
to
be
sure
!
"
<EOS>

Martin
;
"
Sam
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

of
Pecksniff
's

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That

,
<EOS>
sir
,
as

for

,
and

"
Sing'lar

.
"
 
<EOS>
As

,

!
 
<EOS>
There
's

,

---
 
<EOS>
wery

,
as

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
see
him
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
life
,
how

,
Mark
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

!
 
<EOS>
What

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

half

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

not

,

,

change
and

.
 
<EOS>
The

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"
the

.
 
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Lord

!
 
<EOS>
Now

,

.
 
<EOS>
Neat

,

,

-

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

burnt

,

,

;

,

too
,

there
,

;

-

,

in

;

was

,

upon
the

;
rare
provisions
were
there
,
dangling
from
the

as

,
and
something
exquisitely
ripe
and
good
would

of
the

for

.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Lupin
,
who
for

sakes
had
dislodged
the
very
cook
,
high

of
the

,
with
her
own

was
dressing

.
   
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
help
it
---
a
ghost
must
have
hugged

.
 
<EOS>
The
Atlantic
Ocean
and
the
Red
Sea
being
,
in

respect
,
all
one
,
Martin
hugged

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
(
as

the
idea
were
quite
novel
,
and
had
never

to

before
)
,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Little
did
I
ever
think
,
"
said

,

;
yes
,

;
"
often
as
I

that
Mr
Pecksniff
's
young

were
the
life

the
Dragon
,
and
that

would

too

in
---
<EOS>
little
<EOS>
did
I

think
I
am
sure
,
that
any

would
ever
make
so
free
as
you
,
Mr

!
 
<EOS>
And
still
less

,

,

Tapley
for

---
"
   
"
<EOS>
For

,
Mrs
Lupin
,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
For
his
friend
,
"
said

,
evidently

,
but

with

.
 
<EOS>
"
Little
did
I
ever
think
that
!
<EOS>
But

,
that

changes

relate
that
I

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
changing

,
"
what
changes
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
SHE
,
"
said
the

,
"
is

,
and
now
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
.
<EOS>
Do

about

.
 
<EOS>
She
is
everything

could

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
of
no
use
mincing

,
or
making

,

it
?
"
added
Mrs
Lupin
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
all
about
it
,
you

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
good
creature
,
"
returned
Martin
,
"
you
are
exactly
the
person
who
ought
to
know
all
about

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
delighted
to
think
you
DO
know
about
that
!
 
<EOS>
But
what
changes
do
you
hint
at
?
 
<EOS>
Has
any
death
occurred
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
!
"
said
the
hostess
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
as
bad
as
that
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
declare
now
that
I
will
not
be
drawn
into
saying
another
word
till
you
have
had
your
supper
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
ask
me
fifty
questions
in
the
meantime
,
I
wo
n't
answer
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
so
positive
,
that
there
was
nothing
for
it
but
to
get
the
supper
over
as
quickly
as
possible
;
and
as
they
had
been
walking
a
great
many
miles
,
and
had
fasted
since
the
middle
of
the
day
,
they
did
no
great
violence
to
their
own
inclinations
in
falling
on
it
tooth
and
nail
.
 
<EOS>
It
took
rather
longer
to
get
through
than
might
have
been
expected
;
for
,
half
-
a
-
dozen
times
,
when
they
thought
they
had
finished
,
Mrs
Lupin
exposed
the
fallacy
of
that
impression
triumphantly
.
 
<EOS>
But
at
last
,
in
the
course
of
time
and
nature
,
they
gave
in
.
 
<EOS>
Then
,
sitting
with
their
slippered
feet
stretched
out
upon
the
kitchen
hearth
(
which
was
wonderfully
comforting
,
for
the
night
had
grown
by
this
time
raw
and
chilly
)
,
and
looking
with
involuntary
admiration
at
their
dimpled
,
buxom
,
blooming
hostess
,
as
the
firelight
sparkled
in
her
eyes
and
glimmered
in
her
raven
hair
,
they
composed
themselves
to
listen
to
her
news
.
   
<EOS>
Many
were
the
exclamations
of
surprise
which
interrupted
her
,
when
she
told
them
of
the
separation
between
Mr
Pecksniff
and
his
daughters
,
and
between
the
same
good
gentleman
and
Mr
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
were
nothing
to
the
indignant
demonstrations
of
Martin
,
when
she
related
,
as
the
common
talk
of
the
neighbourhood
,
what
entire
possession
he
had
obtained
over
the
mind
and
person
of
old
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
and
what
high
honour
he
designed
for
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
On
receipt
of
this
intelligence
,
Martin
's
slippers
flew
off
in
a
twinkling
,
and
he
began
pulling
on
his
wet
boots
with
that
indefinite
intention
of
going
somewhere
instantly
,
and
doing
something
to
somebody
,
which
is
the
first
safety
-
valve
of
a
hot
temper
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
!
"
said
Martin
,
"
smooth
-
tongued
villain
that
he
is
!
 
<EOS>
He
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
that
other
boot
,
Mark
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Where
was
you
a
-
thinking
of
going
to
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Mr
Tapley
drying
the
sole
at
the
fire
,
and
looking
coolly
at
it
as
he
spoke
,
as
if
it
were
a
slice
of
toast
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
!
"
repeated
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
suppose
I
am
going
to
remain
here
,
do
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
imperturbable
Mark
confessed
that
he
did
.
   
<EOS>
You
do
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Martin
angrily
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
take
me
for
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
take
you
for
what
you
are
,
sir
,
"
said
Mark
;
"
and
,
consequently
,
am
quite
sure
that
whatever
you
do
will
be
right
and
sensible
.
 
<EOS>
The
boot
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
darted
an
impatient
look
at
him
,
without
taking
it
,
and
walked
rapidly
up
and
down
the
kitchen
several
times
,
with
one
boot
and
a
stocking
on
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
mindful
of
his
Eden
resolution
,
he
had
already
gained
many
victories
over
himself
when
Mark
was
in
the
case
,
and
he
resolved
to
conquer
now
.
 
<EOS>
So
he
came
back
to
the
book
-
jack
,
laid
his
hand
on
Mark
's
shoulder
to
steady
himself
,
pulled
the
boot
off
,
picked
up
his
slippers
,
put
them
on
,
and
sat
down
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
help
thrusting
his
hands
to
the
very
bottom
of
his
pockets
,
and
muttering
at
intervals
,
"
Pecksniff
too
!
 
<EOS>
That
fellow
!
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
In
-
deed
!
 
<EOS>
What
next
?
"
<EOS>
and
so
forth
;
nor
could
he
help
occasionally
shaking
his
fist
at
the
chimney
,
with
a
very
threatening
countenance
;
but
this
did
not
last
long
;
and
he
heard
Mrs
Lupin
out
,
if
not

,
at
all

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
Mr
Pecksniff
himself
,
"
observed
the
hostess
in
conclusion
,
spreading
out
the
skirts
of
her

with

,
and
nodding
her
head
a
great

times
as

did

,
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
must
have
poisoned
his
mind
,
or
influenced
him
in
some

.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
believe
that
such
a
noble
-
spoken

would
go
and
do
wrong
of
his
own
accord
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
noble
-
spoken
gentleman
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
people

there
in
the
world
,
who
,
for
no

,
uphold
their
Pecksniffs
to
the

and
abandon

,
when
Pecksniffs

!
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

Mr
Pinch
,
"
pursued

,
"
if

a
dear
,
good
,

,
worthy

alive
,
Pinch
,
and
no

,

.
<EOS>
But

do

that
old
Mr
Chuzzlewit
himself
was

cause

difference

between

?
 
<EOS>
No

but

;
for
Mr
Pinch

a

,
though
he
has
such

quiet

;
and
when
he
left

,
and
was
so

to

,
he
scorned
to
make
his
story
good
,
even

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
old
Tom
!
"
said
Martin
,
in
a

that
sounded
like

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
comfort

,
"
resumed

,
"
that
he
has
his

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
Only

sent

,

,
a

"
---
here

---
 
"
<EOS>
a
little
trifle
<EOS>
I
was
bold

lend

;
saying

,
that

,
