.
 
<EOS>
It

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Kindly

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Is

,
Mark
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
ca

as

,
"

Tapley
;
"
which

.
 
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Do

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Give

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

Mr
Tapley
was
not

Martin
<EOS>
but
he

,
and

:
   
<EOS>
"
That

,

Mark
;

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

that

(

)
<EOS>
no

own
<EOS>
,

?
 
<EOS>
And

,
"

,

,
"

;
<EOS>
my

;

---
Pecksniff
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,
"
that
Pecksniff

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
A

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
Blow
Pecksniff
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Who

!
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pecksniff
!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
What

,

,

,

?
 
<EOS>
We

-

;
"
he

"

,
this

Pecksniff

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pecksniff
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,

;

;

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

call

Pecksniff
,

;

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

himself

.
 
<EOS>
But

,

,

:
   
"
<EOS>
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
Right

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
One

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Only

so

.
 
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
Do

?
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

-

<EOS>
,

!
"
<EOS>
"
   
Martin

,
but

that

was
good

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

from
Mrs

that

had

in

;

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
In

as
agreed
upon
at
this

,
Mr
Tapley
issued

,

,

Martin
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

,
he
soon

at
Mr
Pecksniff
's

.
 
<EOS>
At
that
gentleman
's
door
;
with
a

so
immovable
that
it
would
have

next
to
an

for

to

,
or

;

.
   
<EOS>
A

of
Mr
Tapley
's

could

to

that
Mr
Pecksniff
was

the
end

his

very

against

,
in
an
angular

to
discover

.
 
<EOS>
Nor

Tapley
slow
to

,
by

,

in

.
 
<EOS>
But

Mr
Pecksniff
had

,

Mark
<EOS>
soon
heard
his
shoes
creaking
,
as

to

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
was

,

<EOS>
"
How

,

?
"

"

<EOS>
"
Tapley
,

?
 
<EOS>
The

!
 
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
A

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mark

<EOS>
"
He

.
 
<EOS>
Certainly
,
"

<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Whereupon
he
handed
Mark
the
scraps
;
retired
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
Mark
thought
it
prudent
to
subdue
his
personal
emotions
,
and
return
to
Martin
at
the
Dragon
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
unprepared
for
such
a
reception
,
and
suffered
an
hour
or
so
to
elapse
before
making
another
attempt
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
interval
had
gone
by
,
they
returned
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
in
company
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
knocked
this
time
,
while
Mr
Tapley
prepared
himself
to
keep
the
door
open
with
his
foot
and
shoulder
,
when
anybody
came
,
and
by
that
means
secure
an
enforced
parley
.
 
<EOS>
But
this
precaution
was
needless
,
for
the
servant
-
girl
appeared
almost
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
Brushing
quickly
past
her
as
he
had
resolved
in
such
a
case
to
do
<EOS>
,
Martin
(
closely
followed
by
his
faithful
ally
)
opened
the
door
of
that
parlour
in
which
he
knew
a
visitor
was
most
likely
to
be
found
;
passed
at
once
into
the
room
;
and
stood
,
without
a
word
of
notice
or
announcement
,
in
the
presence
of
his
grandfather
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
also
was
in
the
room
;
and
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
swift
instant
of
their
mutual
recognition
,
Martin
saw
the
old
man
droop
his
grey
head
,
and
hide
his
face
in
his
hands
.
   
<EOS>
It
smote
him
to
the
heart
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
most
selfish
and
most
careless
day
,
this
lingering
remnant
of
the
old
man
's
ancient
love
,
this
buttress
of
a
ruined
tower
he
had
built
up
in
the
time
gone
by
,
with
so
much
pride
and
hope
,
would
have
caused
a
pang
in
Martin
's
heart
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
changed
for
the
better
in
his
worst
respect
;
looking
through
an
altered
medium
on
his
former
friend
,
the
guardian
of
his
childhood
,
so
broken
and
bowed
down
;
resentment
,
sullenness
,
self
-
confidence
,
and
pride
,
were
all
swept
away
,
before
the
starting
tears
upon
the
withered
cheeks
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
bear
to
see
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
bear
to
think
they
fell
at
sight
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
bear
to
view
reflected
in
them
,
the
reproachful
and
irrevocable
Past
.
   
<EOS>
He
hurriedly
advanced
to
seize
the
old
man
's
hand
in
his
,
when
Mr
Pecksniff
interposed
himself
between
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
young
man
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
striking
himself
upon
the
breast
,
and
stretching
out
his
other
arm
towards
his
guest
as
if
it
were
a
wing
to
shelter
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
Strike
here
,
sir
,
here
!
 
<EOS>
Launch
your
arrows
at
me
,
sir
,
if
you
'll
have
the
goodness
;
not
at
Him
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Grandfather
!
"
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
implore
you
,
let
me
speak
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Would
you
,
sir
?
 
<EOS>
Would
you
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
dodging
about
,
so
as
to
keep
himself
always
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
enough
,
sir
,
that
you
come
into
my
house
like
a
thief
in
the
night
,
or
I
should
rather
say
,
for
we
can
never
be
too
particular
on
the
subject
of
Truth
,
like
a
thief
in
the
day
-
time
;
bringing
your
dissolute
companions
with
you
,
to
plant
themselves
with
their
backs
against
the
insides
of
parlour
doors
,
and
prevent
the
entrance
or
issuing
forth
of
any
of
my
household
"
---
Mark
had
taken
up
this
position
,
and
held
it
quite
unmoved
---
"
but
would
you
also
strike
at
venerable
Virtue
?
 
<EOS>
Would
you
?
 
<EOS>
Know
that
it
is
not
defenceless
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
be
its
shield
,
young
man
.
 
<EOS>
Assail
me
.
 
<EOS>
Come
on
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Fire
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Pecksniff
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
in
a
feeble
voice
.
 
<EOS>
"
Calm
yourself
.
<EOS>
Be
quiet
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
be
calm
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
and
I
wo
n't
be
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
My
benefactor
and
my
friend
!
 
<EOS>
Shall
even
my
house
be
no
refuge
for
your
hoary
pillow
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Stand
aside
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
old
man
,
stretching
out
his
hand
;
"
and
let
me
see
what
it
is
I
used
to
love
so
dearly
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
right
that
you
should
see
it
,
my
friend
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
well
that
you
should
see
it
,
my
noble
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
desirable
that
you
should
contemplate
it
in
its
true
proportions
.
 
<EOS>
Behold
it
!
<EOS>
There
it
is
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
There
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
could
hardly
be
a
mortal
man
,
and
not
express
in
his
face
something
of
the
anger
and
disdain
with
which
Mr
Pecksniff
inspired
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
beyond
this
he
evinced
no
knowledge
whatever
of
that
gentleman
's
presence
or
existence
.
 
<EOS>
True
,
he
had
once
,
and
that
at
first
,
glanced
at
him
involuntarily
,
and
with
supreme
contempt
;
but
for
any
other
heed
he
took
of
him
,
there
might
have
been
nothing
in
his
place
save
empty
air
.
   
<EOS>
As
Mr
Pecksniff
withdrew
from
between
them
,
agreeably
to
the
wish
just
now
expressed
(
which
he
did
during
the
delivery
of
the
observations
last
recorded
)
,
old
Martin
,
who
had
taken
Mary
Graham
's
hand
in
his
,
and
whispered
kindly
to
her
,
as
telling
her
she
had
no
cause
to
be
alarmed
,
gently
pushed
her
from
him
,
behind
his
chair
;
and
looked
steadily
at
his
grandson
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
,
"
he
said
,
"
is
he
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
that
is
he
!
 
<EOS>
Say
what
you
wish
to
say
.
 
<EOS>
But
come
no
nearer
,
"
   
"
His
sense
of
justice
is
so
fine
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
that
he
will
hear
even
him
,
although
he
knows
beforehand
that
nothing
can
come
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
Ingenuous
mind
!
"
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
did
not
address
himself
immediately
to
any
person
in
saying
this
,
but
assuming
the
position
of
the
Chorus
in
a
Greek
Tragedy
,
delivered
his
opinion
as
a
commentary
on
the
proceedings
.
   
<EOS>
"
Grandfather
!
<EOS>
"
said
Martin
,
with
great
earnestness
.
 
<EOS>
"
From
a
painful
journey
,
from
a
hard
life
,
from
a
sick
-
bed
,
from
privation
and
distress
,
from
gloom
and
disappointment
,
from
almost
hopelessness
and
despair
,
I
have
come
back
to
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Rovers
of
this
sort
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
,
as
Chorus
,
"
<EOS>
very
commonly
come
back
when
they
find
they
do
n't
meet
with
the
success
they
expected
in
their
marauding
ravages
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
But
for
this
faithful
man
,
"
said
Martin
,
turning
towards
Mark
,
"
whom
I
first
knew
in
this
place
,
and
who
went
away
with
me
voluntarily
,
as
a
servant
,
but
has
been
,
throughout
,
my
zealous
and
devoted
friend
;
<EOS>
but
for
him
,
I
must
have
died
abroad
.
 
<EOS>
Far
from
home
,
far
from
any
help
or
consolation
;
far
from
the
probability
even
of
my
wretched
fate
being
ever
known
to
any
one
who
cared
to
hear
it
---
oh
,
that
you
would
let
me
say
,
of
being
known
to
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
at
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
looked
at
him
.
<EOS>
"
Did
you
speak
,
my
worthy
sir
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
answered
in
the
negative
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
you
thought
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
with
another
smile
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
go
on
my
friend
.
<EOS>
The
development
of
self
-
interest
in
the
human
mind
is
always
a
curious
study
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
go
on
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Go
on
!
"
<EOS>
observed
the
old
man
;
in
a
mechanical
obedience
,
it
appeared
,
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
suggestion
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
so
wretched
and
so
poor
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
that
I
am
indebted
to
the
charitable
help
of
a
stranger
,
in
a
land
of
strangers
,
for
the
means
of
returning
here
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
tells
against
me
in
your
mind
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
given
you
cause
to
think
I
have
been
driven
here
wholly
by
want
,
and
have
not
been
led
on
,
in
any
degree
,
by
affection
or
regret
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
parted
from
you
,
Grandfather
,
I
deserved
that
suspicion
,
but
I
do
not
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
Chorus
put
its
hand
in
its
waistcoat
,
and
smiled
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
go
on
,
my
worthy
sir
,
"
it
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
you
are
thinking
of
,
but
do
n't
express
it
prematurely
.
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
raised
his
eyes
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
face
,
and
appearing
to
derive
renewed
instruction
from
his
looks
and
words
,
said
,
once
again
:
   
"
Go
on
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
little
more
to
say
,
"
returned
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
as
I
say
it
now
,
with
little
or
no
hope
,
Grandfather
;
whatever
dawn
of
hope
I
had
on
entering
the
room
;
believe
it
to
be
true
.
 
<EOS>
At
least
,
believe
it
to
be
true
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Beautiful
Truth
!
"
exclaimed
the
Chorus
,
looking
upward
.
 
<EOS>
"
How
is
your
name
profaned
by
vicious
persons
!
 
<EOS>
You
do
n't
live
in
a
well
,
my
holy
principle
,
but
on
the
lips
of
false
mankind
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
hard
to
bear
with
mankind
,
dear
sir
"
---
addressing
the
elder
Mr
Chuzzlewit
;
"
but
let
us
do
so
meekly
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
our
duty
so
to
do
.
 
<EOS>
Let
us
be
among
the
Few
who
do
their
duty
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
"
pursued
the
Chorus
,
soaring
up
into
a
lofty
flight
,
"
as
the
poet
informs
us
,
England
expects
Every
man
to
do
his
duty
,
England
is
the
most
sanguine
country
on
the
face
of
the
earth
,
and
will
find
itself
continually
disappointed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
that
subject
,
"
said
Martin
,
looking
calmly
at
the
old
man
as
he
spoke
,
but
glancing
once
at
Mary
,
whose
face
was
now
buried
in
her
hands
,
upon
the
back
of
his
easy
-
chair
;
"
upon
that
subject
which
first
occasioned
a
division
between
us
,
<EOS>
my
mind
and
heart
are
incapable
of
change
.
 
<EOS>
Whatever
influence
they
have
undergone
,
since
that
unhappy
time
,
has
not
been
one
to
weaken
but
to
strengthen
me
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
profess
sorrow
for
that
,
nor
irresolution
in
that
,
nor
shame
in
that
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
would
you
wish
me
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
I
might
have
trusted
to
your
love
,
if
I
had
thrown
myself
manfully
upon
it
;
that
I
might
have
won
you
over
with
ease
,
if
I
had
been
more
yielding
and
more
considerate
;
that
I
should
have
best
remembered
myself
in
forgetting
myself
,
and
recollecting
you
;
reflection
,
solitude
,
and
misery
,
have
taught
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
came
resolved
to
say
this
,
and
to
ask
your
forgiveness
;
not
so
much
in
hope
for
the
future
,
as
in
regret
for
the
past
;
for
all
that
I
would
ask
of
you
is
,
that
you
would
aid
me
to
live
.
 
<EOS>
Help
me
to
get
honest
work
to
do
,
and
I
would
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
My
condition
places
me
at
the
disadvantage
of
seeming
to
have
only
my
selfish
ends
to
serve
,
but
try
if
that
be
so
or
not
.
<EOS>
Try
if
I
be
self
-
willed
,
obdurate
,
and
haughty
,
as
I
was
;
or
have
been
disciplined
in
a
rough
school
.
 
<EOS>
Let
the
voice
of
nature
and
association
plead
between
us
,
Grandfather
;
and
do
not
,
for
one
fault
,
however
thankless
,
quite
reject
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
ceased
,
the
grey
head
of
the
old
man
drooped
again
;
and
he
concealed
his
face
behind
his
outspread
fingers
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
sir
,
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
bending
over
him
,
"
you
must
not
give
way
to
this
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
very
natural
,
and
very
amiable
,
but
you
must
not
allow
the
shameless
conduct
of
one
whom
you
long
ago
cast
off
,
to
move
you
so
far
.
 
<EOS>
Rouse
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
Think
,
"
said
Pecksniff
,
"
think
of
Me
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
returned
old
Martin
,
looking
up
into
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
recall
me
to
myself
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
sitting
down
beside
him
in
a
chair
which
he
drew
up
for
the
purpose
,
and
tapping
him
playfully
on
the
arm
<EOS>
,
"
what
is
the
matter
with
my
strong
-
minded
compatriot
,
if
I
may
venture
to
take
the
liberty
of
calling
him
by
that
endearing
expression
?
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
have
to
scold
my
coadjutor
,
or
to
reason
with
an
intellect
like
this
?
 
<EOS>
I
think
not
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
occasion
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
momentary
feeling
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
more
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indignation
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
WILL
bring
the
scalding
tear
into
the
honest
eye
,
I
know
"
---
he
wiped
his
own
elaborately
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
we
have
highest
duties
to
perform
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
Rouse
yourself
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
Shall
I
give
expression
to
your
thoughts
,
my
friend
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
old
Martin
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
and
looking
at
him
,
half
in
vacancy
and
half
in
admiration
,
as
if
he
were
fascinated
by
the
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Speak
for
me
,
Pecksniff
,
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
true
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
not
unman
me
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shaking
his
hand
vigorously
,
"
or
I
shall
be
unequal
to
the
task
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
agreeable
to
my
feelings
,
my
good
sir
,
to
address
the
person
who
is
now
before
us
,
for
when
I
ejected
him
from
this
house
,
<EOS>
after
hearing
of
his
unnatural
conduct
from
your
lips
,
I
renounced
communication
with
him
for
ever
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
desire
it
;
and
that
is
sufficient
.
 
<EOS>
Young
man
!
<EOS>
The
door
is
immediately
behind
the
companion
of
your
infamy
.
 
<EOS>
Blush
if
you
can
;
begone
without
a
blush
,
if
you
ca
n't
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
looked
as
steadily
at
his
grandfather
as
if
there
had
been
a
dead
silence
all
this
time
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
no
less
steadily
at
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
ordered
you
to
leave
this
house
upon
the
last
occasion
of
your
being
dismissed
from
it
with
disgrace
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
;
"
when
,
stung
and
stimulated
beyond
endurance
by
your
shameless
conduct
to
this
extraordinarily
noble
-
minded
individual
,
I
exclaimed
"
Go
forth
!
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
that
I
wept
for
your
depravity
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
suppose
that
the
tear
which
stands
in
my
eye
at
this
moment
,
is
shed
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
shed
for
him
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
shed
for
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Mr
Pecksniff
,
accidentally
dropping
the
tear
in
question
on
a
bald
part
of
Mr
Chuzzlewit
's
head
,
wiped
the
place
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
and
begged
pardon
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
shed
for
him
,
sir
,
whom
you
seek
to
make
the
victim
of
your
arts
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
;
"
whom
you
seek
to
plunder
,
to
deceive
,
and
to
mislead
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
shed
in
sympathy
with
him
,
and
admiration
of
him
;
not
in
pity
for
him
,
for
happily
he
knows
what
you
are
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
not
wrong
him
further
,
sir
,
in
any
way
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
quite
transported
with
enthusiasm
,
"
while
I
have
life
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
bestride
my
senseless
corse
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
very
likely
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
imagine
a
mind
like
yours
deriving
great
satisfaction
from
any
measure
of
that
kind
.
 
<EOS>
But
while
I
continue
to
be
called
upon
to
exist
,
sir
,
you
must
strike
at
him
through
me
.
 
<EOS>
Awe
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shaking
his
head
at
Martin
with
indignant
jocularity
;
"
and
in
such
a
cause
you
will
find
me
,
my
young
sir
,
an
Ugly
Customer
!
"
   
<EOS>
Still
Martin
looked
steadily
and
mildly
at
his
grandfather
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
give
me
no
answer
,
"
he
said
,
at
length
,
"
not
a
word
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
hear
what
has
been
said
,
"
replied
the
old
man
,
without
averting
his
eyes
from
the
face
of
Mr
Pecksniff
;
who
nodded
encouragingly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
heard
your
voice
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
heard
your
spirit
,
"
returned
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
again
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
still
gazing
up
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
only
hear
,
"
replied
Martin
,
strong
in
his
purpose
from
the
first
,
and
stronger
in
it
as
he
felt
how
Pecksniff
winced
and
shrunk
beneath
his
contempt
;
"
I
only
hear
what
you
say
to
me
,
grandfather
.
"
   
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
well
for
Mr
Pecksniff
that
his
venerable
friend
found
in
his
<EOS>
(
Mr
Pecksniff
's
)
features
an
exclusive
and
engrossing
object
of
contemplation
,
for
if
his
eyes
had
gone
astray
,
and
he
had
compared
young
Martin
's
bearing
with
that
of
his
zealous
defender
,
the
latter
disinterested
gentleman
would
scarcely
have
shown
to
greater
advantage
than
on
the
memorable
afternoon
when
he
took
Tom
Pinch
's
last
receipt
in
full
of
all
demands
.
 
<EOS>
One
really
might
have
thought
there
was
some
quality
in
Mr
Pecksniff
---
an
emanation
from
the
brightness
and
purity
within
him
perhaps
---
which
set
off
and
adorned
his
foes
;
they
looked
so
gallant
and
so
manly
beside
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
?
<EOS>
"
said
Martin
,
for
the
second
time
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
that
I
have
a
word
to
say
,
Pecksniff
,
"
observed
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
You
spoke
of
being
indebted
to
the
charitable
help
of
some
stranger
for
the
means
of
returning
to
England
.
 
<EOS>
Who
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
And
what
help
in
money
did
he
render
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Although
he
asked
this
question
of
Martin
,
he
did
not
look
towards
him
,
but
kept
his
eyes
on
Mr
Pecksniff
as
before
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
have
become
a
habit
with
him
,
both
in
a
literal
and
figurative
sense
,
to
look
to
Mr
Pecksniff
alone
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
took
out
his
pencil
,
tore
a
leaf
from
his
pocket
-
book
,
and
hastily
wrote
down
the
particulars
of
his
debt
to
Mr
Bevan
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
stretched
out
his
hand
for
the
paper
,
and
took
it
;
but
his
eyes
did
not
wander
from
Mr
Pecksniff
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
poor
pride
and
a
false
humility
,
"
said
Martin
,
in
a
low
voice
,
"
to
say
,
I
do
not
wish
that
to
be
paid
,
or
that
I
have
any
present
hope
of
being
able
to
pay
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
felt
my
poverty
so
deeply
as
I
feel
it
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Read
it
to
me
,
Pecksniff
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
,
after
approaching
the
perusal
of
the
paper
as
if
it
were
a
manuscript
confession
of
a
murder
,
complied
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Pecksniff
,
"
said
old
Martin
,
"
I
could
wish
that
to
be
discharged
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
not
like
the
lender
,
who
was
abroad
,
who
had
no
opportunity
of
making
inquiry
,
and
who
did
(
as
he
thought
)
a
kind
action
,
to
suffer
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
An
honourable
sentiment
,
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Your
own
entirely
.
 
<EOS>
But
a
dangerous
precedent
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
permit
me
to
suggest
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
shall
not
be
a
precedent
,
"
returned
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
only
recognition
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
we
will
talk
of
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
advise
me
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
else
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Nothing
else
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
buoyantly
,
"
but
for
you
to
recover
this
intrusion
---
this
cowardly
and
indefensible
outrage
on
your
feelings
---
with
all
possible
dispatch
,
and
smile
again
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
nothing
more
to
say
?
<EOS>
"
inquired
the
old
man
,
laying
his
hand
with
unusual
earnestness
on
Mr
Pecksniff
's
sleeve
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
would
not
say
what
rose
to
his
lips
.
 
<EOS>
For
reproaches
he
observed
,
were
useless
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
nothing
at
all
to
urge
?
 
<EOS>
You
are
sure
of
that
!
 
<EOS>
If
you
have
,
no
matter
what
it
is
,
speak
freely
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
oppose
nothing
that
you
ask
of
me
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
   
<EOS>
The
tears
rose
in
such
abundance
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
eyes
at
this
proof
of
unlimited
confidence
on
the
part
of
his
friend
,
that
he
was
fain
to
clasp
the
bridge
of
his
nose
convulsively
before
he
could
at
all
compose
himself
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
the
power
of
utterance
again
,
he
said
with
great
emotion
,
that
he
hoped
he
should
live
to
deserve
this
;
and
added
,
that
he
had
no
other
observation
whatever
to
make
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
few
moments
the
old
man
sat
looking
at
him
,
with
that
blank
and
motionless
expression
which
is
not
uncommon
in
the
faces
of
those
whose
faculties
are
on
the
wane
,
in
age
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
rose
up
firmly
too
,
and
walked
towards
the
door
,
from
which
Mark
withdrew
to
make
way
for
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
obsequious
Mr
Pecksniff
proffered
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
took
it
.
<EOS>
Turning
at
the
door
,
he
said
to
Martin
,
waving
him
off
with
his
hand
,
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
heard
him
.
 
<EOS>
Go
away
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
all
over
.
 
<EOS>
Go
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
murmured
certain
cheering
expressions
of
sympathy
and
encouragement
as
they
retired
;
and
Martin
,
awakening
from
the
stupor
into
which
the
closing
portion
of
this
scene
had
plunged
him
,
to
the
opportunity
afforded
by
their
departure
,
caught
the
innocent
cause
of
all
in
his
embrace
,
and
pressed
her
to
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
girl
!
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
not
changed
you
.
 
<EOS>
Why
,
what
an
impotent
and
harmless
<EOS>
knave
the
fellow
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
restrained
yourself
so
nobly
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
borne
so
much
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Restrained
myself
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
cheerfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
were
by
,
and
were
unchanged
,
I
knew
.
 
<EOS>
What
more
advantage
did
I
want
?
 
<EOS>
The
sight
of
me
was
such
a
bitterness
to
the
dog
,
that
I
had
my
triumph
in
his
being
forced
to
endure
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
tell
me
,
love
---
for
the
few
hasty
words
we
can
exchange
now
are
precious
---
what
is
this
which
has
been
rumoured
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
true
that
you
are
persecuted
by
this
knave
's
addresses
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
,
dear
Martin
,
and
to
some
extent
am
now
;
but
my
chief
source
of
unhappiness
has
been
anxiety
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
you
leave
us
in
such
terrible
suspense
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sickness
,
distance
;
the
dread
of
hinting
at
our
real
condition
,
the
impossibility
of
concealing
it
except
in
perfect
silence
;
the
knowledge
that
the
truth
would
have
pained
you
infinitely
more
than
uncertainty
and
doubt
,
"
said
Martin
,
hurriedly
;
as
indeed
everything
else
was
done
and
said
,
in
those
few
hurried
moments
,
"
were
the
causes
of
my
writing
only
once
.
 
<EOS>
But
Pecksniff
?
 
<EOS>
You
need
n't
fear
to
tell
me
the
whole
tale
;
for
you
saw
me
with
him
face
to
face
,
hearing
him
speak
,
and
not
taking
him
by
the
throat
;
what
is
the
history
of
his
pursuit
of
you
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
known
to
my
grandfather
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And
he
assists
him
in
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
answered
eagerly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thank
Heaven
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
"
that
it
leaves
his
mind
unclouded
in
that
one
respect
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
,
"
said
Mary
,
"
it
was
known
to
him
at
first
.
 
<EOS>
When
this
man
had
sufficiently
prepared
his
mind
,
he
revealed
it
to
him
by
degrees
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
so
,
but
<EOS>
I
only
know
it
from
my
own
impression
:
now
from
anything
they
told
me
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
spoke
to
me
alone
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
grandfather
did
?
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
---
spoke
to
me
alone
,
and
told
me
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
the
hound
had
said
,
"
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
repeat
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
said
I
knew
well
what
qualities
he
possessed
;
that
he
was
moderately
rich
;
in
good
repute
;
and
high
in
his
favour
and
confidence
.
 
<EOS>
But
seeing
me
very
much
distressed
,
he
said
that
he
would
not
control
or
force
my
inclinations
,
but
would
content
himself
with
telling
me
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
not
pain
me
by
dwelling
on
it
,
or
reverting
to
it
;
nor
has
he
ever
done
so
since
,
but
has
truly
kept
his
word
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
man
himself
?
<EOS>
---
"
asked
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
has
had
few
opportunities
of
pursuing
his
suit
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
walked
out
alone
,
or
remained
alone
an
instant
in
his
presence
.
<EOS>
Dear
Martin
,
I
must
tell
you
,
"
she
continued
,
"
that
the
kindness
of
your
grandfather
to
me
remains
unchanged
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
his
companion
still
.
<EOS>
An
indescribable
tenderness
and
compassion
seem
to
have
mingled
themselves
with
his
old
regard
;
and
if
I
were
his
only
child
,
I
could
not
have
a
gentler
father
.
 
<EOS>
What
former
fancy
or
old
habit
survives
in
this
,
when
his
heart
has
turned
so
cold
to
you
,
is
a
mystery
I
can
not
penetrate
;
but
it
has
been
,
and
it
is
,
a
happiness
to
me
,
that
I
remained
true
to
him
;
that
if
he
should
wake
from
his
delusion
,
even
at
the
point
of
death
,
I
am
here
,
love
,
to
recall
you
to
his
thoughts
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
looked
with
admiration
on
her
glowing
face
,
and
pressed
his
lips
to
hers
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
sometimes
heard
,
and
read
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
those
whose
powers
had
been
enfeebled
long
ago
,
and
whose
lives
had
faded
,
as
it
were
,
into
a
dream
,
have
been
known
to
rouse
themselves
before
death
,
and
inquire
for
familiar
faces
once
very
dear
to
them
;
but
forgotten
,
unrecognized
,
hated
even
,
in
the
meantime
.
 
<EOS>
Think
,
if
with
his
old
impressions
of
this
man
,
he
should
suddenly
resume
his
former
self
,
and
find
in
him
his
only
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
not
urge
you
to
abandon
him
,
dearest
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
though
I
could
count
the
years
we
are
to
wear
out
asunder
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
influence
this
fellow
exercises
over
him
has
steadily
increased
,
I
fear
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
could
not
help
admitting
that
.
 
<EOS>
Steadily
,
imperceptibly
,
and
surely
,
until
it
was
paramount
and
supreme
.
 
<EOS>
She
herself
had
none
;
and
yet
he
treated
her
with
more
affection
than
at
any
previous
time
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
thought
the
inconsistency
a
part
of
his
weakness
and
decay
.
   
<EOS>
"
Does
the
influence
extend
to
fear
?
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
he
timid
of
asserting
his
own
opinion
in
the
presence
of
this
infatuation
?
 
<EOS>
I
fancied
so
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
so
,
often
.
 
<EOS>
Often
when
we
are
sitting
alone
,
almost
as
we
used
to
do
,
and
I
have
been
reading
a
favourite
book
to
him
or
he
has
been
talking
quite
cheerfully
<EOS>
,
I
have
observed
that
the
entrance
of
Mr
Pecksniff
has
changed
his
whole
demeanour
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
broken
off
immediately
,
and
become
what
you
have
seen
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
When
we
first
came
here
he
had
his
impetuous
outbreaks
,
in
which
it
was
not
easy
for
Mr
Pecksniff
with
his
utmost

to
appease
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
these
have
long
since
dwindled
away
.
 
<EOS>
He
defers
to
him
in
everything
,
and
has
no
opinion
upon
any
question
,
but
that
which
is
forced
upon
him
by
this
treacherous
man
.
"
   
<EOS>
Such
was
the
account
,
rapidly
furnished
in
whispers
,
and
interrupted
,
brief
as
it
was
,
by
many
false
alarms
of
Mr
Pecksniff
's
return
;
which
Martin
received
of
his
grandfather
's
decline
,
and
of
that
good
gentleman
's
ascendancy
.
 
<EOS>
He
heard
of
Tom
Pinch
too
,
and
Jonas
too
,
with
not
a
little
about
himself
into
the
bargain
;
for
though
lovers
are
remarkable
for
leaving
a
great
deal
unsaid
on
all
occasions
,
and
very
properly
desiring
to
come
back
and
say
it
,
they
are
remarkable
also
for
a
wonderful
power
of
condensation
,
and
can
,
in
one
way
or
other
,
give
utterance
to
more
language
---
eloquent
language
---
in
any

of
time
,
than
all
the
six
hundred
and
fifty
-
eight
members
in
the
Commons
House
of
Parliament
of
the
United
Kingdom
of
Great
Britain
and
Ireland
;
who
are
strong
lovers
no
doubt
,
but
of
their
country
only
,
which
makes
all
the
difference
;
for
in
a
passion
of
that
kind
(
which
is
not
always
returned
)
,
it
is
the
custom
to
use
as
many
words
as
possible
,
and
express
nothing
whatever
.
   
<EOS>
A
caution
from
Mr
Tapley
;
a
hasty
interchange
of
farewells
,
and
of
something
else
which
the
proverb
says
must
not
be
told
of
afterwards
;
a
white
hand
held
out
to
Mr
Tapley
himself
,
which
he
kissed
with
the

of
a
knight
-

;
more
farewells
,
more
something
else
's
;
a
parting
word
from
Martin
that
he
would
write
from
London
and
would
do
great
things
there
yet
<EOS>
(
Heaven
knows
what
,
but
he
quite
believed
it
)
;
and
Mark
and
he
stood
on
the
outside

the
Pecksniffian

.
   
<EOS>
"
A
short
interview
after
such
an
absence
!
<EOS>
"
said
Martin
,
sorrowfully
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
are
well

the

.
 
<EOS>
We
might
have
placed
ourselves
in
a
false

by

,
even

,
Mark
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know

ourselves
,

,
"
he

;
"
but
somebody
else
would
have
got

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

the

,

.
 
<EOS>
If

had

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He
's

,
"

Tapley
,

,
"
as
would

,
I
know
.
"
   
<EOS>
A
person
who
was
evidently
going
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
,
passed

.
 
<EOS>
He

the

the

's

;
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

,

;
for
the

,
as

,
had

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
may

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The
face
seems

,

I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He

amiable

that
his

familiar

,
"

,
"
for

's
a
-
staring

hard
.
<EOS>
He
'd
better
not
waste
his
beauty
,
for
he
ai
n't
got

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Coming

of

Dragon
,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
That
's

in
depend

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
A

,
I
should
n't

.
 
<EOS>
P'raps
it
's

grammar
-

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Before

at
the

,

;
and

to
the

showed

CHUZZLEWIT

.
   
<EOS>
"
Miss
Pecksniff
's
husband
that

,
"

good
woman

.
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
what
terms
you
might
be
on
,
and
was
quite
in
a
worry
till
you
came
back
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
and
I
have
never
interchanged

yet
,
"
observed

;
"
and
as
I

no

better

,
I
will

.
 
<EOS>
We
passed

on
the
road
,
I
have

.
 
<EOS>
I
am

he
timed
his
coming
as
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
!
 
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
's
husband
travels
gaily
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
very
fine
-
looking
gentleman
with
him
---
in
the
best
room
now
,
"
whispered
Mrs
Lupin
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has

everything
that
can

got
for

;
and

and

ever

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Has

?
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
"
why
then
we
'll
endeavour
to

,
in

that
our
self
-

may

strong

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Our
visit
has
met
with
no

,
my

Mrs
Lupin
,

London
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
,

!
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
one
foul
wind
<EOS>
no
more
makes
a

,
than
one

a

.
 
<EOS>
I
'll

again
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
has

.
 
<EOS>
With
his

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
God

!
"
<EOS>

,

;
"

.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
Tom

take

HIS

,

.
"
    
Chapter
44
.
<EOS>
Further
continuation
of
the
enterprise
of
Mr
Jonas
and
his
friend
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
special
quality
,
among
the
many
admirable
qualities
possessed
by
Mr
Pecksniff
,
that
the
more
he
was
found
out
,
the
more
hypocrisy
he
practised
.
 
<EOS>
Let
him
be
discomfited
in
one
quarter
,
and
he
refreshed
and
recompensed
himself
by
carrying
the
war
into
another
.
 
<EOS>
If
his
workings
and
windings
were
detected
by
A
,
so
much
the
greater
reason
was
there
for
practicing
without
loss
of
time
on
B
,
if
it
were
only
to
keep
his
hand
in
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
never
been
such
a
saintly
and
improving
spectacle
to
all
about
him
,
as
after
his
detection
by
Thomas
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
ever
been
at
once
<EOS>
so
tender
in
his
humanity
,
and
so
dignified
and
exalted
in
his
virtue
,
as
when
young
Martin
's
scorn
was
fresh
and
hot
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
Having
this
large
stock
of
superfluous
sentiment
and
morality
on
hand
which
must
positively
be
cleared
off
at
any
sacrifice
,
Mr
Pecksniff
no
sooner
heard
his
son
-
in
-
law
announced
,
than
he
regarded
him
as
a
kind
of
wholesale
or
general
order
,
to
be
immediately
executed
.
 
<EOS>
Descending
,
therefore
,
swiftly
to
the
parlour
,
and
clasping
the
young
man
in
his
arms
,
he
exclaimed
,
with
looks
and
gestures
that
denoted
the
perturbation
of
his
spirit
:
   
<EOS>
"
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
My
child
---
she
is
well
!
 
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
you
're
at
it
again
,
are
you
?
"
<EOS>
replied
his
son
-
in
-
law
.
 
<EOS>
"
Even
with
me
?
 
<EOS>
Get
away
with
you
,
will
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
she
is
well
then
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
she
is
well
my
boy
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
well
enough
,
"
retorted
Jonas
,
disengaging
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
the
matter
with
HER
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
the
matter
with
her
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
sitting
down
in
the
nearest
chair
,
and
rubbing
up
his
hair
.
 
<EOS>
"
Fie
upon
my
weakness
!
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
help
it
,
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
better
now
.
<EOS>
How
is
my
other
child
;
my
eldest
;
my
Cherrywerrychigo
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
inventing
a
playful
little
name
for
her
,
in
the
restored
lightness
of
his
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
's
much
about
the
same
as
usual
,
"
returned
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
sticks
pretty
close
to
the
vinegar
-
bottle
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
she
's
got
a
sweetheart
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
of
it
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
from
headquarters
;
from
my
child
herself
I
will
not
deny
that
it
moved
me
to
contemplate
the
loss
of
my
remaining
daughter
,
Jonas
<EOS>
---
I
am
afraid
we
parents
are
selfish
,
I
am
afraid
we
are
---
but
it
has
ever
been
the
study
of
my
life
to
qualify
them
for
the
domestic
hearth
;
and
it
is
a
sphere
which
Cherry
will
adorn
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She
need
adorn
some
sphere
or
other
,
"
observed
the
son
-
in
-
law
,
for
she
ai
n't
very
ornamental
in
general
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
girls
are
now
provided
for
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
now
happily
provided
for
,
and
I
have
not
laboured
in
vain
!
"
   
<EOS>
This
is
exactly
what
Mr
Pecksniff
would
have
said
,
if
one
of
his
daughters
had
drawn
a
prize
of
thirty
thousand
pounds
in
the
lottery
,
or
if
the
other
had
picked
up
a
valuable
purse
in
the
street
,
which
nobody
appeared
to
claim
.
 
<EOS>
In
either
of
these
cases
he
would
have
invoked
a
patriarchal
blessing
on
the
fortunate
head
,
with
great
solemnity
,
and
would
have
taken
immense
credit
to
himself
,
as
having
meant
it
from
the
infant
's
cradle
.
   
<EOS>
"
Suppose
we
talk
about
something
else
,
now
,
"
observed
Jonas
,
drily
.
<EOS>
"
just
for
a
change
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
quite
agreeable
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
wag
,
you
naughty
wag
!
 
<EOS>
You
laugh
at
poor
old
fond
papa
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
He
deserves
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
do
n't
mind
it
either
,
for
his
feelings
are
their
own
reward
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
come
to
stay
with
me
,
Jonas
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
got
a
friend
with
me
,
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Bring
your
friend
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
in
a
gush
of
hospitality
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
any
number
of
your
friends
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
ai
n't
the
sort
of
man
to
be
brought
,
"
said
Jonas
,
contemptuously
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
see
myself
"
bringing
"
him
to
your
house
,
for
a
treat
!
 
<EOS>
Thank'ee
all
the
same
;
but
he
's
a
little
too
near
the
top
of
the
tree
for
that
,
Pecksniff
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
good
man
pricked
up
his
ears
;
his
interest
was
awakened
.
 
<EOS>
A
position
near
the
top
of
the
tree
was
greatness
,
virtue
,
goodness
,
sense
,
genius
;
or
,
it
should
rather

said
,
a
dispensation
from
all
,
and
in
itself
something
immeasurably
better
than
all
;
with
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
A
man
who
was
able
to
look
down
upon
Mr
Pecksniff
could
not
be
looked
up
at
,
by
that
gentleman
,
with
too
great
an
amount
of
deference
,
or
from
a
position
of
too
much

.
 
<EOS>
So
it
always
is
with
great
spirits
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
you
may
do
,
if
you
like
,
"
said
Jonas
;
"
you
may
come
and
dine
with
us
at
the
Dragon
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
forced
to
come
down
to
Salisbury
last
night
,
on
some
business
,
and
I
got
him
to
bring

over

this

,
in

;
at
least
,
not

own

,
for

,
but
<EOS>
one

hired
instead
<EOS>
;

's

.
 
<EOS>
Mind
<EOS>
what
you
're
about
,

.
 
<EOS>
He
's
not

to
all

;
he

with

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Some
young

who
has
been

of

at

,
eh
?
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shaking

facetiously
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
delighted
to
know
the
gay
sprig
.
"
   
"
Borrowing
!
"
echoed
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Borrowing
!
 
<EOS>
When
you
're
a
twentieth
part
as
rich
as
he
is
,
you
may
shut

!
 
<EOS>
We

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
A

:
Mr
Montague
!
 
<EOS>
Why
since
I

(
come
!
<EOS>
and
I
'll

,
sharp

,
too
)
to

the

office
that
he

<EOS>
,

---

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
But
,
Ecod
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
my
dear
Jonas
,
"
cried

,
with

,
"
a

.
 
<EOS>
Would

?
<EOS>
or

---

.
 
<EOS>
Salisbury
Cathedral
,
my
dear
Jonas
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
;
the
mention
of

and
his

display

to
advantage
,
suggesting
his
usual
phraseology
in
that

,
"
is
an
edifice
replete
with
venerable

,
and

.
 
<EOS>
It
is
here
<EOS>
we
contemplate
the
work
of

.
 
<EOS>
It

here
<EOS>
we
listen

,

.
 
<EOS>
We
have

of
this

from

,

South
,
from
the
East
,
from
the
West
,
from
the
South
-
East
,
from
the
Nor'West
---
"
   
During
this

,
and
indeed

the
whole

,
Jonas
had
been
rocking
on
his
chair
,
with
his
hands
in

and
his

on
one

.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Mr
Pecksniff
now
with
such
shrewd
meaning
twinkling
in
his

,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
stopped
,
and
asked
him
what

was

say
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
!
"
<EOS>
he
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pecksniff
<EOS>
if
I
knew
how
you
meant
to
leave
your
money
,
I
could
put
you
in

way
of
doubling

in

.
<EOS>
It

to

.
<EOS>
But
you
're
such

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jonas
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
much
affected
,
"
I
am
not
a
diplomatical
character
;
my
heart
is
in
my
hand
.
 
<EOS>
By
far

greater
part
of
the

I

---
<EOS>
I

---
a

,

,

,

(

,

,

)
,

,

;
and
in

which
it

mention
to
a
person
whom
I

,
whom

,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Here

gave

his
son
-

-
law
a

,
as

added
,
"
God

;

when

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jonas
only
shook
his

and

,
and
,
seeming
to
think
better
of
what
he
had
had
in

,
said
,
"
No
.
 
<EOS>
He
would
keep
his
own
counsel
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
as
he
observed
that
he
would
take
a

,
Mr
Pecksniff
insisted
on

him
,
remarking
that
he
could
leave
a

for
Mr
Montague
,
as
they
went
along
,
by
way
of
gentleman
-
usher
to
himself
at
dinner
-
time
.
 
<EOS>
Which
he
did
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
their
walk
,
Mr
Jonas
affected
to
maintain
that
close
reserve
which
had
operated
as
a
timely
check
upon
him
during
the
foregoing

.
 
<EOS>
And
as
he
made
no
attempt
to
conciliate
Mr
Pecksniff
,
but
,
on
the
contrary
,
was
more
boorish
and
rude
to
him
than
usual
,
that
gentleman
,
so
far
from
suspecting
his
real
design
,
laid
himself
out
to
be
attacked
with
advantage
.
 
<EOS>
For
it
is
in
the
nature
of
a
knave
to
think
the
tools
with
which
he
works
indispensable
to
knavery
;
and
knowing
what
he

do

in

,
Mr

,
"

wanted
anything

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The
more
Jonas
repelled

in
his

and

,
the
more
solicitous
,
therefore
,
Mr
Pecksniff
became
to
be
initiated
into
the
golden

at
which
he
had

.
 
<EOS>
Why
should
there
be
cold
and
worldly
secrets
,
he
observed
,
between
relations
?
<EOS>
What
was
life
without
confidence
?
 
<EOS>
If
the
chosen

of
his
daughter
,
the
man
to
whom
he
had
delivered

with
so

,
such

and
such

;
if

,
where
was
that

to

?
   
<EOS>
Little
<EOS>
did
Mr
Pecksniff
think
on
what
a
very
green
spot
he
planted
one

at

!
 
<EOS>
Little

when

said
,
"
All
is
but
dust
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
how
very

he
would
come
down
with

!
   
<EOS>
Inch

,
in

ill

;
sustained

,
for

,
the

,

Jonas

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
And

(

,

a

himself
,

<EOS>
some

,

.
 
<EOS>
Otherwise

"

<EOS>
Primed

<EOS>
The

,

,

;

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Welcome
,

,
"

,
"

!
<EOS>
We

;
primitive

,
Mr
Montague
;
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
"

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

,
"

,
"

hair
<EOS>
---
I
must
have
seen
you
,
my

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
Nothing

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

:

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

.

<EOS>
"

?
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
You
would

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Jonas
!
<EOS>
my

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
 
<EOS>
Is

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
and
here

all

---
especially
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
<EOS>
"
said
that

,

-

-

.
 
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
Mr
Pecksniff
,
"
cried
Montague
,
<EOS>
"
I
attach
the
greatest
importance
to
that
last

of

.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
and

's

.
 
<EOS>
Money
can
not

turned
and
turned
again
quickly
enough
in
the

,
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
like
building

on
the

of

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
fie
!
<EOS>
oh
fie
,
for

!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
all
laughed
again
---
especially
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
give
you
my
honour
that
WE
do
it
,
"
said
Montague
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
fie
,
fie
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
am
sure
you
do
n't
!
 
<EOS>
That
I
am
sure
you
do
n't
!
 
<EOS>
How
CAN
you
,
you
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
Again

all
laughed
in
concert
;
and
again
Mr
Pecksniff
laughed
especially
.
   
<EOS>
This
was
very
agreeable
indeed
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
confidential
,
easy
,
straight
-
forward
;
and
still
left
Mr
Pecksniff
in
the
position
of
being
in
a
gentle
way
the
Mentor
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
The
greatest
achievements
in
the
article
of
cookery
that
the
Dragon
had
ever
performed
,
were
set
before
them
;
the
oldest
and
best
wines
in
the
Dragon
's
cellar
saw
the
light
on
that
occasion
;
a
thousand
bubbles
,
indicative
of
the
wealth
and
station
of
Mr
Montague
in
the
depths
of
his
pursuits
,
were
constantly
rising
to
the
surface
of
the
conversation
;
and
they
were
as
frank
and
merry
as
three
honest
men
could
be
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
thought
it
a
pity
(
he
said
so
)
that
Mr
Montague
should
think
lightly
of
mankind
and
their
weaknesses
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
anxious
upon
this
subject
;
his
mind
ran
upon
it
;
in
one
way
or
another
he
was
constantly
coming
back
to
it
;
he
must
make
a
convert
of
him
,
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
often
as
Mr
Montague
repeated
his
sentiment
about
building
fortunes
on
the
weaknesses
of
mankind
,
and
added
frankly
,
"
WE
do
it
!
<EOS>
"
just
as
often
Mr
Pecksniff
repeated
"
Oh
fie
!
<EOS>
oh
fie
,
for
shame
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
How
CAN
you
,
you
know
?
<EOS>
"
laying
a
greater
stress
each
time
on
those
last
words
.
   
<EOS>
The
frequent
repetition
of
this
playful
inquiry
on
the
part
of
Mr
Pecksniff
,
led
at
last
to
playful
answers
on
the
part
of
Mr
Montague
;
but
after
some
little
sharp
-
shooting
on
both
sides
,
Mr
Pecksniff
became
grave
,
almost
to
tears
;
observing
that
if
Mr
Montague
would
give
him
leave
,
he
would
drink
the
health
of
his
young
kinsman
,
Mr
Jonas
;
congratulating
him
upon
the
valuable
and
distinguished
friendship
he
had
formed
,
but
envying
him
,
he
would
confess
,
his
usefulness
to
his
fellow
-
creatures
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
if
he
understood
the
objects
of
that
Institution
with
which
he
was
newly
and
advantageously
connected
---
knowing
them
but
imperfectly
---
they
were
calculated
to
do
Good
;
and
for
his
(
Mr
Pecksniff
's
)
part
,
if
he
could
in
any
way
promote
them
,
he
thought
he
would
be
able
to
lay
his
head
upon
his
pillow
every
night
,
with
an
absolute
certainty
of
going
to
sleep
at
once
.
   
<EOS>
The
transition
from
this
accidental
remark
(
for
it
was
quite
accidental
and
had
fallen
from
Mr
Pecksniff
in
the
openness
of
his
soul
)
,
to
the
discussion
of
the
subject
as
a
matter
of
business
,
was
easy
.
 
<EOS>
Books
,
papers
,
statements
,
tables
,
calculations
of
various
kinds
,
were
soon
spread
out
before
them
;
and
as
they
were
all
framed
with
one
object
,
it
is
not
surprising
that
they
should
all
have
tended
to
one
end
.
 
<EOS>
But
still
,
whenever
Montague
enlarged
upon
the
profits
of
the
office
,
and
said
that
as
long
as
there
were
gulls
upon
the
wing
it
must
succeed
,
Mr
Pecksniff
mildly
said
"
Oh
fie
!
"
<EOS>
---
 
and
might
indeed
have
remonstrated
with
him
,
but
that
he
knew
he
was
joking
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
did
know
he
was
joking
;
because
he
said
so
.
   
<EOS>
There
never
had
been
before
,
and
there
never
would
be
again
,
such
an
opportunity
for
the
investment
of
a
considerable
sum
(
the
rate
of
advantage
increased
in
proportion
to
the
amount
invested
)
,
as
at
that
moment
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
time
that
had
at
all
approached
it
,
was
the
time
when
Jonas
had
come
into
the
concern
;
which
made
him
ill
-
natured
now
,
and
inclined
him
to
pick
out
a
doubt
in
this
place
,
and
a
flaw
in
that
,
and
grumbling
to
advise
Mr
Pecksniff
to
think
better
of
it
.
<EOS>
The
sum
which
would
complete
the
proprietorship
in
this
snug
concern
,
was
nearly
equal
to
Mr
Pecksniff
's
whole
hoard
;
not
counting
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
that
is
to
say
,
whom
he
looked
upon
as
money
in
the
Bank
,
the
possession
of
which
inclined
him
the
more
to
make
a
dash
with
his
own
private
sprats
for
the
capture
of
such
a
whale
as
Mr
Montague
described
.
 
<EOS>
The
returns
began
almost
immediately
,
and
were
immense
.
 
<EOS>
The
end
of
it
was
,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
agreed
to
become
the
last
partner
and
proprietor
in
the
Anglo
-
Bengalee
,
and
made
an
appointment
to
dine
with
Mr
Montague
,
at
Salisbury
,
on
the
next
day
but
one
,
then
and
there
to
complete
the
negotiation
.
   
<EOS>
It
took
so
long
to
bring
the
subject
to
this
head
,
that
it
was
nearly
midnight
when
they
parted
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mr
Pecksniff
walked
downstairs
to
the
door
,
he
found
Mrs
Lupin
standing
there
,
looking
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
my
good
friend
!
"
he
said
;
"
not
a
-
bed
yet
!
 
<EOS>
Contemplating
the
stars
,
Mrs
Lupin
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
beautiful
starlight
night
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
beautiful
starlight
night
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
looking
up
.
<EOS>
"
Behold
the
planets
,
how
they
shine
!
 
<EOS>
Behold
the
---
<EOS>
those
two
persons
who
were
here
this
morning
have
left
your
house
,
I
hope
,
Mrs
Lupin
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
gone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Behold
the
wonders
of
the
firmament
,
Mrs
Lupin
!
<EOS>
how
glorious
is
the
scene
!
 
<EOS>
When
I
look
up
at
those
shining
orbs
,
I
think
that
each
of
them
is
winking
to
the
other
to
take
notice
of
the
vanity
of
men
's
pursuits
.
 
<EOS>
My
fellowmen
!
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
,
shaking
his
head
in
pity
;
"
you
are
much
mistaken
;
my
wormy
relatives
,
you
are
much
deceived
!
 
<EOS>
The
stars
are
perfectly
contented
(
I
suppose
so
)
in
their
several
spheres
.
<EOS>
Why
are
not
you
?
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
do
not
strive
and
struggle
to
enrich
yourselves
,
or
to
get
the
better
of
each
other
,
my
deluded
friends
,
but
look
up
there
,
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Lupin
shook
her
head
,
and
heaved
a
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
very
affecting
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
up
there
,
with
me
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Mr
Pecksniff
,
stretching
out
his
hand
;
"
With
me
,
a
humble
individual
who
is
also
an
insect
like
yourselves
.
 
<EOS>
Can
silver
,
gold
,
or
precious
stones
,
sparkle
like
those
constellations
!
 
<EOS>
I
think
not
.
 
<EOS>
Then
do
not
thirst
for
silver
,
gold
,
or
precious
stones
;
but
look
up
there
,
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
those
words
,
the
good
man
patted
Mrs
Lupin
's
hand
between
his
own
,
as
if
he
would
have
added
"
think
of
this
,
my
good
woman
!
"
and
walked
away
in
a
sort
of
ecstasy
or
rapture
,
with
his
hat
under
his
arm
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
sat
in
the
attitude
in
which
Mr
Pecksniff
had
left
him
,
gazing
moodily
at
his
friend
;
who
,
surrounded
by
a
heap
of
documents
,
was
writing
something
on
an
oblong
slip
of
paper
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
mean
to
wait
at
Salisbury
over
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
,
do
you
,
then
?
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
heard
our
appointment
,
"
returned
Montague
,
without
raising
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
In
any
case
I
should
have
waited
to
see
after
the
boy
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
appeared
to
have
changed
places
again
;
Montague
being
in
high
spirits
;
Jonas
gloomy
and
lowering
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
want
me
,
I
suppose
?
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
you
to
put
your
name
here
,
"
he
returned
,
glancing
at
him
with
a
smile
,
"
as
soon
as
I
have
filled
up
the
stamp
.
 
<EOS>
I
may
as
well
have
your
note
of
hand
for
that
extra
capital
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
I
want
.
<EOS>
If
you
wish
to
go
home
,
I
can
manage
Mr
Pecksniff
now
,
alone
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
a
perfect
understanding
between
us
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
sat
scowling
at
him
as
he
wrote
,
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
finished
his
writing
,
and
had
dried
it
on
the
blotting
paper
in
his
travelling
-
desk
;
he
looked
up
,
and
tossed
the
pen
towards
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
,
not
a
day
's
grace
,
not
a
day
's
trust
,
eh
?
"
said
Jonas
bitterly
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
after
the
pains
I
have
taken
with
to
-
night
's
work
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
night
's
work
was
a
part
of
our
bargain
,
"
replied
Montague
;
"
and
so
was
this
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
drive
a
hard
bargain
,
"
said
Jonas
,
advancing
to
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
best
.
 
<EOS>
Give
it
here
!
"
   
<EOS>
Montague
gave
him
the
paper
.
 
<EOS>
After
pausing
as
if
he
could
not
make
up
his
mind
to
put
his
name
to
it
,
Jonas
dipped
his
pen
hastily
in
the
nearest
inkstand
,
and
began
to
write
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
scarcely
marked
the
paper
when
he
started
back
,
in
a
panic
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
the
devil
's
this
?
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
bloody
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
dipped
the
pen
,
as
another
moment
showed
,
into
red
ink
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
attached
a
strange
degree
of
importance
to
the
mistake
.
 
<EOS>
He
asked
how
it
had
come
there
,
who
had
brought
it
,
why
it
had
been
brought
;
and
looked
at
Montague
,
at
first
,
as
if
he
thought
he
had
put
a
trick
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
he
used
a
different
pen
,
and
the
right
ink
,
he
made
some
scratches
on
another
paper
first
,
as
half
believing
they
would
turn
red
also
.
   
<EOS>
"
Black
enough
,
this
time
,
"
he
said
,
handing
the
note
to
Montague
.
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Going
now
!
<EOS>
how
do
you
mean
to
get
away
from
here
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
cross
early
in
the
morning
to
the
high
road
,
before
you
are
out
of
bed
;
and
catch
the
day
-
coach
,
going
up
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
a
hurry
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
something
to
do
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
friend
looked
after
him
as
he
went
out
,
in
surprise
,
which
gradually
gave
place
to
an
air
of
satisfaction
and
relief
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
happens
all
the
better
.
 
<EOS>
It
brings
about
what
I
wanted
,
without
any
difficulty
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
travel
home
alone
.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
45
.
<EOS>
IN
WHICH
TOM
PINCH
AND
HIS
SISTER
TAKE
A
LITTLE
PLEASURE
;
BUT
QUITE
IN
A
DOMESTIC
WAY
,
<EOS>
AND
WITH
NO
CEREMONY
ABOUT
IT
 
<EOS>
Tom
Pinch
and
his
sister
having
to
part
,
for
the
dispatch
of
the
morning
's
business
,
immediately
after
the
dispersion
of
the
other
actors
in
the
scene
upon
the
wharf
with
which
the
reader
has
been
already
made
acquainted
,
had
no
opportunity
of
discussing
the
subject
at
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
But
Tom
,
in
his
solitary
office
,
and
Ruth
,
in
the
triangular
parlour
,
thought
about
nothing
else
all
day
;
and
,
when
their
hour
of
meeting
in
the
afternoon
approached
,
they
were
very
full
of
it
,
to
be
sure
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
plot
between
them
,
that
Tom
should
always
come
out
of
the
Temple
by
one
way
;
and
that
was
past
the
fountain
.
<EOS>
Coming
through
Fountain
Court
,
he
was
just
to
glance
down
the
steps
leading
into
Garden
Court
,
and
to
look
once
all
round
him
;
and
if
Ruth
had
come
to
meet
him
,
there
he
would
see
her
;
not
sauntering
,
you
understand
(
on
account
of
the
clerks
)
,
but
coming
briskly
up
,
with
the
best
little
laugh
upon
her
face
that
ever
played
in
opposition
to
the
fountain
,
and
beat
it
all
to
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
For
,
fifty
to
one
,
Tom
had
been
looking
for
her
in
the
wrong
direction
,
and
had
quite
given
her
up
,
while
she
had
been
tripping
towards
him
from
the
first
;
jingling
that
little
reticule
of
hers
(
with
all
the
keys
in
it
)
to
attract
his
wandering
observation
.
   
<EOS>
Whether
there
was
life
enough
left
in
the
slow
vegetation
of
Fountain
Court
for
the
smoky
shrubs
to
have
any
consciousness
of
the
brightest
and
purest
-
hearted
little
woman
in
the
world
,
is
a
question
for
gardeners
,
and
those
who
are
learned
in
the
loves
of
plants
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
that
it
was
a
good
thing
for
that
same
paved
yard
to
have
such
a
delicate
little
figure
flitting
through
it
;
that
it
passed
like
a
smile
from
the
grimy
old
houses
,
and
the
worn
flagstones
,
and
left
them
duller
,
darker
,
sterner
than
before
;
there
is
no
sort
of
doubt
.
 
<EOS>
The
Temple
fountain
might
have
leaped
up
twenty
feet
to
greet
the
spring
of
hopeful
maidenhood
,
that
in
her
person
stole
on
,
sparkling
,
through
the
dry
and
dusty
channels
of
the
Law
;
the
chirping
sparrows
,
bred
in
Temple
chinks
and
crannies
,
might
have
held
their
peace
to
listen
to
imaginary
skylarks
,
as
so
fresh
a
little
creature
passed
;
<EOS>
the
dingy
boughs
,
unused
to
droop
,
otherwise
than
in
their
puny
growth
,
might
have
bent
down
in
a
kindred
gracefulness
to
shed
their
benedictions
on
her
graceful
head
;
old
love
letters
,
shut
up
in
iron
boxes
in
the
neighbouring
offices
,
and
made
of
no
account
among
the
heaps
of
family
papers
into
which
they
had
strayed
,
and
of
which
,
in
their
degeneracy
,
they
formed
a
part
,
might
have
stirred
and
fluttered
with
a
moment
's
recollection
of
their
ancient
tenderness
,
as
she
went
lightly
by
.
<EOS>
Anything
might
have
happened
that
did
not
happen
,
and
never
will
,
for
the
love
of
Ruth
.
   
<EOS>
Something
happened
,
too
,
upon
the
afternoon
of
which
the
history
treats
.
 
<EOS>
Not
for
her
love
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
<EOS>
quite
by
accident
,
and
without
the
least
reference
to
her
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
Either
she
was
a
little
too
soon
,
or
Tom
was
a
little
too
late
---
she
was
so
precise
in
general
,
that
she
timed
it
to
half
a
minute
---
but
no
Tom
was
there
.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
But
was
anybody
else
there
,
that
she
blushed
so
deeply
,
after
looking
round
,
and
tripped
off
down
the
steps
with
such
unusual

?
   
<EOS>
Why
,
the
fact
is
,
that
Mr
Westlock
was
passing
at
that
moment
.
 
<EOS>
The
Temple
is
a
public
thoroughfare
;
they
may
write
up
on
the
gates
that
it
is
not
,
but
so
long

the
gates
are
left
open
it
is
,
and
will
be
;
and
Mr
Westlock
had
as
good
a
right
to
be
there
as
anybody
else
.
<EOS>
But
why
did
she
run
away
,
then
?
 
<EOS>
Not
being
ill
dressed
,
for
she
was
much
too
neat
for
that
,
why
did
she
run
away
?
 
<EOS>
The
brown
hair
that
had
fallen
down
beneath
her
bonnet
,
and
had
one
impertinent
imp
of
a
false
flower
clinging
to
it
,
boastful
of
its
licence
before
all
men
<EOS>
,
THAT
could
not
have
been
the
cause
,
for
it
looked
charming
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
!
foolish
,
panting
<EOS>
,
frightened
little
heart
,
why
did
she
run
away
!
   
<EOS>
Merrily
the
tiny
fountain
played
,
and
merrily
the
dimples
sparkled
on
its
sunny
face
.
 
<EOS>
John
Westlock
hurried
after
her
.
 
<EOS>
Softly
the
whispering
water
broke
and
fell
;
as
roguishly
the
dimples
twinkled
,
as
he
stole
upon
her
footsteps
.
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
foolish
,
panting
<EOS>
,
timid
little
heart
,
why
did
she
feign
to
be
unconscious
of
his
coming
!
 
<EOS>
Why
wish
herself
so
far
away
,
yet
be
so
flutteringly
happy
there
!
   
<EOS>
"
I
felt
sure
it
was
you
,
"
said
John
,
when
he
overtook
her
in
the
sanctuary
of
Garden
Court
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
knew
I
could
n't
be
mistaken
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
SO
surprised
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
waiting
for
your
brother
,
"
said
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
me
bear
you
company
.
"
   
<EOS>
So
light
was
the
touch
of
the
coy
little
hand
,
that
he
glanced
down
to
assure
himself
he
had
it
on
his
arm
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
glance
,
stopping
for
an
instant
at
the
bright
eyes
,
forgot
its
first
design
,
and
went
no
farther
.
   
<EOS>
They
walked
up
and
down
three
or
four
times
,
speaking
about
Tom
and
his
mysterious
employment
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
was
a
very
natural
and
innocent
subject
,
surely
.
 
<EOS>
Then
why
,
whenever
Ruth
lifted
up
her
eyes
,
did
she
let
them
fall
again
immediately
,
and
seek
the
uncongenial
pavement
of
the
court
?
 
<EOS>
They
were
not
such
eyes
as
shun
the
light
;
they
were
not
such
eyes
as
require
to
be
hoarded
to
enhance
their
value
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
much
too
precious
and
too
genuine
to
stand
in
need
of
arts
like
those
.
 
<EOS>
Somebody
must
have
been
looking
at
them
!
   
<EOS>
They
found
out
Tom
,
though
,
quickly
enough
.
 
<EOS>
This
pair
of
eyes
descried
him
in
the
distance
,
the
moment
he
appeared
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
staring
about
him
,
as
usual
,
in
all
directions
but
the
right
one
;
and
was
as
obstinate
in
not
looking
towards
them
,
as
if
he
had
intended

.
 
<EOS>
As
it
was
plain
that
,
being
left
to
himself
,
he
would
walk
away

,
John
Westlock
darted
off
to
stop
him
.
   
<EOS>
This
made
the
approach
of
poor
little
Ruth
,
by
herself
,
one
of
the
most
embarrassing
of

.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Tom
,
manifesting
extreme
surprise
(
he
had
no
presence

mind
,
that
Tom
,
on
small

)
;
there
was
John
,
making
as
light
of
it
as
he
could
,
but
explaining
at

same

with
most
unnecessary

;
and
here
was
she
,
coming
towards

,
with
both

them
looking
at

,
conscious
of

to
a

,
but
trying
to
throw

,
and
pout
her
rosy

,
as
if
she
were
the
coolest

.
   
<EOS>
Merrily
the
fountain
plashed
and
plashed
,
until

,
merging
into
one

,
swelled
into
a
general
smile
,
that
covered
the
whole
surface
of
the
basin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
an
extraordinary
meeting
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
never
have
dreamed
of
seeing
you
two
together
here
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Quite
accidental
,
"
John
was
heard
to
murmur
.
   
<EOS>
"
Exactly
,
"
cried
Tom
;
"
that
's
what
I
mean
,
you

.
 
<EOS>
If
it
was
n't
accidental
,
there
would
be
nothing
remarkable

it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
"
said
John
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Such
an
out
-
of
-
the
-

place
for
you
to
have
met
in
,
"
pursued
Tom
,
quite

.
 
<EOS>
"
Such
an
unlikely
spot
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
rather
disputed
that
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
he
considered
it
a
very
likely
spot
,

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
constantly
passing
to
and
fro
there
,
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
should
n't
wonder
if
it
were
to
happen
again
.
 
<EOS>
His
only
wonder
was
,
that
it
had
never
happened
before
.
   
<EOS>
By
this

Ruth
had
got
round
on
the
farther

of
her
brother
,
and
had
taken

.
 
<EOS>
She
was

now
,
as
much

to

"
Are
you
going
to

here
all

,
you

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom

as

.
 
<EOS>
"
John
,
"
he

,
"

'll

,

between

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

to

.
 
<EOS>
Our

could
not

better
.
"
   
<EOS>
Merrily

leaped
and

,
and
merrily

smiling
dimples
twinkled
and

more
and

,
until
they
broke
into
a
laugh
against
the
basin
's

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
,
"
said
his
friend
,
as

into

noisy

,
"
I
have
a
proposition
to

.
 
<EOS>
It

,
that
you
and

---
if

honour
a

's

---

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
,

-

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

-

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pray

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
you

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

the

,
in

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
He

.
 
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
what

?
<EOS>
Shall

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
If

,
Tom
,
"
rejoined

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

,
"
said

,
regarding

;
"
is

?
 
<EOS>
I

do
n't

,
John
;
she
may

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a

at
this
,
and
there
were
divers

from
John
Westlock
---
<EOS>
not
compliments
HE
said
at
least
<EOS>
(
and

was
right
)
,
but
good
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ruth
laughed
,
and
all
that
,
but
she
made
no

;
so
it
was
an
engagement
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
I

known
it
a

,
"
said
John
,
"
I
would
have
tried
another

.
 
<EOS>
Not
in

;
but
merely

.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
on
any

have
had
it
made
with

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Because
that
cookery
-
book
advises

,
"
said
John
Westlock
;
"
and
ours
was
made
with
flour
and
eggs
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
good
gracious
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Ours
was
made
with
flour
and
eggs
,
was
it
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
A
beefsteak
pudding
made
with
flour
and
eggs
!
<EOS>
Why
anybody
knows
better
than
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
better
than
that
!
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
!
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
unnecessary
to
say
that
Tom
had
been
present
at
the
making
of
the
pudding
,
and
had
been
a
devoted
believer
in
it
all
through
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
so
delighted
to
have
this
joke
against
his
busy
little
sister
and
was
tickled
to
that
degree
at
having
found
her
out
,
that
he
stopped
in
Temple
Bar
to
laugh
;
and
it
was
no
more
to
Tom
,
that
he
was
anathematized
and
knocked
about
by
the
surly

,
than
it
would
have
been
to
a
post
;
for
he
continued
to
exclaim
with
unabated
good

,
"
flour
and
eggs
!
 
<EOS>
A
beefsteak
pudding
made
with
flour
and
eggs
!
"
<EOS>
until
John
Westlock
and
his
sister
fairly
ran
away
from
him
,
and
left
him
to
have
his
laugh
out
by
himself
;
which
he
had
,
and
then
came
dodging
across
the
crowded
street
to
them
,
with
such
sweet
temper
and
tenderness
(
it
was
quite
a
tender
joke
of
Tom
's
)
beaming
in
his
face
,
God
bless
it
,
that
it
might
have
purified
the
air
,
though
Temple
Bar
had
been
,
as
in
the
golden
days
gone
by
,
embellished
with
a
row
of
rotting
human
heads
.
   
<EOS>
There
are
snug
chambers
in
those
Inns
where
the
bachelors
live
,
and
,
for
the
desolate
fellows
they
pretend
to
be
,
it
is
quite
surprising
how
well
they
get
on
.
 
<EOS>
John
was
very
pathetic
on
the
subject
of
his
dreary
life
,
and
the
deplorable
makeshifts
and
apologetic
contrivances
it
involved
,
but
he
really
seemed
to
make
himself
pretty
comfortable
.
 
<EOS>
His
rooms
were
the
perfection
of
neatness
and
convenience
at
any
rate
;
and
if
he
were
anything
but
comfortable
,
the
fault
was
certainly
not
theirs
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
no
sooner
ushered
Tom
and
his
sister
into
his
best
room
<EOS>
(
where
there
was
a
beautiful
little
vase
of
fresh
flowers
on
the
table
,
all
ready
for
Ruth
.
 
<EOS>
Just
as
if
he
had
expected
her
,
Tom
said
)
,
than
,
seizing
his
hat
,
he
bustled
out
again
,
in
his
most
energetically
bustling
,
way
;
and
presently
came
hurrying
back
,
as
they
saw
through
the
half
-
opened
door
,
attended
by
a
fiery
-
faced
matron
attired
in
a
crunched
bonnet
,
with
particularly
long
strings
to
it
hanging
down
her
back
;
in
conjunction
with
whom
he
instantly
began
to
lay
the
cloth
for
dinner
,
polishing
up
the
wine
-
glasses
with
his
own
hands
,
brightening
the
silver
top
of
the
pepper
-
caster
on
his
coat
-
sleeve
,
drawing
corks
and
filling
decanters
,
with
a
skill
and
expedition
that
were
quite
dazzling
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
if
,
in
the
course
of
this
rubbing
and
polishing
,
he
had
rubbed
an
enchanted
lamp
or
a
magic
ring
,
obedient
to
which
there
were
twenty
thousand
supernatural
slaves
at
least
,
suddenly
there
appeared
a
being
in
a
white
waistcoat
,
carrying
under
his
arm
a
napkin
,
and
attended
by
another
being
with
an
oblong
box
upon
his
head
,
from
which
a
banquet
,
piping
hot
,
was
taken
out
and
set
upon
the
table
.
   
<EOS>
Salmon
,
lamb
,
peas
,
innocent
young
potatoes
,
a
cool
salad
,
sliced
cucumber
,
a
tender
duckling
,
and
a
tart
---
all
there
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
came
at
the
right
time
.
 
<EOS>
Where
they
came
from
,
did
n't
appear
;
but
the
oblong
box
was
constantly
going
and
coming
,
and
making
its
arrival
known
to
the
man
in
the
white
waistcoat
by
bumping
modestly
against
the
outside
of
the
door
;
for
,
after
its
first
appearance
,
it
entered
the
room
no
more
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
never
surprised
,
this
man
;
he
never
seemed
to
wonder
at
the
extraordinary
things
he
found
in
the
box
,
but
took
them
out
with
a
face
expressive
of
a
steady
purpose
and
impenetrable
character
,
and
put
them
on
the
table
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
kind
man
;
gentle
in
his
manners
,
and
much
interested
in
what
they
ate
and
drank
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
learned
man
,
and
knew
the
flavour
of
John
Westlock
's
private
sauces
,
which
he
softly
and
feelingly
described
,
as
he
handed
the
little
bottles
round
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
a
grave
man
,
and
a
noiseless
;
for
dinner
being
done
,
and
wine
and
fruit
arranged
upon
the
board
,
he
vanished
,
box
and
all
,
like
something
that
had
never
been
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
I
say
he
was
a
tremendous
fellow
in
his
housekeeping
?
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bless
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
wonderful
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Miss
Pinch
,
"
said
John
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
bright
side
of
the
life
we
lead
in
such
a
place
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
dismal
life
,
indeed
,
if
it
did
n't
brighten
up
to
-
day
<EOS>
"
   
"
Do
n't
believe
a
word
he
says
,
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
lives
here
like
a
monarch
,
and
would
n't
change
his
mode
of
life
for
any
consideration
.
<EOS>
He
only
pretends
to
grumble
.
"
   
<EOS>
No
,
John
really
did
not
appear
to
pretend
;
for
he
was
uncommonly
earnest
in
his
desire
to
have
it
understood
that
he
was
as
dull
,
solitary
,
and
uncomfortable
on
ordinary
occasions
as
an
unfortunate
young
man
could
,
in
reason
,
be
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
wretched
life
,
he
said
,
a
miserable
life
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
of
getting
rid
of
the
chambers
as
soon
as
possible
;
and
meant
,
in
fact
,
to
put
a
bill
up
very
shortly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
"
said
Tom
Pinch
,
"
I
do
n't
know
where
you
can
go
,
John
,
to
be
more
comfortable
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
I
can
say
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
YOU
say
,
Ruth
?
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
trifled
with
the
cherries
on
her
plate
,
and
said
that
she
thought
Mr
Westlock
ought
to
be
quite
happy
,
and
that
she
had
no
doubt
he
was
.
   
<EOS>
Ah
,
foolish
,
panting
,
frightened
little
heart
,
how
timidly
she
said
it
!
   
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
forgetting
what
you
had
to
tell
,
Tom
;
what
occurred
this
morning
,
"
she
added
in
the
same
breath
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
I
am
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
so
talkative
on
other
topics
that
I
declare
I
have
not
had
time
to
think
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
it
you
at
once
,
John
,
in
case
I
should
forget
it
altogether
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
Tom
's
relating
what
had
passed
upon
the
wharf
,
his
friend
was
very
much
surprised
,
and
took
such
a
great
interest
in
the
narrative
as
Tom
could
not
quite
understand
.
 
<EOS>
He
believed
he
knew
the
old
lady
whose
acquaintance
they
had
made
,
he
said
;
and
that
he
might
venture
to
say
,
from
their
description
of
her
,
that
her
name
was
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
But
of
what
nature
the
communication
could
have
been
which
Tom
had
borne
so
unexpectedly
<EOS>
;
why
its
delivery
had
been
entrusted
to
him
;
how
it
happened
that
the
parties
were
involved
together
;
and
what
secret
lay
at
the
bottom
of
the
whole
affair
;
perplexed
him
very
much
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
had
been
sure
of
his
taking
some
interest
in
the
matter
;
but
was
not
prepared
for
the
strong
interest
he
showed
.
 
<EOS>
It
held
John
Westlock
to
the
subject
even
after
Ruth
had
left
the
room
;
and
evidently
made
him
anxious
to
pursue
it
further
than
as
a
mere
subject
of
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
shall
remonstrate
with
my
landlord
,
of
course
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
though
he
is
a
very
singular
secret
sort
of
man
,
and
not
likely
to
afford
me
much
satisfaction
;
even
if
he
knew
what
was
in

letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which
you
may
swear
he
did
,
"
John
interposed
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
so
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
certain
of
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
shall
remonstrate
with
him
when
I
see
him
(
he
goes
in
and
out
in
a
strange
way
,
but
I
will
try
to
catch
him
tomorrow
morning
)
,
on
his

asked

to
execute

.
 
<EOS>
And
I
have
been
thinking
,
John
,
that
if
I
went
down
to
Mrs
What's
-
her
-
name
's
in
the
City
,
where
I
was
before
,
you
know
---
Mrs
Todgers
's
---
to
-
morrow

,
I
might
find
poor
Mercy
Pecksniff
there
,
perhaps
,
and
be
able
to
explain
to
her
how
I
came
to
have
any

in
the
business
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
perfectly
right
,
Tom
,
"
returned
his
friend
,
after
a
short
interval
of
reflection
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
do
better
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
quite
clear
to
me
that
whatever
the
business
is
,
there
is
little
good
in
it
;
and
it
is
so
desirable
for
you
to
disentangle

from
any
appearance

connection
with
it
,
that
I
would
counsel
you
to
see
her
husband
,
if
you
can
,
and
wash
your
hands
of
it
by
a
plain

of
the

.
 
<EOS>
I
have
a
misgiving
that
there
is
something
dark
at
work
here
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
tell
you
why
,
at
another
time
;
when
I
have
made
an
inquiry
or
two
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
All
this
sounded
very
mysterious
to
Tom
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
But
as
he
knew
he
could
rely
upon
his
friend
,
he
resolved
to
follow
this
advice
.
   
<EOS>
Ah
,
but
it
would
have
been
a
good
thing
to
have
had
a
coat
of
invisibility
,
wherein
to
have
watched
little
Ruth
,
when
she
was
left
to
herself
in
John
Westlock
's
chambers
,
and
John
and
her
brother
were
talking
thus
,
over
their
wine
!
 
<EOS>
The
gentle
way
in
which
she
tried
to
get
up
a
little
conversation
with
the
fiery
-
faced
matron
in
the
crunched
bonnet
,
who
was
waiting
to
attend
her
;
after
making
a
desperate
rally
in
regard
of
her
dress
,
and
attiring
herself
in
a
washed
-
out
yellow
gown
with
sprigs
of
the
same
upon
it
,
so
that
it
looked
like
a
tesselated
work
of
pats
of
butter
.
 
<EOS>
That
would
have
been
pleasant
.
 
<EOS>
The
grim
and
griffin
-
like
inflexibility
with
which
the
fiery
-
faced
matron
repelled
these
engaging
advances
,
as
proceeding
from
a
hostile
and
dangerous
power
,
who
could
have
no
business
there
,
unless
it
were
to
deprive
her
of
a
customer
,
or
suggest
what
became
of
the
self
-
consuming
tea
and
sugar
,
and
other
general
trifles
.
 
<EOS>
That
would
have
been
agreeable
.
 
<EOS>
The
bashful
,
winning
,
glorious
curiosity
,
with
which
little
Ruth
,
when
fiery
-
face
was
gone
,
peeped
into
the
books
and
nick
-
nacks
that
were
lying
about
,
and
had
a
particular
interest
in
some
delicate
paper
-
matches
on
the
chimney
-
piece
;
wondering
who
could
have
made
them
.
 
<EOS>
That
would
have
been
worth
seeing
.
 
<EOS>
The
faltering
hand
with
which
she
tied
those
flowers
together
;
with
which
,
almost
blushing
at
her
own
fair
self
as
imaged
in
the
glass
,
she
arranged
them
in
her
breast
,
and
looking
at
them
with
her
head
aside
,
now
half
resolved
to
take
them
out
again
,
now
half
resolved
to
leave
them
where
they
were
.
<EOS>
That
would
have
been
delightful
!
   
<EOS>
John
seemed
to
think
it
all
delightful
;
for
coming
in
with
Tom
to
tea
,
he
took
his
seat
beside
her
like
a
man
enchanted
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
the
tea
-
service
had
been
removed
,
and
Tom
,
sitting
down
at
the
piano
,
became
absorbed
in
some
of
his
old
organ
tunes
,
he
was
still
beside
her
at
the
open
window
,
looking
out
upon
the
twilight
.
   
<EOS>
There
is
little
enough
to
see
in
Furnival
's
Inn
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
shady
,
quiet
place
,
echoing
to
the
footsteps
of
the
stragglers
who
have
business
there
;
and
rather
monotonous
and
gloomy
on
summer
evenings
.
 
<EOS>
What
gave
it
such
a
charm
to
them
,
that
they
remained
at
the
window
as
unconscious
of
the
flight
of
time
as
Tom
himself
,
the
dreamer
,
while
the
melodies
which
had
so
often
soothed
his
spirit
were
hovering
again
about
him
!
 
<EOS>
What
power
infused
into
the
fading
light
,
the
gathering
darkness
;
the
stars
that
here
and
there
appeared
;
the
evening
air
,
the
City
's
hum
and
stir
,
the
very
chiming
of
the
old
church
clocks
;
such
exquisite
enthrallment
,
that
the
divinest
regions
of
the
earth
spread
out
before
their
eyes
could
not
have
held
them
captive
in
a
stronger
chain
?
   
<EOS>
The
shadows
deepened
,
deepened
,
and
the
room
became
quite
dark
.
<EOS>
Still
Tom
's
fingers
wandered
over
the
keys
of
the
piano
,
and
still
the
window
had
its
pair
of
tenants
.
 
<EOS>
At
length
,
her
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
her
breath
upon
his
forehead
,
roused
Tom
from
his
reverie
.
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
desisting
with
a
start
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
I
have
been
very
inconsiderate
and
unpolite
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
little
thought
how
much
consideration
and
politeness
he
had
shown
!
   
<EOS>
"
Sing
something
to
us
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
let
us
hear
your
voice
.
<EOS>
Come
!
"
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
added
his
entreaties
with
such
earnestness
that
a
flinty
heart
alone
could
have
resisted
them
.
 
<EOS>
Hers
was
not
a
flinty
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
dear
no
!
 
<EOS>
Quite
another
thing
.
   
<EOS>
So
down
she
sat
,
and
in
a
pleasant
voice
began
to
sing
the
ballads
Tom
loved
well
.
 
<EOS>
Old
rhyming
stories
,
with
here
and
there
a
pause
for
a
few
simple
chords
,
such
as
a
harper
might
have
sounded
in
the
ancient
time
while
looking
upward
for
the
current
of
some
half
-
remembered
legend
;
words
of
old
poets
,
wedded
to
such
measures
that
the
strain
of
music
might
have
been
the
poet
's
breath
,
giving
utterance
and
expression
to
his
thoughts
;
and
now
a
melody
so
joyous
and
light
-
hearted
,
that
the
singer
seemed
incapable
of
sadness
,
until
in
her
inconstancy
(
oh
wicked
little
singer
!
)
<EOS>
she
relapsed
,
and
broke
the
listeners
'
hearts
again
;
these
were
the
simple
means
she
used
to
please
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
that
these
simple
means
prevailed
,
and
she
DID
please
them
,
let
the
still
darkened
chamber
,
and
its
long
-
deferred
illumination
witness
.
   
<EOS>
The
candles
came
at
last
,
and
it
was
time
for
moving
homeward
.
<EOS>
Cutting
paper
carefully
,
and
rolling
it
about
the
stalks
of
those
same
flowers
,
occasioned
some
delay
;
but
even
this
was
done
in
time
,
and
Ruth
was
ready
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
memorable
and
delightful
visit
,
John
!
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
John
thought
he
would
walk
with
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
nonsense
!
 
<EOS>
We
can
get
home
very
well
alone
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
think
of
taking
you
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
But
John
said
he
would
rather
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
you
would
rather
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
you
only
say
so
out
of
politeness
.
"
   
<EOS>
John
being
quite
sure
,
gave
his
arm
to
Ruth
,
and
led
her
out
.
<EOS>
Fiery
-
face
,
who
was
again
in
attendance
,
acknowledged
her
departure
with
so
cold
a
curtsey
that
it
was
hardly
visible
;
and
cut
Tom
,
dead
.
   
<EOS>
Their
host
was
bent
on
walking
the
whole
distance
,
and
would
not
listen
to
Tom
's
dissuasions
.
 
<EOS>
Happy
time
,
happy
walk
,
happy
parting
,
happy
dreams
!
 
<EOS>
But
there
are
some
sweet
day
-
dreams
,
so
<EOS>
there
are
that
put
the
visions
of
the
night
to
shame
.
   
<EOS>
Busily
the
Temple
fountain
murmured
in
the
moonlight
,
while
Ruth
lay
sleeping
,
with
her
flowers
beside
her
;
and
John
Westlock
sketched
a
portrait
---
whose
?
---
from
memory
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
46
.
<EOS>
In
which
Miss
Pecksniff
makes
love
,
Mr
Jonas
makes
wrath
,
Mrs
Gamp
makes
tea
,
and
Mr
Chuffey
makes
business
 
<EOS>
On
the
next
day
's
official
duties
coming
to
a
close
,
Tom
hurried
home
without
losing
any
time
by
the
way
;
and
after
dinner
and
a
short
rest
sallied
out
again
,
accompanied
by
Ruth
,
to
pay
his
projected
visit
to
Todgers
's
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
took
Ruth
with
him
,
not
only
because
it
was
a
great
pleasure
to
him
to
have
her
for
his
companion
whenever
he
could
,
but
because
he
wished
her
to
cherish
and
comfort
poor
Merry
;
which
she
,
for
her
own
part
(
having
heard
the
wretched
history
of
that
young
wife
from
Tom
)
,
was
all
eagerness
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
was
so
glad
to
see
me
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
that
I
am
sure
she
will
be
glad
to
see
you
.
 
<EOS>
Your
sympathy
is
certain
to
be
much
more
delicate
and
acceptable
than
mine
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
far
from
being
certain
of
that
,
Tom
,
"
she
replied
;
"
and
indeed
you
do
yourself
an
injustice
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
you
do
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
hope
she
may
like
me
,
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
she
is
sure
to
do
that
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Tom
,
confidently
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
a
number
of
friends
I
should
have
,
if
everybody
was
of
your
way
of
thinking
.
 
<EOS>
Should
n't
I
,
Tom
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
said
his
little
sister
pinching
him
upon
the
cheek
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
laughed
,
and
said
that
with
reference
to
this
particular
case
he
had
no
doubt
at
all
of
finding
a
disciple
in
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
you
women
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
<EOS>
you
women
,
my
dear
,
are
so
kind
,
and
in
your
kindness
have
such
nice
perception
;
you
know
<EOS>
so
well
how
to
be
affectionate
and
full
of
solicitude
without
appearing
to
be
<EOS>
;
your
gentleness
of
feeling
is
like
your
touch
so
light
and
easy
,
that
the
one
enables
you
to
deal
with
wounds
of
the
mind
as

as
the
other
enables
you
to
deal
with
wounds
of
the
body
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
such
---
"
   
"
My
goodness
,
Tom
!
"
<EOS>
his
sister
interposed
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
ought
to
fall
in
love
immediately
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
put
this
observation
off
good
humouredly
,
but
somewhat
gravely
too
;
and
they
were
soon
very
chatty
again
on
some
other
subject
.
   
<EOS>
As
they
were
passing
through
a
street
in
the
City
,
not
very
far
from
Mrs
Todgers
's
place
of
residence
,
Ruth
checked
Tom
before
the
window
of
a
large
Upholstery
and
Furniture
Warehouse
,
to
call
his
attention
to
something
very
magnificent
and
ingenious
,
displayed
there
to
the
best
advantage
,
for
the
admiration
and
temptation
of
the
public
.
<EOS>
Tom
had
hazarded
some
most
erroneous
and
extravagantly
wrong
guess
in
relation
to
the
price
of
this
article
,
and
had
joined
his
sister
in
laughing
heartily
at
his
mistake
,
when
he
pressed
her
arm
in
his
,
and
pointed
to
two
persons
at
a
little
distance
,
who
were
looking
in
at
the
same
window
with
a
deep
interest
in
the
chests
of
drawers
and
tables
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
Tom
whispered
.
 
<EOS>
"
Miss
Pecksniff
,
and
the
young
gentleman
to
whom
she
is
going
to
be
married
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
does
he
look
as
if
he
was
going
to
be
buried
,
Tom
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
his
little
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
is
naturally
a
dismal
young
gentleman
,
I
believe
,
"
said
Tom
"
but
he
is
very
civil
and
inoffensive
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
they
are
furnishing
their
house
,
"
whispered
Ruth
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
suppose
they
are
,
"
replied
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
avoid
speaking
to
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
could
not
very
well
avoid
looking
at
them
,
however
,
especially
as
some
obstruction
on
the
pavement
,
at
a
little
distance
,
happened
to
detain
them
where
they
were
for
a
few

.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
had
quite
the
air
of
having
taken
the
unhappy
Moddle
captive
,
and
brought
him
up
to
the
contemplation
of
the
furniture
like
a
lamb
to
the
altar
.
 
<EOS>
He
offered
no
resistance
,
but
was
perfectly
resigned
and
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
The
melancholy
depicted
in
the
turn
of
his
languishing
head
,
and
in
his
dejected
attitude
,
was
extreme
;
and
though
there
was
a
full
-
sized
four
-
post
bedstead
in
the
window
,
such
a
tear
stood
trembling
in
his
eye
as
seemed
to
blot
it
out
.
   
<EOS>
"
Augustus
,
my
love
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
ask
the
price
of
the
eight
rosewood
chairs
,
and
the
loo
table
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
they
are
ordered
already
,
"
said
Augustus
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
they
are
Another
's
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
They
can
make
more
like
them
,
if
they
are
,
"
rejoined
Miss
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
they
ca
n't
,
"
said
Moddle
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
impossible
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
appeared
,
for
the
moment
,
to
be
quite
overwhelmed
and
stupefied
by
the
prospect
of
his
approaching
happiness
;
but
recovering
,
entered
the
shop
.
 
<EOS>
He
returned
immediately
,
saying
in
a
tone
of
despair
   
<EOS>
"
Twenty
-
four
pound
ten
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
,
turning
to
receive
this
announcement
,
became
conscious
of
the
observation
of
Tom
Pinch
and
his
sister
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
really
!
"
cried
Miss
Pecksniff
,
glancing
about
her
,
as
if
for
some

of
sinking
into
the
earth
.
 
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
I
---
 
there
never
was
such
a
---
to
think
that
one
should
be
so
very
---
<EOS>
Mr
Augustus
Moddle
,
Miss
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
was
quite
gracious
to
Miss
Pinch
in
this

introduction
;
exceedingly
gracious
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
more
than
gracious
;
she
was
kind
and
cordial
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
the
recollection
of
the
old
service
Tom
had
rendered
her
in
knocking
Mr
Jonas
on
the
head
had
wrought
this
change
in
her

;
or
whether
her

from
her
