had
reconciled
her
to
all
human
-
kind
,
or
to
all
that
interesting
portion
of
human
-
kind
which
was
not
friendly
to
him
;
or
whether
the
delight
of
having
some
new
female

to
whom
to
communicate
her
interesting

was
paramount
to
every
other

;
cordial
and
kind
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
was
.
 
<EOS>
And
twice
Miss
Pecksniff
kissed
Miss
Pinch
upon
the
cheek
.
   
<EOS>
"
Augustus
---
Mr
Pinch
,
you
know
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
!
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
aside
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
was
so
ashamed
in
my
life
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
begged
her
not
to
think
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
mind
your
brother
less
than
anybody
else
,
"
simpered
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
the

of

!
 
<EOS>
Augustus
,
my
child
,
did
you
---
"
   
<EOS>
Here
Miss
Pecksniff
whispered
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
The
suffering
Moddle
repeated
:
   
"
Twenty
-
four
pound
ten
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
silly
man
!
 
<EOS>
I
do

mean
them
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
speaking
of
the
---
"
   
Here

.
   
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
the
same

as
that
in

;
thirty
-

,

,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
very

.
"
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
stopped

by

upon

and

.
<EOS>
She

Tom
Pinch
which

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
We
were

Mrs
Todgers
's
,
where
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It

no

,

,
"

,
"

we

;

<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
But

's

,

.
 
<EOS>
Augustus
---
<EOS>
Mr
Moddle
,
I
mean
---
 
and

,

tea

,

.
 
<EOS>
You
need

HIM
,
"
she

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
at
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
?
"
asked
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
am
quite
sure
of

.
 
<EOS>
I
do

any
MORE
revenge
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
,

,
I
must

to

,

Miss
Pinch
.
 
<EOS>
My
dear
,
I
never

!
"
   
<EOS>
In

of
this
bashful

,
Moddle
gave
his

to
Tom
;
and
Miss
Pecksniff
linked
her

in

's
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
,
my
love
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
it

,

,
that
I

about

to
the
gentleman
who
is

.
 
<EOS>
It

be
in

to

.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
him
?
 
<EOS>
Pray
,

your

.
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
intimated
that
,
as
far
as
she
could
judge
,
he
was
a
very
eligible
swain
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
curious
to
know
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
with

,
"
whether
you
have
observed
,
or

,
in
this

,
that
he
is
of
a

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
So
very
short
a

,
"
Ruth

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
<EOS>
;
but
do

let
that
interfere
with
your

,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
curious
to
hear
what
you
say
.
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
acknowledged
that
he
had
impressed
her
at
first
sight
as
looking
"
rather
low
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
really
?
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
that
is
quite
remarkable
!
<EOS>
Everybody
says
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
says
the
same
;
and
Augustus
informs
me
that
it
is
quite
a
joke
among
the
gentlemen
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
but
for
the
positive
commands
I
have
laid
upon
him
,
I
believe
it
would
have
been
the
occasion
of
loaded
fire
-
arms
being
resorted
to
more
than
once
.
 
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
is
the
cause
of
his
appearance
of
depression
?
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
thought
of
several
things
;
such
as
his
digestion
,
his
tailor
,
his
mother
,
and
the
like
.
 
<EOS>
But
hesitating
to
give
utterance
to
any
one
of
them
,
she
refrained
from
expressing
an
opinion
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
;
"
I
should
n't
wish
it
to
be
known
,
but
I
do
n't
mind
mentioning
it
to
you
,
having
known
your
brother
for
so
many
years
<EOS>
---
I
refused
Augustus
three
times
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
of
a
most
amiable
and
sensitive
nature
,
always
ready
to
shed
tears
if
you
look
at
him
,
which
is
extremely
charming
;
and
he
has
never
recovered
the
effect
of
that

.
 
<EOS>
For
it
WAS
cruel
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
with
a
self
-
conviction
candour
that
might
have
adorned
the

of
her
own
papa
.
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
doubt
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
look
back
upon
my
conduct
now
with
blushes
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
liked
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
felt
that
he
was
not
to
me
what
the
crowd
of
young
men
who
had
made
proposals
had
been
,
but
something
very
different
.
 
<EOS>
Then
what
right
had
I
to
refuse
him
three
times
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
severe
trial
of
his
fidelity
,
no
doubt
,
"
said
Ruth
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
wrong
.
 
<EOS>
But
such
is
the
caprice
and
thoughtlessness
of
our
sex
!
 
<EOS>
Let
me
be
a
warning
to
you
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
try
the
feelings
of
any
one
who
makes
you
an
offer
,
as
I
have
tried
the
feelings
of
Augustus
;
but
if
you
ever
feel
towards
a
person
as
I
really
felt
towards
him
,
at
the
very
time
when
I
was
driving
him
to
distraction
,
let
that
feeling
find
expression
,
if
that
person
throws
himself
at
your
feet
,
as
Augustus
Moddle
did
at
mine
.
 
<EOS>
Think
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
what
my
feelings
would
have
been
,
if
I
had
goaded
him
to
suicide
,
and
it
had
got
into
the
papers
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
observed
that
she
would
have
been
full
of
remorse
,
no
doubt
.
   
<EOS>
"
Remorse
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Pecksniff
,
in
a
sort
of
snug
and
comfortable
penitence
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
my
remorse
is
at
this
moment
,
even
after
making
reparation
by
accepting
him
,
it
would
be
impossible
to
tell
you
!
<EOS>
Looking
back
upon
my
giddy
self
,
my
dear
,
now
that
I
am
sobered
down
and
made
thoughtful
,
by
treading
on
the
very
brink
of
matrimony
;
and
contemplating
myself
as
I
was
when
I
was
like
what
you
are
now
;
I
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
I
shudder
.
 
<EOS>
What
is
the
consequence
of
my
past
conduct
?
<EOS>
Until
Augustus
leads
me
to
the
altar
he
is
not
sure
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
blighted
and
withered
the
affections
of
his
heart
to
that
extent
that
he
is
not
sure
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
that
preying
on
his
mind
and
feeding
on
his
vitals
.
 
<EOS>
What
are
the
reproaches
of
my
conscience
,
when
I
see
this
in
the
man
I
love
!
"
   
<EOS>
Ruth
endeavoured
to
express
some
sense
of
her
unbounded
and
flattering
confidence
;
and
presumed
that
she
was
going
to
be
married
soon
.
   
<EOS>
"
Very
soon
indeed
,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
soon
as
our
house
is
ready
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
furnishing
now
as
fast
as
we
can
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
the
same
vein
of
confidence
Miss
Pecksniff
ran
through
a
general
inventory
of
the
articles
that
were
already
bought
with
the
articles
that
remained
to

;
what
garments
she

to
be
married
in
,
and
where
the

was
to
be

;
and
gave
Miss
Pinch
,
in
short
(
as
she
told
her
)
,
early
and
exclusive
information
on
all
points
of
interest
connected
with
the
event
.
   
<EOS>
While
this
was
going
forward
in
the
rear
,
Tom
and
Mr
Moddle
walked
on
,
arm

,
in

front
,
in
a

,
which
Tom
at
last
broke
;
after
thinking
for
a
long

what
he
could
say
that
should

an

,

of
which
he
might
rely

with
some

on
Mr

's

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
Tom
,
"
that
in

the
foot

passengers

not

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr

,

,

"
<EOS>
The
drivers
wo
n't
do

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
Tom
began
---
    
"
That
there

,
"

Moddle
,

,
"
who
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Coal

,

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
There

.
 
<EOS>
One

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"

"

!
"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

on
the
unconscious
Chuffey
,
who
appeared
to
be
as
little
cognizant
of
their
delivery
as
of
his
having
given
Mrs
Gamp
offence
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
high
-
minded
woman
being
sensitively
alive
to
any
invasion
of
her
professional
province
,
and
imagining
that
Mr
Chuffey
had
given
utterance
to
some
prediction
on
the
subject
of
sons
,
which
ought
to
have
emanated
in
the
first
instance
from
herself
as
the
only
lawful
authority
,
or
which
should
at
least
have
been
on
no
account
proclaimed
without
her
sanction
and
concurrence
,
was
not
so
easily
appeased
.
 
<EOS>
She
continued
to
sidle
at
Mr
Chuffey
with
looks
of
sharp
hostility
,
and
to
defy
him
with
many
other
ironical
remarks
,
uttered
in
that
low
key
which
commonly
denotes
suppressed
indignation
;
until
the
entrance
of
the
teaboard
,
and
a
request
from
Mrs
Jonas
that
she
would
make
tea
at
a
side
-
table
for
the
party
that
had
unexpectedly
assembled
,
restored
her
to
herself
.
 
<EOS>
She
smiled
again
,
and
entered
on
her
ministration
with
her
own
particular
urbanity
.
   
<EOS>
"
And
quite
a
family
it
is
to
make
tea
for
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
;
"
and
wot
a
happiness
to
do
it
!
 
<EOS>
My
good
young
'
ooman
"
---
to
the
servant
-
girl
---
 
"
p'raps
somebody
would
like
to
try
a
new
-
laid
egg
or
two
,
not
biled
too
hard
.
 
<EOS>
Likeways
,
a
few
rounds
o
'
buttered
toast
,
first
cuttin
'
off
the
crust
,
in
consequence
of
tender
teeth
,
and
not
too
many
of
'em
;
which
Gamp
himself
,
Mrs
Chuzzlewit
,
at
one
blow
,
being
in
liquor
,
struck
out
four
,
two
single
,
and
two
double
,
as
was
took
by
Mrs
Harris
for
a
keepsake
,
and
is
carried
in
her
pocket
at
this
present
hour
,
along
with
two
cramp
-
bones
,
a
bit
o
'
ginger
,
and
a
grater
like
a
blessed
infant
's
shoe
,
in
tin
,
with
a
little
heel
to
put
the
nutmeg
in
;
as
many
times
I
've
seen
and
said
,
and
used
for
candle
when
required
,
within
the
month
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
the
privileges
of
the
side
-
table
---
besides
including
the
small
prerogatives
of
sitting
next
the
toast
,
and
taking
two
cups
of
tea
to
other
people
's
one
,
and
always
taking
them
at
a
crisis
,
that
is
to
say
,
before
putting
fresh
water
into
the
tea
-
pot
,
and
after
it
had
been
standing
for
some
time
---
also
comprehended
a
full
view
of
the
company
,
and
an
opportunity
of
addressing
them
as
from
a
rostrum
,
Mrs
Gamp
discharged
the
functions
entrusted
to
her
with
extreme
good
-
humour
and
affability
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
resting
her
saucer
on
the
palm
of
her
outspread
hand
,
and
supporting
her
elbow
on
the
table
,
she
stopped
between
her
sips
of
tea
to
favour
the
circle
with
a
smile
,
a
wink
,
a
roll
of
the
head
,
or
some
other
mark
of
notice
;
and
at
those
periods
her
countenance
was
lighted
up
with
a
degree
of
intelligence
and
vivacity
,
which
it
was
almost
impossible
to
separate
from
the
benignant
influence
of
distilled
waters
.
   
<EOS>
But
for
Mrs
Gamp
,
it
would
have
been
a
curiously
silent
party
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
only
spoke
to
her
Augustus
,
and
to
him
in
whispers
.
<EOS>
Augustus
spoke
to
nobody
,
but
sighed
for
every
one
,
and
occasionally
gave
himself
such
a
sounding
slap
upon
the
forehead
as
would
make
Mrs
Todgers
,
who
was
rather
nervous
,
start
in
her
chair
with
an
involuntary
exclamation
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
was
occupied
in
knitting
,
and
seldom
spoke
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Merry
held
the
hand
of
cheerful
little
Ruth
between
her
own
,
and
listening
with
evident
pleasure
to
all
she
said
,
but
rarely
speaking
herself
,
sometimes
smiled
,
and
sometimes
kissed
her
on
the
cheek
,
and
sometimes
turned
aside
to
hide
the
tears
that
trembled
in
her
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
felt
this
change
in
her
so
much
,
and
was
so
glad
to
see
how
tenderly
Ruth
dealt
with
her
,
and
how
she
knew
and
answered
to
it
,
that
he
had
not
the
heart
to
make
any
movement
towards
their
departure
,
although
he
had
long
since
given
utterance
to
all
he
came
to
say
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
clerk
,
subsiding
into
his
usual
state
,
remained
profoundly
silent
,
while
the
rest
of
the
little
assembly
were
thus
occupied
,
intent
upon
the
dreams
,
whatever
they
might
be
,
which
hardly
seemed
to
stir
the
surface
of
his
sluggish
thoughts
.
 
<EOS>
The
bent
of
these
dull
fancies
combining
probably
with
the
silent
feasting
that
was
going
on
about
him
,
and
some
struggling
recollection
of
the
last
approach
to
revelry
he
had
witnessed
,
suggested
a
strange
question
to
his
mind
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
round
upon
a
sudden
,
and
said
:
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
lying
dead
upstairs
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
,
"
said
Merry
,
turning
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
 
<EOS>
We
are
all
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
All
here
!
"
cried
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
All
here
!
 
<EOS>
Where
is
he
then
---
my
old
master
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
who
had
the
only
son
?
 
<EOS>
Where
is
he
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
 
Hush
!
"
said
Merry
,
speaking
kindly
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
happened
long
ago
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
recollect
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Recollect
!
"
rejoined
the
old
man
,
with
a
cry
of
grief
.
 
<EOS>
"
As
if
I
could
forget
!
 
<EOS>
As
if
I
ever
could
forget
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
hand
up
to
his
face
for
a
moment
;
and
then
repeated
turning
round
exactly
as
before
:
   
"
Who
's
lying
dead
upstairs
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
!
"
said
Merry
.
   
<EOS>
At
first
he
gazed
angrily
upon
her
,
as
upon
a
stranger
who
endeavoured
to
deceive
him
;
but
peering
into
her
face
,
and
seeing
that
it
was
indeed
she
<EOS>
,
he
shook
his
head
in
sorrowful
compassion
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
not
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
do
n't
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
poor
thing
!
 
<EOS>
They
do
n't
tell
you
.
 
<EOS>
Who
are
these
,
and
why
are
they
merry
-
making
here
,
if
there
is
no
one
dead
?
 
<EOS>
Foul
play
!
 
<EOS>
Go
see
who
it
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
made
a
sign
to
them
not
to
speak
to
him
,
which
indeed
they
had
little
inclination
to
do
;
and
remained
silent
herself
.
 
<EOS>
So
did
he
for
a
short
time
;
but
then
he
repeated
the
same
question
with
an
eagerness
that
had
a
peculiar
terror
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
some
one
dead
,
"
he
said
,
"
or
dying
;
and
I
want
to
knows
who
it
is
.
 
<EOS>
Go
see
,
go
see
!
 
<EOS>
Where
's
Jonas
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
In
the
country
,
"
she
replied
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
gazed
at
her
as
if
he
doubted
what
she
said
,
or
had
not
heard
her
;
and
,
rising
from
his
chair
,
walked
across
the
room
and
upstairs
,
whispering
as
he
went
,
"
Foul
play
!
"
 
<EOS>
They
heard
his
footsteps
overhead
,
going
up
into
that
corner
of
the
room
in
which
the
bed
stood
<EOS>
(
it
was
there
old
Anthony
had
died
)
;
and
then
they
heard
him
coming
down
again
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
His
fancy
was
not
so
strong
or
wild
that
it
pictured
to
him
anything
in
the
deserted
bedchamber
which
was
not
there
;
for
he
returned
much
calmer
,
and
appeared
to
have
satisfied
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
They
do
n't
tell
you
,
"
he
said
to
Merry
in
his
quavering
voice
,
as
he
sat
down
again
,
and
patted
her
upon
the
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
do
n't
tell
me
either
;
but
I
'll
watch
,
I
'll
watch
.
 
<EOS>
They
shall
not
hurt
you
;
do
n't
be
frightened
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
have
sat
up
watching
,
I
have
sat
up
watching
too
.
 
<EOS>
Aye
,
aye
,
I
have
!
"
<EOS>
he
piped
out
,
clenching
his
weak
,
shrivelled
hand
.
 
<EOS>
"
Many
a
night
I
have
been
ready
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
said
this
with
such
trembling
gaps
and
pauses
in
his
want
of
breath
,
and
said
it
in
his
jealous
secrecy
so
closely
in
her
ear
,
that
little
or
nothing
of
it
was
understood
by
the
visitors
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
had
heard
and
seen
enough
of
the
old
man
to
be
disquieted
,
and
to
have
left
their
seats
and
gathered
about
him
;
thereby
affording
Mrs
Gamp
,
whose
professional
coolness
was
not
so
easily
disturbed
,
an
eligible
opportunity
for
concentrating
the
whole
resources
of
her
powerful
mind
and
appetite
upon
the
toast
and
butter
,
tea
and
eggs
.
<EOS>
She
had
brought
them
to
bear
upon
those
viands
with
such
vigour
that
her
face
was
in
the
highest
state
of
inflammation
,
when
she
now
(
there
being
nothing
left
to
eat
or
drink
)
saw
fit
to
interpose
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
highty
tighty
,
sir
!
"
cried
Mrs
Gamp
,
"
is
these
your
manners
?
<EOS>
You
want
a
pitcher
of
cold
water
throw'd
over
you
to
bring
you
round
;
that
's
my
belief
,
and
if
you
was
under
Betsey
Prig
you
'd
have
it
,
too
<EOS>
,
I
do
assure
you
,
Mr
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
Spanish
Flies
is
the
only
thing
to
draw
this
nonsense
out
of
you
;
and
if
anybody
wanted
to
do
you
a
kindness
,
they
'd
clap
a
blister
of
'em
on
your
head
,
and
put
a
mustard
poultige
on
your
back
.
 
<EOS>
"
Who
's
dead
,
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
It
would
n't
be
no
grievous
loss
if
some
one
was
,
I
think
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
quiet
now
,
Mrs
Gamp
,
"
said
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
disturb
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
bother
the
old
wictim
,
Mrs
Chuzzlewit
,
"
replied
that
zealous
lady
,
"
I
ai
n't
no
patience
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
You
give
him
his
own
way
too
much
by
half
.
 
<EOS>
A
worritin
'
wexagious
creetur
!
"
   
<EOS>
No
doubt
with
the
view
of
carrying
out
the
precepts
she
enforced
,
and
"
bothering
the
old
wictim
"
in
practice
as
well
as
in
theory
<EOS>
,
Mrs
Gamp
took
him
by
the
collar
of
his
coat
,
and
gave
him
some
dozen
or
two
of
hearty
shakes
backward
and
forward
in
his
chair
;
that
exercise
being
considered
by
the
disciples
of
the
Prig
school
of
nursing
(
who
are
very
numerous
among
professional
ladies
)
as
exceedingly
conducive
to
repose
,
and
highly
beneficial
to
the
performance
of
the
nervous
functions
.
 
<EOS>
Its
effect
in
this
instance
was
to
render
the
patient
so
giddy
and
addle
-
headed
,
that
he
could
say
nothing
more
;
which
Mrs
Gamp
regarded
as
the
triumph
of
her
art
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
she
said
,
loosening
the
old
man
's
cravat
,
in
consequence
of
his
being
rather
black
in
the
face
,
after
this
scientific
treatment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now
,
I
hope
,
you
're
easy
in
your
mind
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
should
turn
at
all
faint
we
can
soon
rewive
you
,
sir
,
I
promige
you
.
 
<EOS>
Bite
a
person
's
thumbs
,
or
turn
their
fingers
the
wrong
way
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
smiling
with
the
consciousness
of
at
once
imparting
pleasure
and
instruction
to
her
auditors
,
"
and
they
comes
to
,
wonderful
,
Lord
bless
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
this
excellent
woman
had
been
formerly
entrusted
with
the
care
of
Mr
Chuffey
on
a
previous
occasion
,
neither
Mrs
Jonas
nor
anybody
else
had
the
resolution
to
interfere
directly
with
her
mode
of
treatment
;
though
all
present
(
Tom
Pinch
and
his
sister
especially
)
appeared
to
be
disposed
to
differ
from
her
views
.
 
<EOS>
For
such
is
the
rash
boldness
of
the
uninitiated
,
that
they
will
frequently
set
up
some
monstrous
abstract
principle
,
such
as
humanity
,
or
tenderness
,
or
the
like
idle
folly
,
in
obstinate
defiance
of
all
precedent
and
usage
;
and
will
even
venture
to
maintain
the
same
against
the
persons
who
have
made
the
precedents
and
established
the
usage
,
and
who
must
therefore
be
the
best
and
most
impartial
judges
of
the
subject
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
Mr
Pinch
!
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
all
comes
of
this
unfortunate
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
If
my
sister
had
not
been
so
precipitate
,
and
had
not
united
herself
to
a
Wretch
,
there
would
have
been
no
Mr
Chuffey
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Hush
!
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
'll
hear
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
sorry
if
she
did
hear
me
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Cherry
,
raising
her
voice
a
little
;
"
for
it
is
not
in
my
nature
to
add
to
the
uneasiness
of
any
person
;
far
less
of
my
own
sister
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
what
a
sister
's
duties
are
,
Mr
Pinch
,
and
<EOS>
I
hope
I
always
showed
it
in
my
practice
.
 
<EOS>
Augustus
,
my
dear
child
,
find
my
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
and
give
it
to
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
Augustus
obeyed
,
and
took
Mrs
Todgers
aside
to
pour
his
griefs
into
her
friendly
bosom
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
Mr
Pinch
,
"
said
Charity
,
looking
after
her
betrothed
and
glancing
at
her
sister
,
"
that
I
ought
to
be
very
grateful
for
the
blessings
I
enjoy
,
and
those
which
are
yet
in
store
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
contrast
Augustus
"
---
here
she
was
modest
and
embarrased
---
"
<EOS>
who
,
I
do
n't
mind
saying
to
you
,
is
all
softness
,
mildness
,
and
devotion
,
with
the
detestable
man
who
is
my
sister
's
husband
;
and
when
I
think
,
Mr
Pinch
,
that
in
the
dispensations
of
this
world
,
our
cases
might
have
been
reversed
;
I
have
much
to
be
thankful
for
,
indeed
,
and
much
to
make
me
humble
and
contented
.
"
   
<EOS>
Contented
she
might
have
been
,
but
humble
she
assuredly
was
not
.
<EOS>
Her
face
and
manner
experienced
something
so
widely
different
from
humility
,
that
Tom
could
not
help
understanding
and
despising
the
base
motives
that
were
working
in
her
breast
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
away
,
and
said
to
Ruth
,
that
it
was
time
for
them
to
go
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
write
to
your
husband
,
"
said
Tom
to
Merry
,
"
and
explain
to
him
,
as
I
would
have
done
if
I
had
met
him
here
,
that
if
he
has
sustained
any
inconvenience
through
my
means
,
it
is
not
my
fault
;
a
postman
not
being
more
innocent
of
the
news
he
brings
,
than
I
was
when
I
handed
him
that
letter
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
!
"
<EOS>
said
Merry
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
may
do
some
good
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
parted
tenderly
from
Ruth
,
who
with
her
brother
was
in
the
act
of
leaving
the
room
,
when
a
key
was
heard
in
the
lock
of
the
door
below
,
and
immediately
afterwards
a
quick
footstep
in
the
passage
.
<EOS>
Tom
stopped
,
and
looked
at
Merry
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
Jonas
,
she
said
timidly
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
had
better
not
meet
him
on
the
stairs
,
perhaps
,
"
said
Tom
,
drawing
his
sister
's
arm
through
his
,
and
coming
back
a
step
or
two
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
wait
for
him
here
,
a
moment
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
said
it
when
the
door
opened
,
and
Jonas
entered
.
<EOS>
His
wife
came
forward
to
receive
him
;
but
he
put
her
aside
with
his
hand
,
and
said
in
a
surly
tone
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
know
you
'd
got
a
party
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
looked
,
at
the
same
time
,
either
by
accident
or
design
,
towards
Miss
Pecksniff
;
and
as
Miss
Pecksniff
was
only
too
delighted
to
quarrel
with
him
,
she
instantly
resented
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
let
us
intrude
upon
your
domestic
happiness
!
 
<EOS>
That
would
be
a
pity
.
 
<EOS>
We
have
taken
tea
here
,
sir
,
in
your
absence
;
but
if
you
will
have
the
goodness
to
send
us
a
note
of
the
expense
,
receipted
,
we
shall
be
happy
to
pay
it
.
<EOS>
Augustus
,
my
love
,
we
will
go
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
,
unless
you
wish
to
remain
here
,
we
shall
be
happy
to
take
you
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
pity
,
indeed
,
to
spoil
the
bliss
which
this
gentleman
always
brings
with
him
,
especially
into
his
own
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Charity
!
 
<EOS>
Charity
!
<EOS>
"
remonstrated
her
sister
,
in
such
a
heartfelt
tone
that
she
might
have
been
imploring
her
to
show
the
cardinal
virtue
whose
name
she
bore
.
   
<EOS>
"
Merry
,
my
dear
,
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
for
your
advice
,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
,
with
a
stately
scorn
---
by
the
way
,
she
had
not
been
offered
any
---
"
<EOS>
but
I
am
not
his
slave
---
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
nor
would
n't
have
been
if
you
could
,
"
interrupted
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
know
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
WHAT
did
you
say
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Miss
Pecksniff
,
sharply
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
you
hear
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Jonas
,
lounging
down
upon
a
chair
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
a
-
going
to
say
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
like
to
stay
,
you
may
stay
.
<EOS>
If
you
like
to
go
,
you
may
go
.
 
<EOS>
But
if
you
stay
,
please
to
be
civil
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Beast
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Pecksniff
,
sweeping
past
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Augustus
!
 
<EOS>
He
is
beneath
your
notice
!
"
 
<EOS>
Augustus
had
been
making
some
faint
and
sickly
demonstration
of
shaking
his
fist
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
away
,
child
,
"
screamed
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
I
command
you
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
scream
was
elicited
from
her
by
Augustus
manifesting
an
intention
to
return
and
grapple
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
Miss
Pecksniff
giving
the
fiery
youth
a
pull
,
and
Mrs
Todgers
giving
him
a
push
they
all
three
tumbled
out
of
the
room
together
,
to
the
music
of
Miss
Pecksniff
's
shrill
remonstrances
.
   
<EOS>
All
this
time
Jonas
had
seen
nothing
of
Tom
and
his
sister
;
for
they
were
almost
behind
the
door
when
he
opened
it
,
and
he
had
sat
down
with
his
back
towards
them
,
and
had
purposely
kept
his
eyes
upon
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
during
his
altercation
with
Miss
Pecksniff
,
in
order
that
his
seeming
carelessness
might
increase
the
exasperation
of
that
wronged
young
damsel
.
 
<EOS>
His
wife
now
faltered
out
that
Tom
had
been
waiting
to
see
him
;
and
Tom
advanced
.
   
<EOS>
The
instant
he
presented
himself
,
Jonas
got
up
from
his
chair
,
and
swearing
a
great
oath
,
caught
it
in
his
grasp
,
as
if
he
would
have
felled
Tom
to
the
ground
with
it
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
most
unquestionably
would
have
done
,
but
that
his
very
passion
and
surprise
made
him
irresolute
,
and
gave
Tom
,
in
his
calmness
,
an
opportunity
of
being
heard
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
no
cause
to
be
violent
,
sir
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Though
what
I
wish
to
say
relates
to
your
own
affairs
,
I
know
nothing
of
them
,
and
desire
to
know
nothing
of
them
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
was
too
enraged
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
He
held
the
door
open
;
and
stamping
his
foot
upon
the
ground
,
motioned
Tom
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
As
you
can
not
suppose
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
that
I
am
here
with
any
view
of
conciliating
you
or
pleasing
myself
,
I
am
quite
indifferent
to
your
reception
of
me
,
or
your
dismissal
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
Hear
what
I
have
to
say
,
if
you
are
not
a
madman
!
 
<EOS>
I
gave
you
a
letter
the
other
day
,
when
you
were
about
to
go
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
Thief
,
you
did
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
pay
you
for
the
carriage
of
it
one
day
,
and
settle
an
old
score
besides
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
you
need
n't
waste
words
or
threats
.
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
to
understand
---
plainly
because
I
would
rather
keep
clear
of
you
and
everything
that
concerns
you
:
not
because
I
have
the
least
apprehension
of
your
doing
me
any
injury
:
which
would
be
weak
indeed
---
that
I
am
no
party
to
the
contents
of
that
letter
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
know
nothing
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
That
I
was
not
even
aware
that
it
was
to
be
delivered
to
you
;
and
that
I
had
it
from
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
By
the
Lord
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
,
fiercely
catching
up
the
chair
<EOS>
,
"
I
'll
knock
your
brains
out
,
if
you
speak
another
word
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
,
nevertheless
,
persisting
in
his
intention
,
and
opening
his
lips
to
speak
again
,
Jonas
set
upon
him
like
a
savage
;
and
in
the
quickness
and
ferocity
of
his
attack
would
have
surely
done
him
some
grievous
injury
,
defenceless
as
he
was
,
and
embarrassed
by
having
his
frightened
sister
clinging
to
his
arm
,
if
Merry
had
not
run
between
them
,
crying
to
Tom
for
the
love
of
Heaven
to
leave
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
agony
of
this
poor
creature
,
the
terror
of
his
sister
,
the
impossibility
of
making
himself
audible
,
and
the
equal
impossibility
of
bearing
up
against
Mrs
Gamp
,
who
threw
herself
upon
him
like
a
feather
-
bed
,
and
forced
him
backwards
down
the
stairs
by
the
mere
oppression
of
her
dead
weight
,
prevailed
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
shook
the
dust
of
that
house
off
his
feet
,
without
having
mentioned
Nadgett
's
name
.
   
<EOS>
If
the
name
could
have
passed
his
lips
;
if
Jonas
,
in
the
insolence
of
his
vile
nature
,
had
never
roused
him
to
do
that
old
act
of
manliness
,
for
which
(
and
not
for
his
last
offence
)
<EOS>
he
hated
him
with
such
malignity
;
if
Jonas
could
have
learned
,
as
then
he
could
and
would
have
learned
,
through
Tom
's
means
,
what
unsuspected
spy
there
was
upon
him
;
he
would
have
been
saved
from
the
commission
of
a
Guilty
Deed
,
then
drawing
on
towards
its
black
accomplishment
.
<EOS>
But
the
fatality
was
of
his
own
working
;
the
pit
was
of
his
own
digging
;
the
gloom
that
gathered
round
him
was
the
shadow
of
his
own
life
.
   
<EOS>
His
wife
had
closed
the
door
,
and
thrown
herself
before
it
,
on
the
ground
,
upon
her
knees
.
 
<EOS>
She
held
up
her
hands
to
him
now
,
and
besought
him
not
to
be
harsh
with
her
,
for
she
had
interposed
in
fear
of
bloodshed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
,
so
!
"
said
Jonas
,
looking
down
upon
her
,
as
he
fetched
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
"
These
are
your
friends
,
are
they
,
when
I
am
away
?
 
<EOS>
You
plot
and
tamper
with
this
sort
of
people
,
do
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
no
knowledge
of
these
secrets
,
and
no
clue
to
their
meaning
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
never
seen
him
since
I
left
home
<EOS>
but
once
---
 
but
twice
---
before
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
sneered
Jonas
,
catching
at
this
correction
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
once
,
but
twice
,
eh
?
 
<EOS>
Which
do
you
mean
?
 
<EOS>
Twice
and
once
,
perhaps
.
 
<EOS>
Three
times
!
 
<EOS>
How
many
more
,
you
lying
jade
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
made
an
angry
motion
with
his
hand
,
she
shrunk
down
hastily
.
<EOS>
A
suggestive
action
!
 
<EOS>
Full
of
a
cruel
truth
!
   
<EOS>
"
How
many
more
times
?
"
he
repeated
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
more
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
morning
,
and
to
-
day
,
and
once
besides
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
He
was
about
to
retort
upon
her
,
when
the
clock
struck
.
 
<EOS>
He
started
stopped
,
and
listened
;
appearing
to
revert
to
some
engagement
,
or
to
some
other
subject
,
a
secret
within
his
own
breast
,
recalled
to
him
by
this
record
of
the
progress
of
the
hours
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
lie
there
!
 
<EOS>
Get
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
Having
helped
her
to
rise
,
or
rather
hauled
her
up
by
the
arm
,
he
went
on
to
say
:
   
<EOS>
"
Listen
to
me
,
young
lady
;
and
do
n't
whine
when
you
have
no
occasion
,
or
I
may
make
some
for
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
find
him
in
my
house
again
,
or
find
that
you
have
seen
him
in
anybody
else
's
house
,
you
'll
repent
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
are
not
deaf
and
dumb
to
everything
that
concerns
me
,
unless
you
have
my
leave
to
hear
and
speak
,
you
'll
repent
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
obey
exactly
what
I
order
,
you
'll
repent
it
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
attend
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
the
time
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
struck
eight
a
minute
ago
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
towards
her
intently
;
and
said
,
with
a
laboured
distinctness
,
as
if
he
had
got
the
words
off
by
heart
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
travelling
day
and
night
,
and
am
tired
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
lost
some
money
,
and
that
do
n't
improve
me
.
 
<EOS>
Put
my
supper
in
the
little
off
-
room
below
,
and
have
the
truckle
-
bed
made
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
sleep
there
to
-
night
,
and
maybe
to
-
morrow
night
;
and
if
I
can
sleep
all
day
to
-
morrow
,
so
much
the
better
,
for
I
've
got
trouble
to
sleep
off
,
if
I
can
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
the
house
quiet
,
and
do
n't
call
me
.
 
<EOS>
Mind
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
call
me
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
anybody
call
me
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
lie
there
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
said
it
should
be
done
.
 
<EOS>
Was
that
all
?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
what
?
 
<EOS>
You
must
be
prying
and
questioning
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
angrily
retorted
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
more
do
you
want
to
know
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
know
nothing
,
Jonas
,
but
what
you
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
All
hope
of
confidence
between
us
has
long
deserted
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Ecod
,
I
should
hope
so
!
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
if
you
will
tell
me
what
you
wish
,
I
will
be
obedient
and
will
try
to

you
.
 
<EOS>
I
make
no
merit
of
that
,
for
I
have
no
friend
in
my
father
or

sister
,
but
am
quite

.
 
<EOS>
I
am
very
humble
and
submissive
.
 
<EOS>
You
told

you
would
break
my
spirit
,
and
you
have
done

.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
break
my
heart
too
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
ventured
,
as
she

,
to
lay
her

upon

.
 
<EOS>
He
suffered
it
to
rest

,
in

;
and
the
whole
mean
,

,

of

,

at

,
for

.
   
<EOS>

;

,

,

by

without

.
 
<EOS>
When

had
withdrawn
he
paced
up
and
down
the
room
several

;
but
always
with

,
as

something
;
which

did

,
being
empty
.
 
<EOS>
When

,

,

;

,

.
   
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"

<EOS>
"
To

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
What

!
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
I

dear

<EOS>
He

"

,

?

"

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

"
   
<EOS>
"
See

,

;

<EOS>
Leaving

,

to
the

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
In

,
he
was
careful
so

key
as

through

;
and

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Chuff
,
"
he

,
"
it
'll

pretty
easy
to
be
even

YOU
.
<EOS>
It
's
of
no

things

,
and

,

.
 
<EOS>
When

.
 
<EOS>
But

's

d####d

,
"

"
that
his

should

.
"
   
<EOS>
After

room
from

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
just
now
,
but

,

.
 
<EOS>
Old
dog
!
 
<EOS>
He
shall

!
"
   
<EOS>
He

in

;
and

,

,
and
looking

.
 
<EOS>
When

had

at
it
for
a
long

,
he
remembered
his
supper
;
and
resuming

chair
he
had
first
occupied
,
began
to
eat
with
great

;
not
like
a
hungry

,
but
as
if
he
were
determined
to
do

.
 
<EOS>
He
drank
too
,
roundly
;
sometimes
stopping
in
the
middle
of
a
draught
to
walk
,
and
change
his
seat
and
walk
again
,
and
dart
back
to
the
table
and
fall
to
,
in
a
ravenous

,
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
now
growing
dark
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
gloom
of
evening
,
deepening
into
night
,
came
on
,
another
dark
shade
emerging
from
within
him
seemed
to
overspread
his
face
,
and
slowly
change
it
.
 
<EOS>
Slowly
,
slowly
;
darker
and
darker
;
more
and
more
haggard
;
creeping
over
him
by
little
and
little
,
until
it
was
black
night
within
him
and
without
.
   
<EOS>
The
room
in
which
he
had
shut
himself
up
,
was
on
the
ground
floor
,
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
lighted
by
a
dirty
skylight
,
and
had
a
door
in
the
wall
,
opening
into
a
narrow
covered
passage
or
blind
-
alley
,
very
little
frequented
after
five
or
six
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
and
not
in
much
use
as
a
thoroughfare
at
any
hour
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
had
an
outlet
in
a
neighbouring
street
.
   
<EOS>
The
ground
on
which
this
chamber
stood
had
,
at
one
time
,
not
within
his
recollection
,
been
a
yard
;
and
had
been
converted
to
its
present
purpose
for
use
as
an
office
.
 
<EOS>
But
the
occasion
for
it
died
with
the
man
who
built
it
;
and
saving
that
it
had
sometimes
served
as
an
apology
for
a
spare
bedroom
,
and
that
the
old
clerk
had
once
held
it
(
but
that
was
years
ago
)
as
his
recognized
apartment
,
it
had
been
little
troubled
by
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
and
Son
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
blotched
,
stained
,
mouldering
room
,
like
a
vault
;
and
there
were
water
-
pipes
running
through
it
,
<EOS>
which
at
unexpected
times
in
the
night
,
when
other
things
were
quiet
,
clicked
and
gurgled
suddenly
,
as
if
they
were
choking
.
   
<EOS>
The
door
into
the
court
had
not
been
open
for
a
long
,
long
time
;
but
the
key
had
always
hung
in
one
place
,
and
there
it
hung
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
prepared
for
its
being
rusty
;
for
he
had
a
little
bottle
of
oil
in
his
pocket
and
the
feather
of
a
pen
,
with
which
he
lubricated
the
key
and
the
lock
too
,
carefully
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
while
he
had
been
without
his
coat
,
and
had
nothing
on
his
feet
but
his
stockings
.
 
<EOS>
He
now
got
softly
into
bed
in
the
same
state
,
and
tossed
from
side
to
side
to
tumble
it
.
 
<EOS>
In
his
restless
condition
that
was
easily
done
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
arose
,
he
took
from
his
portmanteau
,
which
he
had
caused
to
be
carried
into
that
place
when
he
came
home
,
a
pair
of
clumsy
shoes
,
and
put
them
on
his
feet
;
also
a
pair
of
leather
leggings
,
such
as
countrymen
are
used
to
wear
,
with
straps
to
fasten
them
to
the
waistband
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
he
dressed
himself
at
leisure
.
 
<EOS>
Lastly
,
he
took
out
a
common
frock
of
coarse
dark
jean
,
which
he
drew
over
his
own
under
-
clothing
;
and
a
felt
hat
---
he
had
purposely
left
his
own
upstairs
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
sat
himself
down
by
the
door
,
with
the
key
in
his
hand
,
waiting
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
no
light
;
the
time
was
dreary
,
long
,
and
awful
.
 
<EOS>
The
ringers
were
practicing
in
a
neighbouring
church
,
and
the
clashing
of
the
bells
was
almost
maddening
.
 
<EOS>
Curse
the
clamouring
bells
,
they
seemed
to
know
that
he
was
listening
at
the
door
,
and
to
proclaim
it
in
a
crowd
of
voices
to
all
the
town
!
 
<EOS>
Would
they
never
be
still
?
   
<EOS>
They
ceased
at
last
,
and
then
the
silence
was
so
new
and
terrible
that
it
seemed
the
prelude
to
some
dreadful
noise
.
 
<EOS>
Footsteps
in
the
court
!
 
<EOS>
Two
men
.
 
<EOS>
He
fell
back
from
the
door
on
tiptoe
,
as
if
they
could
have
seen
him
through
its
wooden
panels
.
   
<EOS>
They
passed
on
,
talking
(
he
could
make
out
)
about
a
skeleton
which
had
been
dug
up
yesterday
,
in
some
work
of
excavation
near
at
hand
,
and
was
supposed
to
be
that
of
a
murdered
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
murder
is
not
always
found
out
,
you
see
,
"
they
said
to
one
another
as
they
turned
the
corner
.
   
<EOS>
Hush
!
   
<EOS>
He
put
the
key
into
the
lock
,
and
turned
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
door
resisted
for
a
while
,
but
soon
came
stiffly
open
;
mingling
with
the
sense
of
fever
in
his
mouth
,
a
taste
of
rust
,
and
dust
,
and
earth
,
and
rotting
wood
.
 
<EOS>
He
looked
out
;
passed
out
;
locked
it
after
him
.
   
<EOS>
All
was
clear
and
quiet
,
as
he
fled
away
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
47
.
<EOS>
Conclusion
of
the
enterprise
of
Mr
Jonas
and
his
friend
 
<EOS>
Did
no
men
passing
through
the
dim
streets
shrink
without
knowing
why
,
when
he
came
stealing
up
behind
them
?
 
<EOS>
As
he
glided
on
,
had
no
child
in
its
sleep
an
indistinct
perception
of
a
guilty
shadow
falling
on
its
bed
,
that
troubled
its
innocent
rest
?
 
<EOS>
Did
no
dog
howl
,
and
strive
to
break
its
rattling
chain
,
that
it
might
tear
him
;
no
burrowing
rat
,
scenting
the
work
he
had
in
hand
,
essay
to
gnaw
a
passage
after
him
,
that
it
might
hold
a
greedy
revel
at
the
feast
of
his
providing
?
 
<EOS>
When
he
looked
back
,
across
his
shoulder
,
was
it
to
see
if
his
quick
footsteps
still
fell
dry
upon
the
dusty
pavement
,
or
were
already
moist
and
clogged
with
the
red
mire
that
stained
the
naked
feet
of
Cain
!
   
<EOS>
He
shaped
his
course
for
the
main
western
road
,
and
soon
reached
it
;
riding
a
part
of
the
way
,
then
alighting
and
walking
on
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
travelled
for
a
considerable
distance
upon
the
roof
of
a
stage
-
coach
,
which
came
up
while
he
was
afoot
;
and
when
it
turned
out
of
his
road
,
bribed
the
driver
of
a
return
post
-
chaise
to
take
him
on
with
him
;
and
then
made
across
the
country
at
a
run
,
and
saved
a
mile
or
two
before
he
struck
again
into
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
At
last
,
as
his
plan
was
,
he
came
up
with
a
certain
lumbering
,
slow
,
night
-
coach
,
which
stopped
wherever
it
could
,
and
was
stopping
then
at
a
public
-
house
,
while
the
guard
and
coachman
ate
and
drank
within
.
   
<EOS>
He
bargained
for
a
seat
outside
this
coach
,
and
took
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
quitted
it
no
more
until
it
was
within
a
few
miles
of
its
destination
,
but
occupied
the
same
place
all
night
.
   
<EOS>
All
night
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
common
fancy
that
nature
seems
to
sleep
by
night
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
false
fancy
,
as
who
should
know
better
than
he
?
   
<EOS>
The
fishes
slumbered
in
the
cold
,
bright
,
glistening
streams
and
rivers
,
perhaps
;
and
the
birds
roosted
on
the
branches
of
the
trees
;
and
in
their
stalls
and
pastures
beasts
were
quiet
;
and
human
creatures
slept
.
 
<EOS>
But
what
of
that
,
when
the
solemn
night
was
watching
,
when
it
never
winked
,
when
its
darkness
watched
no
less
than
its
light
!
 
<EOS>
The
stately
trees
,
the
moon
and
shining
stars
,
the
softly
stirring
wind
,
the
over
-
shadowed
lane
,
the
broad
,
bright
countryside
<EOS>
,
they
all
kept
watch
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
a
blade
of
growing
grass
or
corn
,
but
watched
;
and
the
quieter
it
was
,
the
more
intent
and
fixed
its
watch
upon
him
seemed
to
be
.
   
<EOS>
And
yet
he
slept
.
 
<EOS>
Riding
on
among
those
sentinels
of
God
,
he
slept
,
and
did
not
change
the
purpose
of
his
journey
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
forgot
it
in
his
troubled
dreams
,
it
came
up
steadily
,
and
woke
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
never
woke
him
to
remorse
,
or
to
abandonment
of
his
design
.
   
<EOS>
He
dreamed
at
one
time
that
he
was
lying
calmly
in
his
bed
,
thinking
of
a
moonlight
night
and
the
noise
of
wheels
,
when
the
old
clerk
put
his
head
in
at
the
door
,
and
beckoned
him
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
signal
he
arose
immediately
---
being
already
dressed
in
the
clothes
he
actually
wore
at
that
time
---
and
accompanied
him
into
a
strange
city
,
where
the
names
of
the
streets
were
written
on
the
walls
in
characters
quite
new
to
him
;
which
gave
him
no
surprise
or
uneasiness
,
for
he
remembered
in
his
dream
to
have
been
there
before
.
 
<EOS>
Although
these
streets
were
very
precipitous
,
insomuch
that
to
get
from
one
to
another
<EOS>
it
was
necessary
to
descend
great
heights
by
ladders
that
were
too
short
,
and
ropes
that
moved
deep
bells
,
and
swung
and
swayed
as
they
were
clung
to
,
the
danger
gave
him
little
emotion
beyond
the
first
thrill
of
terror
;
his
anxieties
being
concentrated
on
his
dress
which
was
quite
unfitted
for
some
festival
that
was
about
to
be
holden
there
,
and
in
which
he
had
come
to
take
a
part
.
<EOS>
Already
,
great
crowds
began
to
fill
the
streets
,
and
in
one
direction
myriads
of
people
came
rushing
down
an
interminable
perspective
,
strewing
flowers
and
making
way
for
others
on
white
horses
,
when
a
terrible
figure
started
from
the
throng
,
and
cried
out
that
it
was
the
Last
Day
for
all
the
world
.
 
<EOS>
The
cry
being
spread
,
there
was
a
wild
hurrying
on
to
Judgment
;
and
the
press
became
so
great
that
he
and
his
companion
(
who
was
constantly
changing
,
and
was
never
the
same
man
two
minutes
together
,
though
he
never
saw
one
man
come
or
another
go
)
,
stood
aside
in
a
porch
,
fearfully
surveying
the
multitude
;
in
which
there
were
many
faces
that
he
knew
,
and
many
that
he
did
not
know
,
but
dreamed
he
did
;
when
all
at
once
a
struggling
head
rose
up
among
the
rest
---
livid
and
deadly
,
but
the
same
as
he
had
known
it
---
and
denounced
him
as
having
appointed
that
direful
day
to
happen
.
 
<EOS>
They
closed
together
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
strove
to
free
the
hand
in
which
he
held
a
club
,
and
strike
the
blow
he
had
so
often
thought
of
,
he
started
to
the
knowledge
of
his
waking
purpose
and
the
rising
of
the
sun
.
   
<EOS>
The
sun
was
welcome
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
life
and
motion
,
and
a
world
astir
,
to
divide
the
attention
of
Day
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
eye
of
Night
---
of
wakeful
,
watchful
,
silent
,
and
attentive
Night
,
with
so
much
leisure
for
the
observation
of
his
wicked
thoughts
---
that
he
dreaded
most
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
glare
in
the
night
.
 
<EOS>
Even
Glory
shows
to
small
advantage
in
the
night
,
upon
a
crowded
battle
-
field
.
 
<EOS>
How
then
shows
Glory
's
blood
-
relation
,
bastard
Murder
!
   
<EOS>
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
He
made
no
compromise
,
and
held
no
secret
with
himself
now
.
<EOS>
Murder
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
do
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
me
get
down
here
<EOS>
"
he
said
   
"
Short
of
the
town
,
eh
!
"
<EOS>
observed
the
coachman
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
may
get
down
<EOS>
where
I
please
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
got
up
to
please
yourself
,
and
may
get
down
to
please
yourself
.
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
break
our
hearts
to
lose
you
,
and
it
would
n't
have
broken
'em
if
we
'd
never
found
you
.
 
<EOS>
Be
a
little
quicker
.
 
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
guard
had
alighted
,
and
was
waiting
in
the
road
to
take
his
money
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
jealousy
and
distrust
of
what
he
contemplated
,
he
thought
this
man
looked
at
him
with
more
than
common
curiosity
   
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
staring
at
?
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
at
a
handsome
man
,
"
returned
the
guard
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
want
your
fortune
told
,
I
'll
tell
you
a
bit
of
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
be
drowned
.
<EOS>
That
's
a
consolation
for
you
.
"
   
<EOS>
Before
he
could
retort
or
turn
away
,
the
coachman
put
an
end
to
the
dialogue
by
giving
him
a
cut
with
his
whip
,
and
biddig
him
get
out
for
a
surly
dog
.
 
<EOS>
The
guard
jumped
up
to
his
seat
at
the
same
moment
,
and
they
drove
off
,
laughing
;
leaving
him
to
stand
in
the
road
and
shake
his
fist
at
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
not
displeased
though
,
on
second
thoughts
,
to
have
been
taken
for
an
ill
-
conditioned
common
country
fellow
;
but
rather
congratulated
himself
upon
it
as
a
proof
that
he
was
well
disguised
.
   
<EOS>
Wandering
into
a
copse
by
the
road
-
side
---
but
not
in
that
place
;
two
or
three
miles
off
---
he
tore
out
from
a
fence
a
thick
,
hard
,
knotted
stake
;
and
,
sitting
down
beneath
a
hayrick
,
spent
some
time
in
shaping
it
,
in
peeling
off
the
bark
,
and
fashioning
its
jagged
head
with
his
knife
.
   
<EOS>
The
day
passed
on
.
 
<EOS>
Noon
,
afternoon
,
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Sunset
.
   
<EOS>
At
that
serene
and
peaceful
time
two
men
,
riding
in
a
gig
,
came
out
of
the
city
by
a
road
not
much
frequented
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
day
on
which
Mr
Pecksniff
had
agreed
to
dine
with
Montague
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
kept
his
appointment
,
and
was
now
going
home
.
 
<EOS>
His
host
was
riding
with
him
for
a
short
distance
;
meaning
to
return
by
a
pleasant
track
,
which
Mr
Pecksniff
had
engaged
to
show
him
,
through
some
fields
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
knew
their
plans
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hung
about
the
inn
-
yard
while
they
were
at
dinner
and
had
heard
their
orders
given
.
   
<EOS>
They
were
loud
and
merry
in
their
conversation
,
and
might
have
been
heard
at
some
distance
;
far
above
the
sound
of
their
carriage
wheels
or
horses
'
hoofs
.
 
<EOS>
They
came
on
noisily
,
to
where
a
stile
and
footpath
indicated
their
point
of
separation
.
 
<EOS>
Here
they
stopped
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
too
soon
.
 
<EOS>
Much
too
soon
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
the
place
,
my
dear
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
the
path
,
and
go
straight
through
the
little
wood
you
'll
come
to
.
 
<EOS>
The
path
is
narrower
there
,
but
you
ca
n't
miss
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
shall
I
see
you
again
?
 
<EOS>
Soon
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
replied
Montague
.
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
night
.
 
<EOS>
And
a
pleasant
ride
!
"
   
<EOS>
So
long
as
Mr
Pecksniff
was
in
sight
,
and
turned
his
head
at
intervals
to
salute
him
,
Montague
stood
in
the
road
smiling
,
and
waving
his
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
when
his
new
partner
had
disappeared
,
and
this
show
was
no
longer
necessary
,
he
sat
down
on
the
stile
with
looks
so
altered
,
that
he
might
have
grown
ten
years
older
in
the
meantime
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
flushed
with
wine
,
but
not
gay
.
 
<EOS>
His
scheme
had
succeeded
,
but
he
showed
no
triumph
.
 
<EOS>
The
effort
of
sustaining
his
difficult
part
before
his
late
companion
had
fatigued
him
,
perhaps
,
or
it
may
be
that
the
evening
whispered
to
his
conscience
,
or
it
may
be
(
as
it
HAS
been
)
that
a
shadowy
veil
was
dropping
round
him
,
closing
out
all
thoughts
but
the
presentiment
and
vague
foreknowledge
of
impending
doom
.
   
<EOS>
If
there
be
fluids
,
as
we
know
there
are
,
which
,
conscious
of
a
coming
wind
,
or
rain
,
or
frost
,
will
shrink
and
strive
to
hide
themselves
in
their
glass
arteries
;
may
not
that
subtle
liquor
of
the
blood
perceive
,
by
properties
within
itself
,
that
hands
are
raised
to
waste
and
spill
it
;
and
in
the
veins
of
men
run
cold
and
dull
as
his
did
,
in
that
hour
!
   
<EOS>
So
cold
,
although
the
air
was
warm
;
so
dull
,
although
the
sky
was
bright
;
that
he
rose
up
shivering
from
his
seat
,
and
hastily
resumed
his
walk
.
 
<EOS>
He
checked
himself
as
hastily
;
undecided
whether
to
pursue
the
footpath
,
which
was
lonely
and
retired
,
or
to
go
back
by
the
road
.
   
<EOS>
He
took
the
footpath
.
   
<EOS>
The
glory
of
the
departing
sun
was
on
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
The
music
of
the
birds
was
in
his
ears
.
 
<EOS>
Sweet
wild
flowers
bloomed
about
him
.
<EOS>
Thatched
roofs
of
poor
men
's
homes
were
in
the
distance
;
and
an
old
grey
spire
,
surmounted
by
a
Cross
,
rose
up
between
him
and
the
coming
night
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
never
read
the
lesson
which
these
things
conveyed
;
he
had
ever
mocked
and
turned
away
from
it
;
but
,
before
going
down
into
a
hollow
place
,
he
looked
round
,
once
,
upon
the
evening
prospect
,
sorrowfully
.
 
<EOS>
Then
he
went
down
,
down
,
down
,
into
the
dell
.
   
<EOS>
It
brought
him
to
the
wood
;
a
close
,
thick
,
shadowy
wood
,
through
which
the
path
went
winding
on
,
dwindling
away
into
a
slender
sheep
-
track
.
 
<EOS>
He
paused
before
entering
;
for
the
stillness
of
this
spot
almost
daunted
him
.
   
<EOS>
The
last
rays
of
the
sun
were
shining
in
,
aslant
,
making
a
path
of
golden
light
along
the
stems
and
branches
in
its
range
,
which
,
even
as
he
looked
,
began
to
die
away
,
yielding
gently
to
the
twilight
that
came
creeping
on
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
very
quiet
that
the
soft
and
stealthy
moss
about
the
trunks
of
some
old
trees
,
seemed
to
have
grown
out
of
the
silence
,
and
to
be
its
proper
offspring
.
 
<EOS>
Those
other
trees
which
were
subdued
by
blasts
of
wind
in
winter
time
,
had
not
quite
tumbled
down
,
but
being
caught
by
others
,
lay
all
bare
and
scathed
across
their
leafy
arms
,
as
if
unwilling
to
disturb
the
general
repose
by
the
crash
of
their
fall
.
 
<EOS>
Vistas
of
silence
opened
everywhere
,
into
the
heart
and
innermost
recesses
of
the
wood
;
beginning
with
the
likeness
of
an
aisle
,
a
cloister
,
or
a
ruin
open
to
the
sky
;
then
tangling
off
into
a
deep
green
rustling
mystery
,
through
which
gnarled
trunks
,
and
twisted
boughs
,
and
ivy
-
covered
stems
,
and
trembling
leaves
,
and
bark
-
stripped
bodies
of
old
trees
stretched
out
at
length
,
were
faintly
seen
in
beautiful
confusion
.
   
<EOS>
As
the
sunlight
died
away
,
and
evening
fell
upon
the
wood
,
he
entered
it
.
 
<EOS>
Moving
,
here
and
there
a
bramble
or
a
drooping
bough
which
stretched
across
his
path
,
he
slowly
disappeared
.
 
<EOS>
At
intervals
a
narrow
opening
showed
him
passing
on
,
or
the
sharp
cracking
of
some
tender
branch
denoted
where
he
went
;
then
,
he
was
seen
or
heard
no
more
.
   
<EOS>
Never
more
beheld
by
mortal
eye
or
heard
by
mortal
ear
;
one
man
excepted
.
 
<EOS>
That
man
,
parting
the
leaves
and
branches
on
the
other
side
,
near
where
the
path
emerged
again
,
came
leaping
out
soon
afterwards
.
   
<EOS>
What
had
he
left
within
the
wood
,
that
he
sprang
out
of
it
as
if
it
were
a
hell
!
   
<EOS>
The
body
of
a
murdered
man
.
 
<EOS>
In
one
thick
solitary
spot
,
it
lay
among
the
last
year
's
leaves
of
oak
and
beech
,
just
as
it
had
fallen
headlong
down
.
 
<EOS>
Sopping
and
soaking
in
among
the
leaves
that
formed
its
pillow
;
oozing
down
into
the
boggy
ground
,
as
if
to
cover
itself
from
human
sight
;
forcing
its
way
between
and
through
the
curling
leaves
,
as
if
those
senseless
things
rejected
and
forswore
it
and
were
coiled
up
in
abhorrence
;
went
a
dark
,
dark
stain
that
dyed
the
whole
summer
night
from
earth
to
heaven
.
   
<EOS>
The
doer
of
this
deed
came
leaping
from
the
wood
so
fiercely
,
that
he
cast
into
the
air
a
shower
of
fragments
of
young
boughs
,
torn
away
in
his
passage
,
and
fell
with
violence
upon
the
grass
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
quickly
gained
his
feet
again
,
and
keeping
underneath
a
hedge
with
his
body
bent
,
went
running
on
towards
the
road
.
 
<EOS>
The
road
once
reached
,
he
fell
into
a
rapid
walk
,
and
set
on
toward
London
.
   
<EOS>
And
he
was
not
sorry
for
what
he
had
done
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
frightened
when
he
thought
of
it
<EOS>
---
when
did
he
not
think
of
it
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
but
he
was
not
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
had
a
terror
and
dread
of
the
wood
when
he
was
in
it
;
but
being
out
of
it
,
and
having
committed
the
crime
,
his
fears
were
now
diverted
,
strangely
,
to
the
dark
room
he
had
left
shut
up
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
a
greater
horror
,
infinitely
greater
,
of
that
room
than
of
the
wood
.
 
<EOS>
Now
that
he
was
on
his
return
to
it
,
it
seemed
beyond
comparison
more
dismal
and
more
dreadful
than
the
wood
.
 
<EOS>
His
hideous
secret
was
shut
up
in
the
room
,
and
all
its
terrors
were
there
;
to
his
thinking
it
was
not
in
the
wood
at
all
.
   
<EOS>
He
walked
on
for
ten
miles
;
and
then
stopped
at
an
ale
-
house
for
a
coach
,
which
he
knew
would
pass
through
,
on
its
way
to
London
,
before
long
;
and
which
he
also
knew
was
not
the
coach
he
had
travelled
down
by
,
for
it
came
from
another
place
.
 
<EOS>
He
sat
down
outside
the
door
here
,
on
a
bench
,
beside
a
man
who
was
smoking
his
pipe
.
 
<EOS>
Having
called
for
some
beer
,
and
drunk
,
he
offered
it
to
this
companion
,
who
thanked
him
,
and
took
a
draught
.
 
<EOS>
He
could
not
help
thinking
that
,
if
the
man
had
known
all
,
he
might
scarcely
have
relished
drinking
out
of
the
same
cup
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
A
fine
night
,
master
!
<EOS>
"
said
this
person
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
a
rare
sunset
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
see
it
,
"
was
his
hasty
answer
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
n't
see
it
?
"
returned
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
the
devil
could
I
see
it
,
if
I
was
asleep
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Asleep
!
 
<EOS>
Aye
,
aye
.
"
 
<EOS>
The
man
appeared
surprised
by
his
unexpected
irritability
,
and
saying
no
more
,
smoked
his
pipe
in
silence
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
not
sat
very
long
,
when
there
was
a
knocking
within
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
?
"
cried
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
say
,
I
'm
sure
,
"
replied
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
He
made
no
further
inquiry
,
for
the
last
question
had
escaped
him
in
spite
of
himself
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
was
thinking
,
at
the
moment
,
of
the
closed
-
up
room
;
of
the
possibility
of
their
knocking
at
the
door
on
some
special
occasion
;
of
their
being
alarmed
at
receiving
no
answer
;
of
their
bursting
it
open
;
of
their
finding
the
room
empty
;
of
their
fastening
the
door
into
the
court
,
and
rendering
it
impossible
for
him
to
get
into
the
house
without
showing
himself
in
the
garb
he
wore
,
which
would
lead
to
rumour
,
rumour
to
detection
,
detection
to
death
.
 
<EOS>
At
that
instant
,
as
if
by
some
design
and
order
of
circumstances
,
the
knocking
had
come
.
   
<EOS>
It
still
continued
;
like
a
warning
echo
of
the
dread
reality
he
had
conjured
up
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
could
not
sit
and
hear
it
,
he
paid
for
his
beer
and
walked
on
again
.
 
<EOS>
And
having
slunk
about
,
in
places
unknown
to
him
all
day
;
and
being
out
at
night
,
in
a
lonely
road
,
in
an
unusual
dress
and
in
that
wandering
and
unsettled
frame
of
mind
;
he
stopped
more
than
once
to
look
about
him
,
hoping
he
might
be
in
a
dream
.
   
<EOS>
Still
he
was
not
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
hated
the
man
too
much
,
and
had
been
bent
,
too
desperately
and
too
long
,
on
setting
himself
free
.
<EOS>
If
the
thing
could
have
come
over
again
,
he
would
have
done
it
again
.
 
<EOS>
His
malignant
and
revengeful
passions
were
not
so
easily
laid
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
more
penitence
or
remorse
within
him
now
than
there
had
been
while
the
deed
was
brewing
.
   
<EOS>
Dread
and
fear
were
upon
him
,
to
an
extent
he
had
never
counted
on
,
and
could
not
manage
in
the
least
degree
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
so
horribly
afraid
of
that
infernal
room
at
home
.
 
<EOS>
This
made
him
,
in
a
gloomy
murderous
,
mad
way
,
not
only
fearful
FOR
himself
,
but
OF
himself
;
for
being
,
as
it
were
,
a
part
of
the
room
:
a
something
supposed
to
be
there
,
yet
missing
from
it
:
he
invested
himself
with
its
mysterious
terrors
;
and
when
he
pictured
in
his
mind
the
ugly
chamber
,
false
and
quiet
,
false
and
quiet
,
through
the
dark
hours
of
two
nights
;
and
the
tumbled
bed
,
and
he
not
in
it
,
though
believed
to
be
;
he
became
in
a
manner
his
own
ghost
and
phantom
,
and
was
at
once
the
haunting
spirit
and
the
haunted
man
.
   
<EOS>
When
the
coach
came
up
,
which
it
soon
did
,
he
got
a
place
outside
and
was
carried
briskly
onward
towards
home
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
in
taking
his
seat
among
the
people
behind
,
who
were
chiefly
country
people
,
he
conceived
a
fear
that
they
knew
of
the
murder
,
and
would
tell
him
that
the
body
had
been
found
;
which
,
considering
the
time
and
place
of
the
commission
of
the
crime
,
were
events
almost
impossible
to
have
happened
yet
,
as
he
very
well
knew
.
 
<EOS>
But
although
he
did
know
it
,
and
had
therefore
no
reason
to
regard
their
ignorance
as
anything
but
the
natural
sequence
to
the
facts
,
still
this
very
ignorance
of
theirs
encouraged
him
.
 
<EOS>
So
far
encouraged
him
,
that
he
began
to
believe
the
body
never
would
be
found
,
and
began
to
speculate
on
that
probability
.
 
<EOS>
Setting
off
from
this
point
,
and
measuring
time
by
the
rapid
hurry
of
his
guilty
thoughts
,
and
what
had
gone
before
the
bloodshed
,
and
the
troops
of
incoherent
and
disordered
images
of
which
he
was
the
constant
prey
;
he
came
by
daylight
to
regard
the
murder
as
an
old
murder
,
and
to
think
himself
comparatively
safe
because
it
had
not
been
discovered
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
!
<EOS>
When
the
sun
which
looked
into
the
wood
,
and
gilded
with
its
rising
light
a
dead
man
's
lace
,
had
seen
that
man
alive
,
and
sought
to
win
him
to
a
thought
of
Heaven
,
on
its
going
down
last
night
!
   
<EOS>
But
here
were
London
streets
again
.
 
<EOS>
Hush
!
   
<EOS>
It
was
but
five
o'clock
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
time
enough
to
reach
his
own
house
unobserved
,
and
before
there
were
many
people
in
the
streets
,
if
nothing
had
happened
so
far
,
tending
to
his
discovery
.
 
<EOS>
He
slipped
down
from
the
coach
without
troubling
the
driver
to
stop
his
horses
;
and
hurrying
across
the
road
,
and
in
and
out
of
every
by
-
way
that
lay
near
his
course
,
at
length
approached
his
own
dwelling
.
 
<EOS>
He
used
additional
caution
in
his
immediate
neighbourhood
;
halting
first
to
look
all
down
the
street
before
him
;
then
gliding
swiftly
through
that
one
,
and
stopping
to
survey
the
next
,
and
so
on
.
   
<EOS>
The
passage
-
way
was
empty
when
his
murderer
's
face
looked
into
it
.
<EOS>
He
stole
on
,
to
the
door
on
tiptoe
,
as
if
he
dreaded
to
disturb
his
own
imaginary
rest
.
   
<EOS>
He
listened
.
 
<EOS>
Not
a
sound
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
turned
the
key
with
a
trembling
hand
,
and
pushed
the
door
softly
open
with
his
knee
,
a
monstrous
fear
beset
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
What
if
the
murdered
man
were
there
before
him
!
   
<EOS>
He
cast
a
fearful
glance
all
round
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
was
nothing
there
.
   
<EOS>
He
went
in
,
locked
the
door
,
drew
the
key
through
and
through
the
dust
and
damp
in
the
fire
-
place
to
sully
it
again
,
and
hung
it
up
as
of
old
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
off
his
disguise
,
tied
it
up
in
a
bundle
ready
for
carrying
away
and
sinking
in
the
river
before
night
,
and
locked
it
up
in
a
cupboard
.
 
<EOS>
These
precautions
taken
,
he
undressed
and
went
to
bed
.
   
<EOS>
The
raging
thirst
,
the
fire
that
burnt
within
him
as
he
lay
beneath
the
clothes
,
the
augmented
horror
of
the
room
when
they
shut
it
out
from
his
view
;
the
agony
of
listening
,
in
which
he
paid
enforced
regard
to
every
sound
,
and
thought
the
most
unlikely
one
the
prelude
to
that
knocking
which
should
bring
the
news
;
the
starts
with
which
he
left
his
couch
,
and
looking
in
the
glass
,
imagined
that
his
deed
was
broadly
written
in
his
face
,
and
lying
down
and
burying
himself
once
more
beneath
the
blankets
,
heard
his
own
heart
beating
Murder
,
Murder
,
Murder
,
in
the
bed
;
what
words
can
paint
tremendous
truths
like
these
!
   
<EOS>
The
morning
advanced
.
 
<EOS>
There
were
footsteps
in
the
house
.
 
<EOS>
He
heard
the
blinds
drawn
up
,
and
shutters
opened
;
and
now
and
then
a
stealthy
tread
outside
his
own
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
call
out
,
more
than
once
,
but
his
mouth
was
dry
as
if
it
had
been
filled
with
sand
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
sat
up
in
his
bed
,
and
cried
:
   
<EOS>
"
Who
's
there
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
his
wife
.
   
<EOS>
He
asked
her
what
it
was
o'clock
?
 
<EOS>
Nine
.
   
<EOS>
"
Did
---
did
no
one
knock
at
my
door
yesterday
?
<EOS>
"
he
faltered
.
<EOS>
"
Something
disturbed
me
;
but
unless
you
had
knocked
the
door
down
,
you
would
have
got
no
notice
from
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
one
,
"
she
replied
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
well
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
waited
,
almost
breathless
,
for
her
answer
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
relief
to
him
,
if
anything
could
be
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Nadgett
wanted
to
see
you
,
"
she
said
,
"
but
I
told
him
you
were
tired
,
and
had
requested
not
to
be
disturbed
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
it
was
of
little
consequence
,
and
went
away
.
 
<EOS>
As
I
was
opening
my
window
to
let
in
the
cool
air
,
I
saw
him
passing
through
the
street
this
morning
,
very
early
;
but
he
has
n't
been
again
.
"
   
<EOS>
Passing
through
the
street
that
morning
?
 
<EOS>
Very
early
!
 
<EOS>
Jonas
trembled
at
the
thought
of
having
had
a
narrow
chance
of
seeing
him
himself
;
even
him
,
who
had
no
object
but
to
avoid
people
,
and
sneak
on
unobserved
,
and
keep
his
own
secrets
;
and
who
saw
nothing
.
   
<EOS>
He
called
to
her
to
get
his
breakfast
ready
,
and
prepared
to
go
upstairs
;
attiring
himself
in
the
clothes
he
had
taken
off
when
he
came
into
that
room
,
which
had
been
,
ever
since
,
outside
the
door
.
<EOS>
In
his
secret
dread
of
meeting
the
household
for
the
first
time
,
after
what
he
had
done
,
he
lingered
at
the
door
on
slight
pretexts
that
they
might
see
him
without
looking
in
his
face
;
and
left
it
ajar
while
he
dressed
;
and
called
out
to
have
the
windows
opened
,
and
the
pavement
watered
,
that
they
might
become
accustomed
to
his
voice
.
 
<EOS>
Even
when
he
had
put
off
the
time
,
by
one
means
or
other
,
so
that
he
had
seen
or
spoken
to
them
all
,
he
could
not
muster
courage
for
a
long
while
to
go
in
among
them
,
but
stood
at
his
own
door
listening
to
the
murmur
of
their
distant
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
He
could
not
stop
there
for
ever
,
and
so
joined
them
.
 
<EOS>
His
last
glance
at
the
glass
had
seen
a
tell
-
tale
face
,
but
that
might
have
been
because
of
his
anxious
looking
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
dared
not
look
at
them
to
see
if
they
observed
him
,
but
he
thought
them
very
silent
.
   
<EOS>
And
whatsoever
guard
<EOS>
he
kept
upon
himself
,
he
could
not
help
listening
,
and
showing
that
he
listened
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
he
attended
to
their
talk
,
or
tried
to
think
of
other
things
,
or
talked
himself
,
or
held
his
peace
,
or
resolutely
counted
the
dull
tickings
of
a
hoarse
clock
at
his
back
,
he
always
lapsed
,
as
if
a
spell
were
on
him
,
into
eager
listening
.
 
<EOS>
For
he
knew
it
must
come
.
 
<EOS>
And
his
present
punishment
,
and
torture
and
distraction
,
were
,
to
listen
for
its
coming
.
   
<EOS>
Hush
!
    
Chapter
48
.
<EOS>
Bears
tidings
of
Martin
and
of
Mark
,
as
well
as
of
a
third
person
not
quite
unknown
to
the
reader
.
 
<EOS>
Exhibits
filial
piety
in
an
ugly
aspect
;
and
casts
a
doubtful
ray
of
light
upon
a
very
dark
place
 
Tom
Pinch
and
Ruth
were
sitting
at
their
early
breakfast
,
with
the
window
open
,
and
a
row
of
the
freshest
little
plants
ranged
before
it
on
the
inside
by
Ruth
's
own
hands
;
and
Ruth
had
fastened
a
sprig
of
geranium
in
Tom
's
button
-
hole
,
to
make
him
very
smart
and
summer
-
like
for
the
day
(
it
was
obliged
to
be
fastened
in
,
or
that
dear
old
Tom
was
certain
to
lose
it
)
;
and
people
were
crying
flowers
up
and
down
the
street
;
and
a
blundering
bee
,
who
had
got
himself
in
between
the
two
sashes
of
the
window
,
was
bruising
his
head
against
the
glass
,
endeavouring
to
force
himself
out
into
the
fine
morning
,
and
considering
himself
enchanted
because
he
could
n't
do
it
;
and
the
morning
was
as
fine
a
morning
as
ever
was
seen
;
and
the
fragrant
air
was
kissing
Ruth
and
rustling
about
Tom
,
as
if
it
said
,
"
how
are
you
,
my
dears
;
I
came
all
this
way
on
purpose
to
salute
you
;
"
and
it
was
one
of
those
glad
times
when
we
form
,
or
ought
to
form
,
the
wish
that
every
one
on
earth
were
able
to
be
happy
,
and
catching
glimpses
of
the
summer
of
the
heart
,
to
feel
the
beauty
of
the
summer
of
the
year
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
even
a
pleasanter
breakfast
than
usual
;
and
it
was
always
a
pleasant
one
.
 
<EOS>
For
little
Ruth
had
now
two
pupils
to
attend
,
each
three
times
a
week
;
and
each
two
hours
at
a
time
;
and
besides
this
,
she
had
painted
some
screens
and
card
-
racks
,
and
,
unknown
to
Tom
<EOS>
(
was
there
ever
anything
so
delightful
!
)
,
had
walked
into
a
certain
shop
which
dealt
in
such
articles
,
after
often
peeping
through
the
window
;
and
had
taken
courage
to
ask
the
Mistress
of
that
shop
whether
she
would
buy
them
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
mistress
had
not
only
bought
them
,
but
had
ordered
more
,
and
that
very
morning
Ruth
had
made
confession
of
these
facts
to
Tom
,
and
had
handed
him
the
money
in
a
little
purse
she
had
worked
expressly
for
the
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
been
in
a
flutter
about
this
,
and
perhaps
had
shed
a
happy
tear
or
two
for
anything
the
history
knows
to
the
contrary
;
but
it
was
all
over
now
;
and
a
brighter
face
than
Tom
's
,
or
a
brighter
face
than
Ruth
's
,
the
bright
sun
had
not
looked
on
since
he
went
to
bed
last
night
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
,
"
said
Tom
,
coming
so
abruptly
on
the
subject
,
that
he
interrupted
himself
in
the
act
of
cutting
a
slice
of
bread
,
and
left
the
knife
sticking
in
the
loaf
,
"
what
a
queer
fellow
our
landlord
is
!
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
he
has
been
home
once
since
he
got
me
into
that
unsatisfactory
scrape
.
 
<EOS>
I
begin
to
think
he
will
never
come
home
again
.
 
<EOS>
What
a
mysterious
life
that
man
does
lead
,
to
be
sure
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
strange
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
hope
it
is
only
strange
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
there
may
be
nothing
wrong
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
begin
to
be
doubtful
of
that
.
 
<EOS>
I
must
have
an

with
him
,
"
said

,

as

this

a

,
"
when
I
can
catch
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
A

at
the
door
put
Tom
's
menacing
looks
to
flight
,
and
awakened
an
expression
of
surprise
instead
.
   
<EOS>
"
Heyday
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
An
early
hour
for
visitors
!
 
<EOS>
It
must
be
John
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
---
do
n't

was
his
knock
,
Tom
,
"
observed

little

.
   
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
surely
ca
n't

suddenly
arrived

;

here

Mr

;
and

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

,

!
 
<EOS>
Come

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
But
when

,
Tom
Pinch
,
instead

,
"
Did

,

?
"

,

;

,

?
"
or

;
cried

,
"
Good
gracious
Heaven
!
"
and
seized

by

,
with
the
liveliest

of

and

.
   
<EOS>
The
visitor
was
not
less

than
Tom
himself
,
and
they
shook
hands
a
great
many
times
,
without
another

being

on

.
 
<EOS>
Tom
was
the
first
to
find
his
voice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mark
Tapley
,
too
!
"
said
Tom
,
running
towards
the
door
,
and
shaking
hands
with
somebody
else
.
 
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mark
,
come
in
.
 
<EOS>
How
are
you
,
Mark
?
 
<EOS>
He
do
n't
look
a
day
older
than
he
used
to
do
at
the
Dragon
.
<EOS>
How
ARE

,
Mark
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Uncommonly
jolly
,
sir
,
thank'ee
,
"
returned
Mr
Tapley
,
all
smiles
and
bows
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
see
you
well
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
me
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
How
delightful
it
is
to

old

again
!
 
<EOS>
My
dear
Martin
,
sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
My
sister
,
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
my

.
 
<EOS>
Mark
Tapley
from
the

,
my

.
 
<EOS>
Good
gracious
me
<EOS>
,
what
a
surprise
this
is
!
 
<EOS>
Sit
down
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
,
bless
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
was
in
such
a
state
of
excitement
that
he
could
n't
keep
himself
still
for
a
moment
,
but
was
constantly
running
between
Mark
and
Martin
,
shaking
hands
with
them
alternately
,
and
presenting

over
and
over

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
remember
the

,
Martin
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
a

it
was
!
<EOS>
and

you
were

!
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't

remember
my
overtaking

in

,
Mark
,
when

in

,

?
 
<EOS>
And

,

,

John
Westlock
,

!
 
<EOS>
Good

me
!
 
<EOS>
Ruth
,

,
Mr

.
 
<EOS>
Mark
Tapley
,

,

.
 
<EOS>
More

,

.
 
<EOS>
Bless
<EOS>
my
soul
,
how

I

to

both
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
then
Tom
(
as
John
Westlock
had
done
on
his

)
ran
off
to

loaf
to
cut
some
bread
and
butter
for

;
and
before

had
spread
a
single
slice
,
remembered
something
else
,
and
came
running
back
again
to
tell

;
and
then

shook
hands
with

again
;
and
then
he
introduced

again
;
and
then
he
did
everything
he
had
done
already
all
over
again
;
and
nothing
Tom
could
do
,
and
nothing
Tom
could
say
,
was
half
sufficient
to
express
his
joy
at
their
safe

.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
was
the
first
to
resume
his
composure
.
 
<EOS>
In
a
very
short
space
of
time
he
was
discovered
to
have
somehow
installed
himself
in
office
as
waiter
,
or
attendant
upon
the
party
;
a
fact
which
was
first
suggested
to
them
by
his

in
the

,
and
speedy
return
with
a

,
from

replenished
the
tea
-
pot
with

-

that
was
quite
his

.
   
<EOS>
"
Sit

,

,
Mark
,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Make
him

,
Martin
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I

,

,
as

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
Miss
Pinch
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
She

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have

Mark
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
Have

,
Ruth
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
all
,
"

,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

Mark
Tapley

,

;
and
but

Mark
he

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mark
!
<EOS>
"

Tom
Pinch
energetically
;
"
if
you
do
n't

this

,
I
'll

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

Mr
Tapley
,
"
sooner
than

should
do
that
<EOS>
,
I
'll
com
-
ply
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
considerable
invasion
of
a
man
's
jollity
to
be
made
so
partickler
welcome
,
but
a
Werb
is
a
word
as
signifies
to
be
,
to
do
,
or
to
suffer
(
which
is
all
the
grammar
,
and
enough
too
,
as
ever
I
wos
taught
)
;
and
if
there
's
a
Werb
alive
,
I
'm
it
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
'm
always
a
-
bein
'
,
sometimes
a
-
doin
'
,
and
continually
a
-
sufferin
'
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Not
jolly
yet
?
"
asked
Tom
,
with
a
smile
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
was
rather
so
,
over
the
water
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mr
Tapley
;
"
and
not
entirely
without

.
 
<EOS>
But
Human
Natur
"
is
in
a
conspiracy
again
'
<EOS>
me
;
I
ca
n't
get
on
.
 
<EOS>
I
shall
have
to
leave
it
in
my
will
,
sir
,
to
be
wrote
upon
my
tomb
:
"
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
as
might
have
come
out
strong
if
he
could

got

.
 
<EOS>
But
it
was
denied
him
.
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
took
this
occasion
of
looking
about
him
with
a
grin
,
and
subsequently
attacking
the
breakfast
,
with
an
appetite
not
at
all
expressive
of
blighted
hopes
,
or
insurmountable
despondency
.
   
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
,
Martin
drew
his
chair
a
little
nearer
to
Tom
and
his
sister
,
and
related
to
them
what
had
passed
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
house
;
adding
in
few
words
a
general
summary
of
the
distresses
and
disappointments
he
had
undergone
since
he
left
England
.
   
<EOS>
"
For
your
faithful
stewardship
in
the
trust
I
left
with
you
,
Tom
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
for
all
your
goodness
and
disinterestedness
,
I
can
never
thank
you
enough
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
add
Mary
's
thanks
to
mine
---
<EOS>
"
   
Ah
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
The
blood
retreated
from
his
cheeks
,
and
came
rushing
back
,
so
violently
,
that
it
was
pain
to
feel
it
;
ease
though
,
ease
,
compared
with
the
aching
of
his
wounded
heart
.
   
<EOS>
"
When
I
add
Mary
's
thanks
to
mine
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
I
have
made
the
only
poor
acknowledgment
it
is
in
our
power
to
offer
;
but
if
you
knew
how
much
we
feel
,
Tom
,
you
would
set
some
store
by
it
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
And
if
they
had
known
how
much
Tom
felt
---
but
that
no
human
creature
ever
knew
---
they
would
have
set
some
store
by
him
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
they
would
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
changed
the
topic
of
discourse
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sorry
he
could
not
pursue
it
,
as
it
gave
Martin
pleasure
;
but
he
was
unable
,
at
that
moment
.
 
<EOS>
No
drop
of
envy
or
bitterness
was
in
his
soul
;
but
he
could
not
master
the
firm
utterance
of
her
name
.
   
<EOS>
He
inquired
what
Martin
's
projects
were
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
longer
to
make
your
fortune
,
Tom
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
but
to
try
to
live
.
 
<EOS>
I
tried
that
once
in
London
,
Tom
;
and
failed
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
give
me
the
benefit
of
your
advice
and
friendly
counsel
,
I
may
succeed
better
under
your
guidance
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
do
anything
Tom
,
anything
,
to
gain
a
livelihood
by
my
own
exertions
.
 
<EOS>
My
hopes
do
not
soar
above
that
,
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
High
-
hearted
,
noble
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
Sorry
to
find
the
pride
of
his
old
companion
humbled
,
and
to
hear
him
speaking
in
this
altered
strain
at
once
<EOS>
,
at
once
,
he
drove
from
his
breast
the
inability
to
contend
with
its
deep
emotions
,
and
spoke
out
bravely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Your
hopes
do
not
soar
above
that
!
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Yes
they
do
.
 
<EOS>
How
can
you
talk
so
!
 
<EOS>
They
soar
up
to
the
time
when
you
will
be
happy
with
her
,
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
They
soar
up
to
the
time
when
you
will
be
able
to
claim
her
,
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
They
soar
up
to
the
time
when
you
will
not
be
able
to
believe
that
you
were
ever
cast
down
in
spirit
,
or
poor
in
pocket
,
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
Advice
,
and
friendly
counsel
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
of
course
.
 
<EOS>
But
you
shall
have
better
advice
and
counsel
(
though
you
can
not
have
more
friendly
)
than
mine
.
 
<EOS>
You
shall
consult
John
Westlock
.
 
<EOS>
We
'll
go
there
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
yet
so
early
that
I
shall
have
time
to
take
you
to
his
chambers
before
I
go
to
business
;
they
are
in
my
way
;
and
I
can
leave
you
there
,
to
talk
over
your
affairs
with
him
.
<EOS>
So
come
along
.
 
<EOS>
Come
along
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
a
man
of
occupation
now
,
you
know
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
his
pleasantest
smile
;
"
and
have
no
time
to
lose
.
 
<EOS>
Your
hopes
do
n't
soar
higher
than
that
?
 
<EOS>
I
dare
say
they
do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
know
you
,
pretty
well
.
 
<EOS>
They
'll
be
soaring
out
of
sight
soon
,
Martin
,
and
leaving
all
the
rest
of
us
leagues
behind
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
may
be
a
little
changed
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
since
you
knew
me
pretty

,
Tom
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
nonsense
!
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
be
changed
?
 
<EOS>
You
talk
as
if
you
were
an
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
never

such

fellow
!
 
<EOS>
Come
to
John
Westlock
's
,

.
 
<EOS>
Come
along
,
Mark
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
Mark
's
doing
<EOS>
,
I
have
no
doubt
;
and
it
serves
you
right
for
having
such
a
grumbler
for
your

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
credit
to
be
got
through
being
jolly
with
YOU
,
Mr
Pinch
,
anyways
,
"
said
Mark
,
with
his
face
all
wrinkled
up
with

.
 
<EOS>
"
A
parish
doctor
might
be
jolly
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
short
of
goin'
to
the
U
-
nited
States
for
a
second
trip
,
as
would
make
it
at
all
creditable
to
be
jolly
,
arter
seein
'
you
again
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
laughed
,
and
taking
leave
of
his
sister
,
hurried
Mark
and
Martin
out
into
the
street
,
and
away
to
John
Westlock
's
by
the
nearest
road
;
for
his
hour
of
business
was
very
near
at
hand
,
and
he
prided
himself
on
always
being
exact
to
his
time
.
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
was
at
home
,
but
,
strange
to
say
,
was
rather
embarrassed
to
see
them
;
and
when
Tom
was
about
to
go
into
the
room
where
he
was
breakfasting
,
said
he
had
a
stranger
there
.
 
<EOS>
It
appeared
to
be
a
mysterious
stranger
,
for
John
shut
that
door
as
he
said
it
,
and
led
them
into
the
next
room
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
very
much
delighted
,
though
,
to
see
Mark
Tapley
;
and
received
Martin
with
his
own
frank
courtesy
.
 
<EOS>
But
Martin
felt
that
he
did
not
inspire
John
Westlock
with
any
unusual
interest
;
and
twice
or
thrice
observed
that
he
looked
at
Tom
Pinch
doubtfully
;
not
to
say
compassionately
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
,
and
blushed
to
think
,
that
he
knew
the
cause
of
this
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
apprehend
you
are
engaged
,
"
said
Martin
,
when
Tom
had
announced
the
purport
of
their
visit
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
allow
me
to
come
again
at
your
own
time
,
I
shall
be
glad
to
do
so
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
AM
engaged
,
"
replied
John
,
with
some
reluctance
;
"
but
the
matter
on
which
I
am
engaged
is
one
,
to
say
the
truth
,
more
immediately
demanding
your
knowledge
than
mine
.
"
   
"
Indeed
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
relates
to
a
member
of
your
family
,
and
is
of
a
serious

.
<EOS>
If
you
will
have
the

to
remain
here
,
it
will

to
have
it
privately

,
in

you
may
judge
of
its

for

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

,
"
said

,
"
I
must
really
take

,
without

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is
your
business
so
very

,
"
asked
Martin
,
"
that
you
can
not
remain
with
us
for
half
an

?
 
<EOS>
I
wish
you
could
.
 
<EOS>
What
IS
your
business
,
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
Tom
's
turn
to
be
embarrassed
now
;
but
he
plainly

,
after

:
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
am
not
at

to
say
what
it

,
Martin
;
though
I
hope
soon
to

to

,

am

no

to

,

the

.
 
<EOS>
It
's

,
"

,
with

of

,
"
as
I

every

;
but
I

,

,
John
?
"
   
<EOS>
John
Westlock
replied
in
the
negative
;
and
Martin
,
expressing
himself
perfectly
satisfied
,
begged
them
not
to
say
another

;
though
he
could
not
help
wondering
very
much
what
curious
office
Tom
held
,
and

was
so
secret
,
and

,
and
unlike

,
in
reference
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Nor

he
help
reverting
to
it
,
in
his
own
mind
,
<EOS>
several
times
after
Tom
went
away
,
which
he
did
as

this
conversation
was
ended
,
taking
Mr
Tapley
with

,
who
,
as

,
might

as

as

without

.
   
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you

,
Mark
?
"
<EOS>

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Mean

,

?
<EOS>
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
.
 
<EOS>
What
course
of

do

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
The

,

a
-

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
 
<EOS>
I
've

a
-

'

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
And

,

?

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
The

.
 
<EOS>
Come
!
 
<EOS>
You

,
"

,

"

I

!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
suppressed
his
own

to

;
and
with

,

"
<EOS>
You

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
How

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
Except
Mrs
Lupin
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

!
"
retorted
Mr
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
supposing
it
was
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
stopping
in

to
look

,
Mr

for

to
his

utterly

;
a

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
and

all
up
as
for

,

:
   
"
Supposin
'
,

,

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
I

n't

,
Mark
,
on
any
terms
!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

!
 
<EOS>
I
used
to

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
But
I
ai

so

.
 
<EOS>
A

,

creetur
,

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
A

,

?
 
<EOS>
To

,
"

Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
But

always
was
a
dear
,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
WAS

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Then
why
on

did

,
Mark
,
instead

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"
retorted

Tapley
,
in
a
spirit
of
unbounded
confidence
<EOS>
,
"
I
'll
tell
you
how
it
come

.
 
<EOS>
You
know
me
,
Mr
Pinch
,
sir
;
there
ai
n't
a
gentleman
alive
as
knows
me
better
.
 
<EOS>
You
're
acquainted
with
my
constitution
,
and
you
're
acquainted
with
my
weakness
.
 
<EOS>
My
constitution
is
,
to
be
jolly
;
and
my
weakness
is
,
to
wish
to
find
a
credit
in
it
.
 
<EOS>
Wery
good
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
state
of
mind
,
I
gets
a
notion
in
my
head
that
she
looks
on
me
with
a
eye
of
---
with
what
you
may
call
a
favourable
sort
of
a
eye
in
fact
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
with
modest
hesitation
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
doubt
,
"
replied
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
We
knew
that
perfectly
well
when
we
spoke
on
this
subject
long
ago
;
before
you
left
the
Dragon
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
nodded
assent
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
But
bein
'
at
that
time
full
of
hopeful
wisions
,
I
arrives
at
the
conclusion
that
no
credit
is
to
be
got
out
of
such
a
way
of
life
as
that
,
where
everything
agreeable
would
be
ready
to
one
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Lookin
'
on
the
bright
side
of
human
life
in
short
,
one
of
my
hopeful
wisions
is
,
that
there
's
a
deal
of
misery
awaitin
'
for
me
;
in
the
midst
of
which
I
may
come
out
tolerable
strong
,
and
be
jolly
under
circumstances
as
reflects
some
credit
.
 
<EOS>
I
goes
into
the
world
,
sir
,
wery
boyant
,
and
I
tries
this
.
<EOS>
I
goes
aboard
ship
first
,
and
wery
soon
discovers
(
by
the
ease
with
which
I
'm
jolly
,
mind
you
)
as
there
's
no
credit
to
be
got
THERE
.
 
<EOS>
I
might
have
took
warning

this
,
and

;

.
 
<EOS>
I
gets

;
and

I
DO
begin

,

wo

,

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
Jest

-

,

-

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Deceives

!
"
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
Swindles

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Turns

as

<EOS>
In

.
 
<EOS>
Wery

.
 
<EOS>
Then

;
and
findin

ai

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>
Good

,
Mr
Pinch
!
"
<EOS>
he

.
 
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Although

ARE

.
 
<EOS>
You
little

,

.
 
<EOS>
Pecksniff

,
but
your

pulled

down
.
 
<EOS>
Good
-

,
Mr
Pinch
!
"
   
<EOS>
While

confidences
were
interchanged
between
Tom
Pinch

Mark
,

John
Westlock
were
very

.
 
<EOS>
They
were
no

together
than

said
,
with

:
   
"
<EOS>
Mr

,

,
but
you
have

Tom
a

,

to

.
 
<EOS>
I
can

with

on

of
what
oppresses

just

.
 
<EOS>
I

you
so
far

that

Tom
's

of

,

,

.

"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

But

?
"

.
   
<EOS>

You

,
"

"
that

,
not
in

but

mere

of
character
,
did
not

and

.
 
<EOS>
It

slight

Tom
Pinch
.
"
   
<EOS>
This
was
not

,

was
energetically

;
for

no

(
but

)

.
   
<EOS>
"

Tom
,
"

,
"

;
and
I

to

as
something
,

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

,
like

,
very

---
and

,

dare

.
 
<EOS>
But

,
and

;
for
I
was
not
upon

,

.
 
<EOS>
You

,
"

,

,
"
that
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

,
in

,
that

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
Why

"
---
<EOS>

"

;

"
   
<EOS>

in

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

,
"

I

in

,
recollect

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
With

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

"
   
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
He

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

.
<EOS>
He

,

's

.
 
<EOS>
His

;
and

,

,

<EOS>
"
This

,
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

,
Mr

,
"

---

,

---
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>
I

Inn
,
that

.
 
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

(

)
,

,
understanding

,

,
in

,

;

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

;

.
 
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

;
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

John
.
<EOS>
"
But

.
"
   
<EOS>
As

,

to

's

.
<EOS>
It
was

fixed

man
before

,
who
,

said
,

:
   
<EOS>
"
What
relation

Mr
Anthony
Chuzzlewit
,

---
"
   
"
---
Who
died
---
to

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
was
my

's

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear

was
made
away
with
.
 
<EOS>
Murdered
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
My
God
!
"
said

.
 
<EOS>
"
By

?
"
   
The

,

,

,
and

,

:
   
"
<EOS>
I
fear
,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By

?
"
cried
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
by
my
act
,
but
I
fear

my
