.
"
   
"
Speak
out
!
"
<EOS>
said
Martin
,
"
and
speak
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
fear
this
IS
the
truth
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
about
to
interrupt
him
again
,
but
John
Westlock
saying
softly
,
"
Let
him
tell
his
story
in
his
own
way
,
"
Lewsome
went
on
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
bred
a
surgeon
,
and
for
the
last
few
years
have
served
a
general
practitioner
in
the
City
,

his

.
 
<EOS>
While
I

in

I
became

Jonas
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
the
principal
in
this
deed
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
demanded

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
he
is
the
son
of
the
old
man
of
whom
you
have
spoken
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
"
he
answered
.
   
<EOS>
He
remained
silent
for
some
moments
,
when
he
resumed
at
the
point
where
he
had
left
off
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
reason
to
know
it
;
for
I
have
often

wish
his
old
father
dead
,
and
complain
of
his
being
wearisome
to
him
,
and
a
drag
upon

.
 
<EOS>
He
was
in
the

of
doing
so
,
at
a
place
of
meeting
we
had
---
three
or
four
of
us
---
at
night
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
good
in
the
place
you
may
suppose
,
when
you
hear
that
he
was
the
chief
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
died
myself
,
and
never
seen
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
again
;
and
again
resumed
as
before
.
   
<EOS>
"
We
met
to
drink
and
game
;
not
for
large
sums
,
but
for
sums
that
were
large
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
He
generally
won
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
or
no
,
he
lent
money
at
interest
to
those
who
lost
;
and
in
this
way
,
though
I
think
we
all
secretly
hated
him
,
he
came
to
be
the
master
of
us
.
 
<EOS>
To
propitiate
him
we
made
a
jest
of
his
father
;
it
began
with
his
debtors
;
I
was
one
;
and
we
used
to
toast
a
quicker
journey
to
the
old
man
,
and
a
swift
inheritance
to
the
young
one
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
paused
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
One
night
he
came
there
in
a
very
bad
humour
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
greatly
tried
,
he
said
,
by
the
old
man
that
day
.
 
<EOS>
He
and
I
were
alone
together
;
and
he
angrily
told
me
,
that
the
old
man
was
in
his
second
childhood
;
that
he
was
weak
,
imbecile
,
and
drivelling
;
as
unbearable
to
himself
as
he
was
to
other
people
;
and
that
it
would
be
a
charity
to
put
him
out
of
the
way
.
 
<EOS>
He
swore
that
he
had
often
thought
of
mixing
something
with
the
stuff
he
took
for
his
cough
,
which
should
help
him
to
die
easily
.
 
<EOS>
People
were
sometimes
smothered
who
were
bitten
by
mad
dogs
,
he
said
;
and
why
not
help
these
lingering
old
men
out
of
their
troubles
too
?
 
<EOS>
He
looked
full
at
me
as
he
said
so
,
and
I
looked
full
at
him
;
but
it
went
no
farther
that
night
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
once
more
,
and
was
silent
for
so
long
an
interval
that
John
Westlock
said
"
Go
on
.
"
 
<EOS>
Martin
had
never
removed
his
eyes
from
his
face
,
but
was
so
absorbed
in
horror
and
astonishment
that
he
could
not
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
may
have
been
a
week
after
that
,
or
it
may
have
been
less
or
more
---
the
matter
was
in
my
mind
all
the
time
,
but
I
can
not
recollect
the
time
,
as
I
should
any
other
period
---
when
he
spoke
to
me
again
.
<EOS>
We
were
alone
then
,
too
;
being
there
before
the
usual
hour
of
assembling
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
appointment
between
us
;
but
I
think
I
went
there
to
meet
him
,
and
I
know
he
came
there
to
meet
me
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
there
first
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
reading
a
newspaper
when
I
went
in
,
and
nodded
to
me
without
looking
up
,
or
leaving
off
reading
.
 
<EOS>
I
sat
down
opposite
and
close
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
,
immediately
,
that
he
wanted
me
to
get
him
some
of
two
sorts
of
drugs
.
 
<EOS>
One
that
was
instantaneous
in
its
effect
;
of
which
he
wanted
very
little
.
 
<EOS>
One
that
was
slow
and
not
suspicious
in
appearance
;
of
which
he
wanted
more
.
 
<EOS>
While
he
was
speaking
to
me
he
still
read
the
newspaper
.
 
<EOS>
He
said
"
Drugs
,
"
and
never
used
any
other
word
.
 
<EOS>
Neither
did
I.
"
   
<EOS>
"
This
all
agrees
with
what
I
have
heard
before
,
"
observed
John
Westlock
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
asked
him
what
he
wanted
the
drugs
for
?
 
<EOS>
He
said
for
no
harm
;
to
physic
cats
;
what
did
it
matter
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
I
was
going
out
to
a
distant
colony
<EOS>
(
I
had
recently
got
the
appointment
,
which
,
as
Mr
Westlock
knows
,
I
have
since
lost
by
my
sickness
,
and
which
was
my
only
hope
of
salvation
from
ruin
)
,
and
what
did
it
matter
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
He
could
get
them
without
my
aid
at
half
a
hundred
places
,
but
not
so
easily
as
he
could
get
them
of
me
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
true
.
 
<EOS>
He
might
not
want
them
at
all
,
he
said
,
and
he
had
no
present
idea
of
using
them
;
but
he
wished
to
have
them
by
him
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
he
still
read
the
newspaper
.
 
<EOS>
We
talked
about
the
price
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
to
forgive
me
a
small
debt
<EOS>
---
I
was
quite
in
his
power
---
and
to
pay
me
five
pounds
;
and
there
the
matter
dropped
,
through
others
coming
in
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
next
night
,
under
exactly
similar

,
I
gave
him
the
drugs
,
on
his
saying
<EOS>
I
was
a

to
think
that
he
should
ever

them
for
any

;
and
he
gave

.
 
<EOS>
We
have
never
met
since
.
 
<EOS>
I
only
know
that
the
poor
old
father
died
soon
afterwards
,
just
as
he
would
have
died
from
this

;
and
that
I
have
undergone
,
and
suffer
now
,
intolerable
misery
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
<EOS>
"
he
added
,
stretching
out

hands
,
"
can
paint
my
misery
!
 
<EOS>
It
is
well
deserved
,
but
nothing
can
paint
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
he
hung
his
head
,
and
said
no
more
,
wasted
and
wretched
,
he
was
not
a
creature
upon
whom
to
heap
reproaches
that
were
unavailing
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
him
remain
at
hand
,
"
said
Martin
,
turning
from

;
"
but
out
of
sight
,
in
Heaven
's
name
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
will
remain
here
,
"
John

.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
with
me
!
"
 
<EOS>
Softly
turning
the
key
upon
him
as
they
went
out
,
he
conducted
Martin
into
the
adjoining
room
,
in
which
they
had
been
before
.
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
so

,
so

,
and
confounded
by
what
he
had
heard
that
it
was
some

before

could

to
any

in

,
or
could

the

one

upon
another
,
to
take

all

one

.
 
<EOS>
When
he
,
at
length
,
had
the
whole
narrative
clearly
before
him
,
John
Westlock
went
on
to
point
out
the
great
probability
of
the
guilt
of
Jonas
being
known
to
other
people
,
who
traded
in
it
for
their
own

,
and
who
were
,
by

,
able
to
exert
that
control
over
him
which
Tom
Pinch
had
accidentally
witnessed
,
and
unconsciously
assisted
.
 
<EOS>
This
appeared
so
plain
,
that
they
agreed
upon
it
without

;
but
instead
of
deriving
the
least
assistance
from
this
source
,
they
found
that
it
embarrassed
them
the
more
.
   
<EOS>
They
knew
nothing
of
the
real
parties
who
possessed
this
power
.
 
<EOS>
The
only
person
before
them
was
Tom
's

.
 
<EOS>
They
had
no
right
to
question
Tom
's
landlord
,
even
if
they
could
find
him
,
which
,
according

Tom
's

,
it
would
not

.
 
<EOS>
And
granting
that
they
did
question
him
,
and
he

(
which
was
taking
a
good
deal
for

)
,
he
had
only
to

,
with

the

,
that
he

from
such

such

to

Jonas
back
on

,
and
there

an
end
of

.
   
<EOS>
Besides
,
there
was
the
great

and

of
moving
at
all
in
the
matter
.
 
<EOS>
Lewsome
's
story
might
be
false
;
in
his
wretched
state
it
might
be
greatly
heightened
by
a

;
or

to

,
the
old
man
might
have
died
a

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
been
there
at
the
time
;
as
Tom
immediately

,
when
he
came
back
in
the

,
and
shared
their

;
and
there
had

no

about

.
<EOS>
Martin
's
grandfather
was
of
right
the
person
to

that
should

;
but

at
his
views
would

,

's

.
<EOS>
And

Pecksniff
's

-
in

.
   
<EOS>
Apart

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
On

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
In

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
And

Mr
Tapley
was

;

,

,

;
still
"

Mr

's

.
   
<EOS>
It

's

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
For

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The

,

?
 
<EOS>
Tom
said
his

clearly
.
 
<EOS>
But
Tom

,

.
 
<EOS>
Was

?
 
<EOS>
Why

.
<EOS>
In

,
Tom

,
he

Mrs
Gamp
,

;

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
Here

a

out
,
developed

.
 
<EOS>
John
Westlock
knew
Mrs

;

;

:

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It

Mrs

,

;

's

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
On

,
Martin

to

that

;

,
at

;

of

,
or

,

,

.
<EOS>
Tom

home
,
that
he
might

of

Nadgett
,
by

.
 
<EOS>
And
Mr
Tapley
remained
(
by

)
for
the
time

in
Furnival
's

,
to
look

Lewsome
;
who
might

been
left
to

,
however
,
for
any

he
seemed
to
entertain
of
giving

.
   
<EOS>
Before
they
parted
on
their
several

,
they
caused
him
to
read

,
in
the
presence
of
them
all
,
the
paper
which
he
had
about

,
and
the
declaration
he
had
attached
to

,
which
was
to

that
he
had
written

voluntarily
,
in
the
fear
of
death
and

of
his

.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
had
done

,
they
all
signed

,
and
taking
it
from
him
,
of
his
free

,
locked

in
a
place
of

.
   
<EOS>
Martin
also
wrote
,
by
John
's

,
a

to
the
trustees
of
the
famous
Grammar
School
,
boldly
claiming
the
successful
design
as
his
,
and
charging
Mr
Pecksniff
with
the

he
had
committed
.
 
<EOS>
In
this
proceeding
also
,
John
was
hotly
interested
;
observing
,
with
his
usual

,
that
Mr
Pecksniff
had
been
a
successful
rascal
all
his
life
through
,
and
that
it
would
be
a
lasting
source
of
happiness
to
him
(
John
)
if
he
could
help
to
do
him
justice
in
the
smallest
particular
.
   
<EOS>
A
busy
day
!
 
<EOS>
But
Martin
had
no
lodgings
yet
;
so
when
these
matters
were
disposed
of
,
he
excused
himself
from
dining
with
John
Westlock
and
was
fain
to
wander
out
alone
,
and
look
for
some
.
 
<EOS>
He
succeeded
,
after
great
trouble
,
in
engaging
two
garrets
for
himself
and
Mark
,
situated
in
a
court
in
the
Strand
,
not
far
from
Temple
Bar
.
 
<EOS>
Their
luggage
,
which
was
waiting
for
them
at
a
coach
-
office
<EOS>
,
he
conveyed
to
this
new
place
of
refuge
;
and
it
was
with
a
glow
of
satisfaction
,
which
as
a
selfish
man
he
never
could
have
known
and
never
had
,
that
,
thinking
how
much
pains
and
trouble
he
had
saved
Mark
,
and
how
pleased
and
astonished
Mark
would
be
,
he
afterwards
walked
up
and
down
,
in
the
Temple
,
eating
a
meat
-
pie
for
his
dinner
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
49
.
<EOS>
In
which
Mrs
Harris
assisted
by
a
teapot
,
is
the
cause
of
a
division
between
friends
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
's
apartment
in
Kingsgate
Street
,
High
Holborn
,
wore
,
metaphorically
speaking
,
a
robe
of
state
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
swept
and
garnished
for
the
reception
of
a
visitor
.
 
<EOS>
That
visitor
was
Betsey
Prig
;
Mrs
Prig
,
of
Bartlemy
's
;
or
as
some
said
Barklemy
's
,
or
as
some
said
Bardlemy
's
;
for
by
all
these
endearing
and
familiar
appellations
,
had
the
hospital
of
Saint
Bartholomew
become
a
household
word
among
the
sisterhood
which
Betsey
Prig
adorned
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
's
apartment
was
not
a
spacious
one
,
but
,
to
a
contented
mind
,
a
closet
is
a
palace
;
and
the
first
-
floor
front
at
Mr
Sweedlepipe
's
may
have
been
,
in
the
imagination
of
Mrs
Gamp
,
a
stately
pile
.
 
<EOS>
If
it
were
not
exactly
that
,
to
restless
intellects
,
it
at
least
comprised
as
much
accommodation
as
any
person
,
not
sanguine
to
insanity
,
could
have
looked
for
in
a
room
of
its
dimensions
.
 
<EOS>
For
only
keep
the
bedstead
always
in
your
mind
;
and
you
were
safe
.
 
<EOS>
That
was
the
grand
secret
.
 
<EOS>
Remembering
the
bedstead
,
you
might
even
stoop
to
look
under
the
little
round
table
for
anything
you
had
dropped
,
without
hurting
yourself
much
against
the
chest
of
drawers
,
or
qualifying
as
a
patient
of
Saint
Bartholomew
,
by
falling
into
the
fire
.
   
<EOS>
Visitors
were
much
assisted
in
their
cautious
efforts
to
preserve
an
unflagging
recollection
of
this
piece
of
furniture
,
by
its
size
;
which
was
great
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
turn
-
up
bedstead
,
nor
yet
a
French
bedstead
,
nor
yet
a
four
-
post
bedstead
,
but
what
is
poetically
called
a
tent
;
the
sacking
whereof
was
low
and
bulgy
,
<EOS>
insomuch
that
Mrs
Gamp
's
box
would
not
go
under
it
,
but
stopped
half
-
way
,
in
a
manner
which
,
while
it
did
violence
to
the
reason
,
likewise
endangered
the
legs
of
a
stranger
.
 
<EOS>
The
frame
too
,
which
would
have
supported
the
canopy
and
hangings
if
there
had
been
any
,
was
ornamented
with
divers
pippins
carved
in
timber
,
which
on
the
slightest
provocation
,
and
frequently
on
none
at
all
,
came
tumbling
down
;
harassing
the
peaceful
guest
with
inexplicable
terrors
.
   
<EOS>
The
bed
itself
was
decorated
with
a
patchwork
quilt
of
great
antiquity
;
and
at
the
upper
end
,
upon
the
side
nearest
to
the
door
,
hung
a
scanty
curtain
of
blue
check
,
which
prevented
the
Zephyrs
that
were
abroad
in
Kingsgate
Street
,
from
visiting
Mrs
Gamp
's
head
too
roughly
.
 
<EOS>
Some
rusty
gowns
and
other
articles
of
that
lady
's
wardrobe
depended
from
the
posts
;
and
these
had
so
adapted
themselves
by
long
usage
to
her
figure
,
that
more
than
one
impatient
husband
coming
in
precipitately
,
at
about
the
time
of
twilight
,
had
been
for
an
instant
stricken
dumb
by
the
supposed
discovery
that
Mrs
Gamp
had
hanged
herself
.
 
<EOS>
One
gentleman
,
coming
on
the
usual
hasty
errand
,
had
said
indeed
,
that
they
looked
like
guardian
angels
"
watching
of
her
in
her
sleep
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
that
,
as
Mrs
Gamp
said
,
"
was
his
first
;
"
and
he
never
repeated
the
sentiment
,
though
he
often
repeated
his
visit
.
   
<EOS>
The
chairs
in
Mrs
Gamp
's
apartment
were
extremely
large
and
broad
-
backed
,
which
was
more
than
a
sufficient
reason
for
there
being
but
two
in
number
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
both
elbow
-
chairs
,
of
ancient
mahogany
;
and
were
chiefly
valuable
for
the
slippery
nature
of
their
seats
,
which
had
been
originally
horsehair
,
but
were
now
covered
with
a
shiny
substance
of
a
bluish
tint
,
from
which
the
visitor
began
to
slide
away
with
a
dismayed
countenance
,
immediately
after
sitting
down
.
 
<EOS>
What
Mrs
Gamp
wanted
in
chairs
she
made
up
in
bandboxes
;
<EOS>
of
which
she
had
a
great
collection
,
devoted
to
the
reception
of
various
miscellaneous
valuables
,
which
were
not
,
however
,
as
well
protected
as
the
good
woman
,
by
a
pleasant
fiction
,
seemed
to
think
;
for
,
though
every
bandbox
had
a
carefully
closed
lid
,
not
one
among
them
had
a
bottom
;
owing
to
which
cause
the
property
within
was
merely
,
as
it
were
,
extinguished
.
 
<EOS>
The
chest
of
drawers
having
been
originally
made
to
stand
upon
the
top
of
another
chest
,
had
a
dwarfish
,
elfin
look
,
alone
;
but
in
regard
of
its
security
it
had
a
great
advantage
over
the
bandboxes
,
for
as
all
the
handles
had
been
long
ago
pulled
off
,
it
was
very
difficult
to
get
at
its
contents
.
<EOS>
This
indeed
was
only
to
be
done
by
one
or
two
devices
;
either
by
tilting
the
whole
structure
forward
until
all
the
drawers
fell
out
together
,
or
by
opening
them
singly
with
knives
,
like
oysters
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
stored
all
her
household
matters
in
a
little
cupboard
by
the
fire
-
place
;
beginning
below
the
surface
(
as
in
nature
)
with
the
coals
,
and
mounting
gradually
upwards
to
the
spirits
,
which
,
from
motives
of
delicacy
,
she
kept
in
a

.
 
<EOS>
The
chimney
-
piece
was

with
a
small

,
marked
here
and
there
in
Mrs
Gamp
's
own
hand
with
a

of
the
date
at

fall

.
 
<EOS>
It
was

:
one
,

,
of
Mrs
Gamp

;

,

,

Mrs
Harris
,

;
and

,
of
Mr

,
deceased
.
<EOS>
The
last
was
a
full

,
in
order
that
the
likeness
might
be
rendered
more
obvious

by
the
introduction
of
the

.
   
<EOS>
A

,

as

,

,

.
<EOS>
Towards

Mrs

,

,

.

"
There
!
 
<EOS>

,

,

!

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Not

.
 
<EOS>
That

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

's

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
I
says
,
"
I
will
not
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
reckon
on

.
 
<EOS>
There
is
,
"
I

,
but
one
creetur

the
world
as
I

on
sech
terms
,

her

Harris
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
"
I

,
"

,

Betsey
Prig
,
that

,

.
 
<EOS>
Betsey
,
"
I

,
"

,
and
will

I

.
"
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Here

Prig
,
without

her
offensive

again

abstraction
of
mind
,
and
stretched
out

teapot
.
 
<EOS>
It

more

Mrs
Gamp

.
 
<EOS>
She
stopped
the

Mrs
Prig
with

,
and

,

:
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Betsey
!
 
<EOS>
Drink
fair
,
wotever

do
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs

,
thus

,
and

the
same
eye

,
and

,

while

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs

:
   
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Harris
,
Betsey
---
"
   
"
<EOS>
Bother
Mrs
Harris
!
"

Betsey
Prig
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp

,

,

;
when
Mrs
Prig
,

,

,

these

:
   
"
I
do
n't
believe
there
's
no
sich
a
person
!
"
   
<EOS>
After
the

of

,

,

,

;

nearer
to
the
face
of
Mrs
Gamp
,

,

,

<EOS>

Prig
had
challenged
---
as

seemed

.
   
<EOS>

I

,
"

,
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Which

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Mr

apinted

<EOS>
"
From

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Do

"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
   
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
But
I

a
-
keepin
'
of

.
"
   
<EOS>
Mingling

;

,
and

with

proceeded

.
   
<EOS>
This

,

,

,

in

.
 
<EOS>
When

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
'

know

,
"

"

'm

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
But

.
   
<EOS>
The

;

,
   
<EOS>
"

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
Mrs

murmur
"
Mrs
Harris
"
in

.
   
<EOS>
"
Rely

,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>
We

,

;

,

<EOS>
Let

;

.
<EOS>
We
shall

.
"
    
<EOS>
Chapter
50
.
<EOS>
Surprises
Tom
Pinch
very
much
,
and
shows
how
certain
confidences
passed
between
him
and
his
sister
 
<EOS>
It
was
the
next
evening
;
and
Tom
and
his
sister
were
sitting
together
before
tea
,
talking
,
in
their
usual
quiet
way
,
about
a
great
many
things
,
but
not
at
all
about
Lewsome
's
story
or
anything
connected
with
it
;
for
John
Westlock
---
really
John
,
for
so
young
a

,
was
one
of
the
most
considerate
fellows
in
the
world
---
had
particularly

Tom
not
to
mention

to
his
sister
just
yet
,
in
case
it
should
disquiet

.
 
<EOS>
"
And
I
would
n't
,
Tom
,
"
he
said
,
with
a
little

,
"
I
would
n't
have
a
shadow
on
her
happy
face
,
or
an
uneasy
thought
in
her
gentle

,
for
all
the
wealth
and
honours
of
the
universe
!
"
 
<EOS>
Really
John
was
uncommonly
kind
;
extraordinarily
kind
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
her
father
,
Tom
said
,
he
could
not
have
taken
a
greater

in
her
.
   
<EOS>
But
although
Tom
and
his
sister
were
extremely

,
they
were
less
lively
,
and
less
cheerful
,
than
usual
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
had
no
idea
that
this
originated
with
Ruth
,
but
took
it
for
granted
that
he
was
rather
dull
himself
.
 
<EOS>
In
truth
he
was
;
for
the
lightest
cloud
upon
the
Heaven
of
her
quiet
mind
,
cast
its
shadow
upon
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
cloud
on
little
Ruth
that
evening
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
When
Tom
was
looking
in
another
direction
,
her
bright
eyes
,
stealing
on
towards
his
face
,
would
sparkle
still
more
brightly
than
their
custom
was
,
and
then
grow
dim
.
 
<EOS>
When
Tom
was
silent
,
looking
out
upon
the
summer
weather
,
she
would
sometimes
make
a
hasty
movement
,
as
if
she
were
about
to
throw
herself
upon
his
neck
;
then
check
the
impulse
,
and
when
he
looked
round
,
show
a
laughing
face
,
and
speak
to
him
very
merrily
;
when
she
had
anything
to
give
Tom
,
or
had
any

for
coming
near
him
,
she
would
flutter
about
him
,
and
lay
her
bashful
hand
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
not
be
willing
to
withdraw
it
;
and
would
show
by
all
such
means
that
there
was
something
on
her
heart
which
in
her
great
love
she
longed
to
say
to
him
,
but
had
not
the
courage
to
utter
.
   
<EOS>
So
they
were
sitting
,
<EOS>
she
with
her
work
before
her
,
but
not
working
,
and
Tom
with
his

beside

,
but
not

,
when
Martin

at

.
 
<EOS>
Anticipating
who

,
Tom
went
to

;
and

Martin

.
 
<EOS>
Tom

,
for
in

cordial

<EOS>
Martin
had
hardly
spoken

.
   
<EOS>
Ruth
also

that

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Tom

,
and
made

.
   
<EOS>
Martin
did
not

down
but
walked

,

out
.
 
<EOS>
He
turned
round
after

,
but

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
What
has

,
Martin
?
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
My

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
To

feign

,

.

<EOS>
"
My

!
 
<EOS>
Martin
!
 
<EOS>
My
---
"
 
Tom

<EOS>
"
How

,
Tom
,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Was

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

,

,
into

!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
Tom
!
"
   
<EOS>
His

one

for

of
a

he

---

Tom
,

---
that

,

,

,

,

if

.
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,
"

I

I
thought
you
;

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I

---
<EOS>
little

I
know
<EOS>
I

---
that

,
Tom
,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
was

,
and

the

Truth
,
in

---
it

<EOS>
---
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>

Martin
,
"

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

,
Martin
.

I
AM

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

My

<EOS>
"

"

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

.
 
<EOS>
But

.
 
<EOS>

"
---

"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Why

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
You

<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
"
He

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

?
 
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>
cried
Martin
,
"
if
it
could
ever
come
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Amen
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
it
will
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
paused
,
and
then
said
in
a
still
milder
voice
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
chosen
for
yourself
,
Tom
,
and
will
be
relieved
by
our
parting
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
an
angry
one
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
anger
on
my
side
---
"
   
"
There
is
none
on
mine
,
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
---
It
is
merely
what
you
have
brought
about
,
and
worked
to
bring
about
.
 
<EOS>
I
say
again
,
you
have
chosen
for
yourself
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
made
the
choice
that
might
have
been
expected
in
most
people
situated
as
you
are
,
but
which
I
did
not
expect
in
you
.
 
<EOS>
For
that
,
perhaps
,
I
should
blame
my
own
judgment
more
than
you
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
wealth
and
favour
worth
having
,
on
one
side
;
and
there
is
the
worthless
friendship
of
an
abandoned
,
struggling
fellow
,
on
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
free
to
make
your
election
,
and
you
made
it
;
and
the
choice
was
not
difficult
.
 
<EOS>
But
those
who
have
not
the
courage
to
resist
such
temptations
,
should
have
the
courage
to
avow
what
they
have
yielded
to
them
;
and
I
DO
blame
you
for
this
,
Tom
:
that
you
received
me
with
a
show
of
warmth
,
encouraged
me
to
be
frank
and
plain
-
spoken
,
tempted
me
to
confide
in
you
,
and
professed
that
you
were
able
to
be
mine
;
when
you
had
sold
yourself
to
others
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
not
believe
,
"
said
Martin
,
with
emotion
<EOS>
---
"
hear
me
say
it
from
my
heart
---
I
CANNOT
believe
,
<EOS>
Tom
,
now
that
I
am
standing
face
to
face
with
you
,
that
it
would
have
been
in
your
nature
to
do
me
any
serious
harm
,
even
though
I
had
not
discovered
,
by
chance
,
in
whose
employment
you
were
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
should
have
encumbered
you
;
I
should
have
led
you
into
more
double
-
dealing
;
I
should
have
hazarded
your
retaining
the
favour
for
which
you
have
paid
so
high
a
price
,
bartering
away
your
former
self
;
and
it
is
best
for
both
of
us
that
I
have
found
out
what
you
so
much
desired
to
keep
secret
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Be
just
,
"
said
Tom
;
who
,
had
not
removed
his
mild
gaze
from
Martin
's
face
since
the
commencement
of
this
last
address
;
"
be
just
even
in
your
injustice
,
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
You
forget
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
not
yet
told
me
what
your
accusation
is
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
?
"
returned
Martin
,
waving
his
hand
,
and
moving
towards
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
could
not
know
it
the
better
for
my
dwelling
on
it
,
and
though
it
would
be
really
none
the
worse
,
it
might
seem
to
me
to
be
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Bygones
shall
be
bygones
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
take
leave
of
you
at
this
moment
,
and
in
this
place
---
in
which
you
are
so
amiable
and
so
good
---
as
heartily
,
if
not
as
cheerfully
,
as
ever
I
have
done
since
we
first

.
 
<EOS>
All
good
go
with
you
,
Tom
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
You
leave
me
so
?
 
<EOS>
You
can
leave
me
so
<EOS>
,
can
you
?
"
said
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
---
you
---
you
have
chosen
for
yourself
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I
hope
it
was
a
rash
choice
,
"
Martin
faltered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
it
was
!
 
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
he
was
gone
.
   
<EOS>
Tom
led
his
little
sister
to
her
chair
,
and
sat
down
in
his
own
.
 
<EOS>
He
took
his
book
,
and
read
,
or
seemed
to
read
.
 
<EOS>
Presently
he
said
aloud
,
turning
a
leaf
as
he
spoke
:
"
He
will
be
very
sorry
for
this
.
"
<EOS>
And
a
tear
stole
down
his
face
,
and
dropped
upon
the
page
.
   
<EOS>
Ruth
nestled
down
beside
him
on
her
knees
,
and
clasped
her
arms
about
his
neck
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
no
!
 
<EOS>
Be
comforted
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
Tom
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
---
comforted
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
set
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Such
a
cruel
,
bad
return
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Ruth
.
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
believes
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
imagine
why
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
will
be
set
right
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
More
closely
<EOS>
yet
,
she
nestled
down
about
him
;
and
wept
as
if
her
heart
would
break
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
,
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
hide
your
face
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
Then
in
a
burst
of
tears
,
it
all
broke
out
at
last
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
Tom
,
dear
Tom
,
I
know
your
secret
heart
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
found
it
out
;
you
could
n't
hide
the
truth
from
me
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
you
tell
me
?
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
could
have
made
you
happier
,
if
you
had
!
 
<EOS>
You
love
her
,
Tom
,
so
dearly
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
made
a
motion
with
his
hand
as
if
he
would
have
put
his
sister
hurriedly
away
;
but
it
clasped
upon
hers
,
and
all
his
little
history
was
written
in
the
action
.
 
<EOS>
All
its
pathetic
eloquence
was
in
the
silent
touch
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
spite
of
that
,
"
said
Ruth
,
"
you
have
been
so
faithful
and
so
good
,
dear
;
in
spite
of
that
,
you
have
been
so
true
and
self
-
denying
,
and
have
struggled
with
yourself
;
in
spite
of
that
,
you
have
been
so
gentle
,
and
so
kind
,
and
even
-
tempered
,
that
I
have
never
seen
you
give
a
hasty
look
,
or
heard
you
say
one
irritable
word
.
 
<EOS>
In
spite
of
all
,
you
have
been
so
cruelly
mistaken
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
Tom
,
dear
Tom
,
will
THIS
be
set
right
too
!
 
<EOS>
Will
it
,
Tom
?
 
<EOS>
Will
you
always
have
this
sorrow
in
your
breast
;
you
who
deserve
to
be
so
happy
;
or
is
there
any
hope
?
"
   
<EOS>
And
still
she
hid
her
face
from
Tom
,
and
clasped
him
round
the
neck
,
and
wept
for
him
,
and
poured
out
all
her
woman
's
heart
and
soul
in
the
relief
and
pain
of
this
disclosure
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
very
long
before
she
and
Tom
were
sitting
side
by
side
,
and
she
was
looking
with
an
earnest
quietness
in
Tom
's
face
.
 
<EOS>
Then
Tom
spoke
to
her
thus
,
cheerily
,
though
gravely
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
glad
,
my
dear
,
that
this
has
passed
between
us
.
 
<EOS>
Not
because
it
assures
me
of
your
tender
affection
(
for
I
was
well
assured
of
that
before
)
,
but
because
it
relieves
my
mind
of
a
great
weight
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
's
eyes
glistened
when
he
spoke
of
her
affection
;
and
he
kissed
her
on
the
cheek
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
girl
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
with
whatever
feeling
I
regard
her
"
---
they
seemed
to
avoid
the
name
by
mutual
consent
---
"
I
have
long
ago
---
I
am
sure
I
may
say
from
the
very
first
---
looked
upon
it
as
a
dream
.
 
<EOS>
As
something
that
might
possibly
have
happened
under
very
different
circumstances
,
but
which
can
never
be
.
 
<EOS>
Now
,
tell
me
.
 
<EOS>
What
would
you
have
set
right
?
"
   
<EOS>
She
gave
Tom
such
a
significant
little
look
,
that
he
was
obliged
to
take
it
for
an
answer
whether
he
would
or
no
;
and
to
go
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
By
her
own
choice
and
free
consent
,
my
love
,
she
is
betrothed
to
Martin
;
and
was
,
long
before
either
of
them
knew
of
my
existence
.
<EOS>
You
would
have
her
betrothed
to
me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
she
said
directly
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
rejoined
Tom
,
"
but
that
might
be
setting
it
wrong
,
instead
of
right
.
 
<EOS>
Do
you
think
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
a
grave

,
"
that
even
if
she
had
never
seen
him
,
it
is
very
likely
she
would
have
fallen
in
love
with
Me
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
not
,
dear
Tom
?
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
shook
his
head
,
and
smiled
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
think
of
me
,
Ruth
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
and
it
is
very
natural
that
you
should
,
as
if
I
were
a
character
in
a
book
;
and
you
make
it
a
sort
of
poetical
justice
that
I
should
,
by
some
impossible
means
or
other
,
come
,
at
last
,
to
marry
the
person
I
love
.
 
<EOS>
But
there
is
a
much
higher
justice
than
poetical
justice
,
my
dear
,
and
it
does
not
order
events
upon
the
same
principle
.
 
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
people
who
read
about
heroes
in
books
,
and
choose
to
make
heroes
of
themselves
out
of
books
,
consider
it
a
very
fine
thing
to
be
discontented
and
gloomy
,
and
misanthropical
,
and
perhaps
a
little
blasphemous
,
because
they
can
not
have
everything
ordered
for
their
individual
accommodation
.
 
<EOS>
Would
you
like
me
to
become
one
of
that
sort
of
people
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
No
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
But
still
I
know
,
"
she
added
timidly
,
"
that
this
is
a
sorrow
to
you
in
your
own
better
way
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
thought
of
disputing
the
position
.
 
<EOS>
But
it
would
have
been
mere
folly
,
and
he
gave
it
up
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
,
"
said
Tom
,
"
I
will
repay
your
affection
with
the
Truth
and
all
the
Truth
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
a
sorrow
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
proved
it
to
be
<EOS>
so
sometimes
,
though
I
have
always
striven
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
somebody
who
is
precious
to
you
may
die
,
and
you
may
dream
that
you
are
in
heaven
with
the
departed
spirit
,
and
you
may
find
it
a
sorrow
to
wake
to
the
life
on
earth
,
which
is
no
harder
to
be
borne
than
when
you
fell
asleep
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
sorrowful
to
me
to
contemplate
my
dream
which
I
always
knew
was
a
dream
,
even
when
it
first
presented
itself
;
but
the
realities
about
me
are
not
to
blame
.
 
<EOS>
They
are
the
same
as
they
were
.
 
<EOS>
My
sister
,
my
sweet
companion
,
who
makes
this
place
<EOS>
so
dear
,
is
she
less
devoted
to
me
,
Ruth
,
than
she
would
have
been
,
if
this
vision
had
never
troubled
me
?
 
<EOS>
My
old
friend
John
,
who
might
so
easily
have
treated
me
with
coldness
and
neglect
,
is
he
less
cordial
to
me
?
 
<EOS>
The
world
about
me
,
is
there
less
good
in
that
?
<EOS>
Are
my
words
to
be
harsh
and
my
looks
to
be
sour
,
and
is
my
heart
to
grow
cold
,
because
there
has
fallen
in
my
way
a
good
and
beautiful
creature
,
who
but
for
the
selfish
regret
that
I
can
not
call
her
my
own
,
would
,
like
all
other
good
and
beautiful
creatures
,
make
me
happier
and
better
!
 
<EOS>
No
,
my
dear
sister
.
 
<EOS>
No
,
"
said
Tom
stoutly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Remembering
all
my
means
of
happiness
,
I
hardly
dare
to
call
this
lurking
something
a
sorrow
;
but
whatever
name
it
may
justly
bear
,
I
thank
Heaven
that
it
renders
me
more
sensible
of
affection
and
attachment
,
and
softens
me
in
fifty
ways
.
 
<EOS>
Not
less
happy
.
 
<EOS>
Not
less
happy
,
Ruth
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
could
not
speak
to
him
,
but
she
loved
him
,
as
he
well
deserved
.
<EOS>
Even
as
he
deserved
,
she
loved
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
will
open
Martin
's
eyes
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
a
glow
of
pride
,
"
and
that
(
which
is
indeed
wrong
)
will
be
set
right
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
will
persuade
her
,
I
know
,
that
I
have
betrayed
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
set
right
through
her
,
and
he
will
be
very
sorry
for
it
.
 
<EOS>
Our
secret
,
Ruth
,
is
our
own
,
and
lives
and
dies
with
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
I
ever
could
have
told
it
you
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
a
smile
,
"
but
how
glad
I
am
to
think
you
have
found
it
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
They
had
never
taken
such
a
pleasant
walk
as
they
took
that
night
.
<EOS>
Tom
told
her
all
so
freely
and
so
simply
,
and
was
so
desirous
to
return
her
tenderness
with
his
fullest
confidence
,
that
they
prolonged
it
far
beyond
their
usual
hour
,
and
sat
up
late
when
they
came
home
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
they
parted
for
the
night
there
was
such
a
tranquil
,
beautiful
expression
in
Tom
's
face
,
that
she
could
not
bear
to
shut
it
out
,
but
going
back
on
tiptoe
to
his
chamber
-
door
,
looked
in
and
stood
there
till
he
saw
her
,
and
then
embracing
him
again
,
withdrew
.
 
<EOS>
And
in
her
prayers
and
in
her
sleep
---
good
times
to
be
remembered
with
such
fervour
,
Tom
!
---
his
name
was
uppermost
.
   
<EOS>
When
he
was
left
alone
,
Tom
pondered
very
much
on
this
discovery
of
hers
,
and
greatly
wondered
what
had
led
her
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
thought
Tom
,
"
I
have
been
so
very
careful
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
foolish
and
unnecessary
in
me
,
as
I
clearly
see
now
,
when
I
am
so
relieved
by
her
knowing
it
;
but
I
have
been
so
very
careful
to
conceal
it
from
her
.
 
<EOS>
Of
course
I
knew
that
she
was
intelligent
and
quick
,
and
for
that
reason
was
more
upon
my
guard
;
but
I
was
not
in
the
least
prepared
for
this
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
her
discovery
has
been
sudden
too
.
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
"
said
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
most
singular
instance
of
penetration
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
could
not
get
it
out
of
his
head
.
 
<EOS>
There
it
was
,
when
his
head
was
on
his
pillow
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
she
trembled
when
she
began
to
tell
me
she
knew
it
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Tom
,
recalling
all
the
little
incidents
and
circumstances
;
"
and
how
her
face
flushed
!
 
<EOS>
But
that
was
natural
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
quite
natural
!
 
<EOS>
That
needs
no
accounting
for
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
little
thought
how
natural
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
little
knew
that
there
was
that
in
Ruth
's
own
heart
,
but
newly
set
there
,
which
had
helped
her
to
the
reading
of
his
mystery
.
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
He
did
n't
understand
the
whispers
of
the
Temple
Fountain
,
though
he
passed
it
every
day
.
   
<EOS>
Who
so
lively
and
cheerful
as
busy
Ruth
next
morning
!
 
<EOS>
Her
early
tap
at
Tom
's
door
,
and
her
light
foot
outside
,
would
have
been
music
to
him
though
she
had
not
spoken
.
 
<EOS>
But
she
said
it
was
the
brightest
morning
ever
seen
;
and
so
it
was
;
<EOS>
and
if
it
had
been
otherwise
,
she
would
have
made
it
so
to
Tom
.
   
<EOS>
She
was
ready
with
his
neat
breakfast
when
he
went
downstairs
,
and
had
her
bonnet
ready
for
the
early
walk
,
and
was
so
full
of
news
,
that
Tom
was
lost
in
wonder
.
 
<EOS>
She
might
have
been
up
all
night
,
collecting
it
for
his
entertainment
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
Mr
Nadgett
not
come
home
yet
,
and
there
was
bread
down
a
penny
a
loaf
,
and
there
was
twice
as
much
strength
in
this
tea
as
in
the
last
,
and
the
milk
-
woman
's
husband
had
come
out
of
the
hospital
cured
,
and
the
curly
-
headed
child
over
the
way
had
been
lost
all
yesterday
,
and
she
was
going
to
make
all
sorts
of
preserves
in
a
desperate
hurry
,
and
there
happened
to
be
a
saucepan
in
the
house
which
was
the
very
saucepan
for
the
purpose
;
and
she
knew
all
about
the
last
book
Tom
had
brought
home
,
all
through
,
though
it
was
a
teaser
to
read
;
and
she
had
so
much
to
tell
him
that
she
had
finished
breakfast
first
.
 
<EOS>
Then
she
had
her
little
bonnet
on
,
and
the
tea
and
sugar
locked
up
,
and
the
keys
in
her
reticule
,
and
the
flower
,
as
usual
,
in
Tom
's
coat
,
and
was
in
all
respects
quite
ready
to
accompany
him
,
before
Tom
knew
she
had
begun
to
prepare
.
 
<EOS>
And
in
short
,
as
Tom
said
,
with
a
confidence
in
his
own
assertion
which
amounted
to
a
defiance
of
the
public
in
general
,
there
never
was
such
a
little
woman
.
   
<EOS>
She
made
Tom
talkative
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
to
resist
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
put
such
enticing
questions
to
him
;
about
books
,
and
about
dates
of
churches
,
and
about
organs
and
about
the
Temple
,
and
about
all
kinds
of
things
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
lightened
the
way
(
and
Tom
's
heart
with
it
)
to
that
degree
,
that
the
Temple
looked
quite
blank
and
solitary
when
he
parted
from
her
at
the
gate
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
Mr
Fips
's
friend
to
-
day
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
,
"
thought
Tom
,
as
he
ascended
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
Not
yet
,
at
any
rate
,
for
the
door
was
closed
as
usual
,
and
Tom
opened
it
with
his
key
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
got
the
books
into
perfect
order
now
,
and
had
mended
the
torn
leaves
,
and
had
pasted
up
the
broken
backs
,
and
substituted
neat
labels
for
the
worn
-
out
letterings
.
 
<EOS>
It
looked
a
different
place
,
it
was
so
orderly
and
neat
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
felt
some
pride
in
comtemplating
the
change
he
had
wrought
,
though
there
was
no
one
to
approve
or
disapprove
of
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
at
present
occupied
in
making
a
fair
copy
of
his
draught
of
the
catalogue
;
on
which
,
as
there
was
no
hurry
,
he
was
painfully
concentrating
all
the
ingenious
and
laborious
neatness
he
had
ever
expended
on
map
or
plan
in
Mr
Pecksniff
's
workroom
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
marvel
of
a
catalogue
;
for
Tom
sometimes
thought
he
was
really
getting
his
money
too
easily
,
and
he
had
determined
within
himself
that
this
document
should
take
a
little
of
his
superfluous
leisure
out
of
him
.
   
<EOS>
So
with
pens
and
ruler
,
and
compasses
and
india
-
rubber
,
and
pencil
,
and
black
ink
,
and
red
ink
,
Tom
worked
away
all
the
morning
.
 
<EOS>
He
thought
a
good
deal
about
Martin
,
and
their
interview
of
yesterday
,
and
would
have
been
far
easier
in
his
mind
if
he
could
have
resolved
to
confide
it
to
his
friend
John
,
and
to
have
taken
his
opinion
on
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
But
besides
that
he
knew
what
John
's
boiling
indignation
would
be
,
he
bethought
himself
that
he
was
helping
Martin
now
in
a
matter
of
great
moment
,
and
that
to
deprive
the
latter
of
his
assistance
at
such
a
crisis
of
affairs
,
would
be
to
inflict
a
serious
injury
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
'll
keep
it
to
myself
,
"
said
Tom
,
with
a
sigh
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
keep
it
to
myself
.
"
   
<EOS>
And
to
work
he
went
again
,
more
assiduously
than
ever
,
with
the
pens
,
and
the
ruler
,
and
the
india
-
rubber
,
and
the
pencils
,
and
the
red
ink
,
that
he
might
forget
it
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
laboured
away
another
hour
or
more
,
when
he
heard
a
footstep
in
the
entry
,
down
below
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Tom
,
looking
towards
the
door
;
"
time
was
,
not
long
ago
either
,
when
that
would
have
set
me
wondering
and
expecting
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
have
left
off
now
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
The
footstep
came
on
,
up
the
stairs
.
   
<EOS>
"
Thirty
-
six
,
thirty
-
seven
,
thirty
-
eight
,
"
said
Tom
,
counting
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
you
'll
stop
.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
ever
comes
past
the
thirty
-
eighth
stair
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
person
did
,
certainly
,
but
only
to
take
breath
;
for
up
the
footstep
came
again
.
 
<EOS>
Forty
,
forty
-
one
,
forty
-
two
,
and
so
on
.
   
<EOS>
The
door
stood
open
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
tread
advanced
,
Tom
looked
impatiently
and
eagerly
towards
it
.
 
<EOS>
When
a
figure
came
upon
the
landing
,
and
arriving
in
the
doorway
,
stopped
and
gazed
at
him
,
he
rose
up
from
his
chair
,
and
half
believed
he
saw
a
spirit
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
Chuzzlewit
!
 
<EOS>
The
same
whom
he
had
left
at
Mr
Pecksniff
's
,
weak
and
sinking
!
   
<EOS>
The
same
?
 
<EOS>
No
,
not
the
same
,
for
this
old
man
,
though
old
,
was
strong
,
and
leaned
upon
his
stick
with
a
vigorous
hand
,
while
with
the
other
he
signed
to
Tom
to
make
no
noise
.
 
<EOS>
One
glance
at
the
resolute
face
,
the
watchful
eye
,
the
vigorous
hand
upon
the
staff
,
the
triumphant
purpose
in
the
figure
,
and
such
a
light
broke
in
on
Tom
as
blinded
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
expected
me
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
a
long
time
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
told
that
my
employer
would
arrive
soon
,
"
said
Tom
;
"
<EOS>
but
---
"
   
"
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
ignorant
who
he
was
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
my
desire
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
glad
it
has
been
so
well
observed
.
 
<EOS>
I
intended
to
have
been
with
you
much
sooner
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
the
time
had
come
.
 
<EOS>
I
thought
I
could
know
no
more
,
and
no
worse
,
of
him
,
than
I
did
on
that
day
when
I
saw
you
last
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
was
wrong
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
by
this
time
come
up
to
Tom
,
and
now
he
grasped
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
lived
in
his
house
,
Pinch
,
and
had
him
fawning
on
me
days
and
weeks
and
months
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
suffered
him
to
treat
me
like
his
tool
and
instrument
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
;
you
have
seen
me
there
.
<EOS>
I
have
undergone
ten
thousand
times
as
much
as
I
could
have
endured
if
I
had
been
the
miserable
weak
old
man
he
took
me
for
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
offer
love
to
Mary
.
 
<EOS>
You
know
it
;
<EOS>
who
better
---
 
<EOS>
who
better
,
my
true
heart
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
had
his
base
soul
bare
before
me
,
day
by
day
,
and
have
not
betrayed
myself
once
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
could
have
undergone
such
torture
but
for
looking
forward
to
this
time
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
even
in
the
passion
of
his
speech
---
if
that
can
be
called
passion
which
was
so
resolute
and
steady
---
to
press
Tom
's
hand
again
.
<EOS>
Then
he
said
,
in
great
excitement
:
   
<EOS>
"
Close
the
door
,
close
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
He
will
not
be
long
after
me
,
but
may
come
too
soon
.
 
<EOS>
The
time
now
drawing
on
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
hurriedly
---
his
eyes
and
whole
face
brightening
as
he
spoke
<EOS>
---
"
will
make
amends
for
all
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
have
him
die
or
hang
himself
,
for
millions
of
golden
pieces
!
 
<EOS>
Close
the
door
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
did
so
;
hardly
knowing
yet
whether
he
was
awake
or
in
a
dream
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
51
.
<EOS>
Sheds
new
and
brighter
light
upon
the
very
dark
place
;
and
contains
the
sequel
of
the
enterprise
of
Mr
Jonas
and
his
friend
 
<EOS>
The
night
had
now
come
,
when
the
old
clerk
was
to
be
delivered
over
to
his
keepers
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
his
guilty
distractions
,
Jonas
had
not
forgotten
it
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
a
part
of
his
guilty
state
of
mind
to
remember
it
;
for
on
his
persistence
in
the
scheme
depended
one
of
his
precautions
for
his
own
safety
.
 
<EOS>
A
hint
,
a
word
,
from
the
old
man
,
uttered
at
such
a
moment
in
attentive
ears
,
might
fire
the
train
of
suspicion
,
and
destroy
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
watchfulness
of
every
avenue
by
which
the
discovery
of
his
guilt
might
be
approached
,
sharpened
with
his
sense
of
the
danger
by
which
he
was
encompassed
.
 
<EOS>
With
murder
on
his
soul
,
and
its
innumerable
alarms
and
terrors
dragging
at
him
night
and
day
,
he
would
have
repeated
the
crime
,
if
he
had
seen
a
path
of
safety
stretching
out
beyond
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
his
punishment
;
it
was
in
his
guilty
condition
.
 
<EOS>
The
very
deed
which
his
fears
rendered
insupportable
,
his
fears
would
have
impelled
him
to
commit
again
.
   
<EOS>
But
keeping
the
old
man
close
,
according
to
his
design
,
would
serve
his
turn
.
 
<EOS>
His
purpose
was
to
escape
,
when
the
first
alarm
and
wonder
had
subsided
;
and
when
he
could
make
the
attempt
without
awakening
instant
suspicion
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
these
women
would
keep
him
quiet
;
and
if
the
talking
humour
came
upon
him
,
would
not
be
easily
startled
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
their
trade
.
   
<EOS>
Nor
had
he
spoken
idly
when
he
said
the
old
man
should
be
gagged
.
<EOS>
He
had
resolved
to
ensure
his
silence
;
and
he
looked
to
the
end
,
not
the
means
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
been
rough
and
rude
and
cruel
to
the
old
man
all
his
life
;
and
violence
was
natural
to
his
mind
in
connection
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
shall
be
gagged
if
he
speaks
,
and
pinioned
if
he
writes
,
"
said
Jonas
,
looking
at
him
;
for
they
sat
alone
together
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
mad
enough
for
that
;
I
'll
go
through
with
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
Hush
!
   
<EOS>
Still
listening
!
 
<EOS>
To
every
sound
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
listened
ever
since
,
and
it
had
not
come
yet
.
 
<EOS>
The
exposure
of
the
Assurance
office
;
the
flight
of
Crimple
and
Bullamy
with
the
plunder
,
and
among
the
rest
,
as
he
feared
,
with
his
own
bill
,
which
he
had
not
found
in
the
pocket
-
book
of
the
murdered
man
,
and
which
with
Mr
Pecksniff
's
money
had
probably
been
remitted
to
one
or
other
of
those
trusty
friends
for
safe
deposit
at
the
banker
's
;
his
immense
losses
,
and
peril
of
being
still
called
to
account
as
a
partner
in
the
broken
firm
;
all
these
things
rose
in
his
mind
at
one
time
and
always
,
but
he
could
not
contemplate
them
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
aware
of
their
presence
,
and
of
the
rage
,
discomfiture
,
and
despair
,
they
brought
along
with
them
;
but
he
thought
---
of
his
own
controlling
power
and
direction
he
thought
---
of
the
one
dread
question
only
.
 
<EOS>
When
they
would
find
the
body
in
the
wood
.
   
<EOS>
He
tried
---
he
had
never
left
off
trying
---
not
to
forget
it
was
there
,
for
that
was
impossible
,
but
to
forget
to
weary
himself
by
drawing
vivid
pictures
of
it
in
his
fancy
;
by
going
softly
about
it
and
about
it
among
the
leaves
,
approaching
it
nearer
and
nearer
through
a
gap
in
the
boughs
,
and
startling
the
very
flies
that
were
thickly
sprinkled
all
over
it
,
like
heaps
of
dried
currants
.
 
<EOS>
His
mind
was
fixed
and
fastened
on
the
discovery
,
for
intelligence
of
which
he
listened
intently
to
every
cry
and
shout
;
listened
when
any
one
came
in
or
went
out
;
watched
from
the
window
the
people
who
passed
up
and
down
the
street
;
mistrusted
his
own
looks
and
words
.
 
<EOS>
And
the
more
his
thoughts
were
set
upon
the
discovery
,
the
stronger
was
the
fascination
which
attracted
them
to
the
thing
itself
;
lying
alone
in
the
wood
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
for
ever
showing
and
presenting
it
,
as
it
were
,
to
every
creature
whom
he
saw
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
of
this
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
found
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
suspect
ME
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
condemned
to
bear
the
body
in
his
arms
,
and
lay
it
down
for
recognition
at
the
feet
of
every
one
he
met
,
it
could
not
have
been
more
constantly
with
him
,
or
a
cause
of
more
monotonous
and
dismal
occupation
than
it
was
in
this
state
of
his
mind
.
   
<EOS>
Still
he
was
not
sorry
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
no
contrition
or
remorse
for
what
he
had
done
that
moved
him
;
it
was
nothing
but
alarm
for
his
own
security
.
 
<EOS>
The
vague
consciousness
he
possessed
of
having
wrecked
his
fortune
in
the
murderous
venture
,
intensified
his
hatred
and
revenge
,
and
made
him
set
the
greater
store
by
what
he
had
gained
The
man
was
dead
;
nothing
could
undo
that
.
 
<EOS>
He
felt
a
triumph
yet
,
in
the
reflection
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
kept
a
jealous
watch
on
Chuffey
ever
since
the
deed
;
seldom
leaving
him
but
on
compulsion
,
and
then
for
as
short
intervals
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
alone
together
now
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
twilight
,
and
the
appointed
time
drew
near
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
walked
up
and
down
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
sat
in
his
accustomed
corner
.
   
<EOS>
The
slightest
circumstance
was
matter
of
disquiet
to
the
murderer
,
and
he
was
made
uneasy
at
this
time
by
the
absence
of
his
wife
,
who
had
left
home
early
in
the
afternoon
,
and
had
not
returned
yet
.
 
<EOS>
No
tenderness
for
her
was
at
the
bottom
of
this
;
but
he
had
a
misgiving
that
she
might
have
been
waylaid
,
and
tempted
into
saying
something
that
would
criminate
him
when
the
news
came
.
 
<EOS>
For
anything
he
knew
,
she
might
have
knocked
at
the
door
of
his
room
,
while
he
was
away
,
and
discovered
his
plot
.
 
<EOS>
Confound
her
,
it
was
like
her
pale
face
to
be
wandering
up
and
down
the
house
!
 
<EOS>
Where
was
she
now
?
   
<EOS>
"
She
went
to
her
good
friend
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
when
he
asked
the
question
with
an
angry
oath
.
   
<EOS>
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
To
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
Always
stealing
away
into
the
company
of
that
woman
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
no
friend
of
his
.
 
<EOS>
Who
could
tell
what
devil
's
mischief
they
might
hatch
together
!
 
<EOS>
Let
her
be
fetched
home
directly
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
muttering
some
words
softly
,
rose
as
if
he
would
have
gone
himself
,
but
Jonas
thrust
him
back
into
his
chair
with
an
impatient
imprecation
,
and
sent
a
servant
-
girl
to
fetch
her
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
charged
her
with
her
errand
he
walked
to
and
fro
again
,
and
never
stopped
till
she
came
back
,
<EOS>
which
she
did
pretty
soon
;
the
way
being
short
,
and
the
woman
having
made
good
haste
.
   
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Where
was
she
?
 
<EOS>
Had
she
come
?
   
<EOS>
No
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
left
there
,
full
three
hours
.
   
<EOS>
"
Left
there
!
 
<EOS>
Alone
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
messenger
had
not
asked
;
taking
that
for
granted
.
   
<EOS>
"
Curse
you
for
a
fool
.
 
<EOS>
Bring
candles
!
"
   
<EOS>
She
had
scarcely
left
the
room
when
the
old
clerk
,
who
had
been
unusually
observant
of
him
ever
since
he
had
asked
about
his
wife
,
came
suddenly
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Give
her
up
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
!
 
<EOS>
Give
her
up
to
me
!
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
what
you
have
done
with
her
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
made
no
promises
on
that
score
.
 
<EOS>
Tell
me
what
you
have
done
with
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
laid
his
hands
upon
his
collar
as
he
spoke
,
and
grasped
it
;
tightly
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
leave
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
strong
enough
to
cry
out
to
the
neighbours
,
and
I
will
,
unless
you
give
her
up
.
 
<EOS>
Give
her
up
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
was
so
dismayed
and
conscience
-
stricken
,
that
he
had
not
even
hardihood
enough
to
unclench
the
old
man
's
hands
with
his
own
;
but
stood
looking
at
him
as
well
as
he
could
in
the

,
without
moving
a
finger
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
much
as
he
could
do
to
ask
him
what
he
meant
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
will
know
what
you
have
done
with
her
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
hurt
a
hair
of
her
head
,
you
shall
answer
it
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
thing
!
 
<EOS>
Poor
thing
!
 
<EOS>
Where
is
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
old
madman
!
"
said
Jonas
,
in
a
low
voice
,
and
with
trembling
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
Bedlam
fit
has
come
upon
you
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
to
make
me
mad
,
seeing
what
I
have
seen
in
this
house
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Where
is
my
dear
old
master
!
 
<EOS>
Where
is
his
only
son
that
I
have
nursed
upon
my
knee
,
a
child
!
 
<EOS>
Where
is
she
,
she
who
was
the
last
;
she
that
I
've
seen
pining
day
by
day
,
and
heard
weeping
in
the
dead
of
night
!
 
<EOS>
She
was
the
last
,
the
last
of
all
my
friends
!
 
<EOS>
Heaven
help
me
,
she
was
the
very
last
!
"
   
<EOS>
Seeing
that
the
tears
were
stealing
down
his
face
,
Jonas
mustered
courage
to
unclench
his
hands
,
and
push
him
off
before
he
answered
:
   
"
Did
you
hear
me
ask
for
her
?
 
<EOS>
Did
you
hear
me
send
for
her
?
 
<EOS>
How
can
I
give
you
up
what
I
have
n't
got
,
idiot
!
 
<EOS>
Ecod
,
I
'd
give
her
up
to
you
and
welcome
,
if
I
could
;
and
a
precious
pair
you
'd
be
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
she
has
come
to
any
harm
,
"
cried
Chuffey
,
"
mind
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
old
and
silly
;
but
I
have
my
memory
sometimes
;
and
if
she
has
come
to
any
harm
---
"
   
"
Devil
take
you
,
"
interrupted
Jonas
,
but
in
a

;
"
what
harm
do
you
suppose
she
has
come
to
?
 
<EOS>
I
know
no
more
where
she
is
than
you

;
I
wish
I

.
 
<EOS>
Wait
till
she
comes
home
,
and
see
;
she
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
Will
that
content
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mind
!
"

the

man
.
 
<EOS>
"
Not
a
hair
of
her
head
!
<EOS>
not
a
hair
of
her
head
ill
-
used
!
 
<EOS>
I
wo
n't

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
have

it
too
long
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
I
am

,

---
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I

---
"

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
You
can

,

!
"
thought
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
So
,
so
,
we
'll
stop
your

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
well
<EOS>
I
knew
of
this
in
good
time
.
 
<EOS>
Prevention
is
better
than
cure
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
made
a
poor
show
of
playing
the
bully
and
evincing
a

to
conciliate
at
the
same

,
but
was
so
afraid
of
the
old
man
that
great
drops
had
started
out
upon
his
brow
;
and
they
stood
there
yet
.
 
<EOS>
His
unusual
tone
of
voice
and
agitated
manner
had
sufficiently
expressed
his
fear
;
but
his
face
would
have
done
so
now
,
without
that
aid
,
as
he
again
walked
to
and
fro
,
glancing
at
him
by
the
candelight
.
   
<EOS>
He
stopped
at
the
window
to
think
.
 
<EOS>
An
opposite
shop
was
lighted
up
;
and
the

and
a
customer
were
reading
some
printed
bill
together
across

.
 
<EOS>
The

brought
him

,

,

the

had

.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
here
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
know
of
this
?
 
<EOS>
Is
it
found
?
 
<EOS>
Do
you
suspect
ME
?
"
   
<EOS>
A
hand
upon

.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
that
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
pleasant
evenin
'
,
"
said

Mrs
Gamp
,
"
though
warm
,
which
,
bless

,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
<EOS>
,
we
must
expect
when
cowcumbers
is
three
for

.
 
<EOS>
How
does
Mr
Chuffey
find
his
self
to
-
night
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
kept
particularly
close
to
the
door
in

,
and
curtseyed

than

.
 
<EOS>
She
did
not

be

.
   
<EOS>
"
Get

,
"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
raving
to
-

---
stark

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
talk
while
he
's
here
,
but
come

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Poor
sweet
dear
!
"

Gamp
,

.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
all
of

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well

,
"
said
Jonas
,
"
after

he

.
 
<EOS>
Get

.
"
   
<EOS>
She
was
by

to

.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
my

old
chick
!
"
<EOS>

Gamp
,
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
There
's
my
darlin
'
Mr
Chuffey
!
<EOS>
Now

,

,

lay

;
for
you
're
a
-
shakin
'

,
as

was
hung

.
 
<EOS>
That
's
a
good
creetur
!
 
<EOS>
Come

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Is

come
home
?
"
<EOS>
inquired

.
   
<EOS>
"
She
'll
be
here

minit
,
"
returned
Mrs
Gamp
.
 
<EOS>
"
Come
with
Sairey
,
Mr
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
Come
with
your
own
Sairey
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
good
woman
had
no
reference
to
any
female
in
the
world
in
promising
this
speedy
advent
of
the
person
for
whom
Mr
Chuffey
inquired
,
but
merely
threw
it
out
as
a

of
pacifying
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
its
effect
,
for
he
permitted
her
to
lead
him

;
and
they
quitted
the
room
together
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
looked
out
of
the
window
again
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
still
reading
the
printed
paper
in
the
shop
opposite
,
and
a
third
man
had

in
the

.
 
<EOS>
What
could
it
be
,
to
interest
them
so
?
"
   
<EOS>
A
dispute
or
discussion
seemed
to
arise
among
them
,
for
they
all
looked
up
from
their
reading
together
,
and
one
of
the
three
,
who
had

glancing
over
the

another
,
stepped

to
explain
or

some

.
   
<EOS>
Horror
!
 
<EOS>
How
like
the
blow
he
had
struck
in
the
wood
!
   
<EOS>
It
beat
him
from
the
window
as
if
it
had
lighted
on

.
 
<EOS>
As
he

into
a

,
he
thought

the
change
in
Mrs
Gamp
exhibited
in
her

her

.
 
<EOS>
Was
that
because
it
was
found
?
---
because
she
knew
of
it
?
---
because
she
suspected

?
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr
Chuffey
is
a
-
lyin
'
down
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
returning
,
"
and
much
good
<EOS>
may
it
do
him
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
which
harm
it
ca
n't
and
good
<EOS>
it

;

!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Sit

,
"

,
