,
"
and
let
us
get
this
business
done
.
 
<EOS>
Where
is
the
other
woman
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
other
person
's
with
him
now
,
"
she
answered
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
right
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
fit
to
be
left
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Why
,
he
fastened
on
me
to
-
night
;
here
,
upon
my
coat
;
like
a
savage
dog
.
 
<EOS>
Old
as
he
is
,
and
feeble
as
he
is
usually
,
I
had
some
trouble
to
shake
him
off
.
 
<EOS>
You
---
Hush
!
---
<EOS>
It
's
nothing
.
 
<EOS>
You
told
me
the
other
woman
's
name
.
 
<EOS>
I
forget
it
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
mentioned
Betsey
Prig
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
She
is
to
be
trusted
,
is
she
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
she
ai
n't
!
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
;
"
nor
have
I
brought
her
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
<EOS>
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
brought
another
,
which
engages
to
give
every
satigefaction
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
her
name
?
"
asked
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
looked
at
him
in
an
odd
way
without
returning
any
answer
,
but
appeared
to
understand
the
question
too
.
   
<EOS>
"
What
is
her
name
?
"
repeated
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Her
name
,
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
,
"
is
Harris
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
extraordinary
how
much
effort
it
cost
Mrs
Gamp
to
pronounce
the
name
she
was
commonly
so
ready
with
.
 
<EOS>
She
made
some
three
or
four
gasps
before
she
could
get
it
out
;
and
,
when
she
had
uttered
it
,
pressed
her
hand
upon
her
side
,
and
turned
up
her
eyes
,
as
if
she
were
going
to
faint
away
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
knowing
her
to
labour
under
a
complication
of
internal
disorders
,
which
rendered
a
few
drops
of
spirits
indispensable
at
certain
times
to
her
existence
,
and
which
came
on
very
strong
when
that
remedy
was
not
at
hand
,
Jonas
merely
supposed
her
to
be
the
victim
of
one
of
these
attacks
.
   
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
hastily
,
for
he
felt
how
incapable
he
was
of
confining
his
wandering
attention
to
the
subject
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
and
she
have
arranged
to
take
care
of
him
,
have
you
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
replied
in
the
affirmative
,
and
softly
discharged
herself
of
her
familiar
phrase
,
"
Turn
and
turn
about
;
one
off
,
one
on
.
"
 
<EOS>
But
she
spoke
so
tremulously
that
she
felt
called
upon
to
add
,
"
which
fiddle
-
strings
is
weakness
to
expredge
my
nerves
this
night
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
stopped
to
listen
.
 
<EOS>
Then
said
,
hurriedly
:
   
<EOS>
"
We
shall
not
quarrel
about
terms
.
 
<EOS>
Let
them
be
the
same
as
they
were
before
.
 
<EOS>
Keep
him
close
,
and
keep
him
quiet
.
 
<EOS>
He
must
be
restrained
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
got
it
in
his
head
to
-
night
that
my
wife
's
dead
,
and
has
been
attacking
me
as
if
I
had
killed
her
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
---
<EOS>
it
's
common
with
mad
people
to
take
the
worst
fancies
of
those
they
like
best
.
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
assented
with
a
short
groan
.
   
<EOS>
"
Keep
him
close
,
then
,
or
in
one
of
his
fits
he
'll
be
doing
me
a
mischief
.
 
<EOS>
And
do
n't
trust
him
at
any
time
;
for
when
he
seems
most
rational
,
he
's
wildest
in
his
talk
.
 
<EOS>
But
that
you
know
already
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
see
the
other
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
t'other
person
,
sir
?
"
said
Mrs
Gamp
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
!
 
<EOS>
Go
you
to
him
and
send
the
other
.
 
<EOS>
Quick
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
busy
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
took
two
or
three
backward
steps
towards
the
door
,
and
stopped
there
.
   
<EOS>
"
It
is
your
wishes
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
she
said
,
in
a
sort
of
quavering
croak
,
"
to
see
the
t'other
person
.
 
<EOS>
Is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
But
the
ghastly
change
in
Jonas
told
her
that
the
other
person
was
already
seen
.
 
<EOS>
Before
she
could
look
round
towards
the
door
,
she
was
put
aside
by
old
Martin
's
hand
;
and
Chuffey
and
John
Westlock
entered
with
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
Let
no
one
leave
the
house
,
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
man
is
my
brother
's
son
.
 
<EOS>
Ill
-
met
,
ill
-
trained
,
ill
-
begotten
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
moves
from
the
spot
on
which
he
stands
,
or
speaks
a
word
above
his
breath
to
any
person
here
,
open
the
window
,
and
call
for
help
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
right
have
you
to
give
such
directions
in
this
house
?
"
asked
Jonas
faintly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
right
of
your
wrong
-
doing
.
 
<EOS>
Come
in
there
!
"
   
<EOS>
An
irrepressible
exclamation
burst
from
the
lips
of
Jonas
,
as
Lewsome
entered
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
groan
,
or
a
shriek
,
or
a
word
,
but
was
wholly
unlike
any
sound
that
had
ever
fallen
on
the
ears
of
those
who
heard
it
,
while
at
the
same
time
it
was
the
most
sharp
and
terrible
expression
of
what
was
working
in
his
guilty
breast
,
that
nature
could
have
invented
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
done
murder
for
this
!
 
<EOS>
He
had
girdled
himself
about
with
perils
,
agonies
of
mind
,
innumerable
fears
,
for
this
!
 
<EOS>
He
had
hidden
his
secret
in
the
wood
;
pressed
and
stamped
it
down
into
the
bloody
ground
;
and
here
it
started
up
when
least
expected
,
miles
upon
miles
away
;
known
to
many
;
proclaiming
itself
from
the
lips
of
an
old
man
who
had
renewed
his
strength
and
vigour
as
by
a
miracle
,
to
give
it
voice
against
him
!
   
<EOS>
He
leaned
his
hand
on
the
back
of
a
chair
,
and
looked
at
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
to
try
to
do
so
scornfully
,
or
with
his
usual
insolence
.
<EOS>
He
required
the
chair
for
his
support
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
made
a
struggle
for
it
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
fellow
,
"
he
said
,
fetching
his
breath
at
every
word
,
and
pointing
his
trembling
finger
towards
Lewsome
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
's
the
greatest
liar
alive
.
 
<EOS>
What
's
his
last
tale
?
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
You
're
rare
fellows
,
too
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
that
uncle
of
mine
is
childish
;
he
's
even
a
greater
child
than
his
brother
,
my
father
,
was
,
in
his
old
age
;
or
than
Chuffey
is
.
 
<EOS>
What
the
devil
do
you
mean
,
"
he
added
,
looking
fiercely
at
John
Westlock
and
Mark
Tapley
(
the
latter
had
entered
with
Lewsome
)
,
"
by
coming
here
,
and
bringing
two
idiots
and
a
knave
with
you
to
take
my
house
by
storm
?
 
<EOS>
Hallo
,
there
!
 
<EOS>
Open
the
door
!
<EOS>
Turn
these
strangers
out
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
"
cried
Mr
Tapley
,
coming
forward
,
"
if
it
was
n't
for
your
name
,
I
'd
drag
you
through
the
streets
of
my
own
accord
,
and
single
-
handed
I
would
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
,
I
would
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
try
and
look
bold
at
me
.
 
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
do
it
!
 
<EOS>
Now
go
on
,
sir
<EOS>
,
"
this
was
to
old
Martin
.
<EOS>
"
Bring
the
murderin
'
wagabond
upon
his
knees
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
wants
noise
,
he
shall
have
enough
of
it
;
for
as
sure
as
he
's
a
shiverin
'
from
head
to
foot
I
'll
raise
a
uproar
at
this
winder
that
shall
bring
half
London
in
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Let
him
try
me
once
,
and
see
whether
I
'm
a
man
of
my
word
or
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
With
that
,
Mark
folded
his
arms
,
and
took
his
seat
upon
the
window
-
ledge
,
with
an
air
of
general
preparation
for
anything
,
which
seemed
to
imply
that
he
was
equally
ready
to
jump
out
himself
,
or
to
throw
Jonas
out
,
upon
receiving
the
slightest
hint
that
it
would
be
agreeable
to
the
company
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
turned
to
Lewsome
:
   
<EOS>
"
This
is
the
man
,
"
he
said
,
extending
his
hand
towards
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
need
do
no
more
than
look
at
him
to
be
sure
of
that
,
or
of
the
truth
of
what
I
have
said
,
"
was
the
reply
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
my
witness
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
brother
!
"
cried
old
Martin
,
clasping
his
hands
and
lifting
up
his
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
brother
,
brother
!
 
<EOS>
Were
we
strangers
half
our
lives
that
you
might
breed
a
wretch
like
this
,
and
I
make
life
a
desert
by
withering
every
flower
that
grew
about
me
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
the
natural
end
of
your
precepts
and
mine
,
that
this
should
be
the
creature
of
your
rearing
,
training
,
teaching
,
hoarding
,
striving
for
;
and
I
the
means
of
bringing
him
to
punishment
,
when
nothing
can
repair
the
wasted
past
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
sat
down
upon
a
chair
as
he
spoke
,
and
turning
away
his
face
,
was
silent
for
a
few
moments
.
 
<EOS>
Then
with
recovered
energy
he
proceeded
:
   
"
<EOS>
But
the
accursed
harvest
of
our
mistaken
lives
shall
be
trodden
down
.
 
<EOS>
It
is
not
too
late
for
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
confronted
with
this
man
,
you
monster
there
;
not
to
be
spared
,
but
to
be
dealt
with
justly
.
 
<EOS>
Hear
what
he
says
!
 
<EOS>
Reply
,
be
silent
,
contradict
,
repeat
,
defy
,
do
what
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
My
course
will
be
the
same
.
 
<EOS>
Go
on
!
 
<EOS>
And
you
,
"
he
said
to
Chuffey
,
"
for
the
love
of
your
old
friend
,
speak
out
,
good
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
silent
for
his
love
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
old
man
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
urged
me
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
made
me
promise
it
upon
his
dying
bed
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
would
have
spoken
,
but
for
your
finding
out
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
thought
about
it
ever
since
;
I
could
n't
help
that
;
and
sometimes
I
have
had
it
all
before
me
in
a
dream
;
but
in
the
day
-
time
,
not
in
sleep
.
 
<EOS>
Is
there
such
a
kind
of
dream
?
"
said
Chuffey
,
looking
anxiously
in
old
Martin
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
As
Martin
made
him
an
encouraging
reply
,
he
listened
attentively
to
his
voice
,
and
smiled
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
aye
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
often
spoke
to
me
like
that
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
at
school
together
,
he
and
I.
 
I
could
n't
turn
against
his
son
,
you
know
---
his
only
son
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
would
to
Heaven
you
had
been
his
son
!
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
speak
so
like
my
dear
old
master
,
"
cried
the
old
man
with
a
childish
delight
,
"
that
I
almost
think
I
hear
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
hear
you
quite
as
well
as
I
used
to
hear
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
makes
me
young
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
never
spoke
unkindly
to
me
,
and
I
always
understood
him
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
always
see
him
too
,
though
my
sight
was
dim
.
 
<EOS>
Well
,
well
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
dead
,
he
's
dead
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
very
good
to
me
,
my
dear
old
master
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
mournfully
over
the
brother
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Mark
,
who
had
been
glancing
out
of
the
window
,
left
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
turn
against
his
only
son
,
you
know
,
"
said
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
has
nearly
driven
me
to
do
it
sometimes
;
he
very
nearly
did
tonight
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
cried
the
old
man
,
with
a
sudden
recollection
of
the
cause
.
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
?
 
<EOS>
She
's
not
come
home
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
his
wife
?
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
removed
her
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
in
my
care
,
and
will
be
spared
the
present
knowledge
of
what
is
passing
here
.
 
<EOS>
She
has
known
misery
enough
,
without
that
addition
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
heard
this
with
a
sinking
heart
.
 
<EOS>
He
knew
that
they
were
on
his
heels
,
and
felt
that
they
were
resolute
to
run
him
to
destruction
.
 
<EOS>
Inch
by
inch
the
ground
beneath
him
was
sliding
from
his
feet
;
faster
and
faster
the
encircling
ruin
contracted
and
contracted
towards
himself
,
its
wicked
centre
,
until
it
should
close
in
and
crush
him
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
he
heard
the
voice
of
his
accomplice
stating
to
his
face
,
with
every
circumstance
of
time
and
place
and
incident
;
and
openly
proclaiming
,
with
no
reserve
,
suppression
,
passion
,
or
concealment
;
all
the
truth
.
 
<EOS>
The
truth
,
which
nothing
would
keep
down
;
which
blood
would
not
smother
,
and
earth
would
not
hide
;
the
truth
,
whose
terrible
inspiration
seemed
to
change
dotards
into
strong
men
;
and
on
whose
avenging
wings
,
one
whom
he
had
supposed
to
be
at
the
extremest
corner
of
the
earth
came
swooping
down
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
He
tried
to
deny
it
,
but
his
tongue
would
not
move
.
 
<EOS>
He
conceived
some
desperate
thought
of
rushing
away
,
and
tearing
through
the
streets
;
but
his
limbs
would
as
little
answer
to
his
will
as
his
stark
,
stiff
staring
face
.
 
<EOS>
All
this
time
the
voice
went
slowly
on
,
denouncing
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
every
drop
of
blood
in
the
wood
had
found
a
voice
to
jeer
him
with
.
   
<EOS>
When
it
ceased
,
another
voice
took
up
the
tale
,
but
strangely
;
for
the
old
clerk
,
who
had
watched
,
and
listened
to
the
whole
,
and
had
wrung
his
hands
from
time
to
time
,
as
if
he
knew
its
truth
and
could
confirm
it
,
broke
in
with
these
words
:
   
"
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
!
<EOS>
you
're
wrong
;
you
're
wrong
---
all
wrong
together
!
 
<EOS>
Have
patience
,
for
the
truth
is
only
known
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
that
be
,
"
said
his
old
master
's
brother
,
"
after
what
you
have
heard
?
 
<EOS>
Besides
,
you
said
just
now
,
above
-
stairs
,
when
I
told
you
of
the
accusation
against
him
,
that
you
knew
he
was
his
father
's
murderer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
yes
!
<EOS>
and
so
he
was
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chuffey
,
wildly
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
not
as
you
suppose
---
not
as
you
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
!
 
<EOS>
Give
me
a
moment
's
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
it
all
here
---
all
here
!
 
<EOS>
It
was
foul
,
foul
,
cruel
,
bad
;
but
not
as
you
suppose
.
 
<EOS>
Stay
,
stay
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
put
his
hands
up
to
his
head
,
as
if
it
throbbed
or
pained
him
.
<EOS>
After
looking
about
him
in
a
wandering
and
vacant
manner
for
some
moments
,
his
eyes
rested
upon
Jonas
,
when
they
kindled
up
with
sudden
recollection
and
intelligence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
cried
old
Chuffey
,
"
yes
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
how
it
was
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
all
upon
me
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
---
he
got
up
from
his
bed
before
he
died
,
to
be
sure
,
to
say
that
he
forgave
him
;
and
he
came
down
with
me
into
this
room
;
and
when
he
saw
him
---
his
only
son
,
the
son
he
loved
---
his
speech
forsook
him
;
he
had
no
speech
for
what
he
knew
---
and
no
one
understood
him
except
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
did
---
I
did
!
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
regarded
him
in
amazement
;
so
did
his
companions
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
,
who
had
said
nothing
yet
;
but
had
kept
two
-
thirds
of
herself
behind
the
door
,
ready
for
escape
,
and
one
-
third
in
the
room
,
ready
for
siding
with
the
strongest
party
;
came
a
little
further
in
and
remarked
,
with
a
sob
,
that
Mr
Chuffey
was
"
the
sweetest
old
creetur
goin'
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
bought
the
stuff
,
"
said
Chuffey
,
stretching
out
his
arm
towards
Jonas
while
an
unwonted
fire
shone
in
his
eye
,
and
lightened
up
his
face
;
"
he
bought
the
stuff
,
no
doubt
,
as
you
have
heard
,
and
brought
it
home
.
 
<EOS>
He
mixed
the
stuff
---
look
at
him
!
<EOS>
---
with
some
sweetmeat
in
a
jar
,
exactly
as
the
medicine
for
his
father
's
cough
was
mixed
,
and
put
it
in
a
drawer
;
in
that
drawer
yonder
in
the
desk
;
he
knows
which
drawer
<EOS>
I
mean
!
 
<EOS>
He
kept
it
there
locked
up
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
courage
failed
him
or
his
heart
was
touched
---
my
God
!
 
<EOS>
I
hope
it
was
his
heart
!
 
<EOS>
He
was
his
only
son
!
<EOS>
---
and
he
did
not
put
it
in
the
usual
place
,
where
my
old
master
would
have
taken
it
twenty
times
a
day
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
trembling
figure
of
the
old
man
shook
with
the
strong
emotions
that
possessed
him
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
with
the
same
light
in
his
eye
,
and
with
his
arm
outstretched
,
and
with
his
grey
hair
stirring
on
his
head
,
he
seemed
to
grow
in
size
,
and
was
like
a
man
inspired
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
shrunk
from
looking
at
him
,
and
cowered
down
into
the
chair
by
which
he
had
held
.
 
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
this
tremendous
Truth
could
make
the
dumb
speak
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
every
word
now
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
Every
word
!
 
<EOS>
He
put
it
in
that
drawer
,
as
I
have
said
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
so
often
there
,
and
was
so
secret
,
that
his
father
took
notice
of
it
;
and
when
he
was
out
,
had
it
opened
.
 
<EOS>
We
were
there
together
,
and
we
found
the
mixture
---
Mr
Chuzzlewit
and
<EOS>
I.
 
He
took
it
into
his
possession
,
and
made
light
of
it
at
the
time
;
but
in
the
night
he
came
to
my
bedside
,
weeping
,
and
told
me
that
his
own
son
had
it
in
his
mind
to
poison
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Chuff
,
"
he
said
,
"
<EOS>
oh
,
dear
old
Chuff
!
<EOS>
a
voice
came
into
my
room
to
-
night
,
and
told
me
that
this
crime
began
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
began
when
I
taught
him
to
be
too
covetous
of
what
I
have
to
leave
,
and
made
the
expectation
of
it
his
great
business
!
"
 
<EOS>
Those
were
his
words
;
aye
,
they
are
his
very
words
!
 
<EOS>
If
he
was
a
hard
man
now
and
then
,
it
was
for
his
only
son
.
 
<EOS>
He
loved
his
only
son
,
and
he
was
always
good
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
listened
with
increased
attention
.
 
<EOS>
Hope
was
breaking
in
upon
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
"
He
shall
not
weary
for
my
death
,
Chuff
;
"
that
was
what
he
said
next
,
"
pursued
the
old
clerk
,
as
he
wiped
his
eyes
;
"
that
was
what
he
said
next
,
crying
like
a
little
child
:
"
He
shall
not
weary
for
my
death
,
Chuff
.
 
<EOS>
He
shall
have
it
now
;
he
shall
marry
where
he
has
a
fancy
,
Chuff
,
although
it
do
n't
please
me
;
and
you
and
I
will
go
away
and
live
upon
a
little
.
 
<EOS>
I
always
loved
him
;
perhaps
he
'll
love
me
then
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
a
dreadful
thing
to
have
my
own
child
thirsting
for
my
death
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
might
have
known
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
sown
,
and
I
must
reap
.
<EOS>
He
shall
believe
that
I
am
taking
this
;
and
when
I
see
that
he
is
sorry
,
and
has
all
he
wants
,
I
'll
tell
him
that
I
found
it
out
,
and
I
'll
forgive
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
'll
make
a
better
man
of
his
own
son
,
and
be
a
better
man
himself
,
perhaps
,
Chuff
!
"
<EOS>
"
   
Poor
Chuffey
paused
to
dry
his
eyes
again
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Martin
's
face
was
hidden
in
his
hands
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
listened
still
more
keenly
,
and
his
breast
heaved
like
a
swollen
water
,
but
with
hope
.
 
<EOS>
With
growing
hope
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
dear
old
master
made
believe
next
day
,
"
said
Chuffey
,
"
that
he
had
opened
the
drawer
by
mistake
with
a
key
from
the
bunch
,
which
happened
to
fit
it
<EOS>
(
we
had
one
made
and
hung
upon
it
)
;
and
that
he
had
been
surprised
to
find
his
fresh
supply
of
cough
medicine
in
such
a
place
,
but
supposed
it
had
been
put
there
in
a
hurry
when
the
drawer
stood
open
.
 
<EOS>
We
burnt
it
;
but
his
son
believed
that
he
was
taking
it
---
he
knows
he
did
.
 
<EOS>
Once
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
to
try
him
,
took
heart
to
say
it
had
a
strange
taste
;
and
he
got
up
directly
,
and
went
out
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
gave
a
short
,
dry
cough
;
and
,
changing
his
position
for
an
easier
one
,
folded
his
arms
without
looking
at
them
,
though
they
could
now
see
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Chuzzlewit
wrote
to
her
father
;
I
mean
the
father
of
the
poor
thing
who
's
his
wife
,
"
said
Chuffey
;
"
and
got
him
to
come
up
,
intending
to
hasten
on
the
marriage
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
mind
,
like
mine
,
went
a
little
wrong
through
grief
,
and
then
his
heart
broke
.
 
<EOS>
He
sank
and
altered
from
the
time
when
he
came
to
me
in
the
night
;
and
never
held
up
his
head
again
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
only
a
few
days
,
but
he
had
never
changed
so
much
in
twice
the
years
.
 
<EOS>
"
Spare
him
,
Chuff
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
before
he
died
.
 
<EOS>
They
were
the
only
words
he
could
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
Spare
him
,
Chuff
!
"
 
<EOS>
I
promised
him
I
would
.
 
<EOS>
I
've
tried
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
He
's
his
only
son
.
"
   
<EOS>
On
his
recollection
of
the
last
scene
in
his
old
friend
's
life
,
poor
Chuffey
's
voice
,
which
had
grown
weaker
and
weaker
,
quite
deserted
him
.
 
<EOS>
Making
a
motion
with
his
hand
,
as
if
he
would
have
said
that
Anthony
had
taken
it
,
and
had
died
with
it
in
his
,
he
retreated
to
the
corner
where
he
usually
concealed
his
sorrows
;
and
was
silent
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
could
look
at
his
company
now
,
and
vauntingly
too
.
 
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
after
a
pause
.
 
<EOS>
"
Are
you
satisfied
?
<EOS>
or
have
you
any
more
of
your
plots
to
broach
?
 
<EOS>
Why
that
fellow
,
Lewsome
,
can
invent
'em
for
you
by
the
score
.
 
<EOS>
Is
this
all
?
 
<EOS>
Have
you
nothing
else
?
"
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
looked
at
him
steadily
.
   
<EOS>
"
Whether
you
are
what
you
seemed
to
be
at
Pecksniff
's
,
or
are
something
else
and
a
mountebank
,
I
do
n't
know
and
I
do
n't
care
,
"
said
Jonas
,
looking
downward
with
a
smile
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
do
n't
want
you
here
.
 
<EOS>
You
were
here
so
often
when
your
brother
was
alive
,
and
were
always
so
fond
of
him
(
your
dear
,
dear
brother
,
and
you
would
have
been
cuffing
one
another
before
this
,
ecod
!
)
,
that
I
am
not
surprised
at
your
being
attached
to
the
place
;
but
the
place
is
not
attached
to
you
,
and
you
ca
n't
leave
it
too
soon
,
though
you
may
leave
it
too
late
.
 
<EOS>
And
for
my
wife
,
old
man
,
send
her
home
straight
,
or
it
will
be
the
worse
for
her
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
You
carry
it
with
a
high
hand
,
too
!
 
<EOS>
But
it
is
n't
hanging
yet
for
a
man
to
keep
a
penn'orth
of
poison
for
his
own
purposes
,
and
have
it
taken
from
him
by
two
old
crazy
jolter
-
heads
who
go
and
act
a
play
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
see
the
door
?
"
   
<EOS>
His
base
triumph
,
struggling
with
his
cowardice
,
and
shame
,
and
guilt
,
was
so
detestable
,
that
they
turned
away
from
him
,
as
if
he
were
some
obscene
and
filthy
animal
,
repugnant
to
the
sight
.
 
<EOS>
And
here
that
last
black
crime
was
busy
with
him
too
;
working
within
him
to
his
perdition
.
 
<EOS>
But
for
that
,
the
old
clerk
's
story
might
have
touched
him
,
though
never
so
lightly
;
but
for
that
,
the
sudden
removal
of
so
great
a
load
might
have
brought
about
some
wholesome
change
even
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
With
that
deed
done
,
however
;
with
that
unnecessary
wasteful
danger
haunting
him
;
despair
was
in
his
very
triumph
and
relief
;
wild
,
ungovernable
,
raging
despair
,
for
the
uselessness
of
the
peril
into
which
he
had
plunged
;
despair
that
hardened
him
and
maddened
him
,
and
set
his
teeth
a
-
grinding
in
a
moment
of
his
exultation
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
good
friend
!
<EOS>
"
said
old
Martin
,
laying
his
hand
on
Chuffey
's
sleeve
.
 
<EOS>
"
This
is
no
place
for
you
to
remain
in
.
 
<EOS>
Come
with
me
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Just
his
old
way
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Chuffey
,
looking
up
into
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
almost
believe
it
's
Mr
Chuzzlewit
alive
again
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
!
 
<EOS>
Take
me
with
you
!
 
<EOS>
Stay
,
though
,
stay
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
what
?
"
asked
old
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
leave
her
,
poor
thing
!
"
said
Chuffey
.
 
<EOS>
"
She
has
been
very
good
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
leave
her
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
Thank
you
kindly
.
<EOS>
I
'll
remain
here
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
n't
long
to
remain
;
it
's
no
great
matter
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
meekly
shook
his
poor
,
grey
head
,
and
thanked
old
Martin
in
these
words
,
Mrs
Gamp
,
now
entirely
in
the
room
,
was
affected
to
tears
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
mercy
as
it
is
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
"
as
sech
a
dear
,
good
,
reverend
creetur
never
got
into
the
clutches
of
Betsey
Prig
,
which
but
for
me
he
would
have
done
,
undoubted
;
facts
bein
'
stubborn
and
not
easy
drove
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
heard
me
speak
to
you
just
now
,
old
man
,
"
said
Jonas
to
his
uncle
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
'll
have
no
more
tampering
with
my
people
,
man
or
woman
.
<EOS>
Do
you
see
the
door
?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
YOU
see
the
door
?
"
returned
the
voice
of
Mark
,
coming
from
that
direction
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
at
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
looked
,
and
his
gaze
was
nailed
there
.
 
<EOS>
Fatal
,
ill
-
omened
blighted
threshold
,
cursed
by
his
father
's
footsteps
in
his
dying
hour
,
cursed
by
his
young
wife
's
sorrowing
tread
,
cursed
by
the
daily
shadow
of
the
old
clerk
's
figure
,
cursed
by
the
crossing
of
his
murderer
's
feet
---
what
men
were
standing
in
the
door
way
!
   
<EOS>
Nadgett
foremost
.
   
<EOS>
Hark
!
 
<EOS>
It
came
on
,
roaring
like
a
sea
!
 
<EOS>
Hawkers
burst
into
the
street
,
crying
it
up
and
down
;
windows
were
thrown
open
that
the
inhabitants
might
hear
it
;
people
stopped
to
listen
in
the
road
and
on
the
pavement
;
the
bells
,
the
same
bells
,
began
to
ring
;
tumbling
over
one
another
in
a
dance
of
boisterous
joy
at
the
discovery
(
that
was
the
sound
they
had
in
his
distempered
thoughts
)
,
and
making
their
airy
play
-
ground
rock
.
   
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
man
,
"
said
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
"
By
the
window
!
"
   
Three
others
came
in
,
laid
hands
upon
him
,
and
secured
him
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
so
quickly
done
,
that
he
had
not
lost
sight
of
the
informer
's
face
for
an
instant
when
his
wrists
were
manacled
together
.
   
<EOS>
"
Murder
,
"
said
Nadgett
,
looking
round
on
the
astonished
group
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
no
one
interfere
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
sounding
street
repeated
Murder
;
barbarous
and
dreadful
Murder
.
<EOS>
Murder
,
Murder
,
Murder
.
 
<EOS>
Rolling
on
from
house
to
house
,
and
echoing
from
stone
to
stone
,
until
the
voices
died
away
into
the
distant
hum
,
which
seemed
to
mutter
the
same
word
!
   
<EOS>
They
all
stood
silent
:
listening
,
and
gazing
in
each
other
's
faces
,
as
the
noise
passed
on
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
was
the
first
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
terrible
history
is
this
?
"
he
demanded
.
   
<EOS>
"
Ask
HIM
,
"
said
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
're
his
friend
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
He
can
tell
you
,
if
he
will
.
 
<EOS>
He
knows
more
of
it
than
I
do
,
though
I
know
much
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
much
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
been
watching
him
so
long
for
nothing
,
"
returned
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
watched
a
man
so
close
as
I
have
watched
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
Another
of
the
phantom
forms
of
this
terrific
Truth
!
 
<EOS>
Another
of
the
many
shapes
in
which
it
started
up
about
him
,
out
of
vacancy
.
 
<EOS>
This
man
,
of
all
men
in
the
world
,
a
spy
upon
him
;
this
man
,
changing
his
identity
;
casting
off
his
shrinking
,
purblind
,
unobservant
character
,
and
springing
up
into
a
watchful
enemy
!
 
<EOS>
The
dead
man
might
have
come
out
of
his
grave
,
and
not
confounded
and
appalled
him
more
.
   
<EOS>
The
game
was
up
.
 
<EOS>
The
race
was
at
an
end
;
the
rope
was
woven
for
his
neck
.
 
<EOS>
If
,
by
a
miracle
,
he
could
escape
from
this
strait
,
he
had
but
to
turn
his
face
another
way
,
no
matter
where
,
and
there
would
rise
some
new
avenger
front
to
front
with
him
;
some
infant
in
an
hour
grown
old
,
or
old
man
in
an
hour
grown
young
,
or
blind
man
with
his
sight
restored
,
or
deaf
man
with
his
hearing
given
him
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
chance
.
 
<EOS>
He
sank
down
in
a
heap
against
the
wall
,
and
never
hoped
again
from
that
moment
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
his
friend
,
although
I
have
the
honour
to
be
his
relative
,
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
speak
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Where
have
you
watched
,
and
what
have
you
seen
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
watched
in
many
places
,
"
returned
Nadgett
,
"
night
and
day
.
<EOS>
I
have
watched
him
lately
,
almost
without
rest
or
relief
;
"
his
anxious
face
and
bloodshot
eyes
confirmed
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
little
thought
to
what
my
watching
was
to
lead
.
 
<EOS>
As
little
as
he
did
when
he
slipped
out
in
the
night
,
dressed
in
those
clothes
which
he
afterwards
sunk
in
a
bundle
at
London
Bridge
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
moved
upon
the
ground
like
a
man
in
bodily
torture
.
 
<EOS>
He
uttered
a
suppressed
groan
,
as
if
he
had
been
wounded
by
some
cruel
weapon
;
and
plucked
at
the
iron
band
upon
his
wrists
,
as
though
(
his
hands
being
free
)
<EOS>
he
would
have
torn
himself
.
   
<EOS>
"
Steady
,
kinsman
!
"
said
the
chief
officer
of
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
violent
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Whom
do
you
call
kinsman
?
<EOS>
"
asked
old
Martin
sternly
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
,
"
said
the
man
,
"
among
others
.
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
turned
his
scrutinizing
gaze
upon
him
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
lazily
across
a
chair
with
his
arms
resting
on
the
back
;
eating
nuts
,
and
throwing
the
shells
out
of
window
as
he
cracked
them
,
which
he
still
continued
to
do
while
speaking
.
   
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
"
he
said
,
with
a
sulky
nod
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
may
deny
your
nephews
till
you
die
;
but
Chevy
Slyme
is
Chevy
Slyme
still
,
all
the
world
over
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
even
you
may
feel
it
some
disgrace
to
your
own
blood
to
be
employed
in
this
way
.
 
<EOS>
I
'm
to
be
bought
off
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
every
turn
!
"
cried
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Self
,
self
,
self
.
 
<EOS>
Every
one
among
them
for
himself
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
save
one
or
two
among
them
the
trouble
then
and
be
for
them
as
well
as
YOURself
,
"
replied
his
nephew
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
here
at
me
!
 
<EOS>
Can
you
see
the
man
of
your
family
who
has
more
talent
in
his
little
finger
than
all
the
rest
in
their
united
brains
,
dressed
as
a
police
officer
without
being
ashamed
?
 
<EOS>
I
took
up
with
this
trade
on
purpose
to
shame
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
n't
think
I
should
have
to
make
a
capture
in
the
family
,
though
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
your
debauchery
,
and
that
of
your
chosen
friends
,
has
really
brought
you
to
this
level
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
"
keep
it
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
living
honestly
,
I
hope
,
and
that
's
something
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
hard
upon
my
chosen
friends
,
"
returned
Slyme
,
"
<EOS>
for
they
were
sometimes
your
chosen
friends
too
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
say
you
never
employed
my
friend
Tigg
,
<EOS>
for
I
know
better
.
 
<EOS>
We
quarrelled
upon
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
hired
the
fellow
,
"
retorted
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
and
I
paid
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
's
<EOS>
well
you
paid
him
,
"
said
his
nephew
,
"
<EOS>
for
it
would
be
too
late
to
do
so
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
has
given
his
receipt
in
full
;
or
had
it
forced
from
him
rather
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
at
him
as
if
he
were
curious
to
know
what
he
meant
,
but
scorned
to
prolong
the
conversation
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
expected
that
he
and
I
would
be
brought
together
again
in
the
course
of
business
,
"
said
Slyme
,
taking
a
fresh
handful
of
nuts
from
his
pocket
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
thought
he
would
be
wanted
for
some
swindling
job
;
it
never
entered
my
head
that
I
should
hold
a
warrant
for
the
apprehension
of
his
murderer
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
HIS
murderer
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
looking
from
one
to
another
.
   
<EOS>
"
His
or
Mr
Montague
's
,
"
said
Nadgett
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
are
the
same
,
I
am
told
.
 
<EOS>
I
accuse
him
yonder
of
the
murder
of
Mr
Montague
,
who
was
found
last
night
,
killed
,
in
a
wood
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
ask
me
why
I
accuse
him
as
you
have
already
asked
me
how
I
know
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
.
<EOS>
It
ca
n't
remain
a
secret
long
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
ruling
passion
of
the
man
expressed
itself
even
then
,
in
the
tone
of
regret
in
which
he
deplored
the
approaching
publicity
of
what
he
knew
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
told
you
I
had
watched
him
,
"
he
proceeded
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
was
instructed
to
do
so
by
Mr
Montague
,
in
whose
employment
I
have
been
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
We
had
our
suspicions
of
him
;
and
you
know
what
they
pointed
at
,
for
you
have
been
discussing
it
since
we
have
been
waiting
here
,
outside
the
room
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
care
to
hear
,
now
it
's
all
over
,
in
what
our
suspicions
began
,
I
'll
tell
you
plainly
:
in
a
quarrel
(
it
first
came
to
our
ears
through
a
hint
of
his
own
)
between
him
and
another
office
in
which
his
father
's
life
was
insured
,
and
which
had
so
much
doubt
and
distrust
upon
the
subject
,
that
he
compounded
with
them
,
and
took
half
the
money
;
and
was
glad
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
Bit
by
bit
,
I
ferreted
out
more
circumstances
against
him
,
and
not
a
few
.
 
<EOS>
It
required
a
little
patience
,
but
it
's
my
calling
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
the
nurse
 
<EOS>
---
here
she
is
to
confirm
me
;
I
found
the
doctor
,
I
found
the
undertaker
,
I
found
the
undertaker
's
man
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
out
how
the
old
gentleman
there
,
Mr
Chuffey
,
had
behaved
at
the
funeral
;
and
I
found
out
what
this
man
,
"
touching
Lewsome
on
the
arm
,
"
had
talked
about
in
his
fever
.
 
<EOS>
I
found
out
how
he
conducted
himself
before
his
father
's
death
,
and
how
since
and
how
at
the
time
;
and
writing
it
all
down
,
and
putting
it
carefully
together
,
made
case
enough
for
Mr
Montague
to
tax
him
with
the
crime
,
which
(
as
he
himself
believed
until
to
-
night
)
he
had
committed
.
 
<EOS>
I
was
by
when
this
was
done
.
 
<EOS>
You
see
him
now
.
 
<EOS>
He
is
only
worse
than
he
was
then
.
"
   
<EOS>
Oh
,
miserable
,
miserable
fool
!
<EOS>
oh
,
insupportable
,
excruciating
torture
!
 
<EOS>
To
find
alive
and
active
---
a
party
to
it
all
---
the
brain
and
right
-
hand
of
the
secret
he
had
thought
to
crush
!
 
<EOS>
In
whom
,
though
he
had
walled
the
murdered
man
up
,
by
enchantment
in
a
rock
,
the
story
would
have
lived
and
walked
abroad
!
 
<EOS>
He
tried
to
stop
his
ears
with
his
fettered
arms
,
that
he
might
shut
out
the
rest
.
   
<EOS>
As
he
crouched
upon
the
floor
,
they
drew
away
from
him
as
if
a
pestilence
were
in
his
breath
.
 
<EOS>
They
fell
off
,
one
by
one
,
from
that
part
of
the
room
,
leaving
him
alone
upon
the
ground
.
 
<EOS>
Even
those
who
had
him
in
their
keeping
shunned
him
,
and
(
with
the
exception
of
Slyme
,
who
was
still
occupied
with
his
nuts
)
kept
apart
.
   
<EOS>
"
From
that
garret
-
window
opposite
,
"
said
Nadgett
,
pointing
across
the
narrow
street
,
"
I
have
watched
this
house
and
him
for
days
and
nights
.
 
<EOS>
From
that
garret
-
window
opposite
I
saw
him
return
home
,
alone
,
from
a
journey
on
which
he
had
set
out
with
Mr
Montague
.
<EOS>
That
was
my
token
that
Mr
Montague
's
end
was
gained
;
and
I
might
rest
easy
on
my
watch
,
though
I
was
not
to
leave
it
until
he
dismissed
me
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
standing
at
the
door
opposite
,
after
dark
that
same
night
,
I
saw
a
countryman
steal
out
of
this
house
,
by
a
side
-
door
in
the
court
,
who
had
never
entered
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
knew
his
walk
,
and
that
it
was
himself
,
disguised
.
 
<EOS>
I
followed
him
immediately
.
 
<EOS>
I
lost
him
on
the
western
road
,
still
travelling
westward
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
looked
up
at
him
for
an
instant
,
and
muttered
an
oath
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
comprehend
what
this
meant
,
"
said
Nadgett
;
"
but
,
having
seen
so
much
,
I
resolved
to
see
it
out
,
and
through
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
did
.
<EOS>
Learning
,
on
inquiry
at
his
house
from
his
wife
,
that
he
was
supposed
to
be
sleeping
in
the
room
from
which
I
had
seen
him
go
out
,
and
that
he
had
given
strict
orders
not
to
be
disturbed
,
I
knew
that
he
was
coming
back
;
and
for
his
coming
back
I
watched
.
 
<EOS>
I
kept
my
watch
in
the
street
---
in
doorways
,
and
such
places
---
all
that
night
;
at
the
same
window
,
all
next
day
;
and
when
night
came
on
again
,
in
the
street
once
more
.
 
<EOS>
For
I
knew
he
would
come
back
,
as
he
had
gone
out
,
when
this
part
of
the
town
was
empty
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
.
<EOS>
Early
in
the
morning
,
the
same
countryman
came
creeping
,
creeping
,
creeping
home
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Look
sharp
!
"
<EOS>
interposed
Slyme
,
who
had
now
finished
his
nuts
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
quite
irregular
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
kept
at
the
window
all
day
,
"
said
Nadgett
,
without
heeding
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
never
closed
my
eyes
.
 
<EOS>
At
night
,
I
saw
him
come
out
with
a
bundle
.
 
<EOS>
I
followed
him
again
.
 
<EOS>
He
went
down
the
steps
at
London
Bridge
,
and
sunk
it
in
the
river
.
 
<EOS>
I
now
began
to
entertain
some
serious
fears
,
and
made
a
communication
to
the
Police
,
which
caused
that
bundle
to
be
---
"
   
"
To
be
fished
up
,
"
interrupted
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
"
Be
alive
,
Mr
Nadgett
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
contained
the
dress
I
had
seen
him
wear
,
"
said
Nadgett
;
"
stained
with
clay
,
and
spotted
with
blood
.
 
<EOS>
Information
of
the
murder
was
received
in
town
last
night
.
 
<EOS>
The
wearer
of
that
dress
is
already
known
to
have
been
seen
near
the
place
;
to
have
been
lurking
in
that
neighbourhood
;
and
to
have
alighted
from
a
coach
coming
from
that
part
of
the
country
,
at
a
time
exactly
tallying
with
the
very
minute
when
I
saw
him
returning
home
.
 
<EOS>
The
warrant
has
been
out
,
and
these
officers
have
been
with
me
,
some
hours
.
 
<EOS>
We
chose
our
time
;
and
seeing
you
come
in
,
and
seeing
this
person
at
the
window
---
"
   
"
Beckoned
to
him
,
"
said
Mark
,
taking
up
the
thread
of
the
narrative
,
on
hearing
this
allusion
to
himself
,
"
to
open
the
door
;
which
he
did
with
a
deal
of
pleasure
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
at
present
,
"
said
Nadgett
,
putting
up
his
great
pocketbook
,
which
from
mere
habit
he
had
produced
when
he
began
his
revelation
,
and
had
kept
in
his
hand
all
the
time
;
"
but
there
is
plenty
more
to
come
.
 
<EOS>
You
asked
me
for
the
facts
,
so
far
I
have
related
them
,
and
need
not
detain
these
gentlemen
any
longer
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
ready
,
Mr
Slyme
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
something
more
,
"
replied
that
worthy
,
rising
.
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
walk
round
to
the
office
,
we
shall
be
there
as
soon
as
you
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
Get
a
coach
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
officer
to
whom
he
spoke
departed
for
that
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
Old
Martin
lingered
for
a
few
moments
,
as
if
he
would
have
addressed
some
words
to
Jonas
;
but
looking
round
,
and
seeing
him
still
seated
on
the
floor
,
rocking
himself
in
a
savage
manner
to
and
fro
,
took
Chuffey
's
arm
,
and
slowly
followed
Nadgett
out
.
 
<EOS>
John
Westlock
and
Mark
Tapley
accompanied
them
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Gamp
had
tottered
out
first
,
for
the
better
display
of
her
feelings
,
in
a
kind
of
walking
swoon
;
for
Mrs
Gamp
performed
swoons
of
different
sorts
,
upon
a
moderate
notice
,
as
Mr
Mould
did
Funerals
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
"
muttered
Slyme
,
looking
after
them
.
 
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
!
 
<EOS>
As
insensible
of
being
disgraced
by
having
such
a
nephew
as
myself
,
in
such
a
situation
,
as
he
was
of
my
being
an
honour
and
a
credit
to
the
family
!
 
<EOS>
That
's
the
return
I
get
for
having
humbled
my
spirit
---
 
<EOS>
such
a
spirit
as
mine
---
to
earn
a
livelihood
,
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
He
got
up
from
his
chair
,
and
kicked
it
away
indignantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
such
a
livelihood
too
!
 
<EOS>
When
there
are
hundreds
of
men
,
not
fit
to
hold
a
candle
to
me
,
rolling
in
carriages
and
living
on
their
fortunes
.
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
it
's
a
nice
world
!
"
   
<EOS>
His
eyes
encountered
Jonas
,
who
looked
earnestly
towards
him
,
and
moved
his
lips
as
if
he
were
whispering
.
   
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
said
Slyme
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
glanced
at
the
attendant
whose
back
was
towards
him
,
and
made
a
clumsy
motion
with
his
bound
hands
towards
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Humph
!
<EOS>
"
said
Slyme
,
thoughtfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
hope
to
disgrace
him
into
anything
when
you
have
shot
so
far
ahead
of
me
though
.
 
<EOS>
I
forgot
that
.
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
repeated
the
same
look
and
gesture
.
   
<EOS>
"
Jack
!
"
said
Slyme
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hallo
!
"
returned
his
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Go
down
to
the
door
,
ready
for
the
coach
.
 
<EOS>
Call
out
when
it
comes
.
<EOS>
I
'd
rather
have
you
there
.
 
<EOS>
Now
then
,
"
he
added
,
turning
hastily
to
Jonas
,
when
the
man
was
gone
.
 
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
Jonas
essayed
to
rise
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
bit
,
"
said
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
so
easy
when
your
wrists
are
tight
together
.
 
<EOS>
Now
then
!
 
<EOS>
Up
!
 
<EOS>
What
is
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Put
your
hand
in
my
pocket
.
 
<EOS>
Here
!
 
<EOS>
The
breast
pocket
,
on
the
left
!
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
He
did
so
;
and
drew
out
a
purse
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
hundred
pound
in
it
,
"
said
Jonas
,
whose
words
were
almost
unintelligible
;
as
his
face
,
in
its
pallor
and
agony
,
was
scarcely
human
.
   
<EOS>
Slyme
looked
at
him
;
gave
it
into
his
hands
;
and
shook
his
head
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
dare
n't
.
 
<EOS>
I
could
n't
if
I
dared
.
 
<EOS>
Those
fellows
below
<EOS>
---
"
   
"
Escape
's
impossible
,
"
said
Jonas
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
One
hundred
pound
for
only
five
minutes
in
the
next
room
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
to
do
?
"
he
asked
.
   
<EOS>
The
face
of
his
prisoner
as
he
advanced
to
whisper
in
his
ear
,
made
him
recoil
involuntarily
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
stopped
and
listened
to
him
.
 
<EOS>
The
words
were
few
,
but
his
own
face
changed
as
he
heard
them
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
it
about
me
,
"
said
Jonas
,
putting
his
hands
to
his
throat
,
as
though
whatever
he
referred
to
were
hidden
in
his
neckerchief
.
<EOS>
"
How
should
you
know
of
it
?
 
<EOS>
How
could
you
know
?
 
<EOS>
A
hundred
pound
for
only
five
minutes
in
the
next
room
!
 
<EOS>
The
time
's
passing
.
 
<EOS>
Speak
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
more
---
more
creditable
to
the
family
,
"
observed
Slyme
,
with
trembling
lips
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had
n't
told
me
half
so
much
.
 
<EOS>
Less
would
have
served
your
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
have
kept
it
to
yourself
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
A
hundred
pound
for
only
five
minutes
in
the
next
room
!
 
<EOS>
Speak
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Jonas
,
desperately
.
   
<EOS>
He
took
the
purse
.
 
<EOS>
Jonas
,
with
a
wild
unsteady
step
,
retreated
to
the
door
in
the
glass
partition
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Slyme
,
catching
at
his
skirts
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
this
.
 
<EOS>
Yet
it
must
end
so
at
last
.
 
<EOS>
Are
you
guilty
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Are
the
proofs
as
they
were
told
just
now
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
said
Jonas
.
   
<EOS>
"
Will
you
---
will
you
engage
to
say
a
---
a
Prayer
,
now
,
or
something
of
that
sort
?
"
<EOS>
faltered
Slyme
.
   
<EOS>
Jonas
broke
from
him
without
replying
,
and
closed
the
door
between
them
.
   
<EOS>
Slyme
listened
at
the
keyhole
.
 
<EOS>
After
that
,
he
crept
away
on
tiptoe
,
as
far
off
as
he
could
;
and
looked
awfully
towards
the
place
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
roused
by
the
arrival
of
the
coach
,
and
their
letting
down
the
steps
.
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
getting
a
few
things
together
,
"
he
said
,
leaning
out
of
window
,
and
speaking
to
the
two
men
below
,
who
stood
in
the
full
light
of
a
street
-
lamp
.
 
<EOS>
"
Keep
your
eye
upon
the
back
,
one
of
you
,
for
form
's
sake
.
"
   
<EOS>
One
of
the
men
withdrew
into
the
court
.
 
<EOS>
The
other
,
seating
himself
self
on
the
steps
of
the
coach
,
remained
in
conversation
with
Slyme
at
the
window
who
perhaps
had
risen
to
be
his
superior
,
in
virtue
of
his
old
propensity
(
one
so
much
lauded
by
the
murdered
man
)
of
being
always
round
the
corner
.
 
<EOS>
A
useful
habit
in
his
present
calling
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
he
?
"
asked
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
Slyme
looked
into
the
room
for
an
instant
and
gave
his
head
a
jerk
as
much
as
to
say
,
"
Close
at
hand
.
 
<EOS>
I
see
him
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
's
booked
,
"
observed
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
"
Through
,
"
said
Slyme
.
   
<EOS>
They
looked
at
each
other
,
and
up
and
down
the
street
.
 
<EOS>
The
man
on
the
coach
-
steps
took
his
hat
off
,
and
put
it
on
again
,
and
whistled
a
little
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
He
's
taking
his
time
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
remonstrated
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
allowed
him
five
minutes
,
"
said
Slyme
.
 
<EOS>
"
Time
's
more
than
up
,
though
.
 
<EOS>
I
'll
bring
him
down
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
withdrew
from
the
window
accordingly
,
and
walked
on
tiptoe
to
the
door
in
the
partition
.
 
<EOS>
He
listened
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
not
a
sound
within
.
<EOS>
He
set
the
candles
near
it
,
that
they
might
shine
through
the
glass
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
not
easy
,
he
found
,
to
make
up
his
mind
to
the
opening
of
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
flung
it
wide
open
suddenly
,
and
with
a
noise
;
then
retreated
.
 
<EOS>
After
peeping
in
and
listening
again
,
he
entered
.
   
<EOS>
He
started
back
as
his
eyes
met
those
of
Jonas
,
standing
in
an
angle
of
the
wall
,
and
staring
at
him
.
 
<EOS>
His
neckerchief
was
off
;
his
face
was
ashy
pale
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
're
too
soon
,
"
said
Jonas
,
with
an
abject
whimper
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
've
not
had
time
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
not
been
able
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
five
minutes
more
---
two
minutes
more
!
---
only
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
Slyme
gave
him
no
reply
,
but
thrusting
the
purse
upon
him
and
forcing
it
back
into
his
pocket
,
called
up
his
men
.
   
<EOS>
He
whined
,
and
cried
,
and
cursed
,
and
entreated
them
,
and
struggled
,
and
submitted
,
in
the
same
breath
,
and
had
no
power
to
stand
.
 
<EOS>
They
got
him
away
and
into
the
coach
,
where
they
put
him
on
a
seat
;
but
he
soon
fell
moaning
down
among
the
straw
at
the
bottom
,
and
lay
there
.
   
<EOS>
The
two
men
were
with
him
.
 
<EOS>
Slyme
being
on
the
box
with
the
driver
;
and
they
let
him
lie
.
 
<EOS>
Happening
to
pass
a
fruiterer
's
on
their
way
;
the
door
of
which
was
open
,
though
the
shop
was
by
this
time
shut
;
one
of
them
remarked
how
faint
the
peaches
smelled
.
   
<EOS>
The
other
assented
at
the
moment
,
but
presently
stooped
down
in
quick
alarm
,
and
looked
at
the
prisoner
.
   
<EOS>
"
Stop
the
coach
!
 
<EOS>
He
has
poisoned
himself
!
 
<EOS>
The
smell
comes
from
this
bottle
in
his
hand
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
hand
had
shut
upon
it
tight
.
 
<EOS>
With
that
rigidity
of
grasp
with
which
no
living
man
,
in
the
full
strength
and
energy
of
life
,
can
clutch
a
prize
he
has
won
.
   
<EOS>
They
dragged
him
out
into
the
dark
street
;
but
jury
,
judge
,
and
hangman
,
could
have
done
no
more
,
and
could
do
nothing
now
.
 
<EOS>
Dead
,
dead
,
dead
.
    
<EOS>
Chapter
52
.
<EOS>
In
which
the
tables
are
turned
,
completely
upside
down
 
Old
Martin
's
cherished
projects
,
so
long
hidden
in
his
own
breast
,
so
frequently
in
danger
of
abrupt
disclosure
through
the
bursting
forth
of
the
indignation
he
had
hoarded
up
during
his
residence
with
Mr
Pecksniff
,
were
retarded
,
but
not
beyond
a
few
hours
,
by
the
occurrences
just
now
related
.
 
<EOS>
Stunned
,
as
he
had
been
at
first
by
the
intelligence
conveyed
to
him
through
Tom
Pinch
and
John
Westlock
,
of
the
supposed
manner
of
his
brother
's
death
;
overwhelmed
as
he
was
by
the
subsequent
narratives
of
Chuffey
and
Nadgett
,
and
the
forging
of
that
chain
of
circumstances
ending
in
the
death
of
Jonas
,
of
which
catastrophe
he
was
immediately
informed
;
scattered
as
his
purposes
and
hopes
were
for
the
moment
,
by
the
crowding
in
of
all
these
incidents
between
him
and
his
end
;
still
their
very
intensity
and
the
tumult
of
their
assemblage
nerved
him
to
the
rapid
and
unyielding
execution
of
his
scheme
.
 
<EOS>
In
every
single
circumstance
,
whether
it
were
cruel
,
cowardly
,
or
false
,
he
saw
the
flowering
of
the
same
pregnant
seed
.
 
<EOS>
Self
;
grasping
,
eager
,
narrow
-
ranging
,
overreaching
self
;
with
its
long
train
of
suspicions
,
lusts
,
deceits
,
and
all
their
growing
consequences
;
was
the
root
of
the
vile
tree
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
so
presented
his
character
before
the
old
man
's
eyes
,
that
he
---
the
good
,
the
tolerant
,
enduring
Pecksniff
---
had
become
the
incarnation
of
all
selfishness
and
treachery
;
and
the
more
odious
the
shapes
in
which
those
vices
ranged
themselves
before
him
now
,
the
sterner
consolation
he
had
in
his
design
of
setting
Mr
Pecksniff
right
and
Mr
Pecksniff
's
victims
too
.
   
<EOS>
To
this
work
he
brought
,
not
only
the
energy
and
determination
natural
to
his
character
(
which
,
as
the
reader
may
have
observed
in
the
beginning
of
his
or
her
acquaintance
with
this
gentleman
,
was
remarkable
for
the
strong
development
of
those
qualities
)
,
but
all
the
forced
and
unnaturally
nurtured
energy
consequent
upon
their
long
suppression
.
 
<EOS>
And
these
two
tides
of
resolution
setting
into
one
and
sweeping
on
,
became
so
strong
and
vigorous
,
that
,
to
prevent
themselves
from
being
carried
away
before
it
<EOS>
,
Heaven
knows
where
,
was
as
much
as
John
Westlock
and
Mark
Tapley
together
(
though
they
were
tolerably
energetic
too
)
could
manage
to
effect
.
   
<EOS>
He
had
sent
for
John
Westlock
immediately
on
his
arrival
;
and
John
,
under
the
conduct
of
Tom
Pinch
,
had
waited
on
him
.
 
<EOS>
Having
a
lively
recollection
of
Mr
Tapley
,
he
had
caused
that
gentleman
's
attendance
to
be
secured
,
through
John
's
means
,
without
delay
;
and
thus
,
as
we
have
seen
,
they
had
all
repaired
together
to
the
City
.
 
<EOS>
But
his
grandson
he
had
refused
to
see
until
to
-
morrow
,
when
Mr
Tapley
was
instructed
to
summon
him
to
the
Temple
at
ten
o'clock
in
the
forenoon
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
he
would
not
allow
to
be
employed
in
anything
,
lest
he
should
be
wrongfully
suspected
;
but
he
was
a
party
to
all
their
proceedings
,
and
was
with
them
until
late
at
night
---
until
after
they
knew
of
the
death
of
Jonas
;
when
he
went
home
to
tell
all
these
wonders
to
little
Ruth
,
and
to
prepare
her
for
accompanying
him
to
the
Temple
in
the
morning
,
agreeably
to
Mr
Chuzzlewit
's
particular
injunction
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
characteristic
of
old
Martin
,
and
his
looking
on
to
something
which
he
had
distinctly
before
him
,
that
he
communicated
to
them
nothing
of
his
intentions
,
beyond
such
hints
of
reprisal
on
Mr
Pecksniff
as
they
gathered
from
the
game
he
had
played
in
that
gentleman
's
house
,
and
the
brightening
of
his
eyes
whenever
his
name
was
mentioned
.
 
<EOS>
Even
to
John
Westlock
,
in
whom
he
was
evidently
disposed
to
place
great
confidence
(
which
may
indeed
be
said
of
every
one
of
them
)
,
he
gave
no
explanation
whatever
.
 
<EOS>
He
merely
requested
him
to
return
in
the
morning
;
and
with
this
for
their
utmost
satisfaction
,
they
left
him
,
when
the
night
was
far
advanced
,
alone
.
   
<EOS>
The
events
of
such
a
day
might
have
worn
out
the
body
and
spirit
of
a
much
younger
man
than
he
,
but
he
sat
in
deep
and
painful
meditation
until
the
morning
was
bright
.
 
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
even
then
seek
any
prolonged
repose
,
but
merely
slumbered
in
his
chair
,
until
seven
o'clock
,
when
Mr
Tapley
had
appointed
to
come
to
him
by
his
desire
;
and
came
---
as
fresh
and
clean
and
cheerful
as
the
morning
itself
.
   
<EOS>
"
You
are
punctual
,
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
opening
the
door
to
him
in
reply
to
his
light
knock
,
which
had
roused
him
instantly
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
wishes
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr
Tapley
,
whose
mind
would
appear
from
the
context
to
have
been
running
on
the
matrimonial
service
,
"
is
to
love
,
honour
,
and

.
 
<EOS>
The
clock
's
a
-
striking
now
,
sir
.
"
   
"
Come
in
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
sir
,
"
rejoined
Mr
Tapley
,
"
what
could
I
do
for
you
first
,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
gave
my
message
to
Martin
?
"
said
the
old
man
,
bending

.
   
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mark
;
"
and
you
never
see
a

more
surprised
in
all

than
he

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
more
did
you
tell

?
"
<EOS>
Mr

.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,

,
"
I
should

a

,
but
not

able
,

,
I
did

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
You

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
But

precious

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
There

very
little
respectin
'
<EOS>
you
<EOS>

I

,

.
 
<EOS>

Mr
Pecksniff

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

?
"

<EOS>
"

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
In

old

.
<EOS>
As

,

,

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
long

,

.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
do

.
 
<EOS>
Nobody
ca
n't
.
 
<EOS>
There

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca

that
'

myself
,
<EOS>
but

"

Go

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
Why

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

---
<EOS>
well
!
 
<EOS>
I

,

I

,

.
 
<EOS>
Unintentional
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
There
!
 
<EOS>
Now

"

in

:
<EOS>
"

ca

-

'

,

'

;

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
wisit

,

,
that

.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
clear
that
Mark
expected

be
ordered

,

was

.
   
<EOS>
"
So

,
"

,
"

his

are

,

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"
retorted

,
"
I
'm
werry

,
but
I
ca
n't

.
 
<EOS>
It

,

,
to

,

DO

.
 
<EOS>
I

,

,

;
but
I
DO

.
"
   
<EOS>
The

's

,

<EOS>
"
Yet

an

man
<EOS>
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Werry

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

a

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Likewise
wery
much
so
,
"
Mr
Tapley
answered
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
with

,
paced

room
twice
or

:
   
<EOS>
"
You
have
left
him
this

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
For

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
do

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
I
told

jest
wot
passed

,

,
and
that

,
"
Can

?
"
<EOS>
and

,

,
"
Can

ten

?
<EOS>
"
and
that
I

"
Yes
"
to

.
 
<EOS>
That

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
His

was
so

that
it
plainly
WAS
all
.
   
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
he

,

?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,

;
"

that

,

is
,

do

.
 
<EOS>
No

,

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Will

,

?
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
With

,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

"

---

,

?
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,

,
"

.
   
<EOS>
"
You

"

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh

,

!
"

,
"
not

.
"
   
<EOS>
Although
he
pledged
himself
to
this
with
perfect
confidence
,
he
was
in
a
state
of
unbounded
astonishment
even
now
.
 
<EOS>
Martin
appeared
to
observe
it
,
and
to
have
some
sense
of
the
ludicrous
bearing
of
Mr
Tapley
under
these
perplexing
circumstances
;
for
,
in
spite
of
the
composure
of
his
voice
and
the
gravity
of
his
face
,
the
same
indistinct
light
flickered
on
the
latter
several
times
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
bestirred
himself
,
however
,
to
execute
the
offices
with
which
he
was
entrusted
;
and
soon
lost
all
tendency
to
any
outward
expression
of
his
surprise
,
in
the
occupation
of
being
brisk
and
busy
.
   
<EOS>
But
when
he
had
put
Mr
Chuzzlewit
's
clothes
in
good
order
for
dressing
,
and
when
that
gentleman
was
dressed
and
sitting
at
his
breakfast
,
Mr
Tapley
's
feelings
of
wonder
began
to
return
upon
him
with
great
violence
;
and
,
standing
beside
the
old
man
with
a
napkin
under
his
arm
(
it
was
as
natural
and
easy
to
joke
to
Mark
to
be
a
butler
in
the
Temple
,
as
it
had
been
to
volunteer
as
cook
on
board
the
Screw
)
,
he
found
it
difficult
to
resist
the
temptation
of
casting
sidelong
glances
at
him
very
often
.
 
<EOS>
Nay
,
he
found
it
impossible
;
and
accordingly
yielded
to
this
impulse
so
often
,
that
Martin
caught
him
in
the
fact
some
fifty
times
.
 
<EOS>
The
extraordinary
things
Mr
Tapley
did
with
his
own
face
when
any
of
these
detections
occurred
;
the
sudden
occasions
he
had
to
rub
his
eyes
or
his
nose
or
his
chin
;
the
look
of
wisdom
with
which
he
immediately
plunged
into
the
deepest
thought
,
or
became
intensely
interested
in
the
habits
and
customs
of
the
flies
upon
the
ceiling
,
or
the
sparrows
out
of
doors
;
or
the
overwhelming
politeness
with
which
he
endeavoured
to
hide
his
confusion
by
handing
the
muffin
;
may
not
unreasonably
be
assumed
to
have
exercised
the
utmost
power
of
feature
that
even
Martin
Chuzzlewit
the
elder
possessed
.
   
<EOS>
But
he
sat
perfectly
quiet
and
took
his
breakfast
at
his
leisure
,
or
made
a
show
of
doing
so
,
for
he
scarcely
ate
or
drank
,
and
frequently
lapsed
into
long
intervals
of
musing
.
 
<EOS>
When
he
had
finished
,
Mark
sat
down
to
his
breakfast
at
the
same
table
;
and
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
quite
silent
still
,
walked
up
and
down
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Mark
cleared
away
in
due
course
,
and
set
a
chair
out
for
him
,
in
which
,
as
the
time
drew
on
towards
ten
o'clock
,
he
took
his
seat
,
leaning
his
hands
upon
his
stick
,
and
clenching
them
upon
the
handle
,
and
resting
his
chin
on
them
again
.
 
<EOS>
All
his
impatience
and
abstraction
of
manner
had
vanished
now
;
and
as
he
sat
there
,
looking
,
with
his
keen
eyes
,
steadily
towards
the
door
,
Mark
could
not
help
thinking
what
a
firm
,
square
,
powerful
face
it
was
;
or
exulting
in
the
thought
that
Mr
Pecksniff
,
after
playing
a
pretty
long
game
of
bowls
with
its
owner
,
seemed
to
be
at
last
in
a
very
fair
way
of
coming
in
for
a
rubber
or
two
.
   
<EOS>
Mark
's
uncertainty
in
respect
of
what
was
going
to
be
done
or
said
,
and
by
whom
to
whom
,
would
have
excited
him
in
itself
.
 
<EOS>
But
knowing
for
a
certainty
besides
,
that
young
Martin
was
coming
,
and
in
a
very
few
minutes
must
arrive
<EOS>
,
he
found
it
by
no
means
easy
to
remain
quiet
and
silent
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
excepting
that
he
occasionally
coughed
in
a
hollow
and
unnatural
manner
to
relieve
himself
,
he
behaved
with
great
decorum
through
the
longest
ten
minutes
he
had
ever
known
.
   
<EOS>
A
knock
at
the
door
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Westlock
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Tapley
,
in
admitting
him
,
raised
his
eyebrows
to
the
highest
possible
pitch
,
implying
thereby
that
he
considered
himself
in
an
unsatisfactory
position
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
received
him
very
courteously
.
   
<EOS>
Mark
waited
at
the
door
for
Tom
Pinch
and
his
sister
,
who
were
coming
up
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
went
to
meet
them
;
took
their
hands
in
his
;
and
kissed
her
on
the
cheek
.
 
<EOS>
As
this
looked
promising
,
Mr
Tapley
smiled
benignantly
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
had
resumed
his
chair
before
young
Martin
,
who
was
close
behind
them
,
entered
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
scarcely
looking
at
him
,
pointed
to
a
distant
seat
.
 
<EOS>
This
was
less
encouraging
;
and
Mr
Tapley
's
spirits
fell
again
.
   
<EOS>
He
was
quickly
summoned
to
the
door
by
another
knock
.
 
<EOS>
He
did
not
start
,
or
cry
,
or
tumble
down
,
at
sight
of
Miss
Graham
and
Mrs
Lupin
,
but
he
drew
a
very
long
breath
,
and
came
back
perfectly
resigned
,
looking
on
them
and
on
the
rest
with
an
expression
which
seemed
to
say
that
nothing
could
surprise
him
any
more
;
and
that
he
was
rather
glad
to
have
done
with
that
sensation
for
ever
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
received
Mary
no
less
tenderly
than
he
had
received
Tom
Pinch
's
sister
.
 
<EOS>
A
look
of
friendly
recognition
passed
between
himself
and
Mrs
Lupin
,
which
implied
the
existence
of
a
perfect
understanding
between
them
.
 
<EOS>
It
engendered
no
astonishment
in
Mr
Tapley
;
for
,
as
he
afterwards
observed
,
he
had
retired
from
the
business
,
and
sold
off
the
stock
.
   
<EOS>
Not
the
least
curious
feature
in
this
assemblage
was
,
that
everybody
present
was
so
much
surprised
and
embarrassed
by
the
sight
of
everybody
else
,
that
nobody
ventured
to
speak
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
alone
broke
silence
.
   
<EOS>
"
Set
the
door
open
,
Mark
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
;
"
and
come
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mark
obeyed
.
   
<EOS>
The
last
appointed
footstep
sounded
now
upon
the
stairs
.
 
<EOS>
They
all
knew
it
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
Mr
Pecksniff
's
;
and
Mr
Pecksniff
was
in
a
hurry
too
,
for
he
came
bounding
up
with
such
uncommon
expedition
that
he
stumbled
twice
or
thrice
.
   
<EOS>
"
Where
is
my
venerable
friend
?
"
<EOS>
he
cried
upon
the
upper
landing
;
and
then
with
open
arms
came
darting
in
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
merely
looked
at
him
;
but
Mr
Pecksniff
started
back
as
if
he
had
received
the
charge
from
an
electric
battery
.
   
<EOS>
"
My
venerable
friend
is
well
?
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr
Pecksniff
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Quite
well
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
reassure
the
anxious
inquirer
.
 
<EOS>
He
clasped
his
hands
and
,
looking
upwards
with
a
pious
joy
,
silently
expressed
his
gratitude
.
 
<EOS>
He
then
looked
round
on
the
assembled
group
,
and
shook
his
head
reproachfully
.
 
<EOS>
For
such
a
man
severely
,
quite
severely
.
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
vermin
!
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
bloodsuckers
!
 
<EOS>
Is
it
not
enough
that
you
have
embittered
the
existence
of
an
individual
wholly
unparalleled
in
the
biographical
records
of
amiable
persons
,
but
must
you
now
,
even
now
,
when
he
has
made
his
election
,
and
reposed
his
trust
in
a
Numble
,
but
at
least
sincere
and
disinterested
relative
;
must
you
now
,
vermin
and
swarmers
(
I
regret
to
make
use
of
these
strong
expressions
,
my
dear
sir
,
but
there
are
times
when
honest
indignation
will
not
be
controlled
)
,
must
you
now
,
vermin
and
swarmers
(
for
I
WILL
repeat
it
)
,
take
advantage
of
his
unprotected
state
,
assemble
round
him
from
all
quarters
,
as
wolves
and
vultures
,
and
other
animals
of
the
feathered
tribe
assemble
round
---
I
will
not
say
round
carrion
or
a
carcass
,
for
Mr
Chuzzlewit
is
quite
the
contrary
---
but
round
their
prey
;
their
prey
;
to
rifle
and
despoil
;
gorging
their
voracious
maws
,
and
staining
their
offensive
beaks
,
with
every
description
of
carnivorous
enjoyment
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
he
stopped
to
fetch
his
breath
,
he
waved
them
off
,
in
a
solemn
manner
,
with
his
hand
.
   
<EOS>
"
Horde
of
unnatural
plunderers
and
robbers
!
"
<EOS>
he
continued
;
"
leave
him
!
<EOS>
leave
him
,
I
say
!
 
<EOS>
Begone
!
 
<EOS>
Abscond
!
 
<EOS>
You
had
better
be
off
!
<EOS>
Wander
over
the
face
of
the
earth
,
young
sirs
,
like
vagabonds
as
you
are
,
and
do
not
presume
to
remain
in
a
spot
which
is
hallowed
by
the
grey
hairs
of
the
patriarchal
gentleman
to
whose
tottering
limbs
<EOS>
I
have
the
honour
to
act
as
an
unworthy
,
but
I
hope
an
unassuming
,
prop
and
staff
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
,
my
tender
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
addressing
himself
in
a
tone
of
gentle
remonstrance
to
the
old
man
,
"
how
could
you
ever
leave
me
,
though
even
for
this
short
period
!
 
<EOS>
You
have
absented
yourself
<EOS>
,
I
do
not
doubt
,
upon
some
act
of
kindness
to
me
;
bless
you
for
it
;
but
you
must
not
do
it
;
you
must
not
be
so
venturesome
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
really
be
angry
with
you
if
I
could
,
my
friend
!
"
   
<EOS>
He
advanced
with
outstretched
arms
to
take
the
old
man
's
hand
.
 
<EOS>
But
he
had
not
seen
how
the
hand
clasped
and
clutched
the
stick
within
its
grasp
.
 
<EOS>
As
he
came
smiling
on
,
and
got
within
his
reach
,
old
Martin
,
with
his
burning
indignation
crowded
into
one
vehement
burst
,
and
flashing
out
of
every
line
and
wrinkle
in
his
face
,
rose
up
,
and
struck
him
down
upon
the
ground
.
   
<EOS>
With
such
a
well
-
directed
nervous
blow
,
that
down
he
went
,
as
heavily
and
true
as
if
the
charge
of
a
Life
-
Guardsman
had
tumbled
him
out
of
a
saddle
.
 
<EOS>
And
whether
he
was
stunned
by
the
shock
,
or
only
confused
by
the
wonder
and
novelty
of
this
warm
reception
,
he
did
not
offer
to
get
up
again
;
but
lay
there
,
looking
about
him
with
a
disconcerted
meekness
in
his
face
so
enormously
ridiculous
,
that
neither
Mark
Tapley
nor
John
Westlock
could
repress
a
smile
,
though
both
were
actively
interposing
to
prevent
a
repetition
of
the
blow
;
which
the
old
man
's
gleaming
eyes
and
vigorous
attitude
seemed
to
render
one
of
the
most
probable
events
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
"
Drag
him
away
!
 
<EOS>
Take
him
out
of
my
reach
!
"
<EOS>
said
Martin
;
"
or
I
ca
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
The
strong
restraint
I
have
put
upon
my
hands
has
been
enough
to
palsy
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
master
of
myself
while
he
is
within
their
range
.
 
<EOS>
Drag
him
away
!
"
   
<EOS>
Seeing
that
he
still
did
not
rise
,
Mr
Tapley
,
without
any
compromise
about
it
,
actually
did
drag
him
away
,
and
stick
him
up
on
the
floor
,
with
his
back
against
the
opposite
wall
.
   
<EOS>
"
Hear
me
,
rascal
!
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
summoned
you
here
to
witness
your
own
work
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
summoned
you
here
to
witness
it
,
because
I
know
it
will
be
gall
and
wormwood
to
you
!
 
<EOS>
I
have
summoned
you
here
to
witness
it
,
because
I
know
the
sight
of
everybody
here
must
be
a
dagger
in
your
mean
,
false
heart
!
 
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
do
you
know
me
as
I
am
,
at
last
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
had
cause
to
stare
at
him
,
for
the
triumph
in
his
face
and
speech
and
figure
was
a
sight
to
stare
at
.
   
<EOS>
"
Look
there
!
"
<EOS>
said
the
old
man
,
pointing
at
him
,
and
appealing
to
the
rest
.
 
<EOS>
"
Look
there
!
 
<EOS>
And
then
---
come
hither
,
<EOS>
my
dear
Martin
---
look
here
!
<EOS>
here
!
<EOS>
here
!
"
 
<EOS>
At
every
repetition
of
the
word
he
pressed
his
grandson
closer
to
his
breast
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
passion
I
felt
,
Martin
,
when
I
dared
not
do
this
,
"
he
said
,
"
was
in
the
blow
I
struck
just
now
.
 
<EOS>
Why
did
we
ever
part
!
 
<EOS>
How
could
we
ever
part
!
 
<EOS>
How
could
you
ever
fly
from
me
to
him
!
"
   
<EOS>
Martin
was
about
to
answer
,
but
he
stopped
him
,
and
went
on
.
   
<EOS>
"
The
fault
was
mine
no
less
than
yours
.
 
<EOS>
Mark
has
told
me
so
today
,
and
I
have
known
it
long
;
though
not
so
long
as
I
might
have
done
.
<EOS>
Mary
,
my
love
,
come
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
As
she
trembled
and
was
very
pale
,
he
sat
her
in
his
own
chair
,
and
stood
beside
it
with
her
hand
in
his
;
and
Martin
standing
by
him
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
curse
of
our
house
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
looking
kindly
down
upon
her
,
"
has
been
the
love
of
self
;
has
ever
been
the
love
of
self
.
<EOS>
How
often
have
I
said
so
,
when
I
never
knew
that
I
had
wrought
it
upon
others
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
drew
one
hand
through
Martin
's
arm
,
and
standing
so
,
between
them
,
proceeded
thus
:
   
<EOS>
"
You
all
know
how
I
bred
this
orphan
up
,
to
tend
me
.
 
<EOS>
None
of
you
can
know
by
what
degrees
<EOS>
I
have
come
to
regard
her
as
a
daughter
;
for
she
has
won
upon
me
,
by
her
self
-
forgetfulness
,
her
tenderness
,
her
patience
,
all
the
goodness
of
her
nature
,
when
Heaven
is
her
witness
that
I
took
but
little
pains
to
draw
it
forth
.
 
<EOS>
It
blossomed
without
cultivation
,
and
it
ripened
without
heat
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
find
it
in
my
heart
to
say
that
I
am
sorry
for
it
now
,
or
yonder
fellow
might
be
holding
up
his
head
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
put
his
hand
into
his
waistcoat
,
and
slightly
shook
that
part
of
him
to
which
allusion
had
been
made
;
as
if
to
signify
that
it
was
still
uppermost
.
   
<EOS>
"
There
is
a
kind
of
selfishness
,
"
said
Martin
---
"
I
have
learned
it
in
my
own
experience
of
my
own
breast
---
which
is
constantly
upon
the
watch
for
selfishness
in
others
;
and
holding
others
at
a
distance
,
by
suspicions
and
distrusts
,
wonders
why
they
do
n't
approach
,
and
do
n't
confide
,
and
calls
that
selfishness
in
them
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
I
once
doubted
those
about
me
---
not
without
reason
in
the
beginning
---
and
thus
I
once
doubted
you
,
Martin
.
"
   
"
Not
without
reason
,
"
Martin
answered
,
"
either
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Listen
,
hypocrite
!
 
<EOS>
Listen
,
smooth
-
tongued
,
servile
,
<EOS>
crawling
knave
!
"
said
Martin
.
 
<EOS>
"
Listen
,
you
shallow
dog
.
 
<EOS>
What
!
 
<EOS>
When
I
was
seeking
him
,
you
had
already
spread
your
nets
;
you
were
already
fishing
for
him
,
were
ye
?
 
<EOS>
When
I
lay
ill
in
this
good
woman
's
house
and
your
meek
spirit
pleaded
for
my
grandson
,
you
had
already
caught
him
,
had
ye
?
 
<EOS>
Counting
on
the
restoration
of
the
love
you
knew
I
bore
him
,
you
designed
him
for
one
of
your
two
daughters
<EOS>
did
ye
?
 
<EOS>
Or
failing
that
,
you
traded
in
him
as
a
speculation
which
at
any
rate
should
blind
me
with
the
lustre
of
your
charity
,
and
found
a
claim
upon
me
!
 
<EOS>
Why
,
even
then
I
knew
you
,
and
I
told
you
so
.
 
<EOS>
Did
I
tell
you
that
I
knew
you
,
even
then
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
angry
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Pecksniff
,
softly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
bear
a
great
deal
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
will
never
contradict
you
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
<EOS>
"
   
"
Observe
!
"
<EOS>
said
Martin
,
looking
round
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
put
myself
in
that
man
's
hands
on
terms
as
mean
and
base
,
and
as
degrading
to
himself
,
as
I
could
render
them
in
words
.
 
<EOS>
I
stated
them
at
length
to
him
,
before
his
own
children
,
syllable
by
syllable
,
as
coarsely
as
I
could
,
and
with
as
much
offence
,
and
with
as
plain
an
exposition
of
my
contempt
,
as
words
---
not
looks
and
manner
merely
---
could
convey
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
only
called
the
angry
blood
into
his
face
,
I
would
have
wavered
in
my
purpose
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
only
stung
him
into
being
a
man
for
a
minute
I
would
have
abandoned
it
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
offered
me
one
word
of
remonstrance
,
in
favour
of
the
grandson
whom
he
supposed
I
had
disinherited
;
if
he
had
pleaded
with
me
,
though
never
so
faintly
,
against
my
appeal
to
him
to
abandon
him
to
misery
and
cast
him
from
his
house
;
I
think
I
could
have
borne
with
him
for
ever
afterwards
.
<EOS>
But
not
a
word
,
not
a
word
.
 
<EOS>
Pandering
to
the
worst
of
human
passions
was
the
office
of
his
nature
;
and
faithfully
he
did
his
work
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
angry
,
"
observed
Mr
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
hurt
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
;
wounded
in
my
feelings
;
but
I
am
not
angry
,
my
good
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
resumed
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Once
resolved
to
try
him
,
I
was
resolute
to
pursue
the
trial
to
the
end
;
but
while
I
was
bent
on
fathoming
the
depth
of
his
duplicity
,
I
made
a
sacred
compact
with
myself
that
I
would
give
him
credit
on
the
other
side
for
any
latent
spark
of
goodness
,
honour
,
forbearance
---
any
virtue
---
that
might
glimmer
in
him
.
 
<EOS>
For
first
to
last
there
has
been
no
such
thing
.
 
<EOS>
Not
once
.
 
<EOS>
He
can
not
say
I
have
not
given
him
opportunity
.
 
<EOS>
He
can
not
say
I
have
ever
led
him
on
.
<EOS>
He
can
not
say
I
have
not
left
him
freely
to
himself
in
all
things
;
or
that
I
have
not
been
a
passive
instrument
in
his
hands
,
which
he
might
have
used
for
good
as
easily
as
evil
.
 
<EOS>
Or
if
he
can
,
he
Lies
!
<EOS>
And
that
's
his
nature
,
too
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
interrupted
Pecksniff
,
shedding
tears
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
angry
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not
be
angry
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
But
did
you
never
,
my
dear
sir
,
express
a
desire
that
the
unnatural
young
man
who
by
his
wicked
arts
has
estranged
your
good
opinion
from
me
,
for
the
time
being
;
only
for
the
time
being
;
that
your
grandson
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
should
be
dismissed
my
house
?
 
<EOS>
Recollect
yourself
,
my
Christian
friend
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
so
,
have
I
not
?
"
retorted
the
old
man
,
sternly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
tell
how
far
your
specious
hypocrisy
had
deceived
him
,
knave
;
and
knew
no
better
way
of
opening
his
eyes
than
by
presenting
you
before
him
in
your
own
servile
character
.
 
<EOS>
Yes
.
 
<EOS>
I
did
express
that
desire
.
 
<EOS>
And
you
leaped
to
meet
it
;
and
you
met
it
;
and
turning
in
an
instant
on
the
hand
you
had
licked
and
beslavered
,
as
only
such
hounds
can
,
you
strengthened
,
and
confirmed
,
and
justified
me
in
my
scheme
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
made
a
bow
;
a
submissive
,
not
to
say
a
grovelling
and
an
abject
bow
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
complimented
on
his
practice
of
the
loftiest
virtues
,
he
never
could
have
bowed
as
he
bowed
then
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
wretched
man
who
has
been
murdered
,
"
Mr
Chuzzlewit
went
on
to
say
;
"
then
passing
by
the
name
of
---
"
   
"
Tigg
,
"
suggested
Mark
.
   
<EOS>
"
Of
Tigg
;
brought
begging
messages
to
me
on
behalf
of
a
friend
of
his
,
and
an
unworthy
relative
of
mine
;
and
finding
him
a
man
well
enough
suited
to
my
purpose
<EOS>
,
I
employed
him
to
glean
some
news
of
you
,
Martin
,
for
me
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
from
him
I
learned
that
you
had
taken
up
your
abode
with
yonder
fellow
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
he
,
who
meeting
you
here
in
town
,
one
evening
<EOS>
---
you
remember
where
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
At
the
pawnbroker
's
shop
,
"
said
Martin
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
watched
you
to
your
lodging
,
and
enabled
me
to
send
you
a
bank
-
note
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
little
thought
,
"
said
Martin
,
greatly
moved
,
"
that
it
had
come
from
you
;
<EOS>
I
little
thought
that
you
were
interested
in
my
fate
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
had
---
"
   
"
If
you
had
,
"
returned
the
old
man
,
sorrowfully
,
"
you
would
have
shown
less
knowledge
of
me
as
I
seemed
to
be
,
and
as
I
really
was
.
<EOS>
I
hoped
to
bring
you
back
,
Martin
,
penitent
and
humbled
.
 
<EOS>
I
hoped
to
distress
you
into
coming
back
to
me
.
 
<EOS>
Much
as
I
loved
you
,
I
had
that
to
acknowledge
which
I
could
not
reconcile
it
to
myself
to
avow
,
then
,
unless
you
made
submission
to
me
first
.
 
<EOS>
Thus
it
was
I
lost
you
.
 
<EOS>
If
I
have
had
,
indirectly
,
any
act
or
part
in
the
fate
of
that
unhappy
man
,
by
putting
means
,
however
small
,
within
his
reach
,
Heaven
forgive
me
!
 
<EOS>
I
might
have
known
,
perhaps
,
that
he
would
misuse
money
;
that
it
was
ill
-
bestowed
upon
him
;
and
that
sown
by
his
hands
it
could
engender
mischief
only
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
never
thought
of
him
at
that
time
as
having
the
disposition
or
ability
to
be
a
serious
impostor
,
or
otherwise
than
as
a
thoughtless
,
idle
-
humoured
,
dissipated
spendthrift
,
sinning
more
against
himself
than
others
,
and
frequenting
low
haunts
and
indulging
vicious
tastes
,
to
his
own
ruin
only
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Beggin
'
your
pardon
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
who
had
Mrs
Lupin
on
his
arm
by
this
time
,
quite
agreeably
;
"
if
I
may
make
so
bold
as
say
so
,
my
opinion
is
,
as
you
was
quite
correct
,
and
that
he
turned
out
perfectly
nat'ral
for
all
that
.
 
<EOS>
There
's
surprisin
'
number
of
men
sir
,
who
as
long
as
they
've
only
got
their
own
shoes
and
stockings
to
depend
upon
,
will
walk
down
hill
,
along
the
gutters
quiet
enough
and
by
themselves
,
and
not
do
much
harm
.
 
<EOS>
But
set
any
on
'em
up
with
a
coach
and
horses
,
sir
;
and
it
's
wonderful
what
a
knowledge
of
drivin
'
he
'll
show
,
and
how
he
'll
fill
his
wehicle
with
passengers
,
and
start
off
in
the
middle
of
the
road
,
neck
or
nothing
,
to
the
Devil
!
 
<EOS>
Bless
your
heart
,
sir
,
there
's
ever
so
many
Tiggs
a
-
passin
'
<EOS>
this
here
Temple
-
gate
any
hour
in
the
day
,
<EOS>
that
only
want
a
chance
to
turn
out
full
-
blown
Montagues
every
one
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
ignorance
,
as
you
call
it
,
Mark
,
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
is
wiser
than
some
men
's
enlightenment
,
and
mine
among
them
.
 
<EOS>
You
are
right
;
not
for
the
first
time
to
-
day
.
 
<EOS>
Now
hear
me
out
,
my
dears
.
<EOS>
And
hear
me
,
you
,
who
,
if
what
I
have
been
told
be
accurately
stated
,
are
Bankrupt
in
pocket
no
less
than
in
good
name
!
 
<EOS>
And
when
you
have
heard
me
,
leave
this
place
,
and
poison
my
sight
no
more
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mr
Pecksniff
laid
his
hand
upon
his
breast
,
and
bowed
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
penance
I
have
done
in
this
house
,
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
has
earned
this
reflection
with
it
constantly
,
above
all
others
.
 
<EOS>
That
if
it
had
pleased
Heaven
to
visit
such
infirmity
on
my
old
age
as
really
had
reduced
me
to
the
state
in
which
I
feigned
to
be
,
I
should
have
brought
its
misery
upon
myself
.
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
whose
wealth
,
like
mine
,
has
been
a
source
of
continual
unhappiness
,
leading
you
to
distrust
the
nearest
and
dearest
,
and
to
dig
yourself
a
living
grave
of
suspicion
and
reserve
;
take
heed
that
,
having
cast
off
all
whom
you
might
have
bound
to
you
,
and
tenderly
,
you
do
not
become
in
your
decay
the
instrument
of
such
a
man
as
this
,
and
waken
in
another
world
to
the
knowledge
of
such
wrong
as
would
embitter
Heaven
itself
,
if
wrong
or
<EOS>
you
could
ever
reach
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
And
then
he
told
them
how
he
had
sometimes
thought
,
in
the
beginning
,
that
love
might
grow
up
between
Mary
and
Martin
;
and
how
he
had
pleased
his
fancy
with
the
picture
of
observing
it
when
it
was
new
,
and
taking
them
to
task
,
apart
,
in
counterfeited
doubt
,
and
then
confessing
to
them
that
it
had
been
an
object
dear
to
his
heart
;
and
by
his
sympathy
with
them
,
and
generous
provision
for
their
young
fortunes
,
establishing
a
claim
on
their
affection
and
regard
which
nothing
should
wither
,
and
which
should
surround
his
old
age
with
means
of
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
How
in
the
first
dawn
of
this
design
,
and
when
the
pleasure
of
such
a
scheme
for
the
happiness
of
others
was
new
and
indistinct
within
him
,
Martin
had
come
to
tell
him
that
he
had
already
chosen
for
himself
;
knowing
that
he
,
the
old
man
,
had
some
faint
project
on
that
head
,
but
ignorant
whom
it
concerned
.
 
<EOS>
How
it
was
little
comfort
to
him
to
know
that
Martin
had
chosen
Her
,
because
the
grace
of
his
design
was
lost
,
and
because
finding
that
she
had
returned
his
love
,
he
tortured
himself
with
the
reflection
that
they
,
so
young
,
to
whom
he
had
been
so
kind
a
benefactor
,
were
already
like
the
world
,
and
bent
on
their
own
selfish
,
stealthy
ends
.
 
<EOS>
How
in
the
bitterness
of
this
impression
,
and
of
his
past
experience
,
he
had
reproached
Martin
so
harshly
(
forgetting
that
he
had
never
invited
his
confidence
on
such
a
point
,
and
confounding
what
he
had
meant
to
do
with
what
he
had
done
)
,
that
high
words
sprung
up
between
them
,
and
they
separated
in
wrath
.
 
<EOS>
How
he
loved
him
still
,
and
hoped
he
would
return
.
 
<EOS>
How
on
the
night
of
his
illness
at
the
Dragon
,
he
had
secretly
written
tenderly
of
him
,
and
made
him
his
heir
,
and
sanctioned
his
marriage
with
Mary
;
and
how
,
after
his
interview
with
Mr
Pecksniff
,
he
had
distrusted
him
again
,
and
burnt
the
paper
to
ashes
,
and
had
lain
down
in
his
bed
distracted
by
suspicions
,
doubts
,
and
regrets
.
   
<EOS>
And
then
he
told
them
how
,
resolved
to
probe
this
Pecksniff
,
and
to
prove
the
constancy
and
truth
of
Mary
(
to
himself
no
less
than
Martin
)
,
he
had
conceived
and
entered
on
his
plan
;
and
how
,
beneath
her
gentleness
and
patience
,
he
had
softened
more
and
more
;
still
more
and
more
beneath
the
goodness
and
simplicity
,
the
honour
and
the
manly
faith
of
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
he
spoke
of
Tom
,
he
said
God
bless
him
;
and
the
tears
were
in
his
eyes
;
for
he
said
that
Tom
,
mistrusted
and
disliked
by
him
at
first
,
had
come
like
summer
rain
upon
his
heart
;
and
had
disposed
it
to
believe
in
better
things
.
<EOS>
And
Martin
took
him
by
the
hand
,
and
Mary
too
,
and
John
,
his
old
friend
,
stoutly
too
;
and
Mark
,
and
Mrs
Lupin
,
and
his
sister
,
little
Ruth
.
 
<EOS>
And
peace
of
mind
,
<EOS>
deep
,
tranquil
peace
of
mind
,
was
in
Tom
's
heart
.
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
then
related
how
nobly
Mr
Pecksniff
had
performed
the
duty
in
which
he
stood
indebted
to
society
,
in
the
matter
of
Tom
's
dismissal
;
and
how
,
having
often
heard
disparagement
of
Mr
Westlock
from
Pecksniffian
lips
,
and
knowing
him
to
be
a
friend
to
Tom
,
he
had
used
,
through
his
confidential
agent
and
solicitor
,
that
little
artifice
which
had
kept
him
in
readiness
to
receive
his
unknown
friend
in
London
.
 
<EOS>
And
he
called
on
Mr
Pecksniff
(
by
the
name
of
Scoundrel
)
to
remember
that
there
again
he
had
not
trapped
him
to
do
evil
,
but
that
he
had
done
it
of
his
own
free
will
and
agency
;
nay
,
that
he
had
cautioned
him
against
it
.
 
<EOS>
And
once
again
he
called
on
Mr
Pecksniff
<EOS>
(
by
the
name
of
Hang
-
dog
)
to
remember
that
when
Martin
coming
home
at
last
,
an
altered
man
,
had
sued
for
the
forgiveness
which
awaited
him
,
he
,
Pecksniff
,
had
rejected
him
in
language
of
his
own
,
and
had
remorsely
stepped
in
between
him
and
the
least
touch
of
natural
tenderness
.
 
<EOS>
"
For
which
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
if
the
bending
of
my
finger
would
remove
a
halter
from
your
neck
,
I
would
n't
bend
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Martin
,
"
he
added
,
"
your
rival
has
not
been
a
dangerous
one
,
but
Mrs
Lupin
here
has
played
duenna
for
some
weeks
;
not
so
much
to

<EOS>

"
---

"

.
 
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
See

.
"
   
<EOS>
Hold

!
 
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
Well

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
His

his

.
   
<EOS>

door

,

"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
   
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
You

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mine

.
 
<EOS>
I

.
 
<EOS>

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
Here

,

.
   
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
No

"

.

"

,
"

,
"
with

(
which

knobs
upon

)
,
on
that
delicate

---
the
brain
.
<EOS>
Several

,

,
without
a

,

that

of

---
my

.
 
<EOS>
You

,

,

in

.
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
I

.
 
<EOS>
By

,

,

;
at

,

when
the

of

,

.

.

into

.
 
<EOS>
She

,

.
   
<EOS>
"
Which
,

"

,
"

Mrs
Harris

liberal

<EOS>
Chapter
53
.
<EOS>
What
John
Westlock

Brilliantly
the
Temple
Fountain
sparkled
in

,
and
laughingly
its

played
,

,

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
And

at

<EOS>

;
for

.
 
<EOS>
It

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
They

,

---
with
Love
,

out

.
   
<EOS>

,
but

.
 
<EOS>
Because
,

,

,

<EOS>
However
,

.

;

.
 
<EOS>
We

.
   
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
With

,
"

<EOS>
"
So

!
"
   
<EOS>
Oh

!
   
<EOS>
They

.
 
<EOS>
The

was

;

---

---

.
 
<EOS>
Then
,

,

,

!
 
<EOS>
Why

,

foot

<EOS>
Through

,

;

.
<EOS>
There

;

---

---

---
 
across

,

said
he
owed

.
 
<EOS>
Celestial

!
   
<EOS>
Green

,

no

,

,

,

---
<EOS>
now

---
they

!
 
<EOS>
Oh

!
 
<EOS>
For

,

,

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

.
 
<EOS>
Fiery
Face
,
Fiery
Face
,

'

NOW
!
   
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
He

;

.
 
<EOS>
Oh

,
you

<EOS>
Why

,

<EOS>
"

!
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
 
<EOS>

---

---

,

.
 
<EOS>
Darling

!
 
<EOS>
My

!
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
