she
sobbed
,
"
than
you
make
me
.
 
<EOS>
No
one
can
be
happier
,
John
,
than
you
make
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Fiery
Face
,
provide
yourself
!
 
<EOS>
The
usual
wages
or
the
usual
warning
.
<EOS>
It
's
all
over
,
Fiery
Face
.
 
<EOS>
We
need
n't
trouble
you
any
further
.
   
<EOS>
The
little
hands
could
meet
each
other
now
,
without
a
rampant
horse
to
urge
them
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
occasion
for
lions
,
bears
,
or
mad
bulls
.
<EOS>
It
could
all
be
done
,
and
infinitely
better
,
without
their
assistance
.
 
<EOS>
No
burly
drayman
or
big
butts
of
beer
,
were
wanted
for
apologies
.
 
<EOS>
No
apology
at
all
was
wanted
.
 
<EOS>
The
soft
light
touch
fell
coyly
,
but
quite
naturally
,
upon
the
lover
's
shoulder
;
the
delicate
waist
,
the
drooping
head
,
the
blushing
cheek
,
the
beautiful
eyes
,
the
exquisite
mouth
itself
,
were
all
as
natural
as
possible
.
 
<EOS>
If
all
the
horses
in
Araby
had
run
away
at
once
,
they
could
n't
have
improved
upon
it
.
   
<EOS>
They
soon
began
to
talk
of
Tom
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
will
be
glad
to
hear
of
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
John
,
with
sparkling
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
Ruth
drew
the
little
hands
a
little
tighter
when
he
said
it
,
and
looked
up
seriously
into
his
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
never
to
leave
him
,
AM
I
,
dear
?
 
<EOS>
I
could
never
leave
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
you
know
that
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
I
would
ask
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
returned
,
with
a
---
well
!
 
<EOS>
Never
mind
with
what
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
never
would
,
"
she
answered
,
the
bright
tears
standing
in
her
eyes
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
will
swear
it
,
Ruth
,
my
darling
,
if
you
please
.
 
<EOS>
Leave
Tom
!
<EOS>
That
would
be
a
strange
beginning
.
 
<EOS>
Leave
Tom
,
dear
!
 
<EOS>
If
Tom
and
we
be
not
inseparable
,
and
Tom
(
God
bless
him
)
have
not
all
honour
and
all
love
in
our
home
,
my
little
wife
,
may
that
home
never
be
!
 
<EOS>
And
that
's
a
strong
oath
,
Ruth
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
Shall
it
be
recorded
how
she
thanked
him
?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,
it
shall
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
simplicity
and
innocence
and
purity
of
heart
,
yet
with
a
timid
,
graceful
,
half
-
determined
hesitation
,
she
set
a
little
rosy
seal
upon
the
vow
,
whose
colour
was
reflected
in
her
face
,
and
flashed
up
to
the
braiding
of
her
dark
brown
hair
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
will
be
so
happy
,
and
so
proud
,
and
glad
,
"
she
said
,
clasping
her
little
hands
.
 
<EOS>
"
But
so
surprised
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
sure
he
had
never
thought
of
such
a
thing
.
"
   
<EOS>
Of
course
John
asked
her
immediately
---
because
you
know
they
were
in
that
foolish
state
when
great
allowances
must
be
made
---
when
SHE
had
begun
to
think
of
such
a
thing
,
and
this
made
a
little
diversion
in
their
talk
;
a
charming

to
them
,
but
not
so
interesting
to
us
;
at
the
end
of
which
,
they
came
back
to
Tom
again
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
dear
Tom
!
"
said
Ruth
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
ought
to
tell
you
everything
now
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
have
no
secrets
from
you
.
 
<EOS>
Should
I
,
John
,
love
?
"
   
<EOS>
It
is
of
no
use
saying
how
that
preposterous
John
answered
her
,
because
he
answered
in
a
manner
which
is
untranslatable
on
paper
though
highly
satisfactory
in

.
 
<EOS>
But
what
he
conveyed
was
,
No
no
no
,
sweet
Ruth
;
or
something
to
that
effect
.
   
<EOS>
Then
she
told
him
Tom
's
great
secret
;
not
exactly
saying
how
she
had
found
it
out
,
but
leaving
him
to
understand
it
if
he
liked
;
and
John
was
sadly
grieved
to
hear
it
,
and
was
full
of
sympathy
and
sorrow
.
<EOS>
But
they
would
try
,
he
said
,
only
the
more
,
on
this
account
to
make
him
happy
,
and
to
beguile
him
with
his
favourite
pursuits
.
 
<EOS>
And
then
,
in
all
the
confidence
of
such
a
time
,
he
told
her
how
he
had
a
capital
opportunity
of
establishing
himself
in
his
old
profession
in
the
country
;
and
how
he
had
been
thinking
,
in
the
event
of
that
happiness
coming
upon
him
which
had
actually
come
---
there
was
another
slight
diversion
here
<EOS>
---
how
he
had
been
thinking
that
it
would
afford
occupation
to
Tom
,
and
enable
them
to
live
together
in
the
easiest

,
without
any
sense
of
dependence
on
Tom
's

;
and
to
be
as

as
the
day
was
long
.
 
<EOS>
And
Ruth
receiving
this
with
joy
,
they
went
on
catering
for
Tom
to
that
extent
that
they
had
already
purchased
him
a
select
library
and
built
him
an
organ
,
on
which
he
was
performing
with
the
greatest
satisfaction
,
when
they
heard
him
knocking
at
the
door
.
   
<EOS>
Though
she
longed
to
tell
him
what
had
happened
,
poor
little
Ruth
was
greatly
agitated
by

;
the
more
so
because
she
knew
that
Mr
Chuzzlewit
was
with

.
 
<EOS>
So
she
said
,
all
in
a

:
   
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
do
,
dear
John
!
 
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
that
he
should
hear
it
from
any
one
but
me
,
and
I
could
not
tell
him
,
unless
we

alone
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Do
,
my
love
,
"
said
John
,
"
whatever
is
natural
to
you
on
the
impulse
of
the
moment
,
and
I
am
sure
it
will
be
right
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
had
hardly
time
to
say
thus
much
,
and
Ruth
had
hardly
time
to
---
 
just
to
get
a
little
farther
off
---
upon
the
sofa
,
when
Tom
and
Mr
Chuzzlewit
came
in
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
came
first
,
and
Tom
was
a

.
   
<EOS>
Now
Ruth
had
hastily
resolved
that
she
would
beckon
Tom
upstairs
after
a

,
and
would
tell
him
in
his

.
 
<EOS>
But
when
she

his
dear
old

,
her

so

that
she
ran

,
and
laid

,
"
Bless

,
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
My
dearest
brother
!
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
looked
up
,
in
surprise
,
and
saw
John
Westlock
close

,
holding
out

.
   
<EOS>
"
John
!
"
cried
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
"
John
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Dear
Tom
,
"
said
his
friend
,
"
give
me

hand
.
 
<EOS>
We
are
brothers
,
Tom
.
"
   
<EOS>
Tom
wrung
it
with
all

,
embraced

,
and
put
her
in
John
Westlock
's

.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
to
me
,
John
.
 
<EOS>
Heaven
is
very
good
to
us
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
"
 
<EOS>
Tom
could
find
no
further
utterance
,
but
left

;
and
Ruth

after

.
   
<EOS>
And
when
they

back
,
which
they
did
by
-
and

bye
,
she
looked
more

,
and
Tom
more

(

)
than

.
 
<EOS>
And
though
Tom
could
not
speak
upon
the
subject
even
now
;
being
yet
too

,
he
put
both
his
hands
in
both
of
John
's
with
emphasis
sufficient
for
the
best
speech
ever
spoken
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
chose
to
-

,
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
to

;
with

knowing

when

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
.
<EOS>
I
hoped
Tom
<EOS>
and
I
lingered
behind
a
discreet

.
 
<EOS>
It
's
so
long

any

of

,
that
I
have

anxious
,
I

.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your

is

pretty

,

,
"

John
,

"
<EOS>
if

led

-

.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I

,
Mr
Westlock
,
"
said

,
"
that

was
needed
,
after

you

Ruth
together
.
<EOS>
Come

,

.
 
<EOS>
See

Tom

purchased
this

,
while
you

in

that
young

there
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
old
man
's

seating

,

as

,
was

,
but
full

,
and

,

,
to

.
   
<EOS>
"
See

!
"
<EOS>

,

,
"
what

.
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
How

!
 
<EOS>
Earrings
,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
This

yours
,

Mary

.
 
<EOS>
Tom
could
n't

I
wanted
two
.
<EOS>
What
a
short
-
sighted
Tom
!
 
<EOS>
Earrings
and
bracelets
,
and
a
zone
for
your
waist
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
Beautiful
!
 
<EOS>
Let

how
brave

look
.
<EOS>
Ask
Mr
Westlock
to
clasp

on
.
"
   
<EOS>
It
was
the
prettiest
thing
to
see
her
holding

round
,
white

;
and
John
(
oh
deep
,
deep
John
!
)
<EOS>
pretending
that
the

was
very
hard

;

,
and
yet

have

because

;

to

,

,

;

that

,
in
the

,
rely

.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
set

and
the

are
so
well

,
"
said

old

,
"
that
I

n't

.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Westlock
could
tell
me
,
I

,
but
I
'll

,
for

.
 
<EOS>
Health
to
wear

,
my
dear
,
and
happiness

forgetful
of

,
except

from

!
"
   
<EOS>
He
patted
her
upon
the

,
and
said
to
Tom
:
   
<EOS>
"
I
must
play
the
part
of

father

,
Tom
,
also
.
 
<EOS>
There
are
not
many
fathers
who
marry
two
such

on
the
same

;
but
we
will
overlook
the

for

of
an
old

's

.
 
<EOS>
I
may
claim
that
much
indulgence
,
"
he
added
,
"
for
I
have
gratified
few
fancies
enough
in
my
life
tending
to
the
happiness
of
others
,
Heaven
knows
!
"
   
<EOS>
These
various
proceedings
had
occupied
so
much
time
,
and
they
fell
into
such
a
pleasant
conversation
now
,
that
it
was
within
a
quarter
of
an
hour
of
the
time
appointed
for
dinner
before
any
of
them
thought
about
it
.
 
<EOS>
A
hackney
-
coach
soon
carried
them
to
the
Temple
,
however
;
and
there
they
found
everything
prepared
for
their
reception
,
   
Mr
Tapley
having
been
furnished
with
unlimited
credentials
relative
to
the
ordering
of
dinner
,
had
so
exerted
himself
for
the
honour
of
the
party
,
that
a
prodigious
banquet
was
served
,
under
the
joint
direction
of
himself
and
his
Intended
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
would
have
had
them
of
the
party
,
and
Martin
urgently
seconded
his
wish
,
but
Mark
could
by
no
means
be
persuaded
to
sit
down
at
table
;
observing
,
that
in
having
the
honour
of
attending
to
their
comforts
,
he
felt
himself
,
indeed
,
the
landlord
of
the
Jolly
Tapley
,
and
could
almost
delude
himself
into
the
belief
that
the
entertainment
was
actually
being
held
under
the
Jolly
Tapley
's
roof
.
   
<EOS>
For
the
better
encouragement
of
himself
in
this
fable
,
Mr
Tapley
took
it
upon
him
to
issue
divers
general
directions
to
the
waiters
from
the
hotel
,
relative
to
the
disposal
of
the
dishes
and
so
forth
;
and
as
they
were
usually
in
direct
opposition
to
all
precedent
,
and
were
always
issued
in
his
most
facetious
form
of
thought
and
speech
,
they
occasioned
great
merriment
among
those
attendants
;
in
which
Mr
Tapley
participated
,
with
an
infinite
enjoyment
of
his
own
humour
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
entertained
them
with
short
anecdotes
of
his
travels
appropriate
to
the
occasion
;
and
now
and
then
with
some
comic
passage
or
other
between
himself
and
Mrs
Lupin
;
so
that
explosive
laughs
were
constantly
issuing
from
the
side
-
board
,
and
from
the
backs
of
chairs
;
and
the
head
-
waiter
(
who
wore
powder
,
and
knee
-
smalls
,
and
was
usually
a
grave
man
)
got
to
be
a
bright
scarlet
in
the
face
,
and
broke
his
waistcoat
-
strings
audibly
.
   
<EOS>
Young
Martin
sat
at
the
head
of
the
table
,
and
Tom
Pinch
at
the
foot
;
and
if
there
were
a
genial
face
at
that
board
,
it
was
Tom
's
.
<EOS>
They
all
took
their
tone
from
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
drank
to
him
,
everybody
looked
to
him
,
everybody
thought
of
him
,
everybody
loved
him
.
 
<EOS>
If
he
so
much
as
laid
down
his

and

,
somebody

to

.
 
<EOS>
Martin

had

,
and
spoken

so

of
the

,

in

,
by
his

,
that
Tom
was

.
 
<EOS>
He
could
n't
bear

.
 
<EOS>
His
heart
was
full
,
he

,
of
happiness
.
 
<EOS>
And

was
.
 
<EOS>
Tom
spoke
the

.
 
<EOS>
It
was
.
 
<EOS>
Large

thy
heart
was
,
<EOS>
dear
Tom
Pinch
,

that

!
   
<EOS>
And
there
was
Fips
,
old
Fips
of

,
present

,
and

that
ever

by

<EOS>

?
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Well

<EOS>

Chapter
54
.
<EOS>
Gives

.
 
<EOS>
For

is
the
last
in

book
 
<EOS>
Todger
's
was
in
high
feather
,
and
mighty
preparations
for
a
late
breakfast
were
astir
in
its
commercial
bowers
.
 
<EOS>
The
blissful
morning
had
arrived
when
Miss
Pecksniff
was
to
be
united
in
holy
matrimony
,
to
Augustus
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
was
in
a
frame
of
mind
equally
becoming
to
herself
and
the
occasion
.
 
<EOS>
She
was
full
of
clemency
and
conciliation
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
laid
in
several
caldrons
of
live
coals
,
and
was
prepared
to
heap
them
on
the
heads
of
her
enemies
.
 
<EOS>
She
bore
no
spite
nor
malice
in
her
heart
.
 
<EOS>
Not
the
least
.
   
<EOS>
Quarrels
,
Miss
Pecksniff
said
,
were
dreadful
things
in
families
;
and
though
she
never
could
forgive
her
dear
papa
,
she
was
willing
to
receive
her
other
relations
.
 
<EOS>
They
had
been
separated
,
she
observed
,
too
long
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
enough
to
call
down
a
judgment
upon
the
family
.
<EOS>
She
believed
the
death
of
Jonas
WAS
a
judgment
on
them
for
their
internal
dissensions
.
 
<EOS>
And
Miss
Pecksniff
was
confirmed
in
this
belief
,
by
the
lightness
with
which
the
visitation
had
fallen
on

.
   
<EOS>
By
way
of
doing
sacrifice
---
not

;
not
,

course
,

,
but
in
humiliation

---
this

person
wrote
,
therefore
,
to
her
kinswoman
of
the
strong
mind
,
and
informed
her
that
her
nuptials
would
take
place
on
such
a
day
.
 
<EOS>
That
she
had
been
much
hurt
by
the
unnatural
conduct
of
herself
and
daughters
,
and
hoped
they
might
not
have
suffered
in
their
consciences
.
 
<EOS>
That
,
being
desirous
to
forgive
her
enemies
,
and
make
her
peace
with
the
world
before
entering
into
the
most
solemn
of
covenants
with
the
most
devoted
of
men
,
she
now
held
out
the
hand
of
friendship
.
 
<EOS>
That
if
the
strong
-
minded
women
took
that
hand
,
in
the
temper
in
which
it
was
extended
to
her
,
she
,
Miss
Pecksniff
,
did

her
to

,

red

,
her

(
but

)
,

.
   
<EOS>
The

women
returned

,
that
herself

daughters
were
,
as
regarded

,
in

,

.
<EOS>
That

<EOS>

,

,

SO
VERY
UNEXPECTED
---

---
SO
VERY

.
   
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Old
Chuffey
.

,

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

;

.
   
<EOS>

I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
judged
you
cruelly
.
 
<EOS>
Let
me
know
that
I
have
your
forgiveness
.
"
   
<EOS>
She
kissed
his
hand
again
;
and
retaining
it
in
hers
,
thanked
him
in
a
broken
voice
,
for
all
his
kindness
to
her
since
.
   
<EOS>
"
Tom
Pinch
,
"
said
Martin
,
"
has
faithfully
related
to
me
all
that
you
desired
him
to
convey
;
at
a
time
when
he
deemed
it
very
improbable
that
he
would
ever
have
an
opportunity
of
delivering
your
message
.
<EOS>
Believe
me
,
that
if
I
ever
deal
again
with
an
ill
-
advised
and
unawakened
nature
,
hiding
the
strength
it
thinks
its
weakness
,
I
will
have
long
and
merciful
consideration
for
it
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
had
for
me
;
even
for
me
,
"
she
answered
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
quite
believe
it
.
<EOS>
I
said
the
words
you
have
repeated
,
when
my
distress
was
very
sharp
and
hard
to
bear
;
I
say
them
now
for
others
;
but
I
can
not
urge
them
for
myself
.
 
<EOS>
You
spoke
to
me
after
you
had
seen
and
watched
me
day
by
day
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
great
consideration
in
that
.
 
<EOS>
You
might
have
spoken
,
perhaps
,
more
kindly
;
you
might
have
tried
to
invite
my
confidence
by
greater
gentleness
;
but
the
end
would
have
been
the
same
.
"
   
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
in
doubt
,
and
not
without
some
inward
self
-
reproach
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
hope
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
your
interposition
would
have
prevailed
with
me
,
when
I
know
how
obdurate
I
was
!
 
<EOS>
I
never
thought
at
all
;
dear
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
I
never
thought
at
all
;
I
had
no
thought
,
no
heart
,
no
care
to
find
one
;
at
that
time
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
grown
out
of
my
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
felt
it
in
my
trouble
.
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
recall
my
trouble
such
as
it
is
and
has
been
---
and
it
is
light
in
comparison
with
trials
which
hundreds
of
good
people
suffer
every
day
,
I
know
---
 
<EOS>
I
would
n't
recall
it
to
-
morrow
,
if
I
could
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
my
friend
,
for
without
it
no
one
could
have
changed
me
;
nothing
could
have
changed
me
.
 
<EOS>
Do
not
mistrust
me
because
of
these
tears
;
I
can
not
help
them
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
grateful
for
it
,
in
my
soul
.
 
<EOS>
Indeed
I
am
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Indeed
she
is
!
"
said
Mrs
Todgers
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
it
,
sir
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
do
I
!
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
"
Now
,
attend
to
me
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Your
late
husband
's
estate
,
if
not
wasted
by
the
confession
of
a
large
debt
to
the
broken
office
(
which
document
,
being
useless
to
the
runaways
,
has
been
sent
over
to
England
by
them
;
not
so
much
for
the
sake
of
the
creditors
as
for
the
gratification
of
their
dislike
to
him
,
whom
they
suppose
to
be
still
living
)
,
will
be
seized
upon
by
law
;
for
it
is
not
exempt
,
as
I
learn
,
from
the
claims
of
those
who
have
suffered
by
the
fraud
in
which
he
was
engaged
.
 
<EOS>
Your
father
's
property
was
all
,
or
nearly
all
,
embarked
in
the
same
transaction
.
 
<EOS>
If
there
be
any
left
,
it
will
be
seized
on
,
in
like
manner
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
no
home
THERE
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
return
to
him
,
"
she
said
,
with
an
instinctive
reference
to
his
having
forced
her
marriage
on
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
return
to
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
,
"
Mr
Chuzzlewit
resumed
;
"
and
I
am
here
because
I
know
it
.
 
<EOS>
Come
with
me
!
 
<EOS>
From
all
who
are
about
me
,
you
are
certain
<EOS>
(
I
have
ascertained
it
)
of
a
generous
welcome
.
 
<EOS>
But
until
your
health
is
re
-
established
,
and
you
are
sufficiently
composed
to
bear
that
welcome
,
you
shall
have
your
abode
in
any
quiet
retreat
of
your
own
choosing
,
near
London
;
not
so
far
removed
but
that
this
kind
-
hearted
lady
may
still
visit
you
as
often
as
she
pleases
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
suffered
much
;
but
you
are
young
,
and
have
a
brighter
and
a
better
future
stretching
out
before
you
.
 
<EOS>
Come
with
me
.
 
<EOS>
Your
sister
is
careless
of
you
,
I
know
.
 
<EOS>
She
hurries
on
and
publishes
her
marriage
,
in
a
spirit
which
(
to
say
no
more
of
it
)
is
barely
decent
,
is
unsisterly
,
and
bad
.
 
<EOS>
Leave
the
house
before
her
guests
arrive
.
 
<EOS>
She
means
to
give
you
pain
.
 
<EOS>
Spare
her
the
offence
,
and
come
with
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
,
though
most
unwilling
to
part
with
her
,
added
her
persuasions
.
 
<EOS>
Even
poor
old
Chuffey
(
of
course
included
in
the
project
)
added
his
.
 
<EOS>
She
hurriedly
attired
herself
,
and
was
ready
to
depart
,
when
Miss
Pecksniff
dashed
into
the
room
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
dashed
in
so
suddenly
,
that
she
was
placed
in
an
embarrassing
position
.
 
<EOS>
For
though
she
had
completed
her
bridal
toilette
as
to
her
head
,
on
which
she
wore
a
bridal
bonnet
with
orange
flowers
,
she
had
not
completed
it
as
to
her
skirts
,
which
displayed
no
choicer
decoration
than
a
dimity
bedgown
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
dashed
in
,
in
fact
,
about
half
-
way
through
,
to
console
her
sister
,
in
her
affliction
,
with
a
sight
of
the
aforesaid
bonnet
;
and
being
quite
unconscious
of
the
presence
of
a
visitor
,
until
she
found
Mr
Chuzzlewit
standing
face
to
face
with
her
,
her
surprise
was
an
uncomfortable
one
.
   
<EOS>
"
So
,
young
lady
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
old
man
,
eyeing
her
with
strong
disfavour
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
to
be
married
to
-
day
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
,
modestly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
am
.
 
<EOS>
I
---
my
dress
is
rather
---
really
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
delicacy
,
"
said
old
Martin
,
"
is
troubled
,
I
perceive
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
surprised
to
find
it
so
.
 
<EOS>
You
have
chosen
the
period
of
your
marriage
unfortunately
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
"
retorted
Cherry
;
very
red
and
angry
in
a
moment
;
"
but
if
you
have
anything
to
say
on
that
subject
,
I
must
beg
to
refer
you
to
Augustus
.
 
<EOS>
You
will
scarcely
think
it
manly
,
I
hope
,
to
force
an
argument
on
me
,
when
Augustus
is
at
all
times
ready
to
discuss
it
with
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
to
do
with
any
deceptions
that
may
have
been
practiced
on
my
parent
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
pointedly
;
"
and
as
I
wish
to
be
on
good
terms
with
everybody
at
such
a
time
,
I
should
have
been
glad
if
you
would
have
favoured
us
with
your
company
at
breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
But
I
will
not
ask
you
as
it
is
;
seeing
that
you
have
been
prepossessed
and
set
against
me
in
another
quarter
.
 
<EOS>
I
hope
I
have
my
natural
affections
for
another
quarter
,
and
my
natural
pity
for
another
quarter
;
but
I
can
not
always
submit
to
be
subservient
to
it
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
That
would
be
a
little
too
much
.
 
<EOS>
I
trust
I
have
more
respect
for
myself
,
as
well
as
for
the
man
who
claims
me
as
his
Bride
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Your
sister
,
meeting
---
as
I
think
;
not
as
she
says
,
for
she
has
said
nothing
about
it
---
with
little
consideration
from
you
,
is
going
away
with
me
,
"
said
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
happy
to
find
that
she
has
some
good
fortune
at
last
,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
,
tossing
her
head
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
congratulate
her
,
I
am
sure
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
surprised
that
this
event
should
be
painful
to
her
---
painful
to
her
---
<EOS>
but
I
ca
n't
help
that
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
.
 
<EOS>
It
's
not
my
fault
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Miss
Pecksniff
!
"
said
the
old
man
,
quietly
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
see
a
better
parting
between
you
.
 
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
see
a
better
parting
on
your
side
,
in
such
circumstances
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
make
me
your
friend
.
 
<EOS>
You
may
want
a
friend
one
day
or
other
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Every
relation
of
life
,
Mr
Chuzzlewit
,
begging
your
pardon
;
and
every
friend
in
life
,
"
returned
Miss
Pecksniff
,
with
dignity
,
"
is
now
bound
up
and
cemented
in
Augustus
.
 
<EOS>
So
long
as
Augustus
is
my
own
,
I
can
not
want
a
friend
.
 
<EOS>
When
you
speak
of
friends
,
sir
,
I
must
beg
,
once
for
all
,
to
refer
you
to
Augustus
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
my
impression
of
the
religious
ceremony
in
which
I
am
so
soon
to
take
a
part
at
that
altar
to
which
Augustus
will
conduct
me
.
 
<EOS>
I
bear
no
malice
at
any
time
,
much
less
in
a
moment
of
triumph
,
towards
any
one
;
much
less
towards
my
sister
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
I
congratulate
her
.
 
<EOS>
If
you
did
n't
hear
me
say
so
,
I
am
not
to
blame
.
 
<EOS>
And
as
I
owe
it
to
Augustus
,
to
be
punctual
on
an
occasion
when
he
may
naturally
be
supposed
to
be
---
to
be
impatient
---
really
,
Mrs
Todgers
!
<EOS>
---
I
must
beg
your
leave
,
sir
,
to
retire
.
"
    
<EOS>
After
these
words
the
bridal
bonnet
disappeared
;
with
as
much
state
as
the
dimity
bedgown
left
in
it
.
   
<EOS>
Old
Martin
gave
his
arm
to
the
younger
sister
without
speaking
;
and
led
her
out
.
 
<EOS>
Mrs
Todgers
,
with
her
holiday
garments
fluttering
in
the
wind
,
accompanied
them
to
the
carriage
,
clung
round
Merry
's
neck
at
parting
,
and
ran
back
to
her
own
dingy
house
,
crying
the
whole
way
.
 
<EOS>
She
had
a
lean
,
lank
body
,
Mrs
Todgers
,
but
a
well
-
conditioned
soul
within
.
 
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
good
Samaritan
was
lean
and
lank
,
and
found
it
hard
to
live
.
 
<EOS>
Who
knows
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
followed
her
so
closely
with
his
eyes
,
that
,
until
she
had
shut
her
own
door
,
they
did
not
encounter
Mr
Tapley
's
face
.
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mark
!
"
he
said
,
as
soon
as
he
observed
it
,
"
what
's
the
matter
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
wonderfulest
ewent
,
sir
!
"
returned
Mark
,
pumping
at
his
voice
in
a
most
laborious
manner
,
and
hardly
able
to
articulate
with
all
his
efforts
.
 
<EOS>
"
A
coincidence
as
never
was
equalled
!
 
<EOS>
I
'm
blessed
if
here
ai
n't
two
old
neighbours
of
ourn
,
sir
!
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
neighbours
?
<EOS>
"
cried
old
Martin
,
looking
out
of
window
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
I
was
a
-
walkin
'
up
and
down
not
five
yards
from
this
spot
,
"
said
Mr
Tapley
,
breathless
,
"
and
they
come
upon
me
like
their
own
ghosts
,
as
I
thought
they
was
!
 
<EOS>
It
's
the
wonderfulest
ewent
that
ever
happened
.
<EOS>
Bring
a
feather
,
somebody
,
and
knock
me
down
with
it
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
old
Martin
,
quite
as
much
excited
by
the
spectacle
of
Mark
's
excitement
as
that
strange
person
was
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
Neighbours
,
where
?
"
   
<EOS>
"
Here
,
sir
!
"
replied
Mr
Tapley
.
 
<EOS>
"
Here
in
the
city
of
London
!
 
<EOS>
Here
upon
these
very
stones
!
 
<EOS>
Here
they
are
,
sir
!
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
know
'em
?
 
<EOS>
Lord
love
their
welcome
faces
<EOS>
,
do
n't
I
know
'
em
!
"
   
<EOS>
With
which
ejaculations
Mr
Tapley
not
only
pointed
to
a
decent
-
looking
man
and
woman
standing
by
,
but
commenced
embracing
them
alternately
,
over
and
over
again
,
in
Monument
Yard
.
   
<EOS>
"
Neighbours
,
WHERE
?
 
<EOS>
old
Martin
shouted
;
almost
maddened
by
his
ineffectual
efforts
to
get
out
at
the
coach
-
door
.
   
<EOS>
"
Neighbours
in
America
!
 
<EOS>
Neighbours
in
Eden
!
"
cried
Mark
.
<EOS>
"
Neighbours
in
the
swamp
,
neighbours
in
the
bush
,
neighbours
in
the
fever
.
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
she
nurse
us
!
 
<EOS>
Did
n't
he
help
us
!
 
<EOS>
Should
n't
we
both
have
died
without
'em
!
 
<EOS>
Have
n't
they
come
a
-
strugglin
'
back
,
without
a
single
child
for
their
consolation
!
 
<EOS>
And
talk
to
me
of
neighbours
!
"
   
<EOS>
Away
he
went
again
,
in
a
perfectly
wild
state
,
hugging
them
,
and
skipping
round
them
,
and
cutting
in
between
them
,
as
if
he
were
performing
some
frantic
and
outlandish
dance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Chuzzlewit
no
sooner
gathered
who
these
people
were
,
than
he
burst
open
the
coach
-
door
somehow
or
other
,
and
came
tumbling
out
among
them
;
and
as
if
the
lunacy
of
Mr
Tapley
were
contagious
,
he
immediately
began
to
shake
hands
too
,
and
exhibit
every
demonstration
of
the
liveliest
joy
.
   
<EOS>
"
Get
up
,
behind
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Get
up
in
the
rumble
.
 
<EOS>
Come
along
with
me
!
 
<EOS>
Go
you
on
the
box
,
Mark
.
 
<EOS>
Home
!
 
<EOS>
Home
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
Home
!
"
cried
Mr
Tapley
,
seizing
the
old
man
's
hand
in
a
burst
of
enthusiasm
.
 
<EOS>
"
Exactly
my
opinion
,
sir
.
 
<EOS>
Home
for
ever
!
 
<EOS>
Excuse
the
liberty
<EOS>
,
sir
,
I
ca
n't
help
it
.
 
<EOS>
Success
to
the
Jolly
Tapley
!
 
<EOS>
There
's
nothin'
in
the
house
they
sha
n't
have
for
the
askin
'
for
,
except
a
bill
.
 
<EOS>
Home
to
be
sure
!
 
<EOS>
Hurrah
!
"
   
<EOS>
Home
they
rolled
accordingly
,
when
he
had
got
the
old
man
in
again
,
as
fast
as
they
could
go
;
Mark
abating
nothing
of
his
fervour
by
the
way
,
by
allowing
it
to
vent
itself
as
unrestrainedly
as
if
he
had
been
on
Salisbury
Plain
.
   
<EOS>
And
now
the
wedding
party
began
to
assemble
at
Todgers
's
.
 
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
,
the
only
boarder
invited
,
was
on
the
ground
first
.
 
<EOS>
He
wore
a
white
favour
in
his
button
-
hole
,
and
a
bran
new
extra
super
double
-
milled
blue
saxony
dress
coat
(
that
was
its
description
in
the
bill
)
,
with
a
variety
of
tortuous
embellishments
about
the
pockets
,
invented
by
the
artist
to
do
honour
to
the
day
.
 
<EOS>
The
miserable
Augustus
no
longer
felt
strongly
even
on
the
subject
of
Jinkins
.
 
<EOS>
He
had
n't
strength
of
mind
enough
to
do
it
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
!
"
<EOS>
he
had
said
,
in
answer
to
Miss
Pecksniff
,
when
she
urged
the
point
.
 
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
!
 
<EOS>
He
has
ever
been
my
rock
ahead
through
life
.
 
<EOS>
"
Tis
meet
he
should
be
there
.
 
<EOS>
Ha
,
ha
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
<EOS>
let
Jinkins
come
!
"
   
<EOS>
Jinkins
had
come
with
all
the
pleasure
in
life
,
and
there
he
was
.
<EOS>
For
some
few
minutes
he
had
no
companion
but
the
breakfast
,
which
was
set
forth
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
with
unusual
taste
and
ceremony
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs
Todgers
soon
joined
him
;
and
the
bachelor
cousin
,
the
hairy
young
gentleman
,
and
Mr
and
Mrs
Spottletoe
,
arrived
in
quick
succession
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Spottletoe
honoured
Jinkins
with
an
encouraging
bow
.
 
<EOS>
"
Glad
to
know
you
,
sir
,
"
he
said
.
 
<EOS>
"
Give
you
joy
!
"
 
<EOS>
Under
the
impression
that
Jinkins
was
the
happy
man
.
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
explained
.
 
<EOS>
He
was
merely
doing
the
honours
for
his
friend
Moddle
,
who
had
ceased
to
reside
in
the
house
,
and
had
not
yet
arrived
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
arrived
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Spottletoe
,
in
a
great
heat
.
   
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
"
said
Mr
Jinkins
.
   
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
!
"
cried
Spottletoe
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
begins
well
!
 
<EOS>
Upon
my
life
and
honour
this
young
man
begins
well
!
 
<EOS>
But
I
should
very
much
like
to
know
how
it
is
that
every
one
who
comes
into
contact
with
this
family
is
guilty
of
some
gross
insult
to
it
.
 
<EOS>
Death
!
 
<EOS>
Not
arrived
yet
.
 
<EOS>
Not
here
to
receive
us
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
nephew
with
the
outline
of
a
countenance
,
suggested
that
perhaps
he
had
ordered
a
new
pair
of
boots
,
and
they
had
n't
come
home
.
   
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
talk
to
me
of
Boots
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Spottletoe
,
with
immense
indignation
.
 
<EOS>
"
He
is
bound
to
come
here
in
his
slippers
then
;
he
is
bound
to
come
here
barefoot
.
 
<EOS>
Do
n't
offer
such
a
wretched
and
evasive
plea
to
me
on
behalf
of
your
friend
,
as
Boots
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
He
is
not
MY
friend
,
"
said
the
nephew
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
never
saw
him
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
fiery
Spottletoe
.
 
<EOS>
"
Then
do
n't
talk
to
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
door
was
thrown
open
at
this
juncture
,
and
Miss
Pecksniff
entered
,
tottering
,
and
supported
by
her
three
bridesmaids
.
 
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
woman
brought
up
the
rear
;
having
waited
outside
until
now
,
for
the
purpose
of
spoiling
the
effect
.
   
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
ma'am
!
"
<EOS>
said
Spottletoe
to
the
strong
-
minded
woman
in
a
tone
of
defiance
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
see
Mrs
Spottletoe
,
ma'am
?
"
   
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
woman
with
an
air
of
great
interest
in
Mrs
Spottletoe
's
health
,
regretted
that
she
was
not
more
easily
seen
.
<EOS>
Nature
erring
,
in
that
lady
's
case
,
upon
the
slim
side
.
   
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Spottletoe
is
at
least
more
easily
seen
than
the
bridegroom
,
ma'am
,
"
returned
that
lady
's
husband
.
 
<EOS>
"
That
is
,
unless
he
has
confined
his
attentions
to
any
particular
part
or
branch
of
this
family
,
which
would
be
quite
in
keeping
with
its
usual
proceedings
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
allude
to
me
,
sir
---
"
the
strong
-
minded
woman
began
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
"
interposed
Miss
Pecksniff
,
"
do
not
allow
Augustus
,
at
this
awful
moment
of
his
life
and
mine
,
to
be
the
means
of
disturbing
that
harmony
which
it
is
ever
Augustus
's
and
my
wish
to
maintain
.
<EOS>
Augustus
has
not
been
introduced
to
any
of
my
relations
now
present
.
<EOS>
He
preferred
not
.
"
   
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
I
venture
to
assert
,
"
cried
Mr
Spottletoe
,
"
that
the
man
who
aspires
to
join
this
family
,
and
"
prefers
not
"
to
be
introduced
to
its
members
,
is
an
impertinent
Puppy
.
 
<EOS>
That
is
my
opinion
of
HIM
!
"
   
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
woman
remarked
with
great
suavity
,
that
she
was
afraid
he
must
be
.
 
<EOS>
Her
three
daughters
observed
aloud
that
it
was
"
Shameful
!
"
   
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
know
Augustus
,
"
said
Miss
Pecksniff
,
tearfully
,
"
<EOS>
indeed
you
do
not
know
him
.
 
<EOS>
Augustus
is
all
mildness
and
humility
.
 
<EOS>
Wait
till
you
see
Augustus
,
and
I
am
sure
he
will
conciliate
your
affections
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
The
question
arises
,
"
said
Spottletoe
,
folding
his
arms
:
"
How
long
we
are
to
wait
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not
accustomed
to
wait
;
that
's
the
fact
.
 
<EOS>
And
I
want
to
know
how
long
we
are
expected
to
wait
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"
Mrs
Todgers
!
"
said
Charity
,
"
Mr
Jinkins
!
 
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
there
must
be
some
mistake
.
 
<EOS>
I
think
Augustus
must
have
gone
straight
to
the
Altar
!
"
   
<EOS>
As
such
a
thing
was
possible
,
and
the
church
was
close
at
hand
,
Mr
Jinkins
ran
off
to
see
,
accompanied
by
Mr
George
Chuzzlewit
the
bachelor
cousin
,
who
preferred
anything
to
the
aggravation
of
sitting
near
the
breakfast
,
without
being
able
to
eat
it
.
 
<EOS>
But
they
came
back
with
no
other
tidings
than
a
familiar
message
from
the
clerk
,
importing
that
if
they
wanted
to
be
married
that
morning
they
had
better
look
sharp
,
as
the
curate
was
n't
going
to
wait
there
all
day
.
   
<EOS>
The
bride
was
now
alarmed
;
seriously
alarmed
.
 
<EOS>
Good
Heavens
,
what
could
have
happened
!
 
<EOS>
Augustus
!
 
<EOS>
Dear
Augustus
!
   
<EOS>
Mr
Jinkins
volunteered
to
take
a
cab
,
and
seek
him
at
the
newly
-
furnished
house
.
 
<EOS>
The
strong
-
minded
woman
administered
comfort
to
Miss
Pecksniff
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
specimen
of
what
she
had
to
expect
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
do
her
good
.
 
<EOS>
It
would
dispel
the
romance
of
the
affair
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
The
red
-
nosed
daughters
also
administered
the
kindest
comfort
.
 
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
'd
come
,
"
they
said
.
 
<EOS>
The
sketchy
nephew
hinted
that
he
might
have
fallen
off
a
bridge
.
 
<EOS>
The
wrath
of
Mr
Spottletoe
resisted
all
the
entreaties
of
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
Everybody
spoke
at
once
,
and
Miss
Pecksniff
,
with
clasped
hands
,
sought
consolation
everywhere
and
found
it
nowhere
,
when
Jinkins
,
having
met
the
postman
at
the
door
,
came
back
with
a
letter
,
which
he
put
into
her
hand
.
   
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
opened
it
,
uttered
a
piercing
shriek
,
threw
it
down
upon
the
ground
,
and
fainted
away
.
   
<EOS>
They
picked
it
up
;
and
crowding
round
,
and
looking
over
one
another
's
shoulders
,
read
,
in
the
words
and
dashes
following
,
this
communication
:
   
"
OFF
GRAVESEND
.
   
<EOS>
"
CLIPPER
SCHOONER
,
CUPID
   
"
<EOS>
Wednesday
night
   
<EOS>
"
EVER
INJURED
MISS
PECKSNIFF
---
<EOS>
Ere
<EOS>
this
reaches
you
,
the
undersigned
will
be
---
if
not
a
corpse
---
on
the
way
to
Van
Dieman
's
Land
.
 
<EOS>
Send
not
in
pursuit
.
 
<EOS>
I
never
will
be
taken
alive
!
   
<EOS>
"
The
burden
---
300
tons
per
register
---
forgive
,
if
in
my
distraction
,
I
allude
to
the
ship
<EOS>
---
on
my
mind
---
has
been
truly
dreadful
.
 
<EOS>
Frequently
 
---
when
you
have
sought
to
soothe
my
brow
with
kisses
---
has
self
-
destruction
flashed
across
me
.
 
<EOS>
Frequently
---
incredible
as
it
may
seem
---
have
I
abandoned
the
idea
.
   
<EOS>
"
I
love
another
.
 
<EOS>
She
is
Another
's
.
 
<EOS>
Everything
appears
to
be
somebody
else
's
.
 
<EOS>
Nothing
in
the
world
is
mine
---
not
even
my
Situation
---
which
I
have
forfeited
---
by
my
rash
conduct
---
in
running
away
.
   
<EOS>
"
If
you
ever
loved
me
,
hear
my
last
appeal
!
 
<EOS>
The
last
appeal
of
a
miserable
and
blighted
exile
.
 
<EOS>
Forward
the
inclosed
---
it
is
the
key
of
my
desk
---
to
the
office
---
by
hand
.
 
<EOS>
Please
address
to
Bobbs
and
Cholberry
---
I
mean
to
Chobbs
and
Bolberry
---
<EOS>
but
my
mind
is
totally
unhinged
.
 
<EOS>
I
left
a
penknife
---
with
a
buckhorn
handle
---
in
your
work
-
box
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
repay
the
messenger
.
 
<EOS>
May
it
make
him
happier
than
ever
<EOS>
it
did
me
!
   
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Miss
Pecksniff
,
why
did
n't
you
leave
me
alone
!
 
<EOS>
Was
it
not
cruel
,
CRUEL
!
 
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
goodness
,
have
you
not
been
a
witness
of
my
feelings
<EOS>
---
have
you
not
seen
them
flowing
from
my
eyes
---
<EOS>
did
you
not
,
yourself
,
reproach
me
with
weeping
more
than
usual
on
that
dreadful
night
when
last
we
met
---
in
that
house
---
where
I
once
was
peaceful
---
 
though
blighted
---
in
the
society
of
Mrs
Todgers
!
   
<EOS>
"
But
it
was
written
---
in
the
Talmud
---
that
you
should
involve
yourself
in
the
inscrutable
and
gloomy
Fate
which
it
is
my
mission
to
accomplish
,
and
which
wreathes
itself
---
e'en
now
---
about
in
temples
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
reproach
,
for
I
have
wronged
you
.
 
<EOS>
May
the
Furniture
make
some
amends
!
   
<EOS>
"
Farewell
!
 
<EOS>
Be
the
proud
bride
of
a
ducal
coronet
,
and
forget
me
!
<EOS>
Long
may
it
be
before
you
know
the
anguish
with
which
I
now
subscribe
myself
---
amid
the
tempestuous
howlings
of
the
---
sailors
,
   
"
<EOS>
Unalterably
,
   
"
Never
yours
,
   
"
AUGUSTUS
.
"
   
<EOS>
They
thought
as
little
of
Miss
Pecksniff
,
while
they
greedily
perused
this
letter
,
as
if
she
were
the
very
last
person
on
earth
whom
it
concerned
.
 
<EOS>
But
Miss
Pecksniff
really
had
fainted
away
.
 
<EOS>
The
bitterness
of
her
mortification
;
the
bitterness
of
having
summoned
witnesses
,
and
such
witnesses
,
to
behold
it
;
the
bitterness
of
knowing
that
the
strong
-
minded
women
and
the
red
-
nosed
daughters
towered
triumphant
in
this
hour
of
their
anticipated
overthrow
;
was
too
much
to
be
borne
.
 
<EOS>
Miss
Pecksniff
had
fainted
away
in
earnest
.
   
<EOS>
What
sounds
are
these
that
fall
so
grandly
on
the
ear
!
 
<EOS>
What
darkening
room
is
this
!
   
<EOS>
And
that
mild
figure
seated
at
an
organ
,
who
is
he
!
 
<EOS>
Ah
Tom
,
dear
Tom
,
old
friend
!
   
<EOS>
Thy
head
is
prematurely
grey
,
though
Time
has
passed
thee
and
our
old
association
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
But
,
in
those
sounds
with
which
it
is
thy
wo
nt
to
bear
the
twilight
company
,
the
music
of
thy
heart
speaks
out
---
the
story
of
thy
life
relates
itself
.
   
<EOS>
Thy
life
is
tranquil
,
calm
,
and
happy
,
Tom
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
soft
strain
which
ever
and
again
comes
stealing
back
upon
the
ear
,
the
memory
of
thine
old
love
may
find
a
voice
perhaps
;
but
it
is
a
pleasant
,
softened
,
whispering
memory
,
like
that
in
which
we
sometimes
hold
the
dead
,
and
does
not
pain
or
grieve
thee
,
God
be
thanked
.
   
<EOS>
Touch
the
notes
lightly
,
Tom
,
as
lightly
as
thou
wilt
,
but
never
will
thine
hand
<EOS>
fall
half
so
lightly
on
that
Instrument
as
on
the
head
of
thine
old
tyrant
brought
down
very
,
very
low
;
and
never
will
it
make
as
hollow
a
response
to
any
touch
of
thine
,
as
he
does
always
.
   
<EOS>
For
a
drunken
,
begging
,
squalid
,
letter
-
writing
man
,
called
Pecksniff
,
with
a
shrewish
daughter
,
haunts
thee
,
Tom
;
and
when
he
makes
appeals
to
thee
for
cash
,
reminds
thee
that
he
built
thy
fortunes
better
than
his
own
;
and
when
he
spends
it
,
entertains
the
alehouse
company
with
tales
of
thine
ingratitude
and
his
munificence
towards
thee
once
upon
a
time
;
and
then
he
shows
his
elbows
worn
in
holes
,
and
puts
his
soleless
shoes
up
on
a
bench
,
and
begs
his
auditors
look
there
,
while
thou
art
comfortably
housed
and
clothed
.
 
<EOS>
All
known
to
thee
,
and
yet
all
borne
with
,
Tom
!
   
<EOS>
So
,
with
a
smile
upon
thy
face
,
thou
passest
gently
to
another
measure
---
to
a
quicker
and
more
joyful
one
---
and
little
feet
are
used
to
dance
about
thee
at
the
sound
,
and
bright
young
eyes
to
glance
up
into
thine
.
 
<EOS>
And
there
is
one
slight
creature
,
Tom
---
her
child
;
not
Ruth
's
---
whom
thine
eyes
follow
in
the
romp
and
dance
;
who
,
wondering
sometimes
to
see
thee
look
so
thoughtful
,
runs
to
climb
up
on
thy
knee
,
and
put
her
cheek
to
thine
;
who
loves
thee
,
Tom
,
above
the
rest
,
if
that
can
be
;
and
falling
sick
once
,
chose
thee
for
her
nurse
,
and
never
knew
impatience
,
Tom
,
when
thou
wert
by
her
side
.
   
<EOS>
Thou
glidest
,
now
,
into
a
graver
air
;
an
air
devoted
to
old
friends
and
bygone
times
;
and
in
thy
lingering
touch
upon
the
keys
,
and
the
rich
swelling
of
the
mellow
harmony
,
they
rise
before
thee
.
 
<EOS>
The
spirit
of
that
old
man
dead
,
who
delighted
to
anticipate
thy
wants
,
and
never
ceased
to
honour
thee
,
is
there
,
among
the
rest
;
repeating
,
with
a
face
composed
and
calm
,
the
words
he
said
to
thee
upon
his
bed
,
and
blessing
thee
!
   
<EOS>
And
coming
from
a
garden
,
Tom
,
bestrewn
with
flowers
by
children
's
hands
,
thy
sister
,
little
Ruth
,
as
light
of
foot
and
heart
as
in
old
days
,
sits
down
beside
thee
.
 
<EOS>
From
the
Present
,
and
the
Past
,
with
which
she
is
so
tenderly
entwined
in
all
thy
thoughts
,
thy
strain
soars
onward
to
the
Future
.
 
<EOS>
As
it
resounds
within
thee
and
without
,
the
noble
music
,
rolling
round
ye
both
,
shuts
out
the
grosser
prospect
of
an
earthly
parting
,
and
uplifts
ye
both
to
Heaven
!
     
<EOS>
